description:
Where were you in 1979?

It was an interesting time in San Francisco for sure. The senseless shootings of mayor Moscone and Supervisor Milk ...the riots....

And it was the opening of Zuni cafe

Think of it a restaurant that has been in existence at the same location for near 40 years (Zuni actually keeps growing and expanding). How many establishments can boast that????

Zuni is still  consistently good.. Service is impeccable and friendly. Ambiance is  great; pretty restaurant, great mix of people, interesting layout.

Probably my only gripe is the smallish menu, not a lot of choices....but you're here for the chicken anyway right?

Yes it takes an hour to prepare the chicken so order it as you sit down. 
Their chicken is pretty amazing; lovely crisp skin, moist flavor

Nice shellfish selection

Solid Cesar Salad

Great wine list and cocktails.

Bar is a great place to meet up and get a drink.

Sure yelpers want to review the latest and greatest ( they'll be closed in a year or two) but Zuni will still be cranking out those tasty birds.
author: David G.

description:
What happened to this "institution"? Yesterday, I returned for dinner for the first time in a few years. My last meal at Zuni had been quite good, and I was looking forward to dinner with my friends. We walked out amazed and decided we will never return.

My friend, a lifelong vegetarian and I, a vegetarian of recent vintage, ordered the heirloom tomato salad and the gnocchi. The heirloom tomato salad was just not good: a few slices of tomato, deeply soaked in vinegar, with some wilted arugula on top. Puzzling for an institution. And $16 for this -- all right, the San Francisco dinner tax on idiots like us, I suppose, who thought that spending a lot of money on dinner would necessarily guarantee a good meal. I rarely get to go out for dinner, so when I do, I try to go somewhere worth going with a mission I support and where I hope the food and service will make the effort worthwhile. Zuni's reputation had suggested this basic expectation would be met.

And so we waited for the gnocchi, filled with hope and longing, but what arrived was the most disgusting plate of something I've ever seen since an accidental plate of Alfredo pasta in the Florida boonies 11 years ago that almost lead to a breakup: a few white balls in a white slime with a couple of carrots on top. We looked at each other and at our companions. What is this? We tried a bite: it was definitely not we, self-described gnocchi experts, know to be gnocchi. Just a few balls of cheese. $19. Puzzling. We told our waitress that we did not find this dish to be palatable, and she said, "we don't use potato or flour in our gnocchi." I couldn't quite tell what she said. Potato flour? Potato or flour? Bizarre. So why label this gnocchi? We told her that neither of us would be able to gum these down, and my friend asked for some sort of a vegetarian replacement. Displeased and without asking me if I wanted anything, the waitress took away these plates after offering to leave them on the table. Why would we want them on the table? Our friends seemed to be enjoying their salmon and pork chop as we waited, and we had to clarify: is she bringing two plates of replacement? Or what? (My friend with the pork chop later corrected my impression: it was "lame and overcooked.")

I have eaten gnocchi throughout my life after first trying it in Italy as a child, and I have never been confronted with whatever it is we found on our plates last night. Curious, we waited, and, finally, the replacement arrived: two thin slices of zucchini, a tiny little pile of flavorless beans, a few flavorless green beans, and some sort of a charred, collapsed piece of grassy green. Maybe a leak? I have no idea, as it wasn't recognizable. All of this was either steamed or roasted or both. There was so little of it, and we had so little time left, that I ate it instead of counting the number of beans. 

On our check we discovered this replacement was worth $20. $1 more than the cheese balls in the slime. Yikes. The check said: "Immigrants Make America Great." My friends and I are all immigrants, whether first or second generation, and we certainly appreciate the gesture, but the restaurant's overall mission did not make up for a lackluster, unpleasant experience. I came home at midnight after visiting a theater, where my husband had a delicious meal waiting for me. Thank all that is good and holy for that.

2 stars for the fact that Zuni uses organic ingredients.
author: Sasha H.

description:
An SF institution. The ambience is very cozy and romantic but also good for small groups. It seems like a perfect place to dine for dinner during the holidays. 

Service and servers were great. We were deciding between a few wines by the glass and they brought us tastings of all three! Amazing, I don't often get tastings if I'm ordering a glass. 

So the classics are Zuni Caesar and the roasted chicken - those don't leave the menu. The rest of the menu changes daily. On the day we were there, they offered scallops as substitutions in any dish with protein. We ordered the Zuni Caesar, scallops as recommended, roasted chicken, broccoli rabe. 

Zuni Caesar - the dressing is made to order so we were able to request no anchovies in the dressing, which was nice. I thought it was the best Caesar I've had but I also don't particularly like caesars. Great to try and the lettuce was very fresh. I was not obsessed since I thought it was a little overdressed / salty? Would still recommend anyone try this at least once 

Scallops - loved this! There were 6 scallops in the dish and it came with veggies. Although they may not offer this again, I'd recommend considering their daily specials. 

Roasted chicken - takes a while (I think 60 minutes) to come out so we ordered this as soon as we sat down. It was about $60 and says it's for two people but you could share with an additional one or two more people depending on what else you get. Comes with a bread salad under the chicken. Chicken was really good but a couple pieces were drier than I expected. Bread salad was yummy since it soaked all the chicken flavor. 

We also ended with a flourless chocolate cake. The texture and lightness was great but it was a bit too rich for us. We ordered two scoops of vanilla ice cream to balance it but dang the ice cream is overpriced ($6 per scoop).
author: Sophia L.

description:
NB: this review is for their famous chicken dish ONLY.  
Came here for a 8pm reservation on the weekend just to try their chicken.

Venue / Service: it's kinda surprising how many people can fit in what seems to be a small restaurant!  It is a bit crowded in the walking areas (nearly ran into a few waiters) when you are heading to your table but once you sit at the table, it's spacious enough that you forget about the small space, probably because of the high ceilings.  The ambiance can best be described as "warm yet chic".  Service was pretty good; the waiters were pretty prompt despite us being in the way way back of the restaurant.  

Food: mind you, we came here mainly for their famous chicken.
-- House-cured anchovies with celery, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and coquillo olives ($12) - Loved this combo!  We are huge anchovy lovers and were surprised at how well the cheese went with the strong little fishes.  The celery was a much needed relief taste-wise and texture-wise.  

-- Chicken for Two (roasted in wood-fire brick oven, warm bread salad with scallions, garlic, mustard greens, dried currants, pine nuts)($58) - you have to wait 60 min for this dish, so be prepared to wait for a while.  Don't worry; if this dish has been around since the restaurant opened, it's gonna be worth the wait!  The whole chicken is so juicy and tender (including the breast meat); I'd say the drumstick and thigh were our favorite part!  I also liked how the chicken itself was lightly seasoned so you could actually let the chicken shine.  Mustard greens added a good hit of bitterness to cut the savoriness of the chicken.  While the bread salad underneath benefited from the chicken jus that it soaked up, I'd say this was a weaker element to the dish, especially since the chicken is big enough for 2 people and therefore we barely touched the bread.  

We also ordered a side of sauteed spinach (forget the price)- we probably didn't need this as much since the chicken came with mustard greens.  That being said, it was still quite tasty and thankfully not so oily / greasy.  

Even after ordering a glass of wine for $12, the bill seemed pretty reasonable, especially given how big / how much effort goes into making the chicken.  

Chicken lovers, come here and get the famous Zuni Cafe chicken!  Even if you don't order, the service was excellent and the ambiance is comfy.  Would highly recommend for any person to visit.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Finally!! I got to visit this place. Well, truth be told, I didn't want to come by myself. Finally, I could convince bunch of friends to come with me by luring them for brunch. Well, after reaching, we realized that they have brunch on Sundays only.
Never mind. We are here. We gotta eat haha..

For me, their hot chocolate stole my heart. So amazing and dense and not super sweet! Yummm!! I had two of those beauties ..
Oysters were fresh and yumm! Burgers were great! Pizzas and mimosas were good too. Honestly, no complains, except little too cozy seating for a large group.
author: Ashutosh K.

description:
Went here for Sunday brunch this weekend and was blown away. The friends I was with had a reservation, so we didn't have to wait, which was nice. We started with drinks, and both the peach Bellini and the Bloody Mary were amazing. Highly recommend the Bloody Mary- tastes just like drinking salsa if you're into that! For food, we started first with oysters, which were perfectly fresh! Someone at the table ordered an egg dish that was unbelievable- both my friend and I commented that we'd never eaten eggs cooked so well. The tomato soup and Caesar salad were also surprisingly good, especially the polenta croutons on the soup!!

We also ordered the infamous Zuni roast chicken, which deserves all the hype it gets! It was perfectly crispy and there was a stuffing-esque bread under the chicken that I think may have been even better. We ate it with the polenta, which just melted in your mouth. The meal was everything I could have wanted, including a couple bottles of excellent red wine!

The wait staff was also extremely nice and attentive!! An overall great brunch experience
author: Sonia S.

description:
Zuni stands the test of time and continues to deliver! I've been coming here since the late 90's and it continues to ROCK!

Beautiful light filled interior that's light and bright even on a rainy day. 

Incredible service with knowledgeable servers that inquire what you like before they make recommendations. 5 stars!

Killer apps and salads but I like to get a pizza from their wood fired oven. Thin crust - crispy - charred - chewy - goodness topped with seasonal fruit veggies meats that would make Zuni a 5 star pizza place if that was all they served. 

Zuni is well known for their burgers and roasted chicken for two. Unless you go for lunch or late night it's hard to get the burgers on the menu. The burgers live up to the hyper. Insanity. The chicken takes a little time but is TOTALLY worth it. Date night winner. 

I came for lunch today. My mom had the duck and I went on a limb and had the pork crepinette. I had no idea it was code for wood fired home made sausage- but HOLY CRAP INCREDIBLE! Mouthwatering. Juicy. Tender. Char marks. Color equals flavor. 

Cheese board to finish. Parmigiano reggiano with dates. 

Full bar with cool bartenders made Zuni a super 5 star experience. I can't wait to go back.
author: Dave K.

description:
The chicken, the chicken, the chicken.  Yes, many people mention it and of course we had to order it to find out what all the fuss was about.   It had nice crispy skin and juicy, flavorful meat.   Did we enjoy it?  Yes.  Did it knock our socks off?  No.

The bread they serve before the meal was very good - chewy crust and very fresh.  But it was served with those hard pats of butter that I hate.  I asked for very light dressing on the Arugula Salad but it came heavily dressed and the leaves were crushed.   The nectarine tart we finished with was excellent!  

Service was fine - nothing memorable.     The restaurant was very crowded and noisy on a Saturday evening.
author: Diane W.

description:
Came here with a bunch of friends. I really wanted to like this place but the service wasn't great and the food was just so-so especially for the price. 

First impression. We started with drinks at the bar downstairs. They told us we'd have to wait a while for our seats since they were really behind. So we all ordered drinks at the bar. After telling the bartender our orders, it took 20 minutes to make our drinks which seems excessive since there were many people at the bar. At around 15 minutes our tables were ready so half of our group went to the table while we waited for the drinks. The bartender told us he'd need to see the IDs of the other people before he could give us the drinks. We told him the host told us it would be fine but he said he couldn't give us the drinks unless they came down to show ID. We thought that was ridiculous and the host asked what was wrong and said our waiter could check IDs at our table.  

After that ordeal I was still optimistic of the food and was hoping it was just a one off. We ordered wine at the table and our server wasn't really helpful at all with the wine choices.  Really at this point the service was just getting worse.  The food came out in random fashion and one of our group didn't get their food for a long time. We asked what was happening but no one really told us. Didn't even get a sorry. We didn't make a big deal about it. 

At the end, the chicken which everyone said was amazing was just so-so. It was tender but wasn't something I'd really rave over.  The extra hour wait for it isn't worth it. Also don't get the soup.  It was really bland. I know they change the soup every so often but probably not worth it.

Maybe I'll try the place again at some point but just really left a bad taste in my mouth the whole experience.  For the price I'd rather try somewhere else.
author: Mark W.

description:
This place is an SF institution but it's a bad combination of expensive and mediocre food.  Two of us came here for lunch after a few hours of walking around the city and decided to order the peach crostini, the White Sea bass, a hamburger and some shoestring fries with a martini and a root beer.  

The crostini was good and I'd recommend ordering it but the fish came out a little dry (and the portion size was small). Also, the shoestring fries were not particularly crispy.  The highlight of the meal was the root beer. 

Service was OK and the ambiance here is quite nice particularly on a sunny day. The meal ended up being around $70 per person - pricey for lunch.  At this price point, there are definitely much better options in SF.
author: Andrew S.

description:
I adore Zuni Café. It's a classic place that keeps the old San Francisco vibe alive. It gets crazy busy for a reason. Even though the service can be slow at times and it gets busy , I've had consistent meals here and that's high on my list. My top three favorites: The brick oven roasted chicken. It really is that good! The Caesar salad and the burger. All simple dishes that executed really, really well. What's not to love about that!? I love Zuni for a long lunch with lots of wine.  The bar is extra cozy with tons of character. This place to me is just about the classics and doing them well. Top tips: Call ahead. The
Chicken can take up to an hour.
author: Isabella J.

description:
The ambiance and waiters are top notch, and the chicken was really tasty. However, it's hard to justify the price because in the end, it's still only chicken. 

Money aside, I was able to take home leftovers and it tasted just as good a day after. I really liked the crunchy stuff and greens that went along with the dish.
author: Andrea T.

description: Zuni Cafe, you are the best.  Thank you for the lovely downstairs table in the back against the brick wall, the impeccable service, the bloody marys that brought me back to life after a little too much fun the night before, and the delicious food.  The caesar salad and chicory salad -- the hamburger -- that chicken.  Yet again we had a wonderful time and I so appreciate living in a city with such a delightful institution.  Our handsome & charming waiter didn't hurt either.  Can't wait to come back! -Scott
author: scott P.

description: An upscale place with a beautiful ambience! Service is amazing and their food options are pretty good as well. I was here during lunch and their turnaround time was pretty quick. If you are looking for a team lunch place in the city, this is a great place to consider.
author: Abeetha B.

description:
Probably our favorite overall meal during our recent trip to San Francisco & LA.

We had a casual, lazy lunch on a Thursday and it was perfection.

We were able to walk in and grab a seat in the open-seating area in the front of the restaurant. Our server (and the whole service team) were exceptionally attentive and warm. 

While we were tempted to order the famed chicken, we had dinner reservations later and didn't want to overdo it for lunch.

We ordered:
- Caesar salad
- Prosciutto with kumquat and farro salad
- Daily special pizza (wagon wheel cheese, artichokes, escarole, olives, orange zest)
- Cowgirl creamery Mt. Tam cheese w/ rhubarb jam and sesame crackers
- Blackberry ice cream with oatmeal cookies

Everything was so simple and so delicious. Each dish was so flavorful and thoughtfully composed and balanced.

All in all, it was the perfect vacation lunch and I wish I could experience it again.
author: Herbie H.

description: Good but unfortunately overhyped. The famous roast chicken here feels a bit gimmicky. You can't order the chicken in advance, so you will have no choice but to wait an hour for it. Don't get me wrong. The roast chicken is good but is it the best I've ever had in my life? Nah... probably not even the best I've had in the city.
author: Charles L.

description:
Maybe a 3.5.  

We ate here on a recent weekend getaway to SF.  We were excited with all the great reviews.  Overall we thought the food was okay to good but nothing spectacular and did not felt it was worth the cost.  

Chicken-  takes an hour for it to be made.  Our table thought the chicken was decent and juicy as others have described but honestly tasted no different than roast chicken we have had.   I guess at $58 an order we were hoping for something different and more interesting.   I would be willing eat this again but not for $58.  We order 1 chicken for 6 of us to share and more than half of it was left uneaten. 

Shoestring fries- came out cold

Ceasar salad- overall good.  We like the decontructed presentation.  Croutons were the best of the salad.  Dressing was good but the salad may have been a little overdressed as the dressing is saltier and definitely more anchovy heavy. 

Grilled salmon-  I love salmon and have eaten plenty of it at restaurants.  The presentation was nice but the salmon was overcooked and a little dry.   

Risotto- not memorable.
author: Christina T.

description: This restaurant is spectacular ( especially note my photos of the bar and the stunning floral arrangement that included real unripe persimmons)  just like we were told many many times by all the staff at our hotel the four seasons... The bartenders all told me to try the baked chicken which takes an hour to prepare so you definitely can't be having a busy rushed day so of course we did that and I'm glad. The taste was spectacular and the stuffing is something I'm still dreaming about one week later. Evidently they brine this chicken for two days to make it so tender. Also the Neighbourhood is adorable with two great antique stores you should try after lunch and great window shopping... Plus it is right on the most famous streetcar line which features a huge variety of renovated and beautifully painted antique streetcars imported from all over the world including Russia and Paris and New Zealand and Australia. Instead of walking back to the hotel we took a street car and it was built in 1944..... It was amazing to see and sit inside history that is still functional and helpful and beautiful. I will include a photo in this review.
author: Julian L.

description:
There's a reason this place has been open as long as it has and it's still one of the hardest place to get a reservation. As further reinforcement, Traci Des Jardins (of Jardiniere fame) was sitting next to us.

Everything we had was fantastic, service was spot on. For the dinner...we started with a picolo fritto which sounded ok, but was amazing. Lightly fried leaves, onions and fennel in chickpea flour. Followed by their fantastic ceasar which really is worth getting. They are great to split the order in the kitchen as we were sharing.

Of course we had the chicken...we had to get the chicken. Looking around so was just about everyone else. I asked and the waitress says about 80% of the tables get the roast chicken. I guess there's a reason for that too eh? The chicken is tender with a unique flavor (not a bland nothing meat of chicken). The mustard greens on top were really tasty and the bread salad soaked in all the chicken juice, fat and olive oil is so savory. It's an incredible dish together.

We were so full, we couldn't have dessert, but had a perfect cappuccino to finish dinner. One of the best, comfy, tasty and non-pretentious meals that you'll ever have. Love this place!!!
author: David L.

description:
Yes 
Five stars 
Any one who can do what these guys do with roast chicken and Caesar's salad???
We had some other stuff: their menu changes daily as far as this goes: a perfect Risotto and battered veggies is what sticks in the mind
Add to this the ambiance, the service,the wonderful cocktails the great wine selection and the desert: yes that flourless chocolate cake!
An institution that continues to live on!!
author: david k.

description: Excellent restaurant and bar in a great location, super nice establishment with a great atmosphere and service. Went there for cocktails and dinner on a Saturday night and we had the best of times. The food is excellent, not big portions but great quality and you can taste the freshness and quality of the ingredients, flavors are amazing and menu changes daily to adapt it to what's fresh, seasonal and available. And VERY important, the bread is amaaaazing! Loved the place, will go back. Also the drinks were awesome, and it feels super chill and cozy inside.
author: Martino P.

description: Not worth the money.  Waited forty minutes for a table even with a reservation; no service recovery.  Food is just ok.  Living on it's rep.  Money better spent elsewhere.
author: david w.

description:
Zuni cafe is a place where the bountiful decor and vibrant noise really get one to be quite excited.

There's something about walking into such an establishment where you immediately notice the copper bar table and the workers are all gleefully smiling, you know that this is a special place. 

The decor of the place is very comfortable and it has almost a New Orleans vibe to it, from the diverse amount of people to the chatter amongst the tables. The service here is just about average, unfortunately. There were a couple mistakes with my requests and they seemed to be a bit understaffed because I felt like the service was quite slow. When I did see service they were very generous.
One also concern was that I could not shake off the hint of a tourist attraction. I get that it's quite popular, but there's just something about this place that really makes it feel like they are just trying to force people in then out. 

I did not have a lot of time to try the famous roasted chicken, but that's not to say my meal was not enjoyable. To start, I got the Zuni salad. One thing strange was that it was marked to have eggs yet my salad had no hard boiled eggs whatsoever, a bit misleading. Otherwise the salad was very good, there is a strong presence of parmesan cheese; so your mileage may vary.

The second course was my main course, the grilled tuna. This is actually one of my favorite entree's this year. The tuna was well-seasoned and the sides with it were divine. The only main issue was that I was served an under-cooked asparagus that was so tough I'd deem it inedible. 

For dessert I had the Pavlova, which I'd get any chance I get. It was delicious. The consistency and the toppings all complimented each other very well.

Some things to consider was that I could see pricing being on the side of imbalance, but I felt like everything was so good I think it is quite worth the visit.
author: Vinh T.

description:
We really wanted to like this restaurant, but honestly it was a disappointing dinner that was absolutely not worth the high price. Neither of us had ever been here but we reserved a table on a celebratory night for us.

 The restaurant itself is nicely decorated and the multiple smaller rooms allowed the sound of the piano downstairs to still carry but kept the conversation volume low and pleasant. We were a little surprised at the paper tablecloth covers, though. 

We didn't want to wait an hour for the chicken for 2 entree, so we went ahead with the pork chile verde and the chantrelle mushroom dishes, and started with the ricotta gnocchi with chives and corn,  and the shoestring potatoes. On a positive note, the food all came very quickly, and the cadence of the wine, small plates, and entrees was good. However, neither of us had an "mmm" moment at all throughout the whole meal. You know when you take a bite of something so delicious that your eyes roll back a bit and you savor the hell out of it? Didn't happen, unfortunately. It was a lot of "...eh." Bland and nothing special.

The shoestring fries (which come in an absurdly large pile) weren't seasoned at all, even with salt. They get cold and limp very quickly because they're so thin and the pile is so huge. The gnocchi were ok, but nothing to write home about. The description sounded delicious, but it just didn't come together for us unfortunately. The chantrelle mushrooms were super dry and spongy...not pleasant. The pork chile verde my husband ordered was ok, but not great. It was the dish with the most flavor, but the flavor bar was low with the rest of the meal :/

My husband says we should go back just to try to chicken that they're supposed to be known for, but honestly i'm hesitant to spend $60 with the risk that the chicken will be just as dry or bland as this meal. I would definitely rather spend the money at other fine dining spots if we're in a splurging mood.
author: Bronwyn H.

description: I've lived in SF for nearly 20 years but this was my first time eating at Zuni. Went there for a meeting. The waiter tried to force me to order dinner rather than lunch by inaccurately answering my questions about the lunch menu. It was a few minutes before 6 so there was a choice to order from lunch menu or dinner menu. Ordered 1 single entree from the dinner menu and two glasses of wine. For this, total bill was $96. The worst part is that they added more than 6% to the cost of the bill in some undisclosed fees. The excessive cost is one thing, but inflating an already inflated meal with fake fees just because they want more money is not acceptable. Service overall was good and food also was good but the plate was dominated with meat and not well balanced between meat/veg/carb. Wish I'd taken a pass on this.
author: Eater S.

description:
Friends treated me to dinner here in October. We had a later reservation and the restaurant was packed. I had heard such great things about this restaurant so was excited to try it. We were seated upstairs. 

It's been a while since the visit so hopefully the pics will provide more detail. Besides, friends did all the ordering. 

We tried:

Caesar salad
Anchovies & cheese plate : wasn't a fan of the house cured anchovies
Fritto misto : small portion
Manila clams: too salty
Fresh raw oysters: very good but pricey
French fries: nicely crispy
Chicken for two: beautifully presented and tasted fine (but I think one can roast a chicken nicely in their own kitchen)

The wines per glass are expensive.

Service was attentive and personable (hence the 4 stars). I'd return to try other items if I was back in the area.
author: Faye L.

description: Great food; simple menu and a nice wine selection; this is a fantastic neighborhood place that is great with friends or for a business lunch.  Never disappoints and always a stop on my trips to that Bay Area.
author: Rob M.

description:
This is probably my favorite restaurant in Martket St.
Tasty, yummy, and comfortable.
I love the staff here!!!
author: Kazuki N.

description: This restaurant (cafe?) is quite fancy and overpriced. We sat on the top floor next to a window which felt like I was in Italy and quite romantic. The chicken is great, but good to know it takes 60min to make. Good experience overall for cocktails and food, but only for a special occasion.
author: Christine A.

description:
Tried this place for lunch because of all the hype. Big disappointment.

1) Food and service was SO SLOW and waiters were inattentive. 

2) Very small portions and overpriced 

3) LACKED FLAVOR

4) polenta was bland, taste like paper

5) sausage patty dish was decent but it only comes with 1 small sausage patty (size of golfball) surrounded by 3-4 lettuces and 3 small grapes- $20, not worth the price in my opinion. 

6) Rabbit dish was super dry and came out cold. It comes with 2 small pieces of rabbit, a couple pieces of corn and a small whip of mustard sauce on side - I sent this dish back. Disgusting 

7) Chicken for 2 was $60 (they raised the prices) - took 1 hour to cook and also lacked flavor and was dry. Only came with leafy greens piled on top. Go to Costco for better rotisserie chicken 

8) Go somewhere else and save your appetite, money and time.
author: Leilani W.

description:
I came here for lunch on a weekday with 2 other friends and Had a very pleasant experience. The restaurant wasn't too busy when we arrived around 11:30 but did get busier as it got closer to lunch time. Zuni cafe seems like it's a favorite amongst the locals and I can see why. They make a great roast chicken. 

The only downside of this chicken is that it takes an hour to prep and can't be ordered ahead. "It's part of the Zuni experience." 

The chicken is huge!! We couldn't finish the whole thing between the 3 of us so it's definitely more of a meal for 4 than 2... 

We shared a couple salads and oysters while we waited and chatted about life. If you have a few hours of free time, grab a few friends and try the Zuni experience.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Had a wonderful experience this weekend. Great ambience, friendly and very attentive wait staff, and delicious food! 

We ordered the polenta and Caesar salad to start off. Both dishes were good. Nothing outstanding about them, but still tasty. We also ordered the shoestring potatoes - once again, really tasty but not outstanding. They're fun to eat though. 

For our entrees we ordered the manila clams in some kind of tomato sauce, a vegetarian pasta dish, steak (I completely forgot the actual name of the dish!), and the famous roast chicken for two. 

The pasta, clams, and steak were all delicious, but I want to talk about the chicken. Before coming here I was very skeptical about it (chicken...for $58???) However, the chicken was extremely moist and juicy, with good flavor. The highlight of the chicken dish for me, though, was the bread salad on the bottom. I would order this dish again just for the warm, crispy bread soaking in chicken juices. With all the chicken, frisee, and bread salad, this dish can easily feed more than 2 people, which makes the $58 dollars worth it when split. 

Overall, food was 4 stars. I give Zuni a 5 for the wonderful ambience and wait staff.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
Bay Area natives know that Zuni Cafe has one of the best chicken dishes and best Caesar salads in town. So I won't waste any more ink overstating the obvious. But I'm surprised that not too many people talk about their bar. It's really quite lovely and inviting.

I recently came here for a pre-dinner drink on a Saturday night. It was certainly a lively scene. But I was still able to saddle up at the bar and order a Fernet. Even though the bartender was busy, he went out of his way to make me feel welcome and engage me in conversation. Once I had my drink in hand, I sat back and soaked in the vibrant setting (and did some shameless people-watching).

With all the changes happening in the city (between the techie residents and the never ending neighborhood construction), Zuni Cafe reminds me of the old, unpretentious San Francisco that I used to love. Places like this still preserve that old SF spirit.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Zuni Cafe's one of those places you hear about everywhere, mainly for their roast chicken, but I could never justify dropping $60 for chicken, and so I never went. However my curiosity continued to build and build, and finally I decided to come for dinner. 

We made reservations about a week in advance, and the only time slot they had available was 5:30 for a Friday afternoon. We arrived and were seated promptly at 5:30, only to find out that their dinner menu doesn't start until 6. Until then, the menu is limited to a couple of small bites (including a good selection of oysters) and cocktails. Who knew?

We both ordered a cherry collins ($13.50) to tide us over until we could order real food at 6. It contained New Deal gin, Cherry Heering, lemon, and club soda, and was a good drink to slowly sip away at over conversation.

The moment it hit 6, we immediately ordered the chicken ($58) as we knew it would take almost an hour. We were probably the first table to place in our order! I'm really glad we did though, as the chicken took the expected hour to be served. 

Did the roast chicken live up to expectations? Surprisingly...yes. The chicken is mostly deboned and served in small pieces so that it is easier to eat, though I still found myself eating with my hands as it was hard to eat all the meat off the bones with only a fork and knife. It's served with a huge mount of mustard greens on top and a warm vinegar-y bread salad on the bottom that was delicious, especially when eaten together with the chicken.

The thighs and drumstucks were tender and moist, but what surprised me was how moist the chicken breast was! Honestly, it was probably the best chicken breast I've ever had, way better than my attempts to sous vide chicken breast at home. Not only was the skin perfectly flavored, but to my surprise so was the meat inside. Oftentimes the salt doesn't penetrate very deep into the skin and you're left with bland meat, but that wasn't the case here. And the skin, which is my favorite part of a chicken, was roasted to a perfect crisp. 

I enjoyed every bite of the chicken, and while we were not able to finish the whole chicken by ourselves, I took a couple pieces home and they were still just as delicious a couple days later (though unfortunately the skin was no longer crispy).

While I still have a hard time wrapping my brain around $58 roast chicken (which is really closer to $80 once you add tax, tip, and the 5% SF health mandate...), I can definitely see the appeal and might be willing to come back and splurge again at some point in the future.

Service was great, as you would expect from a restaurant of this calibre.
author: Dianna H.

description: We went for Sunday brunch. We had the scrambled eggs, fried eggs, and duck breast dishes between us. All were just ok. Portion sizes were very small. After eating the scrambled eggs dish, I was still hungry, and I left hungry because I didn't want to spring $12 for dessert. I would probably not come back for brunch. Way better and less expensive options in the city, even within walking distance of Zuni.
author: Jack M.

description: Delicious meals! Pork and sole plates. It's a little fancy price for me but it was worth eating the dinner and dessert!!!
author: Erena S.

description: I was so disappointed in Zuni cafe. An old chef I used to work for raved about this place. He also lent me the Zuni book. I was so excited to try it. Chicken is good but, in my opinion not worth the wait and money. Caeser was pretty good. The rissoto was way under cooked. Appetizer wasn't anything special.
author: Sebastian P.

description:
This place did not disappoint. I had the pleasure of having the Beausoleil oysters, caesar salad, and a steak with all the champagne and wine pairings. 

The service was impeccable which was attentive with not being overly attentive.
author: Mike B.

description:
This place has been around for such a long time which I respect.  I tried their "famous" chicken about 15 years ago, had lunch there a few months ago, and went back last weekend and tried their chicken again.

The chicken dish was a disappointment, I think the hype is overrated based on their great past 15-20 years ago.  It's still a cool restaurant, the first courses were good and tasty but not 5 star.

But the chicken came served on a bed of a ton of greasy crispy sourdough bread (and they already serve the same sourdough bread with the meal!), and topped with raw and oily frisee type "mustard greens".  The chicken itself was flavorful but a bit plain, and the breast a bit dry.  For $58 they REALLY need to at LEAST step up their game with the sides they serve the chicken with.  Like a REAL cooked vegetable, and a real starch/carb.  We left feeling a bit ill from the heavy unhealthy bread it was served on (hardly ate any) and the oily raw salad stuff.
author: Avi S.

description: I love this place so much! My fav thing is the chicken dinner and the bread salad. I also love the Caesar salad the croutons are the most amazing part.
author: Lillian J.

description:
Their Caesar salad is actually one of the best that I've had in a long time. Their chicken, while delicious, was just a chicken - moist, but relatively plain.

Overall a noisy, but very cute place to have a meal.
author: Christina S.

description:
All my little foodie heart wanted was roasted chicken. I came to Zuni with a plan:

Skip my 4pm snack (which, btw was SO hard to do)
Leave work at 5
Friend shows up at 5 and places an order for chicken
Arrive around 5:30
Kill thirty minutes of time with a plate of shoestring potatoes on repeat while excitedly awaiting chicken (which totally hits the spot)
Conquer the whole chicken by myself

Except, we shared the chicken but I ate most of it since he wasn't super hungry anyways (I blame the bench press PR for my outrageous hunger that day).

It was kind of the best that my friend was visiting and wanted to grab an early dinner. I've heard so much about the roasted chicken with Tuscan style bread salad, this was the perfect opportunity to try it. The chicken actually does take an hour to roast so either don't show up super hungry or pace yourself with some appetizers. 

I know, I know. It's "just chicken". BUT, it's delicious. It's perfectly moist, skin is deliciously crispy, and although it has minimal seasoning it's executed so well! Friend mentioned between eating other things and coming back to the chicken, if you eat a small, small bite you'll savor it and realize actually how delicious it is (instead of hogging it like I did). It's really clean tasting and no frills. Simplicity at its best. 

The salad though, I felt that needed to be salt and peppered and I wasn't a huge fan of the balsamic-vinegar dressing. I enjoyed the pine nuts, yum. Meh. You won't get a whole salad though, just a few frilly mustard greens. 

We also ordered the little gem salad which is a few pieces of butter lettuce, a couple radishes and carrots. I liked the tangy buttermilk dressing. For dessert we opted for two desserts: the pot de creme and something similar to a galette with seasonal fruit. 

That chicken though, I almost ordered a second one.
author: Shereen A.

description: Went to celebrate a friends birthday, the service was disorganized. It was too warm, nothing came in order and Everyone working was very judgmental, the food is mediocre and staff is rude. I used to enjoy this place. Such a bummer.
author: Cristina F.

description:
My mom and I came here because her best friend in used to live in SF in the 70s and frequent Zuni. The space feels open and is decorated beautifully. There are 2 floors, a copper lined bar, a grand piano, and an open kitchen with a wood oven in back. The hostess sat us at the table in front of the kitchen. We were entertained.

We didn't have enough time for the warm bread chicken dish (that takes an hour and is for 2 people), but we watched our neighbors devour the dish and we agreed it looked more of a dinner entree. We opted for lunch dishes: my mom got the Caesar salad and the burger and I got the little gem salad and the ricotta pizza. Both salads were fresh and small enough for an appetizer.  The caesar had crunchy homemade croutons and my gem salad had the best dill dressing. Our mains were also fantastic, the burger came on a focaccia which I felt was not the best bun but tasty and again homemade. The pizza had a thin Neapolitan crust and was baked with the tomato sauce. The ricotta was shaved onto the pizza after it came out of the oven. It was not your regular ricotta, but I was v into it. 
I'll be back for the chicken and warm bread salad, Zuni!
author: Alyssa B.

description: We enjoyed our dinner at Zuni. The food was fresh, tasty and nicely presented. We got the special roasted chicken. The best part was the stuffing. It's otherwise a very moist flavorful roasted chicken, not really worth the hour wait. The caesar salad and drinks were excellent. Service was friendly and accommodating though note it got very hot upstairs on a seasonably warm fall day.
author: Karen W.

description:
I was surprised to learn that Zuni has been around longer than I've been alive, because the entire experience feels fresh and updated with the times. It's wedged in an area of town that's not quite Hayes Valley but not quite Civic Center either, and it offers California cuisine in sophisticated, but approachable surroundings. 

The triangular corner venue is particularly pleasant at lunch, as large windows let in lots of natural light into the airy space, which makes full use of both the ground level as well as a loft-like space. A side dish of polenta was indeed a fresh, sunny way to start the meal. Combined with a savory, well-prepared burger featuring organic, grass-fed beef from Marin, it was quite a satisfying, filling lunch.

Service was as sophisticated as the setting, and the drink selection was quite decent too. Prices were also reasonable given the quality of the ingredients, preparation, and entire experience. Whether you're a local or a visitor, if you're looking for a restaurant that exemplifies Bay Area dining, then Zuni would be a good candidate.
author: Vincent L.

description: Great food and our waiter Teddy was excellent. Try the Point Reyes blue cheese with orange blossom honey for dessert! Go by Teddy's suggestions he knows the great good to order!
author: Troy N.

description:
FINALLY ZUNI!!!!

Not much more to add that the other 2,400 other yelp reviews haven't already stated.
Came here for a special Sunday brunch, and Zuni didn't disappoint!
Amazing ambiance! Make reservations!

Must Order:
Polenta - and ask for both parmiganiano and mascarpone - this is so rich and creamy. 

Shoestring Potatoes - This mound of shoestrings remind me of my child hood favorite snack chips call PikNik, but way better and on an entirely different and non-canister level (where PikNiks were packaged).  Hot, perfectly crisped and salted. This is the best starter while waiting for the Roasted Chicken.

Roasted Chicken - Lives up to the hype and worth the 60 minute wait. Tender, juicy, fall off the bone kind of meat. Chicken is so flavorful and the bread salad with mustard greens, dried currants and pine nuts are the perfect complement to the chicken.

Santa Rosa Plum Ice Cream with blueberry compote and oatmeal cookies - Excellent dessert that was the best end to the amazing meal. I needed something sweet and not too heavy, and wished I could take home more of the oatmeal cookies, as they were warm and fresh!

So happy to finally try Zuni and lived up to and exceeded my expectations.
Great friendly and efficient service. There was always someone refilling waters or clearing plates, etc.,  Did I mention that they serve yummy acme bread (my favorite)?!?

Anyway, I loved my experience here and will undoubtedly return to Zuni.
What I also loved is that on the bottom of the receipt was "IMMIGRANTS MAKE AMERICA GREAT".... and I couldn't agree more with you, Zuni! Love and peace....xoxox
author: Gill C.

description:
Zuni is a very solid 4 star. My girlfriend and I went tonight and we had a great meal. The waiter that was taking care of us let us know right off the bat that 90% of diners choose to go with the Zuni Caesar salad, some shoestring fries to share, and then the chicken. While there were some other tasty looking items on the menu that we wanted to try, we decided to play it safe and we went with his recommendation without any questions. The menu notes that the chicken can take up to an hour I believe, but with a 6:30pm reservation on a Tuesday, we only had to wait less than 40 minutes for our chicken to be ready. The time passes by so fast you won't even notice :)

Now then, let's talk about the chicken, since that's what Zuni is most famous for... The chicken itself honestly isn't the most tender or juiciest chicken in my life, but the dish as a whole, with the delicious bread salad, makes the dish a must get for me. The bread soaks up all the delicious juices of the chicken; I'm sure you'll be wishing you had more bread. Since it was just the two of us, we definitely needed to take leftovers home for the chicken. It's a pretty sizable portion that I expect would be ideal for 3-4.

Would I come again? Definitely. But don't expect to walk it. The place looked like it was PACKED, so be sure to grab a reservation beforehand.
author: Austin W.

description:
I had high hopes but received disappointment 

They don't have a fresh pasta

They didn't have fresh juices, the orange juice is so boring? 

They had one warm vegetarian entree which was a pizza 3/5

The server said I could get a vegetable platter and beans or salad? No thank you 

The soup has beef and chicken 

I definitely don't enjoy restaurants who don't have a dedicated vegetarian option!
author: Sar P.

description: We were excited to have lunch here, and ordered burgers and fries. Sadly, the fries didn't come out with the burgers, and even at the point when the burgers had been finished, the fries still hadn't come out. We let the server know we no longer needed the fries since the meal was over, and I was surprised at how little acknowledgement there was.
author: Brooke H.

description:
I came here a bunch of years ago for the burger at lunch. I was unimpressed. (also that French fries are extra $$'s)

Anyway it was a Tuesday night and 3 of my sisters were in town to see Book of Mormon. I don't see my sisters that often and one is a REAL foodie, and one is a pretty picky eater. but one this we can all agree on is good roast chicken.

They open at 6 and we know the roast chicken takes an hour. SO once we were seated the 6 of us ordered 2 chickens and some wine while we figured out the other things to share. 

If I am remembering everything - we got:
french fries
gnocchi
fritto
calamari
polenta
bread

So in the end we didn't really NEED 2 chickens - but since I was the only one not going to the play we got the leftovers.

The chicken is amazing, but what is really amazing is the bread salad, pine nuts and current - sorta like stuffing and a delicious carb bomb!  the recipe is posted and if you have a kitchen bigger than my postage stamp size one I bet you can make it at home. 
https://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/zuni-roast-chicken-with-bread-salad-56389456
author: Amy W.

description:
I was recommended this place by a foodie friend who swore up and down that this place has the best chicken period.

Not the best roasted chicken, the best chicken. So naturally I had to try it.

We had a really cool table right near the kitchen where we could see the chickens coming out of the wood oven. I could hardly wait. 

We checked out the menu before hand and the chicken has a one hour wait time so we immediately ordered it as soon as we were seated.

We also ordered some gnocchi, a Cesar salad and some polenta so we had stuff to munch on while we waited for this chicken.

The items we ordered were pretty basic, salad was equivalent to any Cesar at any restaurant. The gnocchi was tasty even though it had the texture more like a dumpling. The polenta was weak, it was super generic, 10 cents worth of polenta with a dollop of cheese.

Now I as we were done eating our snacks all we could do was watch and wait for the chicken, watching was a mistake.

The chicken was placed on a cutting board straight out of the oven, and the under counter refrigerator right under the cooked chicken station was where they kept the raw chicken. On more than one occasion I witnessed them grab a raw chicken, put it on a plate, then set the plate on the cutting board inches away from the cooked chicken and even closer to the cutting board surface. I even caught a raw leg hanging off the plate and resting on the cutting board. This place strikes me as a really nice place, everything we ate with the exception of the polenta seemed like it was really good quality and organic so having a raw free range organic chicken touch a cooked chicken or the cutting board is not a huge deal but that could change easily with a purchase of some sub standard ingredients.

My biggest gripe was the wait, damn near the entire time I was watching them cook and carve the chicken they had multiple whole chickens fresh out of the oven just sitting there waiting to be carved and served, the longest stretch for a chicken waiting to be served was 20 min, that's nuts to me if you have an establishment set a president that your chicken will be cooked to order that s**t better be on my table fresh out of the oven, not 20 min later. They might as well just always have a cooked  chicken waiting there for an order so I don't have to wait. 

Overall this place did not have the best chicken ever, it did not even have the best roasted chicken. I will not be returning and my foodie friend who just recommended this place just lost his stripes.
author: Chris G.

description:
A classic SF institution, Zuni Cafe's classic dining room looks like it's from decades ago, but they're mixing in fresh Californian ingredients and flavors into their menu, which changes nightly. However, there are certain classic items that have been on the list for decades--Zuni, of course, is famous for their chicken, which takes a whole hour to make, and this is indeed what most tables around me ordered. Having heard all the hype, I had to try this dish (and a host of others) for myself! Coming in for dinner on a Sunday, we were seated with our reservation, and our kind waiter walked us through his recommendations on the menu.

After starting with Acme bread, we had the Caesar salad, which was a fairly generous portion of romaine lettuce dressed with Casesar dressing, parmesan, and fresh croutons! This was a really refreshing, umami dish, and made for a great start to the meal. Then we had two additional small plates--the piccolo fritto was a plate of deep-fried romanesco, onions, and lemons, served with a charred onion crema. I found it slightly disappointing--it seemed to be a random amalgamation of deep-fried vegetables without any good balance or surprising flavors. The ricotta gnocchi served with lobster mushrooms, corn, and chives were light, ethereal, and creamy, but they lacked a certain heartiness and umami flavor that come with a good gnocchi dish.

And then the chicken! It was indeed perfectly brined and roasted--juicy on the inside and crispy skin on the outside. The chicken is cooked over Acme bread, which absorbs all of the juices, and the bread becomes part of the bread salad, alongside pine nuts and currants, and the whole dish is topped with frilly mustard greens. This was good chicken indeed and executed perfectly, but for me, it was still just chicken and a little hard to justify the $58 price tag. 

Finally came dessert--we split the blackberry panna cotta, which was nice and light and not overly sweet. It was served with nectarines and ginger snap cookies on the side--a nice seasonal dish to round off the meal! Overall, Zuni has a great atmosphere and some of the dishes are decent--however, I didn't find the food particularly creative or any of the flavors particularly surprising. Their chicken is definitely good, but the overall prices and value could have been better.
author: David K.

description:
Zuni is definitely in my "San Francisco Top Five." To me, Zuni is just *classic* San Francisco. I love this place, and have been coming for years. I have been for dinner a only a handful of times - and it's wonderful - but my favorite time to visit for Saturday or Sunday BRUNCH. I sit in the bar area - specifically the "glass corner" - that has maybe 6-7 small tables (no reservations needed here). PERFECT on a sunny day, and great for people watching.

The copper bar is wonderful - great for a glass of bubbly and a couple of oysters if you have to wait for friends or a table. I hate they do not have stools at the bar for dining, but I suppose it keeps the space open. Nice still.

Some San Francisco "classic" places are accused of resting on their laurels. Not the case here. Never disappointed.

For brunch - my usuals: 

 - the burger (one of the best in the city) 
 - oysters (so perfect and fresh here, I am wary of ordering them at other restaurants)
 - Caesar salad (one of the best in the city) 
 - the flatbreads. 

Also, they have this small dish of anchovies, celery, manchego, olives, and olive oil - get it.

Service: Michelin Star quality (2)

As an aside, I have never had their famous whole baked chicken, but I make it at home with Judy Rogers' recipe, and it's perfection. I debone the chicken first, so obviously mine is better. :-|
author: Corey M.

description:
Ah, what a wonderful dining experience. 

Came here for my boyfriend and i's five year anniversary. They accommodated our reservation even though we were half an hour late.

The roasted chicken and warm bread salad was amazing. My boyfriend didn't like the bitter mustard greens, but i liked them. 

We also had the shoestring fries (OH MY GOD) 
And we had the Caesar salad, a nice classic take on it. 

Will definitely come back! Waiter was great.
author: Gauri V.

description:
I believe I've had just about everything on the menu - at some time. 

The roast chicken is the specialty, and it is delicious. But I also enjoy the seafood dishes -- especially the trout -- and the Italian side dishes -- especially the polenta, as well as super selection of wines by the glass.

Also great open environment -- so you can enjoy the culinary delights as well as your conversation/company/dining companion(s).
author: Steven S.

description: This has been my go to in San Francisco for over 10 years now and I have yet to be disappointed! The Zuni chicken roasted in the wood fired brick oven is to die for but be warned it takes 30 minutes to get to the table. Served with warm bread salad, pine nuts and red currants tossed with arugula or mustard greens......heaven. My tip while waiting for the chicken to finish is the oyster bar paired with a nice glass of bubbly. Oh and don't forget the espresso granita layered with heavy cream to cleanse the palette for the finale!!
author: Alexandra V.

description:
Iconic San Francisco cuisine and my favorite restaurant in the city. Can be very very busy-you can make a reservation late in the night which I would recommend.  They are famous for their chicken that feeds two, as well as their Caesar salad.   I always love sitting upstairs by a window, you feel a World away from the insanity of marks street.  
Pricey but worth it for special occasions.  
French fries are good to share!   Late night they have an awesome hamburger.  
Not as busy at lunch.
author: D D.

description:
WOW! we have been here numerous times and boy was the service horrible!! Could not get what we ordered without reminding staff. Just horrific! It took over 3 hours to get lunch. They were busy but as they were seating others that came in 20-30 minutes AFTER us I started to get miffed. i said something and I got a snobby response in return. Small portions for the price. Not worth going back.    
Zuni Café hit with labor lawsuits even as it receives James Beard award. 
Maybe not the best place to patronize?
author: Gregory H.

description: Excellent meal. One of the best tasting fish I've ever had. Wood fired brick ovens add a flavor that can't be replicated by other forms of cooking. The trout had a delicious flavor and crispness though out. I ate everything on my plate. I would highly recommend you give this place a try. The menu changes daily, so trust the wait staff's recommendations.
author: Ryan Y.

description: ...a most comfortable restaurant that never fails to make you not only comfortably welcome it will feed you like mom never did...think chicken...do the wait...it's worth it...
author: Jay F.

description:
Really disappointed by this meal. We've been here many times and usually stick to the classics, and maybe that's where we went wrong. Still, quality was off tonight. Ricotta gnocchi tasted/had texture of scrambled eggs (we've had this dish other places and have made at home); salmon overcooked; fritto misto not properly seasoned. Serving of cheese laughably tiny and thrown on the table. Caesar salad great as always. 

Server was really nice and obviously green. He left and retrieved tasting notes when we asked about a few Italian whites (fair enough, but not helpful to hear about notes of cantaloupe, etc). Water glasses empty all night. We poured our own wine. 

This is an SF institution, and we'll probably be back for the chicken, but pretty disappointed by our experience.
author: Jon G.

description:
The chicken and bread salad was great but everything else was lacking. The flourless chocolate cake was really dry. 

The reason why I'm giving it three stars however is because the waiter that we had was really rude. He was flippant and condescending and it really ruined the dinner. 

When you hear about a restaurant like Zuni over and over and over again, you have high expectations. This was disappointing.
author: Erica C.

description:
Zuni Café was wonderful and deserves a solid 4 stars. The service is absolutely impeccable - the waiters were friendly, water was constantly replenished, and they took note of my request in open table and had the chicken in the oven by the time we were seated.

The chicken for two was worth the wait. Simple and scrumptious roasted chicken with mustard greens, raisins and pine nuts. Served with warm bread salad. The chicken was moist and the skin flavorful. Highly recommend this quintessential SF dish.
author: Arijit P.

description: I hate to give Zuni a 3 star review because the food is actually very good - Hawaiian fish dish and lamb - oysters are super fresh and wine selection is great . Also convenient pre threater place to eat . The portions are very small so the value is just not there.  The service while good was amateurish - server was not familiar with options and seemed apathetic .  Been here several times before but this may be the last .
author: MJ J.

description: Fancy $24 burger here. Not sure if it lived up to the hype but I did really enjoy it. Thick patty, high quality meat. The price of the burger is kind of a joke. $4 or whatever for cheese + grilled onions. Fries were $8 matchstick and they were terrible.
author: J A.

description: I'm not a big fan of chicken with bone in lol don't ask me why. But got the whole roasted chicken and it was amazing, extremely juicy with just the right amount of seasoning. The service is absolutely on point from the hosts to the servers.
author: Daniel V.

description:
Meeting up with a close friend, I chose Zuni since it was close to his hotel.  Reservations for 3 on a weekday night thru Opentable.  We took a Lyft and were about 15 minutes behind.  I called ahead to tell the restaurant and they said, "no problem."

As the driver pulls up, it hits me.  I've been here before; granted it was 8 years ago, but I had a very pleasant dinner here with my children all those years ago.

Hostess said it would be a few minutes so we stepped over to the bar for a drink.  It took a bit for us to get a drink, but we eventually got a round from the friendly bartender and then our table was ready.  We were led to an upstairs table that could seat 2 or 3.  Its a bit loud with everyone involved in their lively conversations.

Ordered a bottle of Sancerre.  Water and fresh bread was brought to the table.

I remembered the oysters here are delicious and we ordered a dozen.  They were perfect.

For dinner I had the special of the evening, the sea bass.  The avocado creme on the side was wonderful; perfect accompaniment for dabbing with each bite of fish.  Veggies were fresh and the asparagus was especially tender, yet crisp.

We weren't ready to end the evening and had a glass of port with a Point Reyes Bay Blue w/orange blossom honey.  Fantastic.

I have to add that my husband was disappointed in his scallops; too bad, there were so many other good things on the menu.

Our server was charming and friendly; I would love to return, but hope its not another 8 years.
author: Melissa L.

description: Wonderful ambiance, spectacular Italian French cuisine. Wife enjoyed the Quail while I enjoyed the Skirt Stake with tomatillo sauce was amazing! Fine choice indeed.
author: John F.

description:
Yes to the roast chicken and the Caesar salad. The anchovies were also stellar. I liked everything we ordered, although I literally cannot remember anything about the pork shoulder. I'd give that a miss. Really, the roast chicken was the star of the dinner. The mustardy salad served with it was just crazy good. Service was excellent and the atmosphere was fun. 

They also gave us a table that worked for us bringing our baby, which I really appreciated. Some SF restaurants are rude about it but they were great.
author: Lauren B.

description:
I've been meaning to write this updated review for some time. You are never rushed out of here, the ambiance is just what you need for comfort. 

My last two lunch dates here have been superb. Zuni makes you feel at home. 

The last time we lunched, both of ordered the rabbit. The dish was sooooo delicious. 

A SF classic.
author: Amy O.

description:
Great ambiance and really friendly bartenders. Wasn't impressed with my ricotta gnocchi dish but the roasted chicken did not disappoint.  The servers are very helpful and the wait staff do a great job of tending to the customers. 

Thanks Zuni Cafe!
author: Tammy L.

description:
We heard firsthand from people we know, received recommendations from top waitstaff in the city and read reviews online that the "Chicken for Two" is a must do at Zuni Cafe in San Francisco. We had to try it on an anniversary weekend.

I give the "Chicken for Two" a healthy thumbs up, yet I give Zuni Cafe a romantic thumbs down.
I usually love a local establishment, with a little history and a niche item on the menu. We were going for the nostalgia.

We had a late afternoon reservation and asked for a quiet, corner table near a window. The restaurant met our request on everything but quiet. We were seated next to a large and noisy group that had downed a few bottles of wine prior to our arrival. It was likely fun for them but not for us.

We asked to be moved and it seemed our only option for peace and comfort was the outside patio. It was a pleasant day by the bay, our order was on the rotisserie and we waited patiently as staff checked in. 

Once we settled in and our food arrived, we were happy. The chicken for two was not mind blowing but it was sweet. Maybe, the premise here is that nostalgia and a good dish alone deserves four stars. Happy Anniversary wherever we go!

#ZuniCafe
#ChickenforTwo
#NostalgiaWins
author: Elle N.

description: One of the best meals I've had in a while. Don't come starving because the roast chicken takes about an hour. Started the meal with shoestring fries, classic Caesar salad, house cured anchovies, and Orange Blossom cocktails. On to the main entree, the skin was not crispy but nonetheless the chicken was well brined and cooked to perfection served atop a dressed salad. The squid ink pasta was delicious and may have been off-menu or seasonal (unsure because my colleague ordered). It was cooked to al dente and served with a nice amount of fresh clams and squid. Overall, service was fine and I can't wait to return.
author: Amy H.

description:
Finally made it to Zuni Cafe after all these years!! And it was just as good, if not more than I expected! Definitely a great SF institution for a reason! We came in the  afternoon on a nice Sunday, and didn't make reservations so settled for sitting outside, even though it was a bit windy (and dust/dirt particles were slowly making its way into our food and drinks). But regardless, it was still a very pleasant brunch experience! Top notch service! We all wanted the duck entree but there was only one dish left so we decided to split 3 different dishes which I'm so glad because I got to try a variety, even if I didn't leave completely stuffed.

We shared the strawberry french toast which was very light, airy, fluffy and delicious! Not overly sweet, and the strawberries were perfectly sugared. The scrambled eggs, sausage and pistachio salad was so good. Probably my favorite, because the eggs were just so buttery and fluffy. Finally the duck was so tender, falling off the bone, and I could see why this dish was so popular! We also tried the anchovies appetizer which was adequately good. Also ordered a coffee which was served in a bowl.

So $40 a person at the end of the meal, but definitely worth it for a great brunch experience. Would return!
author: Vivian D.

description:
Everyone said the chicken here is bomb but you don't really know why a simple oven baked chicken can be bomb unless you tried. A $60 dollar baked chicken- I wasn't sure I'd get it anywhere else, but since everyone said it's the thing here, I tried it- and Ioved it. 


We made reservation here at 10:30 and was seated promptly. Unlike other brunch places, this actually takes reservation( which I love love) considering how restaurants get so crowded in the weekend. 
The restaurant is also located kinda in Hayes valley area- which is great for a brunch walk after getting so much food. There was a farmers market thing going on after we got brunch, and it was definitely nice to be out of FIDI and enjoy a more communal, chill vibe. 
We ordered oysters and the chicken. Make sure you put it on the order as soon as you get there- it takes 60 minutes to make. But was it worth it- yes! It was so tender and soft the meat feels like it just melts in your mouth. Although it's salted but the flavors are still just right you don't feel an overwhelming amount of saltiness in the mouth- just enjoy the juiciness of the chicken! I think the main selling point of this dish is the juiciness. The chicken can be shared by two but I think an additional appetizer would be good to counter the meat. The Caesar salad here is also good. 

The price came out to be 110 for two easily. 

Oh next time I'd try the margaritas- I heard it's amazing. Even if you don't like margaritas.
author: Jenny X.

description: You will regret going there all of their food is too salty. They can't even write down a right order. When I ordered a bolognese pasta they gave me their vegetarian pasta. The vegetarian pasta tasted like straight up salt.The worst restaurant I've been to. Even their caesar salad is 10 times better than their pasta. They should learn how to listen.
author: Ki Yong K.

description:
So I was in town and my friend who lives in the Bay Area had always wanted to go here. I'm so glad she picked this place. This was truly a gem to go to. Definitely not your typical brunch place. While they had items like French toast most of the items are things you don't typically think to find for brunch. We ordered the Pizza with Wagon Wheel cheese with cauliflower which was amazing and had orange zest on top which was a fantastic addition. We had the pasta of the day which had a bolognese like sauce and this was delicious. For dessert we had the panna cotta which was out of this world. The bread that they give you was so fresh. My friend had the cafe latte which came in a large bowl cup that she enjoyed. 

I love the fact the menu changes so next time I'm in town I'd love to go back and try new items! Until next time...

PS since I was heading out of town I had my suitcase with me and we ate upstairs so the waiter was nice enough that at the end asked if I needed help going down the stairs so he carried my bag down for me. Love considerate waiters!
author: Whitney S.

description:
Ordered three dishes, only one was even remotely good. Go elsewhere or order differently. 

Ordered the sweet potato, broccoli and onion fritter starter, the trumpet mushroom risotto and the cod with mussels and clams. 

The starter was good, but the other two dishes seriously missed the mark. The risotto was undercooked, tiny and lacked any sort of richness. 

The cod main was over cooked and completely lacking in flavor and the clams were dry and sinewy. The only saving grace was the two mussels which were delicious.
author: Cory D.

description:
Love the ambience of this place. You can see the wood fired brick oven and the oyster bar on the first floor!

Complimentary bread is not warm, and comes only with butter (not with olive oil or pepper). 

However, the famous chicken did not disappoint. It was perfectly seasoned, and you only taste the smokiness from the oven when you get to the bones of the chicken. The salad had a peppery taste to it. The bread salad is the star of the meal for me- amazingly soaked in chicken flavor and olive oil. Super fragrant and delicious! 

Shoestring fries- good to sustain you during the 1 hour wait for the chicken. 

If I were to visit again, I would try the other main courses (in particular the lamb), but the chicken is a must on the first visit.
author: Julia C.

description: Service is awesome. She knew her oysters and wines! Bar staff is a bit stiff and unhelpful.
author: Kevin M.

description: I used to love this place. No more. The servers and managers have totally lost interest. If you like poor service, go to Zuni.
author: Sean D.

description:
If one is looking for innovation and novelty, one should not go to Zuni Café. If every restaurant experience needs to be the most memorable meal of one's life, one should not go to Zuni Café. And if one wants a dining that can be described by adjectives like "hip," "trendy," "modern," "au courant," "cutting edge," etc., one should not go to Zuni Café. So who should go to Zuni Café? Anyone who wants a damn fine meal in a lovely room with great service, that's who.

Zuni Café has been on my list since I saw the late Judy Rodgers on television talking about brining meat when her cookbook came out some fifteen years ago. Sadly, I never got to Zuni Café before Ms. Rodgers passed away, so dining at her restaurant was my priority on my first visit to San Francisco in years. The room just feels very "San Francisco," with the exposed brick walls (so rare in L.A.), large windows, and loft seating. A dozen years ago, the room's late-'80s vibe almost certainly would have seen at least slightly dated, but now it feels classic; the patience to resist a remodel paid off. The long copper bar is stunning, and the bartender was warm and cheery. I had a San Francisco cocktail at the bar - it was interesting but a bit too sweet. I'd get something drier and boozier next time.

We sat upstairs by the windows with a view of the rain on Market Street. The Caesar salad - a Zuni mainstay, apparently - was delicious, perhaps the best Caesar salad I've ever eaten. The salad comes in whole Romaine leaves, and the kitchen split it automatically for us. My friend said she thought it might be "a little fishy," but to me, that meant it was perfect. The pizza with ricotta salata was simple and elegant; the hard, salted ricotta was shaved over the pizza after baking. That's it. The crust was light and delicate. The famous roast chicken for two was moist and soft and perfect. It came topped with baby mustard greens in a champagne vinaigrette, and beneath was the bread salad - sort of half-panzanella, half-Thanksgiving stuffing - with dried red currants and pine nuts. The bread salad had a vinegary dressing, and it was alternately soft and crunchy. Honestly, it stole the show, so much so that it was hard to pay attention to the beautiful, creamy polenta with mascarpone and Parmigiano-Reggiano, even as perfectly cooked a it was.

Service was attentive but never smothering, just right for a place of this caliber. What sticks in the mind is less how awesome one dish or the other is as much as how everything was just executed so beautifully. At Zuni Café, it's about getting things just right, not about being flashy or creating a scene. That's exactly what I was hoping for, and Zuni delivered. I can't wait to return...
author: Andrew W.

description: Ordered the roast chicken and it was delicious. Our water is Julie was nice and attentive  live piano music playing added to the  ambiance. Husband complained about the bread  being on the floor inside the basket and Manager Ren acted on it quick and  put  it on top of table and must have told all the servers cause they were all on the same page, now that's what I call a restaurant that cares. We'll definitely keep coming back. Thank you Zuni for a great experience.
author: Gloria T.

description: Update: Steven is still great. But Teddy is my favorite. Aged balsamic bloody mary was delicious and strong as always. The eggplant soup with oregano was SO good. Brought my sister with me and asked about vegan options- the vegan platter has various grilled veggies and is really tasty. Kushi oysters, manila clams, and shrimp are the truth.
author: Robert S.

description: Quintessential San Francisco dining. I've been to Zuni so many times over the years and have never been served anything but the best each time I've visited. Opt for the roast chicken despite the 1 hour prep, order a salad or two, you won't be disappointed. This is what eating out should be about.
author: Rich S.

description: Our last meal in San Francisco and it was absolutely amazing! Great food, excellent wine.
author: Aline S.

description:
The chicken is reallly good. Super moist and tender. The toasted bread put on the bottom of the chicken absorbs the flavor too! It's worth the wait. Just make sure to order it first because it'll take an hour. Salad was good too! We got the beet/avocado vinaigrette one that had a nice crunch from the nuts they put on top. 

We didn't have reservations so we waited 45 min. But I'd say, drop someone off to put the reservation down and in the meantime you can try to find parking and maybe get some cocktails at the bar. 

Service is really friendly. If you happen to leave for a bit to go to the restroom for instance, someone usually always folds your napkin up for you.
author: Mayee L.

description:
I brought my parents and fiancée here because I heard that this would be a nice sort of environment and approachable food that they would enjoy. I'm afraid I left regretting the choice.

We ordered a tomato and beet based appetizer, two intermediate size dishes (one pasta, one fish based), shoestring fri s, and the famed chicken and bread dish. Across the board, I can say the dishes were poor value. Portion sizes are quite small for the price, and not very filling. The courses before the chicken and bread all seemed not particularly memorable, and may not even be on the menu when you, the reader, visit. That's a bit of a downside to hit or miss restaurants with constantly changing menus, they don't have the time to improve/iterate individual dishes. 

The chicken and bread I expected to be a knockout, but it was memorable for the wrong reasons. The chicken was quite moist, probably achieved by a good brining. The skin was not anywhere near as browned or crisp as I would expect from a 60 minute wait. Half the croutons in our dish were burned. I don't mind charred food as much, so these were given to me, but it turned my party off a bit and probably affected my ability to taste and enjoy the rest of the dish. I will say that the currants and pine nuts are a nice touch, and I may borrow that idea to class up future thanksgiving stuffings (rather than the more common raisins and walnuts)
author: Neal B.

description:
Came for a 10pm dinner, straight from SFO. I flew in from JFK, which meant I was still on Eastern time, meaning it was really like a 1am dinner. My body was ready.

Located right off Market, the nice interior of the restaurant more than makes up for the outside, which tends to smell like feces. Woof. Not the fault of the restaurant at all, but let's just say it's good that they keep the door closed. 

My friends were very adamant that the 60-minute chicken was the thing to get here, so we ordered that, as well as the shoestring fries, the deep-fried quail, and the brick-oven trout. The shoestring fries were okay, although I personally like fries that have slightly more potato in them. The deep-fried quail was excellent, and the pomegranate actually cut through the richness quite nicely. The brick-oven trout was delicious, although it took me a while to get through all the bones. As for the chicken, it was everything that I hoped for, and the schmaltzy croutons were unbelievably good. The chicken was roasted nicely and quite moist throughout the chicken, even in the white meat.

The service in general was great, although the host made the really odd suggestion of keeping my luggage underneath the piano. I politely declined, trying to hide my puzzled look. Prices are a little expensive for chicken, but it is some darn good chicken, so it's worth a try.

Definitely a solid choice for dinner, especially for group dinners and perhaps even for a date. Will definitely be back for that chicken, and to see what other seasonal offerings will be available.
author: Eric J.

description:
It has been a long time since I wrote a review but Zuni's Roasted Chicken, O.M.G.!! It is probably the best roasted chicken I have ever eaten. Waiting for it for 60mins could also be making it more delicious while hungry :))
