Flourless chocolate dessert was one of the bests I have tried, too. I did not care for shoestring fries but they might be good while waiting for chicken. Anchovies was also good, too but cannot say must-try.
author: Emel M.

description:
This might be one of the best burgers I've ever had! Absolutely delicious and so juicy. I don't know how they do it! We even asked what they put into their burgers and our water told us it was just ground beef with salt and pepper. I'm still in awe.

We also ordered the shoestring potatoes, which are basically super finely cut fries. Pretty good, nothing too noteworthy to share. It came with mustard and ketchup; mustard was good. We also ordered polenta, which was creamy and delicious.

Our waiter was friendly and gave a good wine recommendation. They don't have the most extensive wine menu for single glasses. Although if you're looking to buy a bottle, there's a page long list for reds and another page long list for whites!

The only reason why this experience wasn't 5 stars was because of the extremely long wait for our burger. The wait was nearly an hour long, during a not so busy hour. We were seated at around 2:30 in the afternoon. Also I do want to mention that we came without a reservation at 2:30 and didn't have to wait for a table at all!
author: Julie L.

description: Haven't been to the Zuni in a while, but their Blue Cheese burger was always my fav.  Order it every time I go - used to work around the corner, and Zuni was a regular haunt.
author: Katherine R.

description: I had high expectations going into this restaurant. It came heavily recommended by my co worker who has been raving about it. I looked online and saw all the awards that the place has gotten so I was psyched. The restaurant is deceptively large, and has a nice ambience to it. The service is excellent and our waiter was super nice and accommodating. The chicken. That's what people come for. You have to wait about 40min - 1 hr for the dish. Let's say it's not worth the wait. The chicken was a bit dry and overdone. There is a 'bread' salad served with it, which is basically large, soft croutons. We had the shoestring fries which were good, but nothing to write about. The highlight of the evening was the chocolate cake. It's served with fresh whipped cream and is gluten free. It is surprisingly light yet moist. We would definitely come back just for the dessert and a drink.
author: Ray C.

description: Bloody Mary Review - Anyone who knows bloody marys, knows Zuni is quality. You could order the Classic Bloody Mary with Russian Standard Platinum vodka, tomato juice, Worcestershire, tabasco, salt and pepper. But that's an amateur move. What you really want is the Balsamic Bloody Mary with 6 year old balsamic and a spicy pepper-onion relish. Why go? 6 year old balsamic. | Price: $13
author: Shelley B.

description:
When I think of a classic SF restaurant, I think of Zuni Cafe. The chicken here is a must and my friends who used to live nearby and moved to Chicago always tell me how much they miss the Zuni chicken. 

The food is solid and you seriously can't go wrong dining here with friends. The layout is a little interesting in the upstairs area and there's this one area where you're squished with two other tables in a small box... so it gets really loud and echo-y from all the chatter.
author: Janet H.

description: Save your hard earned cash. Boston Market has better chicken. Far better. I noticed people referring to what comes with the chicken as "stuffing". It's a birds nest of oil, bread, and disappointment. $20 for 12 pieces of gnocchi. I could have bought 2 Boston market chickens. Thank god for the shoestring fries. It was a good enough portion to string together and hang myself.
author: Nick J.

description: This place steals the show. Every dish is so satisfying and well put together. Great brunch menu, oyster bar, generous selection of wines and apperitifs. Perfect for a catch up with family or friends. Menu highlights are the Zuni salad, the chicken to share, pasta dishes are great for vegetarians, pizzas for sharing and lastly the pavlova is amazing for dessert
author: Miriam L.

description: Great atmosphere, full house for a Tuesday evening, first time visit for us, made reservations for five of us, nice table, service good, very few wine selections, small portions, potato fries great, no Ketal one, no "Crown Royal ", lots of stairs, prices reasonable, gnocchi very small portion, flavor good...
author: Judy K.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon and got seated right away. We were actually walking to Hayes Valley from the our home in the Mission and decided to stop in when we saw it wasn't too busy. I was pretty jet-lagged from a trip abroad, so the afternoon meal was perfect.

We couldn't resist ourselves from getting the chicken for two, which is the unmatched, perfect meal for two. Sometimes you have to choose between crispy skin and tender chicken, but in true San Francisco fashion, you can have it all. 

This is a place to stay. And in our world where there is demand to get in and out and on with your day, I appreciate Zuni Cafe's intention of the late lunch lounge.
author: Anthony G.

description:
We were pretty disappointed 
The sea bass was cold and overcooked 
Tiny portions, overrated
author: M M.

description:
Only in SF do you make a reservation 2 weeks in advance for a weekday night, expect to wait an hour for the food, and end up spending a total of $112 on a dinner for two consisting of roasted chicken and a glass of wine each. And only in SF is this all perfectly normal! I feel like I am constantly amidst an existential crisis in my life-hate relationship of this city and its nonsensical yet unique lifestyle.

TL;DR is the infamous hour-long wait for the famous roasted chicken worth it? 
- Yes, if you go with good company. It's a bonding experience that brings back the spirit of good conversation over good food, especially in these busy days of SF where there's a crowd waiting for your table and you feel like a douche staying to chat after you're done eating.
- No, if the idea of the wait and/or price seems ludicrous to you, or if the prospect of an hour-long conversation would make a distressingly awkward date.

The roasted chicken is memorable indeed, and it is no wonder it has such a reputation. The prepration in the fire-brick oven imparts smokey, earthy overtones. (It's so delicious that you'll think it's an organic free-range chicken!) Although the texture is bit tough requiring some fork-and-knife technique, it seems the inevitable byproduct of the roasting. You can tell the flavor and succulence have been fine-tuned over the years to create this signature dish. 

The frisee adds a nutty dimension, and the warm bread "stuffing" is a guilt trip of a buttery garlic bread. Note that the bread seems to be the same as the complimentary bread, expect I suggest you save your stomach for the heavenly stuffing bread--it's a perfect toasty grilled levain with ample butter, olive oil, and chicken broth for a richly indulgent taste. The portions are big; the roasted chicken is definitely enough for three people (or two starving athletic guys).

I paired the meal with the Domaine Patrick Baudouín "Effusíon" Anjou 2014 Chenin Blanc from Loire Valley ($13/glass), which was excellent. (Fun fact - I'm no wine expert; I choose this because I was amused by the connection with pleural effusion, for any medicine nerds out there ^^) Friend got a glass of rose and we felt classy ^^

Zuni Cafe has a long history behind it, with roots as a Mexican restaurant (named after the Zuni tribe). Over the years it was shaped by the influence of the chefs and has now become something of a European-American fusion. The unique split level layout and location on a sharp corner are iconic. Reflecting the history, the ambiance is rustic with wooden fixtures and furniture. However in my opinion, some of the unvarnished and peeling wood by the windows is rather tacky and in need of restorations, especially for a restaurant that's charging $60 for a bird.

Zuni is an SF bucket list place: a delightful and unique dining experience, though with its share of oddity in SF rituals.
author: Edna C.

description: Undisputedly the best roast chicken dish in San Fran. And I know you'll think I'm crazy but possibly in the US..... I could arguably debate this "fact".  If you make a trip to San Fran and don't go to Zuni Cafe and try the roast chicken we can't be friends lol... ‍ it's everything.  It's takes 60 minutes to get so order something to tide you over in the meantime we ordered a pizza and the Caesar salad (the salad should be a strong option). I would take a flight to San Fran simply to go to Zunis... maybe, sure, yes!
author: Nicola F.

description: Perfect place for sunny lunch. Their caesar salad is special as reputations heard. Staffs are professional and I personally like the building and interiors. Sitting by huge window and enjoy street view in sunny day.
author: Jun O.

description:
I guess it was A-OK? I mean from the rave reviews as this being known as an iconic SF spot, I gotta say: not super impressed. It's a nice central location and the space is really nice, but we found the drinks to be adequate, the food and service alright and everything super pricey. Without a reservation (and good luck making one), the wait was a little over an hour and a half on a Saturday night when we arrive at about 6:45.

The husband's margarita wasn't awesome at $12. So limey, he winced with every sip. That was on the cocktail list and one shouldn't be wincing when drinking a house cocktail.

We ended up ordering fries (SO GOOD), clams, extra bread, the chicken for two, caesars salads (all over dressed), the pasta and the pork chop and our table of four all agreed: the fries and the pork chop were tops, everything else was unmemorable. Pair that with 2 bottles of wine and we dropped close to $500 with tip. That's a crap-load of money.

The bread isn't served warm, which is sad. Actually, now that I mention, most of the food isn't served warm. The pasta was room temp, the pork chop was good, but the accompanied mashed potatoes were cold and sent back. The chicken for two took well over an hour (it does say an hour on the menu, but our was closer to an hour and a half). It actually even arrived about 15 minutes after our dining companions' food with no apology. It's a ton of food, but at the end of the day, it was an oven cooked chicken topped with frisee and croutons. Simple. Honestly, it was good, the chicken was juicy, but it was again served room temp, and not knock your socks off for such an expensive meal. My friend's room temp pasta wasn't finished, she didn't care for it. 

The desserts were ok. The service was fine. None of us were that impressed with anything. We came, we saw, we ate, we left. I wouldn't return and probably wouldn't recommend to anyone. There's better out there, but I checked it out to see what the fuss was about.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I've been going to Zuni Café regularly for dinners and always recommend it to friends and visitors to beautiful San Francisco. Each time has been exemplary food and service wise, and I can't count how many delicious roast chickens, impeccably fresh salads and expertly crispy fries I've shared with friends and loved ones over the years. 

Unfortunately a recent lunch while very tasty, was marred by very poor service. Server in front of house had a bit of a condescending tone and did not check in on meal, or offer another drink or cocktail order. Glasses lingered empty but the server had enough time to go outside and have a chat with a passerby on the street. To make matters worse, the server offered bread service to every other table except mine. I pointed this out when he finally came around to the end of my meal. The server was apologetic but by then all the other service issues totally soured the experience. Not the $75 lunch service experience one expects at an iconic place like Zuni Café.

I am hoping this is an isolated experience as I visit San Francisco often and dine out for dinner regularly in the area. I sincerely hope Zuni Café management takes note of this and hope to have a much better experience next time.
author: D C.

description:
Beautiful restaurant and great service! Judy was an amazing waitress and she's so caring and funny! 
Everything was so good and the food was just amazing but the portion was so small! So youhave to keep that in mind if you're really hungry
author: Sara S.

description:
If you want attitude and a tired 25 year old menu go to Zuni.
It used to be exciting and the food was good way back. 
The menu is tired and old
author: robet r.

description:
Excellent restaurant, my first choice whenever I come to San Francisco.
The famous chicken is truly superb, one of the best I've had.
Not to mention the bread (from Acme bakery) and butter - so good, the bread crust - so good.
Eveything I've had here was delicious.
My favorite oysters are the Miyagi.
Prices are high, however, in my opinion, it's worth it.
author: Linda N.

description:
Wonderful little place, with amazing menu. I got the Irish tea off of their cocktail menu and it was great. Then for my starter the wild arugula salad with beats and pistachios were out of this world. You must also order their famous shoestring potatoes, it's a large portion, so ask for a half order if you think you can't eat all. Finally for my main, I ordered the top sirloin steak which comes medium rare but I ordered it medium well. 

Every item in the menu was well though out and well made. Will definitely be back.
author: Berj D.

description:
Lovely dinner overall but house cured anchovies with celery, Parma & olives which was bland.  Arugula salad delicious.
Main dish: Ricotta Gnocchi with spinach, and saffron butter sauce was swimming in what tasted like water. NOT good.  Passmore Ranch trout was amazingly delicious.
Bread: They bring two slices at a time. Really?  
Dessert a bit disappointing too....a chocolate Gateau with delicious whipped cream but a bit dry.    We've eaten here many times and still will..
author: P G.

description: Love this grilled chicken. It usually takes approximate 60 mins , but its worth to wait. The skin was smoky, the meat itself was juicy. For the side menu, shoestrings potato is recommended. Can enjoy 1 plate for two or 3people.
author: Saori Y.

description: Food was pretty delicious and unique, seating is average (hard chairs, straight back booths), service was good. Would recommend visiting once in SF
author: Shannon D.

description:
This is hands down my favorite restaurant in the city. Everything is always the best possible version of itself. 

The casual fine dining vibe is great, and the service is always on point. 

Their drinks are also fantastic. I like to start with a lillet and end with some calvados. 

The food: 
If it's your first time at Zuni, you will want to order the chicken. It is the best chicken you will ever eat. It takes an hour, so you'll want to tell the waiter as soon as you are seated. 

The Caesar salad is one of the best caesars you'll ever get. The dressing is deliciously garlicky without being overpowering. Everything at Zuni has perfect balance. 

I love the shoe string fries so I always get them. 

The brisket is delicious and should be tried. It melts in your mouth and it is paired with some sides that really compliment the flavors. 

The burger is the best burger I've had. It's simply perfect. What makes the burger great is that it isn't reinventing the wheel or trying to be more than it is. The beef patty is so flavorful and cooked to perfection. I also really enjoy the pickled veggies that it is served with. 
Something to note about the burger is that it is not always on the menu. It is on for lunch/brunch and then makes an appearance after 9pm. 

The pizza is also on point in it's simplicity. It isn't loaded with toppings so you can really enjoy the main ingredients: cheese, tomato sauce and bread. 

Can you tell I love this place?
author: Lucio G.

description: Really phenomenal meal. The roast chicken is what everyone raves about and I was not disappointed- especially with the bread underneath. I was a little disappointed that they didn't have gnocchi the day I was there because I was excited to try it. Basically everything was delicious. Definitely recommend!
author: Karen D.

description: Food arrived cold. Portions very small. Espresso was cold too. Service was rushed. They actually blinked the lights to get us to leave. When we got downstairs there were many tables still eating.
author: Derk L.

description:
Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco classic and a great place for dinner any night of the week.

The ambiance is fabulous, with nice views of market street and a quaint feeling on the interior. I came here for dinner with a friend and it was the first time either of us had dined here. I ordered the caesar salad (one of Zuni Cafe's specialities) and the porchetta plate which comes with kale, mushrooms, and a buckwheat polenta. It was a really fantastic meal. My friend ordered the lamb mixed grill, which comes with hummus, carrots, and sesame seeds. We finished the night with a pot of tea (I had the mint and he had the green tea). I was impressed with the attentiveness of the staff, and the timeliness of the service. Overall, it was a great experience.
author: Andrew L.

description: LOVE!!! The food was perfection and the staff was on point. Very knowledgeable and friendly. My glass was always full and they were very quick to bus dirty dishes off the table. That has to be one of my biggest pet peeves when dining out and I was thrilled with the quality of the service there. Worth every penny and I will recommend it to everyone I know!
author: Kaitlyn M.

description:
Maybe it's because of the hype, but I thought Zuni was just okay. Definitely good vibes, cool space, and convenient location from BART, but the food was only slightly above average and everything is really pricey. I was, however, able to make reservations about a week in advance, which is a plus!

I had a cocktail that was called Ginger...Something...because it sounded so refreshing. It was overly sweet and not the refreshing cocktail I was looking for. We ordered two appetizers, the tomatoes and fried vegetables. The tomatoes were really good, but the fried vegetables felt so elementary and there wasn't nothing special about them. They tasted like not-as-good-tempura. 

For entrees, everything was like $30-40. We should've ordered the chicken, but instead decided to order a bunch of smaller plates. We got the arugula salad, caesar salad, bowl of polenta, squid, and gnocchi. I think the best thing we ordered was the gnocchi...but it was only like 10 pieces. I guess given it was half the price of the entrees ($18), I should've known...but also $18 pasta at any other restaurant is usually a pretty sizable dish! 

Maybe I'll be back...maybe I won't...but either way, I wasn't wowed by my first experience, and there are a bazillion other places to try in the Bay Area!
author: Stephanie K.

description:
It's been over twenty years since my last visit.  The owner and founder Judy Rogers was still the chef, making a name for the restaurant and herself at this unassuming location.
She pioneered the brick oven movement for California cuisine in SF back in the 80's and three dishes were often mentioned with this restaurant:  Caesar's salad, roasted chicken, and burger.  My cousin picked this place for a recent weeknight dinner with my uncle.  Street parking is not too difficult on the other side of Market Street, but do remember to take or place all valuables with you or in the trunk respectively; you'll sometimes see shattered glass on the sidewalk as a not-so-subtle hint.  We were seated at an upstairs table overlooking the kitchen which was nice as there weren't too many tables to effect the noise level.
Here's what we shared after a short menu study:

Appetizers
1) Caesar's salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=xHN8_gPmC2UIHBHCyREx4g&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - One of the best in the City, up there in my books with Alfred's which no is no longer in business.  Not overly dressed and crispy fresh.

2) Burratta (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=NLJObChFJr63wQv63UKhXw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - A personification of California cuisine on a plate with the fresh greens, healthy light, and strong flavors in a simple presentation.

Entrees
3) Roasted chicken and bread salad (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=rGmTqXKTR3rMgb33xGNkBg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Their staple dish that should never be compared with Costco's roast chicken... this was as I remembered back in the day, tender and moist chicken pieces with amply dressed greens and their bread salad which reminds me of Thankgiving stuffing.  Just get past the price and you'll enjoy this dish.

4) Pork (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Sa85rXRh130oGpmOc1HHPw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Tender but some stringy pieces of pork.  Apologies for not remembering the dish name as I forgot to take a picture of the menu.  The vegetables, cauliflower and squash, were nicely seasoned and not overcooked.

Desserts
5) Strawberry shortcake (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=JXp7XsrVeAObIi1u104Umg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - With strawberries just coming into season, this was deliciously yet naturally sweet.  The pastry reminded me of a scone.

6) Ice cream sandwich (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=cazUUvSHcdxpFcUYqi5Qbg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - This was a interesting take as it was deliciously light yet the pastry reminded me more bread than dessert and the ice cream flavor wasn't overly sweet or rich.

Kudos to the restaurant in maintaining Judy Roger's vision in creating what would define California cuisine in San Francisco.  In other words, don't expect heavy sauces with hearty portions and rustic cooking styles.  Everything is done with a soft hand where you can better enjoy the original flavors of the ingredients whether it be vegetables, protein, or carbs. My uncle took home most of the pork dish home for later meal. 
The bar was packed with people enjoying their famed bloody Mary's and downing raw oysters.
Great spot for lunch or dinner.  Just don't expect something that will put you in a food coma.
author: Mike C.

description: Wow! This place does have service down to a fine art (and the level of a James Beard nomination). We had lunch here on our last day in San Francisco and couldn't have enjoyed it more. We sat upstairs which is lovely. Everything we had was excellent particularly the Caesar salad. We can't wait to go back when we have more time and can have the roast chicken. We were able to walk in on a weekday after the lunch rush, but even then it was quite busy. It is a large restaurant however and each of the seating areas is unique. This is fine dining with absolutely no attitude or pretention.
author: Brad M.

description:
A $54 brick oven roasted chicken should had taken my soul out of my body, shoot it up into the sky and back.  But it did not.  The chicken itself was good but not $54 worth.  There's a delicate charred flavor on the crispy chicken skin and the brine meat was smooth and almost silky... except it was slightly on the dry side.  Under the chicken was day old bread that soaked up the greasy chicken juice.  And on top was some mixed greens.  Did all this have flavor town?  Yes but then again, not for $54.  

What I did like was the scallop ceviche.  The scallops were thinly sliced horizontally and had slivers of avocado, fresh minced garlic, fresh peas, green onions, I think there were minced capers plus it was drizzled with a generous amount of pure olive oil.  Oh lord!  It was butter in my mouth.  The scallops with the avocado and olive oil made it taste so soft, so fluffy and so smooth.  It was sooo good.  This DID give me an out of body experience I've never had before.  AWESOME!    

The service was good, we practically let the waiter decide what we should eat.  I thought we had the best seats in the house, which was on the 2nd floor facing the oyster bar and cooking area.  The atmosphere is top notch.

NOTES:  It's stressful knowing that the chicken takes 1 freakin' hour to bake.  So, I wish they would accept our pre-orders over the phone!  We had a show to catch, so, time was very sensitive.  It's an expensive stressful feast.  BTW - day old cold chicken tastes better than fresh out of the brick oven chicken.   You can taste the brine chicken meat and greasiness better the next day.

** Good bye hard earned money... $130 bill comes with 1 chicken, 4 oysters, scallop ceviche, a glass of wine, cup of latte, waiters tip and restaurant healthy tax.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Order the Chicken, which takes an hour, then spit a Caesars salad, wagon wheel pizza(whatever the flavor is, it will be great), and throw in a few cosmos and you are in for a great meal, surrounded by mostly regulars from San Francisco , lively and fun, since you are squished like bugs next to each other.
We take most of the chicken home for chicken salad sandwiches, so it spreads the cost for two meals. Simply cut up all the goodies, put it back in the box in the microwave  to warm slightly, and mix a bit of mayo, fresh bread, amazingly fantastic the next day.
Great for a late lunch, open and airy, and even better if there is a parade down Market Street. Its been around for years, hats off to John Smith, the manager that's been taking care of us since we randomly ended up next to him a table years ago. Don't forget to peak in the kitchen, the two tables that face it are great fun for a first visit, sit side by side and watch the action.
author: Laura D.

description: What a great experience! Beautiful interior, amazing food, and top notch service. I would have rated 5 stars, if the young hostess wasn't a little bit snotty. Our bartender, waitress, and servers more than made up for that with their charm and their attentiveness to every detail. This restaurant is one of only a few good ones left. A breath of fresh air in an otherwise smelly city. We look forward to visiting again soon!
author: Bruce F.

description:
Ding 1 star for no brunch on Saturday and only on Sundays :/

My friend and I decided to give it a shot here for lunch since we were starving. We were surprised to see the hamburger's price but it was definitely delicious and cooked perfectly. Medium rare was the way to go. Unfortunately, it was also pretty small and I expected some big *** burger given the price. Perhaps I'll have to come back to try the brunch.
author: Cheri C.

description:
Favorite pre-show dining experience.  
As great as ever. Excellent service. Delightful dishes -- fresh oysters, sea bass with California Pinot noir
author: michael p.

description: Wonderful ceasar salad, lovely atmosphere! Not a casual place, just so you know, but the waitresses are super nice and chilled!
author: Irem E.

description: Haven't eaten at Zuni in several years but had dinner here with a friend tonight. We both ordered the softshell crab and the sword fish. Both items were very good. My martinis were well-crafted drinks but the olives were tiny with pits in them. I prefer larger, pitted olives but that's not a big issue. Like most San Francisco restaurants these days, portions are small and prices are large; however, Zuni remains an excellent choice in San Francisco. Our server, Jeff, was cordial and efficient; service was excellent.
author: IQuack D.

description: The James Beard Foundation Award for best service award is the nation is well deserved. We had Jeff, who was a class act - friendly, informative, professional. Best birthday dinner. Food, ambience, service - A+.
author: Dawn C.

description:
On my way home from work the other day I stopped by Zuni Cafe for a little R&R and anchovies. The main restaurant wasn't open yet because I was in between services but, the bar was open and I happily took a seat. I've dined at Zuni once before and experienced the amazing whole chicken, so I figured I'd see what the bar was all about. 

I was on bike so ordered pretty light (see picture) and had a glass of white wine. The anchovies were ok, nothing special. I would have figured that with a place with such high expectations and great food, that their canned fish would have matched. Oh well. The cheese and olives were just fine too, nothing special. I suppose it's tough to review a place just based on one starter so, I'm taking into account my prior visit which was definitely a 5 star experience. This time around, probably closer to 3. 

Moral of this story...come to Zuni for dinner and you'll have a great experience. Not a great spot for a quick in/out app and drink. Either way, mad respect to place that's been in business so long because it really is a great spot!
author: Benjamin F.

description:
Tried this place again, 10 years later.

$18 buys you:
two slices of dried out focaccia
one spongy patty of mysterious meat
one leaf of lettuce
one slice of pickle 
one teaspoon of "aioli"

By the time you add soggy, undercooked shoestring fries ($6), sliced tomato ($3, are you kidding me????) and a wee bit of cheese ($3), you've spent $30 on one of the worst burgers ever made.

This is outrageous.
author: Tatjana G.

description: I had been wanting to try Zuni for years since living in SF. Unfortunately I was a bit disappointed. Service was excellent. But food was dated and I was unimpressed. But I really wanted to love it!
author: L M.

description: Great food!!!! The location is super, s there are not many restaurants in the area that hold a candle to Zuni! The ambiance is lovely, modern, clean and open! The pomme frites are a must as their signature cocktails!
author: Sandra D.

description: Fav! Service is great. Their chicken and bread plate takes a good 40+ minutes so be sure to plan ahead if you have a show to catch. I love Zuni's fresh oysters too - so delicious!!!
author: Angellica Y.

description:
as I started researching places to eat this was the first place I found and knew we'd have to come here. I jumped and made a brunch reservation at the only time available on opentable of 11 am and couldn't wait. the burger was beyond delicious! this place is also just amazing looking inside. we passed by it a few nights earlier and I was even more excited to come here. plus we overheard our waitress talking about walking dead so yeah awesome staff :) 

I also loved the hot chocolate here! it was so good. I would say this was probably one of our favorite meals in San Fran and well worth the price. plus they didn't mind as we sat a little longer waiting for the rain to stop after brunch.  some people were dressed up but then some were more casual as we were. just such a nice place.
author: Crystal P.

description:
Nice space, good food, but not that good. We came here because of their famous chicken. I'm Portuguese so I'm pretty spoiled when comes to food and chicken. So I would say the chicken is pretty good but not $54 good or even 1h wait good. Yes, you will always need to wait 1 hour to get your chicken because of the way they cook it. 

Apart from the chicken there was honestly nothing that seemed that special or yummy in this place. Yes they have oysters. It also all super expensive. Wine... Expensive too. 

In summary, a forgettable place in my humble opinion. Go to a Peruvian rotisserie and you'll enjoy prob even more their chicken... For a portion of the price.
author: Nuno S.

description: Zuni Cafe is our go to spot for a relaxed dinner. The best thing here is the 1 hour chicken, we get it every time. The chicken comes with greens & bread underneath.... so good  The service here is attentive and helpful. We are always happy and full when we leave here.
author: Jolene J.

description: I went here during brunch time with my family. We ordered their famous roasted chicken before we took a look at the menu since the chicken took ~45 min to make. The waiter told us the chicken was pretty big so in order to avoid too much, we ordered a side French fries and Cesar salad to compliment the chicken dish. The french fries was pretty mediocre. I liked the Cesar salad--the lettuce was crispy and the dressing was not overly heavy. The chicken came faster than we expected but it was not as amazing as we thought would be. The meat was pretty dry and oily and the whole dish was kinda bland. I think our overall experience was pretty MEH. I am not sure if I will come back again.
author: Clare L.

description: Hostess was unprofessional & manager unfairly handled a situation. I'm not certain the chicken is worth the overall negative tone the staff set.
author: Amarita S.

description: It's just chicken.  Nothing very exciting.  The bread salad was really good, though.  We also tried their play on Mexican street corn, prepared in a cotija-spiked sauce.  I think the dish (one ear of corn cut into three pieces) was $13 dollars.  I grew up on a farm.  I could barely wait to get out of the restaurant to call my family to let them know they charge $13 for one ear of corn out here in the "big city". Ludicrous. Also ordered the caesar salad, which easily tasted like every other caesar salad I've had.  All the reviews and word-of-mouth recommendations fell flat, wouldn't come back.
author: Allie G.

description: This place has a beautiful atmosphere and more importantly excellent food. The game hen was fantastic, and the service was fast and easy.
author: John S.

description: Shared a wonderful evening with my daughter.  Food and service was impeccable!  Unhurried. We shared the house specialty which is roasted chicken. Pricy ! $58 but for two.  Delicious. Order it first because it takes about 45 minutes. Caesar salad was great.  Valet parking is $14 and much appreciated. Peach cobbler for dessert. The drip coffee was excellent.
author: Stephen H.

description: This is the second time I have been to Zuni and ordered the famous brick oven chicken and both times they failed. This last week was my guys birthday, and I had a reservation. Everything was great until the chicken. It was not even warm, it was room temperature, the bread underneath was so hard you could not cut it with the butter knife they provided. The greens, needed a little wilting. This is my second attempt here with the chicken. A 250.00 chicken dinner that was not really good. They are slipping. Our waiter Thomas was terrific, the food runner, seemed to not do his job and know what he was delivering. Cold food after an hours wait. I did not complain, as it was a special occasion for us and did not want to introduce that into the evening.
author: The Style R.

description:
I wouldn't call this a salad place...  The food is really good but small portions. 

We had the oysters to start, the bellwether farms ricotta gnocchi (they were like fluffy light clouds, and tasted amazing!!!) Pork chop (juice and flavorful) all food dishes had great taste and flavor to them. Highly recommend this place, definitely looking to come back and this time try the chicken for two.

Excellent service by all there staff.
author: Abby C.

description: Roast chicken might have been the best meal I've ever had. The hour wait was so worth it. The bread salad with it was divine!!!! We also enjoyed the shoestring fries while we waited. Must get the chicken!
author: Jennifer V.

description: We've been eating at Zuni Cafe since the 1980s, and its amazing how they've maintained a standard of excellence in food in food quality throughout that time.  The emphasis on locally sourced and organic ingredients was there long before it was trendy.  Appetizers are superb, the roasted chicken with bread salad is a favorite of ours, and friends want to go back just for the very entertaining shoestring potato appetizer.  Desserts are excellent and varied, as is the wine list.  It is a great place to stop in for a stand up drink at the bar; we stopped by recently on our way home from a symphony concert.  Service is friendly and gracious.  It is not a place for a quick meal, so don't plan to be in and out in an hour.
author: Doug G.

description:
This is a wonderful standby with consistently good food.  The staff works seamlessly together, and they work the best they can to accommodate.  We went on a day when their grill was inoperative, so we had to look to things we don't normally order.  That turned out to be a good exercise in variation.  The four of us finished our meals, so it must've been good!  

The Classic Bloody Mary is rich and fresh and bright.  

I forget sometimes that many people like a lot of dressing on their salad.  My Caesar Salad had too much dressing; ask for it light or on the side, or both.  And this is weird, but they offer no "Chicken Ceasar", huh.  The French Toast was luscious, and merited the label of "foodie-worthy".  The egg dishes were of equal quality and are now on our list of try-again choices.  If you have someone with you that has a less adventurous palate, they could order the Pizza with ricotta salata, tomato sauce, and oregano.  It was very unassuming.  We used it as a hunger-buster first course.

There is one glitch, though. If you want the Roast Whole Chicken (and I hear it's good!), you have to order it as soon as you sit down.  The menu says it can take up to an hour to deliver to your table, and you can't order it as you wait for your table, and certainly not by phone on your way there.  I think they should do so, even if you have to guarantee it by a credit card.  It would help them sell more chickens, and turn over their tables more quickly.  Just a thought.
author: James G.

description: I went there on a Saturday night with a party of 8.  Atmosphere is nice, service is fine, but the food is bad.  Most of us had the rock fish or the special swordfish.  Presentation was unappetizing, food was lukewarm, fish was overcooked, and portions were small, especially for the price.  After a few bites I stopped eating it and just decided to eat the bread instead.  I ordered a drink at the bar when I arrived, then at the table ordered the same drink again, and it was quite different in taste and color (I'm certain that it was the same drink, just different proportions of the ingredients, turning a slightly sweet drink into something quite tart).   I considered 2 stars, but in the end it has to be about the food, and based on my experience here, I would not go back.
author: John D.

description: Cocktails were excellent. Caesar had amazing croutons and good dressing. The most amazing dish was the chicken for two and the shoestring potatoes. Not sure if we waited a whole hour, because the cocktails were flowing, but definitely worth the wait. The portion was huge and the "bread salad," which we discovered underneath about 1/4 of the way in was like nothing we've ever had before. Scrumptious. BTW, we didn't have a reservation, but were immediately seated at a table at the bar. (9 pm on a Wednesday)
author: Kim F.

description:
The service is still good, but the food has passed its prime. The once amazing burger is now a dry choke-hazard, and the salads are simply forgettable. I can't even remember which we ordered. If you think big = better, the shoestring fries will impress your eyes, just don't eat them. Ugh. Over. After all of these years, and dozens of visits, we won't be back.

Also, beware of the mandatory 5% fee that they add on to all checks without explanation. Shady, shady, shady. If you are making your patrons pay your employees a living wage, then you shouldn't sneak it into the bill AFTER you have our credit card, and then have the nerve to ask us to TIP on top of the fees?!!!! 

ELIMINATE TIPPING altogether and adjust your prices accordingly. It's time to end this archaic system that forces good servers to BEG FOR TIPS and good customers to tip poor servers out of guilt. Just PAY YOUR EMPLOYEES A LIVING WAGE already. Period.
author: J D.

description:
This is a great restaurant to try out! The menu changes frequently which keeps things fresh and exciting. The caesar salad was great, it was simple yet delicious. The chicken for two is a must try and definitely worth the wait (typically takes one hour to make). The meat was very soft and juicy and the skin was gently crisp. For dessert I recommend the flourless chocolate cake, another thing the restaurant is known for other than their chicken. It's not thick and fudgy like other flourless cakes, instead it's light and fluffy!

Pro Tip: You can order the chicken right away when you seat so shave off some time. I was told that you could arrive early and place the order. That is NOT the case. You can only place an order when you are seated.
author: David T.

description: Came here with a friend who used to eat here regularly 15+ years ago. Friend noted that we would order the 'Chicken for 2'. While waiting we had some great cocktails (vodka infused red pepper vodka martini) and then had a really great meal. Should be 'Chicken for 4' since we had enough leftover chicken to eat for lunch the next two days.
author: J. Christopher E.

description: The best poulet rôti in the US, it worth à the hour waiting for it to be cooked just for you
author: Jacques H.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night. Our reservation was originally for 9:45 but we got there early (8:30) and they were able to get us seated by 9pm! *this usually works at most restaurants because there are last minute cancellations all the time

First off, the food was impeccable. Every dish, every morsel I had was better than the last. I came in to the evening telling myself to be "healthy" and order only 1 entree. Calamari, salad, entree, two desserts in, I definitely did not do that. 

Apparently the menu changes every service, but perhaps there are some things that always stay on the menu. The guy at the table next to us ordered a burger, which I did not see on the menu.

Appetizer: 
Calamari - this was good, a little too breaded for my liking, but good nonetheless. The sauce for the calamari was haphazardly thrown on to the side of the plate (normally it's in a separate small bowl), and there wasn't enough sauce because of it. 
Avocado and beets salad - very delicious and refreshing! So glad I chose this. The citrus vinaigrette perfectly balanced the avocado and beets.

Main: 
Sea Bass with Zucchini and Hazelnut - very good, ingredients complimented one another and was very, very filling!

Dessert:
Fig Cobbler (of some sort)- this was my favorite dessert. A delicious creme was poured over it, and the pats and peaches and other fruits went so well with the fig.
Chocolate mousse - delicious.
author: Jin C.

description: The atmosphere is very nice. But it certainly is not the place it once was with the original owner. The menu is boring. I didnt go to a place like this for pizza or hamburgers. I mean really? Certainly not the original chef. its nice thats all I can say.
author: Hardy S.

description:
Disappointed with my experience here--I had high expectations, especially with everyone extolling the virtues of the chicken! I chose this restaurant as my final SF restaurant to try before moving out of the Bay Area.

My sister and I ate lunch here and were seated on the 2nd floor. The ambience was great, since it was a sunny day. Service, though sparing due to high traffic, was nice as well. 

We ordered the chicken for two and sat out the hour-long wait with a plate of shoestring fries ($6), which were definitely more than enough to keep us satisfied while we chatted. Unfortunately, though, when the chicken came, we were surprised by how mundane it was. For $58, I expected a dish that would knock my socks off, and I was instead left confused about the place and the ratings. 

I was really excited to try this place and its signature dish, but perhaps I should have tried something else.

tl;dr - Unpopular opinion that the chicken is not worth the price and is quite ordinary.
author: Ada N.

description: Pretty overrated and overpriced. The atmosphere is nice and the service is great and all but the prices don't seem worth it. I guess it depends on how you assign value.
author: Amiya B.

description: The grass fed burger is everything you read about and more. Amazing flavor, simple and clean. Definitely get the shoestring fries with it.
author: Molly S.

description: This is a great place for a celebration, whether a dinner for two or a larger group! Keep in mind the chicken, their signature dish, takes 60 minutes to prepare so it may be too long for lunch, but it is worth the wait. The salad with garlic cardons was good. The white, corn and onion pizza was very flavorful as well.
author: Jennifer A.

description: This was my fourth time dining here, over a span of almost 30 years, and each time has been consistently great.  Their signature dishes, as you'll read in most of the other reviews, are the Caesar Salad and the Slow Cooked Chicken for Two (or 3)...both which are consistently yummy.  Last night we decided to try other dishes, and loved all of them.  First of all their cocktails are fabulous. We had the Gin Twilight which was deliciously spiced with ginger syrup, and then the Granada, which was bubbly with Prosecco, but also a nice balance of sweet and tart...but not too much so. Loved the Piccolo Fritto with Aioli, the Celery Root Soup, and the Fire Roasted Trout with Kale and Fava Beans.  And just as important, I have *always* found both the service and the ambiance to be perfect.  This San Francisco tradition proves to be gem worth returning to, again and again.
author: Greg K.

description: We visited Zuni last night but were disappointed in the less than 5 star food quality we normally expect. The chicken was a bit dry, chewy and burnt. It was also small, and may be why it was overcooked.  Not sure what happened because it's usually phenomenal. The appetizers we ordered were also disappointingly small and  average. There were just a few scattered cauliflower florets on a small plate for the price of an entree elsewhere. The arugula salad was just a handful of leaves with a few roasted almonds. They were hard to share to be honest. The meal came out to over $180 for 3 people. Very overpriced for what we ordered.  I think for the quality and value, I would think twice about coming again, especially since the food seemed to have slipped.
author: Apple M.

description:
I had not been to Zuni for several years, but some friends suggested that we go there for brunch before attending an concert at the SF Jazz Center (which is just a few blocks away).

The ambiance was elegant and inviting, the service was friendly and attentive, and the food I had (French toast with bourbon syrup) was good, and reasonably priced for a restaurant of this type.
author: Jethro B.

description:
Had a brunch reservation before a matinee at the Orpheum. It's a leisurely 15-20min stroll, perfect for the rare sunny day.

We arrived early and there was already a line of people waiting for opening, a testament to how great the food is. We were seated in the back, next to a firewood stove with an amusing view of people walking down Market, all dressed (or not :P) from Bay to Breakers.

Their sourdough bread is absolutely amazing. My parents had never tried polenta before so we shared one as a starter - they gave us each a plate and spoon. It's a good size for four people to taste and was very rich and creamy.

Each entree came with a vibrant arrangement of beautiful veggies. I had the grilled sea bass, super juicy with a fresh hit of lemon juice. We also had the pork sausage, tostada with pork, and skirt steak, everything was delicious.

My dad couldn't stop raving about how rich and fragrant their coffee is. The service was excellent, you can tell they take real pride in the food. We'll definitely be back to try the chicken.
author: Linda F.

description: Each time I visit San Fran I beeline to Zuni and I'm never ever disappointed. From the attentive wait staff to the incredible dishes, I never tire of it. It has spawned other restaurants from adventurous staff branching out on their own...but I still am attached to the mother ship. Zuni is like a wonderful pair of favorite slippers in front of a cozy fire.
author: Ruth F.

description: Awesome balsamic Bloody Mary, However the last time I went, the three of us didn't get a buzz so we are suspicious of whether or not there's any vodka in it.
author: Elpie K.

description: A review from a Washington post critique led us here. My co-workers and I really enjoyed this place.  We went on a Wednesday evening.  The ambiance was classy and light with a music from a pianist on a grand piano in the background. We decided to order two entrees of chicken (yes it does take about an hour or so) along with a melody of salads and various appetizers and drinks.  The food was delicious. I enjoyed my old fashion and the Manhattan (the picky side of me would say the Manhattan was a little thin in consistency but still pretty boozy). Crostini mushroom app was great. Their cheese gnocchi was so-so (think cheese curds). Salads had good flavor.  Their chicken served with bread salad was pretty amazing. One co-worker said it was probably the best he had; moist, flavorful and good combination with the bread salad frisse.  I would definitely come back here again as a splurge meal when I'm back in town.
author: Marc D.

description: I never would have thought of giving three stars to my beloved Zuni, but it's safe to say that they are a bit outdated. In execution and selections it's tiring, getting boring and repetitive. They do have a solid customer base that will come anyway, but it makes me think that they feel way too comfortable.
author: Danny B.

description:
Although I've been here several times over the years, somehow never did a Yelp review. My friend and I had lunch at Zuni Cafe last Saturday pre-ballet so time to make up for the lack.

We both ordered cocktails (Saucy Cranberry for her, Granada for me). A toast was a precarious undertaking as the glasses were full to the brim. We both enjoyed our cocktails.

We then shared a Caesar salad, very good, plenty for two. She got the burger, which she said was more than she could eat. I got the Wagon Wheel pizza. The pork on it was cured in some way, it had cooked greens (baby nettles) and cheese on very thin crust. I did eat the whole thing!

Desserts, she had the espresso granita with whipped cream - looked good although I don't like the taste of coffee. I had trouble deciding between grapefruit sorbet and caramel pot de creme. The waiter recommended the caramel, which was a little too sweet for my taste. A bit of salt to cut the sweetness would have been welcomed.

My friend and I have both made the Zuni Cafe chicken in our own homes but never had it in the restaurant; a 2 PM curtain time makes an hour wait, even with 11:30 reservation, too tight. We decided that next season instead of lunch before we'll come to Zuni for dinner after ballet and try the chicken in its native habitat.
author: Carol S.

description: Traveling on my own, Zuni cafe made me feel welcome. Many locals recommended me this spot.  5 stars for me . Everything was on point. Ambiance, drinks, apps, entree, and desert.
author: Matt T.

description:
got the famous chicken ($58). it was good roast chicken, flavorful skin, moist, tender, but it definitely didn't live up to the hype. i usually judge chicken by the chicken breast, because if even the chicken breast is moist and tender, the rest of the chicken will definitely taste even better. unfortunately,  zuni's chicken breast was not moist :/ i only enjoyed the thigh and leg but for $60 and reputation for "best roast chicken", i expected to enjoy the whole chicken. go get the $5 costco chicken instead.

i also got the ricotta gnocchi, that was pretty good gnocchi! super fluffy and light. it was like biting into a cloud! 

if i do go back, i'm definitely skipping the chicken.
author: Jessica C.

description: Been here twice.  Last year, the chicken was a 50-minute wait.  This year, 60-75 minute wait. The chicken IS very good, likely the best I've ever had.  We passed on it this year, primarily because seating wasn't comfortable at our window table.  No back support on a bench.  Cesar salad was excellent.  Pork chop was nothing exceptional- surprising since I was expecting something exceptional! Got very loud as restaurant filled up - couldn't hear or talk easily. Loved it last year. Not as much this year.  Hey that happens.  Still, very good service.
author: Ken A.

description: Everything is still great at Zuni, not sure about the deserts though.  Service was on point, food was great, wine list seems solid, but the only miss was the grapefruit goo desert. Started with some oysters and a cocktail, then had some wine and the Sea Bass. Our sever was great and timed everything perfectly.  We couldn't decide what to order for desert, the grapefruit tart was recommended. The crust was good but the custard part was astringent and had an odd texture. Going back soon, will probably skip desert.
author: Olivier K.

description:
Oh how I love Zuni. I love the gorgeous, light filled building. I love that it is both casual and elevated at the same time. It makes me feel a little bit fancy, but in an understated way. 

First thing you do: order the chicken with bread salad. It takes an hour. If you are going to the theatre, call ahead and order the chicken. My husband and I went recently and didn't have time for the chicken and while everything we had was lovely, the chicken is a show stopper. It is also a very hearty meal and I would call it generous to say it just for two people. I recommend ordering it for four so that you can taste other things while you wait. 

Ok, so the chicken order has been placed. Next, get a chilled glass of rose, oysters and the shoestring fries. Enjoy conversation with your friends and soak in the atmosphere. 

IF you go rogue and decide against the chicken [god help you], know that all other portions are on the daintier side. My husband and I went recently and ordered oysters, the Caesar salad, a pasta and a fish dish and were sad that we didn't have time to get dessert. We were going to see Hamilton so don't feel sorry for us, but we could have been more full. We sadly opted for peanut M&Ms at the theatre. Don't judge.
author: Molly S.

description: Zuni is solid place to grab a bite. Can be a very casual or an intimate setting. It's an SF classic.
author: Frank Z.

description: I haven't been here in a while, since the time I went with a friend for late-night oysters and a server or busser snatched the ice tray away from the table as I was still chewing. Our second course did not arrive for a while, so either someone had a bad sense of timing or they're just rude when it's near the end of the night. Our server was curt but usually they are friendly. We are heavily tattooed, and as such, feel that we were often treated kindly by servers but poorly by the door staff. This used to be a weekly excursion for us, even though you have to bring a sweater or hoodie to stay warm because they insist on leaving all the transom windows open even on cold nights.
author: L. M.

description:
I would have given five stars.  Meal (fish) was amazing and tasty. 

However, the server, Michele (with one "L") was less than enthusiastic...

Sort of going through the motions.  Made me realize that a server can add to the excitement of a dining experience.  

The bussers (and in particular, the small statured man cutting the bread nearby) were all very professional, busy and in tune with their guests.  Shout out to the guy diligently cutting the bread.  T
author: Susie S.

description:
Best Roast Chicken ever in my life!!!
It is served over bread salad, which is basically chopped up bread (cubes) drizzled with olive oil and dressing and chicken juice, so delicious!!!!

Even though it was the BEST chicken ever, its OVER PRICED!!!! Come on $60? It's chicken guys, you didn't raise them or anything liek that.

Ordered a few appetizers, all were okay but the star is that chicken. Ordered one to share between three ladies. 

Will definitely return when I'm a millionaire.
author: Bonnie P.

description: Yes like everyone confirmed, well brined roasted chicken and slowed cooked to have a lot of moisture in its meat. Fresh oysters to try. Excellent staff service and vibe of restaurant. Yummy Caesar salad. Good cocktails
author: Lilian L.

description: everyone was raving about that chicken! so many raves but really at the end of the day its still just chicken, i bought into all these raves, my bad. 60 minutes for a chicken that basically costs $1 per makes you assume its gonna be some amazing chicken. it was not, it was good, maybe very good but if i had another chance wouldn't pay more than $24 for it. someone pulled the chicken feathers over my eyes. maybe once, never twice. aside from the chicken robbery of SF the onion rings were also bland and over cooked and the salad was mediocre. the service i will say was amazing, thankfully for that, i will miss them!
author: Erni V.

description: Stop reading the menu and get the chicken. It's unreal! I don't know how they do it. It does even taste like there is seasoning on it it's freaking delicious!! Also the bread on the chicken was a nice surprise.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Top 5 of my worst dining experiences ever.  Arrived at 6:07pm for a 6:30pm reservation so we could get to an 8pm show at the Orpheum (yes, 1st world problems, I know...)
Got seated within 15 minutes.  Ordered promptly.  After much "discussion" with our waiter about needing to leave at 7:40pm sharp, the food finally came out at 7:30pm and no we didn't order the chicken (which requires an hour).  Nothing like having to wolf down a $200 dinner in 10 minutes.  The waiter was polite and professional throughout the entire dinner.  Overall though, this was a very disappointing dining experience.  Manager was non-existent and made no effort to improve our experience.
author: Derek J.

description:
Why did we give this place 3 stars ... 

Minus 1 for service and minus 1 for the noise level ( you have to shout over everyone around you to actually have a conversation, while remembering everyone else is talking pretty loudly since they can't hear themselves either) 

The food here is pretty darn good :-) 

Bread - yum!!

Shoe string fries - totally yum and shareable 

Linguine and clams - really good I wish the portion was a little bigger but eating it with the bread they served was ok.

Ricotta gnocchi - small portion but perfect for someone who wants to eat light.

Good strong drinks too!

Try this place out if you are in the area.
author: Darren F.

description:
Lovey happening ambiance on a Wednesday evening on the first floor. Great service. Attentive but not hovering. The bread is good (but not nearly as good as Josey Baker Bread or Frances or Tartine). 

What is great is the chicken and bread--so simple but the ingredients really do shine. I am usually a bit wary of simple food (Chez Panisse is a bit minimalist for me) but this was truly excellent. A good portion but not too heavy. The bread salad really is special. You know his is a star dish if Ottolenghi raved about it and tried to replicate it!

While we waited, we had the anchovies which were nice and different but wouldn't get again because a small portion and a bit on the simple side--but overall good. The Caesar salad was worth getting as it's a dressing that really coated the leaves wonderfully and the combination was more than the sum of its parts. 

We didn't have room for dessert as the two us already had some chicken to take home.

Overall, a great place for an evening out.
author: Madeline S.

description: Quite possibly some of the best (and most pricey) chicken we've ever had. They say to never spend $35+ on a chicken entree out a restaurant--Zuni is the exception. Super crowded on a Saturday night so make resos! We got lucky and got an awesome seat on the balcony overlooking the restaurant. Cool artwork on the walls. Would absolutely return here.
author: Aileen N.

description:
I have been meaning to try Zuni again. Haven't been here in 20 years.  The menu didn't look too inspiring but we decided to try anyway give my the rave reviews. 

We had a great experience and will probably be back.  My hubby shared four courses starting with the prosciutto appetizer.  The tapenade on the side was delicious.  Then it was the root soup and ceasar salad.  The root soup was made with chicken stock, surprisingly delicious and not heavy.  We loved it.  Ceasar was just ok.  Surprisingly overdressed for a nice restaurant. 

Main course we ordered was the lamb mixed grill with sausage.   I thought I would just be okay but it was deliciously tender.  Mix of flavor with Brussel sprouts sweat potato, turnip was perfect. Highly recommend.  I asked for lamb medium as I don't like my meat bloody and it came out just right

Last course - ginger honey granites with butter cookies.  Perfect cleanser finish not too sweet and very refreshing.  

Best of all our server Jeremiah was super helpful throughout the meal with recommendations up front and adjusting the cooking instruction of our lamb. 

We had a very nice evening as a result. :-)
author: Lei H.

description: This place lived up to its reputation. Delicious food and wine in a cozy atmosphere.  My burger was a great surprise, cooked perfectly and so yummy I ate every bite.  Another nice surprise about this place was the wait staff.  For a very busy well known place in the city, the staff were surprisingly warm and kind and unhurried.  One of our group described his dish as "interesting" so it wasn't a totally perfect experience but the bartender made up for it by topping off our wine glasses with a fabulous Pinot before we left the bar :).  Look forward to going back and trying the famous chicken!
author: Kay N.

description: Great atmosphere, very friendly staff and excellent food. The roast chicken is amazing, and well worth the 60 minute wait. Salads were excellent and the bread was fantastic! I had a fettuccini dish with Brussels sprouts and lemon zest, which was good but not great.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Fantastic dining experience! The ambiance is great in the light filled dining area with piano playing in background- I like the old school feel. Service was top notch as well. 

Now to the most important- the food. The Caesar and arugula salads were both fantastic- the Caesar was a solid portion. The gnocchi appetizer was unreal, rich and had the light and fluffy texture of scrambled eggs. The shoestring fries were also very good. I had to order this since it looked and smelled so good when I saw someone else order it at the bar. And finally the sea bass o the menu was fantastic. It was seared lightly to trap moisture and perfectly cooked and seasoned with butter and salt. Really tasty. 

I cannot believe it took me this long to go to Zuni but this is one of my new favorites!
author: Derek S.

description: ZUNI is the perfect local San Francisco cafe' with world class cuisine. We had an early dinner of oysters and their Famous brick oven roasted chicken for two. Our oysters were an assortment of 20 favorites with the most perfectly dressed Ceasar salad I have ever had. Then came the roasted chicken, oh-my-gawd ...... is all we could say, it was a consensus of four adults that this whole roasted chicken was the finest any of us had the privilege of tasting......ever. That is quite a statement but not too surprising seen as this is a winner of the prestigious James Beard Award. Coffee and desert was amazing as well as TOP NOTCH service from the fine staff of professionals. This place is not to be missed. Thank you Thank you Thank you !
author: MMA E.

description:
I mean... It's good food. Don't get me wrong. But the hype does not live up to the reality.

We ordered the anchovies, chicken, and the panna cotta dessert. First of all, is it impossible to roast a chicken in under 70 minutes? It is if you want a dry chicken. With no sauce. I have had better chicken elsewhere. Like, Limon for instance. And the panna cotta was supposed to have Myer lemon, but I could barely taste any lemon at all.

The saving grace for this meal was the anchovies. Some interesting and daring paring going on... And who would have thought celery could taste so good? But if you don't want to get charged $3 for the tonic in your gin and tonic (it was well gin, too) you can find plenty of other dining options who just do this whole "food and beverage" thing better.
author: Andy A.

description:
Great casual fine dining spot,
The chef owner was trained at chez panisse (Alicia Waters)  and follow the path of unpretentious cooking with the freshest quality ingredients.

Ambiance and wooden themed decor are very laid back, with a long bar and open kitchen on the ground floor and a multi leveled mezzanine and feels very fresh. 

I would describe the cuisine modern american with mediterranean influences Their out of this world whole chicken is roasted to order from scratch in the wood oven located right in the center of the dining room.

Service is efficient and courteous, with knowledgeable waitstaff. Wine list pricing is reasonable as well as coktails and their long bar is attended by engaging bartenders. 

If in San Francisco, this is definitely a place to visit.
author: Jacques R.

description: Service was excellent.  Ambience was great. The food was delicious. The burger was so buttery and good.  As for the avocado toast.. prob the best avocado toast I've ever had.  Food was fresh and had great presentation.
author: Bernadette P.

description: Was sad about our experience tonight. I've been coming here for 17yrs..the quality has really declined. Ricotta gnocchi tasted like egg whites with salty butter (no flavor of mushroom or sage) and the beef bourgogne was fatty and biting with uncooked leeks. Blah. Wine and bread were excellent.
author: Erika G.

description: Zuni Cafe is the place to be even though my party didnt fully arrive on time we were greeted by the greatest hostess, Lorena was very friendly and inviting. After seating us she told us that our waiter would be with us shortly after. The food was on point but I was in the best mood after our beloved hostess seated us.
author: Abner S.

description:
Wow, is all I can say, especially when it come to the bill ouch. Altho this place is certainly pricey the food makes up for it. I had the polenta and tried samplings of everyone elses dishes. The chicken by far was my favorite and really superb, the homemade smoked stuffing was a perfect flavor twist.
I dont know if its 55$ great but it was definetly one of the best tasting chicken dunners ive ever had. 
The chicken tenders over at the Tipsy pig are to die for, just as tasty and a lot cheaper.

The deserts were all top shelf and had no problems making them all disappear.
Our service was prompt, helpful and professional.
The place was clean and rather upscale as far as the ambience and clientel. We were not and were carefully placed away from the windows lol.
If you want to impress someone this place will do that for you.
author: Drew F.

description: Favorite meal in San Francisco hands down. The food was fresh and delicious, the wine list is amazing, and service was excellent. Will definitely be back!
author: Dylan H.

description: Salt Salt Salt!  That's the only thing we tasted in our food.   This place is uber overrated.  Everything was below average and I am not even sure why this place is even popular. The only part of the meal we liked was the bread and butter.   Our waiter was nice too but it doesn't compensate for the mediocre food.
author: Seth T.

description: Sadly disappointed, the food had no deep flavor nor pop esp on pasta with clams sadly meh.
author: Stephen B.

description: What happened here? Zuni has always been a regular go-to for fun group lunches and dinners with friends. Very disappointed last time we were here. After working hard all week, we all look forward to our weekend get-togethers with laughter, good food, and flowing wine. We were met with oddly grim service which needless to say, put a big damper on the birthday we were celebrating. For the price, the way we were treated, and the food not knocking our socks off, it made for a less than enjoyable experience. Also, word to the wise, if your policy is to charge for a surprise sliver of cake with a candle it, just say so and do it. Don't ruin the occasion and the surprise by ignoring the request and making a big deal out of Zuni not giving away birthday desserts. Btw we never asked or expected it be thrown in. We're there to enjoy a celebration and have already payed hundreds of dollars in wine and food, we'll be ok with the added 12 bucks.
author: Eliza M.

description:
Service was impeccable, ambiance on point, the restaurant itself is beautiful. This is classic simple dining done well, it is not a new fusion restaurant or play on unique flavors it is a combination of Cali cuisine mixed with traditional French & Italian flavors and techniques, diners should keep this in mind. Yes it is just roast chicken so if you expect something more go elsewhere. This was a great date dining experience with my bae. The bread salad and chicken was good, personally I am a saucy person so I would have liked a little more sauce to the bread salad but nonetheless it was great. We also did the appetizer that night which was fried oranges, I believe, they were amazing! I would go back just for these.

Pre diner was craving a bloody mary with was not very good by the bartender (no olives or garnishes whatsoever), note to self stick with wine next time.
author: Morgan S.

description:
Oysters and martinis + Cesar salad = perfect lunch on a sunny day. The chicken is legendary. Don't pass on the bread - it's the best in town. 

This restaurant is a SF classic, better than any of the hot new spots. Eat here.
author: maple leaf d.

description:
I haven't done a review in years and I haven't been to Zumi Cafe in years but I won't be back. The famous Caesar salad had too many wilted outside leaves( but the croutons were great.) The $20 cheeseburger was almost inedible. A rubbery texture and no taste. The  focaccia bun was dry. The $32 Salmon on the lunch menu was okay but $32 for lunch! The price isn't shown on the menu so unless you ask you get a surprise when the bill comes. We had to move tables as we were originally seated 2 feet away from a noisy 4 top.
Service was indifferent. 3 entrees, two salads, 4 drinks , fries and 1 dessert $240 at lunch for 3 people. So many, many better places to go in SF.  Also parking is impossible.
author: Bob G.

description: when I tell you that their roasted chicken + bread salad continue to be one of the most amazing dishes EVER, I'm not exaggerating. Yes, it takes an hour. Yes, you're thinking "it's chicken. how hard can it be to do chicken?" Trust me, whatever they're doing to this dish before it hits the table - is truly the kind of stuff that could end wars and mend diplomatic fences.
author: Nick S.

description: We are glad we experienced this restaurant. However, The menu is so limited. We enjoyed the food but felt it was too pricey for what it was. A roasted chicken for two (seemed like a whole chicken and was comparable to a Costco roasted chicken at $5.99) should Not cost $60 and for it to take 1 hour is just silly. Restaurant is nice and quaint but tables are very close to each other. We liked our server a lot but it was challenging to have our water glasses filled. ...Always a measure of good service. Also they forgot our tea with dessert. Glad we tried it but no desire to return.
author: R. C.

description:
Straight outta 1979 (which was really not the best year for decor -- I know, I was alive then.)

I'm a native San Franciscan, but have to say that I never did understand what was so wonderul about  the Zuni. I hadn't been there in a number of years, when a friend who lives in the East Bay and loves it suggested going -- maybe six years ago.

Female bar tender was more than full of herself and attitude and she wasn't even busy yet. (I'm friendly, always come in with a smile and "how are you this evening?" )

Ordered dinner, my friend had their "signature" chicken.  SWEAR TO GOD -- a cockroach ran out from underneath a piece of lettuce.  I am not a woman who "freaks" about insects, mice, etc...but let's just say it was a LITTLE distressing for a restaurant that charges so much and is lauded so lavishly by critics. We signalled to the waiter that we needed his attention, and quietly and discreetly pointed out the problem. He was very nice -- but seemed rather remarkably unconcerned. I had a feeling he'd have been more concerned if the salad have been served without dressing. 

 Brought us a new plates (ours hadn't been touched). I understand there are people who try to "work it" in restaurants to get free things.  I have never -- and would never do that.  \

But -- am I wrong in thinking that a cockroach is pretty beyond disgusting?  
 We assumed that the meal would be compe ( we could have yelled "OH MY GOD! A COCKROACH JUST RAN OUT OF OUR SALAD!" at the top of our lungs, disrupted the entire restuarant, and ruined their reputation amongst all those diners).  

Know what the waiter did?  He comped our dessert.  

Our. Dessert.   

Have never been back.  Will never go back.
author: L M.

description: Great cafe. Seating is limited. They don't take reservations so show up early. The food is delicious. Great service.
author: Manjula V.

description:
Best chicken in my entire life!!!!! I have never, to my recollection, raved about chicken, until now. This place had the most naturally flavorful, juiciest yet perfectly cooked, with the most succulent skin to surround it, chicken that my wife or I have ever had, period! The bread salad and greens were perfect with it and left us breath taken:)
Amazing selection of and absolutely the freshest and most perfect pure range of six different pacific oysters. I had them sans anything and was so glad I did!!!
Sancerre recommended by our excellent waiter was perfect with our oysters and ceased salad starter (oh and who would have thought they there could have been an amazing interpretation of ceaser salad that leaves you raving about it as a unique starter as well. 
Unbelievable - deserts didn't disappoint - panna cotta was incredible!
author: John B.

description: So classic- just went again to celebrate my birthday. Love the oysters, burrata salad & of course their roasted chicken
author: Marissa B.

description:
Last meal in San Francisco: Zuni Cafe.

No, I'm not dying! Simply moving out of the Bay Area and becoming more of a grown-up. 

Sure, Denver has plenty of fine dining establishments, especially when it comes to American (new) and comfort food. But there's nothing to compare to Zuni, a San Francisco classic for 20+ years. 

Gnocchi, chicken for two, shoestring potatoes and a Caesar salad. That and a bottle of Santa Barbara Pinot Noir. Can't get much more California than that, can we?

Make a reservation and gorge yourself! It's worth the calories and the price.
author: Abby S.

description: The place has a stand up bar and only things I've tried are the drinks and some appetizers including their famous thin french fries. The menu unfortunately is too "chi chi" meaning I'm not into these high end types of meals and want more down home foods. Maybe I'll revisit again in the future to see if anything jumps out at me on the menu.
author: N A.

description:
So for starters a very fair warning: the roast chicken takes an hour for them to make. I would have really liked to know that beforehand. 

Um yeah so that chicken is stupidly too good. Oh my god its just chicken but somehow one of the best things I have ever eaten? Honestly I only thought roast chicken could be so good and when I saw the price and the wait I was not into the idea of getting it. My brother really pushed for us to order it, and it was completely worth (in my humble opinion). At least once in your lifetime you should have this chicken like god it was pretty darn good.

Second tip: the chicken is really good as a composed bite with the greens, bead, and whatever sauce is in there as well. We made the mistake of eating all the chicken and not really noticing the rest of the stuff on the plate. There's a lot of other stuff there too and its really tasty. 

We had the frisée salad. Im super into the whole roasted lemon vinaigrette thing so i liked it a lot. Had mushroom soup as well and it was good.

But while the food was good, my absolute favorite thing about this restaurant was the zero judgement. My brother and I ate there. We werent dressed nearly as nice and were much younger but were still treated pretty much as everyone else there was. Like the service was so good and the staff was very nice. You know an experience where you walk in expecting to be not taken seriously or treated differently but are actually treated well is so rare. It was pricier than expected but overall very happy with the experience.
author: Megan L.

description:
The atmosphere was very nice and the service was great. I just wasn't that impressed with the menu options. We ended up getting a dozen oysters and they were very good. I don't remember what salad we chose but it was okay.

Out drinks were terrible. It was basically pink lemon juice, not lemonade, straight up super sour lemon juice.

I may have thought differently if I got the recommended chicken for two.

Not a bad place but compared to everywhere else we went in San Fransisco "meh" is a good description.
author: Kari M.

description:
Cool restaurant to grab a afternoon snack while in the city.
Late afternoon seemed to be a good time to wonder in since there was no wait and we scored a corner table perfect for people watching.

The prosciutto and soft taleggio toast were so good and addicting that I made a note to make them at home.  Also had a pizza of the day with nettle.  I think it could've used a bit more flavor but at least the crust was good.
author: Angel W.

description:
Star 1: You can eat outside under the yellow umbrella, with your pet and watch Market street bustle. They'll even bring a bowl of water for your pooch.

Star 2: The most amazing selection of oysters I have ever sampled! I highly recommend that you order a few from the menu. Get a sample platter. You'll appreciate the Bay area's fruits de mer even more. 

Star 3: La Vie en Rose is delectable. That's their signature champagne cocktail. It's perfect for a Sunday meeting with friends. Refreshing and effervescent with a hint of fruit. Ching ching! 

Star 4: The service is spot on time when needed. Spirited, friendly and just plain marvelous. 

This is a wonderful location to meet friends on a sunny day. The location is perfect - you could head South on Valencia into the Mission. Or venture North towards Hayes Valley. Either way your day will be off to a good start if you begin at Zuni Café.
author: Jaylena P.

description:
Classy restaurant in an easy to find location. The restaurants has street side parking a block away(don't leave anything of value in plan view) the restaurant has valet parking too. 

The entire staff treats everyone with respect not snobby like some high end restaurants.
