I had the spaghetti Neri with bay Manila claims and sesame seeds. The sesame seeds made the claims taste very good. The noodles use squid ink for the dark coloring. It may sound odd but it actually taste very good.  Deserts are good too, I can't remember the names at this time.

Inside of the place is nice, the owners did a good job designing the two floor layout.

If your on foot not too far uber , square hq located 1455 market street. Uber and lyft is recommend option to use if you don't want to drive. Easy to pick up and drop off.
author: P D.

description: I really really wanted to like this place, but I just couldn't deal with the pretentious vibe. We put our names at the front and we were told to wait and look for our own table. It got sooo awkward when the staff told us, and others, "first come first serve". We found ourselves fighting for any open table. Once seated, I saw what looked like a cook use the restroom with his apron on. Upon exiting, he wiped his hands off on the apron and continued to work. I really hope he washed his hands. Servers were really nice though. We decided to only order a drink, an appetizer, and eat else where.
author: Cornelius V.

description: Zuni has good food, but even for SF their prices are outrageous. Stopped in for lunch and wanted a burger,  it was $20, fries not included. Oh btw, neither are cheese, onions, or any other topping. If you dress your berger and get fries be prepared to spend minimum $30. The chicken for two takes an hour to make and costs $65. I think I could walk home and make it faster for less. Oddly enough my lamb sausage dinner plate was cheaper. And while certainly good it was slim pickings that left me less than satisfied.   Zuni thinks it's fine dining, but it's just a basic restaurant with high prices. I will however give them credit for a good service staff.
author: Eric M.

description:
We came to Zuni for our reservation about 15 minutes early and were told they would get our table ready. They directed us to the bar for a drink while we wait. I got a glass of rosé and my friend got a riesling, which rang up around $24. Before we could close our tab, the table was ready and we were directed towards the back of the first floor. The ambiance is light and simple, very upscale for a lunch atmosphere, but we were in the neighborhood and couldn't pass it up with its rave reviews. 

We ordered some small plates while we waited for our famous chicken to be freshly roasted. My friend was set on indulging in the shoestring fries, but we wanted a salad option to balance that out. Per the strong recommendation of our waiter, we got the caesar salad. It's one of those things that I love but am skeptical to get all the time because a lot of the time it's bad. Just plain bad. But our waiter went into detail about the housemade caesar dressing, and we were completely sold. 

When the salad came out, it was split into two portions on separate plates for us to share. I love when restaurants do that small step that is so thoughtful. The dressing went above and beyond our expectation. It's the not the thick, creamy dressing you're used to seeing. It was a light and bright dressing with the perfect balance of umami and citrus flavors. Perhaps our favorite part of the meal.

Our shoestring fries came out for us to munch on after the salad, and embarrassingly, we ate the ENTIRE heaping pile of fries in the 60 minutes the chicken took to roast. Went along nicely with my next rosé, ha. 

Finally when our brick oven roasted chicken arrived, it was totally worth the wait. You could tell just by looking at it that it was properly juicy. The bird arrived cut into pieces and we knew we weren't going to be able to finish it after our potato-coma. The sweet currants were the perfect touch to the savory brined chicken. We ended up eating about a third of it and got the rest to go, which made for very delicious leftovers after some (also leftover) garlic pasta. 

While pricey for a lunch, it was a great splurge meal while in town. They take classic dishes and elevate them with simple ingredients and proper technique.
author: Victoria L.

description: We were excited to try brunch here because we've heard such good things. Got there around 12:30p on a Sunday. We were immediately sat which was nice. Food was tasty. But service was ridiculously slow and the food took forever. They never cleared our table when people were done with their plates. Given the prices, we'll probably go elsewhere for brunch.
author: Loralyn S.

description: Never disappoints! Service, food and ambiance are spot on. Only thing I didn't care for was the frizzy mustard greens with the chicken - tasted too much like grass.
author: Rolf C B.

description: The hostess and manager are roasted chicken nazis who do not treat people with dignity or humanity.  The best part of my meal was donating it to a homeless person!
author: Christine P.

description:
meh. 
Food took longer than expected even though we specified we were in a rush. My grapefruit, frisée and hazelnut salad was meh.
Service was good.
author: Julia S.

description:
My boyfriend and I came here last week for pre-Opera dinner (sometimes we're fancy) after walking by for the past year and always noticing how busy Zuni is. We had a bit of hassle making a reservation since you can only book a table 1 month in advance which appears to be a necessity no matter which night you go if you plan on eating during prime hours. The earliest reservation was 6pm (even though they are open earlier) which, for a 7:30pm show, is kind of tight, but we wanted to try this place badly. I knew from Yelp and 7x7 that we needed to order the famous Chicken for 2. Unfortunately, this takes an hour to cook which would have made it impossible to fit in with our timing constraints. When they called to confirm, I asked if I could put in an order for the chicken so it was ready by 6:15, fully prepared to prepay for dinner so it would be ready. While I thought this was a reasonable request, they refused but said that we could come in at 5:30pm or so and we would get seated. I worked from home and my boyfriend left work early all for this friggin' chicken.

And was it worth the hassle and $58? Meh. Was it the juiciest chicken I have had? Sure. Was the bread salad delicious? Yes. Were my socks knocked off? Definitely not. The beauty of the chicken is its simplicity but that is also its downfall. I really see the similarity other reviewers have pointed out to your basic rotisserie chicken. Is Zuni's better? Yes but not for 3-4x the price. I also had a nice glass of Pinot Noir (recommended to pair by the waiter) and my boyfriend had a cocktail which he seemed to like. That being said, with tax and tip added, we paid $110 for 2 people for 2 drinks and a bigger entree. This price isn't TOO bad for a nice restaurant but for a simple roasted chicken and 2 drinks, it just simply isn't worth it.

The service was definitely fitting of a place at this price point and the atmosphere was really quite nice, especially with the live music later in our meal. However, this was disrupted by the anti-trump protesters walking down Market Street during dinner. With a place with huge windows like Zuni, we were able to get dinner and a show :)
author: Carrie W.

description: One of my all time favorite places to dine in the Civic Center area, though usually for special occasions since it isn't easy on the pocketbook. Ate here with friends last in March, had the arugula salad (with Manchego cheese, paprika almond, citrus vinaigrette), Zuni Caesar salad, Llano Seco Ranch porchetta (seasoned with rosemary, garlic, lemon zest, Tuscan kale, black trumpet mushroom, buckwheat polenta, ricotta salata), and roasted chicken (in wood fired brick oven with rugosa squash, wild rice pilaf, miners lettuce, maple vinegar sauce). All so delicious!
author: Andrew L.

description: Terrible service. Chicken was undercooked. Instead of issuing me a refund for the $55 dollar chicken I didn't eat the waiter comes back and says how about we take 50 percent off the entre. Who the fuck does that ? They undercooked the entre I didn't eat it and they insisted I still pay 50 percent off it.
author: Gabriel J.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and have been here a few times for both dinner and brunch. I've ordered all the signature dishes (chicken & bread salad, burger, shoestring fries, etc) and then some, but most dishes do not blow me away. However, the space is beautiful with its floor-to-ceiling windows and their drink menu is extensive. 

My most recent dinner at Zuni is likely my last at this establishment. My husband and I ordered the caesar salad, arugula salad, farrotto, skirt steak and the chocolate gateau (two starters, two entrees and a dessert + drinks). Nearly everything was tasty but service was the worst I've experienced in recent memory anywhere. 

First, the food:
- Arugula salad - Light and refreshing, serving size for one. Recommend.
- Caesar salad - This is huge and should be shared (wish our server told us this!). The dressing tastes classically caesar, but could use a bit more anchovy and more pepper. Good amount of croutons and parm.
- Farrotto - Delicious. Light and very flavorful.
- Skirt steak - The horseradish sauce was underwhelming with no kick, but everything else was as expected (the steak cooked to requested temp, potatoes and broccoli rabe). An average meat and potatoes dish.
- Chocolate gateau - OMG, heavenly flourless chocolate cake topped with whipped cream.

Service:
- Our server was Jeremiah. At first, I didn't notice anything odd about him but it became clear throughout our meal that he was warm and chatty with everyone else but us. He barely made eye contact with us, barely said anything (he muttered indecipherably when he did bother to speak) and his behavior overall was very obviously colder towards us compared to all other tables. I have no idea why he was drastically different with us but it was completely unwarranted. We're repeat customers, were dressed appropriately for the setting, were excited to be dining again at Zuni and ordered a proper full meal. Jeremiah, oddly, made sure to tell another table that they could read about him on Yelp so he clearly looks himself up here. 

In case he's reading, I deliberately left him a paltry 15% tip because he deserved no more. I should've left 10% but since he looks rather old and is still waiting tables, I'll assume he needs the money. I happily leave 20-25% for good service, 30% for great. Jeremiah provided garbage service and I really don't care if I came off looking cheap (I retired at 34, and live and own real estate in SF; I'm doing alright). Screw that guy.

It is worth mentioning that all the patrons at the other tables Jeremiah was serving were white, and he himself is white while my husband and I are not. Jeremiah's obvious lack of customer service towards us may have been for any number of reasons that I'll never know. But what I need to point out is that his behavior sure felt overtly racist, regardless of whatever his personal beliefs actually are about race. This is especially disappointing considering how diverse and accepting SF is in general; I have never actually been treated this poorly in my decade of living here.
author: Jen P.

description:
3.5 stars
This restaurant is much bigger than it looks on the outside.  Definitely, make a rezi.  We were seated at exactly the time of our's and not one minute before, even though the table they sat us in was empty.  
Our server, Michelle, was lovely and attentive.  Our food was good, but a little lackluster.  I loved my polenta and parmigiana cheese appetizer.  I'm a vegetarian and they kindly made me a plate of vegetables for $20.  If I stacked all of the vegetables together, it would have been about one and one half cups of veggies.  It was just okay.  The hubs liked his sea bass.  
For the price, I expected the food to be a bit better.  
Valet parking is $14, but you can find a spot if you drive around a bit.
author: Cassie P.

description:
We arrived at 8 on a Saturday night and were seated without reservation after only 15 minutes. Restaurant is dressy casual, most people dress on the nicer side. Noticed this mainly because I was wearing yoga pants and athletic jacket. My companion and I were seated upstairs in a little crook next to a window overlooking the street, really cozy and a great seat to have an intimate dinner if you can manage it. 

We ordered two Caesar salads, some fried squid and the espresso dessert. We wanted to try the roasted chicken but unfortunately that takes 75 min to make and we didn't have the time. But we saw the dish pass by our table several times and it looks incredible-- will need to go back to try it soon. 

It's true what they say, the Caesar salad is real good. Large enough portion to where you could eat it as a light meal.
author: Hideko T.

description: Pretty good food. Ok service. Little pricey, but totally ok as long as food is tasty.  3 to 4 stars would be a fair grade for this restaurant.  Though parking is a nightmare around there.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Came here with a friend because we were craving oysters. The first thing I loved about this place was their location. It's located on the corner or Rose and Market, literally a corner shaped building with large windows and a very rustic interior.
We had a reso for 2pm, but my friend was running 45 mins late so I was seated and ordered a drink.
After my friend arrived, we ended up ordering 24 oysters (my favourite was the Miyagi), Caesar salad, duck (don't remember the name), and champagne. 
The oysters were delicious and very fresh! They showcase their oysters in this cute oyster bar when you walk further into the restaurant.
Overall, the food came out quickly and was good. I wouldn't order the duck again, but will come back for oysters!
The only complaint I have is their service. The servers were at times attentive, but would forget about filling our water glasses.
author: Samantha Y.

description:
Atmosphere: Very dirty and dusty. An unusual amount of particles of dust floating around landed in our food (probably because they don't clean the high to reach floor to ceiling windows). My black jeans are currently COVERED in dust from their seats.

Food: VERY lackluster and flavorless. Perhaps the kitchen does not own salt. Polenta with Parmesan, a dish filled with butter and cheese, was entirely flavorless. The tower of shoe string fries also lacked  flavor and were served cold. Burger was small. Baked eggs were burnt on the bottom.

Service: Inconsistent. Our table wasn't offered ground pepper to top our food, but the table next to us was. It was difficult to flag down the waiter for water refills.

Price: EXTREMELY OVERPRICED!!! Do not waste your money. Seriously. Just don't.
author: L W.

description:
Zuni Cafe has my vote for....

THE most overpriced, overhyped AND overrated restaurant in SF!

Seriously, I don't understand why Zuni's Cafe is always packed (tourists?) just like I don't understand why GQ awarded Kim K.:  "Woman of the Year". Don't get me wrong, I think Kim is absolutely g-o-r-g-e-o-u-s with bodlicious T&As that I would kill for. But I'm not sure what she has contributed to society other than her naked aerobics video and incessantly taking of vain, shameless selfies? *shrugs*

Zuni Cafe's claim to fame is their $48 roast chicken which is technically $65 after tax, sf health tax and tip.

Yes. $65. For. A. Chicken. http://bit.ly/1qJ6QHl

Five years ago, when I first tried this glorified roast chicken, I wasn't impressed. This time around, it was worse. Yes, the skin is crisp but the chicken is bland and dry (especially the breast). It's accompanied by bread salad that was like burnt croutons with greens dressed with enough acidic vinaigrette to make me do the duck lips. Sorry, but I rather buy 13 [juicy] rotisserie chickens from Costco to feed several needy families.

Did I mention the chicken took 90 minutes? Maybe that's why our chicken was so darn dry.

There's really not much to say about other menu items as the overall theme with their food is both overpriced and mediocre.

What left a sour taste in my mouth is the service. Yah, Zuni Café is a SF "hot spot" but it doesn't give them an excuse to provide sub par and careless service (except for the hostess who was nice).

One of the busboys brought a dirty share plate to my gf with breadcrumbs. Not just a few breadcrumbs but 60% of the plate was covered in breadcrumbs. We were at a loss for words and just blankly stared at him. He responded, "it's just breadcrumbs". Just breadcrumbs? I dare him to say this to Gordon Ramsay. Double dare him.

A fly decided to take nose dive into my cocktail (I feel you, fly...I like getting buzzed too) and I couldn't find our waiter so I alerted one of the wait staff. He said, "Oh", grabbed the drink from my hand, and walked off. Dismissive. I eventually received a replacement but some actual dialogue would have been nice.

Then, there were the interactions with our waiter which was off-putting and came off rude. He would ask a question and as we were responding, he would walk away before we can when finish our response.

WHAT THA HEEZY?!?

After spending $170 for dinner for two, this is NOT the level of service I expect from such a highly touted restaurant.

Ok, end of rant. Now, excuse me while I go take a selfie.
author: Cherylynn N.

description: I have been twice now. And can not say a bad word about his place. The menu changes and keeps on wowing. Great for a date night. You will need a reservation to get in. It is well worth it, from the cocktails to the main dishes, to the dessert.
author: Madeline M.

description: I'm feeling rather ripped off by Zuni's high prices.  At $29 for a lunch entree, I should have left rather full; however, the entree was sized like a large appetizer.  The $29 "white bass" also tasted and had a consistency like swordfish.  Yes, it tasted very fine, as did the bread/butter (thought the butter was served too cold).  Superb service, naturally, but any tables near the door(s) downstairs will get chilly on a chilly day, as did mine.
author: David S.

description:
what is there to say that hasn't already been said? everything was delicious.

we got oysters to start, the roasted chicken for two and a dessert. and wine of course. 

service was impeccable and great vibes all around. we were able to sit in the second floor with a little view of the kitchen, which was really cool.
author: Vanessa S.

description: We had a great time at Zuni Cafe on our last night in San Francisco. We got lucky to walk in without a reservation and still score a great table upstairs. Our server was friendly and the food was awesome. A perfect way to close out our trip.
author: Tri W.

description:
The location is convenient. The building is beautiful! I heard so much about the "Chicken for  Two", so I ordered it. I really wanted to fall in love with this dish, but I can't. Sorry. The chicken was delicious but not  worth the wait (cooked when ordered). Also, the side dishes could have been much better. 
As for the environment, idk on my opinion it seems like typical San Francisco-esq vibe i.e Upper class Caucasians who get a bit loud after a few glasses of wine lol. The server was nice.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I've been here a handful of times and always get the roasted chicken. It's the goddamn best, and that bread salad it comes with is amazing too.

Their shoestring fries and Caesar salads are also great, as are their desserts and cocktails.

The staff here is also good. Not for eating, I mean. They're attentive and accommodating.
author: adrian b.

description:
Fantastic restaurant in a great location on Market. The vibe inside is nice and open atmosphere but they still manage to keep a warm cozy vibe. Jazz piano playing in the background as the chatter and glassware dings lightly fills the big open space. 

Great for business dinners and meetings, and the food is ultimately superb. A bit pricey, which is why I avoided giving a 5 stars, but this is downtown SF so you can't expect much different. 

Will definitely come back!
author: Nick B.

description:
Chicken was great--enough said.  Had the shoshito peppers for something different.  Didn't think light sprinkles of cheese would match, but was actually pretty good.
They start seating at 6 pm (we were there on Fri). Order the chicken the moment you sit down (takes 1 hr) and you'll be done in plenty of time to walk back over the the Orpheum for the show.
author: Wong Wa Y.

description: Have no idea what the hype is about regarding their chicken. Almost an hour wait and it was DRY!!! Costco chicken for $4.99 is even better. Checked with chef and it's always served like that. Also, our waiter was not friendly. Therefore, will never return. Thank you!
author: Julie W.

description:
Geez this was awful. We went in for brunch on saturday. But oh "we only do brunch on sunday." Fine. Lunch it is. No wait which was nice but probably should be a red flag considering how hard it usually is to get into a place for brunch. 

Our waitress was rude. We couldn't tell if she was trying to joke, just having a bad day, totally hating being a waitress, or decided right off she didn't like us. 

One of our glasses had lipstick all over the rim. Not a little but, like a "I question if it was washed at all amount." No response when we said it was dirty. This awkward giggle smirk like we were idiots and it was grabbed off the table.

Several items of our food were literally dropped in front of us. Like, really? It's that hard to set it down?

There were 3 of us. They brought us 3 slices of bread after we'd ordered. When we ate those they asked if we'd like more. We said yes. They brought 2 slices. These aren't giant slices. Definitely a 1 slice per person kind of thing. 3 bites maybe. We pointed out that we could use another piece and again got this sort of eye roll, non-communicative responsive and then a plate of like 5 slices thrown on our table a few minutes later. 

Atmosphere:
It feels worn down. Like it was originally a trendy, cool space but theyre phoning it in at this point. The seating was awful. I was on some sort of sectional type thing where my back was not separated from the back of the person eating behind me. I guess we couldve coordinated our movements to use each other as back rests. A much simpler solution would be seating with seat backs...

Food:
Shoestring fries - bad. they were so small it was like sopping up the crumbs from a normal thing of fries. no graceful way to eat them or put sauce on them.

The "aioli" with the fries - the most bland, blah, stuff ever. it tasted like nothing.

Potato herb soup - wow. that was good. at least one thing about this experience was good.

Polenta - this was my friends bad but the restaurant's as well. It's definitely polenta. Polenta is boring. Why on earth do they serve a portion this big? Imagine a giant bowl of very bland oatmeal. That's polenta. It's corn porridge. Don't order polenta (here or otherwise).

Main course: chicken. Blah. Not worth the hour wait. Not worth ordering at all. It wasnt a bad roast chicken but I can throw one together at home that's far far better. The skin wasnt crispy, not particularly flavorful. Decent at being moist.

The "bread salad" that it came with was absolutely repulsive. Like what on earth are they thinking repulsive. Soggy nasty bread. My best guess is it's all the leftover table bread. 

The chicken and vomit bread came covered in a mound of "frisee" that was absolutely repulsive. Between this and the bread it was like they served our chicken with garbage. Not pleased.

We are big dessert fans. We decided the best treat at the end of our meal was getting out of here as quickly as possible when we finished our food. We all felt worn out by the experience and had to go home for a nap to sleep it off. 

We didn't say anything to the staff. They weren't light fixes but reflective of more structural issues. It didn't seem like they wouldve cared anyway. We just won't be going back.
author: Ryan B.

description: The old great Mare she ain't what she used to be...Went last night and walked into a empty restaurant that should have been our cue. The waitstaff was very sweet but the food was horrible. We had a Calamari app which had almost no Calamari in it, it was basically fried crumbs. Literally like the bottom of a fried clam basket from Cape Cod without the fish.. The Chicken was alright but it sits on top a vinegar soaked piece of bread that tastes like a wet sponge. I have to say this is very sad because It used to be so good and was a fun place to be . Alas no more....
author: Peter K.

description:
I've been wanting to check out this place for a while now and ended up going there for brunch. We sat upstairs in a nook/private room area which was really nice. The bloody mary's were delicious and we also got champagne on the house! We ordered the shoestring potatoes and two pizzas for the table. The pizzas were SO GOOD (ricotta salata especially) - paper thin crust, cooked to perfection. I also had the fetuccini pasta which was a little on the oily side but yummy and not too heavy. 

Planning to come back for dinner and ordering the chicken which they are known for.
author: Laura D.

description:
Charming atmosphere with really friendly service and a creative menu.

We wandered in for some late night snacks and a cocktail and were not disappointed. The Pink Gin and Tonic was well executed and the app list was tasty and fun.

Everyone loves the shoestring potatoes and we particularly enjoyed the calamari.
author: Eric Y.

description:
This restaurant has it all!
Great food (the Roasted chicken meal with greens and warm bread pieces) and a fantastic Cocktail menu.
The staff was very accommodating and courteous.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Ordered an entire roast chicken even though I just was having a "light" brunch with a girlfriend. It takes about an hour but we enjoyed our cappuccinos and the chance to catch up. 

The chicken was pretty good. I wouldn't say it's that much different than other rotisserie chickens that I've had but it did taste very juicy and fresh. I'm just not sure if it's $43 dollars  better than Costco's. I was pretty surprised to find out that it was featured on 7x7 afterwards. 

Service was nice. Our waiter checked on us periodically and made sure our water cups were filled.
author: Xinxin W.

description: The lunch menu is extremely limited and quite frankly not very appealing. The sausage dish is simply a sausage on the middle of the plate with some greens. Although the restaurant promotes their roasted chicken, it takes 60 minutes to prepare. Not conducive for a business lunch. Yes, Zuni's is a San Francisco must so enjoy the atmosphere and its history.
author: David S.

description: Had lunch at Zuni last week.  It seems pretty overpriced for what you get.  The margarita was excellent though, using all fresh ingredients - $12.  Served in a martini glass "up" so not much volume. The wines-by-the-glass list was pathetic. Only 4 reds available - no Zin or Cab Sav or Merlot -  $13 -$16/glass.  Corkage is $30 (which seems high for just providing glasses and opening a bottle) but bringing a nice $40-$50 bottle of Zinfandel or Tannat might be warranted.  Our Arugula and chicory salads were tasty but again, not very big.  $10-$10.50 each.  And our entrees of duck (me) and sausage ($20) (my friend) were decent.  For dessert, attached is a picture of a $16 cheese plate.  Each cheese is $8 and no discount for getting all 3 - it's $24.   The bread was the same as had been served with lunch - no crackers or anything - just this for $16. Did not try the chicken (I roast herb-stuffed chickens weekly and do not order dishes I routinely cook) or fries that others have raved about. I think there are better options in SF for a lovely lunch - namely down by the ferry building where there is also a great view!
author: D. F.

description: Yum! This place totally lives up to its name in culinary food! Everything on the menu is really good so I recommend you come with a foodie partner and crime so you guys can split all the yummy meals. Their chicken is what they're known for but it takes about an hour to cook - and yes it's worth the wait. I recommend you try their desserts too because they're all very tasty :)
author: A N.

description:
Zuni Cafe is one of those places that, as a local, you associate it with SF tradition and a place that EVERYONE has been to at least once.  It took me almost 5 years of living in SF to get to Zuni, and it took my parents coming in to town to finally get around to trying the famous chicken & bread salad.  The four of us were seated in their upstairs area, but in the back corner of their secondary upstairs space.  I'll admit, I initially gushed over how charming it was to sit in the cozy little nook. That was until it took almost 20 minutes for someone to come by and take our beverage orders. In wanting to get the chicken order in ASAFP (it takes an hour to make), this already put me into a mildly bad mood. We ordered everything all at once, not knowing when our server would be back, and went with the following:

Appetizers: Piccolo misto, Bellwether Farms ricotta gnocchi with dried capers and lemon zest, shoestring fries  
Mains: Roast chicken & bread salad (shared amongst 4 people), Llano Seco Ranch porchetta with cannelini beans and white wine sauce, and grilled Santa Cruz sea bass with eggplant, squash and okra
Dessert: Nectarine sorbet with brown butter cookies

So, let's get down to the essentials: the chicken was absolutely amazing and worth ordering.  Having seen it in recipe books, I'm 200% sure that if I tried to make this at home, it'd be an utter failure.  The chicken is tender, juicy, and full of flavor.  And let's not forget about the bread salad, that's literally swimming in the chicken juices, oil, raisins, and lettuce.  It's pretty damn good chicken.  The second item that everyone gushed over were the shoestring fries.  While the mountain o' fries seems intimidating when they put it in front of you, it goes quickly.  And while the ketchup they bring is a nice thing to have, the fries themselves are a little too thin to really dip in to, so I'd safe yourself the effort and just eat them as they are.  My dad had the sea bass, and actually, I really enjoyed it and the eggplant that came with it.

The not so great part of our experience and why I can't give this more than 3 stars, is the service.  After taking forever and a day to order, we were given table bread that was cold and almost stale, rock solid butter, and absolutely no plates to eat it off of.  So, essentially, the paper tablecloth was used.  As food would come to our table, it was all sort of just plopped in front of us, and even sloshed around prior to you eating it.  My mom's pork jus had been sloshing around the plate before eating it since it was dripping over the sides when placed in front.  Beverage service was slow, and included our server breaking a wine glass by our table without so much as looking to see if any loose shards had fallen in the vicinity. All in all, while the food was good, the service prevents this from being a 4+ star experience.  While I did enjoy eating the chicken and something I recommend everyone trying at some point while in SF, I also know that there are a number of other places to check out in Hayes Valley that provide a better service experience.
author: Lisa I.

description:
I have to say... the more I frequent this place, the more & more this place impresses me. O.M.G. that 1-hr chicken over bread salad blew my mind away. The portion size was definitely sufficient for feeding 2-4 people at a time (granted we had 2 delicious salads + 1 soup beforehand). 

Overall, I think that if you are sort of hungry (because it's been so hot lately) or if you could plan out your trip ahead of time for Zuni (e.g., wait an hour for the chicken), it's worth it. But if you are really hungry, probably not worth it.
author: Camie K.

description: Love this place! A great first course to a theater experience! Staff is first-rate and the food never disappoints! We'll be back!
author: Nancy L.

description:
The food here is good.  Very flavorful and expertly prepared.

I had the roasted rabbit.  It was probably one of the best rabbit that I have had.  If you are interested in their roasted chicken dinner, it takes 45 minutes to prepare.  It may be recommended that you call it in.

The restaurant itself has a very cool chic ambiance.  The service is friendly and efficient.

Be prepare to spend money here, the prices are steep.
author: Phat T.

description:
Oh Zuni, I love ya but also, I don't. One part of me was thrilled walking away from a fabulous main course, that even had us with leftovers to spare. The other part of me was a little confused by the pricey, unremarkable appetizers that we killed time with while waiting for our entree.

THE GOOD.
- Roasted chicken w/Tuscan-style bread salad. This was WELL worth the wait, simply fantastic dish with incredible flavor, and I would gladly pay $50 for this meal any day.

THE MEH.
~ House-cured anchovies w/celery. Kind of an odd dish to serve (literally a few slices of cheese, fish, and celery. Maybe for a casual picnic, but not for $10)
~ Toast w/sweet and sour peaches. Again, while I love simple dishes with huge flavor, this was pretty meh.
~ $4 oysters. I don't know what I was thinking when I ordered these, must've been the hunger speaking. Fairly unremarkable for the price point.
~ Cocktails. A little hit-or-miss, I'd stick with a bottle of wine, personally.

I will definitely be back for the roasted chicken, but maybe in a few months - that $200 lunch-bill was a tad insane.
author: Claire S.

description:
People say that you have to come to Zuni when in SF to get a taste of "California cuisine." That means roasted chicken.. and yes before "chicken for two" become a thing in NY, it was rampant here.  We ordered the chicken for two but be sure you do it as soon as you sit down because it takes an hour to make. For real. Now, I'm not sure it was worth an hour wait.. the chicken was good.  Well brined, crispy on the outside (but not really 'fried'), with really good herbs, currants and olive oiled stuffing (bread). And it was more like chicken for 3.. not bad for $48.  It was so much food though that all we had prior was a simple, seasonal persimmon salad and lots of delicious shoestring fries- totally addictive but not too greasy. 

We skipped out on wine and dessert, but I loved the ambiance and I thought the prices were not too terrible. Definitely a classic SF restaurant- and easy to make a res unlike the rest of town.  They seem to eat at more NY hours here.. meaning the restaurant was busy when we dined around 730 and well after, too.  Service is good - the hosts were great about seating us earlier and knew we wanted the chicken before we even sat down and got it going ( I told them when I asked in advance on the phone).
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Stopped in for an afternoon burger. Place was not busy, but the server didn't come back to me after to ask about dessert or offer check. They kind of forgot about me. Servers were talking to each other but didn't even look over so I could signal to them. I had to get up and ask for the check at the bar and wait for them here -- makes me wonder why I felt obligated to tip them.

Burger was good, fresh ingredients but not the best burger. Could be hat focaccia bread is just not right for a hamburger. The sauces and flavors didn't blend all that well, and the meat was just a little greasy, and not actually "medium-rare". Was done medium. Also, $2.50 to include 2 slices of tomato seems a bit much, but I'm glad I went for it.

I had heard they take great pride in their service and food before I came here, so I was disappointed in my experience.
author: Mark P.

description: Finally tried out their famous roasted chicken which took a total of 90 minutes wait time for us.  It could be due to high expectations since we had to wait so long for it, the chicken was not impressive at all. It was fresh but both taste and meat quality was just mediocre. We were very disappointed especially with such a long wait time.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Three of us were dining last knight the was very fat and little the beef filet 
was not tender, desert was very good
service was excellent

 Minoo
author: Hooshang K.

description:
Overall, the food was overrated. Not bad but nothing special which is why it's a 3 star. 

The Caesar salad and fried radicchio were pretty good so if you're there already, get those as appetizers. 

The entrees however were underwhelming. The chicken (what they're famous for) is okay and similar to many other American restaurant's grilled chicken and it takes a while. 

The good thing though is it's a big place so easy to get reservations and the service was really good! Big bar area to hang out in case you're waiting for the rest of your party, you have somewhere to chill and grab a drink.
author: Rohenne L.

description: This is a must do if you're ever in San Francisco.  I recommend to order: oysters, ceaser salad, routissere chicken, and the straw fries. It was epic. I was really lucky the bar tender at Harrington's Pub recommended it. I'll most definitely be back.
author: Christopher R.

description:
Came here for Sunday brunch with a friend and it started terribly because my bag knocked down someone's drink. The sitting area is a bit cramped even though the overall space is pretty big.

The menu is pretty bougie; I ordered a tortilla-based dish and it was really good. Great service and atmosphere too. I also witnessed two solo brunch eaters mingle and end up sharing a table. :D 

Zuni food creating friendships. I'd like to be back to try some of their other items!
author: Juliana P.

description: Excelente experience, our Server Tim was very nice and made us feel very welcome, the manager Jessica was very charming and happy. I would 100% come back.
author: Simon B.

description: Had the baked chicken for two, it was delicious with perfectly brown and crusted skin and an amazing bread salad in the center and it was a good amount of food for two!! I would order this again! The bread put out in the table before the menu was a nice little surprise with the perfect amount of crustiness and moisture!
author: Laura C.

description: I am not sure why people highly rate this place. I've had much better meals for this price. I don't think it is fair to charge this much for mediocre meals. I ordered tuna that was not very flavorful and persimmon salad (the salad had only 2-3 tiny pieces of persimmon). Do not recommend.
author: Helen H.

description: I'm obsessed with this spot. So cute for a white tablecloth date night. The chicken takes awhile to cook. You will be waiting one hour, but seriously it is worth the wait!
author: Ariana B.

description:
Our dear friends highly recommended Zuni Cafe and they visit this place every time they come to SF. 

We came right after arriving at the airport, had a 12:15 reservation and were seated right away. We ordered the clams to start. It was smaller than I expected, just a few clams with a piece of toasted garlic bread and some veggies drizzled with very good olive oil. It was good but I probably won't order it again.

Next was their classic pizza- tomato sauce, oregano and ricotta salata. Thin crust pizza and the cheese just melts in your mouth. Simple but delish!

Last was the burger and shoe string fries. You can taste the quality of the grass fed meat, great combination with their homemade pickles and ketchup. The waiter also reminded us they have a smaller sized fries and that was very nice of him to offer.

Would definitely love to come back to try other dishes!
author: Stacey L.

description: Atmosphere is adorable. Staff is responsive and kind. The Caesar salad was ok. The price for the whole chicken with bread salad seemed very steep once digging in. It wasn't really anything spectacular. In fact, La Fusion in the financial district is almost the same concept and offers the same Rotisserie chicken and bread salad dish for $17 dollars less. I would take picky friends here, the food is pretty straightforward and on the more non-adventurous side. It's just ok.
author: Chandler G.

description:
One of the quintessential California cuisine restaurants with a European sidewalk cafe vibe and ambiance.  

In terms of what to order I'll make this easy. If you come here for lunch or the afternoon, get the burger. If you come here for dinner, order the roast chicken. You will not be disappointed with either!!
author: Mark Y.

description:
Zuni cafe 
Still amazing after all these 35 plus years
The roast chicken for two
The appetizers
The wines
The service
Still one of the best in SF
Thank you Zuni and Judy (RIP) for feeding us so well for four decades!
author: andrew c.

description:
Definitely had a better experience this time around.  The oysters from Zuni are on this list of great things to eat in SF.  I had been to Zuni before (read previous review) to get some of their famous dishes, but I wanted to go this time for oysters. 

I asked the waiter for suggestions since he would probably know best. He got me three different types of oysters:

Pacific Hog Island - sweet and delicious.  They had a firm texture, but it was still really really good. Honestly, it's great and it definitely wants me to go to Hog Island and get some oysters from the source.
Marin Miyagi - This was also sweet. Also pretty large oyster as well.   
Beausoleil - This oyster is a little smaller and saltier than the rest of the ones I've had.  It was a good representation of east coast oysters though. 

Overall, oysters were fresh and so good.  

Protip: from the times I've been here, the gnocchi was delicious and the oysters are also good.
author: Nina Y.

description: Zuni has been opened since 1976, but I finally got to check it out this weekend. Walked in with Christine P on a Saturday night at 8pm and we were seated immediately. Upstairs is the dining section and downstairs is the cafe - only difference apparently is that the cafe doesn't have table cloth. The menu changes daily. We ordered the roasted chicken for 2 ($54), which takes about an hour, so we snacked on bread and caesar salad ($12). The chicken was huge, really juicy and tender, worth the hour wait. We were stuffed but managed to try the Gâteau Victoire with whipped cream ($9), a dense flourless chocolate cake inspired by a Julia Child recipe.
author: Christine C.

description:
It's ok. I mean it is what it is.my mains were bland a sausage with skin on it  and grizzly fatty beef ragu, barely flavorful. My husband's trout was top notch he said. Drinks were strong and best bang for your buck. Apps were just nice. I don't get the hype of this place though, I mean it's all in all food wise just ok, not mind blowing and really for 20$ wire beans in oil with onion it should be ya know.
But decor etc is beautiful and service was 5 star.
author: Janey K.

description:
Tomcat and I arrived a little behind schedule for our 6:15pm reservation and were seated promptly. Maybe I'm just not used to fancy places, but I LOOOOVEED that the wait staff was courteous enough to pull the table out so that I could scooch in and not have to struggle between two tables to get in.

Service was mostly top notch, with plates and utensils almost replaced immediately. I do wish my water was attended to as much as my plates were.

We started with the Crustone with burrata alla panna, cherry tomatoes, anise hyssop, and bee pollen. The burrata was amazing, the sweetness of the cherry tomatoes and the bee pollen really brought this marvelous appetizer together.

The burrata out with the picco frito (deep fried okra, onions, and eggplant with lemon and Urfa pepper). I am a big fan of okra, so this was a real treat. For those who hate okra's sliminess, Zuni eliminates the slime and leaves behind only the flavor. Nicely breaded onions, okra and eggplant without leaving one feeling like a fatass.

Following those two were the Pio Tosini prosciutto with pea shoots, grilled orange tapenade, and pecorino sardo and the Zuni Caesar Salad. The grilled orange tapenade was zesty, tart, and sweet--perfectly complimenting the tang of the prosciutto. The Zuni Caesar Salad was great as it was light on the dressing and not drowning in it like most places.

Now drumroll for the epic Roasted Chicken I've read all about...The chicken was moist and flavorful without packing too much salt, but honestly, Costco's chicken still wins top honors in my book. The warm bread sallad with scallions, garlic, mustard greens, dried currants, and pine nuts that came underneath the chicken was phenemonal though. I wish I could just have ordered the warm bread salad.

Accompanying the chicken were the shoestring potatoes with housemade ketchup. These are so fun and tasty, and the ketchup was tangy and marinara-ish. A small part of me wishes the presentation was better and that they served these in bowls instead. Oh well...guess you have to gobble the fries up before the fry mountain tumbles over! My mouth will happily do that!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I can't begin to tell you how disappointing this place was. I went with my girlfriend and we ordered the soft shell crab, the ricotta gnocchi, and the chicken for two. The soft shell crab wasn't good. It had a chili seasoning which overpowered the crab and had an odd taste to it. They split the gnocchi in half so we could share it which was nice of them, but we both had four pieces of gnocchi. The dish was 17 dollars, that means that each piece of gnocchi was almost two dollars......two dollars for a flavorless potato dumpling the size of an almond?! 

So at this point I'm starving waiting for the chicken (which takes an hour to make, why?) It comes and it is okay to say the least. I mean seriously, reading the reviews I feel like I'm in the fucking twilight zone.  First off no chicken is worth $50....it's chicken. If I'm paying that much for one chicken, I expect it to come back to life at the table and give me a back rub. Secondly, I've had MUCH better chicken. Hell I've even made much better chicken. Has anyone who's been here actually cook and understand what making a good roasted chicken entails? Not much. I am flabbergasted as to why people talk about this place. 

If I were to judge this strictly based off the food and ambiance, I'd give it two and half, maybe three stars if I was being generous. Considering I payed $170 for a meal that I was unsatisfied with, I feel like emailing every five star reviewer a roasted chicken recipe and a fucking clue cause they need to get real.
author: Joe F.

description:
Let it be known that here at Zuni Cafe, it was my very first time ordering and eating rabbit and it was delicious.  (Poor little guy)  

What a nice cafe in the city - it was warm and sunny the day I went (kind of strange being that its SF and its usually not so hot that you start to sweat - mind you, I was walking from the Powell BART Station)  I was meeting my cousins for my birthday lunch! :]  

- Outdoor and Indoor seating
- Great drinks
- Interesting menu (Went out of the box to try their delectable rabbit dish - though they were small pieces of meat scattered on the plate with veggies, I still really enjoyed my new experience)
- Oysters!!! (I tried 3 different kinds... all were pretty amazing)
- Good for groups
- Casual/Trendy


 I felt like a young classy bohemian hipster... it was probably because of the drink and the nice ambiance this place had.  Almost felt like I was in SoCal because of the heat.  Don't get me wrong, this place had guests of all ages - great place for bunch! It was pretty warm inside (I think it was because of the weather that day, but there is also a very warm oven - not sure of the type... but I think its one of those to make pizzas?  Tucked away in the back corner... it was shaped kind of strange, but I liked that.  It also felt like a nice private area for about 6-7 to fit comfortably.  Liked our waiter - very knowledgable.  I can't wait to come back here to try more items off their menu one day.
author: Allie P.

description:
Absolutely amazing.  I return every few years and the food is stellar.  I had mixed grill but will rave over the soups--Rich broth and flavorful.  
Went for the famous roast chicken and didn't have the time so I orderedthe mixed
author: Fred M.

description: Awesome selection of oysters from both coasts.  The Caesar salad was one of the most flavorful I've had in a long time.  I chose the sirloin which was awesome but so many other dishes looked equally as good.  Good wine selection, I'm a CAB guy, but the Italian wines were great.
author: Scott K.

description: The chicken is great. The salads were good. Orange salad was really good -- flavors worked perfectly. Arugula salad was a bit overdressed. Chicken lives up to the hype. Meyer lemon panna cotta was really yum. I'm a fan. It's a staple.
author: Vicki T.

description: I think this place is pretty decent I've had better we had the chicken we had pizza we had a few other things the coffee was OK the service was really good I would come back.
author: Eugene T.

description: Great atmosphere. Super fun. Incredibly tasty food. Very cool rotisserie where you can watch the food being cooked. Down-home, classy, comfortable, two thumbs up
author: Dinky D.

description: Finally got to dig into the famous Zuni chicken! Fresh and moist just like it was promised. A bit shocked it takes an hour (and it does take the full hour) but perhaps it's the kitchen/rotisserie size? The Cesar salad was tasty as was the lentil soup of the day. The wildly popular shoestring fries were just like the ones your grandparent bought in the canister so I was a bit disappointed but my man loved the homemade catsup that went with it. Highlight was the greasy AF bread salad buried beneath the chicken flavored with scallions, currants and pine nuts. Service was kind and attentive.
author: Nicole O.

description: Had a fabulous dining experience.   Started with a very fresh assortment of oysters followed by lovely anchovy with Parmigiano-Reggiano.  Favorite appetizer, however, was the crostini.  For dinner, we enjoyed the wild trout which was perfectly seasoned with fresh herbs, but not so much as to overwhelm the fish.  The rabbit loin dinner was tremendous and unusual.  Not something one would see on a menu everyday.   Highly recommended.   Loved the dual floor ambience and light through the windows.   Mesclun salad was as fresh as could be imagined and appeared to come from farm to table the same day.
author: Roy A.

description: Was fine. The food was good, but not worth the price tag. Everyone was raving about this chicken, and it was good, but not worth $60. Everyone said you have to try it and see what it's like. It's like a really good overpriced chicken. Not sure I want to spend the loot to try anything else there. Also not sure I can recommend anyone else does.
author: Joseph S.

description:
This classic San Francisco dining spot has been on my dream list for years; I finally made it to San Francisco last week, and I had a reservation for two at 7:45p. To be honest, I went into the restaurant knowing I may be disappointed because 1. I had probably built up the anticipation of being blown away in my head and 2. some of the reviews on Yelp made me believe it's not all it's cracked up to be. 

That being said, I was actually blown away by the food. I'm pretty sure I made noises while I ate. It was embarrassing to my husband.

The location is beautiful. You walk in, and immediately are greeted by a friendly hostess. We were seated almost right away; just enough time to take in the gorgeous bar (where people seem to be dressed MUCH more casually), chattering patrons and the piano being played. It is noisy downstairs. We were led upstairs, to the back corner where we were in a quieter, more intimate section, which was nice for a romantic dinner. The lighting and ambiance is perfect upstairs.

We started off the meal with cocktails (delicious) and a medley of oysters. The server explained all the oysters to us, which I appreciated (but honestly, I forgot which ones were which as I ate them). All of the oysters tasted fresh and better than any oyster I've had when I lived in south Florida. We each ordered an entree - I had the trout, my husband had the pork chop. The trout comes as a whole fish (head and tail), placed upon a bed of wilted/sauteed spinach with cauliflower and sunchokes. Each component of the trout entree was perfectly seasoned, cooked and presented. The pork chop, however, was my favorite over the trout. It came with sliced potatoes and greens, however, the pork chop was the real star. It was cooked in the wood-fired brick oven, so there was a nice smokey flavor to it, but it must have been finished with butter, because each bite I had was juicy, tender and buttery. It was the most tender pork chop I have ever eaten. 

We finished the meal with the crème fraîche panna cotta that came with graham cracker crumbles and a berry sauce on the side. It was the perfect end to the evening, and I cannot recommend it enough. The crème fraîche panna cotta is great because it's not super sweet, it's almost savory actually, but still extremely refreshing.

My only issue was with our server. He was pleasant and attentive enough, however, when I asked him for more information about the oysters selection (there were about 20 different kinds you could choose from), he gave me no guidance at all. The list gives you the location and species, and when I asked him for a little guidance, he said that basically what was on the list was all I needed to know. So I asked him for his recommendations and he said he recommended all of them. When I just stared back at him, that's when he suggested he would put together an assortment for me. I don't know... that was just a little off putting to me, and I wished he would at least have recommended two or three of them or maybe explained the differences in the regions they come from?
author: Ashley Marie E.

description:
Just recently, I went to Barbuto and Le Coq Rico in NY to try both of their iconic roast chickens...so when a West Coast foodie friend suggested we try Zuni Cafe, I was excited to compare. 

I love the space...unusually shaped, with nooks and crannies that lend themselves well to requests for specific tables. Really nice bar area with live piano music.The chicken itself was perfect...no doubt about that. However, I was really looking forward to the bread salad. I guess I imagined it more like a stuffing...which sounded really appealing...but it is definitely not a stuffing. It's cubes of bread and lots of wilted (kinda gross) greens and lots and lots and lots of highly vinegared dressing. The dressing does not lend itself well to the subtle flavors of the perfectly cooked and seasoned chicken. It's overwhelming. And the bread just soaks up all the dressing and...well, it's just WAY too strong. I wanted the bread to soak up the pan drippings from the chicken, not be drenched in vinegar.

The Caesar salad was one of the best I've had. The anchovy appetizer was passable. The shoestring fries were yummy. We had the flourless chocolate cake for dessert, which was highly recommended by the server, but was nothing special...certainly nothing that you can't get at literally 10,000 other restaurants, including every mall chain.

*Having just recently dined at Le Coq Rico in NY, I can definitely say that the French win again. It's superior in every way. Their appetizers, mostly concentrating on egg dishes, were unique and spectacular. The baby greens with vinaigrette, included with the chicken and served on the side, was delicious and didn't compete with the chicken. Zuni does not serve their chicken with gravy...the gravy at Le Coq Rico adds so much to the experience. It is literally amazing. And as I mentioned before, the desserts at Le Coq Rico were among the best I've EVER had.

*Barbuto comes in second. It also serves a spectacular roasted chicken, but their signature is the herb "juice"...not really a gravy, just herbed pan drippings, a most flavorful way to moisten the chicken. Really enjoyed that. I also enjoyed their desserts more, and the atmosphere at Barbuto is really fun.
author: Elisa C.

description:
Quite the nice meal! Zuni's is known for their roast chicken (for 2). Well, I did get it. And it was super good! But the best part of it is the bread salad they have underneath. What is bread salad?! Amazingness, that's what! 

The table shared 3 different types of oysters, a black truffle risotto, and some kind of seafood dish. Not big portions, but good tasters. The oysters were great! I finished up the meal with a lemon panna cotta that tasted a little bit more like lemon grass, but was quite refreshing!

Our server was super awesome as well. He knows his stuff, especially the oyster options! He could go into detail for each and gave us perfect recommendations! Their drinks can be quite expensive as I spent about $80 for a round for 5 of us and only about $50 to split the dinner, but it's a great restaurant.

Make sure you make reservations or you can end up waiting at the bar for a while.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
Really enjoyed lunch here during a recent trip to San Francisco.  The service we had was top notch and the food was delicious as well.  We split an arugula lunch salad which had fresh greens and just the right amount of zip from the lemon dressing.  I had the tagliatelle which was perfectly al dente and the vegetables were fresh and of high quality. The other person in my party had one of the special pizzas which was done on thin crust and was light enough on the cheese so that the other flavors were not overpowered.  

Definitely not the most inexpensive place you could chose but highly recommended (when considering the quality of the service and the food it's still good value).
author: Mark S.

description:
Is the roast chicken at Zuni delicious? Yes. Does it take a long time? Yes again. Is it consistently tender, with crispy skin? Absolutely. Is it enough to feed two people, with a couple delicious morsels to take home? Certainly.

We had the renowned roast chicken, along with a mincemeat pie and a Bloody Mary, about a month ago during a midday stop to Hayes Valley. My fiancée did not enjoy mincemeat so much. Theirs is made the traditional way, with actual suet, and it was still bubbling when it came out. I would gladly eat one myself.
author: A L.

description:
The best tasting roast chicken ever been served but, at an unjustifiably high price.  $60??  Even if it came with that great tasting bread salad not sure the price is right.  Now they could make a meal out of it by serving it with a couple of sides but off of the menu that is extra!  The shoestring potatoes are the best (we got them and like the chicken these were at SF prices).  The menu needs a bit of 'renovation'.... maybe add a couple of sides to the roast chicken to justify the 60$ price and I would gladly make a return trip.

Their dessert menu was nice.  The panna cotta was delicious, just the right amount of creamy and for the price they could've add a coulis.....but I guess this restaurant aims straight for your wallet.

The surroundings are great, the restaurant has a wonderful ambiance.  Huge windows to stare out give the restaurant a nice look.
author: Chitra J.

description:
Really funky triangular space. But they make the space work really well. 
We got there for their short menu of dishes between lunch and dinner service. We had the burger which was really flavorful. The caesar salad was the best I've ever had. Skip the shoestring fries though - they were simple and good but not worth the calories. Can't wait to go back!
author: Marilynn L.

description: Overrated , the shoestring potatoes were too salty and cold when served. The chicken was not fully cooked, still raw inside while some parts were burned outside. The Caesar salad had too much dressing. Oysters were the only good.
author: H Y.

description:
This place has been on my list for some time now, so when a reservation popped up on Open Table I took it! I came here for one thing, the famous chicken! But since it takes about an hour to prepare, I ordered a couple of other things.

Oysters - They were out of a lot of the oysters I wanted to try, so I picked 4 that I was familiar with. I can't remember my opinion of them individually,  but they were all a pretty good size and went nicely with the mignonette and hot sauce.

Fritto - Fried nicely. Breading was light and crunchy. A pet peeve of mine is when they fry veggies and other things and mix it in with the squid. So you sometimes end up eating a veggie you may not particularly like.

Shoestring potatoes - A nice mound of freshly fried potatoes. Served with a little side of ketchup.

Chicken - The reason I came here! I had a piece of the thigh which was nice and juicy. But looking at the breast pieces that came out, I could tell they were dry. I asked my friend who ate a breast piece and he confirmed that it was indeed dry. The bread salad underneath was a little inconsistent. There were portions that had good chicken and vinaigrette flavor. And other portions that were dry and tasted like a moist crouton. I tried to avoid those pieces.

If the chicken didn't take about an hour to prepare, I probably would have skipped some of the apps and went straight for the chicken since I wasn't very excited about the rest of the menu. All in all, I'm glad I tried the chicken and can cross Zuni off my list. But I probably won't be back.
author: Elena N.

description:
If Zuni Cafe were a celebrity, it might be George Clooney. It's been around for a while, but it's handsomeness never gets old. And just like I'd respond to an encounter with that salt & pepper stud, I was a bit starstruck walking into Zuni for my first time. A little surreal, and a lot exciting. 

For this spontaneous visit, we literally made a reservation on the Yelp app as we were driving to Zuni and snagged a reservation just an hour from our arrival time. We were able to linger at the long, glimmering copper bar while we waited for our too-romantic-for-words table on the second floor dining area. But, back to that bar...

Zuni's bar shows off it's sexiness to passersby through giant glass walls that face Market Street. I'd walked by enough times to feel left out of the high-class fun, so I felt properly smug being on the other side of the wall, finally. 

Cocktails are classic and pricey, so I skipped straight to the tiny wine list. There are about 10 wines by the glass (underwhelming), but hundreds by the bottle. The light & lovely Italian "Rossese" ($10) was so enjoyable, I took a picture so I could track it down again. 

We could have lingered at the bar all night, but the lack of stools made it tricky (standing bar only). Right on time we were seated at a perfectly cozy & intimate table upstairs and enjoyed attentive but not overly-up-in-your-business service. Zuni ain't cheap, but the service reminds you what you're paying for. 

For dinner, two words: Ricotta Gnocchi. I can't promise you that these melt-in-your-mouth ricotta gems will be on the menu when you visit, but if they are, you must experience Zuni's version of the classic Italian potato puffs. Instead of the dense, overly starchy little carb balls served elsewhere, Zuni's gnocchi are delicate, creamy, and light on the starch. With shaved chanterelles, chives and a lemony sauce, I was very sad to finish that last, mousse-like bite. 

Zuni is iconic. It's one of those SF hot spots that doesn't feel trendy or hyped. It has clearly earned it's fame. Even if you're able to resist it's bourgeoise charms, you must admit that it's done a fine job tempting us all.  Again, my Clooney reference holds up.
author: Nique F.

description:
Would I recommend a pricey 45 minute wait for Roast Chicken?

Yes, yes I would.

I would and I'd give the restaurant Five Stars to boot.
author: James G.

description: This is a long overdue review of Zuni Cafe. If you are visiting, a current resident or planning a trip or move to the SF Bay Area, make sure you try and get yourself here for some of the best food you will ever eat. The atmosphere, the bar, THE WINE. It's truly a gem in SF. The chicken for 2 may have a little bit of a wait time but it is worth every minute that you do.
author: Dana B.

description: I've probably dined at the Zuni more than 150 times over the years, and don't know anyplace else that  consistently matches it for warm ambience, quality ingredients, attentive service, interesting wine list and excellent dishes--classically, the roast chicken, Caesar salad, polenta, shoestrings--and the bread, oh yes, the bread. In a city where the launch-to-flameout time for a hot restaurant is down to several weeks, the Zuni just rolls and rolls.
author: Geoffrey N.

description:
What can I say... Zuni rules. Zuni has been an SF staple for so long that it's easy to assume that they've become complacent. Not so, It's fabulous. Known for their chicken (which is yes, fabulous), it's their other dishes that round out this landmark on Market. I know there are many fabulous (word of the moment) restaurants in SF but if I were to recommend one to out of town friends, it would be Zuni. It's well rounded and you're guaranteed to get the complementary call the next day.

I've had the Tuscan chicken, the burger, the pizza, etc. and it's all great. I've been there for lunch and diner. I don't see the need for detailing out the food because it's the whole package that makes this restaurant and nice place to spend a couple of hours. Zuni is on the expensive side but not over-the-top like many other top SF staples. The setup is interesting as you can be downstairs which has the bar area, the dinning room area or upstairs which is open and lively.

Never go away Zuni, you're an SF classic.
author: Matt T.

description: One of my favorites in a city of delicious food choices. Great atmosphere, superb service and lots to choose from on the menu. My daughter is finally 21 and I couldn't wait for her to experience the magic of Zuni. The oyster selection can't be beat. Our waiter recommended the best oysters and cocktails. Thanks again, Zuni Cafe for a memorable meal.
author: Sommer P.

description:
Came here with a party of five on a friday night. It's a great place to have a celebratory dinner, the decor is gorgeous and the dinning room has great ambiance. I ordered the Zuni Caesar salad to start. It was good, the dressing had more of a vinegar base which I liked and the croutons were yummy. I also had samplings of the gnocchi which is a must order, they tasted as light and soft as pillows. As a table we got the chicken, which is also quite good. My favorite part was the bread pieces that absorbed the chicken's flavor. It's a generous serving and we easily split among our table of five. I also got the halibut which was quite good. For desert I tried the sorbets and blue cheese.

At the end of the meal my aunt asked what ingredients were used in the chicken since she has the Zuni cookbook and has made it at home. Our waiter brought back a packet including the chef's recipes and tips, which made my aunt's night. Overall it was a great meal.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: A great classic restaurant with quality food. It's good to reserve in advance although waiting time isn't long. If this is your first time I recommend having the delicious roasted chicken or the sea bass and for drink the San Francisco classic or the naked and famous cocktail. Add a variety of oysters and deserts and you have an almost perfect meal!
author: Babak S.

description: I feel like when I ate at Zuni 10 years ago it def was a 5 star experience. I was disappointed that it isn't like that anymore. Sunday brunch was ok but nothing to really rave about. The service is great though which always improves a so so meal. We started with the Caesar which was good (heavy on anchovy flavor if you're into that). I got the $18 cheesy scrambled eggs. They were good but not $18 good. I will give Zuni another chance on my next trip to SF.
author: Patty O.

description:
Good food, pleasant atmosphere, excellent service.

Tried the chicken & bread salad....very flavorful.  At the table had the starter salad, steak, mussels and I tried the nectarine gelato for desert.  All were good with the gelato being my least favorite.
author: Tawana J.

description:
Service: Great. My sister and I went to Zuni at 5 on a Sat evening. Got lucky to score a table without reservation. The upstairs has the white table cloths, but we sat floor level. We didn't know the roast chicken takes an hour, and so we asked if we could go run some errands lol. But alas, no dice. 

Food: Okay, it's not life changing roast chicken but solid. It's their signature dish, but it's just roast chicken, folks. The soup of the day was a broccoli/leek soup with fried capers. That soup was absolutely delicious. 

Overall: I'm glad I got to try Zuni and their famed roast chicken, but other things look better on the menu. I would also recommend having a good book or be in good company if you are going to wait an hour for that chicken.
author: William V.

description:
I have had Zuni on my list of places to go for quite some time, mostly for the burger which I was told was by far the best burger in SF. Best burger in SF is a tough accolade to achieve but I accept that taste and judgement is subjective, but for me it is definitely not my favorite burger in SF, but it is an interesting one. i had it with cheddar cheese and it is served on foccacia which already starts to cross the line on whether you should really call this a burger vs a sandwich. I think the burger meat is cooked in a wood fired oven maybe? Overall it is very good but not out of this world/life changing good, just a solid burger that I would happily eat again but wouldn't go out of my way for. The pickled veggies on the side are great.

The whole chicken looks great, but takes quite a bit of time and is probably better shared between at least a few people, so will definitely come back for that at some point.
author: Brent F.

description: Zuni Cafe an San Francisco Landmark, known for it's roasted chicken "for two" (really could feed 3 or 4) Worth the wait! Other than this meal I could only recommend what I ate...the salad with roasted kumquats & flourless chocolate torte. All delicious. Disappointed with our waiter who wasn't fluent in English and made several errors. Also disappointed with the bar being out of several common liquors.
author: Linda D.

description: Wine list is honestly depressing, Napa and Sonoma being so close should be an asset. I tried several different wines from France (I believe that's the issue) and they were honestly just awful. The food was typical French, dry and tasteless. Landed here by accident and I I knew it  as French I would have passed to begin with.
author: Steven W.

description:
My husband booked the reservation on this one, so kudos to him! I've definitely heard of this place over the years, just somehow never been (you know lived in San Jose but never been to the winchester mystery house...okay another story). Anyway last night we finally made the trek. And I mean we got the special version of getting there. My husband thought it be a great idea to "stroll" and I use that term loosely here, from Powell to the restaurant down Market. Maybe other streets would have made this more date-ish, but Market not so much. I will say once arriving to our destination the restaurant is very cute upon walking up sitting on a triangular block, great ambiance once entering. Very cozy bar and even a large piano inside.
We were seated shortly upon arriving across from the kitchen side by side at a small table, which usually wouldn't be in most restaurants the best spot. But in this case since the kitchen is open and we would decide to go for the one hour wait on our dinner (as the menu states)  it was our entertainment. 
So yes, one must on their first visit is go ahead an order their whole roasted chicken for two, which the restaurant are known. I probably should have eaten lunch, not a smart move in my busy day. But with some super crusty bread and a lovely order of Ricotta Gnocchi (split) I survived the wait. And it actually was maybe only 50-55 minutes? We also got to watch the chef in charge of cooking, chopping, and plating all the chickens. He was like a well oiled machine. (All I could think with the amount of chickens me must make every night-day-week, he must hate roasted chicken!). Anyway this kept us busy as we chatted and watched, and the time really didn't seem that long since we both love cooking. Unlike the table to our left who asked "how much longer" right as we were seated, and then proceeded to wait another 20+ minutes. Impatient. But then they couldn't see the glorious process!
So the Chicken, ah.....Smokey and juicy...divine...dark meat first! Even the white meat, the whole bird was amazing. And that light crispy skin, even if you normally wouldn't eat the skin you must you must! And it was served over a lovely fluffy but crisp (can those two descriptives be used together?) stuffing with pinenuts and currants drenched in a vinaigrette/gravy. Topped with arugula....Ahhhh doggie bag was essential at the end. So delicious. But you know not so crazy filling that we couldn't make a little room to share an after dinner treat!
We both agreed on the Buttermilk Panna Cotta with Strawberries. And I have to tell you light and perfect to top off a wonderful dinner.
All of our servers were excellent and so attentive. What a lovely dinner date.
We hoofed it back to the closest bart stop (Civic) forgoing the stroll....Dreaming of deliciousness are whole way home. Wait! I have leftover chicken for today...sweet victory!!!
author: Susan D.

description:
Came here as a prelude dinner to the SHN Theatre's production of the Book of Mormon this Saturday expecting the typical menu of a California cuisine restaurant in the city and ended up indulging in the most delicious takes on some guilty American pleasures: a vegetable "fritto" dish that screams yummy old onion rings, and a heaping dish of their shoestring potatoes that were not only beautifully crisp but served with a very tasty ketchup that is just bursting with flavorful spices--plus it's perfect to share! 

After the appetizers and a couple rounds of the house rum-based cocktail that elicited dreams of warm breezes in some tropical paradise--after a grand hour of waiting--the Chicken for Two meal was served. It was, hands down, the best chicken I have eaten in a long time. Beautifully flavored and so moist, I totally recommend that you try this, even if you are a quasi-vegetarian like me who normally doesn't find poultry appealing, this is a must have!
author: Nicole W.

description:
Food was good, but service not so much.

The BF was catching a flight at 6:30 p.m. so we entered at 4:45 p.m. hoping to try the famous chicken salad. I had a reservation at 5:15 but they said dinner is open at 5:00 p.m. No problem, we sit down by the bar for their late lunch/afternoon menu. Service is shaky but we flag someone and order the chicken. After 30 minutes or so, one hostess comes by asking if we want to sit for dinner. I said we ordered, and she left. Five minutes later, another hostess (I guess there's more than one) comes by and asks the same question. I said that we ordered, but would like to sit in the dining room. She says we can only do that if we order from the dinner menu. You serve your chicken salad on every menu!!! Technically I did order from the dinner menu!!

The chicken salad is good. I can see why it's famous and well-loved. It's good, but it's not $48 good. I would say $20-25 tops. At the end of the day, roast chicken is roast chicken, and it's something most people can either (1) make themselves or (2) buy from the supermarket for like $8. Not sure about the $40 discrepancy.

I'm not trying to sound arrogant or demeaning because the chicken was delicious, but it's not something I would get again. And as to the service, I honestly don't think it should matter *what* I order. It's the little details that customers remember. If I make a dinner reservation and order an $$$ entree, the restaurant should honor it and give me a table!!!
author: Allison S.

description: I thought this place was good. As everyone else seemingly did, we ordered the one hour chicken. It was good but Im not sure if it warranted all the hype. We also had the sausages and the ceaser. Of all the things I had I think the ceaser was strangely my favorite. This is a good restaurant with good service and worth a try.
author: Ian C.

description: If I was just reviewing the food, it would have been 4 stars.  The wait person was lovely but one of our six entrees had a "technical error". Translation one of us got her entree 6 min after the rest of the table. They knew we were celebrating a birthday and needing to make Hamilton. When the late enter was finally served we didn't have time to order desert. We ordered the check instead. When the check arrived the wait person served a canoe on an empty plate.  Ok, points for remembering the birthday, but how long would it have taken to stick a brownie or something underneath it?  And when the check arrived was anything comped in an attempt to make up for the late entree: No.  Really, folks. Damn, this service is so Mickey Mouse I'm taking off another star.
author: Jeanette N.

description:
one work CHICKEN. I had been wanting to try Zuni for so long, and finally got the chance. It did not disappoint. The restaurant itself is very cool.

oysters galore ! They have such a great selection of oysters and they are so fresh. We ordered a bunch of oysters because my boyfriend and I are big oyster people. Ate them all and then ordered more because they were so good. 

At the time we went (back in September) they had a fantastic heirloom tomato salad. It was delicious. 

We ordered the Chicken which is a must. It was so good. Love the warm breadcrumb salad. The chicken was perfectly cooked and so good. Honestly this could feed more then two people. 

They have a great wine list as well. 

We were pleasantly surprised when the bill came out. It was cheaper than we anticipated for the amount of food and drinks we got. 

I think Zuni is a great place for a group. Make sure you have reservations!
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
This for me was like fan girling over a celebrity. It is a must when visiting San Francisco just for the prestige. Judy Rodgers was an amazing and inspirational chef for me when I was coming up through the culinary school. So this was a long awaited visit and it definitely did not disappoint.
Service is impeccable, they even accommodated our time strain because we were going to see Wicked at the Orpheum. Roast Chicken for two was the first thing ordered (it takes almost a hour and half to cook so keep that in mind), along with a selection of oysters that our knowledgeable server Tim picked for us based on our tastes, then fried squid, Caesar salad (that they split for us without asking).
