Taking a chance that a table might be available, I got lucky and got the little bar table right behind the piano player. No, I didn't heckle him or yell at him to play Vince Guaraldi's music from "A Charlie Brown Christmas". I was tempted though since the warm, lofty ambiance made me want to do the Sherman shoulder dance on that brisk evening. Y'know, the one where he pulls his shoulders up to the beat as he shifts his head from side to side.

It was only medium-level crowded for a Thursday night, so it was as ideal as you could get for such a popular watering hole. Even though I was hungry enough to eat the roasted chicken and bread salad for two ($48...ka-ching!), I was way too cheap to consider such a humiliating gorging. Instead, I ordered the $10 Zuni Caesar Salad, which probably was a trendsetter at the time it was concocted but was honestly just a good, hearty Caesar with fresh spears of Romaine lettuce (see photo). Jamie W. finally got out of his neighborhood meeting and was able to come join me at that point. He ordered the $15.50 Spaghetti with Rapini, Pancetta, Red Onions, Garlic, Lemon Zest and Pecorino Romano (see photo), a modest plate filled with robust flavors that were quite satisfying.

My entree was the $27.50 Grilled Sea of Cortex Grouper with Radicchio, Baby Leeks, Faro, Chanterelle Mushrooms and Sage-Lemon Oil - a lovely piece of fish that was nicely contrasted with the faro and the sauteed vegetables (see photo). Between the big wedge of country bread (see photo) and the $6 mountain of Shoestring Potatoes, you would think that would be enough high-end food for two people. But alas, we were on a Zuni roll, so we tried a slice of the Sierra Beauty Apple Tart with Creme Fraiche and Caramel Sauce (see photo), which we had the gall to think was too small. We also thought the creme fraiche tasted more like sour cream than whipped cream giving the meal a somewhat tinny ending. No matter as Zuni still evokes that wraparound feeling that makes me wonder why I don't come back more often. Oh yeah, it's kinda pricey.

FOOD - 4 stars...still classic American cuisine pretty much copied everywhere else somewhat to their detriment 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...cozy, lofty vibe despite the crowds
SERVICE - 4 stars...pretty attentive
TOTAL - 4 stars...I've been Zunified
author: Ed U.

description:
Love love love! I came here on a date with my boyfriend and we had such a wonderful time.

First of all, I love the ambiance. Even though it's on market street in kind of a shady area, it's bright, with floor to ceiling windows, and even a piano player!  We sat upstairs and it was so cute up there!

Our server was great too. Ask for Kristin, if you can! She was so sweet and made wonderful wine and dish recommendations. 

The food we ordered: oysters to start, olives, Caesar salad, and the roasted chicken. The chicken is wood oven roasted, and it takes an hour to prepare so be sure to order it when you sit down! All of the dishes were awesome. The chicken comes served on this bread pudding that has all of the juices, and it's just amazing. It's perfectly cooked, and definitely a highlight on the menu.

I'll definitely be coming back - maybe for brunch? The Bloody Mary looks pretty epic....
author: Taylor L.

description:
I know Cafe Zuni has been through a lot over the years but as a New Yorker who went to this place with a open mind I must admit both myself and my date were pretty blown away. This place definitely still has the magic.

The Chicken, as every foodie on earth seems to know, is really top notch. Yes, it takes an hour to prepare but just tell your waiter right when you sit down that you will be having it and they just put the order in before they bring you drinks. This makes the wait FAR more bearable. 

I had read the polenta was really heavy and not that worth it but I have to say that this really wasn't the case. It was excellent, delicious, and a very appropriate starter, as was the baby arugula salad that they had on the menu that night. 

The chicken was superb, with an inventive and wonderful burnt bread salad beneath. Dessert was an AMAZING Gateau Victoire cake topped with whipped cream. I understand this cake has no flour whatsoever but, when I tasted its crumbly, airy consistency, I seriously could not believe it.

Our waiter was awesome, the setting was beautiful, and the smell of wood smoke filled the air, wafting down to the well-appointed bar. This restaurant may have been in existence for over thirty years but I can assure you that it is a lot more fresh and forward-thinking than a lot of spots that have opened in the last six months. 

A SF classic.
author: Paul A.

description: Food is amazing- came here to celebrate a huge win for the golden state warriors!!! And my sister got engaged :). Big party of 11 people- all enjoying ourselves and having a great time. I never write reviews unless they are somehow positive, and tonight is no different except our waitress. I'm not going to knock a successful business because a member of its staff is reflecting very poorly on them. She has said so many comments, mocking us, after ordering over $1,000 worth of food because of lack of room for plates.... Can't handle her right now, so rude. But still, great food. Xoxo
author: Nicole S.

description:
zuni was really top class brunch place with family.we sat along the transparent glass window looking out the streets.Nice place for sunny summer.It had great ambiance and service.coffee was great.We had wood -fired pizza which were smoking good.Try the polenta-it is buttery and slides smoothly.

I was blown by the dessert : gateau victoire with whipped cream - such an amazing way to bring out texture and flavors - delicate placement of marshmallow chips so beautiful.Never seen a dessert presented so delicately!
author: Priyanka L.

description:
I've eaten here five times now and each time is just as good as the time before.

Naturally, each time has included the famous oven roasted chicken. The chicken lives up to the hype. Never dry, always tasty, and the accompanying warm bread and mustard greens are a perfect pairing and just as good on its own as the chicken.

The almost equally famous crunchy fries (just the right amount of savory) and Caesar salad (so fresh and tasty) are also delicious. 

Every other meal I've had here has been wonderful. And the changing menu ensures there's always something new and delicious to try. Thank the Zuni gods that the fries, Caesar, and chicken are here to stay though.

The inside decor is lovely--very lofty and modern with beautiful brick walls. There is also plenty of room (compared to many other SF restaurants), which is perfect for larger parties. I especially love the upstairs back rooms as they feel very cozy and private.

Service has always been superb. Very attentive. 

The only criticisms I will say is that some staff members (particularly the hosts) aren't the friendliest. But even they still provide good customer service (I.e. They'll greet you, help you and seat you right away but don't expect a warm smile). And the only bathrooms are downstairs. Small sacrifices.

In the end, this place is quintessentially San Francisco and quintessentially California. Every Bay Arean (and beyond!) should discover the reasons why this place remains popular after almost 40 years.
author: Mark M.

description:
I was really excited to come here but was pretty underwhelmed. 

Cocktails - mine was super sour and acidic. I felt like my teeth were going to fall out after sipping half of it.
Caesar salad - fantastic
Ricotta Gnocchi - so awful. I really do not recommend this dish. The texture reminded me of old scrambled eggs smushed together and coated with a generous serving of flavorless butter. Then there they threw some random undercooked carrots in the mix. I usually have this habit of eating everything on my plate, even if it's underwhelming, but I truly could not stomach these slimy little balls of goop.
Roasted chicken - pretty darn good, but wouldn't be enough alone to bring me back.
Chocolate cake - tasted like it was from a grocery store. Would have been 10x better if it was warm. 

Lastly, do not sit upstairs on a hot night. The brick oven is on the first floor and all the heat rises and made it hard to enjoy our warm meal. The one savings grace - the service was fantastic.
author: Sarah M.

description:
What a wonderful restaurant!  After all these years, I'm still a fan of Zuni.  And it's perennial inclusion on SF's best list (usually for their roast whole chicken) is a testament to the strength of this restaurant as well. 

Interestingly, I've never had the chicken and I may never. The fact it has to be shared for two (thus limiting the entrees you can order) and that I've brined at home makes it less tempting than so many of their other menu items. 

Service is spot-on and I love the warm ambiance as well as the two floor dining.  Our choices for lunch:

Balsamic Bloody Mary - holy cow was this good!  I'm a big bloody Mary fan but have not been exposed to the sour sweet combo of balsamic vinegar. Chowhounders apparently have long been in the know but I'm gonna have to research the recipe. 

Oysters - abundantly fresh and the equal of any more seafood centric restaurant I've tried in the city.  Loved the Humboldt Kuma. 

Wood oven pizza - the wood oven is a gem (it's where they roast the chicken for 1 hour) and the pizza is wonderful from there as well.  Great Cowgirl Creamery cheese, fresh onions, and a wonderfully thin crunchy crust. 

Grass fed burger - it was cooked slightly more than I requested but the Zuni pickles and focaccia bread were top notch. If there's any criticism, I don't like that the nickel and dime you for the cheese, grilled onions, and mushrooms. 

House cured anchovies - tasty.  Paired with a great cheese, tiny olives and a top notch olive oil. 

Shoestring potatoes - addictive. Light and crunchy.  Goes great with the house ketchup (a tad sweeter than regular ketchup) and the house mustard. 

It was great to return to Zuni and enjoy the atmosphere and great food once again. It's still a popular spot and it's easy to see why. 

Zuni accepts credit cards, Including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: Duck leg was good and the broccoli. The portions are good and the service is great! The menu changes pretty frequently so I don't know if they will have this dish in the near future but my dish was decent.
author: Vanessa H.

description: This place has great food and service. I do think it's a bit overpriced, but would consider returning.
author: Sarah S.

description:
***************************** 994 *******************************

            RIP legendary chef Judy Rodgers. She'll ever be missed by many chefs, hospitality people, fans around the world, and San Francisco. We are so blessed to have her. Her roasted chicken got us at hello. She changed many menus in San Francisco and California. Cancer had taken her away from us. 

          RIP chef Judy Rodgers!
author: Manda Bear B.

description: One of my favorite spots in SF, especially for late afternoon drinks and food on a weekend.  Stellar service, great cocktails, delicious oysters.  If you wanna go for dinner, make a reservation - the space fills super fast.
author: Stanley W.

description:
4 of us walked in right when they opened at 11 on a Sunday.  No seats in restaurant but plenty in cafe area.  This is simply the area in front on the bar.  Sat down right away and got started with a balsamic Bloody Mary.  It was interesting but not great.  I think I discovered I prefer other things to Tabasco in my drink.

The rabbit and kale salad was tasty with a bit of added salt.  An extra egg and slightly runnier yolk would have made it amazing.

Eggs and sausage was amazing as it came.   Definitely getting this one again.

The French toast with cream, yeh that was solid but I wouldn't come here for that alone.

Easily accessible via Muni and was a good start to the day in Hayes Valley a short walk away.
author: steve a.

description: When you return to a restaurant that you've loved, you always have high expectations that this experience will match the previous.   Well we recently returned to Zuni Cafe' for dinner prior to theatre.   We ordered our favorites:  Caesar salad and the roast chicken.    EVERY BIT AS GOOD as we remembered.    We ordered the chicken when we walked in the door, were seated within minutes of our reservation, we told them about our 8:00 show and service was prompt, courteous and professional.   Chicken arrived about 50 minutes after we sat down.   We left the restaurant about 20 minutes prior to the show and strolled to the theatre.   But it is all about the food.    The Caesar (which we split) was a great start.   We brought a wine that paired very well with the chicken (we waited to enjoy the wine until after our salad course).   Then the roast chicken with bread salad arrived:  moist and flavorful just like the last time.    Hard for us to order anything else for dinner.    We do plan on returning for lunch for their burger.  This place just continues to excel on so many fronts.   Go there soon!  We'll be back soon.
author: Malcolm J.

description: I was mildly disappointed with my visit to Zuni. Not in a big way. I'll be back, but my lamb had been sitting in the kitchen getting cold as they were making my husband's fish, so it was pretty chilly when I got it. I powered through that because I didn't want to send it back to warm up and have to wait. Then after I dug in, on of the chops was pretty rare...uneatibly rare. I ate around it and mentioned my experience to the waiter, just to let them know. I received a free dessert! yum! The sausage was delicious, I have to say. I will just keep my mind focused there. Beautiful restaurant.
author: H S.

description:
So we went for a lunch date and were pretty disappointed. We had a salad and a burger and walked out with a $50 tab. The burger was mediocre and the salad was tiny. 
The chicken they have for two is $48. Really? This place is so overrated. Definitely not going back.
author: Jan W.

description: This is our favorite restaurant in SF! You can't miss the chicken with bread salad, the caesar salad, or the oysters! We go here once a month! Best ambiance as well and everywhere you sit you get a different angle of the restaurant.
author: Ann K.

description:
Oh my god! (Pardon the blaspheme). I went here with a small group of three and we split the amazing, legendary brick chicken. This dish requires a lot of preparation time, so they warn you to order 45 minutes before you plan to be eating. They were right on target. 

So, we ordered appetizers and drinks in the waiting period.  They were also very worth it!!!

He wait staff was very well trained and provided a superb overview of the best options and things to consider. I will definitely go back here.
author: Mitchell F.

description: Overpriced 80's style food. What a waste. This place is past it's day. Tourist trap now.
author: Kirkham C.

description:
I went for lunch last Thursday seeing as it was absolutely gorgeous out and they have a few tables outside on the sidewalk. (although it is a bit noisy out there)

I got the Zuni burger which was Very Good.  The pickled onions that came with it are what really made it though.  Those onions get 5 stars hands down.  Absolutely Delicious.  The Burger itself was actually really delicious as well.  Yummy Beef. The homemade pickles were also quite excellent.

A word of warning (which I was actually really excited about): they cook them on the rare side.  I actually really like my meat RARE, but I always feel weird ordering it rare, so per usual I ordered medium rare - and then surprise surprise it came out and it was really much more like rare!  I was stoked! But, if you are more a well-done person, maybe order more done than you would think.  

The shoes string potatoes were also nice and crispy!

$16 for a burger?  JUST a burger? $6 to add the fries? Yes, I know, it's San Francisco, but really?  I just don't think I'm  going to get used to it.... Unless maybe I get really rich?
author: Sarah C.

description: This place is famous for chicken but honestly their chicken wasn't something new or special so I don't know why lots of overrated reviews about it ! Nice ambience. Great service.I don't know what's wrong with all the tables, all of them were rocking!! I think the roasted chicken is overrated and overpriced. Been there a year ago. Me and fiancee both had chicken and we were like OK it's chicken, nothing special, nothing magical about it. No secret ingredient or sauce!  Just plain chicken. A little bit greasy , it was a lot thu and we couldn't eat much so we took the rest to go. They put some basil and other veggies around it to make it look different, baloney!  our check came at $85 for chicken for 2 and a glass of wine, But it's SF, expensive is the norm there. If u wanna try this place, don't order chicken and order something else. If u r craving roasted chicken then buy one for $8 from staters bros and save $72 cuz it will taste the same.
author: Mohammed B.

description:
We ordered the infamous roasted chicken with bread salad to cross off another item on the 7x7 Big Eat list. While it was tasty, I'm going to say the same thing about it as I did for Limon Rotisserie's chicken. IT'S JUST CHICKEN!!! It's not going to give you magical powers or turn your ugly ass into a supermodel! Good, but not life-changing.

The oysters are worth a try. We asked for a sampler plate and everything tasted extremely fresh. The spaghetti with mushrooms and nettles was also good to graze on while we waited for the chicken to be prepared. It was a nice surprise that the portion was split onto two plates without us having to ask for it. 

Overall, this is a solid place for lunch or late dinner. I'd definitely return to try the burger, which looked amazing on a neighboring table.
author: Suany W.

description:
So I work for this company that has this Founder who is a regular at Zuni. Every time he takes a client, staff to lunch or dinner in the city (San Francisco), he almost always recommend/take them to Zuni. After observing his consistency of his attendance at Zuni, I remember asking him a few months ago, "is Zuni that good?" A gracious man he is, "yes! Have you been there? We will go there one day for lunch or dinner!" And here we are, months later I finally got the opportunity to try this place out. And what better of a person to try it out than Dr. Garcia (Doc -as we like to call him) the regular.

PARKING:
So, if you follow my reviews, you know how much I dread looking for parking in San Francisco. I mean, that is the reason why people sell their cars and invest in bikes after moving to the city. Luckily, it only took me minutes to find a parking spot on the street. Then again, it was a Tuesday (yesterday) night. So far, the evening is looking good!

LOCATION:
This restaurant is located on a street corner with tall glass windows and warmly lit. And when I say, "warmly" I meant the ambiance is very cozy and pleasant. When the Boyfriend and I walked by, we saw people completely packed the place. I thought we might not have a place to sit. Not bad for a Tuesday night eh?

UPON ENTRY:
We saw our Founder at the front podium talking to the hostesses. Very pretty might I say. They smiled at us as we entered and approached Doc. He immediately lead us to the bar. As we make our way through the cozy space to the bar, we were greeted with smiles by every staff member there. Amazing.

INTERIOR:
It's pretty small and narrow. The tables and seatings are pretty close together, but the layout works for this unique place. Tables are close together, but enough room for people to walk through. Pass these tables, you arrive at the beautiful bar (very welcoming). Here you have a little standing room, but it is probably beacause they kitchen is located right behind you so foot space is necessary. There is an upstairs area which I have yet to check out. Pass the bar and kitchen entrance, you walk into another area with booths. Neat! This is where we were seated.

CUSTOMER SERVICE:
Once we were told our table was ready, we were escorted by the hostess with a tray for our drinks. She placed our drinks on it and lead us to our table (reminded me of that 'As Good As It Gets' movies when Helen Hunt was about to get seated and a guy offered his tray for her drink so that she doesn't have to hold her drink to her table. Pretty awesome). Everyone smiled, presented a professional mannerism, even the bus boys were nice and polite. They're on top of their game, after every dish we finished, they were there in a minute to clear it out for us. We were always given clean utensils after every usage (that's crazy).

FOOD:
Wow. Doc ordered a lot of dishes for us so let me see if I can remember them all. We started with 6 different flavors of oysters. I can't remember all of them, but I do remember my favorite: Drake's Bay. However, they were all freaking delish! I didn't know you can make oysters taste different flavors! 

Then, we began our dinner with the Zuni Caesar Salad. I never seen it served a whole leave of lettuce before. And it was perfectly dressed with caesar dressing with a nice large crouton(s). Normally caesar dressing packs too much of a punch so I often request it on the side, but I have to say, best caesar salad ever. So simple but definitely hit the spot.

Our came the Bellwether Farms Ricotta Gnocchi, and honestly when I heard Doc order it, I had no idea what he said nor did I know how it was going to look like. But, just the fact that I've seen him cook at work, I trust his choices in the foods. There was enough for each person to have three Ricotta Gnocchi. Wow, the most tastiest, softest little things ever! (uhm, excuse me, can I order a bucket full of this?) I even asked for the boyfriend's share (I was kidding of course, but he ended up giving me the last one anyways -yep! I'm spoiled!).

Next our chicken for Two Roasted in The Brick Oven came out. This I have heard Doc kept on repeating to our waiter. I was curious, what this was. Anyways, finally our chicken came out and it the presentation was gorgeous. Doc served us each a piece. I even grabbed some of the dandelion greens and stuffing. So tender, juicy, full of flavor and to top it off -I didn't even know pine nuts can be so good with chicken! This must've been their signature dish because our table wasn't the only one that ordered it.

Doc ordered us some short ribs as well, and the meat was soft and juicy. Not touch like I would expect it to be. I'm not usually a fan of short ribs but these were to die for.

VERDICT:
I have tasted many great foods before, but the thing here that won my attention was the costumer service. Smiles everywhere, I love it! Maybe it was because we were with Doc (their regular). Yes, I would return here -soon!
author: Cathy N.

description:
Visitors to our fine city - go to one of the other restaurants with California cuisine that actually care about your dining experience!

What used to be an amazing place is now staffed with scowling, inexperienced management and servers who don't care about the dining experience for the customers spending their hard earned dollars for mediocre food. The poor service overshadowed any possibility of enjoying a meal with family from out of town. Judy Rodger's temple has been sold out. Every minute we sat and waited for service, meal, and check was a minute to long in the excessive decibels of a Saturday night. And we were there early!

Entrees were served to 2 people while the other 2 waited 10 minutes. I had to go to find a manager who took away the food and tried to give us more food as compensation while we waited...we were already waiting for food...The wine we ordered sat at the bus station while the overwhelmed server "Mark", fumbled with his 4 table station. Each table complaining about his horrible service. 

After finally receiving remade entrees that arrived together, the manager never checked back in on our table or came to Mark's station to see how he was doing! The management let Mark continue to ruin our evening and that of the other tables there. A long, expensive, terrible experience with family that I won't soon forget.
author: Kathe M.

description: Classic San Francisco atmosphere and unimpeachably good food. A bit pricey. Service was fantastic.
author: Marilyn S.

description:
3 things amounted to a disappointing experience especially when we paid over $100 each for our dinner: 

1) The bartender did not know what a Sazerac was! This isn't a super unusual drink...we were very surprised. We got an Old Fashioned instead which was mediocre, to be kind. Disappointing considering the prices of cocktails. 

2) We were seated upstairs, and I was sitting against the wall, and felt wedged almost underneath a huge pillar / banister. Lighting on this table was also bright and in my face. Overall uncomfortable seating position and poor lighting. 

3) The smoked pork main dish reminded me of dry Christmas ham. I mentioned this to our waiter who did not do anything about it. 

I also sent this note directly to Zuni's email address with 0 reply, very disappointing.
author: Makiko H.

description:
This is one of those hidden gems in the city. They have a delicious, light brunch and a fun, lively atmosphere for dinner, especially around the bar area. If you want something quieter, then the upper level could be an option.

If you don't have reservations, then the window area by the door is often available and during brunch there is usually no or very little wait.

The food is delicious, the service is great, and the wait is generally not bad.
author: Elena K.

description:
We came for a holiday dinner. Boyf had been meaning to come for awhile, and this was as good a time as any. We waited awhile at the bar for our reserved table to be ready and it was really crowded. We didn't order anything off the cocktails/wine menu bc nothing looked particularly intriguing and we'd brought a bottle of wine.

We ordered a number of dishes to share as always, and we were pretty impressed. Their menu is super seasonal and changes daily, but the chicken is a mainstay.. which we will have to get another night.  We had a lightlly fried semi-asparagus app which came with this.. green pine cone sauce (WHAT) which was really good. There was a clam fettuccine that was fabulous, really simple but just perfect. We ordered the goat leg, which was the first time I'd really seen goat in a nice restaurant where it was pretty rare, and it was SO chewy. I couldn't handle it, our jaws were hurting. I don't know if it's just goat or the leg or what. The flavors were good though. We ended the night with a gateau victoire, which was really light (the waiter's selling point) and we kinda wished it was denser.. but still very cocoa-y.

A couple bumps in the road food-wise, but also a couple really nice dishes. The service was a bit rocky as well; they were either super on top of things, or we didn't see them for awhile and needed them.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Come here with my parents every time I'm in San Francisco. My mother and I share the roast chicken and my father usually gets a special.

I love the chicken. It's simple and amazing. Moist, tender, sublime. Great bread salad comes with it. I want to be there now. One word of warning. It takes an hour to cook. So let your sever know you want it right away. While you are waiting, have a cocktail, enjoy a glass of wine, have some french fries, enjoy conversation with the people you came with. The hour will pass before you know it and you will be treated to something you'll dream about when you are home.

http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g60713-d349460-r322697675-Zuni_Cafe-San_Francisco_California.html#
author: Paul G.

description:
Sorry, but I found it a bit underwhelming. 
Very attractive space, with a number of interesting seating venues.  Staff very friendly and accommodating.
The food was where I felt the disappointment.  I started with a Caesar salad; my dining companion who suggested Zuni said they were known for a great Caesar.  My salad was salade ordinaire:  a bit over-dressed and Ho-hum in flavor.  Croutons were best part.  My main course was a burger (again Recc as a Zuni favorite). Again, for me a bit disappointing:  burger was somewhat dry, cheese was pleasant enough but not particularly satisfying.
Maybe I was there on an off-day for the chef or possibly ordered the wrong items.  But probably would never return; too many other choices in SF.
author: Kevin W.

description: Love this place! Went here recently with my sister who was visiting from out of town. And, Zuni has not lost any of its classy ambience since my first visit 10 years ago. The food is always delicious and the drinks are great. This place is always perfect for a casual lunch date with a loved one or a romantic evening with your sweetie.
author: G F.

description:
Amazing dinner, great atmosphere, nice service.

We started with cocktails, oysters and piccolo fritto. All of the oysters were great, but the Summer Ice were our favorite. The piccolo fritto was ok, but nothing special. Tried their ice tea cocktail - nice an refreshing.

For dinner we split the chicken - it really is as good as everyone says. Even the leftovers were great!

For dessert we tried out the flourless chocolate cake. The cake had a nice crumble while also maintaining a smooth texture expected of flourless cakes. 

I would definitely return again. Great spot for a special occasion or family in town.
author: Emily H.

description:
I really like that they serve Flor De Cona rum. So the salmon with black lentals and dill horse radish salsa was amazing. The combination of ingredients was excellent. The portions on this dish seemed a bit small. I also had a few bites of the chicken for two which was very moist and tender. Perfectly cooked.

I was a little annoyed how long it took to get our food. From the time we placed our order until it arrived was 1 hour 27 minutes.
author: Lyle R.

description: Best restaurant and there's a reason they've been around so long!!! We LOVE the chicken but have also stumbled across the pizzas and may never turn back... delfina has some competition in this department. The service is also impeccable in a beautiful high class setting with out any tinge of snobbery!!
author: Amy V.

description: The entire experience at Zuni was excellent. From the great service and drinks at the bar, to our amazing chicken for two at the table, I cannot recommend this trendy American bistro enough. The chicken was moist beyond compare and the bread salad is "to die for" (from my dining companion). Recommend highly, but make a reservation for parties larger than 2!
author: Mackenzie R.

description:
Every once in awhile, wifey and I stray from our dining mainstays and put on our big people pants and venture out into the grownup dining world. You know, establishments that take reservations and have white table cloths and nicely decorated interiors.

For us, Zuni is such a restaurant. Since they are known for their roast chicken for two, we knew exactly we were getting before we even walked in the door. We knew it was going to be an hour wait. And we hoped it was going to be worth it.

Luckily our table was in a cool spot, where we could see all of the action in the kitchen while waiting for the chicken.  It was like our own episode of a Food Channel show, where we got to see exactly what happens at the various kitchen stations.  We paid close attention to the roast chicken station, and now we can probably make our roast chicken. All we need now is an industrial kitchen!

Anyway, the chicken came out, and we gobbled it all up.  It was moist, flavorful, and delicious. The bread salad was interesting, and good too.  While the meal wasn't worth the hour wait, it was still a cool experience, so we'll go back sometime. When we do, we'll skip the chicken and try some of the other dishes mentioned in the reviews.
author: Nadeem A.

description: Been here many times and had some absolutely memorable meals.   Our last visit in July left us feeling a little underwhelmed compared to our previous visits, and that's the reason for the three star review.   Not sure if it was an off night, sliding standards, or if our palates have evolved a little since discovering this place in 2008.   In any case, the quality of the food is always good, and the service is dependable.  We were just not "thrilled" this time out as we have been in the past.  A good bet is to come in a group and order the roast chicken and a couple more items to share, as I think that's where the kitchen really shines.
author: Robert B.

description:
After reading a list of places I must try out while living in SF, I decided to give Zuni Cafe a try. I was unable to make a res, but luckily snagged a table with little wait in the bar area. My friend and I split the chicken for two, which is where it is at! This has to be the most succulent chicken I have ever tasted! It rests upon a bed of greens and bread pudding (I call it stuffing but whateves). Be forewarned that this dish takes an hour for the chefs to prepare so I don't recommend coming here on an empty stomach. 

Having not been here before, we asked the waiter if the chicken would be enough for two. He talked us into splitting the Cesar Salad. My friends the chicken was PLENTY for two! 

Add this to your list if you have not yet been! Cocktails are great, service is spectacular and the food is delectable! I would give this place 10 Stars if I could. Can't wait to take my boyfriend and perhaps my next out of town guests!
author: Stephanie I.

description: I've lived in San Francisco for almost 17 years, and somehow I'd never been to Zuni.  I'd tried, a few times...In fact I think I've had reservations THREE times before but each time had to cancel for random reasons.  Well, last night was my night and it was worth the wait.  I've been hearing about the rotisserie chicken for nearly a decade, so my friend and I got that.  Perfectly seasoned, so moist, so good - and the "bread salad" was very flavorful and "solid" enough that it didn't trigger my extreme distaste of what I call the 'wet bread texture.'  The women next to us had said that the bread salad was the 'best part' and they might be right, it was almost as good as the chicken.  We started our meal sharing a Caesar salad (on which the dressing was DELICIOUS) and ended the meal with the pot de creme which was perfect.  We'd nearly been tempted to try the gnocchi but as it turns out that these three items were perfect for two people.  In fact, my friend saved her last piece of chicken for take-home and I wished I'd done the same as I left a little fuller than I wanted to.  All in all, a great experience worth the wait.  Our waiter was very helpful, too, I should add.  Oh, and  I made the reservation a week early but we were there on  Super Bowl Sunday so I don't know if that meant their reservations sold out more slowly, or what.  In other words, you might want to plan ahead MORE than a week in advance.  Restaurant reservations were definitely maxed out that night.  I want to go back and try brunch next.
author: Dave M.

description: The Ricotta Gnocchi was unparalleled. Pillows of buttery potato cheesy perfection in every perfect mouthful. The fig salad was too bitter and vinegar for my taste, and just didn't match my expectations based on the menu description. Excellent service. Bring your out of town guests for an authentic SF experience.
author: Sheviche R.

description: Service was welcoming from start to finish. We requested our table up top. Oysters and wine were the best part of our meal. The chicken is never a bad idea. This a SF staple that everyone must try!
author: Brandy R.

description:
Zuni Cafe = 3.5 STARS

I'm visiting SF for vacation and I know there are millions of yummy places to eat that I couldn't decide on a restaurant. I asked my cousin to book a place since I didn't care where I was eating - as long as we got to catch up. We came to Zuni Cafe one lovely evening for dinner. We had made reservations for our meal here about two nights prior and they were easily made. Our party of four was easily seated once we came in.

[decor]
Zuni's ambiance doesn't really have anything going for them. It's not really pretty-looking. It seems a bit run-down, but maybe because the building is old. There's a lot of light from the windows. Weird seating area for the diners. There's a second level for dining as well, but looks a bit as cramped as the rest of the resto. A bar is available and has shelves of liquor. I'm surprised that the hobo's hanging outside haven't broken the windows for some booze =X

[devour]
*OYSTERS ($2.50-3.75/each, ***4 STARS***) - Zuni has a laundry list of oysters! Out of all the ones we tried (~3/person), we were quite fond of the DRAKE'S BAY OYSTERS (from Point Bay). This was recommended by our waiter and I totally agree with his recommendation! I don't recall the names of the other oysters we tried, but they weren't as memorable as the Drake's Bay! =) 

*CEASAR SALAD ($10, ***2 STARS***) - The "infamous" Caesar salad didn't really seem to amuse me. I thought the dressing on the romaine lettuce was lacking some "oomph". Sorry I wasn't getting the hype. BUT!!!!! I did LOVE THE CROUTONS, which were very garlicky, buttery, and crispy - just the way it should be. I just wanted to eat all of the croutons instead of the greens =X ...... and I hate to say it, but I've had better Caesar salad in Portland (Yes, I'm talking about 23 Hoyt and Apizza Scholls).

*SHOESTRING POTATOES ($6, ***3 STARS***) - was your typical run-of-the-mill fries. They are skinny in size, so you can devour more of them. You get a good pile of the shoestring fries, that it's good to share with about 4-5 people. Fries were decently cooked. It came with a side of ketchup. The dish was just a wallflower in my book. Also, it can easily get cold and after a few minutes, it won't be as appetizing after 20 minutes. 

*PORK CHOP ($28, ***3 STARS***) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zuni-cafe-san-francisco?select=3Q4JjgM9Cb_TLGgZjKvAUA) - the pork chop was sadly dry on one end, but tender and succulent on the other side of the bone. Although, most of the chop was well-done and was kinda difficult to manipulate, it did come with flavorful sides - greens and some-what-lookin-mash-potato-dish (can't recall names). I would have rather gobbled up the sides and call it a day. The au jus by the chop was very savory! Everything on the dish was excellently prepared, minus the pork chop..... kinda torn if I would eat this again.  

*ROASTED CHICKEN FOR TWO ($48, ***4.5 STARS***) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zuni-cafe-san-francisco?start=300#y9HIlZT_CvbiXwHzsqS_RA) - I think this is more like roasted chicken for 4 or 5 people! (unless you want leftovers, then it's good for two). If you're thinking about ordering this dish (ORDER IT ONCE YOU SIT DOWN) since it will take 1 hour (yes that's 60 minutes) for them to roast the thing! 

The chicken is roasted in their brick oven for one hour. It came out very moist and succulent. You would think that the breast of the chicken would turn out dry, but I was AMAZED it wasn't! This dish is served fam bam style and comes with a warm bread salad that has chopped scallions, greens, embedded with dried currants and pine nuts. I must say that I loved that bread salad WAYYYY more than the Caesar. I wish they had the bread salad alone as an appetizer. So if I loved everything about this dish, why wasn't it 5 Stars? Well I wish the skin of the chicken was a bit more crispy. Then again, nothing is perfect! It was a good piece of chicken! Way better than your Costco rotisserie my friends! 

[drank]
A glass of their red wine (ranges $8-11) was nice and paired well with the roasted chicken. 

FYI =
-They charge 4% to your bill to support the "SF employer mandates" (so glad PDX doesn't do that!)
-Party of 6+ will have an automatic 18% gratuity
-Complimentary bread & butter: expect LOTS of bread crumbs (mess alert!)
-Great service (water glasses attentively filled)
-Full bar available
-BYOW? Cork fee $20/bottle
-Parking on the street (metered)
-CC's accepted (Visa, MC, Amex)

Although there are mixed reviews about Zuni Cafe, my dining experience was also mixed. But one thing I was certain of.................... 

WINNER WINNER CHICKEN DINNER! 
(Yes I know it's cliche, but I just had to say it!)

Yelp 2013 100 for 100 Challenge - Review #95
author: Kristen M.

description:
Everything at Zuni's is perfect! The architecture of the bar/restaurant is modern rustic with a great view facing the street. 
The dishes were exceptional, service was very welcoming, the Chef was enthusastic and very charming. 

I'd have to say my favorite part of Zuni's was the people who were regulars here. The people you encounter really speak for the classiness of the restaueant. We ran into a few folks who we've never met before, but they were so friendly and polite, and even wanted to buy us some of their favorite dishes. Even those who didn't speak to us gave of a positive energy through their smiles.

So there it is. Dining with great food, beautiful setting, awesome service is already 5 stars. Dining amongst kind folks as well? Way over 5 stars!
author: Gwen D.

description: Disappointing because we expected to be great, and it was just mediocre to good. The chicken was indeed good, but nothing else lived up to the hype. I would not go back.
author: Julie K.

description:
I found this place on yelp searching for brunch
Absolutely nothing on menu would qualify for brunch 
The food menu was very limited to compared to what we are used to have in U.S. More like European restaurants.
The severs where polite
They had many drink options so maybe this is more like a bar !?
author: Arash R.

description:
Dinner here could be summarized as: An awful, cacophonous mess with bad service.

A shame considering how much I enjoyed brunch here. But from start to finish, dinner was an exercise in chaotic futility. Our waiter didn't appear for a full 20 minutes. When he did, he never apologized for the wait. Our courses took about 15-20 min to arrive, with the infamous roasted chicken taking the requisite 1 hour.

The food itself was okay but nothing to rave about. The squid with pesto was the best dish we got. The polenta with mascarpone was bland and forgettable. The roasted chicken? The perfect example of a culinary "the emperor has no clothes", in my opinion. People, there is nothing about this chicken that is "world famous" or "unique" or whatever other hyperbolic descriptions you want to give it. It's as tender and juicy and salty and tasty as the stuff you could get at Safeway, except Safeway's is half the price and has zero wait time. It's served under a bed of raw frisee (seriously?) and over a bed of soggy bread salad that has little to recommend it besides too many scallions. And that's it. That's all you get for $48 and a minimum one-hour wait time.

Despite the disappointing app and entree, my friend and I still would have entertained staying for dessert, but that decision was made for us the minute the already way-too-loud restaurant allowed a mariachi band to play at maximum volume. Picture Zuni Cafe with its many little dining rooms that anyone with the slightest knowledge of acoustics knows are very conducive to amplification being abuzz with a full house of diners on a crazy Wednesday evening. Then picture a mariachi band with several trumpet players performing just below your table with mics attached to their instruments. The noise was deafening. You literally could not hear anything else. I looked around at the many diners around me and all I saw were grimaces of discomfort and annoyance. 

Oh, and a lot of covering of the ears.
author: Josephine L.

description: Ordered oyster Kusshi, Pacific hog island and PT Reyes Kumamoto. Didn't like any of these oysters. Good bread. Anchor California lagger beer is ok. Fries was super thin - quite interesting. The famous chicken was good - it was like between fried and roasted. Crispy skin n juicy meat. It tastes like the famous slow-roasted Taiwanese chickens.
author: Anya C.

description:
Went here for brunch w/ a group of four and had an excellent time. We all shared the strawberries with yogurt, caesar salad, french toast, shoestring potatoes, and a lamb pasta. The shoestring potatoes never end! The lamb pasta was the best dish out of the five. Funny story with the strawberries with yogurt -- after we read the description (with the dried rose petal, bee pollen) I think we had imagined a huge bowl of yogurt with sliced strawberries and large rose petal in the middle, but when we got the dish we laughed because we were surprised at how tiny the dollop of yogurt was... and we could barely tell there were dried rose petals in it. It was still delicious but keep in mind the portion size is very small :)

The ambiance is also nice & the restaurant had a lot of natural light. However, since yesterday was an exceptionally hot day, we were all sweating throughout our meal. There is no AC! If they fixed that, this restaurant would be perfect.
author: Madonna N.

description: Today was Fathers' Day. It was nice and tasty! The sunny light penetrated windows and walls! My mood and appetite improved during the day. Thanks my family and friends for this place!
author: Roman K.

description: The food was outstanding, definitely try the classics: bread salad, roasted chicken for 2 + oystas! The Bloody Mary had a distinct taste to it which may or may not be a hit to some, but I'm definitely a fan..service could be a little bit more pleasant but then again it was a Saturday night
author: Marie P.

description:
We came for the food prepared by the people in the kitchen and may not return any time soon as wait staff let kitchen down. 

The wait staff delivered poor sevice in as much as it was slow and at times inattentive. And then they'd rush about to recover and it all and simply did not work.

We did enjoy - when it was finally served - the gem lettuce salad, goat cheese and beet crostini and tostada de puerco main. But the value for money proposition albeit tiny portions in return for too much money in this diner's opinion is not convincing.

Put a wee bit more on the plate or better harmonize your prices for what you do plate and please extend help to upstairs wait staff so as not to let down an admirable kitchen.
author: Jay D.

description: Every time I'm in SF, I come here just for the Chicken for two with an amazing bread salad and I also get the bloody Marys which are the best I've ever had. Service is top notch. Be careful if you dine outside tho, lots of people wanting to pan handle and sometimes it may get scary,  if you're not use to that sort of thing. Zuni has been working on some of these issues. ( I think they have security now.). Having said all that tho..the food is amazing!
author: Vinnie B.

description: Chicken for two was great! Unfortunately for us, it was actually enough food for 3-4 people and, way too much food for a couple of tourist with no refrigerator or oven in the hotel. It was delicious tho and I do recommend. The chicken was perfectly cooked, super moist and juicy and worth the wait. The shoestring potatoes are very tempting and delicious but I would hold out the full hours wait for the chicken and come hungry. Btw, fell in love with the ginger beer soda.
author: Alex D.

description: We have been going to Zuni's for more years than we dare count. Just when we think it can't get any better, it does! That is largely because of the delightful manager, Jessica Kanat and her outstanding team. Together, they have created one of the best restaurant vibes in San Francisco with consistently delicious cuisine. From the fabulous fresh lime margaritas and incredible selection of oysters to the mouth watering shoe strings, leading up to the world famous Zuni chicken, in the most attractive and fun environment, we were in heaven! Thank you to Kevin for the excellent and attentive service after a warm welcome from the charming and lovely Jessica and Vicki. There is no more enjoyable way to spend a Sunday afternoon with dear friends (that lingered into early evening ) than at fabulous Zuni's.
author: Cherie L.

description:
First time...had heard great things.

Stupidly expensive...frankly, offensively so.  I ordered the pork dish...the concept of the sauce and such was great but the pork was a bad cut and terribly dry...which they tried to cover with extra sauce...didnt work.  For a $34 plate,  they should have had tenderloin, something braised or at the very least,  a well cooked piece of whatever it was...

The appetizers were incredibly small...the Gnocchi was quite good but the Anchovies, while decent,  were hardly worth the little scraps they put on the plate.

My wife ordered the Squab and if anyone knows squab,  they have painfully little meat...coupled with almost no sides,  I wonder how the Chef thought this was a reasonable meal for someone paying $32.  Very disappointing, cheaply made and not at all thought out.

One gets the impression that they are simply trying to squeeze money of you...and that they do very well!  But soon not worth it.  Afterwards,  we were left hungry and disappointed with the quality of the food.

The one bright spot was our server.  He killed it...but alas,  that will only go so far.  Maybe they had an off night or whatever but honestly,  I wouldn't even go back for a second try considering the price to quality ratio...its just not even worth it.  


On top of all that,  they claim to have to impose a 4% surcharge to pay for their employees additional expenses...ridiculous and offensive to any lover of good food and a great restaurant experience.
author: Andrew S.

description:
What a cute restaurant.  It's brightly lit, surrounded by windows with an open kitchen, full bar, and seating upstairs.  I saw quite a few people eating solo, which says a lot about the ambiance.  It's a comfortable environment whether it be with a group of people or just by yourself.

My friends and I got the Kusshi oysters, rabbit and kale salad, cranberry-squash soup, and prosciutto with goat cheese, almonds, and peppers.  I think the menu changes seasonally and by the time of day.

We sat between a window and brick oven and shared little plates.  I loved the ambiance and style of food.
author: Elise G.

description:
I don't know why someone would give this restaurant a good review!
First of all, staffs are not very friendly. Definitely they need more training. 
The food is just ok! We ordered two salads and two main courses. Both main courses were more on the salty side.  
The restrooms... OMG... Smelly, dirty, pee on the floor...horrible horrible
author: Haleh D.

description:
Disappointed overall.  Roast chicken wasn't anything special - definitely not worth $54, nor having to wait an hour for it.  I was expecting something out of the ordinary, but didn't get it.

The warm bread salad that came with the chicken was good, except that parts had been overcooked/burnt.  Caesar salad was good, as was the shoestring fries.

Menu is fairly short, so if you aren't going to order the chicken, there weren't a lot of other choices.
author: Peter R.

description:
I finally came here for their infamous roasted chicken and shoe string fries.  

The menu says chicken for 2 but BOY!  More like chicken for 3 or 4.  I know I have a big stomach but seriously though, this was way too much for just two people.  The chicken was very moist, tender, juicy, and importantly, flavorful.  The bread was the perfect texture and absorbed all the juices from the chicken.  Perfecto.  

The fries, plentiful.  It was so thin that after consuming the whole plate, it didn't make you feel full at all.  

Overall, it was worth the 45 minutes for the chicken but I don't think it was worth the $48.
author: Linda N.

description:
My food ricotta gnocchi  was plain no taste and my partners too much salt ...I had better food there before 
 I probably will not go back any time soon
author: A. M.

description:
Was really pleased with this spot. The service was on point (thanks Garrett!). 

After pouring our bottle of wine, he didn't come back to bug us to order anything until he saw us pick up the menus. The oyster recommendations were spot on. The trout was amazing. The lamb was decent. 

Great date night spot.
author: Matthew A.

description:
Unprecedented poor display of character should be the proper name for this restaurant.

After sitting down at this establishment, my girlfriend rapported that the menu was not suited for her food allergies. 

So we had a quick drink and wanted to find another place. The server was disappointed learning this- so he pursued immediately to removed silverware and everything in a rash fashion - way rash I thought, which made me feel that tips were not due.

We left and the host came charging down the street after us and proceeded to educate us on our poor manners and that 'karma' would have 'the better of us' 

We were shocked anybody would go out of their way to be so offensive after we just paid $28 for two drinks and spending mere 8 mins in the place.

Of my 20 years of dining all over the world I have never been to a place that went out of their way to display such pompess sense if entitlement. To quote the possibly most snooty person I have had the poor fortune of crossing paths with 'I hope karma will have the better of you'
author: Rasmus B.

description: Renowned for their roasted chicken. Crowded, long cooking time wait. Raw oysters.. Outside has street urchins (homeless druggies and the lovely SF urine smell on the sidewalks. My wife says I make a better roast chicken.. So we've been once, or twice in six years. Go try it though!
author: Kirk M.

description:
I loved the interior of the restaurant. So much natural light! 

We got there around 10:45 and there was already a line forming. By the time the doors opened there were at least 25 people in the line! So glad we got there early.

We got the Caesar salad and one of the pizzas to start. The dressing on the salad was pretty fishy, so if you're not into anchovies, you may not like it. Pizza was super flavorful and I loved the thin crust. 

As everyone has said you just have to get the roasted chicken. I've never tasted chicken that juicy. It took about an hour, like the menu said, but we never felt rushed to get out of there. The service was extremely lovely. 

Also I think I may have been converted to liking Bloody Marys after trying the one at Zuni. God it was amazing..
author: Yoonie Y.

description:
I have eaten here several times during off-peak hours, the food and services are always great.  They may not have some dinner items available when you show up but they are spot on with friendliness, service and their available food creations.  If you are hanging out with friends and don't need or want the additional crowd or scene of a packed restaurant, try ZUNI before dinner or during a late dinner (1 hour before close).

This is truly one of my favorite restaurants in the SF, Hayes valley and SOMO area.
author: Brett D.

description: Don't let the 60 minute wait for the roasted chicken hold you back from ordering cause all the other entrees take even longer (waited 70 minutes for it to get to our table). Terrible service.
author: Diana C.

description: Very Medicare in taste, super expensive, slow service when not very busy.  Three of us were there for for lunch and ordered middle priced dishes and  1/2 bottle of lowest priced wine.  Restaurant was not particularly busy.  After awhile the food arrived at room temperature (instead of hot or warm).  Taste of all three dishes was below average.   Total bill was $115. All three of us were disappointed.  We have eaten at far super our restaurants for 50%-60% of the cost.  Find yourself a good, satisfying restaurant and save $50.
author: Michael B.

description:
I'm giving two stars based on ambiance and the bread salad. Yup, you read it....bread salad.

Our trip to the great city of San Francisco started off with this one place that was 'sworn' as the 'best' chicken ever. Honestly, after waiting an HOUR for a chicken at $48.00 that had minimal taste, served cold and skin no longer crispy....with a very well behaved 7 year old and an exhausted boyfriend brought on a feeling of 'why did we just get this cold chicken?!'...we were tired and starving to the point of ordering the kale soup...which was served WARM....

One a side note, the couple next to us must have been VIPS or something because everyone was falling all over them to cater to them. I was tempted to ask if their dinner was warm. However the man and woman looked to be intoxicated and were eating nothing but oysters...served on the rocks....so their dinner should not be served warm nor hot.

Note to establishment, you want to charge $48 for chicken at approximately 4 or so pounds....serve it hot.

Treat all customers the same, same attention and same respect.

Drop the pretentious attitude and the notion that you are above everyone else. People are people and if they come to your place of business then fair treatment is what we expect to pay for.

Will I return and try this place again? Maybe....

Do I suggest this place to my friends and family? Absolutely not....

For under $5 I can make the same bread salad, chicken and serve it hot to my family and friends....with a smile and sans attitude....

**Update-So glad the last time we came-we avoided this place! Guess what? For a bit over twenty bucks-I was able to recreate the bread salad and made my own chickens at home better than ZC and hey Yelp Gang-THE FOOD WAS HOT! Also-I made the chickens into Cornish Game Hens. No fighting for breasts, thighs, wings...etc. $20 bucks-free parking-best wine in house-down to earth service-no rushing and most of all-intimate. ZC-$48 chicken-shame on you.**
author: Silvia C.

description: Fresh oysters, excellent variety of meat, fish and veggies.  Chicken for two came highly recommended, but you have to allow 45 min or an hour for it.  I had an excellent pork chop.  Wonderful location and friendly, relaxed atmosphere,  good wine and cocktails.
author: Glenn H.

description:
Two star for the food. The famous chicken was overrated. The bill was not worth the experience. 

Bumped this up to three star because we had a good server. He wad cool and was attentive.
author: Lily Y.

description:
I remember the first time I came here with my parents. Our waiter James was one of the nicest and most attentive servers I have ever met, so much so that I still remember him 2 years later. He recommended the chicken special with bread salad and we were quite honestly blown away by how tasty and unique it was. My parents ordered me a second one to take home so I could share it with my roommates.

I've been back here a few times since then and have not had and negative experiences. I'd recommend this cafe to someone looking for excellent food and a relaxed atmosphere.
author: Jacob A.

description:
I was really not impressed, at all, with this place. Yet another hyped SF restaurant that misses the mark. First off the restaurant is LOUD, forget trying to having a conversation...the acoustics are just terrible. Second, service sucked. I can't stand servers that wait until the end of your meal to kiss your ass for a tip. Our server, bc it's SO LOUD, totally missed all the oysters I ordered and only 2 were brought...of course he rarely checked on us so it wasn't until my entree was ready to come that he was able fix his mistake with the oysters. The server doesn't run the food, so the least the server could do was come and check on us as soon as the dishes are brought to the table, which he didn't do. 

As for the food. Not at all impressed. A tip about your burrata and figs, those figs should be warmed they were just cold, cut and thrown in the bowl...the burrata was terribly bland and frankly the combo of flavors between the figs and the burrata did not work. We had another app, but I'm blanking on what it was...clearly it wasn't memorable. I had the pork confit and duck sausage, the sausage was amazing...but overall the dish was plain. 2 small rectangle cuts of pork and one small link of sausage on top of a veg with some white beans, all for $34. I don't mind overpaying for a small entree when the flavors and presentation are amazing, this dish had neither of those. The other entree was steak and again, it was pretty boring and overpriced. 

Drinks weren't impressive either.
author: Dorothygale T.

description:
The Boyfriend has been taking this 6-days-a-week test prep class & has bee working really hard so I wanted to treat him to a nice belated birthday dinner with just the 2 of us.

We started with half a dozen Oysters that were really fresh, really sweet, & definitely fairly priced.  I did find a small shell fragment in one of my oysters though.  We then moved on to the House-cured anchovies which were not too salty or mushy but they looked really different from the ones we got @ Delfina (read my review).  We weren't sure what to do with the celery, cheese, & olives & wished there was a crostini or something to help hold everything together.

We got the Chicken for two with bread salad for our main course & it was so delicious!  The chicken was flavorful & moist.  The bread salad was bright & acidic & well balanced once it soaked up the chicken juices.

We ended with dessert where I got a Mascarpone tartlet which was light & fluffy but it didn't have very much flavor.  What flavor it did have was overwhelmed by the buttery crust.  It is a nice dessert but it would have ben better appreciated if I had had something more substantial - like a steak - for entree.  The guest of honor got a Meyer lemon sorbet.  It was not really sour but still had a nice pucker;  & I could even taste the fragrance of the fruit.  And the candied lemon was absolutely perfect.

We had been talking about eating here for 2+ years & now that we have enjoyed our meal, I can say that i lived to up to our expectations & it was worth the wait.
author: Karen S.

description:
My experience with the famous chicken seems so wildly out of sync with the effusive reviews for it, I'm wondering what it is I'm just not getting. It's lightly seasoned and roasted well and so achingly average. I've made better chicken at home, and that's not a compliment I give myself easily or often. And the bread salad that came with it... now I love a good zesty vinaigrette but the salad tasted like it was drenched in straight up balsamic vinegar; there was no balance of flavors. The (dubiously) good news is $50 chicken for two is a fair price, considering most single-serving chicken dishes at comparable restaurants go for $25ish elsewhere in the city. My dining partner and I ended up taking most of the chicken home and shredding it up for noodle soup the next day. Overall, the chicken was not worth the wait. 

Shoestring fries were nice and crunchy, but overly salty, so maybe request lightly salted fries if you're as sensitive to enthusiastic salting as I am. Cocktails were great. Servers were polite and attentive.
author: Angela N.

description:
Wow.  Just wow.  That was one DAMNED fine roast chicken.  Brought me back to France, and we were just there before comin' here.

Been there a couple times now.  It's always been tasty, ever dish and glass.  

Service is friendly and prompt.  Location's beautiful, and the view's pretty good, and generally interesting. :)

But the dinner.  OMG.  I *love* the food.  Love.  Love.  Love.
author: Dave B.

description:
Lovely place to spend an evening with the daughter!

We ordered the chicken, the famous chicken, you know that chicken that takes an hour to come out of the kitchen. Obviously we had to have a cocktail whilst we were waiting (bee sting for me, delicious, but heavy on the absinthe for those that don't like it as much as I do; & elderflower cocktail for her, one of the better examples I've tasted), therefore we had to order something to mop up the alcohol too. We chose piccolo fritto - truly delicious batter! & the fries. I don't know what Zuni Cafe calls them, but they were just like the game chips my mother used to make!  

The roast chicken was very good. What makes it legendary is the bread salad beneath it. San Francisco Magazine published some iconic San Francisco recipes last year, including this one, labelled sthg like SF on a budget, but this is one of those dishes I'm sure your arteries would prefer you not to eat too often, so I'll just eat it there!  And I will eat it again soon!

Word to the wise, most of the walk-in tables are uncomfortably positioned, until 9'ish, when it seems to become easy to walk into a good table. We booked & had a fantastic table overlooking the main dining room, we could see all the food we might try one day  if there are enough of us to not be stuffed on the chicken alone.
author: Joanna G.

description: Honestly, the Chicken was the only good thing here, but it was not out of this world either. The service was not the best I came for my dad's birthday, and they were quite rude, to be frank, and there Caesar salad was average. This place is all hype and overrated. Not planning to come back anytime soon until they put some fish on the menu and add more variety on there.
author: Ashwin C.

description:
First of all; Thank you Janice & Jeff.

Wow! My partner and I really enjoyed our experience here. From the quirky architecture outside to the alluring romance of the interior, we were enchanted by the smell of the beautiful crispy, juicy Chicken for Two wafting past our faces to many of the nearby tables. Upon entering the restaurant we were welcomed by warm smiles and offered a spot at the bar to have a martini as we waited for our table. (We arrived early)

We had no need for the menu as we followed the advice for all of the food and pairings from our fantastic and very knowledgable server, Jeff. 
This is how our night went 
7:30-11:15pm 

Hangar 1 dirty martini
(Yum)

Bouillot Crémant Rosé
(I love the bubbles)
Oysters, o-yummy oysters.
(6 pairs)

Chidaine Touraine (sav blanc)
(Smooth, fruity perfection)
Yellow-fin tuna confit crostini with avocado
(Yes please)
New potato salad with smoked bacon, crème fraîche, and pea shoots
(This ain't your granny's potato salad)
Caesar salad with white shrimp
(There's a reason it's been on the menu from the start)
Shoestring potatoes
(This is a vegetable right?!)


Capezzana Barco Reale di Carmignano
(Warmed my heart with spicy 
love)
Onion and nettle soup with croutons and Beecher's cheese
(What a savory surprise)
Ricotta gnocchi with Hen of the Woods mushrooms
(It's like a little hug from Jesus)
Llano secco pork chop with sweet potato purée and brussels sprouts
(Melted my little southern heart)
Zuni burger
(Because we had to)

Espresso
(Good idea after all the adult grape juice)
Gateau Victoire with whipped cream
(Thank you Julia Child!)
Profiteroles with coffee-cinnamon ice cream, bitter-sweet chocolate sauce and almonds
(Another hug from Jesus)

Hebiki scotch
(Because that's just how we do things)
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
This famous spot didn't disappoint. It was a beautifully designed restaurant that feels warm and welcoming. Service is excellent.

Menu changes a lot so hard to recommend any one thing though I didn't have anything bad here. The stand out and most famous item is the roast chicken. Expect to wait for it but it's definitely the best restaurant made house chicken you'll find in the city.
author: Victor W.

description: Stick with the basics. Cesar salad fabulous. Pasta great. Tuna dry over cooked farro sticky and bland.
author: Jackie K.

description:
That night, I took my time getting ready. I applied my make-up with care, combed my hair til its silky, ran a lint brush on my black leggings.

I felt pretty. 

Polished.

LIke a prized horse on the auction block.

Enough horsing around. Zuni Cafe is one of those SF restos that's both pretty (brick walls, ambient lighting) and polished (white tablecloths, waiters in collar shirts and ties). It occupies a weird triangular space on Market and Hayes sts. but once inside, you'll find there are nooks and cranies perfect for small groups or couples on dates.

The food is as good as the ambiance. When I think California cuisine at its best, Zuni takes the lead. The freshness of each dish and deliciousness of seasonal ingredients really shine. (I'm so in love with mushrooms right now!) 

Zuni's take on caesar salad has whole romaine lettuce, big blocks of crisp croutons, shredded parmesan and the dressing --whoa! You can taste the anchovy flavor, but it's not overpowering and the salad is not overdressed.

The ricotta gnocchi with sage, butter and walnuts was a recommendation from our server. To quote him: "its like little pillows of heaven!" and you know what? it was! I'm thinking, he must be a yelper too!

We also tried the pan roasted salmon with pancetta, brussel sprouts and chanterelle mushrooms. So delicious.  The fish was only 5 oz and I know it's probably wild caught, etc, etc but this was $27!

The roasted chicken and bread salad. Jeebus. The best roasted chicken ever?!? Sure. You get the golden brown crispy skin.  The moist, juicy meat.  It doesn't matter whether you're a breast, leg, thigh kinda guy, you get the WHOLE shebang. BUT. Let's just break this down for a minute. The cheap Asian in me says, that's equivalent to 8 rotisserie chickens at Costco! (or as Darryl P pointed out "that's 2 pork chops at nopa!") needless to say, I won't be ordering this anymore next time I come to Zuni. (unless I'm here on an expense account)

Zuni cafe still has room for improvement. Their cocktail menu doesn't impress me (good thing we brought wine) and I feel their dessert selections were ordinary. I was expecting a restaurant of this caliber to have better looking dessert options on the menu, but we weren't disappointed with a classic creme brulee. 

The service is friendly and unrushed. Perfect for catching up with friends in a classy, relaxed atmosphere. Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco treasure, so expense account or not, make sure not to miss it.
author: Janice C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF. One of the most perfect meals I've had - I came in for lunch with a friend on a late Sunday morning. We strolled in with no reservation and were surprised when they sat us right away. We ordered a bottle of white wine, enjoyed some oysters and shrimp to start. Super fresh, super tasty. And since the chicken takes 45 minutes, we ordered that right away. While we waited, we enjoyed the simple but delicious Caesar salad (and a plate of fries). And the chicken...I usually don't like ordering chicken because it can be kind of blah, but the Zuni Chicken is famous for a reason - juicy, crispy skin, tasty bread salad. Just perfect
author: Stacie C.

description:
I was told the Zuni's roasted chicken was a legend. I think it is a legend...of the urban variety. Sure, it's tender, but the skin tasted burnt, with no trace of any herbs or spices. Everyone at the table raved at the warm bread salad underneath, but it tasted more like warm oil salad to me. 

Main dish disaster aside, the apps were actually pretty awesome. The Piccolo Fritto featured sharp, bitter puntarelle with silky-sweet wildflower honey to draw out the bitters.
Silky little Nantucket Bay Scallops tasted like they went straight from the ocean onto my plate, and the deep green spinach lightened the butter sauce.
The Risotto was more of a soupy rice than the expected ricey soup. It swam in a chicken-stock-like-soup, and those plump grains of wild rice were actually pretty mind-blowing.
The first three are great, but feel free to pass on Rymee's Finocchiona. The finocchiona is tasty, but despite quality over quantity, it's just a smaller, more delicate version of your childhood sandwich topper. The salad with chicory and sunchokes is crisp and crunchy, but it's really just sliced roots.

I love Zuni, and I'd be crazy not to. The ingredients are top-notch and the menu has at least 6 words I can't pronounce and far more I can't define. But the dishes are really a compilation of good things rather than a combination. And I'd rather hold out for a good combination.
author: Kelsey C.

description: Roast chicken is great as is the wine list. Everything else though was a little useless. We decided to do 4 small plates and roast chickens. Beef with quinoa was great, burrata was too soggy, anchovies + kiwi + cheese did not land, gnocchi was too sweet. Go for the roast chicken.
author: Amritava D.

description: What a letdown, a legendary foodie spot that I'd always been curious about but never been. Famous for their chicken but needed 60 mins, decided that a burger is a good way to judge what the kitchen can do ... sadly not good !  For starters, Foccacia bread always just seems wrong for a burger (too much bread), as do those "shoestring" fries ... just not a fan, they get cold super quick and kinda awkward to eat, you gotta shovel them in to get a decent amount. The burger itself was kind of bland, not cooked well for med-rare, I LOVE and appreciate Grass-Fed meat and maybe that was it, just not enough fat to make it interesting ... burnt and crisped meat isn't healthy but once in a while that's OK for a burger, their meat seemed barely cooked, this just didn't deliver. The Avacado Crostini & salad were great, wine by the glass expensive but some really great bottle options and amazing prices if you're a Burgundy fan .. worth the visit on that alone. Next time, I'll try the Chicken !
author: Nick l.

description:
Zuni is my partner's favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  He wanted to go there to celebrate his 50th birthday with his family.  It was an ordeal getting a reservation for 7 and then they made me fill out a form that, if all 7 people did not show up, they would charge me $25 per person unless I updated them 48 hours in advance.  I had to give them a credit card number and sign and fax the form.  I called them 3 times to let them know that we were celebrating my partner's 50th birthday and to make sure they were up to date on how many people would be there.  

Unfortunately, the service was not what we typically expect from Zuni.  It took forever to get our drinks and our salad orders were mixed up and we had to trade plates.  Plus, I had told the waiter I wanted wine with my dinner but was halfway done with my dinner before he ever came to check on us.  By that time, it was too late to order wine.  Very disappointing service.  To make things worse, they did nothing to recognize my partner's birthday (even though we were opening presents at the table).  I was insulted that they made me jump through so many hoops to get the reservation and I called them 3 times but they did not even bother to acknowledge my partner's birthday.  

The food is still good but the service is obviously declining at this San Francisco institution.
author: Bob K.

description:
I took my partner in crime here the other day, for a nice lunch before the show.

Easy motorcycle parking.

Nice ambiance/decor.

Good service.

Good food BUT a wee bit overpriced for the quality.  Le wine list c'est un rip off total.

Tell the chef to ensure fresh romaine for the caesar salad.

I can now check this place off the list of places to eat at in sF.  No need for me to return.
author: Anthony D.

description:
As I haven't had the same opportunity to hit up as many of the awesome eateries around the Bay this past year, I was pretty thrilled when Zuni happened to be one that popped up on the calendar.  I have been looking forward to it for quite some time.  Everyone's made it out to be pretty epic.  'You gotta try the chicken, man!'  'Bread salad is to die for!'  Okay, roger that.  Choo choo, all aboard the chicken train!

So how'd it all pan out?

Can't say I was super impressed, but it was pretty decent overall. The bad: Got seated in an awkward nook upstairs where the acoustics were terrible.  The noise from the kitchen and other patrons below really carried up and made conversation a bit more strained.  It was also uncomfortably warm even after removing layers.  Truth be told, those are the only minor quibbles.

The service was excellent and the four of us all ended up having a good time.  The wine was flowing and the dishes were coming out at a perfect pace.  Can't remember exactly which appetizers we ordered, but I do remember having a large number of rather tasty olives and indulging in a creamy vegetable soup.

When our chicken finally came out, we were ready to destroy it.  It was cooked well enough, but not quite the crispy-caped superhero chicken that I was hoping it would be.  I was able to query my mental database and easily returned no less than three places (including home made) where I had superior or equivalent chicken of similar preparation.  Then again, it is just chicken--how tasty can chicken+skin possibly get?  Bread salad?  Sure, it was good, but there's a reason it sits under the chicken as its faithful sidekick.

All in all it was a good time, definitely a fine dining experience.  Next time I'll try some other dishes in hopes that I can leave and rave about them to no end.
author: Al C.

description: Zuni has long been a stalwart of the SF food scene, and rightfully so, with their delicious roast chicken, proper cocktails, and professional service. However, my last visit was all too disappointing. The place felt stuffy, come and gone, and the chicken is just a briny mass produced dish churned out not unlike a flame broiled Whopper. Over and over again. Salted flesh. The salads are salty small dishes that taste like hospital cafeteria food. This food is not complex, but feels churned out and way too thrown together to warrant any standing in the upper reaches of the SF food scene. (Yes, they still wear ties, but that does not mean the food is still good.) Zuni has expired. They need to reinvent. Go elsewhere.
author: Ronco B.

description:
Visiting San Francisco from out of town? Chances are you have been told to head to Zuni Cafe for their legendary roast chicken. After hearing about it over and over again, that is precisely what I did while heading to the Napa Valley for a music festival. Since I was flying into SFO, my friend and I figured we might as well make a night out of it. Alas, with her driving and me feeling the jet lag coming on, we didn't get to truly toast to the occassion, but an Abita Root Beer and Reed's Ginger Brew *almost" made up for that fact. 

Knowing the chicken takes almost an hour, we ordered immediately and had plenty of time to take in our surroundings and catch up. The restaurant itself is big and airy, with huge windows and a cozy feel. Would be perfect for a romantic date nigt. As for the chicken, it is as good as they say, however the bread salad it is served on top of is almost as good! My friend and I were fighting over the last pine nuts and currants, and the mustard greens were about as far from bitter as you can imagine. We also ordered the shoestring potatoes on the side, because who can eat chicken without potatoes? They were fun and tasty, but nothing especially memorable. They were more fun to eat than anyhing. They sort of reminded me of those potato stix in a can that I loved when I was little. 

The price is fair and you will likely never have a better roast chicken. I definitely recommend.
