author: Caroline K.

description:
Not super impressed here. 

First off - place is listed as hayes valley - its definitely more market. The atmosphere was nice and the wait staff were good, but it took a while to get our first waters. 

The food was not great - the menu was actually really hard to understand - the way it was printed was really unclear - very odd alignment and bucketing - you couldnt just navigate to the "breakfast section" or "pasta section". Anyway, we got some mandarins in honey with sesame brittle, which were just a little weird. We got a pizza on which was really odd cheese that was not cooked with it. And we got the shoestring potatoes, which were excellent bc they were super fried and its impossible to go wrong with that.
author: Stephanie M.

description:
C'mon Zuni, seriously? You're resting on the reputation you earned 15 years ago. Knock it off.

The Good
Staff started out attentive.
Gnocchi is a pillowy delight, as always.
Bread + butter to start is delish.

The Meh
Squab app was ridiculously salty. Were you serving or curing it?
Persimmons in the $12 salad weren't ripe.
Pear sorbet had great flavor, but also had big hunks of ice. :-(
Shoestring fries were cold and tasted like potato stix from a can. Double :-(
Espressos to end the night were watery and bitter. Cmon!
Server full on disappeared towards the end of the meal. We had to flag someone down for the check, then flag someone down to take the card. 

Overall, eh, there's a lot of good food in this city for $150/couple. Leave Zuni for the tourists who don't know any better.
author: reyna s.

description: How many years have I been going here - 10, 20 years?  Most things are very good, some great, but the Caesar salad and roasted chicken are the two can't miss 5-star menu items.
author: Dennis S.

description:
Chicken, right away.
Caesar: extra croutons, please.
Bar seating is best.
author: Nish N.

description: Great food- easy to get to, the perfect spot for girlfriends getting together! One of our favorite places!
author: Martha R.

description: A little pricey and crowded. The food is great though. We got some local fish. The Cesar salad was amazing.
author: Khalid N.

description: Very solid. The chicken is obviously the must here -- it's a San Francisco staple at this point. The anchovies were good, and the shoe string fries are literally a mountain. Good service. Great wine and drink selection. Just a consistently pleasant experience.
author: Rita K.

description:
My BF and I came here after reading so many awesome yelp reviews. 

Perhaps my expectations were too high, but we both were really looking forward to their famous chicken. 

We ordered the chicken right when we got there on a Tuesday night, and it still took 1.5 hours to come out. Overall... we thought it was a bit dry, and the meat didn't fall off the bones (like good chicken should). Needless to say, to pay $48 for a chicken... we weren't impressed. 

Everything else was mediocre (pasta, clams, apps), and I felt that there wasn't anything that particularly stood out. Some day I'll give them another try, but in the mean time... there are so many other great options in SF. 

On the bright side, I do love their atmosphere, friendly & attentive waiters, and the view from the 2nd floor.
author: Cynthia L.

description: A true San Francisco classic - fantastic food, well-priced, in a warm atmosphere with great service. We go back every few months and have the oysters, the caesar salad, the chicken, the blue cheese - it is always a great night!
author: Paul T.

description:
Oh my.  Really tasty!  

Food:
1. Oysters - A..............  Really fresh
2. Fancy Salad - B
3. Chicken for 2 - A...............  Tender, flavorful but subtle.  The additions that came w/ it were also quite great.

Drinks:
Martinis, martinis & martinis - A  (old school traditional martinis, none of that craft cocktail crap)  
Altho, they do have trendy mixed drinks if you're into that kind of thing

Atmosphere: 
Not sure why they called it a "cafe"  kind of misleading, this is no cafe......  Restaurant is big, but tables are somewhat close to each other.  Ambiance is nice, classy but can get loud, busy.  Recommend sitting upstairs in the front room.   

Service:
Good & attentive

Price:
Ok.....  Is it worth the price?  Prob not.  Is French Laundry worth an Ipad?  Dunno.  Was the food delicious?  YES.  

It's an expensive place (3$$$).  So expect to shell out $$$.  Are you going to be full?  Depends on how much you order.  THANKFULLY, it's a larger than typical small plates kind of concept as w/ most of the restaurants these days.........
author: CatwomanRoar M.

description: My favorite restaurant EVER. Every time I am in town I make sure to get a reservation to get my chicken fix. Living down south I have had to become quite good at a mock chicken recipe if I want anything like the chicken here. Watch out Zuni you might have a strong competitor soon, okay, maybe not. I cant wait to visit again, thanks for providing outstanding food and service.
author: Miles M.

description: I don't even want to rate this restaurant as much as I want to say what happened. I called one evening to see if seating was available before I made my way to the restaurant.  The hostess who helped me on the phone was nice, but not informative. I specifically told her I would be dining alone, and I also told her specifically what I was interested in ordering since I did know ahead of time that it takes an hour to prepare.  She says no problem, come on in. I get to the restaurant after a streetcar ride and bus ride. I walk in and I'm excited to get to try this restaurant. I'm seated and I tell my waiter what I'd like, Chicken under a brick. He informs me they only serve this as a whole chicken, and it's $50. Now I'm a little upset because I called ahead and told the hostess I was dining alone, but she did not mention they only serve this dish as a whole chicken. I didn't even mind the price, but there's no way I can eat even half a chicken much less a whole one. Plus, to make matters worse I was flying out the next morning so it didn't even make sense to take leftovers back to the hotel. Needless to say I was very disappointed since I had trekked all the way to the restaurant for nothing. By this time I was so frustrated I didn't even want anything they had to offer, and just left to make my trek back toward another area to find dinner.
author: Kate D.

description:
Great place to have a very long dinner with good company.

Get:
Chicken - Signature Dish for a reason.  Very expensive for chicken, but still awesome.  Warning: If you order this, you will be at the restaurant for over 2 hours...

Fries - Huge portion, taste great, super duper thin fries,  Careful not to fill up on it.

Okay:
Caeser Salad - Just a standard decent causer salad.  Good app.

Avoid:
Anchovies - It was just a small portion and clumsily plated, overall not up the par with the rest of the restaurant.  It did taste decent tho.
author: Steven F.

description:
The Zuni is a great location for a lunch meeting, an early happy hour or a dinner date. I've been coming here for years and it surprised me that I neglected to review it. I just couldn't bare to leave it out of my list of good eats. 

I've sat in almost every area of the restaurant and the window seats are my favorite. Especially the corner one overlooking Market street. I could sit there for days eating oysters and drinking bloody mary's. Both of which are great here.

The one thing I miss, is working nearby and taking long or late lunches. Celebrating birthdays and promotions at Zuni means you deserve it. 

I like the cesar salads for the traditional flavor and with added anchovies. Add olives and the house bread with butter too. Then order up a wood fired pizza to split, sharing is caring and pairs well with the salad.  I love this meal and it's so Zuni to me. 

There is no question about the fact it's been on the 7x7 list of top eats in San Francisco.
author: Rebekah T.

description: Ok this place is a winner. Came here for lunch on a saturday and ordered oysters.. pretty fresh. Had the caesar salad and that was a GOOD caesar salad. The menu changes daily here so not sure if they'll have the spaghetti but it was one of the best ones i've had.. it was no traditional spaghetti.
author: Christine T.

description: I must say, I've been here couple of times and I've always love the food.  The Caesar salad is absolutely delicious.  Unfortunately there are moments like today that puts such a distaste in my mouth to where I do not care to spend anymore money on this place.  The service... In particular the bar.. Is completely unacceptable.  Very rude, short, kurt...if you are not having a good day,  please do what you need to do and fix that and do not reflect that in your work as you are still trying to provide a great experience to the patrons in your establishment.  The manager needs to assess his/her current staffing and maybe needs to consider getting new and upbeat staff.  Thank goodness for the food otherwise, I would have given them a lower rating.
author: Cyrus M.

description: Zuni's roast chicken is spectacular! Totally worthy of the hype. Service was excellent and the other dishes were very good too.
author: Scott P.

description: Had the chicken.   Big surprise!  And it was not disappointing.  Make a reservation and try this place!
author: Patrick D.

description:
I am a big fan and normally I'd rate this place 4.5 star. I was at this place few days ago for lunch. I ordered the burger and I was very clear I wanted it pink and that is was important not to cook it well done. She assured my that they will get it right. Unfortunately as soon as I took my first bite it was apparent the burger was cooked well done. I didn't say anything but when the waitress asked me about the burger, I just showed her so she can see it with her own eyes. Her response was "Ha they usually get it right, I don't know what to say". 
You know for $32.00 for a burger and a beer (and nothing else) I expected a better response than just walking away from it. 
I love this place and I just didn't make any other comment. Didn't finish the burger; paid and just left. What can I say I just wanted my food served right; maybe next time.
author: Ernest P.

description: The Roasted Chicken is as good as everyone raves. It's definitely big enough for two people but my date had hungry eyes and opted to order the pasta dish of the night which was good but quite plain and forgettable. Unfortunately, they didn't have the gnocchi the night we were there as I was very curious about this dish. I'm always looking for good gnocchi. As good as the roasted chicken is, I think Isa does a very comparable job and it's a lot less expensive. I may come back one day to try the gnocchi but if I'm craving for roasted chicken, I'll just go to Isa and save myself $20
author: Chi N.

description: Great food, bread, wine, cocktails etc. Pro tip... go at lunch and get the zuni burger. Not as expensive as their dinners. Not as many of the typical Zuni dinner type people with their noses in the air and just as good as the chicken. If you can resist the urge to get apps, dessert and multiple cocktails/glasses of wine you can escape for a good price. Also, save room for a glass of wine next door at Hotel Biron.
author: Cory P.

description:
Hubby and I were arguing all the way to the restaurant on whether or not to order the chicken for dinner. First off it was our anniversary dinner - who orders chicken?!? Secondly, according to my fantasy friend Tony Bourdain, chicken is for boring people who don't know what to order. It was only based on the breathless recommendations of our friends, and the excellent salesmanship of our server, that we caved and did it.

It didn't disappoint. The flesh was soft and juicy, the bread was melty with all the chicken fat, the currants were tart and sweet, and the ricotta gnocchi we ordered on the side was re-donk-a-donk delish.

Oh and did I mention the bartenders are great and don't mind being asked to make something like a whisky drink and a margarita had a baby? Yeah, that too.

I do have to take away one star for what seems to be a weird service system. We had 2 separate servers and 3 bussers during our dinner. Between them, the white wine I ordered right when we got seated wasn't delivered till 30 minutes after. The table next to me spilled some water that hit our table, and that took another busser to clean up. And while it says "1 hour to prepare" on the menu, our bird took about an hour and a half. Not bad while you're toasting to your marriage with your hubby, but not ideal in any other circumstance.
author: Michi V.

description:
The food is awesome.  The service is abysmal.  Even the hostess who simply walked us to our table was so smug and weird!  Our waiter was aloof and odd.  Bad bad vibes here.  Very unhappy employees.

Now on to the good news, we enjoyed all the food we ordered:

Oysters
Tempura
Cesar saad
Chicken (it took one hour 15 minutes)
Pork chop
Hangar steak

Portion sizes pretty small for the extremely high prices.  Especially the hangar steak, it was more like an appetizer size.

P.s.  The  table  was very wobbly, tipsy. That's so annoying!  Things like that make it seem  so sloppy.  It was obvious and a normal attentive waiter would have fixed it.  Also, the  chairs are old and wooden and very uncomfortable,

And my last complaint, is that  it's very loud and we were basically yelling to hear each other.  But that's not really anyone's fault that works at the restaurant   The ladies next to us were very upset about  one woman's boss who kept making inappropriate comments to her and she was going to threaten him with a law suit and yes we all ended up listening to them as they were louder than  us.  I felt I could be a witness , if her lawsuit went to trial, as I heard all the details .
author: Foodlover B.

description:
By far, this is one of my favourite everyday yet excellent restaurants to visit in San Francisco. I really enjoyed my recent luncheon experience. 

The Cal.-Ital. menu features elemental dishes. Plain pizza was just what I needed, along with a dish featuring a melange of fresh clams, beans, and greens, rounded out the meal. Excellent bread was served with good olive oil. Salt-of-the-earth place, with friendly yet professional service. Wine list had many worldly gems, all mostly affordable. Decor and corner location of this establishment make this place even more likable. 

Can't go wrong dining here.
author: Richard M.

description:
all i gotta say is..best. burger. ever. (in the bay area) next to Kronner Burger (oakland) 



to be continued.
author: Cynthia T.

description: I have been going to Zuni for 20 years.  This last time the bald gentleman was rude and did not want to service me. It was a dead Tuesday night and still the rude man said 20 min wait when there were open tables which could clearly be seen.   That man should be fired.
author: Jon B.

description:
This is a must for everyone visiting San Francisco. It is definitely one of the land mark restaurants that you have to try. Definitely get the shoe string fries and the whole chicken with salad and fried bread. This dish takes an hour to make but its worth the wait.
Definitely make reservations because this place gets packed even during the week. The staff is very knowledgeable and friendly.  They offer valet but its quite tricky to get there. Its a one way street , so make sure you are coming from the right direction of market.
author: Claudine V.

description: Oh my god the chicken. Do yourself a favour and eat a bird here. It might just change your whole outlook on life and Thanksgiving as we all know it. FYI, there's a good recipe for this on smitten kitchen if anyone is interested in trying to make it on their own.
author: Weiyi Y.

description:
The chicken is absolutely not overrated. It was cooked to perfection, well seasoned and the bread salad that it came with was to die for. Other things were ordered that were also very good: Shoestring fries, cease salad and a special scallop appetizer.

Even though the deserts we ordered were meh (flourless chocolate tart and some pudding) I am still going with 5 stars. Service was exceptional and very friendly. 

Again the chicken, omg so good.
author: Lulu S.

description:
Pre-Ballet dinner found us at Zuni's doorstep.  This place is ALWAYS booked so we were excited that the planets finally lined up

Given we had 1 of the first rezzies of the evening, found it weird that they *still* made us wait at the bar for 15 min before they would seat us.....we're on a timetable folks!

Elderflower Cocktail - too much grapefruit & not enough elderflower but liked the sparkling wine it was paired with....but would probably skip it next time

Arugula, Endive, Asparagus salad - tons of arugula & nowhere near enough endive

Polenta w/ Marscapone - I think they actually gave me the Parmesan since there were teeny shreds of cheese instead of a dollop of creamy marscapone but regardless, this was out of this world delish - super creamy & smooth polenta

Ricotta Gnocchi - omg was this phenomenal!!  I've never had gnocchi like this before - the tenderest dumplings all creamy that practically melted in our mouths - paired w/ Trumpet Mushrooms & Nettles.....wasn't too mushroomy as they let the dumpling have center stage.....could have had like 3 orders of this!

Dessert was a miss - nothing really floated our boats, combined w/ the fact we wouldn't have had enough time since they seated us late & we had a ballet to catch, we were forced to pass......

But would look forward to coming back for that polenta & gnocchi, any day!!

NOTE:  Veggies beware of the Potato & Leek Soup - it's made w/ chicken stock!  Always pays to ask!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
Man, I felt I wasted a wonderful Sunday brunch for coming here.

With much expectations, my friends & I came and left unhappy

The food is alright, the chicken is expensive but it doesn't really taste like its out of this world and it takes an hour to prepare, wtf?

The fish was FISHY (seabass) and the burger is better than average, but again, lack of wow factors.

The place is super busy, I really don't know why, perhaps locations play a key factor in it?

I do not recommend this place.
author: Ken H.

description:
Came here with a group of 10 for brunch...that was an ordeal in itself. *sigh.  I wanted to come around 12, and they only had 11AM open...when they opened. My group got here a bit early and waited around outside a bit. We saw the staff get prepped and ready to go, which is kind of nice.

The place itself feels huge. Giant space, open plans, a loft upstairs that overlooks the downstairs. Only strange thing is looking at their awning from above - its quite dirty...and after a light shower, its really apparent that no one washes that thing.

The food was mostly just OK. The portions are quite small, so don't expect to fill up on just one order.

French Toast: One of the better items I had. If I could stand an entire meal of sweet, I'd go for this.

Flank Steak: tiny portion. Their sauce was the best part of this. Our waiter made a note to clarify that their mid-rare would be fine with me, and I said yes. Except...now I'm expecting mid-rare, and they gave me something closer to medium. Sad face.

Sausage: Pretty delicious. Also tiny portion. The sausage itself was moist. 

Roasted Chicken with Bread Salad: It IS worth the hype. The chicken was delicious, and very moist. The bread salad...was a little too greasy and sour (I assume they used some sort of sourdough bread). But the chicken was delicious.
author: Lily W.

description:
I am sad to write this review of one of my favorite San Francisco institutions. But sadly the time has come as Zuni cafe has been inflicted by the common "popular restaurant" bug.

Symptoms: over a period of time really good restaurants develop bad attitudes - terrible service, chronic overbooking, pushy selling of drinks and lasse faire approach to cooking.

Case in point: Arrived for a 8:15 reservation with the in-laws on a Friday evening. Part of the standard itinerary when they are in town. 
Bar was packed. We were asked to wait there even though there was no space. Tried to order a drink at the bar but apparently we had to wait for someone to come to us. No one did but bartender yelled at us to order. 
8:30 still no sign of table. More people getting crammed into the bar area. Crazy noise level definitely way above what you would expect in a restaurant. 

8:40 we are seated. Waiter tries to push more drinks on us. We order food and a couple of glasses of wine to pair with it.Thankfully we were seated upstairs where the decibel level was slightly better.

Apps: heirloom tomato soup ( not bad), mergez (hubby liked it), clams, Caesar salad (decent) 

After almost a 30 minute break the entrees finally arrived. 

Entrees: whole trout (tasty but very dry, overcooked), salmon (tasty but tiny portion for $29, duck (a bit chewy and the wild rice with it was inedible)
And they forgot the wine that my father in law had specially paired with the duck 

Desserts: suckers for punishment my hubby and mom in law got dessert - gateau victorie (really dry), fig tart (passable)

For a whopping $260 plus tip bill we had 3.5 star food, a 2 star service and a meh (2-3 star) experience overall 

Won't be returning unless there is an emergency
author: Cookie M.

description: CHICKEN!!!!!!!!!!!!!! You MUST get the roast Chicken. It takes 1 hour to make and it's worth every min. Also the bar tender was great! Truly a great meal. I will go back often!
author: Gwen L.

description:
I phoned ahead since we didn't have reservations and the host said to come along and that walk-ins had been getting seated pretty quickly since it was cold and raining. Well we arrived and were promptly offered a table in the waiting area by the window or standing to eat at the bar. We were offered a shawl since it was pretty frigid sitting right against the big windows near the door. There were open tables visible in other parts of the restaurant throughout our meal, but the host said none were available.  

The food has always been great and I've been coming here for years. So next we were told that all of the shawls were out being cleaned. To cut to the chase the food was as good as usual but between the host and the wait staff the experience was terrible. My second glass of wine sat on the bar waiting to be brought to the table. It did make it to me before I finished my last bite of entree. I actually had to get up from the table to ask to have it served.

I hope Judy Rodgers wasn't looking down at what her jewel of a restaurant has become.
author: J H.

description:
Have savored ZC for over 10 yrs & were thrilled to snag a 7-top for Father's Day dinner.  Muchas gracias to the good folks who worked so patiently to facilitate.  We brought my dad from out of town for a first-time Zuni treat.  Having been to Boulevard, our other SF benchmark, the previous night, we were primed for extended dining bliss.

Bottom line--the food, as usual, never disappoints.  The Caesar, the chicken, the oysters, all hit their mark.  

However--for the first time in 40+ dining experiences, the service disappointed big-time.  Side plates for bread & appetizers were doled out only on request.  The bus boys had itchy trigger fingers & wanted to clear our table ASAP.  No time to linger over the last bits of dessert.  Our server became progressively less-attentive once our entrees were served.  We were seated at 5PM & the place was far from full.

Our advice:  don't go to Zuni w/ more than a 5-top or your server will check out knowing they're guaranteed 18% minimum for the large party. 

Our total spend equalled our Boulevard tab the night before.  Unfortunately it was less-than-well-earned at Zuni.  When you're willing to drop $500+ for dinner (we brought the wine) you should reasonably expect 5-star service.
author: B. A.

description: This is one of new favorite places to eat in San Fran. It was recommended to us and it didn't disappoint. There was a bit of wait when we got there which was fine because they had a jazz pianist right next to the bar which was a cool copper bar. When we were sat at our table we ordered the chicken right away since we know it takes an hour. That was one of the best chicken dishes I've ever eaten. it was well worth the wait. We also ordered the pork shoulder and the trout which was to be honest disappointing. Im glad we decided to do a family style meal because if i ordered either of those by itself it would be left hungry but the chicken made up for both. Drinks were great and the service was nice. The place was bright and we really liked the decor.
author: Alan S.

description:
Caesar salad, roast chicken, a bottle of Loire white - simple but perfection. I must admit that I usually get the same thing when I go to Zuni which isn't my normal course of action. But that combo is so delicious! Zuni makes the best chicken in SF - game over.  It is well worth the 45 minute wait. The greens and the panzanella just add to the dish. But the real true measure of the restaurant is the salad. So simple and yet so hard to make delicious after we have all had it a hundred times at bad chain restaurants. It's redeemed here. I have had other dishes on occasion and they have been good as well. 

Zuni is a true SF institution that is still operating at the top of its game. I love how the restaurant brings all different facets of the city together. The atmosphere is warm and the big windows on Market St frame the streetscape. Ok I'm going on a bit more than usual and verbosely at that but Zuni is a special place.
author: Michael E.

description: We could not enjoy the good food'cuzz we went though the wrong door (omg) so the bar tender let us go back to the street (cold raining) to use the right door, on the process one of the seniors felt down (2 seniors 3 adults and 1 little baby, remenber, kick out to the cold and rain for using the wrong door), so the senior felt down inside the bar, it was a mess, he landed ON TOP OF THE SILVERWARE! (Forks and knives). The manager and the bar tender poorly managed the situation let us go back to the street and use the "right" door,  after that nobody took care of us for like 5 or 10 min. I'm a restaurant manager at Denver Colorado, so I know very clear how to handle this situations and of course we left very offended. Better u have good food guys, because the service needs a "little" improvement.
author: Alejandro G.

description:
Okay, I tried the chicken everyone raves about. Jesus, people, their other meals are much more flavorful and worth the money. 

My boyfriend and I ordered the chicken; we felt fairly ripped off. Fifty bucks for chicken that was good but certainly not worth fifty dollars. I kept thinking that I could have eaten a Costco chicken for six dollars and it would be just as satisfying as this chicken. 

However, their service was still excellent and the other dishes proved wonderful. Also, it is 1000 times quieter in the dining area versus the bar area.

I absolutely have no qualms about paying four dollars an oyster. Their vinaigrette is simply perfect with oysters. I couldn't eat enough but my wallet placed a limitation. 

In short, if you like more gutsy meals, try their other dishes. Don't get the chicken.
author: Elsvette B.

description: Another place I must visit when in the Bay Area. I've been going to Zuni since the 80's when it as a tiny restaurant. Order the chicken the moment you arrive then sit back with some oysters and salad and enjoy the people watching. Truly a gift to the city.
author: mary r.

description:
I've been here many times and the food is OK. Food 2-3 stars.  Ambiance 5 stars and service is usually 4 stars.  Not recently. 

 I live in the neighborhood and my wife likes it so we go and ignore that it is way overpriced tourist bait. Usually the food is served fairly cold.  The place is on two levels and like most larger places they struggle to get it to you quickly. I get that. It's a destination and 90% of your value is that you're eating at Zuni.  Some of the tables even have a view of the restaurant . But they really don't try very hard. Why bother, there's a line after all. This is like some of the "best" places in any city, Paris to NYC to here.  Long line, no real value for the price. People show up anyway. 

Today my soup was so hot , (surprising as hell for a place that puts out so little effort.) that I burnt the #%*! out of my mouth. I was shocked because getting food that isn't ice cold is generally a challenge Zuni isn't up to. So I burnt my mouth and couldn't eat my soup. Kind of my bad. I mean, I probably should be open to them serving hot food for once. I must have looked pained because my waiter asked what was up. I explained and he did his job. Apologized. Offered a different dish, etc. really did it right. 

Then the manager came over. He explained how as a first timer I probably didn't appreciate how they made each dish to order and sometimes they might be hot. REALLY? Apparently condescension is the new apology. Waiter earned a 30% tip. Manager eared them this 2 star review. 

So I don't mind that you're a mediocre  restaurant in a nice space.  Or that you make mediocre food. But please, don't treat me like I'm the asshole for showing up any paying for your overpriced operation. I mean, I AM the asshole for showing up after such poor food every time I've been here, but PLEASE don't treat me that way. Leave me my illusion that I'm not being ripped off.

If someone beats the manager senseless and sends me some pics I'll be back. It's a short walk and my wife likes it. Otherwise I will walk the 3 extra blocks to McDonalds.
author: Don C.

description:
Zuni cafe was a recommendation from a friend as well as a restaurant we saw on many lists for places to eat in San Francisco. The restaurant did not disappoint. 
It's a beautiful 2 floor space with lots of windows and light. 
We ordered the gnocchi appetizer which was so light and eggy as well as the beet salad. The chicken for 2 entree was fantastic. I hardly ever order chicken at a restaurant but I highly recommend this dish. It comes with greens and a toasted bread stuffing. 
Unfortunately no room for dessert! 
Would definitely return here.
author: Marissa C.

description: Very good place. The neighborhood is really nice, and the decor is too. We had the shoestring potatoes and chicken for two, along with the polenta. Everything was great, especially the polenta!
author: Zach H.

description:
So wanted that damn chicken. But couldn't wait the hour.

I thought the caesar ROCKED.
The orange salad was awesome too.
Great glass of wine and top notch service.
Didn't love the mahi or the polenta - neither were flavorful.

Fun for late night.

Not cheap, but fun and urbane.
author: Andrew K.

description:
My co-workers and I went to Zuni's for a goodbye lunch, and the entire experience was o.k. I don't mind paying for an expensive meal, but I think that the meal was not worth the high price.

The best part of the experience was our waiter (and I'm sorry that I don't remember his name). He was great at explaining some menu items that were disguised by unnecessarily complicated names.  I had the lamb - and while tasty - the portion was tiny. I got one chop from some anorexic lamb and three baby chunks of lamb meat on a skinny wooden skewer. Needless to say, this is not a place to go if you're really hungry.

One of my co-workers got the pizza with the mushrooms and shaved cheese (about $14) and she loved it. 

Overall, an ok experience, but I'm not sure I'd go again.
author: Jay P.

description: This is my favorite place in the city for a burger. Excellent food, top notch service...they even figured out it was my birthday! Gotta love it! Thanks Zuni Cafe for a delicious birthday lunch!
author: Kim B.

description:
Roast chicken is pricey but I think it's worth trying at least once if you are curious about it. It does take them about an hour to cook it though, so make sure you come on a day where you have plenty of time. I thought the chicken was pretty good but not amazing. The best part of the dish was the bread salad underneath the chicken. It is super oily, which would usually bother me, but it was so tasty that I could not stop eating it! The dish is supposed to be for 2 people but it's a pretty good amount of food. I would recommend getting that to split among 3-4 people and maybe a few other things.
I also enjoyed the shoestring fries but not much else, the scallop dish that day was definitely not worth the price.

We came here in the late afternoon before the ballet, and there wasn't that much space for us to sit. We grabbed a bar table and all crowded around it, luckily they didn't mind. They don't start dinner service until 5pm though and they would not give the dinner menus until exactly 5pm. The chicken is on the afternoon menu but generally the afternoon menu is limited.
author: Sophie Y.

description:
So over-rated it defies description.
It's not that it's overpriced, but the portions are very small for what you pay.  The "signature" chicken dish is frequently undercooked and nothing special.
And the food is no better than at less "trendy" spots.  3 stars (average) for the food, 1 star (poor) for the unpleasant environment (see below) = 2 stars
Main complaint - the noise - oppressive and I would guess probably actually not healthy.  When you have to scream to be heard by your dining companions, something is very wrong IMHO.  Maybe it's just I, but it's hard to believe people prefer such a concussive atmosphere.
author: S K.

description: We came for lunch so the menu was limited. My friend and I had the burger and my other friend had the sausage. It was all delicious. I especially liked the pickled radish and focaccia bread the burger came on. It was soft and paired perfectly with the patty. We also ordered a piece of their chocolate flourless cake. Was so tasty. Melted in my mouth and the cream on top complimented it perfectly. A little pricey but would come here once in a while. I definitely want to come back for dinner and see what other dishes they have to offer.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Called for lunch reservation and it was booked, but they said there was room at the bar. So we arrived and got a great window seat. 

Our server was a bit aloof and below average. 

Food was excellent.  I had a pasta w crisp cauliflower, raisins, and other stuff I can't remember.  Wonderful. I left nothing on the plate.  My wife got a pork dish and was very happy.  We had a panna cotta that was smooth, not too sweet and fruit accompanying matched perfect.  

Nice open and social ambiance.
author: David D.

description:
Good service, but I don't understand hypes about their chicken. It did take about an hour, but it's good amount time to have some drinks and nice chat with friends. The famous chicken was just a baked chicken, it comes with nice bread pudding, but really it's a baked chicken that anyone can make it at home. It would have been nice if the skin was a little crispier. Maybe I made a mistake that I ordered a quail salad and the chicken?
The location is a little odd, but inside of it is very nice. I will go back, but I won't get the chicken for sure. They seem to have other things look interesting.
author: Anna H.

description:
Just marvelous.  Our visit was completely wonderful.  

We came on a beautiful  Saturday with late lunch reservations.  We were immediately charmed by the eccentric shape of the restaurant, the open kitchen, the wood burning stove and the stack of firewood near our table.  We were clustered on a corner our table and group fitting neatly up against the big windows facing Market St..

Our waiter showed up promptly and we immediately told him our foursome were there to share the chicken, he immediately put in the order (it takes an hour to cook) then he returned so we could enjot drinks and order lots from the menu.

Everything is fresh, simple and almost perfect in execution.  We had a soup with wilted kale and a lovely dollop of broiled tomato on top.  Just exquisite.  The roasted Cauliflower penne was also wonderful.  

We loved the chicken, succulent, crispy skin beautiful bread salad tucked inside the sliced portions.  Simple, wonderful.  Worth everyone's while.
author: Don P.

description:
(See pics) Review #1164. Super snooty service if you don't order drinks. The extra star was for the other server whom we were able to ask to get extra bread.

We came here for a business lunch (April 5 and server name was Sarah from receipt) and could not wait for the minimum 1-hour chicken. The grass fed beef burger was only okay. The beef patty was not with any major flavor and the focaccia bread was too oily so I could not finish the bread. Pearl's has way better burgers. My colleagues' dishes looked just okay and didn't impress enough to take pictures.

The horrible part of the lunch was the service. As soon as we decided to not order any alcohol, the server turned into a pissed-off face. When we tried to get more bread (4 small slices for 4 people as starter), she practically avoided the table altogether. Eventually we were able to ask the other server to bring us bread.

When people said you should tip generously because the servers rely on it as the major source of the income. I agreed and generally tip 23-25%.

But for the restaurant, I cannot recommend if that's how they treat their customers. Ultimately it should not matter what you order to measure the service. And just as it's their hard earned money, so is ours.
author: T L.

description:
Awesome! From the service to the cocktails to the menu, simply fantastic! We walked in fifteen minutes before dinner service with no reservation. We told the host we would like to have dinner. She was super welcoming and asked for my name, then saw us to the bar, where we started with drinks before service started. The bartender whipped up our drinks (The Captain & Margarita) in no time. Shortly thereafter (6pm) we were approached by a gentleman who saw us to our table. Another gentleman kindly swooped up my jacket, which I had accidentally left at the bar, and brought it to our table. Between the two of us we shared the Yellowfin tuna appetizer, the kale and sorrel salad, the rabbit and the sirloin (which they prepared to a beautifully done black and blue... Jaws dropped!) The service was on point, as they are definitely well staffed.

Such an enjoyable experience! I will definitely be returning. Thank you Zuni staff of Tuesday February 24th!
author: Cyrus N.

description:
San Francisco. Sigh...  Such a lovely city.

We sat down next to this old couple.  It is their favorite restaurant and they come here all the time.   When they learned that we ordered the chicken, they smiled and said that's what they just finished.   Then they left, it was 7:15pm or so.

The new young couple sat down and chatted amiably.  When our chicken arrived, they said they ordered the same.  We smiled, but were too busy eating.  The Zuni Chardonnay paired very nicely with the chicken.

The pair of ladies on our other side were finishing the oysters and half way through a bottle of wine.  Then their chicken arrived.  Wow!  In this tight quarter over an hour, 4 chicken were consumed.

Yes, order the chicken.  It is $48 for two to three people.  Pair it with their Chardonnay. It takes about 45 minutes to arrive.  Be patient or order something light to chew on.

The Kumquat ice cream was exquisite with the nice strong coffee.
author: Sin-Yaw W.

description:
Winner winner chicken dinner!

Finally made it in to Zuni. Got a prime seat up above the kitchen so we could see all the action. The fowl lived up to the hype. Loved the tender meat and juicy bread salad. Started off with a heirloom tomato app that was also very good. Great cocktails.
author: Nicole W.

description: This landmark restaurant is absolutely delicious...from start to finish.  We were walk-ins after trying to get a reservation...and seating upstairs was perfect (only waited 5 minutes).  Jeff, our server, has more charisma and charm than most, and he guided us through the meal, the wine, and dessert.  We didn't want to wait for the chicken dish, which requires about 75 minutes of preparation, but we will return for that signature dish (it looked amazing).  I cannot wait to return!
author: Jeannie B.

description: The food at Zuni is amazing! Most reviewers rave about the chicken for two which is very good. We opted for something different, starting with the ricotta gnocchi appetizer, I am certain no one makes it as good as Zuni. We also tried the Llano Seco Ranch porchetta which was served with polenta and to die for! They had rabbit on the menu and we never pass that up so decided to try it, again, amazing!!  Dinner at Zuni is not complete without a side of shoe string fries. I need to go back soon.
author: G A.

description: Remarkable food, difficult to describe.  Exquisitely presented. Exotic menu. Great bread and rolls. Fabulous desserts.  Didn't have time for the chicken for two people, but I hear it's worth the wait.
author: Jerry Y.

description: Great chicken. Nice dessert selection. Attentive waitstaff. A downside - it is very noisy. It is well set up for larger groups - 6 or 8. Good parking across Market.
author: Mike H.

description: Finally went and ordered the famous chicken. It was everything and more, totally worth the wait. The staff was also nice and accommodating as we arrived without a reservation. And their wine list was quite appealing. I just wish it wasn't such a drafty spot, but not enough of a problem to know my review down by a star.
author: Erin W.

description:
One of the best dining experiences in the city. The service is unbelievably perfect, the food is incredible and well worth the money, and the atmosphere is calming and aesthetically pleasing. The oysters are so good, my family always gets two dozen! The goat cheese appetizer is absolutely delicious, and they have one of the best rosé's I've ever had.

Treat yo' self and go to Zuni.
author: Emma S.

description:
My boss closed the office for 3 hours yesterday afternoon so that we could go  observe our beliefs.  Since I believe in the City and its food,  I made a reservation to meet up with a friend and her son for lunch at Zuni Cafe.

We started with a Caesar salad and the broccoli di ciccio and Manila clams a la plancha with Rancho Gordo white beans, lemon zest, and garlic.  The Caesar was tasty with a fantastic garlicky, anchovy dressing.  And those beans were just off the hook.  Smooth and delicious.  Both dishes were so good, I used the bread to sop up the plate so I wouldn't miss/waste any of the flavors!

But there was something else we really came for.  For years I'd heard of and wondered about this dish.  I even felt inferior as a native San Franciscan for never having tried it.  Even 7x7 Magazine seemed to remind me of this inferiority by listing it high on the Big Eat every year.  Unfortunately, on previous visits to Zuni, it just didn't feel like the thing to order.  Maybe it was the company or maybe it was because I was there for brunch during those other times.  

No matter.  My friend and I were here now and we were both here for the roasted chicken for two with warm Tuscan-style bread salad.

OhmigawdOhmigawdOhmigawd YUM!  

The chicken was juicy with fantastic crispy skin.  My friend and I inhaled it in.  The Boy loved it also.  The bread salad is indescribable.  There was a crunch to it but it was also soft.  There was currants and pine nuts mixed in. We all loved it.  The presentation was beautiful before we started in on it.  And I don't care what they say.  The dish is not for two.  There were 2.5 people working on it at the table and we almost finished half of it.  My friend and I split the leftovers so technically it fed 4.5 people.  

And I no longer feel inferior because I have eaten what every native San Franciscan should at least once in their lifetime.

We also ordered the bowl of polenta with mascarpone that went very well with the chicken.

All in all, a great meal and a delicious way to renew my belief in this City and its food.
author: J. P.

description: Amazing food! Ordered the bruschetta, spring salad, Brussels sprouts, and the rustic pizza. The service on the other hand was pretty terrible. Had to ask for every refill on tea and water. Never came by on his own except to drop the check off.
author: Kahlua A.

description:
Here's the memo in case you haven't gotten it: Order the perfect roast chicken served over a bread salad and dressed greens and a glass of house red.

This place isn't overrated and I'd go back in a heartbeat. 

A few more things...
- Make a reservation
- Expect a phenomenally browned bird with crackling skin and moist meat and exceptional service
- Enjoy the lovely ambiance as the restaurant is surrounded by glass walls
-  Take the public transpo or cab as there's street parking only
author: Eunice M.

description:
I had high expectations for this place.  It was on a list of top 10 places to eat in the WORLD.... For the prices, the food is not worth it.  We had a burger, and one of their pizzas.  Left me feeling exactly how the 2 star is titled "meh. i've experienced better."  and for a better price. 

Save yourself the long wait, and dent in your wallet.
author: Gloria G.

description:
First, a disclaimer: I've only been to Zuni Cafe once, and I appreciate that once may not be enough to judge a restaurant's merits.

I understand that I belong in the minority of people who think the roast chicken for two is overrated. Many clearly love it, but I found my chicken to be bland and the bread salad soggy and unimpressive. It was definitely not worth the hour-long wait. We did order an appetizer that I can't recall - it was a cured fish plate - but I remember it being very flavorful. The service was quite adequate, if unremarkable. The restaurant's design is uneven, in that the ground level is very beautiful but the extensions on the upper level can be - at random - cramped or spacious, have a decent view of the street or look directly into someone's living room. 

Obviously, a restaurant so well-regarded must have its strengths. There appeared to be regulars who were enjoying their non-roast-chicken meals at adjacent tables. Perhaps I will revisit and update this review, but at the moment I find little motivation to do so from our first meal at Zuni Cafe.
author: Ro C.

description: I loved my experience with Zuni Cafe. The food is delicious and the service is great. The roasted chicken was the best chicken I have ever had. Its a must have! The bread and chcocolate cake is also tasty. I will come back to this restaurant.
author: J.J. S.

description: I've been coming to Zuni for years and always enjoyed the burger.  No longer.  Now it is a tasteless slab of meat that costs $19.  I didn't have it with cheese because I wanted to taste the meat, but that was a mistake.  Others who have written positive reviews about the burger seem to enjoy it with cheese, which adds flavor, so that would be the way to go.  I still like the decor and service, so 1 star for that.
author: Robert R.

description:
Disappointed and upset. I have been there before and it was good. The manager,Rob, was regrettable. We voiced a complaint, said he would look into it but did not have the decency to get back to us. His reply was "oh, I thought this was for our information only".
 Incident, we had a 2pm reserv, got their by 1:50. We saw a empty table that would fit our group of 6. Thought it was for someone, waited till 2:20 before we got seated which was next to the same empty table we had being watching. Maybe 20 mins later a party of 4 got seated there. Spoke to manager at that point. For the next 5 mins there was a lot of servers attending to us, but that ended. 

2nd fault, we had ordered the chicken at 2:15 (takes an hour). It didn't arrive until 3:40, but the previous empty table got their chicken before us and they had not pre ordered!! (we asked them personally).  We expected quality service and a response since this not a fly by restaurant. They say the restaurant can be judged by the tone that the manager sets. Obviously, the manager did not set the bar very high or was sitting on past reputations.

Unfortunately, our group and other friends will  not be returning. Such a shame for what was an exceptional restaurant before.
author: LQ W.

description: Zuni is terrific.  The food is light, delicious, well-prepared.  Great choice!
author: Kirsten P.

description:
Tablecloth art at Cafe Zuni:

Nine Men Waiting on One Hour Chicken:

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oqsu3pKpgRMGHj9QItsx0A#9H4e_vG0jKdyPMPl6NKe5g
author: Jay D.

description:
3.5 stars.

I had the avocado, beet & arugula salad and split the chicken with a friend. All I have to say is: way, way overpriced. Firstly, do they know their neighbors at Limon Rotisserie can make rotisserie chicken that's half the price and just as good, if not better? Secondly, did they know I can make a juicy chicken about 80% as good as theirs for about $6? If $6:80% and $48:100%... then they are way, way overpriced.

I did not think their arugula beet avocado salad was too great.. and they were stingy with the beets and avocado, and the salad cost me $8 or so.

I also did not dig the slightly soggy bread and the very bitter greens that went with it. I would have preferred my greens be arugula and on the side, tossed in dressing. I would have also preferred the bread nice and toasty on the side, with my option of dipping it into the chicken juices as I liked. But admittedly, overall, their chicken was pretty good. Tasty indeed... but for 48 whopping bucks, I want more! A more fair price would be...$28-32.

Overall, I am quite underwhelmed by my expectations and the rave reviews I've heard of from this place, but I will come back someday to try their infamous burger... hopefully not to be underwhelmed again.
author: Joanne Y.

description: Great tender juicy tasty burgers--fantastic shoestring fries. Too pricey though, it should've included any cheese for that price, but no they charged extra - how cheesy is that :-/
author: Marni E.

description:
I only had a few days in San Francisco, but Zuni Cafe was a must do. I wasn't able to find a reservation available for any of the time I had free, so I took a chance and tried a walk in on Friday just before 5. Luckily, I seemed to beat the rush and got a table! It was packed by the time I left, so I was there just in time. Worth noting: the dinner menu isn't printed or available until 6, so the late afternoon menu is very abbreviated and basically a best of list.

I had a glass of the chenin blanc, the shoestring potatoes and the caesar, all at the recommendation of my very good server. Everything was delicious and pretty reasonably priced, especially for SF.

I would definitely recommend booking well ahead of time and getting a reservation. That's the only thing I would change about my experience.
author: Tiffany I.

description:
A 3 hour lunch for the ages!

We arrived on time for our reservation and the place was hopping (Saturday so go figure). We are taken to our table which was a tad awkward, sitting next to each other on a strange angle. We asked to be moved to another table so we could talk better and without a problem we were seated at another table. No problem at all.

We started with drinks, fries and olives to tide us over while waiting for the roasted chicken for two (takes aprox an hour).  The fries are delicious and can be eaten daintily without looking like a starved prisoner. Thin, crispy and salted perfectly. The house-made catsup is the perfect accompaniment.  The olives were buttery and divine, a splendid mix. The conversation was so fantastic that before we knew it, an hour had passed and our chicken arrived. A wood oven roasted chicken, cut in pieces on top of a Tuscan style bread salad with currants and pine nuts and topped with greens - it was a thing of beauty. The chicken was moist all around, even the breast. Each piece had a caramelized, brown skin that was well seasoned and crispy in some parts. It was everything I had dreamed of and more! So worth the wait - which doesn't seem like a wait at all if dining with the right person.

Dessert is always the same for me here - the Gâteaux Victoire. Hands down the best flourless chocolate cake I've ever had. Not heavily dense and fudgy like most, it almost seems as though it's steamed like an English pudding and not super rich and chocolatey. Perfection.

An epic lunch indeed with one of my best friends. I'll remember this one for a while.

* Just a suggestion for the restaurant...If a reservation has been made, it's probably best to seat them at a table where the guests are looking at each other and save the side-by-side seats for walk-ins or single diners.
author: Katie S.

description:
My husband and I recently dined at Zuni and were pretty disappointed. I've wanted to try it for ages and had always heard good things about it. It's been around for a long time, so I was surprised that the food was less than amazing. I ordered the hen with asparagus - the hen was dry & rubbery. My husband ordered the pork shoulder with polenta and all he could say was - blah. We did hear that their head chef recently left, so perhaps they are going through a bit of a transition? I'm not sure that we will be back...

On the positive - The restaurant itself if very welcoming and nicely laid out - great atmosphere. The service was good as well.
author: Julie C.

description:
This was a fabulous dining experience. My boyfriend and I went to Zuni for an early dinner. The ambiance is lovely. Even though it's on Market Street, the restaurant's big and bright windows offer a great atmosphere. It's elegant and upscale without being stuffy or overly fancy.

We ordered an appetizer of fried fava beans and onions with goat cheese, the shoestring potatoes, and the infamous chicken for two. Munching on the appetizers made the time fly by as we were waiting for the chicken to cook. 

The chicken itself is what you would expect, but the dish as a whole is delicious. The greens, pine nuts and bread soaked up in chicken juice and dressing is phenomenal. We will definitely be back.
author: Sara S.

description: Hip and great vibe. The chicken is delicious, it's worth the wait. The cheesy noche is to die for. We were placed us in an awkward area (upstairs in walkway) for seating but the rest of the restaurant seats looked good. Will go back.
author: Terese O.

description: This place is OK. The "iconic" chicken dish was good ;moist in the inside with an extra crunch of the skin on the outside but nothing phenomenal with the flavor . I don't really like the bread salad with the chicken  as it's too soaked in chicken fat which I found to be too overwhelming that a full bodied red couldn't even cut the greasiness. If the one hour wait was worth it, maybe for once and just  to satisfy my curiosity . I would rather explore some other dishes from the menu if I happen to visit Zuni again. Service was fine and  generic . The wine list was kind of a drought and how I wished they     could promote more local wines. I also tried their polenta and the espresso granita for dessert and just OK. If the place was worth my 45 mile drive--not really.
author: Jed D.

description:
We went to try their famous roasted chicken- it took about an hour and cost $49. I had high expectation especially since one of our friends told us how amazing it was. Well, it was  just fine. Not worth the wait or the cost. The "bread salad" was mushy and greasy, and we really missed the crispy chicken skin. The celery root soup was delicious and the scallops, while over-priced, were cooked properly. 
Although we were slightly underwhelmed by the food, we were pleased with the space, atmosphere and the overall service. If we happen to be in the neighborhood, we might try it again- just with different dishes.
author: S M.

description:
Just got home from Zuni for lunch and I need to make myself a sandwich because I'm starving. The portion sizes are ridiculously small. In the spectrum of portions, if Cheesecake Factory is on one side of the scale, Zuni Cafe is on the other.

I had the Salmon entree for $27 and my piece of salmon had to be only 3-4 oz. with perhaps a few spoons of the faro salad. My guests entree was the Italian sausage ($17) which consisted of one sausage link and about 3 fingerling potatoes cut in half to fill the plate. Upon getting our entrees we immediately ordered a caesar salad to share. 

While the food itself was delicious and the service was excellent, for those prices I expect to leave with my hunger satiated. I did see the next table order get a pizza and the hamburger and those appeared to be quite nicely portioned.

The last time I'd been to Zuni was over 10 years ago for dinner and I don't remember having this same impression, so perhaps its better at dinner. But I will not be going back to Zuni nor would I put it on my list of recommendations.
author: Gregory W.

description:
Zuni, I'm still so into you!

Yelpers, listen up: THE CHICKEN FOR TWO TAKES AN HOUR!  IT'S WRITTEN RIGHT THERE ON THE MENU!  CONSIDER YOURSELF NOTIFIED!  And quit complaining about it!

If you want the chicken you gotta PLAN YOUR NIGHT ACCORDINGLY!  Or, if you're starving, don't get the chicken.  (I recently had the ricotta gnocchi as my main and was blown away.)

But truly I think it's all about getting a little saucy with oysters and cocktails and waiting it out for the chicken in the lovely environment (you will want to order it right when you sit down - the servers totally get this and won't be offended by it if you literally flag them down as you're sitting and are like, "chicken").  It is the most succulent thing around and it is also excellent the next day.  I've even made chicken salad out of the leftovers - bread included.

You can tell by what's being served around you what are the big hits here: oysters, cocktails, red wine, caesar salads, and The Chicken.  All such good stuff and classics for a reason.

I am still a sucker for the gorgeous bar with the views of the street cars going by, the piano player, the occasional Alice Waters sighting, the fun people-watching in general, the kooky building, and what I've always experienced to be excellent service.  The only bad thing I can ever say happened to me is some oyster that we ordered turned out to be sold out that night.  Not worth a star, in my book.

Zuni, I'm still crazy for you, after all these years.
author: Bobbie J.

description:
I LOVE Zuni Cafe. That in and of itself is probably an understatement. Hayes Valley has a lot of amazing restaurants but one can never go wrong eating at Zuni Cafe. The ambiance is friendly and cozy, simple and yet very welcoming. 

Zuni is mine and one of my friend's go-to spot for date night since it's uber close to both of our offices and we usually don't (want) go anywhere else. Our usual dinner consists of: cocktails, oysters, ROAST CHICKEN w/ bread salad, and a bottle of wine. And really, this review is based only on their roast chicken salad. The chicken is delicious - not too salty, it's skin is perfectly cooked - very crispy (I'm Filipina and having crispy chicken skin is a must) and very flavorful. The salad has a nice dressing, not too overpowering. 

Pointers:
- don't rush your meal, especially if you order the Roast Chicken salad. That alone takes awhile to cook (30 minutes or so as stated on the menu)
- if you're into oysters, get some. Their options are usually minimal but all are delicious
- it can get very loud in the restaurant

I've had other dishes throughout the years I've dined here and while they haven't impressed me as much as the roast chicken, I would have to say they've all been solid each and every time. It's such a treat to come here for a consistently solid, well cooked meal.
author: Jocelle A.

description: Def 5 star food, service and ambience. Esp the Caesar salad and cheeseburger and shoestring potatoes. Espresso granita with whipped cream for me and persimmon pudding for the Huz were delish. However -- and this is huge -- the iced tea is $4.50 a person and the drinks are short pours. We'll go back but stick with tap water. Almost marked it down a star for price gouging but it's still Zuni.
author: Cydney B.

description:
We ordered the caesar salad and the salmon. It was pretty good, but a bit salty. The dressing for the salad overpowered the vegetables a little. The salmon was good, but it was salty. It started out alright, but the more we ate it, the saltier it got (we shared too!). The juices were very fresh. I thought my friend and I wouldn't be able to finish the shoestring potato, but it was quite manageable, we almost finished, lol.

It was a very relaxing place to have lunch in the middle of the city. Not a good midwork lunch spot, but it' a nice place to eat when you have one of those "spend half the day eating lunch" days.
author: Stacy C.

description:
Was there a few days ago and the things I enjoyed were:
My friends
The decor and brightness of the place
It was nice and quiet even since we had a little table out away from the main entrance
The wines were good
Now for the bad, my main course was the Papardelle with chanterelles and creme fraiche...what a sorry dish this was just very plain and maybe 3 chanterelles at the most and the portion was really small!
I don't get it, your offer pasta on your menu and can't even do it right?
Also $50 for a roasted chicken with an hour wait?
Come on, is this for real?
There has to be better alternatives than this place...
author: Alan M.

description:
Good service - 1 point
Nice ambiance - 1 point 
Fresh oysters - 1 point 

I really wanted to like this place but apart from the above, the food was only average. The chicken for two could feed about 4 girls.  Dark meat was juicy and tasty but the white meat was way drier than we expected (considering other reviews). Overall good but not good enough for us to come back, pay fifty bucks and wait another hour for the kitchen to cook it. 

Everything else was just mediocre or disappointing. 

Fried squid and okra - too salty and reminded me of any other calamari happy hour special, except there wasn't much squid amidst the okra and onion rings 

Polenta - no flavor and overcooked. Waitress was nice to remove it from our bill

Salmon, lobster mushroom risotto, halibut - all just average, nothing memorable. Each tasted over cooked, yet wasn't hot upon arrival. 

No attendants for the restroom. No toilet paper. Paper towels were all over the floor. I expected more from their restrooms.
author: Ly N.

description: I have been to Zuni every other year since 1979 and also to countless flash-in-the-pan restaurants that never lasted more than a couple of years. Zuni's endurance is a testament to the support from their many loyal fans in San Francisco.
author: Victor M.

description:
This place is ALL FLUFF and nothing more...

After reading all the amazing reviews, it seems that perhaps they were all about the old chef (that passed away). 

I have no idea who this NEW chef is, but unfortunately the experience here was absolutely terrible - yet somehow oddly entertaining as a result! My parents and I were super ready to have this amazing, legendary and extravagantly tasty experience that everyone and their mom who has apparently gone here for 30 some odd years is talking about...but that was not the case :( 

Let's start with the good and the only reason this place gets 2 stars - the service. The service was good, we got seated fast and the ambience was nice. That's about it.  

Now for the bad - the FOOD!!! 

At first, the waiter placed waters and a small plate with 3 pieces of bread (because there were three of us) and a small plate of a slice of butter -_- fine...whatever. 

They asked what we wanted to order, so we order a $40 bottle of wine and then the food. I noticed a few things in the restaurant which should've been a red flag - first there's a painting of a woman eating a piece of cardboard (ok....) and then I noticed a couple sitting with a bottle of wine eating a plate of fries.....for dinner :/ 

After we got the food, I regretted not asking for more bread...

The portions are teeny tiny! The menu doesn't have too much to choose from and at first I ordered the duck but then the waiter came up to me and said it's an appetizer and there's nothing really to eat (what?!?!) ...and then I understood why he said that when I actually got a main course instead (which was quail). When I say the portions are tiny - they really really really are. I'm a 98lb 4'10" human being...I ate every single crumb on my plate and was starving! My quail had 4 small pieces of quail with 1.5 little potatoes in some sauce. 

The only nice part is that we were laughing hysterically because the whole thing was pretty ridiculous, considering a main course costs a minimum of $30/plate - you'd think there'd be some food on it. But just to give you an idea of what the "sea bass" plate contains (we ordered 2 of them)...it's a small helping of sea bass + 4 lima beans - yes 4! and a small artichoke cut in half..

Since we were still hungry and a bit upset we decided to go for some dessert to raise the mood. Each desert is approximately $9-10 and we ordered 3 plus 2 lattes. 

We were literally hysterical when we got the lattes! First off they were in soup bowls and extremely watered down (maybe because they filled a soup bowl with coffee) and the desserts were teeny tiny (just like the food). But at least they kept filling up our cups of water (maybe in hopes of making us feel somewhat full??) 

We ate the dessert and asked for the check ($200 for 3 people) swearing to never come here again. 

Thank you but no thank you Zuni.
author: Diana T.

description: Gorgeous building with a cozy urban feel. Their roast chicken with savory bread salad is one of my top 5 meals in the city. Yes, it's that good. I've tried a few other dishes but nothing has been as memorable as the chicken. This place is not cheap but if you can go with at least 4 people you can get a few additional dishes to try. When there are only 2 of us we can't seem to order anything but the chicken! Servers are always helpful and pleasant.
author: Kelly C.

description: RIP Judy Rodgers
author: Kim N.

description: We've been here a couple of times. The last time we were here it wasn't as good as the first- a bit too trendy for our tastes. But we still rate this restaurant highly primarily because of the roast chicken. Seriously I think everyone in the world needs to experience their roast chicken. When they're on their game I don't think there's a better roast chicken dish anywhere.
author: Art C.

description: Very tasty food but you have to come in full unless you want to spend 100$ to get daily nutrients that your body needs.
author: Igor R.

description:
My friends and I decided to have a late dinner at Zuni after getting drinks nearby. It was close to 10 and we were too hungry to wait an hour for their famed roast chicken for two ($48), so we didn't order that (the one that came out for another table looked good but that was close to the end of our meal). We started with two appetizers - the raw oysters and the deep fried figs and onions. Oysters were good while the latter was mostly onion rings and at most 3 figs split into halves. We all agreed that while we liked fresh figs, deep frying them didn't make the figs better but rather masked the sweet flavor of the figs. 

For the main course, I tried the ricotta gnocchi which tasted like eggs. The ricotta was very subtle. My friend who also ordered the same dish referred to it as "fake gnocchi," but to be fair our server explained that the gnocchi wasn't made with potato. Ricotta gnocchi also looks like a lot of work to make according to the recipe from the Zuni Cafe Cookbook (http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/Zuni-Ricotta-Gnocchi-241532). We did enjoy the shoe string potato fries that another friend ordered with his burger. Free bread was good too. Three stars for now, maybe four if I tried the chicken.
author: Diana B.

description:
Was not impressed.  Despite their very interesting decor and layout, I could get a rotisserie chicken at Safeway that's just as food, an eighth of the price, and doesn't take an hour to wait for!

The Caesar Salad was a headache to cut up so it could be ingested, and the dressing had absolutely no kick.

The fries were salty.  Would take steak fries at a hamburger joint any day of the week over these. 

The panna cotta was boring.

Need I share any more negativity?
author: Darren V.

description: Finally made it here and loved it. The wine list was great and the infamous chicken over the bread salad lived up to the hype.
author: Teryll H.

description:
I have not been here in over 10 years.  All I could remember was the Bloody Mary with Balsamic Vinegar.  Came here last weekend with my husband to celebrate Christmas with no gifts to each other.  We are doing a major home remodel so we thought that will be our big present to each other.

With all the great restaurants in SF, I chose this place because of the great Bloody Mary I remember and my husband is a huge bloody mary man.  Reservation is highly recommended as there were quite a few people waiting when we arrived.  The place is very swanky on the inside.  From the outside not so much.  However, you can't miss the place with its bright yellow canopies right off Market Street just outside of the Castro Street.

We were seated right away and we studied the menu.  It's not the best place for my picky pescatarian husband.  Most of the vegetarian offerings have cheese and there is only 1 Salmon dish.  But I did remember the chicken for 2 even though it is only me that is eating it.  I went for it any ways...I can take the rest home as left overs.  My husband went with a salad with....no ricotta.  BE AWARE, the chicken for 2 takes about 1 hour to cook.  We munched on assorted warm olives and string fries and Bloody Mary while we waited.

The Bloody Mary is a little more tomatoie than I remembered which is not my preference.  The balsamic vinaigrette gave it a sugary finish as well.  Unfortunately, I've tasted better...such a disappointment.

When the chicken finally arrived, it was worth the wait.  The chicken is roasted to perfection set on top of a bed of spring greens and toasted bread which is soaked with the chicken drippings.  OH...My.... My husband's salad was tasty as a salad with no cheese can be.

If we spend another day in SF again, I don't think I would come back to Zuni again.  Not that it was bad; it just not great when there are so many great restaurants in SF.  Sorry Zuni, in a town like SF, a restaurant has to be great now a days.  Tough competition.
author: G K.

description: Finally, had the roast chicken for two today.  Totally worth the wait!!!  Five stars.  The restaurant is always welcoming starting with cheerful & professional hosting staff.  Service was also top notch, and depending on where you sit, there always seems to be kind of a different vibe.  Started with the Cesar (split it,) best I've ever had.  Added a couple of selections of cheese (with honeycomb,) cuz they say the chicken takes an hour (a little less,) a couple of glasses of Pinot, and there was no problem with the fact that the Butterscotch pudding had left the menu...who gets six stars anyways?  No valet at lunch so, park on the opposite side of Market.  ZUNI...Go again!
author: Vince C.

description:
Lunch order: Cesar Salad, pizza with ricotta. 
Dinner order: oysters, Cesar Salad, Zuni chicken. 
Cocktails order: Balsamic Bloody Mary followed by a Margarita. 
These orders are the reason I've been going to Zuni for 25+ yrs. 
Now I'm hungry!
author: Susan S.

description:
I have known about you for years, Zuni, for years.  I have seen you on all of the Lists for years.  Yet I took you for granted and said "I'll try their roasted chicken" someday.  Well, on the eve of the last day of the last day of my birthday (40) month, I finally showed up with my good friend to try your illustrious roasted chicken and salad, and I was so happy!!  

First I had a couple glasses of the Zuni Pinor Noir - niiice!!  We had the burrata over eggplant - mmmm!  With the first bite, we looked at each other in astonishment!  Next we had the gnocchi - now I had an ex-Italian boyfriend who knew how to make gnocchi and I always compare.  Zuni's gnocchi was exquisite - mmmm!  Also hit the spot!  

Time passed quickly as we chatted and caught up on life, and then the famous, listed roasted chicken over salad arrived.  I broke out clapping aloud and cheering.  The server didn't seemed daunted, this must happen a lot.  

We were hungry, we attacked the chicken, salad, pine nuts, all of it -- it met all expectations.  Tasty, tender and a perfect balance with the salad, pine nuts, dressing.  We kept talking and appreciated the taste of our lovely main dish.  

For dessert, we had the bourbon ice cream with drunken peaches and oatmeal cookies - perfect!  Also with a Italian digestive!  

Mmmm!  Service was friendy, gracious, and understanding.   We thoroughly enjoyed our dining experience from beginning, middle to end at Zuni Cafe.  There is no doubt why Zuni is on all the lists - BELIEVE it!!  

I will be back!!  :)  Thank you.
author: Maile N.

description:
Used to love this place, and it is a bit of a San Francisco institution.  Went for dinner on a Sunday night, called ahead and asked for a reservation (we were out and about for the day), told sorry they only do those online.  Their Sunday Dinner menu is pretty limited, maybe 6 Entrees on the menu.  My daughter is gluten sensitive, so we ordered her the rib eye steak.  Turns the gravy has wheat flower, after she was 1/4 finished eating it, the waiter apologized and took it away.  We all put our forks down and waited another 20 mins for them to bring a plate with no gravy.  Hope she isn't sick tonight!

We would have ordered the Chicken for her but there is an hour wait for that dish.  Don't they expect a few to be ordered and put them into the oven?

This whole experience was super annoying.  They can care less!
author: Matthew P.

description:
I've passed by this establishment several times without trying it, but it looks just so appealing because of the funky shaped building and the light it brings to this dark corner of Market.  

We sat upstairs which is nice and cozy, but can definitely get a bit stuffy on a warm night (as rare as they are in SF). 

The two best dishes we had were:
1. Spaghetti. The perfect amount of cream and butter. I wish I had ordered a seconds.
2. Chicken. The chicken is bomb and cooked perfectly.  It's rotisserie and served with some greens. It's perfect to split among four.
author: Laura E.

description:
I usually come here for their caesar salad, roast chicken, and shoestring potatoes. These 3 dishes are a must have for me. Very simple dishes and yet very delicious. 

Caesar salad - whole lettuce leaf coated perfectly with anchovies caesar dressing and perfectly baked croutons (slightly chewy in the inside and crunch on the outside)

Roast chicken - you have to wait for an hour for this dish but it's totally worth it. The meat is perfectly moist and tender. It comes with a bread salad, some greens and currants. It's a perfect balance of flavor - salty and sweet.

Shoestring potatoes - do I even need to explain? This thing is so addicting - you don't want to stop. Ask for a side of ketchup and aioli.
author: Sam M.

description:
Zuni is a clamorous café on the edge of the notorious Tenderloin district. (Hint: If on foot, approach from the west!). It's funky both in configuration and atmosphere. We loved it! Fortunately, we had been advised by some locals to order the whole roasted chicken, something of a signature dish, in spite of the one hour (!) wait time that that would entail. (Doesn't sound like a great business plan to limit your turnover by having your signature dish take so long, but that's just one of the funky things about the place!)

Words cannot do justice to the broth-based soup swimming with fresh vegetables and mushrooms I ordered as an appetizer. Usually the soup course is a warmup to the main event. In this case, it was a worthy partner of the feature act. 

And the chicken! Worth the wait and then some! Impeccably prepared, oozing herbal scents and tastes, sitting on what they called a "bread salad" (what I would call "stuffing") that complemented the chicken perfectly in taste and texture.

Zuni is a unique experience in our travels. It will linger in our memories for both substance and style.
author: Richard T.

description: Go! This place is amazing! The famous chicken is as good as everyone says it is. Very elegant space, big bar, and sometimes live piano music. Oysters and champagne are also a favorite here. This SF staple has been one of my family's favorites for years! I can't wait to go back!
author: Katherine H.

description:
Stellar food. Shitty ice. 

I've seen better cubes (that don't water down drinks) in a Motel 6. Get a flippin' Hoshizaki or Kold Draft for chrissakes!
author: Michael M.

description:
Zuni Cafe was well worth the visit.. It wasn't the strongest 5 I've had, but didn't warrant a 4. The cocktails were quite good. We had some olives and some fried veggie app. There was a dark green olive that was probably the best olive I've ever had. Unfortunately there were only a few of those while most of the rest were a kind that was nothing special. The coating on the fried veggies was exceptional. I'm not a big fan of fried okra, but I think you could've put anything in that breading and made it palatable. 

We shared the roasted chicken which is every bit as good as advertised. Juicy and flavorful, If you're reading this while deciding where to go, you should have enough of an advance to order it when you arrive and save complaining about the wait. It was pretty oily which likely accounts for a lot of the flavor, but expecting lean cooking at a gastropub is like expecting the bread salad with this dish to be a healthy salad. On that note...bread salad? Wow. It's like a fork-worthy bruschetta, with strong notes of balsamic. It was plentiful with half leftover, and it was good the next day. We ordered  the Gateau Victoire for desert in order to reverse the idea that we should stop eating since we were full. I thought it was great. Impressive they can make it so airy without flour.
author: Jo B.

description:
I was fortunate enough to be taken out to dinner by my roommates' father and was even more fortunate that he decided on Zuni's. 

It was definitely quite a treat and I left feeling spoiled and very satisfied... Although I ate a ton I must add that I did not feel like I needed to be wheeled out of the restaurant due to a food coma nor did I feel like I needed to adjust my belt a few notches. It was a great meal, with great atmosphere - an open kitchen which I thoroughly enjoy to see - and very high quality ingredients.

For dinner we ordered the melon salad, which was light and very flavorful, the trout with red peppers and lentils which was perfectly cooked and at times melted in mouth. For dessert I had the raspberry sorbet served with a blueberry compote while also sampling bites of the espresso shaved ice and the wild fig tart with a side of goat cheese ice cream.
