If I am fortunate enough to return, I would try the roasted chicken and also order oysters. All in all it was great night with delicious food, high quality ingredients, and a very well thought out menu. Great place to go for an anniversary or celebration.
author: Em T.

description: Wife and I came for an anniversary and it was a delicious meal. She had the polenta and thought it was really delicious. It's better to go late, the tables in some areas of the restaurant are close together but if you do go later in the evening the tables empty out and the place becomes more private. Definitely worth a second visit; bread is delicious!
author: Marvin P.

description:
I am fascinating by the low marks because I do not agree with any of them.  
Though I live nearby I don't get to Zuni as often as I would like.  First, I love the name--a fascinating native American tribe in western New Mexico.   A great enigmatic name.  

Each visit for lunch or dinner is reminder of pure goodness and a great solid execution.  The service is sterling and friendly, attentive but not overly so--it is always at the right level.  

San Francisco restaurants are often very similar a left and right seating zones--like entering a theatre.  Zuni is unique in lightness and space.

I like to visit and enjoy Zuni family style--to taste many dishes and get a full feel of the entire menu.  My last visit included:

The fennel and arugula salad was perfectly dressed with small slices of Mandarin oranges.  

Llano Seco Ranch fennel sausage with Japanese eggplant, roasted tomato croûtons, and persillade - a perfect plate to share; a wonderful item to enjoy before the chicken dish.

Chicken for two roasted in the brick oven; warm bread salad with scallions, pine nuts, garlic, dandelion greens - don't listen to the negative comments. This dish--takes an hour--it is worth the wait--how many restaurants in San Francisco are okay with you waiting an hour for your second plate?   Succulent, delicate flavour and the bread salad is a perfect highlight--a rotisserie chicken dressed in greens--satisfying, superbly well prepared.  Who knew how non-fried food could be so good.

The portions were perfect--not too big and not too small--I sampled a wide array of foods and recommend a family style approach to taste a varied array of foods.  

I enjoyed everything from simple things like the plating, focused menu, service execution and the menu layout--especially dessert menu.  I felt like I was transported to a restaurant in Paris.  Always a great meal and experience.  I feel ordering family style will capture something for everyone and give satisfaction in tasting diversity.  

Buen provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I went here with the explicit intention of eating the famous Zuni Cafe roast chicken, and it was every bit as wonderful as it was cracked up to be. The skin was crispy and almost caramelized, with the meat tender, salty and moist. The bread salad soaked in chicken drippings was heavenly. This is definitely worth the wait and the $50.

Other than the chicken, my guest and I split the kale salad as a starter, which was good but a little oily. The wine selection is a little limited if you're just looking for a glass, but I was satisfied with the Cabernet-Sangiovese blend that I settled on. 

Service was good - not overly attentive which I usually find annoying, our waiter was friendly and efficient.

All in all a wonderful dining experience and a definite bucket list entry for anyone either visiting or living in the Bay Area.
author: Emily G.

description: I have eaten meals at Zuni Cafe periodically over the past few decades, so I associate this restaurant with a number of good San Francisco memories. The food and service are consistently excellent.
author: Morris R.

description:
We went to Zuni with a large-ish group (7) and were promptly seated upstairs at a table that somewhat resembled a trapezoid. Our server was very pleasant - when she accidentally forgot to fill my glass after I tasted the first of two bottles we bought, she was very apologetic. No big deal.

Onto the food. We sampled 3 or 4 of the lighter "main" dishes, to include the anchovies and bucatini. Neither were particularly impressive. The bread on the table was outstanding. 

As for our main courses, the chicken for two over bread salad is (as many mention), quite terrific. Although be sure to give yourself 50 minutes because that's how long it takes, come hell or high water. The salmon was fair, the leg of lamb decent, as well.

All told, a very pricey meal. The chicken and bread salad was enough to lift this spot from 1.5 to 3 stars. Underwhelming aside from that dish.
author: Bryan P.

description: It's the case of high expectations.  If I had gone here without my co-worker's glowing recommendation, I would have loved the roasted chicken but it turned out being dry and average to me.  I did come back to try the oysters with my bf but instead got the hamburger and Cesar's salad, which were both really good.
author: C L.

description: I always make at least 1 rez when staying in SF for a 2-3 visit. Great wine list. It's roasted chicken every time for me. Only the apps rotate.
author: Scott T.

description: I came here for dinner with my aunt before going to the opera. The staff was careful to get us in and out in time for the show, the food was amazing, and our waiter was extremely helpful with helping us choose the perfect cocktails. I can't wait to go back!
author: Maggy G.

description:
Very nice, cool atmosphere for a cafe; my friend and I stopped in on a Saturday at noon for lunch. Since we were stuffed from a large lunch, we only had the burger on focaccia bread; the burger was pretty good and the bread a nice touch (not too dry, which is key), but for me, the highlight of the burger were the pickles. They were delicious and provided a nice punch to the burger.

I wasn't terribly impressed with the burger, but I would come back and try some of the other food, which looked pretty good.
author: Dennis J.

description:
Constipated atmosphere with the staff the day we went but food was great. 
We came for Sunday brunch because we heard this was one of the top places for a Bloody Mary in SF, so expectations were high and I was disappointed. I felt it needed to be less sweet and the flavor was lacking a lot of depth. 

However the building is gorgeous. Located on the corner with large windows spilling inside with natural light. You can sit outside too which looked charming & reminded me of Europe. 

Our appetizers was heavenly, goat cheese with dried apricots, nuts, crackers & bread. 
We got a variety of fresh oysters and they tasted exquisite. 
I saw many people ordering the burger and that looked amazing.
author: Jessabelle R.

description:
We have been here twice and have had great meals both times.... the bartenders were super nice (get to know them because you will be waiting a LONG time if you don't have a reservation). 
You've gotta try the Zuni Chicken, though there are some other great stuff on the menu, it is their signature dish. 
If you can get a table upstairs, it is a bit less crowded.
author: Dawn R.

description: First, the service was exceptional. Our server stopped by regularly and told all sorts of background for each dish. Second, all of the food we ordered was amazing. Fresh, light and tasty. We ordered the chicken, of course. An hour wait wasn't bad at all - we ordered appetizers to kill time. The chicken came out just perfect. We also ordered a desert (sadly, can't recall the name).  All in all, great experience and this place is on our list of favorites to eat at in the City.
author: Ivan M.

description: Get the chicken!!!! Yes it takes an hour, but it's so worth it. It says it's for two people, but 3 could easily split it. I definitely  plan to come here again. Excellent service, excellent food and drinks.
author: Alex R.

description:
I visited Zuni solo after an appointment nearby on strictly a whim at 11:30 on a weekday. Mind you the daily oncoming lunch rush is nowhere in sight at this time so I was able to get a corner seat on the first floor. My waiter was super attentive and knew the menu to a tee. I was in the mood for a vodka tonic and some oysters when I really wanted Martinis and oysters but decided against that.  A shortish Tito's and tonic arrived, well done, but I wondered if anyone ever ordered a V&T here? I'm used to a good sized cocktail not a three sipper. 
I decided on six oysters to start a small lunch before the Pizza with ricotta salata, tomato sauce, and oregano. The fresh oysters were presented with a mignonette sauce and lemon. The pizza was a disappointment as it lacked any oven spring on the dough resulting in a terribly thin lifeless pie.  I know that's the 'style' but done correctly it is another animal. 
I'm impressed by the service and room, albeit pretty noisy with all the glass, but there's something about a restaurant that has been around for as long as this place has a bunch of great offerings, I just didn't have one.
author: John F.

description: I've been here a few times and it's always amazing but this review is about my last visit. This review is for one thing only. The burger. Get it. Best Burger in San Francisco! There, I said it. Believe me, I'm as surprised as anyone. Possibly the best burger of my life! P.S. Get the blue cheese on top.
author: Vickie B.

description:
Excellent food, beautiful atmosphere, and great beverage selection. I will definitely be back.

I recommend the chicken (duh) and the oysters.
author: Jay S.

description:
As many of the reviews below I also fell in love with the chicken here. There is no doubt in my mind that I have never had better chicken in restaurants in sf! The meat was a little crisp on the outside but extremely moist and delicious on the inside. The bread salad that came with the dish was probably my favorite. 

Drinks here were really well made! I suggest you venture onto that cocktail menu and try something new!
author: James H.

description:
The food was not worth the cost. We left still hungry.

The blackberry sorbet for dessert tasted like there was sweetener in it.

In general, the food is rustic and not super gourmet but the prices reflect high end gourmet food.
author: christina b.

description:
I picked Zuni Café as the location for our last lunch in SFO. I had decided that a late lunch was best before our flight back to Canada and it was nice to be at Zuni mid afternoon to have a nice, relaxed lunch. There were a few other occupied tables but the place was not full. We had the undivided attention of our server and the kitchen staff.
We were almost seated at a bit of a cramped table to begin with but I spied a lovely looking window table and asked if it was available and it was. I was really glad to make the switch as it was really nice to sit there and watch the world go by as we ate our lunch. The bench seats were the most comfortable I've ever sat in and we were quite relaxed during our Zuni experience.
I had really wanted to get the roasted chicken but I didn't realize that it takes an hour to prepare so we settled on other dishes from the lunch menu. 
Our server let us know that there was only one serving left of the day's special which was meatballs on polenta and that would reserve it for us if we wished. We did! Though we weren't exactly clear on whether or not it was a starter or a main...
We had to have another platter of oysters because they are the one of the best things to eat in SFO. So we had the oysters and meatballs to start off with. We each also ordered a main and a cocktail.
I had the sage sausage with asparagus and potatoes. It was tasty but I found the sausage to have a very odd texture as to be packed quite loosely in the very tough casing (I come from a sausage making family) and the whole dish was quite oily.
My husband did enjoy his pizza with wagon wheel cheese, fava bean leaves, bacon, and Brussels sprouts very much. My son also really enjoyed his burger and the excellent shoestring fries were a big hit with all of us.
We were glad to have picked Zuni Café as our last meal in SFO.
author: Bernice H.

description:
I've been looking forward to trying Zuni Cafe after one of my friends went and raved about the chicken.  I love chicken.  I eat chicken almost every night of the week and routinely order it at restaurants over more popular steak or fish options.  Good restaurant chicken typically has crispy, salty skin and amazingly moist meat.  It's this contrast of crunchy outside and juicy inside that makes a great chicken.  Zuni Cafe's chicken was dry, tough and flavorless.  The skin had a horrible smokey taste.  The meat was VERY dry; I haven't had chicken this dry in a long time.  Maybe I caught them on an off night, but it was the Saturday before Christmas so you would expect them to be on top of their game.

There were only two of us, so we only ordered the caesar salad and the chicken dish.  The salad was fantastic, the chicken dish not so much.  To top it off, once you order the chicken you are basically waiting for 1 hour while they prepare it.  During that time our waiter didn't come by and check on us or offer more drinks or refill water.  Our waiter was no where to be found once our meal arrived, as I was going to ask for a steak knife to cut my dry, tough chicken.  It was a strange experience to wait so long with so much anticipation and then be totally let down.  

Overall, the restaurant has great ambiance and a good wine and cocktail menu.  If the other items on the menu were as good as the salad, this could be a very good restaurant.  However, the service and the chicken were not great so I probably won't give them another shot.
author: Rob F.

description:
Zuni is the restaurant I always recommend for any friends or relatives visiting SF.

If you are not vegetarian I'm going to save you some time: ORDER THE CHICKEN. You will have to wait 45 minutes for it, but it will be the best chicken of your life. Tender, juicy, perfectly seasoned. The bread salad that it's served on is phenomenal. It's crispy, buttery, tangy and there's little currants that just...Unnnf. I have dreams about that bread salad. Everything else is good too, always fresh and creative. I've never once been disappointed with anything I've ordered at Zuni. 

The restaurant also has great ambiance. Lots of windows, fairy lights, interesting shape and a large central hearth. Simple and elegant.

10/10 would recommend.
author: Cassandra D.

description: Had lunch here on 12/15/16. Great vibe! Friendly staff - everyone from bartender to hostess to waiter. What a treat to feel so welcome. Food doesn't disappoint. Something for everyone. Even a delicious pasta with brussel sprouts, nuts and orange zest for the vegan in our group. Service very attentive. Love the ambiance and layout. So glad to see this classic SF restaurant thriving after 25 years!
author: Steve D.

description:
Zuni is a staple in the San Francisco dining scene (so I hear), and it definitely lived up to its reputation.  We were a party of 9 and we ended up in the upstairs area.  It was a perfect area for such a large party.  We had some of the olives and the pomme frittes to start, as we were all ravenous after a long day of site seeing and playing tourists.  The pomme frittes were so skinny and crunchy, they were great.

We then had the cesear salads that are also famous, also delicious...  I had tuna steak for dinner, while others had pork chops, and the other famous chicken dish.  The tuna was amazing, cooked rare (seared), with a very interesting side of veggies and olives.  The tastes were great coming together as you took bites.  A good combination of everything.

Zuni is definitely a staple.  The food is fresh and wonderful.
author: Danielle B.

description:
No worries, the chicken is still wonderful but something at the heart of the place is gone for sure and that is Judy! 
The wait staff could not give a damn about serving unless you're a regular, or better, a celebrity.   The portions have become scant, like the house cured anchovies, about 6 and should come with a magnifier, they are so small.  Same is true for the salad, notably the arugula salad barely enough for one.  The fish is good, small portions again, had the trout and salmon.
Shoestring potatoes are usually great but arrived totally cold and took another 15 minutes to get another order out. 
And the menu debacle hours should have one concerned as they would not serve you the dinner menu if you sit down before 5:45 and get started  with the afternoon menu. So we made reservation at 6 pm, got in around 5:30 and kept us in the bar area until 6:20 even though the restaurant was half empty and had already ordered a round of drinks; totally sleazy and obviously old management.  

Left a bare 10% tip, which was more than the server deserved.   I'm getting the Zuni cookbook and roasting my own chicken at home and skipping the 'Zuni experience.'  Lots of good memories here but the last meal was aggravating enough to make me not want to go back.
author: Daniel U.

description:
I came here on a date night with recently and we had a great time. The monterey bay calamari with padron peppers was great, my squab was perfectly cooked, and her ricotta and potato gnocci were rich and tasty. They had a great oyster selection ($3-4/ea),  a long wine list, and a coctail menu that looked pretty good (although we stuck to wine). Even the rustic bread they put on the table was really great. 

Service was impeccable. Atmosphere was open and nice. Overall a recommendation for sure.
author: Jake L.

description:
The chicken with bread salad lives up to the hype. The juices from the perfectly roasted chicken drip into the bread underneath and it's even better than you could have imagined. 

It takes an hour for the chicken so plan your meal right and order enough beforehand to fill the time. We had winter root soup and super light,  pillowy gnocchi. Both were incredible. 

Service was a little lacking and I didn't think much of the wines by the glass,  but other than that I can see why this place is such an institution.
author: Victoria W.

description: Loved our dinner at Zuni.  Chicken for two was delicious and we had great service too.
author: Wes M.

description:
I'll keep this short and sweet. Every single menu item we ordered was spot on. The quality of the food was amazing (juicy, flavorful chicken, crunchy lettuce, etc.) After we tasted our first appetizer my husband and added three more items because there simply was no way to resist the temptation. Our waitress (I wish I could remember her name) knew what she was talking about, gave excellent recommendations AND described the flavor of each item so accurately. 

Advice: you're going to want their famous chicken dish so put that order in as soon as you arrive since it tends to take a while to cook. (We put our orders in a bit on the late side and had to suffer through 45 minutes of irresistibly amazing scents wafting out of the kitchen). 

Counting down the days until we go there again!
author: Shireen K.

description:
More like a 3.5 stars for me but anyway!!! 
I have been looking forward to try this restaurant and finally I come here for my friend's birthday dinner.  

Overall all the food are good but not like a surprised. We got Cesar salad and the clam to started, the salad is a salad, but the clam was pretty good (must order!)
For the entrees I got the tuna and two of my friends got the robbie leg and the duck breast. 

Okay!  Here is the down side, I like my tuna! The texture was good and not too dry BUT there a punch of oil underneath the Tuna and all over to the side dishe so the veggie next to it was too oily!!  It also happened on the duck beast too,  my friend's stomach doesn't feeling good because that  =[
The Robbie wasn't oil at all cuz it was too DRY and no favorite at all.  Weird huh ~~~
author: Mavis L.

description: Unfortunately, this is no longer the Zuni that we remember. Kitchen issues, bad service, and a truly weird dining experience, capped off by the fact that we were not able to get a copy of our receipt. The food was pretty good. But pretty good is just average. It is sad to see an old favorite not aging well.
author: Ryan G.

description: To begin with Zuni's has been of my favorite restaurants in SF for years, and it has always been expensive, but worth it. I had dinner there this week and the prices have skyrocketed. The famous chicken is now $54.00! That's 3 price hikes in a very short period of time. When I asked why? Another price hike? The waiter, who was great, said it was because of the $15 per hr. Wages. Hmm ok. I ordered the roasted pork also very expensive, and not good. Grey overlooked and bland. I also noticed that there weren't as many choices on the menu as in the past. Hey Zuni's if your gonna charge these prices, better get it right every time. And I've been a friend for years, won't go back unless it's for a drink. Too many fabulous restaurants to go to that don't disappoint.
author: Margarett J.

description:
I had been dying to try Zuni since I moved here. It's an institution, I was told. And once I heard Hilary Clinton went there and knocked back a few whiskey sours, I knew it was time to hit it. 

But I have cheap friends. Which is why I keep employed, adult parental figures in my rolodex and dial them up when I need expensive lunch buddies. And a self esteem boost. 

We met for lunch at 11:30 on a Friday, and were seated near the window. The wine I picked, the Zuni Estates' Pinot Noir was soooo soft. Wow. It paired perfectly with my perfectly-cooked sea bass. I also got to sample their pasta with eggplant, and their pizza. Their pasta was the best pasta I've had outside of Italy. Their pizza was good, but it wouldn't be my first choice.

And because this was essentially one of the best meals I had ever had in San Francisco, both in terms of the food and the company, we split their creme brulee, which is made from angel tears. You should go here just to get one of them. Seriously: Angel. Tears. 

FYI- They put extra oil and butter on every dish before its served. And it's delicious. But if you're worried your fish will have too much oil on it, request less.
author: Emily D.

description: This is the perfect place to go with your sugar daddy. It's upscale but accessible. Piano bar, adult wait staff and all. The crowd is middle age Pacific Height type. Your meal ticket will fit right in without being judged. He might even get a few high fives. Let him talk you into ordering the roasted chicken, but do it quickly so you are not stuck there for 3 hours. All the food there is pretty good and non-threatening. Get him drunk on the excellent drinks, kiss him good night, put him in a uber and on with your night in Hayes Valley or Mission.
author: K T.

description:
I was trying to find a nice restaurant for my boyfriends birthday dinner. Seeing that he is the type to choose chicken or steak at these fancy restaurant, I chose Zuni Cafe after reading all the reviews about their "Chicken for Two" at 48 dollars. 

We made reservations through open table and were set for Friday night on Memorial Day weekend. We arrived a hour ahead of our reservations due to a starving boyfriend. They gave us the option of sitting at the bar area seats. We did not mind. Hey, if you have to wait an hour for the chicken, might as well get seated earlier; they do not put in the order for the chicken until you are seated. 
 
Meanwhile, we ordered the shoe string fries that were six dollars. It was abundant and tasty, a nice divergence. Also, as a huge oyster fan, I ordered a dozen oysters ranging from miyagi, kumamoto, tomales bay, and kushi. They were very fresh and delightful. They range from about $2.50-3.75 each. 
  
Our chicken finally arrived after my boyfriend eagerly awaited, constantly checking his watch.  Overall, I am sorry to put this bluntly, but it tastes like rotisserie chicken similar to that of Costco. It came with a vinaigrette salad mixed with baked bread/crouton. Therefore, I must give this dish an A-OK.  
 
As I anticipated from reading the prior reviews, the service is slow. Not the worst that I have received though.
author: Becky Q.

description: Really liked it here. The lighting is great as the evening rolls in. Nice vibe. Seems like a bit of a more mature crowd which is fine with me. The food was very good. I loved everything except the main course. The appetizer, salad and pasta dishes were delicious and the desserts divine but the main course fish (and porchette ordered by my compadre) were just "okay". Great wine list and non-alcoholic drinks (from fresh squeezed juices to iced bergamot tea and hot gemicha tea, various other teas, coffees, etc. Can't wait to go back.
author: Piper W.

description: Over priced, past it's prime, with a lack of diversity (ethnic) that takes your breath away. Do yourself a favor and go to "Alta CA" instead. The wait staff at Alta CA is nicer, the crowd is more diverse, the food better and the waitstaff nicer! Alta Ca is located at 1420 Market Street. I work at a private school nearby and try to eat there at least once a month.
author: David T.

description:
Completely over rated by the 4 and 5 stars and the 3 star reviews stretch it.  I would give it 3 because their french fries are oysters are a 5 but the main courses there were a 0, thus a rating of 1.

For $30.00 I had the Tuna which was the thinnest and weak pink looking tuna I have ever seen at a restaurant that is supposed to be at this level.  Clearly the lady who wrote the cook book is not controlling the quality any longer and I have heard this from others who ate there and won't go back.  My daughter had the duck.  The 4 tiny pieces were extrememly thin like roast beef in a sandwich and looked almost as thin as my tuna!  1/8 inch which was a complete rip off.  It should have been called an appetizer platter because the portion size was ridiculous for the price.

We also ordered the sea bass which I have never experienced fishy sea bass but this had a very prominent fishy smell,  We were in a rush to get out of there for a show which was down the street and the waitress was gone so much we ended up asking for things from another waiter who was walking by.  Our waitress had no enthusiasm about the restaurant and couldn't make a single recommendation when I asked her about the menu.  Everything was "Oh yeah that's good." and so I just believed her everything was good.

Well everything we ordered was HORRIBLE!  Cold, and cold fish is just gross.  The only highlight was the french fries which were fantastic, as I do give praise where praise is do.  They were crispy on the outside, and the portion was nice and large so we go to eat french fries for dinner because the other food just didn't fill you up (due to the tiny thin pieces they give you of meat and fish).

SAVE YOUR MONEY!!  We spent more hear than many better places in San Francsico.
We used to always go to Espetus right down the street for Brazilian Barbeque and thought we would mix it up as we have never been here.  Sorry we wasted our money hear and we'll be back at Espetus which for the same price you get all you can each salads, 15 different meats, and a wait staff that is top notch.   

Sorry, to be blunt but this place just sucks when it comes to main courses.
Gordon Ramsey would have been gagging in the garbage bucket when he ate the fish, especially the cold tuna which was tasteless.

Russell H. and Jeffrey Y. are very accurate.  This place has become way over rated!
author: Jay G.

description:
Food was haphazardly prepared with ill proportioned elements. One example: crostini means "small toast" - 'tini' is IN the word, folks. The burger is two triangles of toast with a bland ball of meat in it and giant slices of tomato. For the prices, one expects a little more focus on the basics of a solid burger.

Everyone who knows got a table at NoPa instead.
author: Navi O.

description:
Wow, haven't been here for years and I haven no idea why!  We had a fabulous evening with some fabulous people!  The place was pretty packed when we arrived around 8ish (to be expected) and we stayed so long that was supposed to be a quick drink to catch up ended up in more drinks, oysters, the works.  What a lovely staff too...I think we were the last ones out without them kicking us out! 

And should you go there for a cocktail, find Sarah!  She is amazing!  If you feel real adventurous tell her to surprise you.  I did, and let's just say, what she brought me made me glow in delight.  Thanks Sarah!!
author: Zin M.

description:
I love this place. An ultimate go-to spot. Perfect on a sunny saturday for al fresco dining and people watching. Go for the excellent drinks, the tastiest oysters (yes, pricier then shucking your own, but hey, you're not shucking your own :) and the great service (seated quickly, attended to mostly.) 
However this time, I tried the fish on a bed of quinoa with roasted green onions and sprinkled with kumquats. The fish was fine, the onion was savory and kumquats added a perfect citrus kick, but the quinoa was mixed with some other grain like pearl barley and seemed undercooked and tasteless. It needed more kumquats and a little more flavor to carry this dish. 
A hot cappuccino is always the way the end the meal.
author: Naomi K.

description: Zuni, do you ever disappoint? Been coming here for decades and am still in awe at the level of service, execution and crowds of patrons lining up to experience this always welcome SF institution.
author: E. L.

description:
The restaurant seems to have a solid hour wait because everyone gets the baked chicken dish, which in itself takes an hour to make. They have a bar which is first come, first serve so you can try to snag one while waiting for a regular table. I also noticed they had some dining tables in the kitchen, which would be neat to sit at. Who doesn't enjoy watching the kitchen as they prep and plate the meals! 

They bring you bread and butter once you sit down, but I highly recommend you ordering some appetizers to pass the time and hold you over. We had some oysters and the shoestring potatoes. The oysters were your normal fresh fair, and the fries were perfectly fried and salted.

The baked chicken lives up to the hype and raves everyone mentions on here. It is definitely worth the long wait. The chicken is super juicy, even the breast pieces which is normally always dry since it's so thick. The bread and salad that accompany the chicken is super flavorful and compliment the chicken wonderfully. The bread is brined and soaks up a ton of flavor. Be aware the chicken is $48, which might be a sticker shock since everything else on the menu is about $20 or less. However, the chicken dish is made for two so it balances out price wise.
author: Alice L.

description:
Eh, not as great as I expected it to be.  The main reason I came here was to try their famous chicken bread salad, which was on SF's Big Eats list.  I've had bread salad before, but really wanted to try how good the chicken was! 

Came here for dinner with my girlfriends, and got seated upstairs at the window, so we got to overlook Market street, which was really nice.  Dinner was at 6, but since the chicken salad takes about an hour, we thought it'd be perfect to start with other dishes first.  

We ordered:
- Yellow Fin Tuna:  It was almost like ahi tuna, lightly grilled on the outside and rare in the middle.  I liked the outside a lot, because it had this salty taste to it, which brought out the flavor!  The fish itself was pretty bland, but it went well with the lemony garbanzo beans and greens that came with it!

- Grilled Pork Chop:  Love pork chops!  This was a bit on the salty side, but so are most pork chops.  It came with sauteed onions and potatoes.  The onions were reallllly good!  I'd say this was my favorite dish of the night!

- Chicken Bread Salad:  It smelled and looked really good.  I had a taste of the drumstick first, so that was crispy and juicy, but as I bit into my second piece of chicken breast, it started to lack flavor.  The middle tended to be a bit dry and I couldn't get much flavor and juice from my piece anymore.  I'm not sure if this would be an hour wait chicken.  On the other hand, the bread salad alone with delish!

Our server was really polite and attentive, so I give 4 stars for the service, but as for their well known chicken dish, only 3 stars.
author: Nancy S.

description:
I have been here a few times since first visiting for lunch in 2007. This last time around, I was very disappointed. The initial service was meh, we were told to wait to be seated (we had reservations & were about 15 mins early). No problem, grabbed a drink at the bar and waited...waited...waited. Finally at the time of our actual reservation we checked in & they seemed surprised and were ready to seat us. Oh well...

Moving on to food and menu, I was very disappointed with the menu. There seemed to be very little variety in the type of food selections for all courses. It all seemed about the same and nothing really struck my fancy. Ended up deciding to share a salad, oysters, app, and getting a pasta dish for dinner while the fiancee got the pork. Oysters were good, salad was fine, appetizer was really great & unexpected - it was the fettunta which is garlic & olive oil bread served with fresh veggies. However, when it came down to the entrees they were really small and not very filling. To top it off, we had hoped to order dessert before heading to the theater but our waitress straight up disappeared after our entrees were served. 

The food was still pretty good, but some things left a bad taste in my mouth. For the prices you are paying, I expect good service & more substantial meal sizes. Will likely be back, but not as regularly as before.
author: Jessica B.

description:
I ordered the famous roasted chicken. We waited exactly 1 hour for it. In the meanwhile, we tried the oysters (Drake's Bay and Hog Island Pacific which were both excellent). We also tried the polenta which was a mistake (too filling and nothing extraordinary). The bread was good and we tried our best not to fill up on it. 

After an hour, the chicken arrived. It was well seasoned throughout. The skin was not as crispy as I'd have liked it. It was not as warm as I would have liked so it probably should have been served a few minutes sooner. The chicken was plated over a bread salad which was fantastic. Almost better than the chicken itself. 

The chicken is good but I'm not sure if I'd wait an hour for it and pay $48 again. I might go try other food here again at some point though since the rest of the menu looked quite intriguing.
author: Sasha K.

description: This restaurant is a breath of fresh air on dirty Market Street. I was a Zuni twice and like the food a lot. They are famous for their chicken which lives up to its reputation because it is tasty and moist, caveat it takes 30 minutes to prepare so go with someone you like :) their Cesar salad is also famous and tasty, the lettuce has the right crunchiness and the crouton are well seasoned. I also had their famous burger-- delicious- served on focaccia bread and with cheese with a side of fries. I really enjoyed both and had a good hot chocolate while I was waiting. The staff is friendly and the the service is fast. I will definitely go back!
author: Schroder C.

description:
Zuni was one of the best restaurants I've been to in a long time. We had a great corner table right by the window, and both the food and service were excellent.

We started our meal with some of Zuni's many varieties of fresh oysters (a dozen kumamotos, and half a dozen miyagi). They were small and briny, and the mignonette added just the right vinegar touch. We also partook of the anchovies and burrata, both of which were very tasty, although anchovies aren't really my thing.

Our group of 5 people share 3 entrees: the roasted chicken for 2, double-cut pork chop, and rare albacore. The chicken was easily the MVP of this meal, because it was simply the best roasted chicken I have ever tasted. It seemed to be seasoned with only salt and pepper because the spice was not at all overwhelming. The flavor of the chicken was really present and just delicious. Do yourself a favor, and order at least one of these chickens. It's a whole bird, cut up into pieces on top of their fresh sourdough. Wow.

I felt the pork chop was a little salty, but it was cooked perfectly and very flavorful. If we hadn't ordered the chicken as well, I would have a lot more nice things to say about the pork chop. The albacore was also very nicely done, on the rare side, but just couldn't beat out the chicken as the darling of this dinner.

Two excellent desserts: pot de creme, and bread pudding, both wonderful. I haven't had bread pudding many times, but I plan to correct that now because it blew me away. Will definitely be back again.
author: Jeff S.

description:
This has been on my to-try list for quite some time. Zuni makes all the Top 100 places in the city. Each review I read, said that the roasted chicken was a must try! 

So after a lot of planning, we finally made a point to brave the parking and come here on our anniversary. I must say I was a bit disappointed.  

Our anniversary was on a Wednesday, so we didn't think we needed a reservation. The place was packed! But luckily we found an open corner right next to the door. They have a section that is perfect for local walk-ins. It was a bit cramped, but had a nice view of Market Street and the beautiful Christmas Decor they had set up. 

They warn you, but 1 hour wait for the roasted chicken is a lot. That chicken better be flying onto my plate. 

While we waited for the chicken, we ordered some west coast oysters, which were really fresh. Then came the main dish. A fully roasted (dry brine) chicken for two. Some parts of it were very juicy; the breast still left something to be desired for. I didn't feel the chicken was any better than the Holiday turkey we were use to having that holiday. We did try the panna cotta for dessert and it was divine. 

Would probably not go out of my way to come back. But it's nice enough to bring clients and out of towners for those who really want to try the 1 hour wait chicken.
author: Winny F.

description: Went to Zuni's for lunch yesterday with my husband and a good friend. We had a reservation and only a short wait to be seated. Awesome wine list. We shared an endive salad which was small for sharing, 2 soups of the day - a lovely Jerusalem artichoke soup, the ricotta salata pizza, the roast chicken and a pear and chocolate dessert and the cardamom ice cream with quince. Everything was top notch from the food to the service to the ambience. Can't wait to go again!
author: Jen T.

description:
Zuni Cafe is the restaurant that changed the way I looked at food. It will always have a special place in my heart. Get the roast chicken for two. Seriously, just get it.

The burger is good too, if it's on the menu (lunch and late nights).
author: Winston L.

description:
3.5 stars. Will keep this review as real as it gets. Copying my feedback on the place that I texted to my friend right after dining at Zuni :) 

"Was good. Got the frisee salad which was nothing special. A little overdressed. Chicken was definitely really good. Not to the point where I'll be like "OMG i gotta get the chicken at Zuni again" but def exceptional. My white meat piece was a little dry".
author: Erica L.

description:
Zuni did not live up to my (high) expectations, and if you are looking for an outstanding, legendary SF restaurant, I'd recommend going elsewhere. But the food is fine and we had a nice evening. 

We enjoyed the roast chicken, but it really doesn't stand out among all the standard excellent roast chicken I've had. The bread salad was tasty, sure, but with that much drippings/grease, it would be strange if it weren't. The greens did compliment it nicely. Personally, I did not like the squab - I found it tough and didn't realize it would be served so rare (maybe that's just my own ignorance).

Many other items were fine but not memorable - the anchovies were pretty dull, the bread was not notable, and the hazelnut biscotti was not too different from what I might expect to find from trader joe's. We did have a dessert with meringue discs and I believe huckleberry jam that was outstanding, though.
author: Lisa K.

description: This place is an SF classic. You're not going to get anything new or different, but it'll definitely be delicious! Of course you should try the two-person chicken (and if you do, order it as soon as possible, because it takes a bit of time to make it to the table) and enjoy oyster bar.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
Came here for a lunch with the manager on Friday (TGIF). Glad my manager picked Zuni Cafe, as it is on the 7x7 list waiting for me to cross it off. Make sure you make reservations!

Specifically, I was looking forward to the chicken bread bowl that is so infamous. I couldn't believe the price--$48!!! Good thing I didn't have to pay for it, otherwise I don't think I could order it. Note, if you are going to order this item, order right when you sit down because it takes an hour. I kid you not.

Now, I wondered how can chicken be that great, especially when it takes an hour. When I make my chicken, if I go beyond a short period of time, it get dry. I really wondered. My confusion was resolved once the chicken came out. And, OMG, the chicken melted in my mouth. It was so soft and juicy. I guess those wood-fired brick ovens really work wonders. The bread underneath was soaked in the chicken juice. It was delicious! I highly recommend it, and no wonder it's on the 7x7 list.

Prior to the chicken, we had house-cured anchovies with celery, and the wild arugula salad with pomegranate seeds, mint, walnuts and sheep's milk ricotta, as appetizers. The anchovies worked really well with the celery and parmigiano-regiiano cheese--they were complement for each other. I don't like olives, so I can't speak for the coquillo olives that came with that appetizer. I was surprised at how the anchovies weren't too strong (so I didn't really need to chew gum after lunch). The salad was pretty good, but not too special.

I also had the balsamic bloody mary with spicy pepper-onion relish--one of the BEST bloody mary's I've had. The spicy-ness was a powerful kick to my taste buds. Now that I'm thinking about it, I crave it! I had one of the champagnes as well--I forgot which one, but the waiter had recommended it, and it was very delicious. It was fruity, like a cocktail champagne. 

As for service, our waiter was wonderful. Great service, although it can be slow during busy times, as expected.
author: Vera W.

description: Serving staff was brusque and unwelcoming, and practically snatched plates away from us before we were even done. Both food and drinks are overpriced, small portions, and average quality. I would highly recommend avoiding this restaurant.
author: D E.

description:
I felt ashamed to claim to be a true San Franciscan but have never tried Zuni's infamous roasted chicken for two with warm Tuscan-style bread salad. 

Now that I've had it, turns out... I wasn't missing out on anything at all. 

Has Cafe Zuni's glory days come and gone? I expected this chicken to be the best roast chicken I have ever had in my life. I expected this roast chicken to come singing and dancing out of the kitchen and kick me in the head with the gloriousness of its flavor. And instead, this roast chicken was unmemorable, decent at best. The meat was clearly juicy, but the flavor was lackluster, almost underseasoned. The skin, maybe the one thing that could've redeemed this chicken, was average. 

I was more impressed by the warm Tuscan-style bread salad served with the chicken.  I can eat Acme bread for days. Torn up and served warm with a dressing made from the chicken drippings and a simple vinagrette, the bread perfectly complimented the greens. The salad was delicious, but not enough to salvage the chicken.
author: Monelle A.

description:
I have been wanting to try this place out for a while, since I heard good reviews about it. 

We went there with a few friends for lunch on a Saturday. It's always good to make reservation ahead of time. 

We were arranged to sit at a table next to the window. There was an exposing metal beam next to it, which looks quite interesting. I also liked the exposed brick walls. The atmosphere was quite rustic yet modern. 

Our waitress was friendly and helpful. I asked for recommendation for a white wine. She helped pick out an albariño, which turned out to be pretty good. 

We ordered a pizza, a caesar salad, the heirloom tomato soup, and a pasta dish. They were all very delicious. The dishes came out pretty quickly as well. 

I was pleased that I finally tried Zuni and liked it. I heard their chicken dish is well-knownly tasty. Since it takes about an hour for the dish to get ready, we didn't order it this time. I would love to try it next time for sure, given their other dishes turned out to be satisfying.
author: Kai Y.

description:
The gnocchi were the highlight of the meal for me. They were incredibly fresh and flavorful. The texture was perfect, the sauce was divine... it was one of those dishes that makes your soul smile. I don't even know what that means, I'm just trying to convey how amazing these gnocchi were.

Some other great things:

-Wasabi mashed potatoes. 
-Fresh oysters, the ones from humboldt bay stand out in my mind as being particularly good.
-The roasted chicken for two. It was stuffed with a crunchy sourdough that was fantastic. I thought it was a generous size for 2 people. 
- Our server was very knowledgeable about the wine list. 
- The restaurant was bigger than I anticipated with a nice loft dining area.

The anchovies plate was teeny tiny. I could've scooped the entire thing in my mouth and still have had room for more. Service was a tad slow at times but didn't really effect our experience. Other than that, I really don't have any complaints. I give this place 4.5 stars.
author: Melissa T.

description: Been back to Zuni a few times since my last review 7 months ago.  I would recommend vimv for brunch on Sunday.  I had the baked eggs with house made bacon.  Zuni elevates the bar for eggs and bacon to a level that - how do i put it... I literally licked my dish clean.  I did have meals here where the legendary chicken was a little dry and the some of the croutons were not edible.  There were also times pasta were cut too thick it was really chewy.  But today the brunch was well executed.   Will come back for the baked eggs.
author: Edmond T.

description: Food is ok, Cesar salad was good with really fresh greens, oysters fresh and tasty. Seabass wasn't good at all, burger was ok, in general it is overpriced
author: Roman M.

description:
First time stopped by for lunch. Had the rabbit it was good not great, husband had the burger again, good not great.  service was ok, but the food took forever way to long for just ok food   Great location!
If we go back i will order a pizza and salad, they looked pretty good. Portions are small for the price. It was ok  
If you want a great burger go to Bourbon Steak House, Union Square
author: Tracy G.

description: So the bf wanted some chicken and somehow Zuni is the spot to be. We ordered the chicken, the rabbit, and the giant stack of fries. The chicken was flavorful, but it wasn't as moist as I had hoped for. The rabbit was more moist and actually tasted better to me. The fries were good. The service was wonderful and I loved sitting in a hidden part of the restaurant looking down.
author: Anji W.

description: Exceptional dinner. Beautiful but not pretentious people. Tim was our server and he is impressive and highly knowledgeable. Very gracious guy. The oysters we ordered were so fresh from the sea, we ordered more. Try them with some Sancerre. Get the mushrooms and the anchovies. The clam squid black ink pasta. Seriously amazing. My buddy got the steak and she raved. Can't wait to go back to this gem.
author: Karen C.

description: The roasted chicken for two with the Tuscan-style bread salad is fabulous.  Be warned, it takes an hour to cook.  Unfortunately noting that with my reservation didn't help because my husband and I still waited the full hour, plus 10 minutes.
author: Rose A.

description:
The chicken was faaaantastic! The stakes were high, and Zuni fulfilled all expectations! The table we sat in was romantic, the vibe was chill, the style of the restaurant was chic - the ceilings were so high! 

Really enjoyed the attentive service, our wait staff was very alert and helpful. I would recommend the chicken for two - to anyone visiting Zuni. 

I will definitely return for that scrumptious, comforting, chicken!
author: Julie O.

description: Came here for the second time and wasn't nearly as impressed as the reviews say. Came early to have a drink and there was barely anyone there as it'd just opened. We went to the bar and couldn't even get service so we left and went to another place to have a drink. We had a reservation so came back in time for that. However, when we got back we still had to wail 15 min for our table. It still wasn't very busy so I don't know what the hold up was at all! Once we finally got seated service was good. I had the ricotta gnocchi. It was good but not amazing. I think it was a bit of lemon on top but it was way to string of flavor and sort of ruined it for me. My friend got the squab and was pretty good. We really wanted to try the chicken but since we got seated so late and wasn't able to order right away it was going to be too late. We tried two different desserts. I had the espresso one and was entirely too strong. I ended up taking about one bite and couldn't eat the rest. I doubt I'd come back again. It still just didn't live up to the reviews after the second time at Zuni. A bit overpriced and too hard to get a table even when reservations are made!
author: Emily F.

description:
I was invited to a business lunch, my host made reservations for Zuni Café' which made me happy since this would be my first visit. Let me start by saying I've walked past Zuni numerous times, it always seems like a fun place to dine, not sure why I have never dined here.

Reservations were for 1215p, I showed up at 1130a, was greeted by a very friendly host who invited me to have a seat and wait or pull up to the copper covered stand up bar. The bar looked more inviting. Bar tender greeted me, asked me for my drink order, since the weather was nice I asked for a Pino Grigio but she didn't have it but offered a Sauvignon Blanc instead, $9 for the glass seems about the going rate and it was tasty.

My lunch host arrived, we were seated at a nice table for two and given a few minutes to go over the menu before our friendly waiter took our order. I usually do my homework before dining somewhere new and find out what the restaurant is known for, today I just went in blind and ordered from whatever looked good. I will say the oysters on ice caught my eye as I walked in, something to think about on my next visit.

I appreciated having some space between our table and the adjacent diners so we could speak without hearing their conversation. 

We both ordered the burger which I had seen when I was at the bar, it looked great. It's not your ordinary burger, quality beef, I ordered mine medium rare, served on a focaccia bread, no cheese for me but grilled onions please. I loved the home made pickles on the side, not your average kosher dills and definitely enhanced the burger. What started off looking like a beautiful burger did not handle very well, the focaccia started to fall apart, this was going to be a knife and fork experience. We ordered the shoe string potatoes which to me are potato chips meet French fries, short, thin, crisp, lightly salted, fun to eat, before you know it the plate was gone!

What a great meal, loved the dining room, the servers took care of us, what more could I ask for?

I'm a fan!
author: David P.

description: This meal was so freakin good, I still have dreams about it! The chicken was worth the wait. The "bread salad" as my boyfriend calls it, was scrumptious. I loved the atmosphere and the cocktails. I have been told that the burger during happy hour is good  and I plan on getting it in the future.
author: Heather W.

description:
I wanted to try this place for a long time because it's always crowded and I thought it would be amazing. 

Unfortunately I really think this place is overrated. The service is slow, and the food is good but really nothing to die for, or let's say alright for the price that I've paid and my expectations. 

I would not come back again, there's a lot more other restaurants in San Francisco that you should try before this one.
author: Carole P.

description:
We had to wait about 15 minutes even though we had a reservation. Lucky they had a full bar, but the drinks were expensive. I ended up with a draft beer, whatever, no biggie. But our table was ready in the middle of my beer and they wouldn't let me transfer the tab to our table so I had to close out.

We were warned that the roasted chicken would take about an hour to cook, so we ordered it right away. They weren't kidding about the wait, but since it was expected, all was good.

The ambiance is nice. We were sitting near the big, brick fireplace. The crowd is varied; people getting off work, hipsters, locals, tourists...
author: Richard K.

description:
Frisee salad: Nicely dressed an good olive toast, but could've had more substance
Wild nettle soup: Tasty, but more brothy than hearty, which was unexpected
Burger: Great flavor, fresh meat, foccacia bread not quite fitting
Flourless chocolate cake: Amazingly tall and airy

Decor is great. Location is great. Look out onto the street through large windows in a space custom made for them.

French american cafe where you may order and just have to guess or ask what you're actually getting unless you're just really into that scene :)
author: Debbie Chiou S.

description: Very disappointing. We had the soft shell crab, the ricotta gnocchi, and the famous chicken. None of it was any better than something I could make at home - and I'm not an especially good cook. Maybe things have gone downhill since Judy Rodgers passed away? I don't understand the passion for this place at all.
author: HJ U.

description: A must to try if you lived in the bay area long enough.  Oysters were superb.  Have been here several times and it's just a wonderful place to have dinner.  It does take a while for the food to be serviced but then you can talk to your dinner companions and have wine.
author: Grace C.

description:
A pale shadow of it's former glory.

We used to frequent this place about a decade ago. The food and service was always good and my wife liked it alot but I always thought it was a bit overpriced for what it was.  

We went there again tonight and were quite disappointed. Both of our dishes arrived at a temperature somewhere between lukewarm and tepid, and the flavor was nothing special. 

Service was inattentive at best. Our drinks were slow to arrive and when they were empty nobody came around to ask us if we would like anything more to drink. If tonight's experience is indicative of the general quality of food and service, then this place is riding on its past glory. I hope for their sake that we were just unlucky. Still, at this price point, this level of food and service is unacceptable.
author: Ken C.

description:
You've read about it, been discussed on Yelp talk threads for years yet my chase for the famous Zuni burger has been futile. 

I've been to Zuni on several occasions, but it seems always at the wrong time. The traditional dinner hour in my book is burger-acceptable but not at Zuni. It's offered only at lunch or "late night". 

What is considered "late night" by the nice folks at Zuni is beyond me, but ok. I'll just come back on Monday for lunch.

Ummm, they are closed on Mondays (that my friend is another story for another time).

Finally today I would capture my own Zuni burger.

Without hesitation I ordered the burger (medium rare) and shoestring fries. It's lunch and I'm feeling European and order a glass of Mourvedre (not listed on the menu, but recommended by my server). 

"Salad to star perhaps?" 

Wha?? I'm here for the burger! If anything I will have a burger to start and then another burger for my entree! Care to ask what I want for dessert?

The burger arrived and placed in front of my anxiously waiting taste buds. I must admit, at first the burger did not seem that appear that impressive. What? no bun? but instead they use an Italian focaccia, a thin layer of white cheddar cheese that barely covered the burger and a side of pickles. But my friend, it's the simplify of the burger that makes this burger part of the Holy Grail of the burger world. I took a big bite and my mouth sunk into some of the most tasty ground beef I have ever experienced in my nearly 40 years on this planet. Fresh, mouth-watering, oozing of pure juicy-nessesess. This was burger-sex to the maximus!

The shoestring fries, I must say did not do much for me. I think they take pride on how skinny they make them, and even though I prefer thin cut fries these were just too thin. But the burger experience more than made up for it.

Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco destination restaurant. Make no mistake about it. The burger is certainly one of it's signature dishes that in itself is a true landmark of this city that is not to be missed.
author: V B.

description:
I went with a friend to Zuni Café on a Tuesday after work. We got there a little early and sat along the copper topped bar, enjoying a nice single malt scotch while people watching and waiting for our table.  Apparently, Zuni Café has been around for years and is a local favorite. It's got an interesting architecture with all these rooms pieced together to create the restaurant and you have to weave in, though and around to get finally to your table. Which makes each area quiet and intimate. We sat upstairs, near an open window, and the cool breeze coming in was refreshing.  This restaurant is comfortable, casual and welcoming.  Come as you are; no need to put on a tie. 

The menus are updated daily based on season and what's locally available. Our server was amazing - she answered all our questions and explained the dishes expertly.  When we asked if the pork would be well done and dry, she immediately set out to describe a piece of meat that was flavorful, moist and would not disappoint.  (note: we ordered the dish and were not disappointed!) 

Between us, we ordered some appetizers, entrees and dessert.  We didn't get the famous chicken on this visit; we thought about it, but didn't have the time to wait.  Each dish was wonderful - unique flavoring and combination of ingredients, expertly cooked proteins, just simple and satisfying.  The server was attentive, but out of the way.  We took our time and never felt rushed. 

I remember walking out, thinking what a fabulous dinner we just had. I look forward to returning soon.
author: Marc W.

description: I can hands down say that this place has the BEST rotisserie chicken I've ever tasted in my life.  If you can find a better rotisserie chicken place please let me know.  This place ALSO has the best gnocchi i've ever tasted in my life.  The texture was just puuuurfect and very buttery. mmmm what you should NOT order however if the grapefruit avocado salad.  Order it and you'll see why.
author: Vince L.

description: My friend invites me to zuni. As we saw it has a lot good review. We decide to have a try. We ordered their signature roast chicken. It took almost one hour bring to table. But it is worthy. The chicken is tender and jucy, especially the bread. The pizza and salad taste good too. We are very enjoy !
author: Jia Y.

description: One of the best restaurants in SF. Place is great - chicken for two is excellent, shoestring fries are delicious, as is just about everything else on the menu. Bartenders make tasty cocktails. Very cool space. Oh and they have beausoleil oysters. Most delicious oysters you can get.
author: Michael C.

description: Caesar salad is fresh and light, oysters were fresh -- our waiter was really conscientious and gave good recommendations based on our preferences, and of course the brined chicken with bread salad. Worth the hour long wait as long as you get some starters -- besides oysters and the Caesar salad, try a bloody mary or the thin cut potato strings. Consistent quality, always tastes good each time I come back. Still really have to try their famous burgers which looked delicious!
author: Shirley L.

description:
I was almost hoping NOT to like this place since it is pricier than the usual places I eat at.  It was excellent and a splendid meal to wish our dear lunch bud and lovely Yelper, Anna, farewell before she, her husband and pooches leave for Australia.

When Toni & I found a parking place on Market Street less than half a block away from Zuni.  and Anna was parked in the space ahead of us----We knew we were off to an auspicious start! 

We got there a few minutes before their opening time of 11:30 and had to wait for them to open the door.  A  couple of people were grumbling because we were getting wet standing in the rain. As soon as they opened the door the grumbling vanished as the gracious hostess tamed and choreographed the crowd. We were ushered to our table which at first glance seemed to be cramped and too close to our future table mates.
It worked out fine.  The couple that sat next to us were warm and friendly
without bring intrusive.  The fellow would make cute remarks about our food choices.  He seemed to be a "regular" and interacted with the staff as if they were lifelong friends.


As we sat trying to figure out to order we were served water and bread & butter--yum!

We narrowed down our choices from their menu of the day.
Our sweet and excellent server, Cherish, smiled and nodded her day at each of our choices.

Onion Soup--deliciously light and flavorful with best crostini (toasted garlicky bits of Heaven) that were satisfyingly crunchy!

Polenta with mascarpone.  Creamy and scrumptious.

Shoestring fries--being the potato-holic I didn't mind that not all of them were as crunchy as they could be.  Toni compared our batch to the 
" first pancake" one makes that is not as perfect as it's predecessors,

I must admit I probably ate more than my share of those potatoes.

The chicken was well worth the wait.  It came with dark arugula leaves and a bread stuffing.  It reminded me of roasted chicken we had for special Sundays when I was a kid.  Moist and delicately seasoned.

We still had some leftover chicken despite our best efforts to eat it all.
Toni was able to take the leftovers home to Alan.

We of course had dessert--bittersweet chocolate mousse with whipped cream.  Wow--creamy and made from a very high quality chocolate.

Its kind of ironic we ended our meal with the bittersweet mousse since
we felt sad to say good-bye to Anna but happy that she, her husband and puppies will be having untold adventures in their new home in Australia.

Thanks Zuni for the great meal and A+ service.
I appreciated that they kept our water glasses full--my cup runneth over with gratitude!

Although I have my gripes about Yelp I am grateful for all the wonderful people I've met through their website. Some folks I've yet to meet in person but hope to someday. Anna and Toni are two of my favorite Yelp buds.

Good Luck Anna---we'll miss you!
author: Rinky N.

description: Another amazing experience. Exceptional wait staff. The roasted chicken continues to keep us coming back. Great French wine list. Thanks for a Great Sunday night dining experience.
author: Curtis H.

description: This place is definitely delicious for anybody that comes here I would recommend to get the roasted chicken... It takes over an hour to cook but it is amazing when it comes out and very very delicious this is a great spot in the middle of downtown San Francisco and they are open late I would recommend anyone to stop by
author: Derek F.

description: Been here twice & I have yet to try their acclaimed chicken. I was heading over here for lunch thinking, third time's a charm but, last minute my friend & I decided to grab a bite at our hideout instead. I will say both visits have been extremely pleasant. Ambience is very friendly, minimalistic with lots of natural light. Both times, I was seated upstairs by the window with no reservations. The wait staff knows their menu very well & are quick to suggest other options asides from their roasted chicken. The last visit, I ordered their arugula fennel salad w/ kumquats. I can still remember how delicious the vinaigrette dressing was. We shared a pizza but it was just like any other nice wood fired brick pizza. Their cocktails list is great, though. Next visit I'm going to make sure I have enough time to grub on the chicken.
author: Kero S.

description:
Not sure what the hype is all about.  Supposedly their roast chicken is amazing - I did not have that.  

Drink: Prosecco with elderflower YUMMY.  You can give me champagne, sparkling wine, prosecco anytime. I LOVE THEM. Elderflower was a nice touch.

Appetizer: Mussels - was pretty good. 

Shoe string fries: I love the quantity of shoe string fries you get.  It's a massive PILE.

Mains:
Pork chop - was good
Lamb - was good
Grouper - was good (but their brussel sprout side was not)

Dessert:
Gateaux Victoire (basically flourless chocolate cake) - was okay - not really dense which is what I expected flourless chocolate cake to be.

Lemon Tartlet - probably the runniest tartlet I've ever had.  Was tangy and pretty good.

As a birthday do we got kumquat ice cream - and I thought this was probably the best dessert out of 3 we had. 

As you can see from my review, I wasn't blown away.  It was not bad - atmosphere was clean and cute and it's definitely a decent restaurant, but not mindblowingly amazing.
author: Sujan H.

description:
There was nothing special about the food or ambiance to merit returning. 

Sunday lunch: 
Rabbit and poached egg & frisée  sprigs. Meager portion size.  Seasoned with smoked paprika oil but otherwise flavorless. 
Caesar salad - overpriced romaine & bread cubes.  This could be easily thrown together at home, so why bother spending $10 for it at a restaurant?
We were a party of five.  There was an obligatory 18% gratuity added to bill.   While the service was pleasant, it didn't compensate for the over-priced and under-sized food.  
The noise level made us shout to be heard.   The "music" only worsened this situation.
No reason to go back in this town with so many choices of eateries.
author: Anne J.

description: Great food, nice atmosphere.  A little bit pricey but food was delicious.  We had our two year old and they didn't have any kid selections besides simple pasta..but I don't think most people bring children here.
author: Andrea R.

description:
We had reservations at 8:30 and our table wasn't ready when we arrived, which I didn't mind because they conveniently had a nice bar on their first floor. Drinks were strong, but good.

This restaurant had quite an..... interesting building structure. All of the seating is upstairs and it kind of felt like a maze - a narrow hallway and there were rooms branching from the hallway. Apart from that, i enjoyed the ambiance of the place; the music was great and we received good service from our waitress. 

We were told the chicken for 2 dish takes an hour to cook so we ordered that ahead of time. Started off with oysters - they were good, but after all of the $1 happy hour oysters around town, $3/oyster seemed a bit steep. 

The chicken was surprisingly good. My favorite part was the stuffing which paired really well with the chicken. Yeah, it was definitely good, but $50 for the dish was kind of pricey (i could get like 10 Costco chickens with that and probably be just as satisfied!).

Anyways, this place is a cute little place to come to for dinner, if you're in the mood for chicken i would suggest giving this place a try.
author: Angela K.

description:
I'm mixed on this place. Here's why:

The good:
-Decent cocktails
-Good ambiance
-The burger. Although they only serve it at lunchtime or after 10 p.m.
-The chicken -- or so I hear. We were surrounded by people getting the chicken, although it takes an hour to prepare. It was already after 10 p.m., and we were starving. Perhaps next time.
-The pot de creme was awesome.

The bad:
-My food came out cold. I mentioned it to the server, he took it back to the kitchen, and 15 minutes later, brought it out. The plate was steaming hot, but the food was still cold. The server took it off the bill.
-My steak (cold or not) was decent, but it was pretty overpriced for what it was.

Would I give it another chance? Maybe for the chicken. But that's probably about it.
author: Paulette B.

description: I liked it!   The staff were helpful, the food good, the atmosphere pleasant.  I wish I had time to get the chicken, alas we were on a tight schedule as we had a show to catch.  The food was pretty and tasty, but portions are small.  My entree felt more like an appetizer, the appetizer like an amuse bouche.  The anchovy and celery plate, with the olives and cheese, would fit into a 1/4 measuring cup.  Maybe less.  Don't come with a big appetite, or fill up on bread and butter.
author: Rebecca H.

description: Our experience at Zuni was hit and miss. The oysters, bread, Manhattan, vegetable gratin, Caesar salad and panna cota were all very good. The Bloody Mary (both styles) were instant heartburn. Waaaaay too much vinegar and totally unbalanced. The roasted chicken for two (which is supposed to be their specialty) was absolutely awful. The meat was dry and chewy and clung to your teeth. The skin was soft and rubbery. Gross. You'd be better off with a roast chicken from Costco (which are gross also, but better than what we were served at Zuni for $50). I also got a 12 dollar salad that was basically a pile of arugula, overpriced and poorly executed. Atmosphere and service were good.
author: Hannah Aria W.

description:
White table cloths, waiters with long white aprons,  distinct architecture with exposed brick, and large red tiles on the floors and copper bar. 

So overall great atmosphere - however it was hot because of the oven they use to roast their chicken.  So when we asked to open the window our problems started there.. 

The my aunt ordered the Caesar salad after checking that the anchovies were pureed into the dressing - they weren't.. there were small chunks of anchovies through out the salad - YUCK.

My aunt and I had both ordered the burger - mine rare and hers medium rare - mine showed up raw and hers showed up just squeaking by raw.  

When my aunt pointed out that the meat wasn't well done enough and said she didn't want  a replacement - all our server could say was Oh.  

Which is sad to say because we had been here previously and had better service from the same server.  At least the server could have said.. Oh I am sorry.

Sheesh where has customer service gone these days?

The chicken which my mom and spouse ordered was great.

The fries were good although over salted and frustrating to eat they were so thin although it made for a good presentation.

The bathrooms needed to be cleaned more frequently - given the trash was overflowing.

Other things to be aware of-
4% health surcharge will be added to support San Francisco universal health care program.  $20 corkage fee and 18% gratitude of groups 6 or more

Eh.. it was a less than mediocre experience for the price.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Zuni has absolutely amazing service, from the hostess to our waitress very knowledgable and super helpful and friendly.
Roast chicken is delicious, so is the burger.. and the fries and well just about everything! Love the ambience, it's a great venue will definitely return soon.
author: Shelly W.

description: got an email from Yelp, "How was Zuni?". ill tell ya how good Zuni was, better than ever thats how. You would think with a place where the menu does not change much and is relatively small they could get a bit tired. Not the case at all. And the menu has some welcome additions. Had the Chicken and Cesar of course and a new addition which i cant remember what it was called or how it was described but it was amazing. it was some kind of pork on a slice of sourdough. The aroma was immediately familiar and after a few seconds it hit me. Pho! it was Pho without the consume and noddles. i know its sounds weird but it was amazing. One short coming, we had the wagon wheel pizza also, which we have had before, but it was pretty sad to say the least. cold, under seasoned and flimsy. I chalk it up to ya cant hit a homerun every time. Oh and the service was as always perfect.
author: Dennis K.

description: If you love oysters, Zuni Cafe will, unlike life, never let you down.  I've had oysters every time I eat here, & I always feel they're the best oysters I've ever had.  I'm at Zuni now, in fact, & yet again, feel that the Washington kumamoto I just swallowed whole was the best single oyster I've ever enjoyed.  In, like, life!  Zuni!  My favorite spot in SF!
author: Roland C.

description:
We were looking forward to trying this restaurant, knowing it was influenced by my all-time favorite - Chez Panisse - in Berkeley: creative food made with local, organic, sustainable ingredients. The place is big and open and was quite busy on a Saturday night. We had made a reservation and were promptly seated. I had mentioned then that I was gluten intolerant and they confirmed that most of the menu was gf, aside from a couple dishes. The starters were either gluten or not too inspiring, so we ordered 2 entrees directly: halibut and duck. After gazing at our neighbors anchovy starter, we were comforted in our decision to skip the starters. The portions were ridiculously small, more like an amuse-bouche! Our entrees arrived, piping hot and well presented. The meats were cooked properly, but the vegetables were more ornamental. I was hoping to order a side of vegetables, but there were none. They offer various gf dessert options. We decided to go for the flour-less chocolate cake, aka Gateau Victoire. It had a nice texture, strong chocolate flavor and was not too sweet. Service was fine, could have been more knowledgable of gluten sensitivity. The wine list per glass was limited and did not offer any organic or local wine surprisingly, considering this is what the restaurant is about. 
All would have been well and could have warranted a 4-star rating, if it was not for the overly priced dishes coming in small portions, lack of vegetables and GLUTEN reaction I am still suffering from 24h later... Not sure if it was cross-contamination or if the waitress/cook did not know what they were talking about.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
My husband and I went here 4 or 5 years ago on a trip to SF after reading reviews about the roast chicken for two. We had such an amazing dinner that night that we haven't stopped talking about it since - which sounds silly when you're talking about roast chicken. 
We recently went back for our first wedding anniversary, and wondered if it would live up to our memories. It did. Since we didn't have (and couldn't get) a reservation, we got there around 6:15 on a Saturday and had no trouble getting a table in the small bar. Service was okay, not great. The chicken was exactly as we remembered, and the point Reyes Miyagi oysters were delicious. Oh, the mojitos and flourless chocolate cake weren't bad either....
author: Lisa B.

description:
Just went here this morning for the first time. Awesome spot. We walked right in and got seated. The food comes out super quick and it's delicious! They change the menu every day and get their food from local farmers markets. The panna cotta dessert melts in your mouth. The portions are a perfect size. And to top it all off the service is top notch  It's a bit pricey, but you get what you pay for

~ TheWaterGuy
author: Daniel T.

description: Food is incredible but sit downstairs if you want to hear yourself think. The piano player was great but the restaurant has poor acoustics. We were upstairs with a party of six and basically decided not to have conversations as it wasn't worth the effort. The 20-somethings with us agreed that the sound was just terrible. If this place makes some changes to accommodate the noise I would easily give 5 stars.
author: T C.

description:
Came here in a party of 7 for an early dinner before catching a show. We tried to make reservations earlier that week but they were all booked so we decided to just try walking in. We got lucky and squished into a couple small tables downstairs in the bar area. It was a bit cramped but luckily a couple near us finished their meal quickly and the waiter gave us some extra table space. They were in the middle of transitioning their menu from afternoon to dinner when we sat down. Their menus are actually printed at meal time on a daily basis, so we had to wait a bit to get their dinner menu . Many of us were still full having eaten lunch only a few hours prior so we decided to just get a few dishes to split.

We ended up getting two orders of their famous brick-oven roasted chicken with bread salad, shoestring fries, a scallops appetizer, and their gnocchi. Sad to say, the chicken was a bit underwhelming. I dare say that the rotiserrie chicken from Costco is comparable to this one...although that isn't necessarily a bad thing as I love Costco chicken. But taking into consideration that Zuni's costs 10x more, it leaves a whole lot to be desired. I will credit them with the fantastic bread salad underneath the chicken which is a stroke of pure genius. I've never had anything like that with a chicken dish. The bread soaks up all the oil and juices running off from the chicken and just picks up all the great flavors in a delicious package.

Everything else was just pretty good, nothing exceptional. I will note that their gnocchi was unlike anything I've ever tried before. It had a silk smooth texture, my teeth cut into it like butter. Although I'm not really fan of gnocchi, I'm guessing this dish took a great deal of finesse. Overall, I had a great time, but I think that was more so to do with the company I was with that night than the food. I would like to come back to try the burger sometime as their seems to be a general positive consensus about it, but I'm not really in a rush to do so.
author: Kevin N.

description: We stopped in for their famous Bloody Mary and were not disappointed. We also ordered their French fries as a late morning snack. As seen in the pictures, they are piled high and perfectly delicious, whether as a side or just on their own. I'd come from any side of town for those things! The service was nothing to complain about either, despite the fact we didn't order a meal!
author: Lauren P.

description:
Location is everything, and it's the one aspect of Zuni that will hook you in. Having passed by their enticing windows several times during my visit to SF, we finally caved when the piano man's rousing music was too much to resist from the outside.
