The name "Cafe" is an awful descriptor. While their coffee was great, the food, libations and ambiance exceeded that of a typical cafe. 

For a party of two, our eyes were bigger than our stomachs. Our platter of oysters, house-cured anchovy appetizer, chicken for two and dessert sent us over the moon. 

Oysters didn't come with Tabasco or grated horseradish. Instead, there was a choice of a vodka vinaigrette or fresh lemon. The famous chicken? Absolutely moist and delicious. Topped off with a few glasses from their wine list, and some figs with cheese and you have an effervescent night!
author: Sharon F.

description:
I have lived in SF for 4 years and I have heard only great things about this restaurant. I cannot believe I have waited this long!

But I am happy to say that my husband and I were able to enjoy a fantastic meal on a Tuesday evening.  

Here are my thoughts. Hope this helps! 

1)  Booking a reservation is highly recommended. 
2)  Get a cocktail or two while you wait to be seated. (Elderflower Cocktail -- So divine and always classy)
3)  Space is so beautiful, so try to sit at the top or near where all the chefs are preparing the magical cuisine.  
    (I would love to live in this type of loft as a home!) 
4)  When you get seated, order the ROASTED CHICKEN immediately! It takes about one hour to cook.  Keep in mind to  order 1, which feeds 4 people and more.  Trust me, we took the leftovers home. :)  Juiciest chicken I have ever ate in my life! This changed my life! Please enjoy the warm bread piled underneath the chicken.
5)  Enjoy the personalized menu that changes ever-so-often.  

Ambiance:
Amazing, romantic (but not too much),  vintage with hints of modern art throughout the restaurant,  love the brick walls, long glass windows, elaborate cocktail bar, spacious, welcoming.  

Service: 
Friendly, attentive and super informative.  We couldn't finish our glass of water because they kept refilling it.  I call this great service! :)

Price: 
Not bad at all.  Portion was definitely a generous amount.  (This is what I am talking about!)  Above all, definitely worth paying $48 for a roasted chicken.  Their warm bread and salad is delicious. 

Everything went so well and we will definitely come back to Zuni again! 

I totally recommend this place to all locals and visitors! 

Happy Yelping!
author: Deborah C.

description:
Excellent food, decor, and service.  The only problem is that getting a table is quite competitive for a weekend dinner.  

SEATS:  Very interesting multi-level triangular structure that offers various seating arrangements.  Every seat is so different, so cross your fingers and hope that you get a nice seat.  While the bar area was loud, seating upstairs was relatively quiet.

SERVICE:  Our server Nathan was very nice and accommodating.  Although the restaurant was full, he had time to chat with us and didn't rush the service at all.  

FOOD:  Their signature dish, roasted chicken for two ($41), was definitely worth the one hour wait.  The meat was very juicy, not dry at all, seasoned very nicely with salt and vinegar.  I really enjoyed their Espresso Granita, which was frozen espresso made into shaved ice with tasty cream.  Wow, I could come here just for that!  

PRICE:  For one of the best restaurants in the city, price wasn't too expensive.  

Dinner for two:
$41 - Chicken for Two 
$32 --- Bottle of Merlot
$6 --- Espresso Granita Dessert
$21 --- Tip and Taxes
-----------------------
$101 Total ($50/person)
author: トモ T.

description: Nice food and atmosphere! The oven baked chicken is as good as they say and the service is not too bad too. This place is crowded though and needs reservation far in advance.
author: Sharon L.

description:
Don't talk just yet.

Don't look at the menu just yet.

Don't stand up and excuse yourself for the bathroom just yet.

First things first. Handle business. Before you start anything else, anything at all, put your order in for their roasted chicken and bread salad. There is an expected hour of cooking time required. Get that out of the way and you can proceed with your dining experience. Your waiter will even thank you for asking in advance.

Some things to consider about their roasted chicken:

*it's their signature item
*it takes an hour to make, no less
*it's pricey at $48, but can be shared between 2-3 people
*it's full of tender, flavorful meat with delicately crispy skin
*it's served with delightful vinegarette-infused bread salad & lightly olive-oiled arugula, currants, and pine nuts
*it should never be confused or ever compared to a Costco type of chicken
*it's definitely worth the wait

Whew, glad we got that out of the way!

Other dishes my gal pals & I shared:
*zuni caesar salad 
*salmon with brussel sprouts and pancetta
*ricotta gnocchi- aka pillows of love
*classicly delicious creme brulee

Bottom line: We absolutely enjoyed the food-  especially the roasted chicken, the service was immaculate (thank you, Jeff), the ambiance was perfect, and the company was wonderful. 

Thank you for bringing the wine, Janice C. 

Tips:
*the menu changes daily
*make reservations, otherwise only the bar & patio are available for walk-in guests
*once you've had their chicken, you've completed item #1 from the SF 7x7 list of places to try before you die. Score!
author: Joy A.

description:
Cute corner bar filled with many professionals. Easy place to bump in and 

meet people like Christine & Kelly did with "sweater guy"...

The bar is always full and the crowd slightly older but you can walk up to 

"B" wine bar if you need a change of scenery.
author: Jennifer C. L.

description: Good food, light on the portions.  Had the lamb and sausage.  Great area nice location.
author: Todd A.

description:
After many years of saying that I'll try this place, it's finally happened. 

When we got seated, we made sure to put in our order for the Roasted Chicken (it really did take an hour, so don't forget this time saving tip). We also ordered ricotta Gnocchi, manila clams, & duck breast dishes to share.

Everything that came to our table was nicely presented and really tasty. The gnocchi was unique, the clams light and fresh, and the duck breast seared perfectly. Of course, the main dish everyone talks about, the roasted chicken (which could have fed more then two) was juicy with crispy skin with a delicious bread salad.

For dessert we had the Gâteau Victoire, aka the flourless chocolate cake. This was AMAZING. I expected it to be heavy and dense like most flourless cakes, but it was the complete opposite. It was light and really felt like it melted in your mouth. Delicious.

Overall thoughts: All the food was delicious, no doubt. However, I felt that I wasn't completely satisfied, as the portions didn't balance with the bill. I would totally come back just for that cake though. Can I get it "to go"?
author: Stephanie K.

description:
Zuni is one of those places I always assumed I'd go to, but never have because you can't just walk in and I don't usually plan ahead to eat at restaurants that have been around forever.  I got lucky, and got in with some coworkers recently.  The space was nice and urban, though oddly laid out.  Service was great, but I wasn't wowed by the food or drinks.
I had a dark and stormy at the bar and eh, it was okay.  I had oysters (for the first time ever!) and they were just fine, despite my lifelong avoidance of the little bivalves.  The food was . . . good.  Not amazing, but good.  I guess I should've gone on an evening when I had an hour to wait for the chicken.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
5 Stars, 5 Golden Rings, Snap-snap-snap and the BEST Roasted Chicken on the planet!!!  A special birthday celebration for my fiancé -- what better venue than Zuni Cafe.  After delicious and perfect martinis at Martunis, we strolled across and down the street to our celebratory dinner for two at Zuni!  The young woman that greeted us unfortunately not enthusiastic about her evening but we moved quickly to the bar to await our trek upstairs and across to the perfect table, private, yet included in the hustle/bustle and a splendid view!

We were greeted by our fabulous waiter and attended to in a wonderful fashion all evening.  To start, we were brought fresh and amazingly scrumptious bread/butter to be enjoyed by the first sip of Ehlers estate, 120/80 Cabernet, we brought from home. First, our waiter selected 6 spectacular oysters, 3 different kinds--we LOVED them!  Second, we shared the potato puree with black truffle, caramelized onions - enough said, it was lovely and we enjoyed every last bit!  Third, we savored a winter root soup --total perfection in taste and presentation--beautiful in every respect!  And for the finale, we fell in love with the roasted chicken and bread salad--The best chicken/bread salad I have had, ever, ever, ever!  The combination of flavors, cooked perfectly -- heaven, heaven, heaven.

We are eager to return to Zuni for cocktails, dinner or both!

Thank you to the waiter and the chefs for a perfect evening and delicious dinner.

A most pleasant surprise indeed!
author: Jeff P.

description:
We were able to secure a last minute table via Open Table as the hostess who answered the phone said they were booked solid.  Zuni is located in a sleek-hip spot in cool area in the business district of the CIty.  

Disabled beware as there are many tight spaces and stairs to negotiate should you venture off the main floor.  Wheel Chairists and those with mobility issues need to specify a ground floor table request. 

Albeit cool ambiance and architecturally intricate design, the upstairs dining spaces are rather tight and lacking a tad in air-flow.  Loud patrons can be intrusive especially if a huge party is present.  This is not for the quiet crowd.

We were welcomed by a pleasant hostess who was surprised by our reservation.  We were taken up a steep staircase then traversed a maze of rooms and stairways that went up and down.  We were seated in a tight space at a table which was also rather confining.  It was a bit warm especially for San Francisco.

The meal was very good. We ordered a bottle of Kistler Pinot which had not been stored in a wine cellar, but rather in the basement of the restaurant.  The vino was quite tasty, just wish it was stored a little better for the price. Our apps were a selection of fresh and delish oysters.  Wow. They were terrific! We also enjoyed the Caesar Salad. We shared the Pork Chop, Tuna and of course, their highly regarded chicken.  Each one of the entrees were sumptuous and well plated.  All three were cooked to perfection.  Likewise the desserts were might fine. We enjoyed a nice tart. flour-less chocolate cake and a lovely cappuccino gilate treat.

Our server was knowledgeable, professional and courteous. She knew her peeps; the foods and made excellent recommendations.

I enjoyed this dining experience very much.
author: Max M.

description:
Zuni cafe - my absolute go-to for my 4pm late "brunches".

It is the perfect place to nurse a hangover with a balsamic Bloody Mary with the lunch crowds gone, and a great place to enjoy a long, lazy late lunch.

I usually get:

- Oysters: Kuushi (my favorites) and the Washington kumamotos. Zuni has a great blanc de blancs champagne by the glass, get that and some shoe lace fries to go with your oysters!

- Roast chicken for two OR the Burger (divine, note that they do not serve this at dinner) // A bottle of 2008 Casanova di Neri Brunello always makes the afternoon better.

- Gateau Victoire - possibly one of the lightest, fluffiest flourless chocolate cakes I've ever had in my life.

Also love the staff at Zuni, always friendly and welcoming. The restaurant hostess Francesca and our waitress Michelle are both lovely girls so be sure to look out for them.
author: Amber S.

description:
DONT COME HERE IF YOU ARE STARVING!!!!!!

One hour wait for the chicken.

We had a bottle of Pinot with oysters and shoestring fries.
The waiter was very helping with the selection of the oysters.

Now to the chicken. AHHHHH MAZINGGGGGG!!!!

MOIST check
CRISPY SPIN check
FLAVORFUL check


will def come here again but not hungry -___-
author: Anne-Mary P.

description: Nice environment and good service, the food, is really sub par, we ordered sea bass and duck leg, not very well made but 30$ each, cocktail is better but not impressive, I think you really just pay for the environment like many other pretentious restaurants in Hayes valley
author: Jeff Y.

description:
Hearing about  Zuni Café forever, we decided to take our family of 9 (includes 3 children ages 8 and 12) for Break The Fast,  Our dinner reservations were for 6:00PM but we got there at 5:35PM.  We were told, and saw, that our table was empty but they could not seat us until 6:00.  So after a $205, not including tip, bar bill they sent us upstairs.

The kids wanted hamburgers, but were told they stopped serving them at 6:00PM (go figure) and the chef would not make an exception.  Not much on the menu for kids, in fact there is not much on the menu.  When we finally received our dinners  everyone was very disappointed with the portions and taste.  As I have been reading previous reviews I find the  common complaint is portion size and noise.  I will also add service to that list and value ( a lot of money for very little)

The service was very poor.  I know we were not the type of guests they want, and it showed.  As the room filled up, the noise level increased, and as the noise level increased we couldn't hear so we got louder.  We also got louder because we were not get served so rather than eating we were talking and play games. Oh did I mention it was hot upstairs.

I can think of many great restaurants in the area were I would rather spend my $675.00 and would feel welcomed.
author: Charles C.

description:
Came here with my sweetheart to celebrate my birthday.
Good thing we got there early and had a seat at the bar area which did not feel like a bar area.
The drinks were excellent.
Our server, Stephen, was excellent and had recommended a great bottle of wine.
We started out with some drinks on the menu
Oysters from different regions
Entree: The baked chicken was delish with the Crack Bread. OMG - the bread!
We ended with finding out a lady sitting next to us was also celebrating her bday, same day and same name! That was fun!
author: PreciousSwt P.

description:
I love, love, love this place for a wintertime late lunch -- oysters with sancerre, roast chicken with a nice burgundy -- the wine list is well chosen.  I try to go every year.  

i was less excited about it for an early dinner during the summer.  The caesar salad is kind of a mess -- and an arugula salad with a burrata crostini had oddly tough & unpalatable arugula.  (and naturally, i wanted more burrata on that crostini, but maybe that's just me).  The mains were OK.  I would say 'solid' more than 'remarkable.'  

I have to say i find it annoying that you cannot order the burger between 5 pm - 10 pm.  if it's a price thing (i.e. they'd rather sell a more expensive entree), then maybe they should just raise the price between those hours, maybe adding an extra side to make it more of a dinner entree.  But if somebody's heard about that burger -- and wants to try the restaurant because he wants to try that burger -- it should be possible to get the burger.  Maybe offer it on request only, not putting it on the menu?  I don't know, it seems to be a thing for them.  

So 5-star winter late lunch, averaged with 3-star summer early dinner (sans burger) - i think 4 star yelp makes sense for Zuni.
author: Jaina S.

description:
The list of things I am willing to wait for is pretty short, bathrooms don't even make the cut most of the time.  When it is food, I will usually make an exception. The brick oven roasted chicken for two is worthy of its *hour wait. The crispy skin melts in your mouth with a certain decadence that is just the right amount of wrong. The guest-starring bread salad is warm, spongey and so good you kind of want to eat it with your hands. Try to resist though, you're in a restaurant. 

*during the hour wait, I sampled some of the shoe-string potatoes and cured olives. I can't pretend I waited an entire hour without eating or drinking anything. That would be dishonest and your trust means a lot to me, strangers.
author: Abby M.

description:
Most overrated restaurant I've been to in SF. Everything tasted fine, but each dish I had made me think of somewhere else I'd had it better (and cheaper). I want to give this place 2 stars, but I'll bump it up to 3 because the service was very good. 

The chicken takes an hour to cook and it's $50. You can go to Limon in the mission and get a bird out to you in 20 minutes that's half the cost and twice as flavorful. Zuni's doesn't even come close to theirs. 

I really wanted to like this place more given it's a "classic" restaurant here in the city.  But given the abundance of choices in SF, you could do so much more with your time and money.
author: Erik L.

description: Been wanting to come here for years and try the roast chicken and it was definitely worth the wait.  Delicious chicken with an amazing bread salad.  All items we ordered were great including the salads and fresh oysters.  Wine list isn't deep but it is full of high quality wines for very fair prices.  Service was excellent.  I definitely want to come back and sample the rest of the menu.
author: John O.

description:
Here's the short version: nice ambiance, good food, but small dishes (two of us left hungry). Not worth the price. 

Now the long version: We had a pleasant dinner at Zuni. We sat in a small room with a nice ambiance, and our server was pleasant, though he responded to almost everything by saying "lovely." The food was mostly good, not great (the sole entree tasted only of butter). 

One star off for the sole, and another for this: after appetizers, entrees, and dessert, the men in our party were still hungry, and talked about going to get a torta. 

For the price, better food can be had.
author: Kurt A.

description:
Zuni's Cafe is quite a San Francisco establishment.  This restaurant is famed for Roast Chicken for Two with Warm Tuscan Style Bread Salad (48.00).

Be warned however.  The roast chicken tastes shockingly similar in texture and flavor to the $5.00 Costco rotisserie chicken (in fact our party thought the Costco chicken was less dry).  To achieve a similar experience, place seasonal greens and bread salad on a white platter and place Costco rotisserie chicken on top.

Et voila !  You have saved yourself more than $45.00 on this one dish alone and have created it in the ambiance of your very own home.

DIY is all the rage.
author: Fei L.

description:
Nope. Came here for dinner, and it was a no-go for this vegetarian.

With barely any vegetarian options, we ended up getting pasta, which was pretty bad. The gnocchi was all right but a bit small and drenched in EVOO. Bucatini was terrible.

Shoe sting potatoes were too salty and too greasy.

Come on.. This is San Fran... step it up on the veggie options, please. #VegetariansGetSickOfPastaToo

#vegetarian review
author: Eric H.

description: I have been to Zuni a few times. I have to say i always order the chicken that they are famous for and its always great, I just add the fries with it. The service is good but just remember it does take a little time if you order the chicken but worth the wait.
author: Robert R.

description:
My coworkers and I went here for my birthday. I was excited with the supposedly best chicken in SF. The restaurant is sun-filled, kinda small. but gorgeous in a sunny day. It's not really great for talking though, since the mostly-glass wall just bounce around people's voices.

Once we sit down, I ordered the roast chicken since it's gonna take an hour. We ordered the shoestring fries and pizza to curb our hunger while waiting for the chicken.

The pizza with mozzarella, fresh Asiago, Parmesan, Gorgonzola, and walnuts is pretty good and simple. Shoestring fries is a little bit too thin for me. I need to grab a few in my hand since one piece doesn't make me feel like I've eaten any.

Finally the roast chicken comes, which literally takes an hour. Chicken is really moist but I find it a little bit too boring since the portion is really big. We shared the chicken for 3 people. The bread stuffing is soaked in olive oil and balsamic, didn't taste super great since my lips become all oily.

I think their roast chicken is good, but too boring for my liking. Give me fried chicken any time.
author: Novalina N.

description:
so yes, we came here because my friend was visiting from NYC and was talking about this restaurant for a really long time. We finally made it to the restaurant and got to try the famous chicken. so it was more about the stuffing greasiness than the chicken for 2 itself, i think. Delicious and everyone talks about it even when waiting in line for the restroom. right... 
also tried fresh oysters and the friee salad with beets and avacado. alllllll worth the money and anticipation! Definitely going back again to try more of their yumminess.

great ambiance and service. we made a reservation a while back. so hm, not too sure what the wait is usually.
author: Ai L.

description:
This was my 1 fancy dinner for the weekend. So glad that it was here.
Based on reviews and press, I just had to try this damn chicken. 
Yes I waited the hour.
Yes we noshed on a sampler of a dozen oysters (my faves were the hog kumamotos as it was the creamiest & smoothest one)
Yes I prepped my tummy with a clean endive salad...perfectly dressed and light. I actually finished the entire plate which I rarely do.
Yes we dived into the chicken like hyenas.
SURPRISE we ordered the cod braised with mussels and I actually liked this better than the chicken. 
Top that off, we had the panna cotta dessert to share and I jiggled it as if it were a boob. I just cant help it with panna cotta. but i digress. This was very very delicious.

This place is worth a repeat performance for sure.
author: Rae F.

description:
Z U N I 
Always excellent.  I used to work there, as a headstrong mid-twenties explorer enjoying the food scene and really enjoying the benefits of such a busy restaurant.  I took my parents there after the Nutcracker and we had a lovely time.  The bar service was lack-luster, hence the 3 stars - otherwise I'd give it a resounding 5.

A D R I E N N E
What can I say?  If I owned a restaurant, I would want her to run it.  She is simply amazing (oh, and so is Rob Smith).

B A R + C O C K T A I L S
The bartender (dark hair, young woman) was particularly rude to my father.  He asked for a "peach martini" (he is not as sophisticated as other ZUNI-ites, but a customer nonetheless).  She said I don't have peach or anything peach-related.  He then asked for an appletini, and was told - "we don't have pucker."  

Guess what?  I'm privy to the whole upscale-pre-prohibition era cocktail movement (I work in the industry), the trend away from colored crap in drinks, etc. - but the proper response would have been - "I don't have a peach martini, but perhaps something fruity and holiday-esque might be what you're looking for" or "I can make you something with calvados, an apple brandy from France - ever had an apple-style Sazerac?"  or really anything other than what was said.  

My dad said he felt "stupid" and a guest should never feel that way.  Not all customers are foodies ordering Sazeracs and Elderflower cocktails, but it's an establishment's job to non-pretensiously create an experience for the paying customer, who they are.  He wasn't ordering "SAKE BOMBS" or "JAGGER BOMBS" - he just wanted a fruity cocktail.

The cocktails were otherwise delicious.

J E F F + T R A I N E E
Charming, attentive and non-intrusive.  My parents and I can be quite a bit to handle, and they did it with grace.  We stayed late and were not rushed out.  Jeff is a gem and we LOVED him and his trainee.  Thank you again!
author: Mo J.

description:
Just to start with - if you're planning on coming here for their 7x7-listed, signature item, be prepared.  Not only is it going to require a bit of patience, but perhaps a relatively thick wallet (depending on how much you're willing to pay for chicken).

Zuni Cafe's famed Roasted Chicken with Bread Salad is a whole, organic (and possibly free range?) chicken that's roasted in a wood oven and served over a lightly toasted bread salad with a balsamic vinegar-ish dressing.  If you're getting it, there are two important things to know.  First, make sure to put in your order with your server as soon as you're seated.  Given that it takes about 45-60 minutes, you're definitely going to want that head start!

Second, it's priced at about $48.  While that might seem scary, think of it this way - given that it's meant to serve two (thanks for being there foodie buddy!), it's really only $24 a person for half a chicken and salad.  Much more reasonable!  And if you're on a date, then shelling out $48 might win you points for being a serious foodie!  Sure, the alternative is that they'll think you're crazy for paying that much for CHICKEN, but I'm an optimist.

If you're still worried, take comfort in the fact that the chicken is pretty darn good.  Not only do they do a great job of breaking it down into meaty, manageable pieces, but it's cooked perfectly as well.  Each bite was moist and tender and the skin was nice and crispy.  The seasoning is a little too delicate, but it had just a kiss of smokiness from their wood oven.

As for the bread salad, I think it was almost as good as the chicken itself (my friend commented that she actually enjoyed the salad more than the chicken),  The bread is lightly toasted on the outside, but (for better or worse) has soaked up some of the chicken drippings (so that's where the fat/juices went...) to make it really flavorful.  The dressing was a bit sharp/tart, but it worked well by cutting though all of that savoriness from the chicken.

Since we wanted to save our appetite for the Roasted Chicken, we only ordered one other dish.  I can't recall the name or description of what we had (it's been a few months and it's not listed on their online menu), but it was a pasta dish with red sauce and duck (I think).  It was decent enough; nothing exceptional, nothing terrible.  I agree with what Sophia K. said though - their smaller dishes are more to tie you over and complement the chicken than anything else.

Although the chicken is definitely worth trying if you've never had it, I'd temper expectations just so that you don't overhype it for yourself.  Then again, you could easily do worse by spending this much on a bad steak...
author: Mike L.

description:
there are very few options for vegans here, but it's a great place for people watching, delish cocktails and POMME FRITES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!  

if you come early, it's easy to get a bistro table over by the bar.
author: Virginia D.

description: $48 for a chicken dinner . . . .  Ok, I got it.  Was it good?  Yes.  Was it better than the rotisserie chicken I got from my Costco two weeks ago?  No.  Plus the waitress really got on my nerves when she informed me they did not do refills on soft drinks.  Well, you sell them don't you?
author: Roger Y.

description:
I have to confess that my much-anticipated dinner at Zuni was a bit fuzzy thanks to a few too many Moscow Mules in the afternoon.  I recall running downstairs to stick my head in a toilet before ordering - which is all to say, take my review with a grain of salt.

Considering I was a bit sick at dinner, I had a great time at Zuni.  I came with a party of ten, which was the maximum party size, and we were seated upstairs among white walls and light wood at a long table set with white tablecloth.  We had a six o'clock reservation and with the sun still out, the space felt cheerful and welcoming.  Service was helpful.  We were a large party and I can't think of a single goof on Zuni's end.

The food was pretty fantastic.  I was able to enjoy it despite my debilitated state, and I remember everything I ate.  We started with some crusty rustic brown bread, then ordered a bunch of dishes more or less family style.

Believe everything you hear about Zuni's roast chicken.  It is an absolute must.  It serves two people, and I would recommend it even if ordering it means you don't try anything else.  It was probably the best roast chicken I've ever had, moist and juicy and utterly dripping with pure chicken flavor.  It came on a bed of warm bread salad with scallions, dried currants, red mustard greens, and pine nuts, and this hearty salad would have been worth ordering on its own.  It was excellent under the chicken, as it soaked up the bird's flavorful juices.

Everything else was solid as well.  Zuni uses simple ingredients and precise cooking to deliver some pretty impressive food.  Shoestring potatoes were great, salty and crispy, as was a bowl of gritty, corny polenta with mascarpone.  The burrata alla panna with grilled squash blossom, green beans, and Marash pepper was a superb little dish, with oozy cheese and earthy, piquant flavors.  The orecchiette was another winner, with greens, garlic, lemon zest, red onions, fresh ricotta, and black pepper.  The pasta was perfectly al dente and the flavors were clear and bright.  The Liberty duck breast may not have wowed as much as the chicken, but it was another fabulous entree, served with baby carrots, wild nettles, fresh shelling beans, and chanterelle mushroom relish.

Dessert was less strong than the savory portion of the meal, but still worth getting.  The Maywood Farm fig tart with wildflower honey ice cream was nice, but a little flat.  The figginess was good, but I could have used a little more sugar, even if just from the fruit.  The Gateau Victoire with whipped cream was the better dessert.  I tend to find many chocolate desserts too rich, but this one had a light, almost whipped texture that made it easy to swallow.

Without the chicken, Zuni Cafe would be a strong four star restaurant in my book.  The other dishes were wonderful, but none of them had the same wow factor as that chicken.  That said, the food was consistently delicious and the succulent roasted chicken alone would have been worth going out of our way for.  Maybe I dined in a drunken rapture, but I thought the chicken was perfect, and certainly good enough to merit a full five stars.
author: Steph C.

description:
Sad to see Zuni so far from where it's been. The menu is a sad affair with 5 entree choices. The sausage entree was absurdly wet and crumbly, but simply tasteless. The pizza had a fine thin crust, but why would you slather it with spicy tomato sauce, and then only add the cheese (some kind of mini-ball affair) AFTER baking it, so the cheese was cold and unmelted. The polenta was just OK. the fries were good, not great. 

We've loved Zuni for many years, but it seems to be coasting. Downhill.
author: Joseph D.

description:
Our family had lunch here on our recent trip to SF.  A friend of ours recommended their oysters and it did not disappoint.  However, everything else was.  Their Polenta was seriously underseasoned.  Their hamburger bun was so greasy and not the appropriate for a burger.  They used a panini bread.  The shoe string potato fries were so over fried they tasted like chips.  For the price, I expected a lot more.  
Also, this place is NOT FOR KIDS.  Their bathroom did not have a changing table.  I had to change my daugther in the ladies room with my husband holding her up.
author: Boni P.

description:
Must get the chicken! The whole chicken, and order it as soon as you sit down, even before you order drinks, because it takes an hour to cook, and the anticipation + hunger might make you over order. 

We shared the chicken amongst four of us. We also ordered a salad to share. The Zuni caeser salad, which was delicious, nothing out of the ordinary, but delicious.
author: Anoo L.

description:
Hubby and I went to Zuni Cafe for dinner 5/18/06.  I've read the reviews and chowhounds report so knew exactly what I wanted to order.  We had to wait even though I had reservation because the perfect table that I wanted was occupied, but we still got a nice enough table upstairs in the back-looking down at diners.

You get free bread w/ butter, refilled once for us.  We ordered the chicken w/ bread salad ($39--enough food for 4 though), squid salad ($11), Cesar salad ($9-they split the order in half for us to share-nice), bowl of polenta w/ mascarpone $5.50-they split it for us to share, and the gateau victoire cake $6.50-awesome chocolate cake, you can even get the recipe from the front desk since it's not in the Zuni Cafe cookbook.

Price with tax came to $76.76, not cheap but tasty never the less.  Only leftovers was the chicken dish.  Bathrooms for men and women--only 1 toilet in each, so women plan  to wait in line.

Recommended.
author: Ann L.

description: For the expectations,  price and all, this restaurant doesn't measure. Ordered the Top Sirloin and it was tough and chewy. To make matters worse, waitress still charged for it even though it wasn't touched. Stated "its our policy that even if a plate is returned,  we charge full price". Seriously?
author: Carlos A.

description:
if you order the chicken for 2 (which is ok for 3) & share the caesar salad & stick to just a glass of wine - this place is great & you wont feel ripped off.  
those 2 dishes are excellent & exactly the way they should be.
otherwise, prepare for extremely expensive dishes
 ( like $32 for a fish "stew" which was actually a few very small pieces of seafood in a small puddle of broth - tasty but tiny,
or 
like $19 for a fried appetizer plate which was actually  3 pieces of fried veg & 3 skinny onion rings
or
$10 for a watermelon granita which was actually a few ounces of a  salty (yes salty)watermelon icee with what they said was mezcal but was actually not detectable .

but if you stick to the chicken & caesar  you'll be fine & you'll walk out happy.
author: Kim Y.

description:
Good burger, but at a less than impressive value and price. My friends and I usually go to Umami Burger, but we never gave this place a try so we came here for a quick brunch. 

This place offers a pretty nice ambience, comparable to some 'up-scale' restaurants and some decent food, but the portions are definitely not worth the price. 

I had the House-ground grass-fed beef hamburger on grilled rosemary focaccia with aïoli and Zuni pickles. Surprisingly cheese, onions, and other condiments are extra - you would think that a $15+ burger would have all that already included. Nope. Cheese and sauteed mushrooms costed me an extra $4. Not impressed. What was good though was the actual beef. Cooked very well and to my liking - medium rare. The sauce and bread of the burger was also very very good - especially the focassia bread. Mmm definitely up there. Overall, a good tasting burger, just at a super premium price. 

My friends also ordered some fresh cut fries and oysters which they claim to be pretty good. I'm allergic to the oysters so I can't really have an opinion on them - They were however imported (supposedly) so I doubt that they're fresh. The fries were good, but also had a premium price on them (super thin cut, straw fries). 

Good burger, but to me it left me still hungry and my wallet a lot lighter than I expected.
author: Killah K.

description: To be fair we went at 3 pm Sunday which is not prime time.  But the experience was bad and we won't be back.  The menu had only 4 entrees - chicken that takes 60 minutes, unspecified "fish" with eggplant, something else, and burgers.  Oh and a big menu of oysters and alcohol.  I suppose that might be why people come there.  It's certainly not for the burgers which are what we ordered.  Three burgers cooked medium, one of them plain, how hard can that be?  Everything was messed up.  One burger was red raw and turned my stomach.  The next burger was overdone.  The third which was supposed to be plain was not plain and had to be sent back.  In addition the service was slow and I waited forever for drink refills.  I couldn't finish my burger so the waiter took it back to the kitchen to show them.  The kitchen put it back on the skillet (after I had eaten part of it) which I am sure would not be approved by the health department.  The waiter took this burger off the bill which I appreciated, but we won't be back.  The burgers didn't even taste good - I don't know what kind of meat they use, it's not the standard basic ground chuck, but we didn't care for it.
author: Alan H.

description:
I loved this place, and would certainly find it the perfect type of restaurant for any occasion - a date, a group outing, bringing the parents, or for a business lunch. The restaurant is 2 stories, with the downstairs offering a stunning view of the bar outdoors, whereas the upstairs has about 5 tables with a rustic feel.

Their menu is unique from most others in the city. Their polenta (Appetizers) is super creamy and delicious! They also have their famous roasted chicken that made 7x7's Top 100 List of Foods to Try. Note: It takes nearly an hour, so be patient or call in. As for sides, their fries are a must! Light and crunchy towering a plate - they're fun to eat and super yummy!

They serve brunch on Sundays, lunch Tuesdays-Saturday, and dinner everyday except Monday. Try to make reservations!
author: Veronica S.

description:
Came here to celebrate a special occasion with my girl and it did not disappoint!  I had heard about this place from the 2010 7x7 list, the menu looked interesting, and the reviews/pictures made me think this place would be a winner.

We ordered some of the raw Humboldt Kumamoto oysters and littleneck clams.  The Kumamotos were super smooth and tasty, but we were a little disappointed with the littlenecks.  However, you could tell that both of those were really fresh.

The Hog Island Manila clam appetizer was a definite winner!  So tasty and fresh, the Sungold tomatoes were to die for and my girl said the crouton was "the best I've ever eaten".

The main dish we ordered was the roasted chicken and bread salad for two.  The chicken was flavorful and tender and the bread salad was so de-lish, soaked in the chicken juice and a vinegarette, baked and served with greens.  Yum!

We also ordered a glass of the riesling which was superb as well.  Fresh seafood, beautiful presentation, attentive service, nice atmosphere...  I couldn't have asked for more.  A little on the pricey side, but every once in awhile you've got to splurge and this is a worthy place to do it.
author: Jeff C.

description: Don't know why it took me so long to visit this legendary cafe, but I hope to make up for that on every succeeding trip to San Francisco. It was so balmy we were able to sit outdoors and enjoy the street scene while lunching on peach crostini, fettuccine unlike any I've tasted before, and a meringue concoction studded with perfectly ripened local strawberries. The owner even stopped by to chat. Our best meal by far this trip.
author: Kay W.

description: Top flight. Experienced foodies will likely not be disappointed.  Local eatery prices too.
author: Rob H.

description:
I came here for a special birthday dinner and was thoroughly impressed.

We started out waiting at the bar because we were too early for our reservation. We ordered some cocktails -- they prepare it right in front of you and the mister almost drank his before they put the garnish in! Haha...they were pretty good, but I've definitely had much better cocktails in the city. (Edit: the mister says he really liked the cocktails. Maybe it's just mine that I didn't like that much ;))

We got a table by the window, which is great because we could adjust the window. The restaurant is separated into many dining rooms and it makes it a bit more homey even though the actual space is huge.

Our server is great. She suggested some creamy oysters for me, and they're one of the best, creamiest oysters I've ever had. Amazing. She's also knowledgeable about the wine on the menu.

Apart from the oysters, we also ordered the persimmon appetizer. It's got some sliced persimmons with onions and what not on top -- fantastic! Great way to have persimmons with your meal!

We did order the roasted chicken, and just munched on the persimmons and the bread/butter while waiting. When it finally came...phew! It looked amazing! It was worth every cent of it, the juicy tender deliciousness. Rrrright, some people think it's not that special, but it is done really well, especially with the kale and the sourdough bread salad absorbing the juice of the chicken...if you just want KFC, go get KFC and don't compare or complain.

We ordered the Zuni wine, because, apparently, they work with a winery to make the best wine to go with the chicken. It's a pinot noir, and it does match very well with the chicken. I suggest you try it.

Dessert was great too. I had the piccolo...whatever. It's a couple layer of meringue wafers with nut cream in between the layers, served with walnuts...not too sweet but great. Definitely would want to try their other desserts in the future.

Overall, this was a fantastic experience...great server, great atmosphere, great food. One little problem I had was with the bathroom -- only 1 stall per gender? The ladies kept going into the men's bathroom because there was always a line. Also, the bathroom interior could use some work for an establishment like this ;)
author: Alice C.

description: Excellent!  Food is absolutely fantastic here.  Be sure to try the polenta as it's delicious!
author: M B.

description:
I'd heard of the chicken and bread salad from here a lot and so maybe just had built up too high of expectations.  I came here with my family for a final dinner before heading back out of town.  For four of us, we shared one order of the chicken (I know they say it feeds two, but there is no way I could eat half of a chicken!) and shoestring potatoes.  We all got a starter - two caesar salads, a spanish pepper with wax beans dish, and a clam dish.  The chicken took the expected hour.  Our starters also took probably about 40 minutes, which felt long for starters, but maybe was intentional to align with the chicken.  

I was impressed with the starters - all were really good.  The croutons on the caesar were the awesome, flavorful, garlicky homemade kind.  The pepper and bean appetizer was different, flavorful, and interesting.  The clams were well cooked with a flavorful sauce.  So, no complaints on the actual starter dishes.  The disappointment was in the chicken.  The chicken is good, but so is Costco chicken.  It's a whole procession with the one hour wait for the chicken and I'm not convinced it's worth it.  The chicken comes on a (pretty small serving of) bread salad and is covered with mustard greens.  There's a ton of mustard greens, which are pretty bitter, so it seems as if they are there for decoration but there is a ton fo them!  The bread salad is good, especially the part that is moist from the chicken (some of the outside pieces were just bread...).  The chicken is good, but I definitely don't need to come back for it.  Maybe I just don't like chicken enough!

Also, as a side note, we accidentally came on the Sunday of gay pride parade.  The bar downstairs, and really the whole street corner, were insane.  We were seated upstairs to the back, which we thought would be pretty quiet, but were next to a super noisy and inappropriate table.  Not exactly what we had in mind for family dinner before heading out of town.  Also, the bathroom wait was insane - like about 20-30 minutes, literally.  I would recommend avoiding gay pride parade day if you're looking for a quieter dinner experience.
author: Rachael M.

description:
I have been coming to Zuni for 12 years straight and have had some very memorable times there.  I have always loved walking into the restaurant and being there for hours.  I think its been the perfect SF restaurant for as long as I can recall.
Sadly, the other night all of us in our party felt that Zuni is no longer Zuni.  We were disappointed with each dish we ordered.  Even the Chicken was dry and felt as though it lacked in any love whatsoever.  The portions have become silly small and it takes away from the meal as its very noticeable. 
Do not get me wrong, our server was excellent and the wine selected was very nice and we all loved being in the now almost iconic space however, the food, is no longer at their once well-known and much praised standard.
author: Kate S.

description:
Food and service was great!

They have a daily menu so you're never sure about what they'll have, but whatever they do have you know it's going to be delicious.

They have a very nice wine list to go with the food.

We say by the kitchen which was really cool because you get to see everything they do and they use a real wood fire oven and grill which adds so much flavor to the food.
author: Jhesse G.

description:
It was good, don't get me wrong. Everything was tasty and arrived hot. The service was good and they had great wine. But, it was not worth the money. The portions were very small and we left hungry. This place is always packed and popular, but  overall, its overpriced. We also have gone a few times thinking that we'd try their world class chicken, but, I'm never up for waiting an hour for my food once i'm in the restaurant. 

We also had an issue with the bill. The manager called me at 11:15 pm (yes, you read that right) to say that they couldn't find the slip with the tip written on it. When I called back to say we'd left it on the table and to complain about the late night call, nobody seemed to know what I was talking about. I'm waiting for my card to register whether this poor waitress got a tip, because she did deserve one. But 11:15??!! I have a small child. Thank goodness my ringer was off.
author: Susie D.

description:
Whatever you do, do not come here without ordering the roast chicken and bread salad. You'd be a fool.  This specialty item is worth the hefty price tag,  with succulent (yes, succulent) pieces of chicken, both crispy and tender at the same time, a layer of fresh greens and tangy vinaigrette, with delicious bread to soak up all the juices.  There were other crunchy elements to the salad (pine nuts perhaps?) but the memory escapes me now.

Honestly,  the atmosphere is a touch fancier than I'd expect from a place whose specialty is a chicken salad, and the crowd a bit older (grandma style).  I would suggest this place for a fancier night out (opera anyone?) or for impressing someone's parents.

The fiance and I shared some oysters, a soup (carrot?), the main entree and a delicious chocolate dessert. We were pleasantly surprised by every single dish!  Our waitress was so kind, and made great suggestions for drinks to pair with our food. All in all, a great meal.
author: Roxane W.

description: For a fairly nice (and fairly pricey) meal, Zuni cafe is hard to beat. The food is delicious and the atmosphere of the restaurant is cozy and warm. Highly recommend it!
author: Daniel W.

description:
I've honestly never thought to dine right on Market Street before (hellooooo homeless!), but I'm so glad I tried Zuni!

I came here with a friend and we sat on the patio with our dogs.  Even when my puppy was psychotically barking, the waiters were totally gracious and accommodating - even brought out a water bowl and issued some tummy scratches. 

We ordered a few adult beverages and some appetizers.  The Quail Egg Crostini is a must try, but the oysters left us swooning.  Literally.  They were absolutely amazing!  So amazing that I've been thinking about them a little more than I should lately.  I wish I could remember the name - I think they were from Oregon.. ridiculously fresh and delicious.  Best I've ever had, actually.
author: Rachelle P.

description:
Delicious! 

A wonderful new friend was gracious enough to take me and a couple friends to Zuni Cafe. I had a great overall experience! The atmosphere is a great, hip, and modern one to be in.

Service - The service was a little spotty here and there, but the waiter got the job done... Definitely room for improvement.

Drinks - I had several of their cocktails and enjoyed them both! If you are a Ramos Gin Fizz fan, then you will be pleased to know that this is one of the rare places that will know what it is and will serve it!

Food - For my appetizer, I had the Fried Broccoli. MAN OH MAN was that tasty. If all vegetables tasted like this, I'd be in good shape. As an entree, I had the duck. It was delicious! A tender, juicy, and flavorful meal.

If you are in the area, be sure to stop by! Thanks Bryan Y. (a crazy adorable man) for the tour of San Francisco.
author: Kevin Charles M.

description: Good food, but I think it's a bit pricey.  The bar is pretty well stocked though if you want to grab a nice drink.  Great place to entertain friends or family.
author: Steven H.

description: Get the roasted chicken and bread salad. It is perfection. This would be my last meal, hands down. The way meats are salted days beforehand makes everything so juicy and tender. I would live here if I could.
author: Elizabeth W.

description: Prepare to wait the 1-hour (they're not exaggerating) for the chicken.  It's good, I have to say.  I'd like to come back and try more of their food and drinks for brunch.
author: Jeff B.

description:
An hour wait for the roast chicken and bread salad, it was worth it.
The chicken was delicious but what got me going mmmm was the bread salad accompanied by the chicken - it's the perfect couple.

Even though the wait for our table, we sat at a bar with our wine and oysters and the time flew by quickly. While we waited for the chicken, we had a persimmon salad - yum. The person who created this menu has an awesome imagination.
author: Yuki A.

description: Well, this used to be the place for oysters and of course, their chicken has been notable forever.  Sadly, the luster is clearly gone.  Service here was spotty at best; completely dysfunctional at its worst.  What could have been a nice meal was flawed by weird "kitchen policies" and a switched up server who could not have cared less about our table. I've been coming here for 15 years.  I'll NEVER go back.
author: Chance R.

description:
So I came here once back in July of 2011 as a going away lunch with my mom and my aunt and uncles. They kept telling me I haaaaddddd to try their pork chop and chocolate cake, and let me tell you that I was not disappointed.

A month later, so happens I'm not leaving yet and this time we wanted to try their chicken. I wasn't so excited for the chicken as I was feigning for their pork chops, I had been ever since I first had it. They are soooo good!

As soon as we got inside we ordered two chicken for 6 people and when we got seated, a pork chop for myself, and a salmon for my cousin. We talk, we laugh, we make time go by. The chicken comes out and it is beautiful and the aroma from the chicken fills up the place around us. You can smell the sweetness with a tinge of the vinegar, it was just amazing! Then my pork chop came out and this was my face.. (o.O) I looked over to my mom and my aunt & we thought the same exact thing. Why is it soooo small this time?? It was the size of the left over I had taken home the first time I had been at the restaurant for lunch. =( 

However, this is the reason I'm giving them an overall 5 star rating:

Tim our server, young handsome and sweet caring waiter, came over to check on our food as soon as we had taken our first couple of bites. (Now I never do this at steak houses or anywhere else but it bothered me enough to say something.) I asked him why my pork chop was so small & he looked at it and said, "I think that's the size that they normally are." But after seeing that I still wasn't satisfied because my mom and aunt said, "No, we had this for lunch last time and it wasn't this small.." Tim immediately offered to take it back and to give me a new one. As reluctant as I was, I said "Okay, please and thank you." No later than a couple of minutes, I believe he was the manager...? He came up to talk to us and explained that I might have gotten a smaller piece. He apologized and it was all good. They didn't make me feel bad at all. Which I was sooo relieved! Thank you so much!! :) 

Pork Chop:
Amazing! Thick juicy piece, the flavor penetrates into the meat itself. The seasonal vegetables are always soo0o delicious!

Chicken: 
Takes an hour to make but so0 worth the wait! My mom thought the meat was a bit too dry, but I thought otherwise. Yes chicken breasts are known to be dryer but it wasn't bad at all. What I noticed was that, as soon as you bit down into it, the chicken was just fall apart easily and it went down great. You can taste the flavor, it's light, but it's there. 

Salmon:
Took a small bit of it from my cousin, good. It's not fishy and has flavor in it as well. Good choice if you're going for a vegetarian dish.

Chocolate cake:
MUST ORDER! It is FLOURLESS!! :) Say what? Yes! It is flourless! But it melts in your mouth! What I got from them.. it's made with espresso, how? No idea, but it gives it is richness, which I  loved. It's not super sweet and sugary, it's chocolatey. 

Final verdict?-- MUST COME BACK WITH MORE OF MY FRIENDS! :)
author: Terinna R.

description:
This is such a beautiful brunch spot! The restaurant is brightly lit w/ natural lighting streaming through their high-ceiling glass windows.  Everything was pretty mediocre from there. 

I was a bit dissapointed that their infamous chicken was an hour wait long, that we had to skip it due to time constraints. We shared the rabbit and kale salad, cranberry-squash soup, prosciutto w/ goat cheese and a dozen Kusshi oysters.

I liked the fact that their menu changes seasonally, and offered fresh local ingredients. However, I think the portions were really meager and it was overpriced for what we had. We had tried some amazing Kusshi oysters at Hog Island earlier and were dying for more but the quality at Zuni Cafe was surely lacking.

Service was attentive but I felt there was a thick air of pretentiousness amongst the wait-staff and from the patrons dining. I might give this spot another try just to try their roasted chicken and grass-fed beef hamburger, but I wasn't completely impressed w/ the food albeit the beautiful surroundings.
author: Marie N.

description:
i've now eaten here twice, once for lunch and once for dinner. got the chicken both times, was blown away both times. when the restaurant, and the chicken specifically, were recommended to me, i have to admit i was a bit skeptical: i never order chicken in restaurants because, well, it's CHICKEN. i make chicken at home. but i went, and i ordered it, and it was so amazing that i immediately made plans to return when i knew i was going to San Francisco again. yes, it is that good -- this is not any chicken i can make at home.

the chicken itself is delicious and the "bread salad" is amazing. i would order this every time. on my first visit there were only two of us so we just had the chicken, with some oysters and salads to start. my second visit we were a group of three, so we shared oysters, one caesar salad, the chicken, and the lamb/merguez entree as well.  everything was delicious, though i'd still say the chicken is the standout.

lastly, the service on our first visit was meh -- our waiter wasn't mean or anything but he didn't seem agreeable (or equipped) to making recommendations.  however, on our second visit our waiter was GREAT -- he was immediately ready with recommendations for which oysters we should get, and he had the perfect level of attentiveness.  he was awesome.

i've been thinking about that bread salad for the 4 months since the first time i ate it, and now i'll definitely be thinking about it for the next 4 months at least.
author: Lily T.

description:
I wanted to love this place. All my friends have been raving about it. I was disppointed...and as much as I tried to find excuses for them, my final decision is a 2 star.

1. Lamb Sweet Breads: Yes! Delicious. Wanted more. (this kept them from getting a 1 star).

2. Chicken for two: Bread salad was yummy...but the chicken was salty and dry. Was it because our chicken was burnt? The skin was slightly charcoaled but crunchy and tasty....so it couldn't have been burnt. My bf and I were downing the water because it was so salty! And the chicken was not as juicy as everyone claims. 

I probably won't be coming back even though I enjoyed the ambiance and sweet breads.
author: Logan N.

description:
I seem to be tiring of San Francisco's visitor-oriented restaurants. (And yes, I am a visitor.) On this visit, I was disappointed first by Boulevard, and then by Zuni café. The food was OK (better at Zuni than Boulevard), but the noise and the somewhat perfunctory service were downers.

For starters, a frisee & grapefruit salad was a bit drab. Entrées were OK, but could have been better. My pork chop was tasty, but a bit skimpy and fattier than I'd like. My companion's roasted rabbit was chewy - a little over done. Dessert, however, was a high point - roasted figs and sugar plums with raspberries in grappa crème - delightful!

All in all, though, there are so many places that offer greater innovation and attention to detail for the money. I think I'm over Zuni...
author: Comensal A.

description:
I really do want to give Zuni a better rating, it's so hyped, but for me it's just meh.  The location is great and the space could be too for the most part, but the place definitely has problems for the prices they charge.

First of all the food: the menu is so, f-ing, boring and hasn't seemed to change for years, though that may be changing now due to changes in management/ownership.  The burger, the chicken and maybe some other dishes thrown in, but really there's not much variety at all and sometimes the execution is very poor, especially for the price point.  I've gotten some of the most terribly mangled oysters here than I have at any other restaurant in SF - at that price point slow down and shuck them correctly.  It's nice that they sometimes have rabbit on the menu, but not when they serve it very dried out (I know rabbit is tricky, but really).  And the roast chicken - for the hour wait it requires (though your waitress will offer you a pack of cards to pass the time) - really should come out as more than just roast chicken.  Also, I've had to send a steak back three times before because somehow to the kitchen medium still meant bloody.

The atmosphere is also troublesome.  It can be very, very loud in there and I really don't go out to restaurants to have shouting matches with me dining comrades.  And god help you if you're seated close to the wood stove - nice aesthetic idea until it's put into practice unless you planned on sweating through your shirt during dinner.  Also, only two restrooms for a place that size becomes rather troublesome/annoying.  SF is a very competitive restaurant town and it's really time this place ups its game to keep in the running.
author: William C.

description:
Finally made my way to Zuni, but found it a bit underwhelming.

The chicken wasn't bad but it also wasn't special.  The hype is baffling.  I liked the slight wasabi-like spiciness of the mustard greens served with the chicken.  I also ordered the Bellwether ricotta gnocchi and loved it.  

Some may consider Zuni overpriced but even at these prices there are still more diners than they can handle.  Service was adequate when we were there.  The hostess and bartender were friendly.   

Anyone can make the chicken dish at home in a regular oven, it'd only be missing the slight smokiness from the restaurant's brick oven.  I followed the recipe widely available online and it came out nearly identical.  I was underwhelmed then and hoped to try the actual thing to see if there was a difference.  Nope!    

I've seen some reviews here complain about the pink color of the meat.  Don't assume the chicken is undercooked.  There are many harmless explanations for this, like grilling can cause this coloration in young chicken.  (http://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/wcm/connect/ad74bb8d-1dab-49c1-b05e-390a74ba7471/Chicken_from_Farm_to_Table.pdf?MOD=AJPERES)

In summary:
Pros: good quality ingredients, cute space, adequate service
Cons: overrated, long wait time, overpriced, noisy
author: Elle S.

description:
They're right about that roast chicken. 

I finally had a chance to dine here last weekend with a few friends. I got reservations for a Saturday night dinner. I made them on Tuesday which is unheard of, but I was lucky since apparently they had a cancellation right before I called. 

We had a very spacious table for 4 right by the kitchen so we could see the chefs preparing the food. We ordered the roast chicken and yes, it really is a one hour wait and yes, it's worth it.  

Our service was good. They do have valet parking available for $10, but again we got lucky and found parking about a block away for free. So if you have extra time to drive around, you can sometimes find some free parking. But it's nice to know you can valet. 

This place is a San Francisco institution and I will definitely be back. I'm even considering buying their cookbook.
author: Andrea T.

description:
I had the burger and shoestring fries.  It was aite.  I can think of a ton of places I'd rather go instead.  Haven't had the chicken but never really order chicken dishes anyway, so I'm not sad about not wanting to come back.

The waiter had a stick up his ass but we still left a good tip.  My friend commented that it was scary how waiters are essentially the face of the restaurant and could easily ruin a business.
author: Erika C.

description: Disappointed. Heard about their caesar salad, burger and great food experience. service was so so. our waiter got our orders wrong (from drinks to food). the salmon was raw inside.  i heard of fancy fish not being well done, but raw.  I can understand grilled ahi, but salmon?  ew.  for the price - the service, quality and taste - the value was poor.  I want my money back.  I will definitely tell family and friends Zuni's is overrated and a poor value.
author: Benny A.

description: Great atmosphere. SF legendary for long time. Oysters are small size but bar is one of my favorite. Get Chicken and shoestrings to start with.
author: Mickey T.

description:
Had a very good meal that was capped off with the famous roast chicken.  The restaurant itself looks like a typical bistro, with multi-level design being a more memorable feature.  It looks just a bit dated, but does possess a nice looking patio.  The area is shady at night however with not much to look at out on the street.  We sat by the window and repeatedly caught hobos staring in as they ambled by--not so pleasant.

Food was generally excellent.  Vibrant vegetables, simple preparations that let the ingredients shine.  Like the general feel of the restaurant though, there's the feeling that Zuni wants to be safe and solid, rather than to wow and excite.  You need to have the right expectations.  The highlight of the meal not surprisingly was the roast chicken, and it was truly marvelous.  Tender, juicy, pack full of that good chicken-y flavor.  One of the best I've had.  And it looks so damn simple.  Some restaurants etch themselves onto your memory with mastery of a single signature dish.  This was one of those instances, one of those dishes.  If you already know you are getting the chicken (why would you not?), be sure to make like a pro and order it as soon as you sit down, as it takes about an hour to make from the time you order it.  This way you avoid an awkward waiting period after first course or whatever stuff you order are finished, and chicken is still like 30 minutes from ready.
author: Kozmo C.

description:
Since I am planning a trip back to SF - I remembered Zuni and the memorable greatest bestest ever chicken dish I ever ate.  It was compliments of my fiance's cousin - she wanted to treat us to a "SF" meal!

All I can remember was the Chicken for two took about 1 hr to prepare, it was $48, and it was worth the wait!!!

The chicken was delicious - it was perfectly cooked, tender, moist - any adjective I can throw in there.  What put it over the top was the bread salad that created the greatest chicken plate I ever tasted.

Anyways, fond memories and if you get to go here only once - be sure to order this plate!
author: Dennis H.

description:
I think this staple is still good, but it's not as vibrant as some of the more recent hits in the Mission. However, if you're looking for a place that's safe to take mom & dad when they come to visit, this is it. I'd give it more of a 3.75 if I had a choice

- The ceasar salad: 3* decent, but not mind blowing. The romaine hearts were a little soggy
- The sweetbreads: 4* It's deep fried and TASTY
- The burrata: 4* but a little small on the portion. Burrata is freagin amazing, so I need more of it.
- The roast chicken over bread: 4* It's really nice, juicy chicken. A giant serving that's more than enough for two, and even worked well as leftovers.

A small note on the service: our waiter was really great. Super fun, sweet. But one of the bussers really didn't fit with the vibe. He was clanking forks and throwing plates down on our table. It was actually so bad it was funny. But really, he just didn't get the white-tablecloth approach. Maybe he was just having a bad day?
author: Shanee B.

description:
I went a while back and ordered the Bellwether Farms ricotta gnocchi with nettles ($15.50). Here's a picture my friend posted: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/zuni-cafe-san-francisco?select=D_m_UBCbvHS0I4o35giNoQ#D_m_UBCbvHS0I4o35giNoQ

So I'll caveat this with a two things--
1. I'm a vegetarian, and thus unable to try a lot of what Zuni Cafe is famous for. because of this i had limited options on the menu. 
2. I ordered the gnocchi expecting something that tasted like gnocchi I had tried in the past, but instead got something very different and hence was disappointed

The gnocchi was rather bland, quite milky-tasting (which is never a hit with me), and had no chewy or crispy texture to it. It also didn't seem like a very good bang for the buck. Very little gnocchi for $16+tip.

If you've tried ricotta gnocchi in the past and have sense of what to expect / know you like it, you may want to try it, but it definitely wasn't my cup of tea.
author: Neeharika B.

description:
I'm not so sure why this place is so popular...

Atmosphere:  on the one hand, this is where the restaurant really shines. The rooms snake around, and have dividers. Yet, there are 'cut out' windows in the walls.  It's a trendy spot and has this private yet everyone can see you thing going on.  Interesting. 

On the other hand, I felt very rushed here.  The salads came out within moments of our order bring placed.  I had barely forked my last piece of lettuce before our plates where whisked away and the entree laid out.  I felt I had to guard my plate from roving busboys to ensure I would be allowed to finish.  Forget about a relaxed date night, I think we were in and out in 45min.  

Food:  caveat here, I'm vegan so they prepared me something off the menu.  It was a very lackluster vegetable plate.  They just roasted some veggies and poured oil all over the top.   Boring.  The salad appetizer was really boring as well

My husband had the steak and he said it was nothing memorable.  

Overall, I would say the quality of the food was like a slightly upscale cafeteria.  Nothing interesting or inventive.  Very rushed and quick to serve, indicative of the complexity and thought that goes into the food. 

Our table was right across from the kitchen and the whole night pretty much the only thing I saw flying out to tables was the roasted chicken. Over and over and over again.  Maybe that dish is really good?  

Overall, I MIGHT come here again if I had friends who really wanted to go.  But there are lots of other trendy places to be seen, that wont necessarily rush you so much, and that probably have better food.   I would not recommend Zuni for a date or a date night. 

Ps. Even if they are fully booked they leave a certain percent of tables for walk ins.
author: Evelyn N.

description:
This is a San Francisco staple.  If you are visiting from out of town or if you want a romantic night on the town but ache to get away from the busy streets of downtown Zuni Cafe is the place to be.  The food here is divine and the wait-staff truly know what they're doing.

I recommend reservations since the restaurant can get booked fairly quick.  the windows are large and always clean so seating inside is probably your best bet, although their few small tables outside are nice for drinks while you're waiting.  The burger is fantastic and the chicken is what they're famous for.  Try it out and you'll be giving it 5 stars too.
author: Kevin J.

description: We wanted a reliable place for a good lunch, and this was a complete fail. We ordered two appetizers and a bottle of water and a sparkling rose. It started out good enough. The appetizers were fine and the wine was very nice. We finished everything and started waiting. The waitress asked if I'd like another glass of wine, and I said sure. I thought I could have it with my entree. The wait continued. . . .  The waitress came by and asked if we were ok with a "leisurely lunch" because the pizzas were a little backed up. We said sure and that we weren't in a hurry. The wait continued . . .  It had been 30 minutes or more.  We finished the second glass of wine and the water. The waitress didn't even ask if we wanted more bread. All that remained on the table were some crumbs.  The wait continued . . .  We flagged the waitress down to ask how much longer it would be. She couldn't say and her only response was "it's unfortunate."  Her only attempt at an accommodation was to ask if she should take the entrees off the bill or see about boxing them up for us. She charged us for everything we had for a total of $67.00. We're out now looking for lunch.
author: Lena S.

description:
SF Staple- and a must try at some point. 

I have been to Zuni Cafe before and remember the food being better. 

My friend and I came here (no reservations) on  Friday night around 6:45PM and got a table by the bar. 

We ordered:

Ceasar Salad- Tasty
King Farm Garden Salad- it was ok
Bowl of polenta- My choice and wish we skipped it, pretty bland
Roasted Chicken- I felt that some of the parts close to the bone should have been cooked more but it was juicy and moist otherwise.. It was ok, nothing to exciting. The bread salad was delicious. 

Drinks- I got extra dirty martini, the first one was great, the second one wasn't as good... consistency is impt. 

Dessert- I can't even remember what we got (is that bad)... oh nevermind, it was the flourless chocolate cake...

Service- Our waiter was great, pretty attentive and helpful. 

Its good, but not as good as I remember it...
author: N N.

description:
Zuni Café in San Francisco is an institution. I have been there several times, but have never had a full dinner; I always went to the bar for the wide range of oysters. 

In the center of the Zuni Café, a large open kitchen opens, built around a wood-burning oven that doubles as a fireplace. Food is served on two floors; the rabbit warren of rooms on the second level includes a balcony overlooking the main dining room.  The crowd is a mix of young families and old-money San Francisco aristocracy.

As noted earlier, I always went there for oysters, often before an Opera performance. There is oysters, or course, but there is also a menu with a Mediterranean touch, including a good selection of main courses made in the wood-fired brick oven or on the grill.

For more, see: 

http://schiller-wine.blogspot.com/2012/10/oysters-and-wine-at-zuni-cafe-in-san.html
author: Christian S.

description:
The first time to Zuni, my mind was blown away by the wine selection, caesar salad, and the PANNA COTTA! Seriously I had my share of panna cottas throughout the year, but Zuni really had the best. I screamed out "Oh my god, this is f*ing good and I will put that in my mouth everyday!" Needless to say, my "When Sally meets Harry" moment totally had the next table patron look and say "I want whatever she's having!"

Come second time in a month back to Zuni, I have to say I was disappointed that Panna Cotta was not on the menu! How can this be?? If you have to make something a stable, this should be it and not the chicken! We had the chicken both times. First time was average, and the second time was a bit undercooked around the bones. Meh! The sea bass was so overcooked and it was dry. (How can you screw up such a fatty, buttery fish to something closer to an overcooked, dry halibut!?)

Recommendation: If you come here, just order a few drinks, get the polenta, caesar salad, and the panna cotta if they have it.
author: Winnie A.

description:
Meh.  Everything was ok.  

ok service
ok hostess
ok food
ok bloody mary
Seating was cramped but still ok.  
Parking took a few minutes to find but wasn't irritating so that was ok too.

I probably would not go back... just meh.
author: Annmarie K.

description:
Zuni has a reputation for good, consistent and rustic food in a beautiful setting on Market street.  I have sampled quite a bit, and there are some good things, some poor choices, and perhaps a few unsupervised cooks.

The oyster selection is wonderful.  The people shucking them however, aren't always.  It's pretty common to get a really sad looking oyster, or one that's even spawning, but after observing the kitchen, the chef de cuisine or sous chef does not appear to be checking them before they go out.  

What's curious to me is why they only offer a basic mignonette.  Black pepper and shallots in vinegar is so boring.  There's no inventiveness there, and even the very popular choice of cocktail sauce is not available, as well as prepared horseradish.  I understand not offering horseradish out of season, but there's not much harm in having prepared or pickled horseradish for your customers.  

Zuni's caesar salad has quite the reputation.  Even though they for some reason decide to use a broken aioli dressing for this salad, it's delicious.  What doesn't stack up are the croutons.  They look like they came from a salad buffet bar, and they don't taste like much.  I would love to see long crostinis with baked parmesan and garlic on top, or even rustically torn and dressed toasted bread served with the chicken.  

The plate of fries are crispy and delicious, but I cannot understand the choice to only offer an unusually large amount of fries for $6.  Even for two people, it can be too many fries.  For 3 or 4, it works out great.  I'd happily pay a couple bucks less for a much smaller plate.  But, if you can eat them all or share them, I recommend getting them!  Just make sure to ask for extra condiments, cause they'll give you a tiny morsel of ketchup (I mean literally an ounce).

The $15 Zuni burger that comes without fries is praised as one of the cities best, but a burger can only be as well as it's cooked.  I can never get a properly cooked burger here.  Even before I eat the burger, I can tell just by touching it what the temp is.  How come no one else is checking this? I've had a burger here a few times within the last year, and every time I ask for medium rare, I get something between medium and mid well, and they are always dry.  If I send them back, I get the exact same thing.

The burger itself is round, but served on square foccacia bread that is lathered in aioli.  Round burger on square bread?  Okay, well as conceptually flawed as that is, the foccacia is very delicious and a great vessel.  Another one of the problems you'll find is the garnishes.  If you get sliced tomato, they're narrow and too thick.  Same issue with the onions.  They also choose a lettuce that wilts far too easily resting underneath the burger.  Because of this, it makes it flat out impossible to eat your burger without deconstructing it.  The burgers most redeeming qualities are the pickles on the side, which are very excellent.

The roasted chicken for two is definitely a wait, but a good thing to wait for if you fancy paying way too much money for chicken.  The skin is crispy, the chicken is moist and well seasoned, and the bread salad with mustard greens is delicious.  I really wish the bread salad was larger, considering it's a $48 plate.  If you're a chicken lover, you will really enjoy this, but your wallet will not, especially when you can recreate this dish at home for less money.  

The cocktails here are just okay, very pricy, and very small.  Take special note if you get a martini, for they serve you unpitted olives on a toothpick that sink into the glass.  Good (over priced) wine selection, and really bad beer selection.  

Overall, I have found the food very inconsistent, and for the very high prices they charge along with really bad service, I'm not terribly eager to return. I want to love this place, but I can't afford to burn $50 on a chicken with bread salad or $16 on an overcooked burger.
author: Nathan B.

description:
My friend later snarled at me for not ordering the roasted chicken, but there were so many other things to try. One thing I liked about their menu is that it was not too long, but it had a variety of prices and choices.

My wife had their margarita, which was a little tart. And small for $10. But good anyway. I had an Aperol, which sounded bitter but in fact was a gloriously balanced citrus drink. I could've finished a pitcher of them.

We ordered a number of the starters, which had a lot of vegetarian choices:

Ceasar salad
Wild arugula salad with tangerines and shaved purple asparagus
Potato and green garlic soup
Roasted chicken frisee salad
Ricotta salata pizza
Clams with broccoli di ciccio and white beans

The Caesar salad was indeed the best I have ever tasted. It had the perfect balance of lemon, anchovy, garlic, and cheese. The croutons were crusty, but saturated with dressing flavor. We probably should have split it, since it's enormous. At $10, this was probably the best value for salad I have had in the city.

The wild arugula salad was also delicious, a perfect balance of sweet dressing and spicy arugula. It created the perfect bite, with the combination of all the ingredients. It was just the right size, too. Nothing ruins arugula like too much of it.

Then we tried the soup and the clams. The soup was unusually light for potato and the green garlic added a delicious, balanced flavor. Surprisingly good, considering how humble the ingredients are. But if that's not the sign of a great kitchen, I don't know what is.

The only thing that was not rub your cheek like Rick Moranis in Ghostbusters good was the frisee with roasted chicken. Too much frisee, not enough dressing.

My wife and I had great service and sat by a window. It was a fantastic meal, although the walk afterward was very slow for a while. To get your exercise, hike to Alamo Square. To take it easy, go down Valencia into the Mission.
author: Henry M.

description: Food excellent. Dessert not to be missed. Waiting staff awesome. Bus boys too loud bang plates. Train them to be more quiet.
author: Michael L.

description:
