This was my first time to Zuni.  My wife and I got there about 30 minutes before the official seating (6:00pm) on a Friday night.  Their menu was prepared that night.  We had the shoestring potatoes and olives in the bar area.  The olives were excellent.  They were soaked in fine olive oil and had small pieces of licorice root.  Our waiters in the bar area and in our seated area on the second floor overlooking the restaurant were not inhibiting, but prompt and very knowledgeable about the menu.  

For the meal courses, we had  two oysters, the cesar salad, figs, gnocchi, and the chicken for two.  They are supposedly known for their gnocchi and cesar salad and they did not disappoint.  The oysters were fresh and delicious.  The fig dish was slices of fig, onions and thin slices of lemon that were lightly breaded, lightly fried and then seasoned.  The dish was an amazing sensory experience.  My wife and I are not normally big chicken eaters.  However, this was a recommended "can't miss" item.  You need about a one hour prep time for the chicken.  It is a fire cooked dish.  The skin was a perfect crispy seasoned good.  The meat was tender, and the complimenting bread squares, greens, and balsamic tasting sauce were the perfect compliment.  Wow!  Amazing!  I can't wait to go back.
author: Darren S.

description:
As you trudge down the mean streets of Market, Zuni Cafe beckons like a jewel. Lining the front are bottles of every kind. You enter in the back into the bar, which is a shining bronze. A pianist plays away. If you have made a reservation, which is a good idea, you will be whisked through the maze-like alcoves into one of the many dining rooms. The space is warm and cozy, and you see why San Franciscans have loved this place forever.

To start, we got the caesar salad and the squid crostini. The salad is almost obligatory if you haven't tried it, since they've made thousands of them over the years. The squid crostini was very delicious and came with some pickled onions. 

As mains, we got the rabbit and the duck. Both of them were delicious, the rabbit with a great sauce including morels and radicchio and the duck coming with beans. The duck was a little skimpy and could have been warmer (it seemed to have cooled down too long). For dessert, we had the grapefruit granita and the nectarine tart, both excellent.

Since the menu is always changing here, you can come all the time and try various things (though they always have the standbys like the salad and the chicken).

I wouldn't say this is fine dining--after all, it is a cafe. It's more like comfort food done with an expert touch, in a lovely and cozy setting.
author: Ryan C.

description:
Finally got to try this place... and I have to say, I loved the restaurant's ambiance, but the food was just all right. It's tasty... but for the price, I've had much better in the rest of SF. And if you want to try the chicken, remember that it takes over an hour for them to prepare! And you can't call ahead to order!

I made reservations a few days in advance for a double-date night at 8:15pm on a Tuesday. We arrived a bit early, and I told the restaurant to get started on the chicken since I knew it'd take a ridiculously long time to prepare. Here's a rundown of everything we had:

*Caesar Salad (2.5 stars - $10): There was a TON of dressing on the salad. The salad was presented with whole romaine lettuce leaves, which I like, but it would've benefited from a lot less dressing.

*Fettucine with corn/pancetta/squash (3 stars - $16.50): Texture of the noodles was not bad, but the dish overall was a little bland. There wasn't really a sauce on the noodles, just a light butter coating.

*Chicken for two (3.5 stars - $48): The chicken was tender and moist... But it wasn't worth waiting 1.5 hours for it along with $48. I thought it'd be more flavorful, but the chicken just had a very light herb seasoning. And I thought the bread salad was WAY overrated... It was just bread with balsamic vinegar soaked in it. A bit salty for my taste. Overall, I liked the chicken here but I can find cheaper, better alternatives like Limon Rotisserie's chicken. Or Costco $5 rotisserie chicken yum! 

*Pork Chop with green beans and fingerling potatoes (4 stars - $28): This was the star of the show! Very tender pork with good flavor. A little bit salty but the dish overall was prepared very well.

Although the food did not blow me away, I'm still glad I tried this place, even though I most likely will not be coming back soon. BUT... it is a very cute place for dinner with friends or a date! Not too much noise and very spacious.
author: Jennifer L.

description: The food is good but it is incredibly overpriced.  2 salads, 2 entrees, 3 coffees, 1 pizza, 1 dessert.....$150 for lunch including tax and tip.  The service was friendly but not particularly attentive.
author: Keith L.

description:
2 words... Roasted Chicken.

It is worth the wait...amazing food, great atmosphere.
author: Chris S.

description:
Ah, Zuni. Hundreds of reviews and such a high rating so I knew it wasn't going to be bad. I love the bustling atmosphere here, the cozy brick walls, the tables in close proximity to one another, the very professional service, all of it combines for a delightful dinner.

While I must admit I was intrigued by the half of a chicken option I wasn't quite ready to commit to that much meat and so I followed my normal pattern and ordered a bunch of stuff with no rhyme or reason just so I could taste a lot of things. I started with a selection of cheeses that I kindly shared with Sir Nicholas. They offer 5 daily for $5.25 a piece. I choose two - a goat cheese and Parmesan. Nick thought ordering the Parmesan was one of the odder things I picked, but I have to say I was interested in the accompanying side item. I'm still not sure what it was, but it was like a mash up of fruit and mustard maybe? Either way, it was a perfect accompaniment and I'm a fan of Parmesan anyway so I enjoyed it.

I also ordered a Caesar salad that I loved, but Nick did not due to it being topped with real Caesar dressing. (It was too fishy for Nick, but that's the way I prefer it actually.) For my "main" course I chose to try the side of polenta and a Serrano ham appetizer. The appetizer came with little slices of bread topped with mashed chickpeas covered in a sauce and I thought it all came together really nicely for that dish. Nick ordered a traditional dinner as he usually does in the form of a pork chop entrée. This was a pretty big serving and heavy on the garlic. While I think the flavor was good, it was also quite strong.

Cocktails were had, too and mine was a glass of bubbly infused with St. Germain. Nick simply enjoyed a bottle of beer. It was on the expensive side for a dinner for two, but that could just be because I actually ordered 4 dishes total in my never-ending sampling quest. However, I'd say the quality is worth the dinero so I definitely recommend giving it a try.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
PROS
+ 2nd floor seats by the window - try to snag one of these!
+ Hostess(es) were very accommodating even though we were late for our reservation

CONS
- Only one bathroom each for M/F - long bathroom waiting lines
- Chicken breast was dry :(

TIPS
* Call in during the days leading up to your intended dining date to see if anything opens up that doesn't appear to be available online via OpenTable.
* Appetizers are really only enough to share between 2 people (would be skimpy with 3+)
* Roast chicken can easily feed 3-4 


Zuni is another one of those placed-on-a-pedestal restaurants that you can't have NOT tried if you've lived in SF/the bay area for any significant amount of time.

I like chicken. I like rotisserie chicken. Okay, why not?

So I finally snagged some last-minute reservations for 2 for a Saturday evening.  Turns out we got amazing seats for such a last-minute booking - they sat us at a table on the 2nd floor right next to the window, so we had the street view and could people watch during our meal. 

To squander some time/zap hunger pangs during the 1 hour chicken wait, we had:

--DRINKS--
1. The MOJITO was good. Solid, nothing special.

2. The ELDERFLOWER COCKTAIL was delicious. Slightly bubbly. Comes in a champagne glass. Not too sweet, just right. 

--APPETIZERS--
1. HOUSE CURED ANCHOVIES - comes w/ crescents (stalk cut the short way) of celery, squares of parmigiano-reggiano slices, & coquillo olives. I didn't find this dish to be a particularly glamorous or fancy dish. The anchovies were briny and tasty but I didn't care much for the celery. The cheese and olives were just okay. 

2. DEVIL'S GULCH RANCH RABBIT SALAD - comes with a few big leaves of red leaf lettuce, Pixie tangerines, and creme fraiche. The rabbit was mighty tasty and not gamey at all. I especially liked the bacon-textured pieces - chewy and flavorful. 

--MAIN--
Of course we got the ROAST CHICKEN FOR 2. I'm not easily impressed by roast/rotisserie chickens as many places in the city serve them (e.g. Morning Due Cafe, La Fusion, etc). Unfortunately I was not wowed by the chicken here. It is definitely not $48-worthy chicken. Yes, it was tasty and the bread salad was decadent with all the roasting juices. For $48 I expect even the chicken breasts to be tender and juicy. The chicken breasts here are not - I found them quite dry. The thighs were good as were the drumsticks, but for $48...... I would probably not get this again. The red mustard greens are similar to arugula in taste, but with the heat and fats from the chicken, they quickly wilted. 

We also had the SHOESTRING POTATOES alongside the chicken. It comes as a huge mound of shoestring fries on a dinner-size plate. Huuuuge portion! We could barely make a dent in it. They're really too stringy and crispy to qualify as fries - they're more like crunchy strands meant more for texture than for substance. 


Verdict?
I'd be willing to come back to try their brunch menu and some of the other highly-reviewed dinner items, e.g. the pork chop.
author: Megan L.

description:
You ever run into a good friend you haven't seen in years and wonder why you stopped hanging out?  That's what my meal at Zuni was like tonight.  The last time I ate here was at least 15 years ago--I remember the meal being great and thinking that I would try to make it a somewhat regular event... and then life intervened.

When I realized I'd be going to a play right down the street, I decided to revisit my old friend, and I have to say we picked right up where we left off.

I started with some Tomales Bay Pacific Hog Island Oysters.  They were perfectly fresh and the sauce was tasty but not overpowering--still, I'm kind of a purist and mainly ate them au natural.  They paired nicely with the Sauvignon Blanc recommended by my waiter.  While I'm on the subject, I have to say that, though the place was packed, the service was excellent.  I was seated nearly right away by a host who actually took the trouble to learn my name and use it.  He seated me at a table for one (no tacky extra chair to spoil my people watching), and told me that he typically seats 20-30 solo diners like myself, and that I would likely enjoy the view--which I did.

Next up was a delicious mixed green salad with some garlic croutons that were clearly house-made and delivered a huge garlic punch to go with the vinaigrette and bitter greens--perfection.  My main course was Monterey Bay King Salmon served with Basil, mushrooms, and green beans.  The salmon was perfectly cooked, and the basil, mushrooms and green beans couldn't have been better.  Let me also say that the portion was exactly what I wanted--not huge, but not so small I'm wondering what I'll be ordering later when I'm hungry again.  I paired it with a Mt. Eden Pinot Noir, which, as with the Sauv Blanc, was recommended by my waiter and did not disappoint.

The wine list was not huge, but if what they serve by the glass is any indication, I suspect you will find ample selections to match your meal.

Overall, I'd have to say that the evening was a success and that I am looking forward to future visits with my old friend--who knows--next time, we might even get to desert!
author: Sean F.

description: I had high hopes for this restaurant. My friends have been telling me to come here for the longest time, so last night I invited one of my friends to join me. It took a while for someone to come by and take our order. I ordered a Moscow mule and it was sour my friend ordered a daiquiri she said was just ok. We ordered the frutto appetizer to start and it was salty and weird, mostly fried endive and onion rings, should have passed. My friend wanted to order extra balsamic aioli from our waitress but we hadn't seen her for a while so we ordered from a server who passed by us, 5 minutes goes by and we see the same server pass by our table, just kind of walking around...not bringing what we asked for. Finally our server comes back and we eventually get the damn sauce. We ordered the pork shoulder as mains and it's totally delicious but that really wasn't enough to salvage the experience. We didn't arrive early enough to order the famous chicken and to be honest I probably won't be back to ever try it. Bummer.
author: PJ L.

description:
I think I hyped myself up with this one.

Had some friends visiting from Seattle so I thought I'd look up a new place to take them. And what's more SF than being on the 7x7 list and having 4 solid stars from 1500+ reviews on yelp? 

All in all, we weren't that impressed. We ordered the spinach soup, the shoestring fries, the lamb and the pork chop. Don't get me wrong, nothing was disappointing by any means, but it just didn't really give us the WOW factor. Nothing was out of the ordinary or original. I guess we should've gotten the chicken. Our guest put it the best when we asked what the highlight of the dinner was. He said, "the fries." 

Sigh, fail on my part I guess. I'm going to try really hard not to hype myself up and actually try the chicken next time. (If there is a next time...)
author: Lynn C.

description:
In my opinion a total rip off.  I ordered the gnocchi....10 little dumplings in a boringly bland sauce...$15.50. Give me a break!  Not tasty or plentiful....
There are too many great restaurants in the City....don't waste your money here.
author: Steve G.

description: Oh the chicken!! I was excited for my date night at Zuni Cafe because I had heard such great things about the chicken, and the entire evening did not disappoint. Everything was great from start to finish. Our server was very knowledgeable and attentive, and we got our food at the perfect rate (except for the chicken, but they tell you upfront that it's going to take an hour). We started with a dozen oysters and our server picked out a variety. Can't get enough of 'em. Then we had the duck sausage (SO good), the anchovies (not too fishy, great olive oil), and the tuna confit. The only thing I didn't like was the tuna confit because there was WAY too much ginger in it. Then the glorious chicken arrived and even though I was pretty full by then, we almost ate the entire plate. I don't ever think I've had juicer chicken in my life.
author: Regina L.

description:
Probably the best meal I have had in my life.  Not kidding.  Yes it is difficult to get in but dont give up!!  The menu changes constantly so just get ready for anything.

We had the sardines, dont stop reading here please, they were fantastic.  Everyone at the table tried them and adored them.  I had the flank steak with potatoes and veggies.  Steak cooked rare, perfectly executed.

Service was fantastic, get the window table in the front corner if possible!  Awesome people watching!!!
author: Melissa B.

description:
I came here for a small snack and everything was delicious. We started with the Caesar salad, which was probably one of the best I've ever had. The dressing was amazingly delicious and the lettuce was fresh and crisp. Next, we had the quail served with an abundance of garlic. Although it was tiny, it was tender and served with a flavorful sauce.  Last, we had the fresh raw oysters. All were tasty, fresh, and quality was up to par. 

The ambiance was quiet and dim with a touch of class. Our server was very attentive, respectful, and professional. Although we couldn't stuff ourselves anymore and it was near closing, I could not wait to go back for their one-hour-brick-oven-roasted chicken breast.
author: Denise W.

description: This has been on my list of restaurants to try since forever and we finally got around to trying it for lunch. I had very high expectations since I heard nothing but great things about their famous roasted chicken. Keep in mind, there's a 60 min wait from the time you order (it also says it very clearly on the menu too). Honestly, the chicken was good but it wasn't so oh-so-damn fabulous. It's worth trying but honestly, I probably wouldn't come back again just to order that. Maybe my expectations were way too high but I definitely didn't leave thinking "oh that lived up to the hype". Still, it was good, just not amazing.
author: Diana Y.

description: Currently my favorite restaurant. I get to Zuni at least once a week, often for brunch, something for dinner. I love sitting in the open bar seating in the big windows. They do a fantastic job with oysters. They are not cheap but always top quality. Also well loved there are the basaltic bloodies and Caesar salad w anchovies blended into the dressing.
author: Lark M.

description:
epicurious rated the zuni burger as one of the top burgers in america. sf chronicle listed it as one of the top 10 in sf. my friend matt said it was "the best burger in sf". 

...verdict is...

pretty freakin' good but not quite worth all the hype. the burger fell short in some of the core elements. below are my plus/deltas.

plus:
* meat: really good quality grass fed beef 
* garnish: zuni pickles and the blue cheese gave the burger some great flavor

deltas: 
* bread: surprisingly i was not a fan of the 4" squares of focaccia. i usually love focaccia but in this case the bread got soggy after you took your first bite and the juiciness of the beef spilled over 
* fries: thin shoestring fries that lacked the hearty goodness that i prefer when i eat burgers

zuni burger with cheese, fries and a iced tea was $30.
author: Debbie C.

description: Drinks are really good but food is wayyy overpriced. Ordered the anchovies as a starter ($9.50) and got a plate with 6 mini anchovies and 5 pieces of hair thin Parmesan. After that got annoyed and didn't order no more...
author: Leon V.

description:
I had higher expectations for this average restaurant. Below is a breakdown of my night:

Atmosphere
Sat on the second floor near the railing, and it offered a great view of the bar and busy street. +1

Food
Appetizers
- House-cured anchovies: Literally an inch or smaller, and I can't even remember what they tasted like

- Caesar Salad: Excellent

Entrees
- Chicken for Two: After waiting for a hour, I was expecting something phenomenal. Nope, just tasted like regular chicken to me. It wasn't as juicy as I was hoping and the flavor was pretty bland. The only good part of this dish was the bread and dried currants on the bottom of the plate.

- Pork Chop: I ordered a medium-rare pork chop and the only part that was pink was a quarter sized spot right in the middle. The rest of the meat was on the dry side. Flavor was OK, but try Park Tavern for an amazing pork chop.

- Grilled Mahi Mahi: Ordered it rare and it came out rare, but again, nothing special about the taste.
author: Alfonzo J.

description:
Went super late. Hostess was really nice, we were still able to order the chicken (it says 1 hr wait on the menu). Interior was pretty nice, they have a pretty open kitchen and we were seated close to it.

We got:
jade oolong tea - be sure to request that it be shared, or else they will bring 2 orders of it (this keeps happening to me...).  Tasty, fresh and grassy.

oysters - really fresh, sauce seemed like a light vinegar/garlic. The kumamoto they had was really small...I guess that's normal.  $_$;

chicken - they were accommodating to my allergies and did the bread salad on the side. Be sure to say you still want the 'salad' part or else they will just serve chicken.  Friend didn't like the bread salad but he's not into oil on bread.  I was sad that most of the oil went onto the bread instead of stay on the chicken (I wanted some of that golden sauce too).  The chicken was way overhyped unfortunately.  It was pretty dry and I couldn't finish the breast pieces--the rest were ok.  Maybe it would be a different story not overcooked, but truthfully I would've preferred my own roast chicken.   They don't seem to truss the chicken (or seem to stuff it with anything), so I was afraid it would be a bit dry.  Don't know if that actually contributed.  The mustard greens were nice.

Overall it was okay but not really worth the price.  Also unfortunately sat next to an old guy that was incredibly rude which ruined the experience.
author: Xue H.

description: Loved everything about this place. We had a wonderful seat in the corner on the second floor, perfect for a romantic date with the hubs. The steak frites for expensive but worth it...and the trout was possibly the best tasting fish I've ever had.
author: Sara H.

description:
7x7 list: ZHEE chicken.

As soon as we sat down, we ordered the chicken (i.e. chicken bread salad for two - $48), knowing itll take an hour.

The chicken really did come in an hour, it was delicious. Really juicy, not salty, and cooked so well, the bread that the chicken was sitting on was the perfectly soft and chicken-juiced. I'd say it's worth the wait! :)

Went for Saturday lunch at noon, but was surprised to see so many empty tables, although by 1 it was packed. interesante.

While waiting, got their caesar salad that they're famous for, which was.. okay, really. Nothing really special about it.

If you really want to hold yourself over while waiting, order the shoestring fries. If not, the real smart thing is to eat a banana before you get there, so you can order a glass of wine while you wait an hour for the chicken.
author: Ami Y.

description:
Zuni is just a spectacular dinner option. The cheese gnocchi is amazing. The roast chicken is out of this world. The wine selection is not enormous, but what they have is quite good and reasonably priced. Always great service. Pricey, yes, but absolutely worth it. If only I could afford to go more often! The only reason I don't give it five stars is because I've sometimes been underwhelmed by dessert. The sorbet, however, is always an excellent bet.

Be sure to get a reservation for dinner -- otherwise you may be sad. Oh, and as a tip, tell them as soon as possible if you know you'll be ordering the chicken. It takes an hour to cook, but if you tell them while you're waiting to sit down or right as you're seated, they'll throw one in for you so that it's ready with the rest of your food.
author: Angela B.

description: Chicken was killer. Very cool wine list as well. As others have noted, the space itself is distinctive and adds to the experience.
author: Kent C.

description:
When I heard about this place I thought that it was called "Zuni Chicken" because that is what everyone raves about!

Luckily I was prepared and we were ready to wait for it. You can call ahead too if you're going to order the chicken. (Although I see that some reviews say no, but I've been told differently).  We had a wonderful jewel lettuce appetizer (sadly no longer on the menu) and a few others that were wonderful, although I don't remember the details.

The service was attentive but unobtrusive. It was lovely sitting right in view of the clay oven.  The evening was on the pricey side - but well, well worth it.  Can't wait to go again!
author: Rosie S.

description: Creative dishes. Pleasant service. Cozy interior.
author: Tomoki H.

description:
Since I'm nearing LEGAL DRINKING AGE, I thought I would start Yelping again in order to make myself a better Elite candidate! I really can't wait until I can start whoring myself out to every restaurant in town, so that I can become an Elite Yelper and whore myself out EVEN MORE!

My visit to Zuni Cafe was very relaxed and enjoyable, although it was a little more than a year ago. My bf and I caught the last reservation slot, so the restaurant was not as crowded as expected. If you are taking public transportation, I suggest that you walk down Market from Civic Center BART! Just dress warmly and be prepared to ward off those who have strayed too far from their post at the Tenderloin.

Rabbit salad: The salad was pretty ordinary, but the rabbit was very tender and cooked to perfection. If you're having dinner with a male who is not in the culinary industry, don't order this. There is a 99.99% chance that they will complain of small portions.

Risotto: Delicious! Creamy, with just the right amount of texture from the rice. Death to those below me who didn't enjoy it!

Chicken for Two w/ Bread Salad: When they say it's for two, they really mean it! We barely finished this masterpiece because the portions were very generous. It does take a while to prepare (~30-45 minutes depending on crowdedness), but it is worth the wait. The chicken was moist and soft, with the bread salad providing a welcome contrast in texture and taste. Wait until the bread mops up all the chicken juice.

Our underage asses couldn't pair the dinner with any libations, but they did have my favorite yuppie juice on the menu! $$$ Navarro grape drank FOR THE WIN! (For the interested parties: http://www.navarrowine.com/shop/productdetail.php?prodid=1001 )

For the family of 4 sitting next to us who ordered one chicken for two and limitless amounts of French fries: If you wanted chicken and French fries you could have gone to KFC :\
author: Hanui C.

description:
What a totally perfect dinner. Zuni's got it all... A reputation as an SF classic. Ambiance that's intimate but not stuffy, both rustic and clean. Absolutely top-notch service (from the hosts who promptly honored our reservation to the busser who politely cleared crumbs off our table). Most importantly, Zuni's got the food.

We came to dinner famished, and put in our order for the roasted chicken immediately (highly recommended, as it indeed took the full hour to come out). For apps, we all ordered the yellowtail tuna confit salad with quinoa and almonds -- an excellent choice. Our friend ordered the Moroccan lamb over sausage, which, judging by his plate licked clean by the end of dinner, was delicious. The roast chicken, which I shared with my boyfriend, was just TO.DIE.FOR. I'm already a huge fan of chicken (I even prefer it over steak), but Zuni's will sway even the non-poultry-believers. So incredibly moist and flavorful -- and that bread salad. Ugh. I thought I'd miss potatoes with my chicken, but the bread's even better; it provides crisp and soaks up all the herby chicken drippings perfectly. Like others have said... definitely worth the wait.

I'll admit, I didn't think Zuni's could live up to the hype. Glad to be proven wrong!
author: Julie D.

description:
Friday, 10:00PM.
Reservations.

Quickie:
+ Food quality
+ Hygiene
* Service
* Turnaround
+ Layout

And then...?
Food was yummy. Waitress saved the hostess' bad attitude. Round 2!

**********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Gnocchi
     + Firm skin
2. Polenta with Parmesan 
     + Fresh cheese mixed with smooth polenta
3. Steak
     + Tender
4. Pot de Creme
     + Lite taste
5. Meringata (chocolate pudding)
     ++ Sweet n' dark
author: Chuck N.

description:
I've been wanting to eat at Zuni Cafe since it opened in 1979.  Somehow, it just never happened until my farewell lunch with two of my sons before I returned to India for a five month visit.  It was worth the wait - though I really wanted to try that roasted chicken!  We were in too big a hurry to eat so I will be returning to Zuni, beyond a doubt.  

Zuni is a light and airy place, with an open kitchen so you can watch the hard
working chefs as they prepare their dishes.  While the menu choices are not extensive, in some ways, that is good.  You don't linger too long making a decision.  
I had a wonderful dish -  Hog Island Manila clams with Sungold tomatoes, garlic, rosemary breadcrumbs, and piment d'Espelett and a delicious arugula salad.

There is an extensive international wine list with many bottles under $40.

I will definitely return, this time for the roasted chicken.  I'll settle in with a bottle of wine and a nice appetizer, the company of friends, and wait the necessary hour.
author: Carmen H.

description: Extremely overpriced and mediocre cocktails. Went on a Sunday, experienced slow service, a $3.50 mark-up for a mezcal margarita (clocked in at $17.50) and found the drink to be very blah. When asked why a mezcal margarita was more expensive than a tequila marg, the answer I was told was that when you change any drink, you incur a charge. For such a cool location and decent ambiance, I expected better.
author: Gates S.

description:
I got to study with Judy Rogers in 1997 at Greystone. ( seasonal market basket)  so it's like MECCA for me in the bay area.  My seating was prompt and service exceptional.  The kitchen was efficient and  fun to watch!  Rustic and efficient it's always nice to enjoy the daily creations of the Zuni team. 

Drake's Bay Oyster Point Reyes @Kummato Tomalas Bay

Formage de Tete and duck tongues with pickled agretti, grain mustard, and frisse

Lanana Seco Ranch Pork Confit Boudin Noir with dandelion greens quince beets and roasted polena

Pot de Cream with Francelico and candied Hazelnuts.
author: Alex F.

description:
We were just here for a couple drinks - what a beautiful architecture and what a great place to unwind and have a couple cocktails.  I was sorry that I had dinner reservations elsewhere - but will definitely be back for more.

Highly recommend sazerac - they do it right.
author: Mike P.

description:
Chicken - its good but not worth $50. Safeway chickens are just as good! Their margin must be like 600% lol
Caesar salad - awesome! Get it!
Oysters - my fav part of the meal!!!!
Classic Bloody mary - SUPER GOOD! One of the best bloody Mary's!
$150 / two people
author: Cindy L.

description:
Two stars minus for
1) very limited menu, esp if you are a vegetarian.
2)Overpriced.
The service was good. The hostess told us that the menu is very limited for a late lunch, the time when we arrived. The server was very good. She even mentioned pizzas which weren't even on the menu. We tried their arugula salad and it was very ordinary, nothing special and very small. The goat cheese and asparagus pizza was very good. Too bad we couldn't try their famous chicken salad. I wish it was kosher. 
Our waitress told us that the brunch is always very good but we couldn't return. 
Might go back to try their brunch someday.
author: S B.

description:
This is a classic restaurant - it seems like its been around forever, and you wonder if its still going to hold up?  I had not been here in 15 years so that question crossed my mind a few weeks ago when the wife and I stopped in for a drink. . .and. .well oh yeah, lets try some food.  We split some delicious soup and a salad and had a glass of wine and it was excellent. Everything about the soup was perfect - it was a bean soup with some truffle oil and it was outstanding - there were three different flavors all competing for my attention as I took each spoonful.  The salad was also perfectly balanced.  It had the right mix of greens and interesting things and it tasted fantastic. Big plus for the delicious wine list too.  We liked our dishes so much we had to try dessert. The chocolate flourless cake was really beyond description -just unbelievably light and fluffy and not cakey at all. (normally I hate cake, but this was REALLY good!)  And the topper was the service - the waiter was super friendly and helpful.

So at the end for the night I have to ask; is it worth it?  sure it was  expensive but yes it was worth it. Everything exceeded my expectations.   Now I know why this restaurant stays in business.  And yes, I will be back.
author: David Z.

description:
Disappointed.

I REALLY, really wanted to like ZUNI-- but it just didn't work out.

First and foremost they didn't have black napkins- which is minor, but irritating given that their white linen napkins shed all over my black pants.

Second, their midday menu between lunch and dinner consisted of overpriced average dishes.

The food was.. average. My salad and soup were good.. but not worth 35 bucks.
I had high expectations for ZUNI from all of the good things I had heard and they sadly were not met.

Furthermore, I had to ask for bread twice and for glasses of water to be brought to our table.

On the plus side the ambiance is pleasant and the paintings on the wall are modern and wonderful.
author: Taylor O.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this restaurant. I liked it on my first visit but I was a little let down on my last brunch. I just wasn't as wowed as I am by some of the other places and my rating is price sensitive. The more expensive a restaurant the higher my expectations. The food was so lacking that i didn't even want to finish my plate.

The oysters are fantastic, but fantastic oysters in the bay aren't hard to come by. 

I am not one who likes to wait one hour for a chicken. I don't really understand why it should take an hour to serve an extremely popular dish but i didn't count any stars off for this.

Service is TERRIBLE. Possibly the most pretentious restaurant I've been to in the city. 

There are some things on the menu that are great, but it doesn't live up to the hype and there are many other places that are better.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Always impeccable. The dinner was a nice finish to an already great night. We were seated perfectly on time even though the restaurant was busy. Food arrived promptly, it was delicious as always. I do  not remember one time when I had a bad meal here.  
I don't know how the untimely death of Judy Rodgers will effect the restaurant but I  hope it will remain on the top of the local list.
author: K Z.

description: We stopped in for a quick drink and a snack.  So good!  My bloody mary was extra zippy.  Nice to see proper care taken to pour a fine version of this classic cocktail.  The true revelation were the oysters, a perfect dozen.  Hats off to Zuni for schucking these bad boys properly--not a speck of shell, and none of the critical oyster liquor spilled.  I could have eaten many more dozens had time allowed.  Staff are professional, and it shows.  Next time I'm in town I want to eat a full meal here.
author: Adam W.

description:
Get. The. Chicken.

We came here for a belated Valentine's Day. Got a Caesar salad some fried Brussels and a few old fashioneds. It was a perfect perfect meal!

There is chicken left offer also for lunch the next day.
author: Adam H.

description: If you love roasted chicken, you have to try this place but make sure you are willing to wait for an hour from ordering, as this is the standard "roasting" waiting time...not sure why they cant start roasting their scrumptious birds way in advance as most people go to Zuni for that.  If you love food other than chicken, you are out of luck as most of their "other" dishes are sub-par and not worth the $$$.
author: Adriana P.

description:
Manfriend and I were here for an early lunch before catching a 2pm show at the Orpheum.

I enjoyed the sunny, airy-feel to the restaurant. Our table for two was located at the top-of-the-stairs, next to the window, I loved it! Romantic!

Order:
Burger w/ white cheddar & Shoestring potatoes: Manfriend enjoyed his burger but felt it was over-priced. I wish I would've had a taste!
Mahi Mahi served with baby carrots and artichokes: The fish was tasty, however, I was still hungry after my meal. Maybe the fish portion should be slightly larger...?? 

The service was a bit slow and unattentive, our waiter was quiet and didn't seem confident. Maybe my expectations for this restaurant were set too high or maybe because "motorcycle type" don't fit in with the whole lunch scene....???

Ladies Room was clean AND the door has a hook for jackets, purses, etc. PLUS PLUS

Our consensus: Meals were good but TOO pricey.
author: Marisol P.

description: I had no idea where my boyfriend was taking me for our one year dinner, but I was hoping for something memorable. Zuni did not disappoint!  The Ricotta Gnocchi was pleasantly light and refreshing, melt-in-your-mouth perfection in every indulgent bite.  The roasted chicken was worth the wait, and I now understand why people highly recommend it.  The flour-less chocolate cake was mouthwateringly rich and perfectly balanced served with whipped cream.  The cocktails were smooth and strong (just the way I like em!) The atmosphere is lovely and romantic, and the servers are professional, fast, and knowledgeable!  Definitely an incredibly memorable meal.  Thanks Zuni!
author: Haley G.

description: 'never been here tho lives here all my life! Wow. Had the gnocchi and spaghetti and a delicious rosé !!! Perfect for after the Symphony! Forget waiting for the table. Go for the "copper counter"!! You'll thank me!
author: Kevin F.

description:
Went here last Friday for dinner with a girlfriend to catch up. We got reservations for 7:45, and I was looking forward to it since we picked the place because it was on the 7x7 list. 

Our server, John, started off the night on the wrong foot. I'll refrain from name-calling; I'll try to give him benefit of doubt, but hey, John, you basically screwed up your own tip from the get-go. His greeting to us was, "You were the girls that nearly ran me over earlier." 

Um, what? I was right behind my friend, and you had stepped aside, carrying a tray full of maybe 5 empty glasses. I didn't think anything of it; maybe I'm spoiled or whatever, but I guess I'm kind of used to servers at most places (yes, even Chinese restaurants, for example) allowing diners to proceed before them. Always. 

Anyway, we ordered a caesar salad and the rabbit appetizer. The rabbit was underwhelming, there was barely any rabbit in there. There were slivers of rabbit, but a whole lot of beets or something. The caesar salad really wasn't anything special. The bread in the bread basket was burnt. 

In the meantime, we were waiting for my friend's wine to arrive. My oysters arrived (after the two appetizers), and still, no wine. At this point, I was hoping John would redeem himself,service-wise, since he helped me choose which oysters to sample. 

Finally, someone brought over her wine...to the wrong table. When the wine made it to our table, John just said another drunk lady took the original glass, which was why it took so long. No apology.

We ordered the roast chicken with warm bread salad to share. Now, this is where I felt really ripped off. The chicken was amazingly dry. I can't cook, and I can make better chicken. The outside was overly salty, the meat was overly bland and dry, even the dark meat. The salad wasn't anything unusual, just greens and bread tossed in oil and chicken juices. 

We passed on dessert and asked for the check. John thought it was okay to TOSS the check folder onto the table without saying a word. It slid a couple inches before coming to a stop. 

He's lucky my friend determined the tip and not me because I would've tipped much less, even though he kinda helped with the oyster choices. The greeting, the lack of apology for the late wine, and the check tossing (the last straw) really turned me off from coming to Zuni ever again. I can do without pretentious service, thanks. Especially when the food itself isn't all that great.
author: Evelyn C.

description:
What is it about this place that people love so much? The tasteless, under seasoned food, the poor service or the pretentious atmosphere? Above all, the food is so tasteless that you feel horrible for spending your money on something you could made at home. This restaurant is a complete waste of time. 

We order the asparagus soup, which was simply chicken broth, sliced asparagus, and onions. The soup was severely under seasoned, lacked garlic or some unique flavor, and was not even hot at the time it was served.

My husband had the Mahi Mahi, which had ZERO seasoning. Luckily they served a coriander chutney (which I can make in my sleep) with the fish otherwise the fish would have been completely dry. They also, in hindsight, added tasteless and under seasoned veggies. 

I order a pasta dish with veggies, which was simply pasta (that was not made fresh in house), with butter, onions, and peas. No salt, no black pepper! My 3 year old niece eats food like this. GROSS!

Wow, this was place is such a disappointment. Save your money and time and go somewhere else. ugghh
author: LAIKA K.

description:
02.11.10

917 other people cannot be wrong about a restaurant.

7x7 cannot be wrong to put Zuni's chicken #1 of their SF Things to Eat/Drink Before You Die List.

I, totally, agree.

This dinner has been a long time coming.  I've been dreaming about this chicken for months.  I didn't even mind the hour wait for the chicken [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oqsu3pKpgRMGHj9QItsx0A?select=F8u8EwV8RgVVzLqexPfi2Q] to be perfect.  And boy, was it perfect.

To hold us over until the chicken arrived, we also had three appetizers.  The potato soup was by far the best one [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oqsu3pKpgRMGHj9QItsx0A?select=r4N-OpULXI-K_CfQveQBGA]!  Close second is the gnocchi [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oqsu3pKpgRMGHj9QItsx0A?select=vEKZWbKECFVsMggy_cEnKA], followed by the lamb sausage [http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/oqsu3pKpgRMGHj9QItsx0A?select=07GFkCNwuV7R_Jc98Ev1Mg].  I'm not a big lamb fan, but the kale saved the dish for me.

So glad I finally got to have the chicken!
author: Jenny L.

description:
After almost four years in San Francisco, I finally made it to Zuni Cafe. When we arrived, we were seated promptly. My friend and I were seated upstairs right next to open windows. We had all the benefits of the outdoors with all the comfort of being inside.  Our server was good right off the bat, giving us just the right balance of privacy and attentiveness.

We started things off with the house bread and fresh butter. It was delightful, with an excellent crust. For my main dish, I had a lovely salmon dish that had a salmon fillets surrounded by leek, fennel, olives, greens, and roasted baby potatoes. The fish was cooked to perfection and the balance of flavors was wonderful. I completely cleared my plate. I followed that with a slice of the gateau victoire, an airy flowerless chocolate cake topped with a dollop of fresh whipped cream. It was divine, as was the spoonful of bittersweet chocolate pot de creme I had. My friend and I didn't have the chicken, because 48 minutes at lunch isn't doable on a work day. That just means I'll have to go back. Some classics, like Zuni, are that way for a reason.
author: Nicole M.

description: Who do they think they are??? There are now a lot of GREAT choices around the Theatre district e.g. Hayes Street Grill and Zuni is a JOKE and pricey. They lied to us about the availability of the chicken for two; the menu is VERY limited. We will never go back. This is the third time we have tried them over the last 30 years but never again!!!
author: Roger M.

description: It's time for this venerable institution to review its' performance. Myself and 5 friends had the sad experience of dinner here last night. The service was good but the menu and food preparation lacked in almost all respects. The good points were the salads and the fresh oysters which were excellent. The main courses were lacking. Two of my companions ordered a squash soup on the menu. The soup was never delivered and when we inquired as to its absence, the wait person had no idea why it was missing. Finally, after a considerable wait, the manager came to inform us that soup had been removed from the menu, but they had failed to inform the wait staff. The chicken, for which one has to wait one hour, was only passable. Quit frankly, I prepare a better brined fowl at home. The same goes for the pork: uninspired! As a long time patron, I was very disappointed and embarrassed I had recommended Zuni to my friends.
author: Charles B.

description: What can I say about Zuni Cafe that hasn't been said?  Absolutely nothing!  Get the chicken dinner for two.  You will not be disappointed.  We added the fries, and it made it even more awesomer!  The chicken had the right amount of salt, and the acidity of the dressing in the bread salad provided a good balance of flavors.  Jessica, our waitress, was one of the best servers we've had at any restaurant ever, and we've been to a fair amount of restaurants.  She was friendly and attentive without being disruptive.  She knew when to move us to our next course and provided the correct spacing between the courses.  Great food!  Great service!  Stop reading and make a reservation already!
author: Melofel O.

description: Zuni is a nice restaurant with excellent drinks, did not eat, however the service came with a healthy dose of snotty attitude from the server.
author: Michael M.

description: Shared the Zuni Caesar Salad, Roast Chicken for Two and the Gnocchi with the family.  In particular, the roast chicken takes an hour to make, but is tender and has great flavor - definitely worth the wait if you are going here.  Good food, great service, but pretty high prices.
author: Bryce A.

description:
This place in incredibly overrated. I came here with my friends in December. The 7x7 list brought us here, and I was so excited about trying the roasted chicken. Let me tell you, think twice before shelling almost 50 bucks for the chicken, I think whole foods roterserie chicken is comparable, and its only like 10 bucks. And it was undercooked and it made me sick. It was clearly undercooked, and i ate it, so obviously, that was my fault. But still... you can do better then that Zuni!

The breaded salad however, was so delicious. I would come back, only for that. 

Also, the bartenders are super condescending. I asked for an Appletini, and the bartender made me feel like a moron for asking. If I am going to shell out 12 dollars for a cocktail plus tip, you can at least pretend to be nice.
author: Magdalena G.

description:
Zuni Cafe is on everyone's list of all-time San Francisco favorites.  I don't come often, but I do keep on coming back.  Each visit is a pleasure.  I can't remember all the times that I've been here -- at least a half-dozen I'd say -- but I do recall one great evening when a large group of us showed up late at night for the famous post-10PM hamburgers.

I was last here a few nights ago with a group of 6.  As usual, my companions were wowed by the architecture and the views of the street.  Our server was fine, although she used "awesome" to describe most of the dishes that we asked about.

It may be that I've never had the famous chicken.  Or maybe I have had the chicken, but it was so long ago that I've forgotten the experience.  Walking to Zuni the other night, I really had Zuni chicken on the brain, but the one-hour wait for it was sufficiently dissuasive that I went for the sliced leg of lamb as my main dish.  That dish was the low point of the evening for me -- it was OK, but my socks were still on even after the first bite.  It was a perfectly executed 3-star dish.

Back to the starters: I had a warm white bean salad that was a total knockout.  I negotiated a swap with the guy across from me and gave him some of that salad in return for a small portion of the caesar that he ordered.  The Zuni caesar is another of their iconic dishes -- just like the chicken, it may be something that I had in the past, but I sure couldn't remember it.  Let me just record the fact that the caesar is great (as everyone knows).  Even tasting it was a wonderful pleasure.

Wines, we did order some.  I went for two of the cheaper bottles.  The big winner was the 2007 "vielles vignes" St. Joseph, which had Kermit's label on the back.  If I have a moment, I will stop into Kermit Lynch's shop at buy a few bottles.  Everyone loved the wine, which seemed to me like a fine value.  The wine that wasn't a big winner was an arneis that we started with.  It had some spritz to it, possibly as the result of a secondary fermentation.  I was put off by the slight fizz and didn't think that the wine was noteworthy.
author: Kenneth R.

description: I love their chicken and crave it quite frequently.  Sometimes the wait for a table can me slow.   Sometimes their wait time for your entrees can be a bit slow as well.  However, it's just about the best chicken in this universe.  Don't opt for the fish or the duck, get what they are famous for.  Their chicken and polenta....
author: Michael G.

description: I would definitely go back here next time I'm in SF. Good was unique and great. Staff seemed to be quick and work as a team. Very fast and friendly service. Great location. Romantic and elegant perfect for date night.
author: Sherra B.

description:
NOTE: I am a Zuni-devotee. The Zuni Cafe Cookbook is my favorite cookbook, and I am familiar with many of the dishes offered at the restaurant because of it.

I've been to Zuni Cafe a handful of times, and yet I still get excited each time, as if it were the first. I've had brunch, lunch, and dinner here.

This past Sunday I went for brunch. We ordered:
1. Belgian-style brioche with Meyer lemon preserves
2. Eggs baked with sorrel and cream; grilled levain bread
3. Scrambled eggs with chervil; house-made fennel sausage, garden lettuces, and marinated beets
4. Pistachio milk granita

The brioche was just out of the oven, warm and fluffy. The Meyer lemon preserves were sweet, lemony, and not sour or bitter at all. Together, it was a beautiful meld of flavors. I could have eaten at least two, but sadly, I only had a half of one.

My main dish was the eggs baked with sorrel. I wasn't sure what sorrel was (an herb), but it tasted perfect with the eggs and cream. The dish was smooth and creamy from the eggs and cream, and bright from the sorrel. Yum. It tasted even better on the grilled bread.

The scrambled eggs with chervil were incredibly tender. Scrambled eggs aren't hard to make, but I have never had them so good. And who would have thought they'd be so perfect with a salad?

The pistachio milk granita was cold and creamy, but not really my thing. I don't think it's because of Zuni, though. I think I was expecting it to be flavored stronger than it was because I hadn't had pistachio milk before.

Overall, it was an excellent meal, possibly the best breakfast ever.
author: Melissa O.

description: We have their famous chicken, which was excellent. Our waiter was also very good, knew the wine list, and was very helpful in making selections.  The salad was really meager for the price, but the atmosphere was very happening and fun.
author: Wayne S.

description:
Where are the vegetables? 
Bread salad w/ 12 leaves?
$48 bucks for a chicken?

When I moved to the City in '83 this place was popular. Good food. 
'85 and the snobs were moving in, taking over.
'95 OMG what a pretentious staff-worse than the patrons.

'10 reads from the top of this review.

The staff is a bit warmer, but the room is still full of swells and attitude drips off the walls. And the food...not so much. Very small portions @ high prices, and a the desserts are so stark and bare of the plate you'll wonder what you're getting for $7, oh, and don't order the almond panna cotta is you like almonds, there's little taste of them.

Good wine list, not great. 

Nice selection of oysters.

but once again, Zuni left me flat, glad that I don't come here very often.
author: William M.

description:
I came here expecting to be impressed, because I've read about them in various food articles.  People have claimed they have the best burger ever, but I beg to differ.

They do, however have great pizzas, and it's a nice environment.  They have outdoor seating and lots of light on the inside.  However, again, the burger is disappointing.  I like a simple burger that's juicy.  This burger wasn't juicy, and wasn't simple.

So, I wouldn't come back, unless I was with someone who really wanted to go.
author: Jade F.

description:
Atmosphere, Cleanliness, Cesar salad, Latte, and Service.. all were exceptional. 

Thank you Eric Jimenez for the recommendation.
author: Martha S.

description: Chicken Bread Salad!!! Yes, it is a bit pricey but not too bad when you splurge occasionally.
author: Yin D.

description:
After all the hype (from Yelp and my roommate), I finally decided it was time to make a stop at Zuni to try their roasted chicken - yes the much raved about- French- wood fire roasted chicken. I made the reservation on Open Table for a Sunday morning and my taste buds were ready! BRING ON THE CHICKEN!

Unfortunately, what I was not prepared for was the one hour wait... They pop the chicken in oven when you get seated, so there's no ordering ahead of time or taking out. It all compromises the flavor of the chicken. Since my bf was in a rush and we were both hungry, we ordered the pork chop and one of the pizzas instead. I also munched on poletta to keep me happy. 

Both the pork chop and the pizza were good. I've had better pizza at Delfina and I enjoyed the pork chop at The House better, but hey, it's not their specialty so I can't be too critical. 2.5 stars overall for the food.

I really like the ambiance of the restaurant - they have windows in the roof that let in the light, and the tables are arranged in a spacious but dynamic way. It almost felt like we were eating outside even though we saw the kitchen right in front of us. 4 stars.

I'm not sure if I'll ever return for the chicken - maybe if we were more prepared. But then again, wouldn't anything taste like it's the best after waiting for an hour? Maybeeee. And for a time comparison, we finished our meal in 45 mins!
author: Lucia C.

description:
We were seated quite quickly without a reservation. Our hostess was attentive and remembered to check back on us many times even after we received our food. 

I ordered the Sole with greens, kumquats, brown rice, and watermelon. My friend ordered the lamb. Her portion was monstrous and looked delicious. I don't eat red meat, but I definitely plucked a few..........or most of her roasted garlic cloves. My fish was way over cooked; something I was surprised to see at such an upscale place. There was some sort of aoili mixed in with the brown rice and it was a nice balance to the acidity/tartness from the kumbquats. The slivers of watermelon brought a freshness to the dish. This was a very summer/spring type of dish. I was hoping for something a bit more hearty for my entree. I give them three stars for their creativity, but there was just something lacking in that entree. 

I'll probably give them another shot, another day. Or maybe this just isn't a place for pescees.
author: Alesia T.

description: Worst most overpriced meal I've had in a long time.  Server was strange.  Was there on a date and was seated next to a table of 3 all of which were literally looking right at us from 2 ft away for the entire meal - very awkward.  Very cramped.  Fish was dry, soaked in oil, and tasteless.  In fact, all the dishes were soaked in oil - most likely to cover up what was underneath.  Wine was horrid, even though the strange waiter talked it up quite extensively.  Really ruined my night. Do not go here for a good time, nor good food/wine.
author: San francisco C.

description:
nice decor but some of the tables and seatings are very cramped up.

table for 2, got a small table upstairs.  view from the table was lovely.

service was attentive and not too annoying at all.  
-eggs with potatoes, bacons, and cabbage: very greasy but done well.  yolks were runny and potatoes were perfectly crisp.

-pizza with wheel wagon cheese and onions: crispy thin crust that was not soggy.  tasty!

-grilled chicken with bread pudding: waited for this while we devoured the other 2 dishes.  we only had enough space for a piece of chicken each.  breast was moist and juicy; drumstick was moist and tender.  skin was thin and yummy.  bread crunchy but oily.  it was good, but worth $48??

-always need room for dessert: meringue stacked with some whipped creme.  deliciously light and soft. good way to end a full meal.
author: Linda T.

description:
This place is not good. Very simple food not done properly. I don't know how a restaurant with the reputation of this one can get wrong a pasta carbonara, a grilled sea bass or a traditional tarte au citron.. Well they did unfortunately. Expensive and somehow pretentious.

Good wine selection and nice ambience.
author: David L.

description:
If the roasted chicken was their most popular dish, wouldn't it make sense to constantly place chickens into the oven during peak hours, so customers wouldn't have to wait for an hour? I think yes, but then, not as many drinks and appetizers would be ordered. (They even charge for refills!) Real smart, Zuni.

I love all things chicken, so I really wanted to try Zuni's roasted chicken. I was a little disappointed. The chicken was cooked well, but also fairly bland.

As for some of the other dishes ordered:
- Spinach soup was way better at Range.
- Hamburger was surprisingly good.
- Shoestring potatoes were okay, but very salty.
- Piccola meringata was eh and definitely not worth the $9.75.

Good food, but not great. This place is best for lunch, especially with all of the natural lighting through the huge windows.
author: Sophia B.

description: One of the overly hyped places in San Francisco.. (This one particularly because of A company's CEO).. I had heard so much about their roasted chicken which takes over 45 minutes to cook.. It was nothing great and was too greasy/buttery from the bottom.. In all tried their chicken wine and potato fries and all of them were pretty decent ...
author: Jatin A.

description:
Too many people have reviewed this establishment and for a good reason. Zuni Cafe obviously brings out delicious food. So being brought up to the second level towards the back near the window but in a booth...this is what we dined on...

- The Polenta - as heavy as it looked was actually quite light and with the faint bits of marscapone cheese..
- The Cured Anchovies - were nice, especially with the addition of the parmigiano.
- Oysters - on the half shell, who would complain? wonderfully fresh.
- Chicken - the chicken, that buttery buttery chicken with the bread salad. The bread soaked up the buttery goodness of the chicken and I know if I ate too much I would of got sick but I still I did anyways. 

And for dessert...
now I don't remember the name of that dessert...and I only have a photo of it left on my phone. But that dessert was really good. Now I dont usually order such things after a heavy dinner too but this dessert, I would definitely order again and again. It was amazing. The next time I head there I will let you guys know what it was.

Service at Zuni was top notch, the staff were informative and quick. They made sure we were comfortable. OH and they made sure our bubbly was not stale and got us a new bottle because they felt the quality was not there.

I will be back again Zuni...I will definitely be back...
author: phillip w.

description: Food was delicious, but I wish they had a couple more options on their menu. Their portions of salad are a tad small tho. The shoestring fries were tasty! The service was good as well.
author: Mar J.

description:
- one star for excellent service (highly trained wait staff) 
-one star for ambiance
- one star for fresh, local cuisine, although the chicken... not worth it in my book, and way overpriced, and the bread salad... a bit greasy and not enough acid for my personal taste. 

- the oysters were delicious, and our fresh seasonal salads were delicious

- the burrata was a bit runny and served almost ice cold

- the gnocci were mushy.... and very under-seasoned, certainly agreed upon as our least favorite dish 

- if you want fresh american cuisine in a gourmet setting, consider absinthe down the street, or starbelly in the castro.... 

- I think there is equivalent or better chicken at good friggin chicken in south mission... although obviously the dining experience isn't comparable in the least!
author: Beth P.

description: Outstanding service, good and unusual food, somewhat pricey. We shared a salad, then I had the sea bass and my daughter had the gnocchi. With one soft drink and a bottle of water, $100 including tip. The place was on my daughter's bucket list, and we had a good meal.
author: Rick R.

description:
Location:  Great.  Service:  Excellent.  Wine list: Very good.  Food: Exactly as described in the menu.  Have eaten here 30+ times, and never gets old.  Well, the homeless asking for a handout on Market get old, but that ain't about Zuni -- that's the Human Condition.
Better steak than Morton's at half the price.
Eat here, early and often.
author: Russell R.

description: Zuni is a consistently good restaurant with fresh and tasty meals.  I love the cocktails and wine list and of course, who wouldn't want to have the best chicken ever?  The salads are outstanding.  The service was just fine.  The only complaint I have is that the tables are very close together and the woman at the next table was very loud and annoying.  But it made me happy when she saw our chicken and complained that she wanted some but wouldn't wait an hour for anything!  Because it is worth waiting for, and how pleasant to spend time in San Francisco, drinking and watching the world pass by while someone bakes you a fantastic and perfectly cooked bird?
author: Leslie W.

description:
Has it really been two months since my last review?!?

I haven't stopped going out to eat or anything.  It's that something happens when I'm about to start writing a review - that something is called Farmville.

I'm currently in an addicting cycle of plowing, planting, and then harvesting which leads to more plowing, planting, and . . . you get the point (right my fellow farmers?).

Well since I'm not over Farmville yet, I'll have to try writing a review while I wait to harvest my crops.

Mood Music:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7dF96UFfGrw&feature=player_embedded

You know how ordering the wrong thing can diminish your overall dining experience?
It's sad but I've had more than my fair share of miscues and left some highly rated Yelp restaurants feeling bewildered and empty because I didn't get the right dish.
I needed Help!

Then there came The Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die.  Finally, a guideline of stuff to order at some of the City's better eateries.

For those interested, here's the afore mentioned list:
http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

Number One on the list is the Roast chicken and bread salad at Zuni Cafe and for good reason.
The tall glass windows on Market Street showcasing all the alcohol had me assuming it was going to be a more casual kind of a place.  I was wrong.  Once I stepped inside, I was surprised by how stylish yet still comfortable it really was.

Then there was the chicken.
It is totally amazing - crisp skin and succulent meat all without being deep fried.
At first I was shocked how much they charge for their chicken for two, but in the end, it was so worth every penny!

It leads me to wonder if the chicken is  . . . wait.  Did you hear that?
I think my crops are ready.

So until the next review, happy eating.
author: Dan B.

description: Fantastic food. Fantastic service. Their chicken has now ruined all other chicken for me. Ridiculously juicy, tender, smoky, crispy, and the charred bits of bread underneath, just ridiculous. I'd eat it over and over again, and I don't ever say that about a restaurant, or about chicken.
author: Simcha K.

description:
If you like being ignored and/or humiliated by wait staff, paying too much for okay food, and having your conversation overheard by every other diner in the restaurant, then this place is for you.

If not, I can recommend a dozen other restaurants that are a better deal for your hard-earned money, or the interest of your trust fund the size of Texas. (And which are much more fun!)

Had a freaky loud-voiced "helpful" waiter tell me how to "properly" get ketchup out of a bottle--all because he went to the goddamn Heinz 57 plant in Wagga Wagga, New South Wales. (Pretty cheeky for someone who relies on tips for a living.) "YOU POINT IT AT A 45-DEGREE ANGLE, SEE, LIKE THIS! AND THEN YOU HIT IT RIGHT AT THE 57 LOGO. YES, JUST LIKE THAT! YOU GOT IT!"

Con-effing-gratulations, honey. You turned every head in the place to stare at me and make me feel like a moron. (And $28 for a burger? Will the ghost of the cow give me the winning lottery numbers or clue me in to the next big stock tip? Or am I paying for the haute-cuisine knowledge of their world-traveled wait staff?)

Well, it backfired. I have never gone back, and will suggest other locations to anyone who brings up this over-rated establishment.

D-I-S-A-P-P-O-I-N-T-I-N-G
author: Russell H.

description: I don't understand the hype. I just went for the second time, to see if I missed something from the first visit.  The food was fine but nothing special. Maybe the chicken is really the thing to get but I didn't really want to wait an hour. This last visit nothing really jumped out at me so I settled for the Caesar and the quail. Both good, the quail was pretty moist and flavorful, but not a place I would make a point of going back to.
author: Heather G.

description:
I am sad to report that Zuni is not what it used to be.  Hopefully, it's just a one time
aberration and it will return to its formal glory immediately.  Our expectations were high, as we have enjoyed Zuni for many, many years both pre-performance and  with almost every out of town guest we've ever hosted.  

The wonderful bar was not so great.  Our lemon drops were not sweet enough so my husband requested a little simple syrup.  They returned his drink to the bar and it came back with an odd bitter taste.  He returned it once again and this time, the helpful waiter told us he made a new drink himself.  It was much better, not the spectacular drink we  previously took for granted but perfectly acceptable. 

My husbands favorite Caesar salad was nothing special either and lacked the shower of shaved Parmesan that previously topped it. The pasta with cauliflower was only okay. The halibut was good.  The chicken was a disappointment and the bread salad was oily.  The timing is also an issue when you have a performance; there isn't enough time for much of a delay over the hour listed on the menu when you have to walk to Davies. And finally, my favorite dessert anywhere, the espresso granita, lacked sugar.  I'm sure I've had this a hundred times; it always married coffee and dessert in one spectacular ending. Last night, it was like unsweetened coffee.

We noticed that there were empty tables on a Saturday night, the entire time that we were there.  Maybe there was a reason.
author: Debra T.

description:
One hour for chicken?

For a one hour wait on rotisserie chicken, I expected it something that melted in the mouth.  It was disappointing.  Costco probably could have delivered more.  The chicken was relatively dry and flavorless.  The sides were not that great either.  The only thing that stood out was probably the salad.  We stuffed ourselves with french fries during the one hour wait, and those were not quite special either.  

The restaurant itself is in a nice location, but the food left much to be desired.  The service was decent but the atmosphere was a little snobbier than expected.  I think next time I'll opt for Costco rotisserie chicken takeout instead.
author: Victor S.

description:
We just got back from a show-Shen Yun 2013 looking for a place to eat that was open. Zuni Cafe-The Atmosphere was amazing very unique. The restaurant changes its menu daily. 

What we had:
Lentil soup to start-
-We had pork shoulder tasty it was 28, I felt it was pricey for what you got
-Another person had the grass fed burger--that was simply to die for Delicious
-Then the Quail which was so tasty

For dessert shared Gâteau Victoire with whipped cream-
author: Semira J.

description:
They have the roasted chicken that launched a thousand ships.

Their chicken is a total CILF.

That roasted chicken is both a whore and an angel, the alpha and the omega.

We waited an hour for it, as the menu said we had to, but we didn't even notice the time pass because there were lots of yummy distractions: House-cured anchovies with celery, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and coquillo olive, the Zuni Caesar salad, and a rabbit salad. The anchovies and the Caesar share a lot of the same flavors so if you're not an anchovy fiend like me and my uncle then you're best off just having the Caesar. Their Caesar is pretty unique in that it's just really raw--- nothing is cut up into little pieces and there are three major flavors (garlic, anchovy, egg) and the dressing sits glistening on the leaves with cool slivers of parmigiano over them. The croutons are rustic cubes that perfectly complimented the tangy-ness of the dressing. 

Once the chicken was on the table, everything in the world was obliterated. There was just this chicken dish. You know when flavors work perfectly together--- like chocolate and hazelnuts? Apparently warm bread salad with scallions, mustard greens, dried currants, and pine nuts is the best combination for roast chicken in the world.  What's more is that the chicken was so, so, so, so, juicy and its drippings are soaked up tenderly by the bread salad. If I could just eat that bread salad I'd be happy, but oh happy day I get to have the best roasted chicken in the world with it!

Seriously, I have not had a better roasted chicken since. The roasted chicken at Barbuto in the West Village of NYC comes pretty close and so does the chicken at Range in the MIssion of SF. But the number one chicken in the world for me is at Zuni Cafe. If you don't order the roasted chicken you'll have ordered wrong, so come correct.
author: Lisa Q.

description: Excellent service.  The food in general was great but I went there for the famous chicken and wasn't that impress.  I mean it was good chicken, but did not WOW me.
author: Pavarti B.

description: Excellent service. Very welcoming. Great quality food. Pizza not my fav but everything else great. Another busy restaurant. Reservations a must for thurs-sat. Been here 4 times already. Will return again.
author: Food L.

description:
I live in three cities NYC, Sf and LA and Zuni Cafe is my favorite restaurant in the USA hands down. And I eat most every meal of my life in a restaurant so it's not a review I make litely. But this bears saying this week!

I just received news that I lost a friend today, the restaurant was very kind to personally call me before I heard elsewhere. Thank you!

Judy Rodgers of the famed Zuni Cafe passed away and it's a day to celebrate food! What's curious about this is we were not really close but I have been a regular at her restaurant for over 26 years. It's my FAVORITE restaurant in the world! And I have eaten at thousands.

Judy and Zuni are FOOD. Zuni is my second home, I have literally eaten there over 5000 times! I'm not kidding. I know most of the staff well, many who have worked there for decades. I have had family and staff parties, celebrations of every type or encounter there you can imagine. I have attend their parties and benefits and I have dreamed up companies, written songs, poems, letters and created some of my finest work on their paper table covers, carefully tearing them at the end of my meals and folding them away for further development more times than I can count. I have met some of my closest friends while sitting next to them as strangers only to end up sliding over and sharing wine together, I have shown off Zuni to my Celebrity friends and referred 1000's of people to it's doors. I am in love with Zuni Cafe and what Judy thoughtfully and passionately built over the years with her partners and colleagues.

Judy did not like to be called "Chef"! I love that because I do not like to be called anyone's "Boss" we are a team doing great things together is how I view my staff. But she led Zuni, and promoted from within. Bussers to Servers etc., and people stay at Zuni!

I love the family of Zuni, I loved how Judy and her food have nourished my soul, my ideas and have allowed me a home away from home, each time I walked in it's doors. 

My favorite memory of Judy is the night I got to cook for her and her husband Kirk. I was nervous because my friends and my favorite chef were coming to my home for dinner. This was also the night that OJ Simpson ran from the police through the streets of Los Angeles in his Bronco. Judy called and said, "Sorry we're late but are you watching this on TV?" I replied, "Yes, it's so unbelievable I think I burned my sauce while watching the news!" Everyone was over an hour and a half late to dinner which while still good, was not as good as I had hoped. But she was gracious and we had a great meal and lots of fun together despite OJ's antics! And I got to cook for THE cook!

So here's to my favorite "cook"! My favorite restaurant, my favorite restaurant staff and to a lifetime of wonderful shared experiences. I will miss you Judy, as will the world for your style, grace and humility as well as the flavors you have given so many of us for so many years. 

I don't believe in heaven and all that stuff but I know that IF there was a place like it, it's better have an Oyster Bar and a Brick Oven waiting because things are about to get a whole lot more tasty! 

As for me, it's Noon in San Francisco and I'm going to Zuni for lunch!

With Love,

Mark E. Sackett
author: Mark E. S.

description: Been coming here for years.  Yes, the chicken is that good.  Bring a friend and order it.  Have some small dishes beforehand to share also.  Lots of options. The oyster selection is good
author: Clifford S.

description:
Boom! My new favorite burger in San Francisco. Is it the flavorful, but not greasy, patty that was ground in-house? The grilled rosemary foccacia bread? The aioli? The selection of cheeses? Yes to all. I can't stop telling people about this burger, probably because of the inherent surprise that my new #1 was made at a restaurant that has been around for many years. 

Keep in mind we're talking about a price of $20 or higher with toppings, taxes (yes, they still charge 4% Healthy SF separately?!), and tip. Just remember that you can order it during lunch, afternoon, and late night....typically not during dinner, however.

Have you ever ordered Sanbitter, which is bitter San Pellegrino? Mmm mmm, quite tasty. I wish more restaurants carried it.

On my next visit, I'll definitely talk someone in my group into sharing the roasted chicken dish. A couple friends have said it's excellent. 

Service is friendly, knowledgeable, and professional. The location couldn't be more convenient, though parking within a block isn't easy.
author: Mike H.

description: Food was good. Great oyster selection & interesting dishes. Extensive wine list & wonderful, upbeat & cozy atmosphere. The portions & price are rather out of wack. And the service was not overly friendly or fast. Maybe it was an off night but with all the choices in SF it will be hard to convince me to go back.
author: Danielle H.

description:
A review of Zuni would probably not be complete without a review of the exotic oyster selection. Unfortunately, we did not have oysters so I will try regardless.

For an appetizer we had the anchovies, olives and reggiano drizzled with olive oil. Very tasty but a bit of a "delicate" portion for $8.75.

I had the Llano Seco ranch pork chop which was very generously sized and quite delicious. Perfectly seasoned and perfectly cooked. My wife ordered the spaghetti with the nettle hearts which she seemed pleased with. We didn't have the time to wait for the 1 hour chicken for two, but was a bit surprised to see a single chicken brought out for $48. That must be one damn good chicken.

An excellent dining experience for our trip from Austin to the Bay Area.
author: Alec W.

description: The brunch menu leave a LOT to be desired and is overpriced. Zuni definitely sells a lot of alcohol, there were 3 alcohol menus and only half a page for brunch food. My gut told me to bail and leave but I sadly ignored the message. The service was average. Zuni staff are experts in refilling glasses with water and offering desert, but that's about it.  I had the duck with poached egg, and I was in shock when they brought out my dish. There was no food on my plate. My friend had the scrambled eggs with trout fish. Both looked like appetizer dishes. We also ordered an appetizer to share which endued up being 2 small pieces of bread with some cheese and beats. Also, they took forever to make such small dishes.  I did not order alcohol. $28 per person; two people; we both felt like we got ripped off. I will never go back to Zuni.
author: JH J.

description:
Zuni is why i love food and drink...

We ate at 1:30 on Saturday. At first, we weren't stoked on the upstairs, 'balcony' table we were given. But, that's restaurants, some tables are good, some not so much. But, within a few moments, it sorta took on that "Real Housewives" made for TV, no one else is in the room vibe, and it was pretty fun up there looking out over the room.

And, it gave our waitress a chance to shine. So, let's start there. Cherish was one of the best servers I've encountered in awhile. I've played the waiter-game many times for many years. And, some people have got it. Cherish has it. You can tell she loves the food and knows a LOT about it. She understood our palate, and brought an amazing series of wines to us throughout what would become a 4.5 hour eating and drinking day. Can't say enough good about her.

The food was amazing. The oysters were perfect as they should be (thank you hog island) and they were better because of the wine(s) Cherish suggested. The anchovy, cheese and celery was great. The trumpet and hedgehog risotto was cooked to perfection. The sole was very good, not my favorite piece of fish I've ever eaten. But, it was competing with some crazy good food. Lastly, the pork chop I ordered easily won the entree olympics - salty, sweet, tender and perfectly pink.

All in all it was an insane meal, with insane wines served by a great (and not insane) waitress.

Loved it.
author: Rich H.

description:
chicken, chicken, chicken, bread salad, martini(s), ceasar salad, chicken.

I hate going into situations (dinners, high school dances, friday nights...you get my point) with high expectations however with all of the hype surrounding this place, I couldn't help but have mile high hopes of having a phenomenal experience here.  

I must say that the pessimistic side of me was a little bummed because good lord- this was one of the best meals I've had in the city.  While the service was a little awkward and intrusive, the delicious ceasar, crispy potato strings & the CHICKEN---ohhhhh the chicken---sigh...was absolutely stellar.  The skin was crispy, the meat moist and flavorful, yowza was it awesome.

The food was so delectable, it overshadowed the creeper/awkward waiter.
