Even if you are not a big chicken person, I highly recommend giving this place a chance for a date night or just a dinner away from home - you WON'T be disappointed.
author: Lindsay P.

description: Girlfriend took me here last night for my Birthday Dinner, and it was nothing short of amazing! we had a 7:15 reservation on a busy Sunday night and we were seated 5 minutes before. Instantly greeted by our waited who's name I forgot, but he was great all night. We went there for the chicken and before we could ask, he mentioned that it is their most popular dish and if we would like it, its best to put in your order right away because it takes a little over an hour to slow cook. 100% worth the wait. We started out with a couple cocktails that were both great and reasonably priced. The mezcal was both of our favorite out of the 2, and we also brought a bottle of wine that was opened to breathe right away. We went with the suckling pork starter which I would give a 4 out of 5. Put a little butter on your bread and soak the rest of the juices up when you are done with it.... Soooo good! Then the chicken.... ohhhhh the chicken. First off, "plate for 2" is an understatement. You can easily feed a table of 4 with 2 appetizers and the chicken plate. Sooo tender, sooo juicy, flavor was outrageous! Dare I say the best chicken I have ever had. And the savory bread pudding is insane. I had to stop myself from over eating it was so good. Check this place out! I am looking for an excuse to go back here as soon as I can. Hats off Zuni Cafe! You guys are great.
author: Michael R.

description: Recently went back after a 10+ year gap.  Read up on the reviews and got their staples - shoe string fries, baked chicken, and a pasta dish. The fries were good but hard to mess up on fries. The chicken is really good and worth the $48 and one hour wait. Everything was moist and skin crisp. Flavor went deep into the chicken. It is not like a Costco rotisserie chicken, as one Yelper had wrote. Service was good. Would go back.
author: Sylvia C.

description:
Fabulous. Thanks Yelp for letting us make a reservation!

Looking at the menu? No need, get the chicken. Takes an hour, but it's worth it.

Be sure to get a salad, family got a little crazy and ordered the fries too. But it's a bunch of food, so you'll be taking some home.

Recommend bringing your own bottle, corkage fee however, much cheaper than paying $15 a glass.

Eclectic seating arrangement, but makes it fun and private almost.

Definitely not going to be a cheap night out of the town, but the experience is awesome, food and service is great.

Give Zuni a go and you'll be recommending it to a friend right after!
author: Matthew H.

description:
My GF and I celebrated an anniversary at Zuni Cafe.  Having heard so much about the chicken and bread salad, we figured we had to try it.  We also opted to share the Caesar Salad, the arugula salad and the gnocchi.  

I'm not sure there are enough words to describe the gnocchi.  Little pillows of awesomeness is about the best description I can come up with.  I could have devoured two orders of the gnocchi and I would have been happy.  

The Caesar salad was also good and is enough to share between two people.

The chicken was good.  $50 good?  That's hard to say.  I mean it was a good chicken but it was still just a roasted chicken.  

I'd definitely come back, but I might not order the chicken again,
author: Larry L.

description:
This year we decided on Zuni for my birthday. My mom, my brother and my boyfriend all really enjoyed our dinner. It was excellent from beginning to end. All the food was fresh and full of flavor, our drinks were well made and a wonderful bottle of Pinot Noir to complement the meal. The desserts and Graffeo coffee are a must. And I have to say that our waitress Cherish was so pleasant, a real dream.
 my dinner:
2 vodka martinis
Caesar salad with anchovy fillets
Halibut
glass of Pinot Noir
Crepes w/ strawberries and peaches
Coffee

Delicious..... This is a very well run restaurant and you can taste the love and passion in the food.
author: Sabrina L.

description: Like so many, I love this place. Their roasted chicken and bread salad is pure love. Period.
author: L A.

description:
The service was outstanding -- even when they called to confirm our reservation they checked to see if we needed to be out at a certain time to see a play or get to a concert.  And the waiter indicated he knew we had a time constraint when he first walked up to our table.  That's customer service!

Unfortunately, my food didn't live up to my past experiences at Zuni -- everything on my dish (pork & veggies) was very salty and oily.  Hopefully it was just a bad night for the chef.  I'm giving Zuni 3 stars instead of 2 only because I've had better meals there in the past, but I hope I don't have to downgrade them in the future!
author: Sarah F.

description:
Just like practically all the other yelpers on here, I had the roasted chicken and bread salad for two. It was one of those comforting, really well-made delicious meals that's good, but not outstanding. Succulent, flavorful chicken whose hot juices and seasonings wonderfully complemented cubes of crusty, toasty bread. Note: this meal is definitely a generous portion of poultry protein. The best part? Leftovers!

I am not a big oyster fan, but my family loves them and found much gastronomic pleasure in Zuni's oysters. 

I am yelping about this much later than the time I actually went, but from what I recall the menu is quite small and you should really look to see if this is somewhere you want to go or you may not jive well with the choices. I love the decor of this place -- farm/industrial look with lots of wood and open spaces.
author: Amber M.

description:
Roasted chicken and bread salad, check!  That's #1 from 7x7's Big Eat SF.  We got there right at 11:30am on a Saturday and there was a small line forming waiting to get in.  We were seated immediately and the place filled up fairly quick.  We were anxious to place our order since we new exactly what we wanted and we knew it would take 1 hour to finally make it to our table.  

Thank goodness they gave us bread because I was starving.  The crust of our sliced bread was burnt so we had to eat around it.  But we did finish it, after all, we did have a whole hour to wait.  We even got a 2nd helping of bread which was probably a bad mistake.  They brought our dish about 40 mins later.  Apparently when there are only 5 chickens in the roaster it takes only 40 mins, any more then it's the full hour.  I guess we got lucky.

So, you remember when I told you we got the 2nd helping of bread?  Well, the salad comes with more of the same bread, everywhere.  Not only was there more bread than greens, it was drenched in olive oil and chicken juices.  I was sooo breaded out.  No more please!  I ate around all of the bread and finished off the greens.  At that point my body was just craving vegetables!  I ate a couple pieces of chicken and then we had to pack the rest away.  

I'm actually feeling kinda grossed out right now about how heavy that meal is sitting in my tummy as I type.  And this is 4 hours later too!  I know everyone loves this dish but geez, I feel like i just drank a tub of oil.  Having said that, I would not order that dish again.  At $48 that's a pricey roasted chicken.  I can get one from Safeway for under $10 and add all of the greens I want.  Come here to check #1 off your list but come back to try something else on the menu.
author: Rosalind S.

description: This place has absolutely everything a foodie can ask for! The ambiance is very relaxing and casual, food is fresh and delicious, the cocktails actually use good liquor, and the service is superb! I had the privilege of having Jessica as our waitress and she was very sweet and attentive the entire time. Def will come again and refer this place to everyone I know.
author: Cindy S.

description:
I have to say, I've been to Zuni Cafe numerous times over the years and hadn't been there for a couple of years. I thought they'd gotten kind of tired.

Well I went there with friends 2 weekends ago, and the food was fabulous!  I had sea bass with rhubarb and ginger and it was excellent.

We sat upstairs which is my favorite area of the restaurant. The server was very attentive and also a nice person.

Great experience at Zuni.  I'm glad they're back on the up and up.
author: M S.

description:
Tasty meal.
Nice decor / ambiance.
Great service (not pretentious, as so many SF restaurants can be). 
Fair prices.
I'll be back and would recommend to a friend.
author: Cynthia J.

description:
I am a huge fan of Zuni Cafe and have been for pre-opera to post baseball game dinners. I have taken my mom, customers and my son. The atmosphere is still incredible, the building is fun and quirky. The food just gets better and never disappoints. Last week I was there for a friend's birthday. We ordered several appetizers including the kale salad and smoked trout and oranges. We three shared the roast chicken. It was so yummy and my friends really thought it was terrific.
I love that a person can go to this restaurant in very casual dress or dressed to the nines. The cocktails are fun, the crowd is wide ranging (can you tell I love this place?).
Go to this wonderful restaurant and have fun!
author: Lu K.

description:
My friend brought me here right after I stepped off the plane from Taiwan (where I had been for 8.5 months).  

Loved the atmosphere and at 5:30pm, metered, street parking was not hard to find.

We made reservations and they had the table ready 5-10 minutes after we arrived.

Our waiter was sort of awkward and weird...he was informative, although he did come back to inform us about additional ingredients in the chicken.  but in general, his eyes sort of wandered when he spoke to us.. i don't know.  

Anyway, I wasn't sure what to order since I had just gotten off the plane and wasn't too hungry, but my friend said everyone yelped about the chicken, so we got that.  

We were sat across diagonally from the kitchen so while we waited for our roasted chicken on bread salad ($50 for 2 people shared), I watched them cook. REALLY FUN.  (my friend went off to get more quarters for the meter).  You have to wait an hour for them to bake it, but between the good conversation (supplied by friend, not restaurant) and the yummy bread and butter (honestly, not an unbiased report.. I just haven't had rustic chewy bread in a long time.. perhaps if I've been living in America for a while, I would have been more picky).. the time flew by.

The chicken WAS tender and delicious, and the bread salad.. i wish there were more of it.  I enjoyed the contrast of the bitter greens and the texture that the pine nuts and currants provided.

The dessert menu looked delicious (albeit pricey) but we had some place to go for dessert so we opted out of it.  

The chicken was more than sufficient for 2 women, and our boxed leftovers were finished by a 3rd girl at our dessert stop.

It *was* pricey though, and I don't think I'd come back.. but it was tasty and now holds good memories!
author: Jun K.

description: Had an hour and came here for lunch. It took them close to 35 mins to bring me my fennel sausage. Come-on, I know you didn't just fill the casing from scratch (if you did, it should be noted on the menu). Then we had to inquire about the fries we ordered with our meal. That came after I was pretty much done with my single smallish sausage. I guess I would only come back at this point for the famed 1 hour wait Roast Chicken experience.
author: John H.

description:
Gayle and I stopped here yesterday for lunch and even found a parking spot on the street within a block.  We were already in the City to meet with our wedding caterer and then decided that it would be good to sit down and chat about all those surrounding details.  It's times like this that both of us are tempted to just go down to City Hall, get married, head off to Europe, and have a simple party for our friends and family after we get back.

We were nicely greeted up front and found a nice table in the bar area.  Our waiter was just the right amount of friendly and very professional in his service from start to finish. And except for one other customer's repeated and annoying laugh (of which the whole cafe couldn't help but take notice), the noise level and ambiance was very pleasant and conducive to a good conversation. I also enjoyed the copper accents at the bag, the wedge shape of the room, and watching some warm personal interactions at the bar between on of the bartenders and a couple that had dropped in for a drink.

As for the food, please be warned that when you order a burger medium rare here, that's what you get.  And since I'm not that much of a "red" meat guy, the whole blue cheese burger experience was a little uncomfortable.  However, the rest of the burger presentation and taste was great, as were the string fries and Gayle's spinach soup. And after a few drinks, our wedding planning was much clearer.
author: Eric B.

description:
After all that hype, I hate to only give it 3 stars but it just didn't live upon the food side.

For one--the chicken for 2 people is $48.  And yes it comes with a great bread salad, but still.  I feel like that chicken better be organic, artisinal, milk-fed, and gold plated for that price.  We just ate at Limon and got a whole chicken for less than $20 and that chicken had more flavor and was WAY juicier.

So it's hard for me to justify the price, yes, that is one thing.

Overall--service is absolutely great.  Super friendly and nice.  When we sat down and inquired about the chicken, the person who sat us down said he would inform our server to get our chicken started right away.  We also went on a Tuesday night so we waited less than an hour for our chicken!

The asparagus and rice soup was pretty good--they even split the portions.  It's hearty and down home good cookin'.

The chicken was good.  But like I said, it's hard for me to compare.  But on its own it was a good piece of chicken cooked well. But it wasn't anything to write home about.  The bread salad was tasty and good but the green parts were super bitter.

They do serve fresh squeezed orange juice, which was a plus for me.

The atmosphere was cool and chill and it has a neat 2-story inside.

Make your reservations early as they seem to always fill up.

I think it's a good restaurant but overall if I was going for the chicken, I'd probably head over to Limon. If you want a neat cool dinner spot, then this is still a cool place to check out.
author: Traci H.

description:
A business associate took us to Zuni for lunch, noting its prominence in the vanguard of the sustainable cuisine trend.  Big deal.  The food is kind of boring.  The roast chicken intrigued me, but the 1 hour preparation time is ridiculous.  I'm sure there's some sort of culinary justification for it, but it's just not a very user-friendly concept, especially at lunch for those of us who are gainfully employed.  In fact, the concept is so absurd that even putting it on a lunch menu is bordering on pretension.  (Even on a dinner menu it's a little silly, unless they add a disclaimer that reads, "1 hour roasted chicken is designed to encourage you to drink more alcohol, which is where we make our profits.")  I never spent so much time yelping about something I didn't actually order.

Unfortunately, the chicken (which I didn't have) was more memorable than the pizza (which I did order).  It was thin, crispy and totally unremarkable.

I'm all for good, simple cuisine, just don't leave out the "good" part.
author: Ryan W.

description:
My story is a bit different but I'm giving Zuni 5 stars because they gave my sister the gift of a fun, fabulous meal and were helpful resolving some goofs on my side regarding the gift certificate.

My wife, mother and I bought my sister a gift certificate for a milestone birthday after friends in the bay area recommended Zuni.  It was her first time in SF and we wanted to send her and her husband somewhere special but we're not rich enough to spring for a $1,000 meal.

It was my fault that Zuni was unable to send the gift certificate to my sister and unable to reach me except by snail mail.  Before I got their letter, I called and they straightened everything out in very little time and with the utmost calm and professionalism.  

The meal and experience needed to be really good and it was.  Zuni came through.  My sister and her husband had a blast.  That's worth everything so thank you Zuni.
author: Gordon G.

description:
The chicken is perfection. The meat is juicy and flavorful, the skin all burnished and golden, and the bread salad is to die for! Full of pine nuts and currants and chicken juices and vinegar...I'm drooling just thinking about it.  But Zuni is more than a one trick pony - yummy polenta, the house cured anchovies smooth and perfectly briny, and the Ceasar salad is fantastic - sweet and crisp lettuce, crunchy Croutons, and just enough of the perfectly balanced dressing. Awesome oyster selection too, and they're perfectly shucked, plus they use freshly grated horseradish which enhanceds them so well. 

Our server was also just fantastic - super knowledgable and friendly and eager to make suggestions; but not afraid to recommend something different. Zuni is warm and inviting and would be good for a date or to gather a bunch of friends. I wish I didn't live across the country so I could eat there much more often.
author: Jenn C.

description: I had a few glasses of champagne at the bar last night, the bartender Tristan was wonderful. Zuni is an icon, always love the scene
author: Jeannine R.

description:
Went for the burger and the burger gets 5 stars!! The service brought the stars down to 3 (way too long of a wait for someone to greet us and our drinks took almost 15-20 minutes) and the wine brought the final star count to 4. 

Overall my meal was great. The burger is served on light bread, nice and juicy. I got mine with cheese and grilled onions. It was delicious! Also cost $17 which, in my opinion, is a bit steep. 

I would resist going back, but I probably wouldn't be the one to recommend it. If you like burgers, its worth making a point of stopping by (oh, and the burger is served at off times so make sure you check when they are serving before you go).
author: Shanna T.

description: What a cool place. Has the vibe of a European cafe and you can really make it as involved as you want. We ordered lots of little things, as opposed to 2 entrees. The scone was one of the best baked goods I have ever had. The Bloody Mary and the lentil soup were also stand outs. Everything is just really fresh and the people watching was good.
author: Madeline T.

description:
We came here for one thing- chicken with warm bread salad!  i made reservations and we got there a few minutes early.  for some reason a couple who came in after us with a reservation at the same time were seated first, but whatever no big deal- they expedited our chicken and we were out of there in less than 1.5 hours.

we started the a caesar salad which was pretty tasty but not as delicious as i had heard about.  For dinner, we shared the whole roasted chicken with bread salad.  YUM.  I can see why people come here just for it and wait an hour for it to be cooked.  I do think it's a little pricey considering how much a whole chicken costs, but it's enough food for potentially 3 people so it's not so bad.  The chicken was juicy and flavorful and cooked to perfection.  the bread salad was buttery and delicious.

i would come back here just to have the chicken again.  yum.
author: Lisa C.

description:
Pretty good  burger, and that's the end of my kind words. Honestly this place should easily get 4 stars, the food overall was excellent, unfortunately, the service was not.  

I've had more attentive and friendly customer service at an airport burger king. The waiter  forgot if I asked for fries right after he asked, then forgot my drink and was no where to be found for 10 minutes, or at least it seemed that long. I ended up having to flag down another waiter who looked positively annoyed that I had to ask her anything. No smiles, no sorry, no thank you, just a "I hate you, and my job and this stupid white shirt," and yes "i'll get your freaking drink".

When the waiter finally got back he took his time getting to my check. The only person that was attentive was the guy who cleaned my food from the table, I'll give him 5 stars because he did his freakin job.

Oh, and the burger, fries and a coke cost $30. Now, this isn't exactly an In n' Out, but still, that's pricey.
author: Jon C.

description: Always a classic, a friend and I returned for lunch on Saturday over Superbowl weekend.  This is the place for a proper lunch session.  Our waiter was a delight, starting us off with a selection of his favorite oysters.  We moved on to a plate of anchovies.  These were paired with Parmesan Reggiano, olive oil, olives, and thinly shaved slices of celery.  A perfect pairing creating a buttery bite with a clean, fresh finish.  After realizing we were in for the long haul we decided to go with the Roasted whole chicken for two.  The chicken is seasoned wonderfully and arrives in 8 nicely carved pieces.  The Tuscan-style bread soaks up just enough of the juicy goodness from the chicken yet remains a bit crunchy creating a lovely bite.  We ended with all four cheeses, all were delicious with the standout being the blue with the addition of the wildflower honey.  The wine selection is broad enough to pair with anything on the menu.  3 hours, a proper lunch.
author: Troy B.

description:
Oh Zuni, how do you do it? I came here with my girlfriend as a treat to celebrating the semester being over and we were simply amazed by the place. The food here was amazing. If I could give the place higher stars, I honestly would.

We saw a review for this place and how they have the best burgers in the city and honestly we needed to try them. The girlfriend has been here before but never ordered the burger, so it was a first for the both of us. It was amazing. I order my burger with cheese and a grilled onion and she just ordered the grilled onion. It was honestly so delicious I wanted another. Everything about the burger was so amazing, from the focaccia bread to the succulent patty itself. I was simply dumbfounded by it all. Thank you Zuni chefs. You made my day
author: Michael N.

description:
After eating at Umami Burger, my friend and I were on a quest to find a burger place to top it. Definitely not an easy task to do, but Google begged to differ. Apparently this place was voted #1 burger joint in San Francisco at one point.

We came here at around 9 in the evening and got seated 40 minutes later. To our utmost disappointment, they weren't serving burgers at this time. They have certain hours for it and the closets window would be at 10.

I ended up ordering the Grilled Mahi while my friend ordered the Roasted Chicken For Two to himself because he is a prideful giant piece of lard that didn't want to share.

We also ordered about a two dozen oysters and the Potato Strings. The oysters OMG. These had to be the best oysters I've had. I'm sorry Farallons, but I think you have some real competition here, at least in terms of shellfish. Our favorite one was the Nootka Sound Oyster. I didn't even know there were so many different types of oysters with different taste until now. The Potatoe Strings were good too. They were like hot freshly made Pik Niks.

However, I was kind of disappointed with my Grilled Mahi. It was definitely made with different spices and seasoning of high quality, but I just wasn't feeling it. The chicken was really good though. But I'd come here more for the oysters and appetizers next time. Well that and the mysterious best burger in SF I have yet to try...
author: Andrew A.

description: Excellent meal.  The food was exceptional and the service excellent.  The only downside was that the restaurant is extremely noisy and it is very difficult to have a conversation. Definitely someplace to go back to.
author: Chris F.

description:
fantastic ambience, live jazz music when we were there on sunday. solid wine. great ingredients for food. 

Nothing was phenomenal to single out except for the rotisserie chicken (better than Lemon and worth the wait). Our table of 8 shared it as a cheese course!
author: Rebecca C.

description: Zuni Cafe, it had been so long since I ate in your oddly shaped but clever building. After a Turtle Island Quartet concert at the jazz Center, we were a group of 4 and decided to have a late bite in your walls at around 10 pm. The Christmas tree was lit up on the piano, the place was packed with fashionable types on high heels or with 3-day old stubbles: all was resplendent and inviting. You got us a table without fuss and served us very courteously. We had 2 desserts between the 4 of us, a plate of gnocchis and a big plate of pommes allumettes. I moved to the East bay, you know....Zuni: I miss you.
author: Allen C.

description:
So this review is strictly for the burger as Andrei Z and Melanie N and I were on our second stop comparing 7x7 Magazine's Top Ten Burgers and seeing what we thought of their list.

Zuni was #9 on their list so we anticipated a tasty burger, and me especially since I've been to Zuni before and it's always been excellent.  Plus 9 is my favorite number as well.

Anyhow, the burger itself comes on a square foccacia bun which was some nice bread, but of course the square over round burger patty thing means you will have a lil extra corners of just carbs.  Some people might like that and some might not - at first I wasn't as much into it but that bread is good so I didn't really mind...

The burger automagically comes with pickled onions w/hints of cinnamon (of which Melanie got a full stick) and that combination is really subtle but good. The meat itself was a bit overcooked to my taste since I ordered it Medium Rare and it was more close to Medium or even Medium well so that was a bit disappointing.

The beef was still juicy though so I am betting that if it was exactly MR then it would have been even tastier.  So where does that put this burger?  So far (after Namu's 7x7 #10) it's in the top two but of course we've only had two.  Will have to wait until the other seven to make final comparisons but it's definitely a good solid burger, but I am guessing it will be in a similar ranking to where 7x7 rated it.
author: Gene X.

description:
This review is certainly a few months overdue, since I last came here for dinner. Perhaps, the lapse in time is because I haven't quite been able to find the right words to capture my experience, which I must admit was a perfect way to compliment an evening at a Baccalaureate fine-art exhibition beforehand.

I am impressed that they were absolutely flexible with being able to accommodate our reservation for about an hour later since we were running longer than expected at the event. So, upon arrival -I enjoyed a very fragrant and smooth Margarita made with fresh limes at the sparkling bar beneath on the lower tier, while we were waiting to be seated.  The place overall is completely atmospheric with beautifully exposed architecture, with an open lofty flair.

I would recommend the Roasted Squab with quince-apple charlotte and curly endive-fennel salad as a precursor to any meal, and wish it were more readily present with my meals at home. It is absolutely light, refreshing, with just a tinge of spice -you absolutely cannot go wrong with this. The waiter was quite knowledgeable about the oyster selection they had available that night, and there was such a large breadth of variety to choose from so we opted for the large sampling of the chef's recommendations.. I don't quite remember all of the overwhelming variety, but the Kumamoto definitely left a lasting impression.  

At about the same moment, I had to remind myself to stop, be aware, and resume control before continuing on with the rest of dinner.  It was an overwhelming sensory experience, but in a good way.

I had the lamb as my main course, which was falling apart in my mouth.  It was quite rich plated with some quartered carrots which had a nice firm bite to them.

Everyone raves about the whole chicken, so I will definitely have to go back to try it!
author: Ty T.

description:
Took the cute trolley down Market to eat at Zuni on a random Sunday for a late brunch in hopes that we wouldn't have to wait too long.  Ended up with a 20 min wait but got seated upstairs at a cute table by the window.  I have to admit, I've been DYING to try Zuni Cafe and was so excited I finally talked my mother into going.  We started with oysters and I got a bloody Mary, then I got the fried egg with bacon and my mom got the rabbit salad with a poached egg.  The housemade bacon was the BEST bacon I have ever had in my life; I want to roll myself up in it and never leave.  The fried egg was amazing as was my mother's dish and the bloody mary was so delicious.   Also, I hate oysters, but I actually really liked these! 

Service was good, though it took them awhile to come over after we'd been seated BUT our waiter looked like a Disney prince!  He was dashing and so all was forgiven.
author: Madeline W.

description: What a huge disappointment! I have never had a steak that looked and tasted like it was processed and synthetic! It was flat iron steak and was grey, overcooked and inedible, with the strangest texture. I wonder if they baked it--no grill marks on it. The desserts were also a letdown. Blueberry/strawberry with minuscule meringues in a stainless steel compote cup was so meager as to be laughable. The flourless chocolate cake was also disappointing. We mentioned our displeasure with the food to our waiter, and his response was, well maybe this is just not your restaurant. I think that is correct! We won't be going back! There are so many fantastic restaurants in San Francisco, there is no reason to endure a mediocre meal.
author: Jalyn L.

description: One of the very few times my husband and I disagree on the quality of a restaurant but he's not on Yelp so here we go: 5 stars, well deserved. Oysters, cocktails, famous chicken, great service. Not a big fan of the location though.
author: Karlijn V.

description: If you're gonna try Zuni Cafe for their roasted chicken make sure that you're ready for the wait. It takes an hour! And, for us, it really didn't help telling them we were gonna order the chicken when we made the reservation either. But the saying, "Good things come to those who wait" is SOOOO TRUE!!! When the chicken finally came and we dug in, we were in Roasted Chicken Heaven!! If you find yourselves wondering if you should get the chicken, wonder no more. GET THE ROASTED CHICKEN!!! You won't be disappointed!
author: Delbert A.

description:
The million dollar question -- WAS THE CHICKEN WORTH IT??  hmmm let me think about this one....  WEEEELLLL it was probably the best chicken I've had in a long loooong time.  The warm bread salad was HEAVEN..!!  I wish there was more of THAT in the mix.  But to me, chicken [kinda like pizza] is chicken!  If i can get pretty decent rotisserie chicken at costco for $5, then i'm a happy camper.  So overall, I will say it was good, but I'm not really a chicken expert, so I shouldn't have the last word on it.  It was definitely moist, juicy, aromatic, etc etc.  But for $48 - it better darn be! 

On a side note, we also ordered the anchovies and gnocchi - not bad, but not super memorable either.  Would I come back?  hmmm, maybe, maybe not?!
author: T C.

description: This place lived up to the hype! I've heard how amazing the one hour brick chicken for two is and it did not dissappoint. The bread salad on top was also amazing. I went with my fiance and we also ordered the addictive shoe string potatoes (fries) and the cesear salad. The ambiance was great and the food was even better. Can't wait to go back for more!
author: Debbie L.

description:
We had an after ceremony lunch at Zuni after our wedding in 2008 so we returned to celebrate our 5th wedding anniversary with our two groomsmen last night. The meal was not what we remembered from previous excellent meals at Zuni. 

The polenta starter was great as were the anchovies. Desserts good also. 

My lamb portion seemed like it was made up of the last scraps of lamb with some pieces OK, and others tough and gristly. The squab was disappointing.

Service was good and attentive. 

I think that we expected exceptional dishes as we have enjoyed in the past at Zuni and last night it seems that the kitchen was off its game.
author: Aldus M.

description: I have not been in a number of years. Went there this past Friday night and was beyond disappointed. Service was not great at the bar or during dinner. The squash appetizer was completely overwhelmed by a very strong garlic component. The size of the main courses were about the size of the appetizers. I had the pork which looked like dog food with a side of beans. The meat was over cooked and was over powered by one spice. The fish was the same and the pasta dish looked like it had four or five pieces. The desserts were not much better. It was a very sad, disappointing experience. Will not be back.
author: Stephen Z.

description: Hmmmm. I was super excited to go here since I've heard great things but unfortunately my experience was less than expected. Don't get me wrong the food was good but definitely pricey. We also had a reservation for my sisters birthday and they still made us wait 45 minutes. The service was ok, we were a little tucked away so I think they may have forgotten about us, but they were at least friendly. The bloody Mary's were fantastic so I might go back just for that and skip the wait.
author: Rachel M.

description: Very expensive over rated restaurant. I feel the city has lost its zest for good food and overcharges for the mediocre.  Maybe we all should start eating at the food trucks where people cook their hearts out and keep the prices affordable.  Pork chop (from Llano Secco) delicious. Nettles?  Isn't spinach just as good. My husband thought the Ceasar salad was one of the best he's ever had, but the spaghetti was inedible. Thought he should have stopped at the Caesar's.  I'm not going back. I can find better food at better prices in this city.
author: Mary B.

description:
We went there for lunch. When you are paying $18 for a cheeseburger, it had better be spectacular, but the buns were burnt. The menu did not accurately represent the dishI ordered--I thought I was ordering an ordinary pizza with the listed ingredients, but it turned out to be some sort of avant-garde pizza with tomato sauce and a sprinkling of cold shredded cheese rather than the usual melted cheese topping. I would have ordered something else if the menu had accurately represented the dish. The service was poor and two of the entrees came out 15 minutes after the others.

Furthermore, a 4% "surcharge" was added to the bill. The charge was not listed on the menu and there was no explanation for the charge. This is simply a dishonest way of making very high prices even higher.
author: Arev I.

description:
For me, lunch at Zuni Cafe was the ultimate meal that met my high expectations of San Francisco cuisine.  Every single detail was amazing!

The atmosphere-- I like the sort of industrial interior and the open, airy space.  It reminds me of an art gallery, which sort of makes sense with the gorgeous food they serve here. 

The service-- From the host (a cutie, to boot) to our waitress to the bus boys, everyone was friendly, polite, and lovely.  Zuni definitely is laid back in a way that many upscale restaurants in New York aren't-- and I love that in a restaurant.  

The food-- As I said, this is exactly what I envisioned when I was researching our trip to SF.  Fresh produce, artfully showcased, powerful flavors that rely on the integrity of the ingredients and not simply gussying up inferior ingredients, pride in the bounty of the area, and skill in execution.  Zuni hit all those points for us.  

As we nibbled on crusty bread and butter (I think we just about licked the butter bowl clean), we started with an arugula salad served with pistachio and fennel.  The kitchen split this for us onto two plates without us asking into two perfect servings.  It was refreshing and beautifully composed, with a light vinaigrette.

For my main dish, I ordered two smaller plates.  The first was a soup with pureed potato, corn, and pepper, both hearty and rich.  I also had a small salmon filet with a cilantro (maybe?) pesto, succulent heirloom tomatoes, and green and white beans.  Light, flavorful, leaving me feeling totally satisfied but not stuffed as I do after a night at Dinosaur BBQ.

The dessert was our favorite.  It was a meringata, discs of thin meringue layered between mascarpone mousse and blackberry compote.  The mousse was cloud-like-- airy, light, sweet, complemented perfectly by the tart berries; the meringue melted on our tongues.  It was truly an ethereal dessert.

Zuni Cafe was without a doubt my favorite meal in SF and one of the most memorable meals I've ever had!  It was so special to feel as though I really were in a temple to food-- the love and care that goes into each dish is so apparent, and I appreciate so much the respect paid to quality ingredients.
author: L C.

description:
My girlfriend goes to  Zuni Cafe everytime she's in SF so we thought we'd give it a try.  We waited for an hour for our roasted chicken but knew about that and ordered as soon as we sat down. While waiting for the chicken, we tried some of their delicious pizzas, which I'd get again, and maybe all for myself instead of sharing!!  The chicken was great and some of the best I've tasted.  
The atmosphere is airey, which I like a lot.  The tables are close to each other but far enough apart so that you don't feel like you're on top of each other.  Great place for lunch.  Would try for dinner in the future.
author: Carol M.

description:
Delicious food, excellent service. 

Had the lamb tongue appetizer, house Caesar salad and the chicken for two and all were quite good. However, be prepared for the one hour wait for the chicken - which is kinda crazy. 

That said, this restaurant actually knows how to honor a reservation (made on OpenTable) which is not that common anymore for some reason. 

Probably the one drawback is the price. Still a bit on the pricy side for most of the items, but an overall great experience. Would certainly go back.
author: Dave C.

description:
I love this place. The physical plant is just plain cool, with funky angles and a huge window opening up onto Market from the bar area.  There are so many nooks and crannies to Zuni, and being taken to your seat can seem, at first blush, like being led through a labyrinth!

Be sure to make reservations as well.  While waiting for ours, we took a spot in the bar, had some wine, and some great oysters (favorites were the Pacific and the Miyagi), accompanied by the chicory, pomegranate salad.  All was superb, flawless, as was the service.

Our reservation time finally rolled around, and we were led through the labrynthine hallways, upstairs, to our seat, by a window.  NIce cozy spot.  There are so many very "personal" nooks here, with tucked away tables, and very private spaces.  

Service continued to be superb, friendly, suggestive, and non-intrusive.  We of course ordered the chicken, having to try this famous denizen of the 7x7 top 100 list.  It takes an hour to arrive, and they won't let you order it ahead of time.  

Gotta say...nonplussed.  I mean, it was good, sitting there all pretty on its salad of bread, lettuce, and pine nuts.  But it didn't blow me away...after all, it's chicken.  It was well prepared, succulent, and tasty enough, but for $48, I honestly doubt I'd get it again.  

Crostinis were average and overpriced.  I've had better at Metropol for half the price.

However, the butternut squat soup was a thing of beauty, smooth, creamy, with a hint of tang.  

Nice wine list as well.  

I'll definitely be back. Want to try that blue burger that started this big burger kick in the City.  

Food: 3.5
Value: 3
Ambiance: 4.5
Service: 4.5
author: Ethan R.

description: Excellent Fd. Excellent and very professional service. The chicken for two was exceptional. A perfect "harvest" type of meal. I loved how the bread, currants, arugula, pine nuts and of course the beautifully prepared chicken all came together. Truly unique. The oysters we enjoyed as a first course were wonderful. This is a great find. We sat in the bar area as walk-ins, which is first come, first serve.  The small dining room area looked to be much more comfortable. I will try to make a reservation well in advance next time. This is the only way I think I could improve the experience.
author: Paul R.

description: Food is fantastic but wine is the worst. Bring a bottle and be so happy. Don't pay 60 for a crappy bottle. Buy a nice bottle at the grocery store and pay the 20 dollars to cork it. Will cost you ten less and be so much happier
author: Sean H.

description:
Made a reservation and still waited for 30 minutes before they sat us.  To top it off, the maitre'd was so rude when I asked after 25 minutes of waiting when our table would be ready (had it not been for this, I would've given this place a 4.5 - 5 star).

Nonetheless, the Caeser Salad was incredible!  I wanted to order a second!

I didn't have the chicken, but heard it was incredible (although it takes an hour to cook).

I had the pasta and it was just okay (another reason that this place was not a 5).

The waiter was so interactive with the couple next to us, but was very straightforward with us (which we found odd).  However, he was still friendly.

I would definitely visit again (and definitely will soon!)
author: Eric D.

description: Such hype.  Tried this place twice to make sure I hated it as much as I did.  First the vibe of the place is cool and the pasta that I had there was quite good and the shoestring fries were crispy and salty, so it gets at least three stars.  Everything else was very average.  The much talked about chicken which one has to wait an hour to get and then pay $28 to eat...well, it is slightly better than Costco roasted chicken.  They really dont do much to it other than use lots of salt and roast it fresh for your meal.  I can pretty much get the same thing at costco for $5 and I dont have to wait an hour for it.   Service is slow, so plan to hang out a while and drink.  If that is what you are looking for, this place will do the trick.  Outside of that, I would say pass.
author: Scott C.

description:
OMG OMG OMG my mouth had a DOUBLE RAINBOW Orgasm eating this deliciously crispy-skin-on-the-outside tender-juicy-flavorful-meat-on-the-inside one hour slow cooked roast chicken for two on bread that soaks up its perfectly spiced olive oil and creamy fat. 

The chicken was SO worth the wait and price. The service was excellent. The night I went there was even a jazz pianist on the ground floor which I was able to hear on my table at the second floor facing Market. Major Plus Points for live music to go well with the delicioso food!

LOVE it and CANNOT wait to go back.
author: Jason S.

description: This place was busy and packed. The menu is limited and expensive. There really weren't many items to choose from. I am disappointed by the menu. Since I wasn't that hungry and only wanted to pay $15 I had a pasta that was spaghetti with oil and some vegetables. It was okay. I had a cafe latte too.
author: Denise C.

description: Multi varieties of oysters. Small outside tables for a sunny lunch. Caesar salad a specialty. Restaurant is many years old but always tastes fresh. Great for sitting and chatting
author: mik L.

description:
Zuni Cafe was good!
Came here for my mom's birthday dinner and enjoyed a nice and delicious meal. 
Tried the chicken for two (very tasty. moist, and worth the 1 hour wait!), the steak with polenta (also lots of flavor!), and the shoestring potatoes. The chicken for two is definitely large enough to feed between 2 hungry people and the other portions were reasonable. 
Prices here are $25 and up per person.
Service here was attentive and our waitress was very friendly and helpful.
Restaurant also has a nice simple and casual vibe. Wouldn't mind returning soon.
author: Miss H K.

description: Zuni is great!  They seated us without a reservation right away even though they were pretty busy.  Other servers were helpful and polite when they brought dishes to the table and we requested condiments or other items.  I was not thrilled with my drink The Captain, but we loved the Gimlets and had those instead.  The fries are yummy and my companion and I were all smiles.
author: Shasta S.

description: I think that this place is going downhill.  From some of the newer places that are opening, Zuni doesn't seem as inventive or as tasty anymore.  We shared some oysters.  I love oysters when they have a lot of the natural brine in them, and these were almost dry I thought.  The chicken which took over 1hr to cook was a nice size but the taste was average and it came out "luke warm".  We sat downstairs and almost had to yell at each other to hear, the noise volume was overwhelming.  I do love this place as far as the service, decor, location and the large windows so I hope they make a change at some point to bring it to SF 2013 standards.
author: Mitch A.

description:
quintessential californian cuisine.

i absolutely love the ambience at zuni cafe. bring, sunny with an absolutely intoxicating aroma. it is obviously the wood oven roasted chicken: succulent, smoky, crispy skinned chicken with the amazing bread salad and balsamic to bring the dish together. not lying when i say it is gush worthy. such an sf staple, life will be empty if i visit sf without stopping by.
author: Diana Y.

description:
It's been years since my first visit to Zuni, and its always nice to have a reliable place thats both upscale and casual, for good food and drinks when in San Francisco. Visited this past Saturday night, it was busy as always, but its great people watching while waiting in the bar area.
Ordered differently this time -- two apps -- squid and clams, lentil soup, Zuni caesar, and the duck. Everything was amazing, but their soups really stand out. Did kind of regret not ordering the chicken because it looked and smelled SO amazing, but were too impatient to wait the hour for it. Next time we'll go not as hungry so we can make it through the wait!
author: Amy S.

description: First, if you don't like the heat, definitely don't sit upstairs on a warm day. Mamma mia, it must have been 95 degrees with one fan. My friends were melting. Second, the food is just okay. We had the burratta, which was unusually thick-skinned, and a smaller-than-normal size portion. We also had the Caesar, which was good but not the signature dish I'd expected, and the polenta was...fine. For my main course, I selected the salmon. (I'm TRYING to be healthy...sometimes!) The fish was fine, but this weird 1.5x7" cut that looked like a Lyft mustache. Shockingly, the standout was the okra. Yes, I said okra. No slime, well seasoned, nice cooked. The chocolate granita was also very nice. I only had a bite (see aforementioned health effort) but it was tasty and refreshing.
author: Karen Z.

description:
Food was very good. Great place to celebrate. But service was lacking just a bit. I wan't totally disappointed but I like to be wowed when eating at a place like this ($$) and sadly, I wasn't. I think our server was a little busy because he would disappear for long periods and not check in on us (he did, however suggest some amazing oysters!).  

Shoestring fries were amazing. We didn't try the famous chicken or the famous burger (only available during lunch), but I definitely want to return for both eventually. I had the duck which was flavorful and cooked at the perfect temperature to preserve flavor and texture. Duck dries easily and this was nowhere near that. 

My friend ordered the grilled cheese sandwich. The menu says it comes with grilled onions and tomatoes--which we both actually assumed came *in* the sandwich--but note, they come on the side. 

The desert was phenomenal (it was a fruit and merengue crisp)!

Downstairs, the bar is great. The ambiance of this place is really nice. Low lighting, lots of different nooks and crannies where you can sit. Staff is very friendly. 

Make reservations well in advance if you plan on dining from Thursday through the weekend.
author: Cindy M.

description:
After having the roast chicken, I could not stop saying how delicious it was. I could barely stop myself from picking at the plate, even though I was SO full. 

Lets start at the beginning. Friday night, approximately 530pm after a long hard day at work, and fiancee wants to head out for dinner. He suggests checking open table to get dinner ideas, so that's what I do. As I scroll through the open reservations at around 7pm, I see that Zuni has a lone, open reservation at 7pm. Score! Naturally, Zuni has been on my "to-try" list forever, so I snatch up the reservation faster than I can even ask fiancee if he agrees with my choice. 

Later at the restaurant, we were seated upstairs and automatically put our order in with the hostess for the roast chicken. We ordered 6 oysters and split a cesar salad while we waited for our hour long chicken to roast. Oysters were delicious and recommended by our waiter. The cesar salad was also great, loved the croutons, I usually hate croutons. 

Finally, our roast chicken arrives, probably the best chicken i have ever tasted. Each bite combined with the delicious bread salad. I never thought chicken could taste so good. The atmosphere, food and service were all great, Definitely a must-try at least once.
author: Carolyn K.

description:
The walk to Zuni down Market was pretty sketchy, I'm not gonna lie, even in broad daylight, but Zuni itself was warm open and airy - a little oasis of sorts.

The staff were nice enough, but there was definitely a little bit of a 'tude and it wasn't the most organized of services at Sunday brunch hours.

Decent bread, crispy shoestring fries, very thin crust Margherita pizza that was a shade on the bland side. When they say the famed 7x7 chicken bread salad took an hour, the MEANT an hour. Honestly, I can make that roast chicken, its good but if I can make it, its not THAT good. What is that good is the bread salad - b/c it is _drenched_ in olive oil. This beast can easily feed 4 people as a meal,  but is it a $50 chicken? (Is ANY chicken a $50 chicken???)
author: Snuffles B.

description:
I was so looking forward to dining at Zuni's. How disappointing.  I have to say, I've been there & won't be going back & won't recommend Zuni's to my friends.  The food was mediocre...tasty but nothing to die for & definitely not worth the wait & poor service.   

You can get a better meal somewhere else.  
We had reservations waited more than 30 mins. before being seated when there open tables.  The nice hostess preordered their infamous roast chicken upon our arrival at the restaurant.  But it took 1 1/2 hrs  for the chicken to arrival at the table after we were seated at the table, a whole 2 hrs.  A family was seated at the  table next to ours 15 mins after we did, ordered their chicken & received their chicken before we did.  Now that's doesn't make sense.   The manager was disinterested in our comments which reflects on the lack of service & organization of the restaurant.

San Francisco has so many more wonderful restaurants to patronize & receive the service one expects when dining out.  Bon Appetite!
author: Brenda G.

description:
I'm kind of against reviewing places with more than 1,000 reviews but I just had to put in my 2 cents about Zuni.  Zuni has been such a SF staple that when my friends from out of town suggested it, I really wanted to try it out.

I would say Zuni Cafe is a place I'd recommend going when my grandparents want to take me out in the city.  The food doesn't wow and the offerings aren't new and scary.  It's food they are familiar with. They want to impress you by taking you somewhere nice and fancy and seemingly trendy for SF.  It's huge with different levels of seating and you can get tons of different wines here and there is valet parking so the grandparents aren't left to find street parking and walk around Market Street.

The menu is a little un-inspiring.  There wasn't anything in particular that I had to have.  We didn't order the chicken but our friends did and it was a delicious chicken.  It was moist and the bread salad was very good since it had soaked up the juices form the chicken.  It's just not something I'm dying to wait 1 hour for or split with someone.  Their menu changes every 2 weeks except for the caesar salad and the chicken.  I had the fish dish and it was fine.  Nothing notable to say either way.  My husband had the squab and same thought.  The caesar salad was very good and enough for 2 people to share.  I did like that salad.

The dessert menu was the same, un-inspiring.  We opted for the cheese plate and I have definitely had better.  The cheese was good but the accompaniments were meh.

Service was very attentive and pleasant.  The place wasn't bad, but I'm not dying to ever go back or would I suggest it to someone as a must try in SF.  I would give the food 3 stars overall but the prices for that food have brought this down to 2 stars for me.
author: Mylinh M.

description: Great menu. Creative and unique flavors. Cool decor... Adequate service at best.... Slow. Very Loud. The food is good and worth a visit for something new. Have a lot of time
author: Kimberly R.

description: I came here for dinner, our server was named Matthew. A piece of advice, listen to Matthew's advice he's very helpful and most likely right. Two of us ordered the pine nut tart he suggested having it with the vanilla ice cream rather than the Orange. One got the vanilla and the other person found the Orange too acidic. Very knowledgeable on oysters! Great time had by all.
author: Miryam S.

description:
The food is very good especially brunch on Sundays. But, the service (at least the one woman serving at lunch time on Friday July 3rd) was terrible.  She may be new.  We asked for water without ice but didn't pay attention and served water with ice, we asked for more ketchup but because there was still a little bit left in the tiny dish she didn't feel she needed to bring more pointing out the tiny dish: there is your ketchup!!   I had a question about a dish and she looked at me speechless as in: What is there to explain.  She basically read what was written in the menu.  Didn't she know how it was prepared or didn't she want to bother to describe the preparation?  and we can go on and on.  
Either Zuni does not train people well or she can't stand the job she does.   If I get her next time I will ask to be moved to another table or leave, because she soured the whole lunch experience from beginning to end.
author: Camila W.

description:
This place is an institution. If you talk to anyone who loves food and has been in SF longer than a few months - they've been here and rave about it. I've been here several times since moving back to SF and have yet to be disappointed. 

The food is great, service is friendly and everyone always loves the bars (oyster and the other). 

I personally love the cesar salad here. They make it table side and its all kinds of yum! The burger is also always hits the spot and of course the chicken. I personally thought the chicken was really well executed but I prefer the Roli Roti chicken at the ferry building. That said the order of chicken can easily serve a table of 4 if you have apps as well.
author: Komal B.

description:
The restaurant is conveniently located near Van Ness muni station. It was a quick walk to the restaurant. And the restaurant was super cute! We got a table upstairs in a little corner by an open window which was very nice. We came knowing exactly what we wanted: the one hour chicken, and, to help pass the time, the fries. As soon as we sat down, we asked for the chicken and started the stopwatch. 

The fries WERE an awesome way to pass the time! There was a giant mound of shoestring fries on a nice large plate - they were great! Not too crispy (shoestring fries tend to get burnt if too crispy) and not too soggy. There wasn't any special oil or sauce for the fries, but I kindof preferred it this way - nice and simple. I read in other reviews that the plate was too large - but my friend and I (both small Asian girl types) obliterated the entire plate, and we spent the last 15 minutes of our wait longingly staring (and SIGHING) at the other plates of fries the servers were holding as they passed by us. 

True to promise, I think my time was 1 hour and 3 minutes after we sat down, the chicken came out! And it was good chicken. Very moist and tender. Wish they gave us more bread salad in the chicken. It complemented to chicken very well. But that was kindof all? It was really good, but I don't know about must trying before I die - or even wanting to pay $48 for it again. It was definitely food enough for 2 people, plus. My friend and I had to pack a few chicken pieces home as leftovers. Maybe we overdid it on the fries? 

So with regards to the famous chicken, am I glad to have tried it? Sure. Will I try it again. Nooooope. There were too many other things in the menu that caught my eye, and the chicken wasn't SUPER OMG AMAZING ball of awesome in my mouth - it was just, "pretty good." Plus, overpriced. I think if it was priced more at ~$40, it would be much more satisfactory for the value. 

Overall, I'd rate it a 3.5 stars (based on the fries, it'd be 4 stars, but with the overhyped chicken, I dropped it to 3 stars). 

The roasted chicken and bread salad at Zuni is #2 on the 2012 7x7 100 Big Eats list.
author: Lena Y.

description:
My bf and I came here for dinner a few months ago to celebrate my new job offer.  I had always wanted to try the roasted chicken with warm bread salad.  When we got there, however, we noticed that it takes an hour to cook, and we were too hungry to wait so we ordered burgers instead.  We shared:

*Marinated olives - marinated to perfection w/ citrus infused olive oil
*Miyagi oysters - sweet, succulent, slurp-tastic
*Kumomoto oysters - a little too fishy for my tastes
*12 year aged balsamic vinegar w/ bread - for an extra $1, we got the aged balsamic to dip our bread in, and it's totally worth it.  It's quite pungent, yet sweet
*2 burgers - loved the garlic aoili and bread and the pickles are so unique and amazing here
*Shoestring fries - thin, crunchy, yumssss
*Flourless chocolate cake w/ whipped cream - this was a bit too dry and crumbled everywhere
author: Jen Y.

description:
I write this review with the disappointment of a 1000 Harold Camping followers on May 22, 2011.

After spending more than an hour earlier this week at a restaurant discussing food at another restaurant, I decided to try said restaurant tonight: Zuni Café.

Perhaps my hopes were too high.  Perhaps my expectations were too lofty, but nothing I tasted was fantastic, and one of the dishes - a simple salad - wasn't even good!

My friend and I looked over the menu with curiosity... wondering what 'squab' was and ultimately looking it up and laughing before definitively deciding to pass and keep looking at the other options (upon googling, we found 'squab' to be pigeon, which neither one of us were down to try).  I decided on the quail appetizer with a side of the Caesar salad after being persuaded from my original choice of the arugula salad.  The waiter told me the Caesar was 'a signature at Zuni,' so I figured I would go with the masses.  He tried to tell me that the quail would be too small and that I would want an entrée, but after eating beyond measure for the better part of the last week, I decided less was more and to go with my gut (instead of against it).

When a second waiter brought the quail, I noticed that it was larger than the waiter pitched it as and began to eat.  It didn't look like quail much or even taste like quail much, but it had been awhile since I had quail even so I just thought I was mistaken.  As I started to eat, our original waiter came by the table and apologized:

"I'm sorry, but there was a mix up with your order.  You received the squab entrée." (I could almost FEEL my friend stifling a laugh).   "Don't worry though," he continued. "We won't charge you for it."

I told him it was fine and kept eating. The squab didn't taste so bad after I stopped thinking of flying rats in NYC and started thinking of, well, pigeon. Ok, no... I am trying to make it better with revisionist history. The minute I knew what I was eating, it was harder to eat it.  Pigeon isn't exactly a delicacy in demand around these parts.

I moved on to the Caesar salad thinking it could save me from the awkwardness that became my meal, but was further repelled.  How do you mess us Caesar salad? Much less a 'signature' Caesar Salad?  The dressing was not Caesar in the least and had a bit of a tangy taste.  I thought maybe, just maybe, I was being unfair because I was still disappointed about being fed a flying rat, so I had my friend take a bite without mentioning my thoughts about it.  Her face turned up the same way.  "It's tangy," she complained.  "I know," I commiserated.  I couldn't understand.

The waiter didn't come back for awhile, so I finally flagged down another waiter and asked him to get our waiter.  When he arrived, I told him I was not pleased with the salad (which, save for about three pieces of lettuce, was still completely intact, croutons and all).  Instead of just taking it, he asked me why.  Rude, but fair I supposed.  I replied, informing him it was 'tangy and odd.'  He was kind enough, apologized, and asked if he could get me anything else.  I asked for the original salad I wanted before being persuaded otherwise: the arugula salad.

I wish I could tell you how it was, but I can't.  After another 20 minutes of waiting, my replacement salad still hadn't come and my friend was more than done with her plate... in fact, it had already been cleared away from the table.  I informed the other waiter (since our original was once again M.I.A.)  that I didn't want the replacement salad now because it had taken too long to get it and we were ready to leave. 

The manager stopped by our table about 10 minutes later, apologizing for the issue with the salad.  He was very kind and I told him it was ok, but we just had to get going at this point.  I also told him that my friend enjoyed her meal very much (the pork chops and turnip greens) and that the wine was perfect, so it wasn't all a loss. Pleasant smiles were exchanged and he brought us a bill.

Upon opening it though, I found that we were indeed charged for the quail, even though I never received it and was told the squab/pigeon would be free since it wasn't what I order to begin with. I flagged down the manager again to let him know of the mistake and he said that they only charged for the quail because it was a $13-appetizer and the squab that I received was a $30-entrée.  He tried to pitch getting the WRONG meal as a deal... a meal I laughed at when reading the menu and dismissed as not even a remote possibility.  "No sir, you are mistaken.  That is not what the waiter said," I said.

He took the receipt back and came back with the right one.

We paid and got the hell out of dodge as quickly as possible.  I was honestly embarrassed.  I had picked the place to meet my friend (whom I hadn't seen in 10 years!) and I had raved about all the good things I heard about it.  Once there, all I wanted to do was crawl under the table!
author: Elsa M.

description:
Full review blogged:

At first planning to skip Zuni once again as I simply couldn't justify the price or the portion as a snack and did not want to commit to a full meal it was with great fortune that literally a few weeks before flying out it became known to me that a friend had recently relocated to San Francisco from Boston - a friend, no less, well versed in clean eating and nutrition as it relates to bodybuilding (IE an expert in all the ways to prepare a chicken breast as a source of low fat protein, often at the expense of taste.)

Planning to meet at Zuni around 3:30pm - after brunch but before dinner - reservations were reportedly unnecessary when I called to inquire, yet unfortunately when I arrived at the restaurant just after 3:00 and stepped up to the hostess stand I was told that it would be an hour before we could sit in the dining room but that seating in the front bar was available "immediately."  Slightly confused by this fact given the 3/4 empty space but not wanting to cause a fuss I stated that this arrangement would be "fine" and two steps later I found myself seated at a somewhat shaky table for two where I was greeted by our server, a young and entirely inattentive Hispanic man who dropped off menus and disappeared.

With Jeff running late and myself growing impatient due to the earth-mother next to me making strange requests for meal modifications to fit her children's needs I seized the opportunity to hail our waiter the next time I saw him and requesting a glass of water I inquired as to whether I could place an order for the chicken then and have some bread - a toothsome cold sourdough served with creamy salted butter that I quite enjoyed.

With Jeff arriving moments after our order was placed and pleasantries exchanged our server once again appeared to fill our water glasses and on inquiring as to whether we would like anything while we waited for the chicken a quick perusal of the limited afternoon menu led to the decision of a shared appetizer - the polenta with mascarpone - and a coffee for Jeff...a coffee that would require a second request twenty minutes later.

With conversation flowing our first course of the afternoon would arrive and although simple and rustic it truly was one of the best preparations I've ever tasted with the cornmeal a medium grain and perfectly textured balancing against the creamy mascarpone and just a touch of salt and cracked black pepper.  A veritable bargain at $6 for two large bowls I would recommend this without hesitation.

With the table next to us thankfully clearing out and the service stepping up a notch to keep water and coffee full the arrival of our main course, a dish considered by some to be the #1 "must try" dish in San Francisco, was announced by the hostess first rearranging our silverware to accommodate the plate and then by an aroma somewhere between sweet and savory, vinegar and rosemary, garlic and onion...and utterly enticing.

Described in the menu as "Roasted chicken for two with warm bread salad with scallions, currants, and pine nuts" but invariably more than the sum of its parts enough has been written about Zuni Café's chicken to fill a book, but carrying such a hefty price tag I can only say it is worth the price largely because it redefines any preconceived notions you may have about chicken being boring.  Beginning first with the bird itself-uniformly succulent and wowing you at each turn with its subtleties the crisp skin was nearly shattering and briny yet lacking fattiness and grease while the flesh was so moist I could have been fooled to believe it was sous-vide.  Moving on to the bread salad-at times crispy and others soaked with chicken drippings and olive oil-I absolutely loved the manner in which it augmented the chicken's taste with the sweetness of currants poking through with one bite and then the bitter mustard greens with another all under the veil of occasionally spicy notes of black pepper bringing the marjoram, garlic, and onion to full attention.

Eating slowly as we chatted I first enjoyed a breast, then a leg, and then a thigh plus a substantial amount of the salad before I realized just how big the bird was and taking into consideration my plans for the evening I decided the better part of valor was to stop here-a gesture that provided Jeff with at least lunch and possibly dinner for the following day-and commending us on our effort the hostess collected our plate and returned it to the kitchen for packaging before returning and offering us dessert which we considered but declined and subsequently presenting the bill-a tab that really did not seem all that out of line given the quality and quantity of the food.

Having heard some people complain that Zuni is expensive for what it is; essentially food you could just as easily prepare at home I will note that while this may be true the fact of the matter is that I don't often cook like this at home and when I do it rarely is this good.
author: Michael U.

description:
I had been wanting to go to Zuni for some time but every time I tried to make a reservation they were booked so we made one for pretty early in the evening and were able to get in.  Now I can see why it's so popular.  Everything about Zuni Cafe was great.  The service was good although our waiter was not too talkative, the atmosphere was very open and pleasant and the food was amazing.  

We started with the olives (which had a very nice flavor to it) and the Caesar salad which was large enough to share between the two of us.  I cold have made a meal off of the croûtons alone as they were so tasty.  We wanted to try the chicken for two but we didn't have enough time so instead I got the steak which was excellent and had a very nice sauce on there.

Definitely a great spot and would return in a hearbeat.
author: Blake B.

description:
I'm a man in the Mission. Wait, I mean I'm a man on a mission. Ever since I stumbled upon 7x7's list of The 10 Best Burgers in San Francisco, I've been systematically crossing off places on that list. I have been devouring fancy burgers like a mad man and justifying it by noting, that you know, the patties are made from grass fed beef, thus sustainable and thus good for me and Mother Earth. Guilt free.  

I came for lunch on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. Zuni Cafe is located in an interesting intersection point of San Francisco. If you head north and you are in Hayes Valley, a rather well-to-do and fou-fou neighborhood, but if you head south down Market St. you are entering the danger zone (okay, I exaggerate).

Anyway. The burger here is delicious to say the least. It's definitely not the best I've had in San Francisco, but still worthy enough to be listed as one of the best. For that reason alone I applaud you.

The burger patty, made with grass fed beef obviously, was juicy and delicious. I'm not sure if these are the appropriate adjectives, but the meat was airy and almost "light." I believe the patty is hand made in the sense that they grind their own meat. No, no, no, I don't mean "grind your meat" in a bored and lonely Friday night sort of way, but in a well-crafted, artisan, and do-it-yourself sort of way.

They forgo the traditional burger bun and instead use some sort of spongy type of bread (pardon my lack of bread knowledge). It was an interesting choice, but I would have much preferred the traditional bun.

The burger comes with a side of pickled veggies that are fresh and crisp. I also ordered a side of shoe string potato fries. These were annoying to eat. They are extremely tiny and difficult to grab. They lacked the texture and grab-ability of your traditional steak fries. They reminded me of the fried veggie sticks that you can get at your local convenience store. 

My friend ordered some pizza thing. It wasn't overly memorable, so I don't remember the deets about it. 

Overall, I enjoyed Zuni Café and would definitely come back here. The food is definitely very summer-y. The giant glass windows that surround this place allows your eyes to wander and see the hustle and bustle of Upper Market. Just try not to look southward down Market, you might see something unpleasant..
author: Allan Y.

description: I had the rabbit for Easter dinner. It was delicious! The brick oven really brought out the lavender rub! Super tasty!
author: Caroline L.

description:
Who doesn't love Zuni Cafe? I've been coming here before I moved to SF and I love it. Yes, the roasted chicken with bread salad is as amazing as everyone says it is. I had the burger for the first time this weekend for lunch and it was amazing. Juicy, meaty, focaccia bread...and, the shoestring potato fries were salty thin pieces of sinful carbohydrates!

My boyfriend had the pizza with ricotta salata, tomato sauce, and oregano. It was a bit bland-ish....but regardless, Zuni Cafe is a SF must.
author: Jessica S.

description:
This is a struggle for me because this place has a lot of good points.  My BFF came here after drinks at Hotel Biron because we wanted to get dinner.  We asked the hostess for a table and she said it would be about 20 minutes and she would find us at the bar.  So we had drinks and decided to wait.

Half an hour later we saw two open tables by the bar and just took one.  The hostess never came back, never tried to find us or seat us. 

The waiter was very professional, super friendly and took great care of us.  We ordered the pasta with asparagus and the sea bass.  This is where things go bad, the pasta was very blah, no real flavor and something that I could whip up in 10 minutes, it was also white, and it would have been nice to see whole wheat.  The sea bass was good, very well prepared but for $27 it was tiny.  We already had a cheese plate at a previous stop and had a lot of bread, but we were still hungry after sharing these two dishes.  

So I would recommend to come here for a drink, it has a really nice crowed and there was a guy playing the piano which was a nice touch, but for dinner go somewhere else, it's not worth the price tag.
author: Inga W.

description:
Came for lunch on a Saturday, and overall I was pleased. My particular experience was probably worthy of 3.5 stars, but it has the potential for 5 stars (if I had ordered differently...), so I averaged it out to 4 ish.

The ambiance was lovely, and I loved watching the kitchen buzz while they crafted delicious dishes.

Burger was amazing. Requested it to be "medium" but it was definitely "medium-rare" -- be warned. But it was delicious and the fries were a great addition. 

The pizza was just NOT good. Would not order again.
author: K. D.

description:
***Review is for brunch***

I visited this place with a friend. We were looking for a breakfast spot, but didn't want to wait in the ridiculous lines at other breakfast places and Zuni took reservations. I heard Zuni was good and its been around for almost ever, so why not good it a whirl. 

Firstly, I did my research and saw that their brunch menu had several interesting menu items that I was excited to order. However, when I got there, the menu was quite different and offered 2 actual breakfast dishes that wasn't too exciting. 

I got the scrambled eggs with chives, chicken sausage, and beet salad. Overall, this has been one of the most disappointing dishes I've ever ordered at an "established" restaurant. The eggs were extremely boring, just had chives thrown in there and it was a TINY portion!!! It was literally the size of my palm (and I have medium sized hands!) and I finished it in less than 5-6 bites. The chicken sausage was nothing to get all riled up about. However, the beet salad was good. To top it off it was $16.50!!! Boring eggs, boring sausage, good salad for $16.50??? You got to be kidding me... I ate at Plow a few days ago and I got totally stuffed with the the Plow dish for $14. 

I left hungry and a bit taken a back. I was totally unimpressed with this place. I have heard that their chicken dish at dinner was good, but after having a very uninspiring brunch, I may have to hold off on another visit at Zuni. 

Otherwise, service was whatever, you can tell they hire the crappy servers during lunch time as they didn't give a crap about their jobs and just simply "did their jobs". Overall, I felt a bit ripped off from this place, I had high expectations and for a place that's fairly expensive, I would have expected more.

Do yourself a favor and avoid Zuni for brunch at all costs!
author: Justin L.

description:
Went there last week before a symphony concert. First time I had been there in a few months. I shared the roasted chicken with bread/pepper salad, which was plentiful and tasty. The chicken was dry, though, and the bread salad was greasy. Our appetizers of shaved asparagus and anchovies were well-balanced and very fresh, but the portions were tiny - more on the scale of an appetizer at a restaurant that will be serving you 5-7 courses. Their caesar salad was outstanding, however. The romaine was crisp, the dressing that perfect balance of lemon, creamy and fishy. My friends ordered their fish with beans dish and were pleased with the flavors but felt very hungry still afterward. 

Zuni is a classic, of course, and it's been around forever. Quite, frankly, they seem to have stopped innovating, their renowned top-down quality control has slipped, making their higher prices unjustifiable. I'd rather pay less and go to Bar Tartine, Range, or Gather (in Berkeley).
author: Mike T.

description:
Walk in the door and get a window table by the bar, bang.
Order the 45 minute chicken,  while you wait drink martinis and eat oysters.  Then move this show to a table and feast on the best whole chicken yet.  Rotisserie chicken with perfect spice, croutons that have the drippings from the chicken, seasonal lettuce and some cranberry raisins with a bottle of wine.  Yet another Heavenly experience.  There is a reason places like this never fade.
Daytime burgers, balsamic bloody mary's, and bowls of coffee are "hot".
author: D B.

description:
It doesn't really deserve five stars, more like four and a half, but I rounded up.

Really nice quality food. Cheap? No. If you require cheap, go the Mission for Mexican food or to a small cafe or burger joint.  With cocktails, champagne, appetizers and a dessert dinner was about $70 per person.

The yellow fin tuna was very, very good as was the pork. The sesame encrusted petrale sole was also very good, although perhaps a touch over crusted with the sesame for my taste, but still delicious. The oysters were terrific, fresh, different per selection and the sides were good as well.  I wish I paid more attention to how they prepared the sides as I'd like to replicate it at home.  The Ceaser salad was hand dressed per plate and also very good.

It says clearly on the menu that if you want the roasted chicken (which is purportedly very good but I never tried it) that you'll have to wait for at least an hour. So if you're going to complain about that, you can't read.

Service was attentive without being bothersome.  

Look at the menu (online and perhaps on the door) before you go. If you have specific "food allergies" or require a vegetarian only meal, go someplace else and don't bother make reservations. Perhaps somewhere else can cater to finicky eaters. It isn't very easy to get reservations on busy nights and the tables are needed for people who like a wide variety of food. This place is about high quality, savory food, not frozen peas, gluten free wheat pasta or lentils on arrugula topped with an egg.
