I'm quite impressed with the kitchen's organization, as we had a table where I could watch. 

Again, not really five stars, but four and a half.  Nothing's perfect.
author: Don m.

description: Amazing brunches! Hard to get in since they don't accept reservations.
author: Siavash N.

description:
Meh is actually the best description. Came here for brunch not that long ago to get a feel for the place before deciding if it was worth returning for the famous chicken. I would not return but the bf really wants to try the roast chicken so might return.

The place itself is awesome, it has a great interior and service is great, polite but not imposing. Brunch was boring. The menu was extremely simple and pretentious sounding and it arrived even less impressive than I could have imagined. I got some sort of poached egg dish with chard and it was just that - unflavored chard with a poached egg for $15

The boyfriend got something with parmesan and mushrooms I think and I can't even remember it, I just remember staring at my meal and wanting to get some food afterward. The bread and olive oil pre meal was probably unnecessary for brunch, but I appreciated it as the best part.

Probably would have been a lot happier with oysters than something they would have prepared. I understand simple ingredients but this almost felt like a joke.
author: Sam H.

description: Went for brunch, and was pretty underwhelmed (especially for the price). The menu is booooooring. I ordered scrambled eggs with rabbit sausage, and the sausage (single) was tiny and soggy and weird. The egg was cooked perfectly, but that was pretty much it. The service is good and the space is pretty nice. But the food is just dull. Probably won't go again.
author: Kate H.

description:
Best burrata ever. Best roasted chicken (for two!) ever. Went with a beet salad to start and it was incredibly savory. The enormous pile of shoestring fries are a MUST. It's reputation speaks for itself.

A bit of an older crowd, didn't see any particularly interesting cocktails, decent wine selection but not extensive. Loved the interior and ambiance.

Walked in on a Friday night around 8 with no reservations. 40 min wait for the dining area but we ended up sitting within 5 min at their open table cafe seating near the front.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: I had salmon fish and it was a bit excessive on butter but tasty overall. shoestring potatoes were awesome! their olives are definitely fresh! they were running out of an ingredient for La Vie en Rose drink, but had other good choices on champagne and desert wine. Our waitress was very polite and friendly, just a bit slow (they were busy for dinner) great lively atmosphere
author: Giselle C.

description:
We made our reservation for Valentine's Day dinner exactly one-month in advance (as soon as I knew we'd be in town for this lovely out-to-dinner holiday), and then almost missed it trying to get there!  

Who knew hailing a cab in SF was so bloody difficult on Valentine's Day evening?  Well it is.  

Thank you to the young woman who gave up her cab for us so we could snag our table at the nick of time.  Anyway, we were seated at the chef's table, and were watching the kitchen preparations throughout our meal, which we rather like, the people watchers that we are. 

Of course we had planned in advance for the roast chicken with bread salad, but began with an arugula salad with beets and the ricotta gnocchi with hedgehog mushrooms. 

...and the bread!  The crusty, slightly sourdough bread! Love love love.  

I had enjoyed the chicken prior to this visit, but my boyfriend had not been to Zuni before.  I'm looking over at him now and he says, "it was really effing good,"  when I asked him how to describe his reaction to the meal.  We even took the leftovers on the plane with us the next morning, he was that dedicated to finishing that chicken.  

Everything was lovely that night, we finished with the flourless chocolate cake and the creme brulee.  A perfect end to a perfect night.
author: Suzanne J.

description:
Now I know everyone says the chicken is to die for, but....really.

Have you guys not tried rotisserie chicken from costco?? Costco chicken is just as damn good. 

The only part I have to say I truly loved is the bread salad the chicken rests upon. Very delicious with that and if I could I'd order that alone. As for the chicken itself.. wasn't worth the hour wait or the price.
author: Natassia S.

description: Best chicken, bread salad and Cesar I have ever had!  Our waiter told us that they dry brine the chicken with salt for 24 hours before putting it on the rotisserie; and that the bread is dry toasted in the wood fire oven in big hunks, before being placed under the almost done chicken to soak up the cooking juices...OMG....awesome!
author: Leslie R.

description: The chicken was every bit as good as advertised. This is not your Safeway Select rotisserie chicken. They supposedly brine the chicken for 24 hours before roasting it. The bread salad was tangy, full of delicious chicken drippin's and moist but had a nice crunch all at the same time. What really surprised us was the impeccable service. Our server, Anthony, checked on us every few minutes and even made sure our random requests on OpenTable were satisfied. He also gave us some great recommendations and clued us in that we could order the bread salad without the chicken and skip the 1 hour wait. Although I'm not sure why anyone would go there and not eat the chicken. Well worth the $49.
author: Dan X.

description: Zuni has been around for years. Years ago, Zuni was the "it" place for people watching and solid, simple, decent food and uncomfortable seating. NOW, it's too expensive, not worth it, too simple and the uncomfortable, hard seating remains. The other day, I had the Burger. It was $16.75 and includes nothing. Grilled onions were another $1.75 and my ice tea was $4.75. TOTAL: $23.25 and this was at lunch! With tip, it was almost $30!! If I were to have ordered those shoe string potato's, that would have brought the bill close to $40. Forget it! So many other places exist now for great, affordable food (burgers that include fries for around $12 can be had almost anywhere). I think its time for Zuni to change. Its just not exciting anymore..
author: Superbucky N.

description:
Hubby and I were arguing all the way to the restaurant on whether or not to order the chicken for dinner. First off it was our anniversary dinner - who orders chicken?!? Secondly, according to my fantasy friend Tony Bourdain, chicken is for boring people who don't know what to order. It was only based on the breathless recommendations of our friends, and the excellent salesmanship of our server, that we caved and did it.

It didn't disappoint. The flesh was soft and juicy, the bread was melty with all the chicken fat, the currants were tart and sweet, and the ricotta gnocchi we ordered on the side was re-donk-a-donk delish.

Oh and did I mention the bartenders are great and don't mind being asked to make something like a whisky drink and a margarita had a baby? Yeah, that too.

I do have to take away one star for what seems to be a weird service system. We had 2 separate servers and 3 bussers during our dinner. Between them, the white wine I ordered right when we got seated wasn't delivered till 30 minutes after. The table next to me spilled some water that hit our table, and that took another busser to clean up. And while it says "1 hour to prepare" on the menu, our bird took about an hour and a half. Not bad while you're toasting to your marriage with your hubby, but not ideal in any other circumstance.
author: steve s.

description:
The baked eggs in tomato sauce was pretty good.  Our service was attentive and refilled my water & tea many times.  The hamburger was also good.  Pizza was a little too oily.

I like how sunny the place is.
author: Niniane W.

description:
Stopped in for lunch on a whim, so glad I did.  Food was great, service was amazing.

Started with chickpea soup with orange peel, amazing.  Also had the arugula salad which was also great.  Finished with a ricotta salata pizza, absolutely delicious.  Service was perfection, our server even made my Balsamic Bloody Mary extra spicy for me.  Will come back here next time I'm in town.
author: Kate K.

description: Awesome food, service, atmosphere, and location. I highly recommend this place.  The drinks are tasty, and so is the food! The service is quick and the wait staff is extremely fast and a pleasure to interact with.
author: Julian C.

description:
With over 1,000 reviews, not sure if this place needs another great review, but here goes.

So, you're probably thinking about whether or not you should order the roast chicken? You've read plenty of reviews, and you're not convinced you want to wait the extra time? Do it. There's something very warm, and satisfying about a simple roast chicken, and while Ive made roast chicken plenty of times at home, it doesn't ever quite taste as great as the Zuni Cafe's. It's a must share with the table, and while I've had it before, I look forward to sharing each time I visit. I also had an amazing corn soup with pasilla peppers, and a touch of cream. The soup was just great. I should mention that I am writing this review months after my dinner at Zuni, but I remember this corn soup as if it were yesterday. I've attempted to recreate this soup plenty of times, but Im always missing something...Ill get it one day.

The service was spot on, the location is great with plenty of public transportation access, and the space is unique. Make sure to make a reservation because this place is always bursting at the seams. Even at 10pm, there was a wait for space at the bar. Keep doing what you're doing Zuni, it's awesome!
author: David M.

description:
I didn't hear much about this place until recently, but apparently Zuni is a bit of an SF institution. And now I understand why.

Located in between a fork in the road, Zuni has a really unique layout with lots of little nooks and crannies where you'll find hidden dining rooms behind other hidden dining rooms.

Pretty upscale and classy atmosphere, this place is ideal for both large groups as well as intimate dates.

Service was excellent, and all the dishes we had leading up to the main course were tasty and unique.

The main event is the Roasted Chicken with bread salad. I was initially going to give this place a 4 stars, but I haven't been able to stop thinking about the chicken and bread salad since I left, so now I am upgrading it to 5. The only thing holding this place back from being a full 5.5 is the fact that the menu is pretty limited, and the chicken takes one hour to cook - no shortcuts, no pre-ordering, and no exceptions. But in the end it's worth it, especially if you order some drinks and a few rounds of appetizers to warm up your appetite.
author: Raza M.

description: Our waiter, Steve, went above and beyond the call of duty.  Great restaurant, excellent food and service. Valet parking available and recommended ($12).
author: James F.

description:
It tastes like chicken.

Normally that kind of response means that you'll get an acceptable, but bland, meal. Something that fills your appetite, but not your spiritual soul. 

Unless you're at Zuni.

It tastes like chicken at Zuni means that you are tasting for the first time what chicken SHOULD always taste like. I thought I knew what chicken was until I had the Zuni roast chicken. For the first time, I tasted the pure flavor of chicken. There was nothing else, but the pure essence of the chicken and that's how good it is at Zuni. You don't need anything else but chicken. No lemon. No rosemary. No BBQ sauce. Just pure chicken. So flavorful and evenly moist and tender throughout. No unpure or dry chicken anywhere. 

And as good as the chicken was, the bread salad was even better in my opinion. I could have just gorged on that alone. Crispy and at the same time soaked with the jus from the chicken. The bread, the pine nuts, the currents, and the chicken made for an incredible taste sensation.

The roast chicken (which they say is for two, but would serve four comfortably) was too much for me and my friend for dinner, so I had the chicken cold the next day for lunch. Even cold, the chicken was incredible and still very very moist.
author: Elle P.

description: Five stars for my first experience at Zuni Cafe. Why? One: though we were seated upstairs at a table hard by the waiter station (not prime seating) our server was a friendly and professional as one could hope for. He was always there for menu and wine advice, etc. when we needed him but he was never hovering. Two: the terrific food. We enjoyed a selection of oysters and the Caesar salad. Then, we split the  roast chicken with bread salad and dressed greens. Amazing. Must have hit Zuni at the right day and time (a Thursday at 8pm - with a reservation. Too busy to ever just show up and expect quick seating.) because this was ridiculously good. I'll never be able to eat chicken again without thinking about this bird and its accompanying bread salad. Divine.
author: Jim C.

description: I had Lamp Shank, and must say that is the best Lamp Shank I ever have.  The meat texture is dense but tender.  I think for couples of days over how they did it.  I beleive the lamp Shank was wind dry to keep the texture dense.  Anyway, strong recommend.  This is one of places you don't want to miss in SF.
author: H. L.

description:
ah...Zuni. I really wanted to be impressed (again) by this place, but it, rather, left me hanging.

there were 4 of us, and we tried:

ZUNI ceasar salad: which was probably the best dish we had, quite great.
Polenta: not bad, but not so spectacular either.
Egg sandwich: bland, average.
duck breast: very good

over roasted chicken: for an hour that it takes to cook, definitely a big disappointment. I will tell people to stay away from this and instead tell them to try Dobbs Ferry's (about 3 blocks from Zuni) roast chicken which is cheaper and takes much less time.

the service was great. but what matters the most is the quality of dishes.
author: Sung C.

description:
The Caesar Salad at Zuni's is one of the best I've had in the bay area.  It certainly is one of the most authentic, with real one-piece romaine hearts and copious sardines, along with a caesar dressing that is probably handmade.  The burgers are good, too, if a bit small compared to the competition at similar restaurants in SF.  

Zuni also has a very open, sleek, yet convivial atmosphere.  The patina on the real copper bar is a nice European-feeling touch.  Zuni isn't cheap, but it does represent good, consistent value and I believe it is one of those landmark restaurants that truly help give San Francisco its reputation for food lovers.  It isn't one of those stuffy, very expensive restaurants with monthlong waiting lists.  Instead, it's a place that you can drop in, sit at the large, inviting bar, grab a glass of wine, and casually pick something to eat from the bar menu if you want.   Chances are, whatever you pick is going to be good.
author: Dave N.

description:
The food here is simply amazing. It didn't matter what I was eating, it was delicious. I would definitely recommend the chicken, but the beauty part is that because it take an hour you have plenty of time for drinks and appetizers. The menu seems like it's always changing, but we got a spaghetti and peppers dish that was light and fresh. Even when I told myself to save space for the rest of the meal I kept going back for more. The chicken was great, crispy outside and juicy inside. You would almost swear it was deep fried. Desert was great too, so if you manage to save enough room it's definitely worth it. 

On top of the amazing food, the service was great and the ambiance is pretty cool too.
author: Nick R.

description:
Have been here twice before, last evening was my third.  Zuni never disappoints.

My husband and I didn't have time to order and wait for their famous roast chicken (it takes an hour), but their other menu items -- the gnocchi, mussel tagliatelle, and onion soup -- were sublime.   The service was also very good.
author: Sheri K.

description: Overall excellent meal. Had the Caesar which could have had a touch more acid.  Chicken was excellent and the gnocchi melted in out mouths.
author: I Y.

description: I really wanted to love love love this place.  It has been highly recommended by a foodie who I trust.  As an appetizer i got the crostini, which was pretty much toasted bread with seasoned scrambled eggs and fish roe.  This was actually really great.  The flavors really complimented each other.  Now on to the main course.  I really wanted to try the roasted chicken salad, but it's an hour wait!  I was far too hungry for that, so I opted for the sea bass and muscles.  This dish was pretty good, but it didn't really stand out.  The main thing was that I was still SUPER hungry afterwards.  I wasn't the only one either.  So maybe I ordered the wrong thing, and maybe I'll have to come here again.  Oh and the other let down is the service.  It wasn't bad, but rather non existent.  Our waiter kept on disappearing, and we couldn't find him.  I think we were looking for the waiter for about 20 minutes just to get the check.  Gotta come back again and get the chicken and see if this was just a fluke.
author: Tiffany C.

description: 5 stars for the roasted chicken with bread salad for 2. YUM.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I took advantage of my first day back after a week in Florida visiting with family to remind myself how much I love San Francisco.  I walked a few blocks to Duboce Triangle with the goal of devouring the much-heralded burger at Zuni Cafe. 

Now I had been to Zuni more than 4 years ago and enjoyed some choice, fresh oysters as part of a more traditional meal from their French/Italian menu but I only got word about their prized burger well after that visit.

Sitting down in the sunlight pouring through the large gallery windows of their narrow building alongside Market St, I began to sip on a Grenach-Syrah blend and patiently awaited my burger.  I chose gorgonzola and some grilled onions as my toppings and there were a few others from which to choose but I soon discovered that none were necessary; the burger stood soundly on its own.  The burger is a Mesquite-grilled house-ground chuck on rosemary foccacia with garden lettuce, red onion, aioli, and Zuni pickles.  It was juicy and quite flavorful, and the pungent cheese did nothing but accentuate a tremendous cut of meat and its rich flavor. 

I only had to wait a scant 10 minutes for my burger but I learned later that it had waited 24 hours for me!  That's how long it's pre-seasoned but only with salt, highlighting again the the quality of the organic meat.

I don't recall specifically what I had during that first Zuni outing 4 years back, only that it was good.  But it's moot now because I recommend you go and try the burger first and foremost and don't balk at the $17 price, it's well worth it.
author: Saminda W.

description:
This is my go-to restaurant. 

I've been going to Zuni for more than 15 years and they always deliver a wonderful meal. 

The reason to love this restaurant is the same reasons that you love your visits to Grandmas. It's comfortable, knows exactly what you want, and makes you feel warm and fuzzy every time you leave. 

Below are the must haves when you visit: 

The Chicken - yes, it's chicken. BUT it will be the best and moisted chicken you have ever tasted. The bread salad with the currents and arugula add a wonderful complexity to the dish. 

Caesar Salad- it comes with anchovies, and there is just something about a classic Caesar with just the right amount of dressing making this a classic dish. 

The fries- NO ONE does fries better. Not even those chain restaurants. These fries are skinny so each one is perfectly crisp... OMG! 

I've gotten the oysters and drinks here which are always great. I have never had anything but dependable meals here... and I take comfort in knowing that when I come here... I am in for a reliable treat.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The food is pretty good, but the prices are too high to merit what you get. Also the 4% Healthy SF surcharge is an insult. With prices this high, that 4% ought to pay for a full medical clinic in the building!

The highlight was the oysters. They were pricey but superb. The Caesar salad had great croutons and the dressing had a delicate, satisfying flavor, but there was too much of it and it drowned the lettuce. The ricotta gnocchi tasted a bit like cheese floating around in a butter soup. A small bite was good but it was much too rich for a full dish.

As thousands of other reviewers have noted, the chicken is delicious, as is the bread pudding that comes with it. It's also a heavy dish, so if you want to make it to dessert you'd be wise to stick to oysters for your appetizers!
author: David C.

description:
Zuni was my birthday dinner spot. 

A daily-based menu, semi-industrial atmosphere - sounds charming. The waiter not giving us plates for bread - not so hot. Paying $1.50 for a shot of balsamic for the bread - silly, but ok. Waiter spilling the balsamic all over the table and not replacing it - I'll just nip a star off of your yelp review. I'm allowed to be a little diva... er divo (does that work?) on my birthday.

I had an amazingly flavorful but weak mojito while we waited for our entrees, tasty but so is an iced tea. We ordered the chicken for two, out of incessant recommendations and the couple next to us practically climaxing over their order. It is worth the hour wait, but that makes an expensive hour of drinks, salads, etc. The bread salad and greens with the chicken were a great combination, it was one of the best meals I have had in a long time.

Atmosphere: Happening if you're thirty - loud if you're twenty-one. A few straggling singles at the bar, and I swear I heard "we can just write this off" from at least two tables. Soundtrack: No music, lots of chit chat.

Price: $15+ for entrees

Order: Mojito, shot of balsamic (at least we could have bought a shot of something that could be shot), shoestring fries, chicken for two: $74.87

Crowd: Tommy Bahama fans, thirties-forties women

Try: Roasted chicken for two (of course)

Forget: Getting drunk off of a few mixed drinks here (even on your birthday)
author: Taylor S.

description:
the rabbit salad is pretty delish.
i would say that it was the highlight of my meal.
everyone does seem to get the chicken.

don't get me wrong, the chicken is delish.
it's pretty juicy and maybe a tad salty.
but i don't know if id come again to wait an hour to eat the $48 chicken.
i think the serving size of it can be good for 3 people if you get appetizers.
author: Heejin L.

description:
Oh Zuni, how I adore you. 

Zuni Cafe is awesome and I highly recommend it!  The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because on my last visit, the service was sub par.

Other than that, the ambience is really cool and I love the unique layout of the restaurant.  The food is absolutely amazing.  I love the frisée salad, especially with some freshly ground pepper on top! Yum!  My new obsession is their famous "Chicken for Two" entree, which does take 1 hour to cook.  I recommend placing the chicken order right as you get seated so that they can start it while you decide on appetizers, drinks, etc.  The wait for the roasted chicken is WELL worth it.  It is so tender and cooked to perfection.  It is served with some dandelion greens and bread salad.  The bread is at the bottom of the plate, soaking up all the juices.  In my opinion, that bread was even better than the chicken, or at least equally delicious.  It is one of the best things that I have ever tasted.  Seriously.  It is warm, moist, and just flat-out amazing.  My mouth is watering as I'm writing about it.  Gosh, I haven't even gotten to the desserts yet.  For dessert , get the strawberry shortcake or the almond panna-cotta!
author: Juliana K.

description: Had a fabulous time here. The superb chicken was rivaled only by the charming company
author: Mina A.

description:
Came here for a quick lunch, my parents came out of town, so I thought it might be nice to take them there. No one but tourists seats there, so it just seems appropriate. 

I ordered the soup of the day which came with a poached egg in it. But not only poached egg, but also the egg shell. I don't know if you ever chewed an egg shell to say the least it is not a pleasant experience. I told the waiter about it, and he apologize and replaced my soup in another one. Thank god - the cook that poached the egg in the second soup - already learned how to break eggs without using the egg shell.

We were very surprised to see they did not take this dish of our bill. 

All the rest of  the lunch was simply boring, same old tiered dishes, nothing to tell about. When deserts time came, we decided to try someplace else like Citizen Cake. 

Zuni is clearly pass its glory days, unless you're a dumb tourist, please avoid this place - so many terrific places in San Francisco, why go there?
author: Too M.

description:
Went there with husband for dinner. Was expecting something MUCH better based on the reviews and star ratings. Seating was VERY tight... we were crammed between 2 other couples which made conversation not very private.

The Cesar Salad was so-so. The sea-bass I ordered was slightly dry, and tasted a bit fishy... I was expecting much better quality for that price. It was also a bit too salty for me, with not much flavour. Husband ordered the vegetable gnocchi and was pleased with it.

For Dessert, I liked the the Gateau Victoire, was fluffy and light and tasted very good. Apart from the dessert though, overall I didn't find the taste or quality that good (considering the price.) Saving grace was the service, pleasant servers and the interior was warm and cosy. 

Probably will not go back.
author: M S.

description:
It was surprisingly easy to get a reservation for lunch on a Sunday. We were seated downstairs near one of the doors, so there was lots of natural lighting. It was a rare, sunny, nearly 80 degree day, so all the windows were open, and it was the perfect setting for a relaxing lunch.

A whole roast chicken for 2 seems a bit much for brunch, but it is their signature dish.  Note - it takes almost an hour to get this prepared, since they roast it after you order.  While waiting, I got the got the spring vegetable soup, which is a light green, slightly coarse vegetable purée, which definitely involved some asparagus.  I liked that it wasn't overly creamed nor salted.  

We also got some apertifs, cocktails, and wine while waiting.  They have less commonly seen drinks like Dubonnet blanc.  The mojito was standard, and wines by the glass come with generous pours.

As for the star of the meal, the coveted chicken was everything I had hoped it would be. It was cut up, and the skin was roasted crisp and easy to remove if you'd like.  There was so much flavor without being overly salty, and it was super moist.  The bread salad in the center was too oily for my tastes, but I liked how the pine nuts and currants added to the dish.  Ask for a little cracked pepper, and this is definitely one of the best roast chickens I've ever had.

The server was super attentive despite it being pretty busy.  We also got lucky with free parking right around the corner, since this is a less busy part of Market.

I'd heard about the famous chicken since I was in college, and it was everything it was built up to be.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Is any chicken dish worth $50? 

So I went here for lunch on a Saturday based on so many yelp reviews proclaiming the chicken to be a must try. 

I don't normally order chicken when I dine out. When dining out, I prefer to try complex dishes which I have no hope of producing in my own kitchen. I thought about it for weeks wondering if I should trek all the way into the city to have chicken,  $50 chicken.

I made a reservation and asked for the chicken to be started prior to my arrival. It was a hopeful request which didn't happen. Waited the one hour prep time for the chicken to come out.

Nice presentation. The chicken was really moist. Nice subtle roast flavor. I thought the chicken was food fired?  Didn't get any of that flavor. I didn't really care for the tangy salad dressing.   Overall, I thought it was good chicken, but not worth $50 or the hour wait.  To be fair the dish does easily serve two. 

On another note, I really liked the ambiance. Nice decor. Place is deceptively large inside. Two floors. I'd have no problem going back to dine there. But next time, I'd try a different dish.  Seating is pretty tight. Perhaps not the best place for an intimate date.

Service is very good.

Street parking is challenging.
author: Marshall C.

description: Perfect ambiance for a date night!  The sea bass and quail were amazing, especially the sea bass!
author: E G.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed Zuni before.  Not that I go there a lot.  I've only been twice but I LOVE this place.  

The first time I went I shared the roast chicken special for two.  It was divine goodness.  It came with delicious charred fava beans that were so finger licking good it was stupifying.  This time I had the prosciutto plate starter served with farro, avocado and lettuce greens.  Yum.  Next we had the ricotta gnocchi that my dining partner dubbed pillows from heaven.  I must agree wholeheartedly.  I had a beef filet with a fantastic kale salad and for dessert -- creme brulee perfection.  Oh and my friend had a sampling of oysters that she quite enjoyed.  

This place is great and if it were in LA, I would be hugely fat and broke.
author: Kate M.

description: I came for the burger, which was hailed as one of the best in SF. I have to say it didn't live up to the hype. It was good, but not thaat good. And at $17 (+1.50 for cheese) and $6 for fries (although the fries are clearly meant for 2 people), it's pretty damn expensive. Otherwise, the service was good, and I liked the ambience. Plenty of light comes through the windows, making it a great lunch spot.
author: Jimmy K.

description:
Get the Pork Chop with greens and roasted onion + shoestring potatoes.  Superb. Very nice staff, great atmosphere and a great place for a late morning brunch. 

We were seated right in front of the kitchen and we able to watch as they prepared the food and made the famous $48 1 hour chicken. I was not about to wait that long, so we decided on the pork chops. You will get 1 giant chop plated with a fresh mustard green and olive oil crouton salad. (plus a roasted onion. It looked pretty but I did not touch it). Normally I find it hard to enjoy pork in restaurants because it tends to come out with a really strong gamey flavor, but not at Zuni. High quality white pork meat with a succulent fresh off the grill flavor. (I have been trying to replicate this flavor ever since! I think they brine the meat, so this is maybe why it is so juicy).

I had a white wine while my friend had a kir. I thought the kir could have been better because it did not taste like the kirs we had in France. 

For dessert I had the flour-less chocolate cake and he had the date ice cream with walnut and shortbread cookies. The cake was the winner. Light and flavorful. I needed a glass of milk. 

Nice experience for a high class meal
author: Antoinette C.

description:
What really made me decide to give Zuni 4 stars was their flourless chocolate cake dessert which was rich, decadent and fantastic. 

Our server was....interesting. Everything was either "fantastic" or "delicious". I felt like she was about to break out with a cheer at any given moment. Although to her credit, when my mom severely under-whelmed by the original wine pairing she suggested she handled it beautifully and brought a different wine. 

We had the manilla clams as an appetizer and they were delicious. The broth that comes with them is perfect for dipping the bread in. I had the pork chop as my entree and it was really good. Nothing extraordinary but no complaints either.

I do have to give kudos to the staff. We told them in advance that we were attending the symphony at 7 and they made sure to get us out of the restaraunt in plenty of time to park adn get to our seats.
author: Vanessa J.

description: The roast chicken is delicious -- well-browned skin and tender meat with a certain smokiness. This experience has inspired me at home when I make roast chicken. Now, I often will avoid rosemary and lemons for seasoning, and instead focus on bringing out my chicken's natural flavor through brining. Thank you, Zuni Cafe!
author: Jason P.

description:
Awww yes the roast chicken....some critics and nay sayers may say what's the big deal??? It's just a roasted $5 chicken. Oh how I pity the fool because this is just not the case. If there were a perfect way to have chicken this is it. It is perfectly  seasoned, perfectly cooked, perfect texture and moisture.... I could go on, not to mention the delectable goodness called bread salad served underneath, hmmmmm hmmm good. So what it takes an hour to cook, it is well worth it. Just order a delicious Cesar salad for an appetizer, have some bread, wine, and good conversation and the chicken is at your table before you know it.

If you are ever in the area this is the restaurant to visit, and the roast chicken is the dish to have. Period.
author: Ashley M.

description:
I first ate at Zuni Cafe 3 years ago when a childhood neighbor of mine (TIna) got a job there in the kitchen. First experience was brunch, on a Sunday in March we sat by the window and watched the rain. Tina was off and joined us and as I ate from a bowl of delicious spring pea soup we all shared a nice flat bread wood fired pizza and in checking my flight status a huge blizzard was headed for NY and my flight was cancelled! Thus what was suppose to be a quick brunch turned into a nice leisurely one with a nice tour of some local galleries. 

In 2010 I had the chance to come back and had dinner with 5 other friends. This evening Tina was shoveling coal and turning chickens back in the kitchen. We were able to drag her out for a minute and as her recos - ALL of which were phemonemal! As I cook myself there are a couple of things I never order in restaurants such as roasted chicken and salmon but as we were a large party TIna convinced us to order the whole roasted chicken and who knew currants were such a nice accompaniment to chicken?

Musts for dinner - the roasted chicken, ahi tuna - seared to perfection and oysters from the daily selection. The wine list is incredible and several local brewery beers are listed for those beer lovers dining here. The chocolate mousse served for dessert was so delicious we had to order more. 

A must for every foodie passing through SF and if you don't consider yourself a foodie but if you love eating local and California style cuisine Zuni empitomizes this to the core. Come hungry. Leave happy. And if you're like me and not fortunate enough to live in San Francisco (yet) make sure to pick up a copy of the Zuni cook book - I did :)
author: Michelle T.

description:
What is with all the raves about this place?  It's in a crappy location, the food is overpriced and average at best; and, the staff is snotty.  I have been here three times over the past ten years and the verdict?

1. Disappointed

2. Disappointed

3. Disappointed

Will I ever go again?  No, three strikes your out and Zuni is right off my list.
author: Sean O.

description:
The Zuni Burger.  Classic, traditional, simple and leaves you ruined for any future hamburger that comes your way.

A quartet of friends and I shared a beautiful lunch at Zuni Cafe last weekend.  Not wanting to miss out on the opportunity, we all ordered the famous hamburger.  Some topped theirs with grilled onions, or bleu cheese, or portabello mushrooms ... and some ordered theirs medium rare, well done, or bloody.  

All came out perfectly to our individual tastes.  Our conversation actually stopped with hungry joy.  Our table consisted of "ahhhs" and "ohhhs" and "yummms."  I am positive we looked like ravenous carnivores, but it was well worth the embarrassment.
author: Bridget W.

description:
The first time I came to Zuni, I made the mistake of just dropping in casually for lunch. Unless you want to drop $15-$20 on a burger that is just good, not fantastic, you'd be much better off saving your appetite and coming here for a dinner with your favorite people and loved ones. Zuni is much more of a treat for dinner, and it's where this place truly shines as a San Francisco institution.

Came here for my birthday a few weeks ago with a few friends and had a delightful evening here, thanks to the following dishes: 

pork tenderloin - by far the best dish on the menu. The pork was tender, succulent, and full of flavor.

ahi tuna - well-prepared and great flavor, but wouldn't be on the top of my list when I come back to Zuni.

guinea hen - would you believe me if I told you it tastes like chicken? Well after trying their guinea hen, it'll be a while before I go back to regular old chicken. This dish spoiled me for good!

orechiette/gnocchi pasta - very rich, wonderful pasta with knockout cheeses/sauce

Our server, Brenna, was terrific and very sincerely attentive to our table throughout the evening. Really on top of her game. 

Aside from the amazing food here all around, it's worth a visit just to get a load of the incredible physical space Zuni has. Huge floor-to-ceiling windows and multi-tiered seating areas make the restaurant both visually stunning and intimate at the same time.
author: David P.

description: Love this place so much!  Except the fact that the chicken for two is $48.  When you eat it I suppose it seems worth it, though it's actually enough for 4 (far more reasonable per head)!
author: Patrick S.

description:
I don't need to talk about why Zuni's Yelp score is so high. The chicken's extra moist and the appetizers and other dishes are awesome. 
Unfortunately for me, my experience (not food) wasn't as great as others. 

Few reasons as to why Zuni's one of those "glad-I-tried-it,-but-I-won't-go-back" restaurants: 
- Our Server: He missed one of our appetizer orders, and when we asked about it, he looked at us as if that item didn't even exist on the menu. He then later apologized for the miscommuncation. 

-Not once did he check up on us to see how we were doing fully knowing it's an "hour" wait for the chicken. After our miscommunication and chicken mishap? He came by more than 3 times. even to refill the waters! 

-A table across from us received their chicken first and we were there a good 30 mins before they sat down. Our server explained that the chicken takes 1 hour to cook and that ours went into the oven at 7:15 and that it was 8:16 and "should be out in a bit". He then tells us that since the chicken was in at 7:15 and (looks at his watch) it was 8:16 the "chicken should be ready shortly." 
Despite the fact that I'm Chinese, my math sucks BUT... if it takes an hour for the chicken to cook, why did the other table's chicken only take 45 mins (7:30 seating with chicken out at  8:10)? 

He apologizes for the wait and the miscommunication on the missing appetizer order and gives us shoestring "fun" fries. "They're fun!" 
I hate it when I go to a restaurant and the servers think you're fresh out of college and ignore you until you approach THEM about the status of your entree or correct them on a missing dish. I hate it when they don't check up on you knowing that your entree will take about one hour to cook. He must've passed by us at least 10 times before our main entrees arrived, but not once did he stop by to see if we were alright. I hate it when they apologize and try to send out a "sorry dish" called "fun fries" as if to lighten the mood. Is it an ego thing? Because he was clearly older than us that he can give off this attitude when he served us? I know this isn't some fancy schmancy restaurant, I don't expect GREAT service but some good service would've been nice. 

For some reason, I don't think it's the kitchen/chef's fault even though He said the Chef apologizes.
The FOOD was GOOD... but the service screwed Zuni over. Sorry.  Better off making it yourself, you don't get the crappy service. http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/4401342/ns/today-food/
author: Mare C.

description:
Wow! They have an AMAZING selection of oysters! This place is hands down the best oyster bar I have ever been to and this is saying a lot from the west coast to the east coast. 

Their daily oyster selection is absolutely enormous, but do get there early as they sell out fast on their various selections. I've found that west coast and east coast oysters all tend to taste the same in saltiness but this place has exotic oysters you'll be hard pressed to find anywhere else.

The atmosphere is great and you can typically find a wonderful selection of drinks as well as a good selection of sandwiches and food. I am totally coming back!
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Zuni is coasting....bigtime. The service there is just atrocious. From the front door, to the bar, to the waitstaff...it's just all gone wrong Pete Tong.

9PM reservation. We can barely fit through the front door as there are so many people waiting for tables. Waiting for tables at 9PM? Did you suddenly forget how many tables you can turn over on a Saturday night? Did you accept too many walk-ins? Either way, that's a front office problem right there. You should be fired. After squeezing in, no one asked to take our coats, hats, or umbrellas. We were expected to fend for ourselves. Also, no one asked us if we had a reservation, if we wanted to eat, or even if we were there to rob the place. They just talked with each other, looked at us, and kept talking. Also, we're not dressed like hobos -- so it's not like they were turning their noses up at us. They were just flat out ignoring us. We were told to "wait at the bar" which was a teeming throng of people waiting to get both drinks and a table.

While waiting for our table, a busboy smashed into me, spilling my drink and causing me to drop my hat and gloves. Rather than apologizing, he turned around and asked in broken Spanglish if he did that. He knew damned well that he did that. He walked away without apologizing. At least someone finally realized what was going on and came by to check our coats -- 20 minutes after we had arrived. Better late than never.

We waited some more and during this time, I noticed the staff was "creating" new tables. Spare 2 feet against a wall? Throw a table there with two chairs. Another sign of screwed up reservations. Finally, our table was ready (30 minutes late) and they led us to it through this crazy maze of tight spaces and having to dodge people. When we got to our table, we were like WTF we could have just walked straight up the back stairs.

The waiter knew the headlines about the daily specials, but none of the details. Nor did he know how much they cost. Really dude?

The roasted chicken was good, but it wasn't worth the crap we went through. Telling everyone I know to avoid Zuni; it's merely coasting on previous successes.
author: Richard H.

description: The only reason I gave them a 4 was I thought while the food was excellent and well prepared and very fresh the menu seemed unimaginative and I was underwhelmed. I was sorry that they cannot do the roast chicken for 1 person but that is the rule and the waitress while very nice said the owners had their rules and they never varied from them. I also felt the bus persons were in to much of a hurry and sped around. My waitress was good but I also know that one person is not the same as a table of 6 or 8. The desert was the best part although once again the choices are very limited. As I only get to SF once every 5 years or so I was hoping for a better experience but it was packed.
author: Tom E.

description:
Today was our final lunch before Anna and her husband and their dogs move to Australia.  Rinky and I drove into SF and found a parking spot right behind Anna on Market, a scant block away from the restaurant.  It helps to meet at 11:30.  We walked over and joined a very small milling throng waiting for the door to be opened.  When we were admitted it didn't take long to sort everyone out and to seat us.

The building is a flatiron w/ a bar along the Market Street windows in the first room.  The bartender offered us drinks while we waited but we didn't take him up on it.  There were a few tables by the bar and then more and larger tables in an adjacent room and even more tables in the room after that.  There are stairs behind the hostess stand to a loft-like upstairs dining area.  We were seated in front of the fireplace in the third room.  There were few tables filled when we arrived but they pretty much all filled as we ate.  Ceilings were high and the artwork on the walls was original and attractive.

Service was flawless, friendly and attentive.  We immediately ordered the chicken as we knew it would take about an hour.  Once the chicken was ordered we decided to share an order of shoestring potatoes, one of polenta and one of onion soup.  We were brought a plate of bread w/ butter, crusty, tasty, dense bread that was a pleasure to eat.  I ordered tea and Anna ordered coffee.  Rinky drank water.  My tea was in a small, square metal pot and was refilled w/ water three times.  The tea remained strong and tasty.  The shoestring potatoes were very flavorful, w/ just the right amount of salt, although not all of them were as crisp as they should have been.  A later order being delivered to another table was more uniformly golden.  Ours was like the first waffle.  Not bad, but not the best.  The polenta was thick and comforting, perfect for a rainy day.  The onion soup was light and delicious, w/ lovely, light croutons and thinly sliced onions.  

When the chicken arrived it had been cut into pieces (the leg separated from the thigh, which I liked), atop a bread pudding of the same bread as the croutons in the soup, w/ lightly dressed greens garnishing the chicken.  The chicken was moist and slightly smoky w/ crisp skin.  The bread pudding was light but rich and was flavored w/ some of the salad dressing.  The greens were very tasty.  It was a generous portion (as well it might be for $48) and we had enough for me to take home a box w/ a couple of pieces of chicken, some bread pudding and greens for Alan.  For desert we shared a chocolate pot de creme.  It was rich and smooth, served in a small white ramekin.  It was just the taste we wanted to end our meal.
author: Toni M.

description: The food did not really blow my mind. Teddy waited on us and his service was exceptional. The grub was not crappy by any means, but if it stacked up with Teddy's service, this would have definitely been a five star spot.
author: Vivek N.

description: Yah, they changed the restrooms to be coed!  Go Zuni!
author: Debbie W.

description:
This place was recommended to me. They said it was amazing. So I yelped it. Sounded like the chicken was the way to go. Caesar salad to start and the fries. The Cesar salad was the only dish to crave later. While the chicken was good, it wasn't worth the hour wait. 

Service was great. Atmosphere very cool and relaxed. All in all we wish we tried the other entrees, the duck and sea bass looked great.
author: Diane K.

description: love it! To be honest I have never ordered a full meal here. Zuni is my favorite place to stop in before or after attending an event in the area to grab a glass of champagne or cocktails and some appetizers. A small salad, bowl of periwinkles or plate of sardines, marinated olives, aioli and a tower of shoestring potatoes and our table of four is complete for a mid-afternoon snack. Service is consistently superb.
author: Suzanne R.

description: Prices are very high and the portion sizes are ridiculously tiny. Lots of waiters standing around, it would be better to hire fewer people and serve larger portions. The pizza was plain and uninspiring.
author: Nelly C.

description:
Even if you're not hungry, you should go to hang out at the beautiful bar and people watch. The interior of this place is done so well with every spot fully utilized with tables custom built for every nook and cranny. 
My friend ordered their famous burger and he never put it down after the first bite. I tried the side of pickled onions and zucchinis and they were super yummy. I had the fettuccine pasta with snap peas an although it was a fairly dish, the pasta and all the ingredients blended very well together. 
For a yummy side, don't forget to get the shoestring potatoes which are perfectly crispy and salted. 
To add to their decor, they also have a high stack of chopped wood for their own wood burning stove. 
I highly recommend this place for an easy weekend brunch so you can leisurely enjoy the meal and views.
author: Lanny N.

description: I have been hearing about this place for years and finally got my butt in there!  My boyfriend and I went for a special date and got oysters, gnocchi, and the chicken.  Everything was to die for!!!!!  Even though the chicken is pricey it is enough food for 4 servings, so we had the rest for lunch the next day.  The bread salad is so amazing I wish there was more of it.
author: Julie B.

description: Have been here before but hadn't had the brick chicken with bread salad until tonight. Wow. Super tasty and awesome. Definitely worth the wait to have it cooked. Also enjoyed the tomato salad, and it was the perfect starter before the main meal.
author: Kenton  K.

description: Came here years ago when it first opened and have been back a couple of times since. Had the roast chicken and bread salad then, and we had it again for dinner the other night. Always a winner. It is so hard to find good bread salad and Zuni aces it.
author: Alan R.

description: I only went to Zuni Cafe because it was raining and it was the only restaurant in the area that wasn't fully booked out already for Christmas feasts. This restaurant was surprisingly good! I had a rabbit dish and my friend had a scallop dish. Both dishes were cooked perfectly, and the chefs incorporated a respectable degree of creativity with regards to flavour profiles and presentation. I was expecting a simple meal but was instead greeted with a surprise of gastronomic proportions.
author: Eric Y.

description:
We don't dine here frequently enough !

Always excellent, high quality food.  My one gripe is their burger, which I tried just once; much better burgers at dozens of places in The City !

Get your burger fix at "Tipsy Pig", " Johnny Rockets" etc and order a different really terrific entree
author: Kiyoshi W.

description:
Earlier this month, a dear friend of mine closed on a condo just near Zuni so we met here for brunch. I vacillated between the burger, the creamy polenta, the Caesar salad and the pizza. I probably should have chosen the burger, having sampled its richness in the past and been impressed. But instead I went for the Caesar and the pizza. 

The salad was every bit the tangy indulgence I remember. The pizza, which I hadn't ever ordered, was a bit underdone in the middle (read: soggy). Now, I know I've become a bit of a pizza snob since relocating to New York but sogginess is a quality that ought never to befall pizza, no matter the city. And especially not in a hallowed establishment like Zuni.

Likely, I'll be back but doubtful I'll order the pizza again.
author: Miriam W.

description:
"This chicken tastes like bacon."

I think that aptly summarizes the absolute divine deliciousness of Zuni's "chicken for two roasted in a brick oven; warm bread salad with red mustard greens, scallions, currants and pine nuts." 

The approximately one hour wait for this dish is beyond worth it. 

I could wax poetic about the white beans, the prosciutto, the AMAZING caesar salad...but Zuni gets 5 stars in my book for the best chicken I've probably ever had -- certainly in this country. Juicy and tender, the flavor is out of this world. And the bread salad that comes with it is the perfect complement, especially with the currants and pine nuts.

For chicken lovers, Zuni's a must. And it will convert all non-chicken lovers into believers.
author: Julie E.

description:
I got lured in here by the smell. So good. Sooooo goooood. Head spinningly nice smells. It was a long time ago, so I can't say much about the specifics. All I can say is that this place had the tastiest burger I remember ever eating. Ever. It was so gourmet. I ended up having to eat it with a fork and knife, which I think is sort of a slight against the burger-form, but I don't care.

Definitely want to go back here when I am filthy rich.
author: Sasha W.

description:
Have been three different times, because many folks that I know rave about this place and I figured that it must be me that isn't getting it. I just don't get what all of the hype is about. Meh.

I have had much, much better and not a lot worse.

There is street parking (metered) available and there are some parking lots as well.
author: S M.

description: Their reputation is good for a reason. I've been here several times, and have yet to be disappointed. Service had always been great, and the food is always done well...never feels like they've just shoved something out of the kitchen just to get orders out on a busy night. Especially if you are going to visit the symphony or SF jazz, it's a perfect spot.
author: Garrett B.

description:
Finally, I can say I've tried the chicken at Zuni Cafe. It was good, but not as good as it's hyped up to be.

I didn't realize the place was so big with an upstairs and divided into nice sections. It almost felt like we had our own private room with tasteful artwork all around. Great oyster and wine selections. Service was excellent and very professional.

- Fried Quail: excellent flavor, tender, stingy with the portion, the accompanying salad was not that exciting
- Oysters: wide selection, Marin Miyagi's are good & sweet, pass on the Sister Point ones if you don't like anything too "fishy"

- Chicken for 2: the famous chicken, oh how i've waited too long to try. it was really good, but i've had better. MUCH better. it tastes similar to the chinese style "white cut chicken" but flavored slightly different. the outer layer of the chicken is somewhat flavored but the middle lacked any at all. yes, it's good, don't get me wrong, but i expected more. the breast was dry and i personally enjoyed the quail more than the chicken.

the bread pudding was good too. i wish the chicken dish came with more sides like veggies. they should really serve it in half portions too. a whole chicken can feed 4 people if you order oysters or appetizers.

I think for this place, trying the chicken once is good enough, but I don't think it's anything to drool over or come back for. I will probably come back to try their burgers and other items. In the end, overall great experience, despite the disappointment with the famous chicken.
author: Linda C.

description:
A very disappointing experience.  After reading rave reviews about the chicken my  husband ,who is a chicken fanatic made a reservation for lunch. 
The restaurant is charming, although the location is less than desirable.
The waiter was pleasant and attentive.
Now as far as the food - the cost for a roasted chicken for 2 is OUTRAGEOUS, not to mention the one hour wait for a meal that arrived    At room temperature. The taste was less than impressive than the presentation, very salty and dry.
author: Pamela N.

description:
4.5 stars. Helen T. brought me here for a birthday dinner. for quite some time we'd been anticipating eating the famous roasted chicken and bread salad on the "7x7 100 things you must eat before you die." but really, how good could a roast chicken taste? Costco and Pak N Save have pretty tasty chickens for somewhere between $5-$7, so to inflate the cost of a chicken ten fold seems a tad bit extreme. in order to not over hype the chicken and shatter our visions of the most amazing chicken we were supposedly going to eat, we kept demoting the chicken so that when we ate it we wouldn't be disappointed. exchanges like "i'm glad you're a great conversationalist because this chicken we're going to eat is probably going to be horrible," and "this is going to be the worst meal of our lives!" 

and finally one stormy day we were going to eat chicken and either be very pleased or super disappointed. and very pleased we were! the chicken was perfectly crisp and seasoned. every piece i had was still juicy (except we didn't eat the breast so who knows) and flavorful. still, i'd rather pay $5 for a decent chicken than $50 for a very good chicken. but......

but the shining star was the bread salad. chewy and crispy all at the same time. buttery (more like olive oily and chicken drippings-y) and tossed with a nice vinegarette. it was my favorite part of dinner. over the past few weeks i've found that my mind wanders back to the day where the bread salad and i first met and my hopes of revisiting heighten. if i could order the bread salad on it's own, i would. but i don't think that's an option and i don't know when i'd be willing to pay $50 so that i could get to eat revamped and incredibly amazing tasty stale bread again. le sigh. 

---THANKS HELEN!!!!
author: Regina C.

description:
I know they're known for their chicken, but I honestly think their burger is one of the best in the City. Not sure where it's sourced, but it's phenomenal. Doesn't hurt that it's served on focaccia. 

And the feeling of a French cafe really does come through. I actually prefer Zuni for lunch over dinner...just my 2 cents.
author: Scott N.

description: The bread was cold and didn't quite taste fresh. The squid stew left a bitter taste in my mouth. The chicken was incredibly tender, but the fatty chewy skin and the overly greasy bead salad left much to be desired.
author: Amin S.

description:
Zuni's day has come and gone. Don't waste your time. I've been here many times, mostly because it's close and always has room for large groups at the last minute. There is a reason for that. The food is expensive and unimaginative. If I still lived in Kansas I'm sure I would think it was great but it is not on the standard of SF's many fine establishments.

Food: Chicken is hit and miss and  can be good, but who wants to eat chicken anyway? Other options are not enough to keep you coming back.

Service: horrible. The wait staff always seems to leave you hanging halfway through your meal. The manager is a troll and it permeates down through the organization. I once had aps, salads and entrees all arrive at the same time. Who does that? On another occasion I was unable to order wine until after I finished my aps.

Ambiance is ok on the inside, the bar area forces people to stand On top of one another. Bad neighborhood, no where to park.

In short, if you want to go somewhere that will be rude to you, serve you sub par uninspired food, then forget about you and overcharge for the experience, this is your spot.
author: Christian Z.

description:
Wear hearing protection:

First, I must admit that the food is very good.  However, if you expect to be able to carry on a conversation with the people you're dining with, forget it.  Especially, if you're seated upstairs.  The noise level is unbelievable.  Of course, since it's loud, everyone shouts to be heard and that makes it worse.  While the food is good, the noise level makes it difficult to enjoy.  The best thing is when you leave and the door closes behind you, the quiet is truly a pleasure.  

There are other restaurants with good food and where the owners have designed the space with sound absorbing details so that you can actually have a conversation while you're eating.  There's no need to put up with the discomfort at the Zuni.
author: Dan F.

description:
We had a sadly disappointing dinner at Zuni two nights ago.  It's got a great location and ambiance, and we've enjoyed many tasty meals there over the years, but our recent dinner was mediocre, overpriced, and had small portions to boot.  The hanger steak was sliced into small pieces and was somewhat dry and tough, though the peppery oil and chimichurri sauce helped moisten it.  The mahi mahi was good but not great, and for entrees that cost $28-32, we should get a much better experience.  The salad and gnocchi we started with were fine but not memorable.  I left feeling hungry and had to eat some more at home to fill up; that should not happen after a $165 dinner for two, including three glasses of wine.

On the plus side, our server was friendly and professional, answered our questions about the dishes well, and suggested some excellent wines by the glass to go with both courses.

Based on this meal, Zuni has really gone downhill of late.  I hope they pull it together soon and get back to the level of excellence they used to attain.
author: Chris B.

description: Totes adorbs this restaurant! Make a reservation and arrive early so you can enjoy a cocktail at the lively bar before you sit. I love standing at the counter watching the foot traffic on Market street. It's the perfect date spot. You can order a couple of sides and one entree to share but you also must get the chicken. It is their specialty. I make the chicken at home. The recipe is in the their cookbook and on their website. Key ingredient = salt. :) The restaurant has a weird layout so you have to make sure to get the right table for you. I always ask to be seated in a cozy space where I can see the action. Zuni has a great buzz. That's what I really enjoy about it. Well, that and the tasty food and drink of course.
author: Kelly C.

description:
Great atmosphere, upscale-casual, great ambiance, interesting space with hidden spaces and multiple levels.

Chicken was amazing, great oysters -incredibly fresh with a lot of depth.  The salmon was okay.

I decided to dock a star because our server was in general very nice, but was a tad rude and let's not mince words...'bitchy'.  For some context my buddy doesnt eat pork/bacon and the salmon dish is peppered with it - he simply asked for it to be removed.  Anyhow, our server gave out this sigh and then said..."well thats a shame, bacon is so good...are you sure...you're really missing out".  Yes asshole, he is sure.  Take the order and move on.

It was just a bit of awkwardness that could have been avoided.   Anyhow, the food was really good and the server was great the rest of the time. Not a reason to skip this gem.
author: Aasim K.

description: 3 3/4 stars -- Arrived at 5:30pm which is an off time for Zuni.  In between lunch and dinner and it takes 1 hour after ordering to receive a chicken.  Service was very good and the salad I had was beautifully done, but the lunch menu didn't have many choices.  Parking is really really tough in this neighborhood so I ended up using the valet which costs $12.
author: Lalu B.

description:
Simple food, more appropriate size portions that you may get other places.  The flavors were fantastic, pricing was descent.  The ricotta pizza was shockingly good considering when it comes out you think "where is the cheese?".  

With all of the other options in the city, would likely not come back.
author: Scott S.

description:
Overall experience was great.

Service was by far the best service I've received in a long time!  


Our hostesses and waitress were welcoming, friendly, and proactive.  

Hostess:
The hostess helped us placed our chicken order in advance (1 hour cook time) and proactively confirmed that it had been taken care of.  She also actively came to the bar to give us updates, and to take us to our seats.  I didn't have to check in nor did we have to listen for our name to be called. 

Waitress:  (Anna Kendrick look-a-like)
She checked in with us throughout our meal, but wasn't hovering ... and didn't show annoyance when I requested the menu several times to order more drinks.  (I admit, that's a little annoying.)  She had good menu suggestions, but didn't try to sell us on anything.  

What stood out is ... we had ordered the polenta (I recommend) and it came out before the roasted chicken we had ordered.  Once she realized we were waiting to eat the polenta and chicken together, she brought out a fresh order so that it would be hot with our chicken.

Chicken was pretty damn good ... but in retrospect, you have to wonder if any chicken meal is worth $48?

Still, the food and service was great. 

They also get credit for ambiance/environment.  Overall, one of the best SF dining experiences.
author: Good U.

description: Quite a cute location, you almost feel as though you are somewhere else, besides Market St, San Francisco.  The oyster list had many options (which is rare) and the oysters themselves were perfect...so fresh.  The service was not as good as I would have expected.  The menu doesn't cater to those of us that lean vegetarian.  Therefor, I decided on oysters and a salad, and where both were good, I would probably not go back.  Dessert was small, although good and despite having brought one bottle of wine and only purchased one other for dinner - dinner was so absurdly expensive which I can only equivocate to did not get what I paid for. I would go somewhere else.
author: Jenn D.

description: I have been coming to the Zuni for decades but this was the first time since the chef/owner passed away  We had dinner last Thursday at the Zuni Cafe and it was disappointing. The service was dreadful and we should have not had to wait so long for drinks. The Chicken which takes an hour to cook was not worth the wait. I have had much better chicken elsewhere.  The quality of the food is no longer there and the zuni had lost its edge.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
Grab a friend and order the famous "Zuni Chicken with Bread Salad." The well-seasoned, juicy, crispy-skinned chicken is the best of the best, and the toasted chunks of bread tossed with red wine vinegar, mustard greens, and currents provide zing, spice, and substance. It's mind-blowing. 

For those who balk at the price ($48!), note that the dish serves two, which makes this feat of culinary genius no more expensive than other entrees. 

Their hamburger is pretty delicious, although not exceptionally so.
author: Monica S.

description:
Wow...wow...I have always loved ZUNI - for more than 20 years!  I had my damn wedding here...but after a recent dinner - doubt I will go back. 

OK waiters - if you can't remember things, it's ok to write notes down.  Our waiter "took it all in " for the two of us ...then smiled knowingly...and EVERYTHING was dead wrong - dishes, temperature, beverages.... REALLY??   And when we finally got the correct EXPENSIVE  salad it was so tiny that we both snickered (and we do not care for large portions.). Oh and another blow --  the tea...the waiter brought coffee to me for tea - then he insisted it was tea. LOL.  Ok - there can always be a disaster meal in good restaurants - it just happens. But this was EVERYTHING - I forgot to mention one slice of bread for 2 people.

AND THEN -  READY??  -  a 4% surcharge? A 4% SURCHARGE !!  As we now have ( Thank God) a national healthcare system, this seems ridiculously high - even at the standard SF norm of 1.6% - ask about the legality of this folks - federal health care AND city health care (someone is benefitting and it is not the hospitals or doctors)  I called ZUNI about this and they said since their prices don't go up it covers much...but your prices have gone up, probably more than most other restaurants we frequent.  Really, Zuni?
author: Richard H.

description:
we arrived on time for a 6:30 reservation on a tuesday night even though traffic on gough was RE-DIC-U-LUSS. the taxi driver kept going over to the leftmost lane knowing he would eventually have to make a turn at market but dude you don't have to do it a mile away.

as you can see i gave zuni four stars so let's get the unpleasantness out of the way first. we were seated at a nice table on the main dining floor. got all comfortable, ordered the chicken right away, bread was brought out and then i put a little weight on the table and it rocked big time. i don't mean a wobble, i mean it seesawed back and forth. our as of yet unopened bottle of wine almost fell off of the table. to make a long story short the waiter made two unsuccessful attempts to correct the situation and we moved to another table. this one was a banquette in a small room on the second floor with the backrest being a rough brick wall. very uncomfortable and the whole rhythm of the meal was messed up. strike one.

now let's talk stemware. when the server opened our bottle of wine i asked for red wine glasses and was told that zuni only has one type of wine glass. the glasses are  relatively small, heavy, squat, clumsy; the kind of glass you'd expect to find in north korea or in moscow during the cold war. granted zuni is a cafe but... strike two.

knowing we had a lot of time to kill before the chicken was ready we ordered the house-cured anchovies, fried peppers and half a dozen oysters. all of it was good. the best being the oysters.

we brought our own wine, a '11 linne calodo "problem child". what a terrific wine. primarily a zin but with some syrah and a touch of mourvedre. great balance with a silky mouth feel. paso robles is blowing up with some great wine makers making innovative red blends and matt trevisan is one of the ones leading the charge. if you're ever in paso, linne calodo has a cool, appointment only tasting room. unfortunately their wines sellout quickly and they have a very limited selection available from their portfolio. if you want to try their stuff: get on their mailing list. corkage was $20.

now... the chicken. just like you don't go to a steak house and order the fish or go to ihop and order a burrito, you don't go to zuni and order anything other than the chicken. they've been making it close  to thirty years. an example of the "lindy effect". juicy, flavorful served on a bed of "bread salad" and topped with some greens moist with a tangy vinaigrette. i told my wife the chicken could use just a little more salt and she looked at me like i was crazy. it was delicious.

we concluded the meal by sharing the gateau victoire and a couple of cocktails. i'm starting to really enjoy having a cocktail with dessert. in this case we had the "lido" and the "dark and stormy". all was good not great.

service was friendly with no complaints.

adding to the convivial atmosphere was a couple celebrating their anniversary at an adjoining table. we couldn't resist sending over a couple of glasses of champagne. guys: salute!

all's well that ends well.
author: Sanil S.

description:
Food and drinks:
- Cocktails and wine were very good.  One cocktail was nicely customized as requested.
- Caesar salad was disappointing.  Too much dressing left the salad tasting drowned.  Two of our party who had eaten there multiple times previously said that it was not so previously.
- Lamb with sausage was good.  Not great, but good.  Sausage was a bit bland.
- Pork was somewhat better than the lamb.
- Fish was good.
- Dessert and coffee were very good.

Service:
- When present it was fine.  Unfortunately we were left waiting several times to order, for water, and when we wanted to request the check.

Atmosphere:
- We sat in an alcove upstairs.  Nice decor.  Not quiet but not too noisy either.

Bottom line, though it did not live up to the hype, it was an enjoyable meal.  Was it worth the price?  Maybe not.  I think if the price were lower, I might have assigned four stars instead of three.  But though far from perfect, we enjoyed the evening.
author: R B.

description: My husband and I went there for the first time to meet up with couple of friends from out of town. The restaurant was highly recommended by a co worker. Of course we made a reservation.  Our overall experience were okay, not impressive!! We tried their famous chicken for two. Definitely a well roasted chicken. Very moist!!  However, the bread salad mixed in the plate was too hard for me.  I think it was over price.  It's good but not all much better than a rotisserie chicken you can get at Costco. Which I believed it's only 6-7 bucks at Costco. We ordered oysters, shrimps, clams as well. The oysters were fresh. The shrimp with head were not really up to par. The shrimp came out little over cook. I think if they left the head and d-shell the shrimp will be better.   I think the overall food quality compare to the price they charged is over rated.  They really need to impress me if they charge that much. I don't think their plating is all that nice either. They are on the sloppy end.  I have been to other restaurants with the same price range and their food were like art. Also their service sux!!  The bartender was rude. She taken our order halfway and walked off.   We then saw her taking order from other people.  When we mentioned to her that she haven't finish taking our order she said to us that well everyone here wants to order from me you just have to wait.  Just plain rude!! Anyways maybe I'm being little picky this time but I am just not impress with the restaurant at all.  If they bring the price little lower and their service little better maybe I can rate them better.
author: Becky K.

description: Nothing special. Caesar salad is okay, good dressing, large size croutons. The kitchen managed to undercooked Orecchiette. Bowl of polenta is bland. Sablefish is quite good. We were sitting upstairs in the corner and the area got really warm even with all open windows. Deep fried burrata is probably the best dish, but hey, anything deep fried is always good.
author: Cafee B.

description: One of THOSE restaurants... you know, overpriced and underserved... portions that is! I left there still hungry. Luckily it was lunch on the boss, so a free meal for me, YAY! I do want to try their infamous chicken that takes 45min to prepare... maybe one day.
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Disappointed.

I have fond memories of Zuni from many years ago, so I decided to celebrate my birthday there this year.  It will be my last time.

Food
The food was good.  Not great or memorable, but good.  Were the teeny tiny portions worth the price? Nope.

Service
We were met by the hostess who was either A) a lobotomized deaf-mute or B) the least friendly person on the planet.  I'm pretty sure it's option B.  Try and crack a smile or utter a word next time.
The pace of the service was similar to the lunch rush during "all you can eat shrimp month" at Red lobster.  Clearly we were taking up valuable real estate and we needed to get F--- out so they could overcharge their next patrons.

Sorry for the 2 stars Mr. Zuni, but I am sincerely disappointed by a place I used to hold in such high regard.
author: Edward R.

description:
We had a wonderful dining experience on a Thursday night with another couple. 

I would definitely return for their roast chicken. (Note that it takes up to an hour, but it's worth the wait, not to mention they have wonderful starters, like fresh oysters and seasonal salads.)

The service was welcoming and attentive. We enjoyed our meal and were able to catch up with our out-of-town guests at a comfortable pace.

The atmosphere was pleasant and not too noisy.
author: Amanda M. C.

description:
and id like to present my 100th review tooooooo..... 
ZUNI CAFE 

hands down, (for the time being), the most amazing burger in SF!!! 

after strolling through hayes valley, we stopped into zuni for a late lunch... i highly suggest reservations, we were a walk in around 1pm and the wait for 2 was 45 min, but it was closer to over an hour. 

its ok... just hang out at the bar, (that is if you can push in some elbow room), and drink their very smooth bloody mary!!! 

the apps: 

house cured anchovies... very nice...not overly salty as one would think... complimented with parmigiano, celery slivers and olives 

prosciutto crostini.. . ab-fab!!! ... simple and full of wonderful aromatics 

...and drum roll please!!!! 

THE ZUNI BURGER.... 

this has now topped the charts for the best hamburger in SF...YES I SAID "THE BEST!!!" ... there is no way to describe the simple complexities that your taste buds will be over joyed with... i mean, most people think..WTF a burger??? ...youve tried one, youve had them all, but this statement couldnt be father from the truth... a combo of fun textures, sweet and sour and juicy... its like the everlasting gobstopper of burgers!!! 

.. yes, the wait is long, and sorry this place isnt about trying to impress you with crazy imported games or meats... simple delicious comfort foods that have been tested over time... next time im going to try the 1 r wait roasted chicken... 

cheers to Judy Rodgers for her amazing simplicities
author: Nic M.

description:
Just, wow.  Service was wonderful - the server was friendly and helpful.  Drinks were great, mussels were OUT OF THIS WORLD.  Seriously, I actually said "oh my god!" when I popped the first (and second and third) in my mouth.  They were that amazing.  The caesar salad is meh, but not BAD, just not nearly as amazing as everything else.  I know, I keep saying amazing, but believe me, when it comes to amazing, nothing topped the ridiculously juicy, freshly roasted, perfectly seasoned chicken.  Wait, I'm wrong. The bread salad it sat on had us digging it out from underneath, wanting more and more! 

Best part? There was plenty left over (we were STUFFED!), and I got to have some for lunch the next day, which also reminded my of my awesome date that night.  YAY!
author: Jennifer L.

description: Didn't know chicken could taste so good. Takes forever but well worth it.
author: Robbie N.

description: Went for brunch - great space, great service.  I wanted more egg options, otherwise very good.  Meringue dessert with pistachios was awesome.
author: Lizzie R.

description: So after all these years my friend and I hit up the world famous Zuni Cafe. I couldn't believe how noisy and crowded it was for a Tuesday night!. While the bartenders and servers were professional, the food and drinks are way overpriced. Three "specialty" cocktails ran me $36 and most of the dinners were upwards of $30. We shared the gnocchi and a salad. Portions were small on both. The roast chicken looked good and is probably the best deal. Frankly, the portions are not worth it. I could have had twice the food at half the price somewhere else.
author: Maria C.

description: Good drinks. We had scallops and pork entre. Scallops were tasty and a small portion. Wouldn't order these again. Pork did not have much taste. I had to send my very cold dish back to kitchen to have a slightly heated dish returned. Wouldn't order these again. Bottom line drinks ok, food is sub-par and overpriced for what we had.
author: Dennis C.

description:
Open later was a plus.
Good wine selection
Had a little bit of everything
Service was prompt and unobtrusive.
author: Numa R.

description:
I took my friend here for dinner last night, and I was definitely disappointed.  

My waiter was supernice and knowledgeable about the menu and wines, but the service was not spot-on.  First we ordered a round of drinks.  She had a Hendricks martini, and I asked for a gin and tonic.
