Waiter didn't ask my preference of gin, which was strange, and I should have told him, but I plum forgot, and I ended up with a (regular, not Sapphire) Bombay gin and tonic, which was not my choice of gin at all...!  We thought about ordering the chicken for two dish, but decided against it, because we don't come out that much, so separate entrees seemed to provide more variety.

We ordered a starter of a yellowfin tuna confit, which turned out to be incorporated into a pasta dish.  It was tasty, but my pasta was definitely a little undercooked.  I wanted to eat it, but unfortunately I had to send it back.  I hate sending stuff back to the kitchen.  If I can suck it up and eat it, then I will, but it was practically bone dry in the middle and could not pass for al dente.

We had the Blue Nose Bass for the next course.  The caper sauce was delicious, as was the grilled cabbage. Then following that, we had the Pork and the bread salad on the side.  Both dishes were good, but not outstanding.  

To be honest, I really really wanted to like Zuni.  I've been reading reviews about their famed burgers, but the experience as a whole fell short.  The ambience was wonderful.  Beautiful building, artwork, layout of the dining area, great lighting.  I loved how the waiter suggested we course the meal and how they split all the dishes for us.  Friends of mine who like Zuni tell me when it's good, it's REALLY good, but it is not consistently good.  For the amount of money I spent, I'd go to Boulevard, where dinner is impeccable every single time.  I would maybe come back for lunch to try their burger.
author: Sandy T.

description:
For years I've been referring people to Zuni, saying that trendy restos will be here one day, gone the next, but you can always get a reliably good meal at Zuni. 
After a recent visit, I think I'll stop. Their signature chicken dish (oh that term sounds tired, like a Food Network toss away) was so oversalinated it was almost inedible. And I'm a proponent of brining and a fan of the salt...I salt, then salt again. So if I say it was too salty, listen up. 
The complete highlight was the raw seafood platter which was out of this world, so yes, of course I'd go again for oysters and whatnot. 

I just wouldn't tell others to go and expect a brilliant turn out of every dish, and it's too much trouble to get specific on what to order and what to avoid. They forget anyway and you're to blame...
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Burgers. Chicken & Bread. Amazing Wine & Cocktails.  Can I have this everyday? Thank you.
author: Cherlyn M.

description:
Talk about a perfect evening: Quaint, cozy, classy, romantic, and delicious.

We sat on the second level by the window, ordered a bottle of wine and shared the arugula salad, the burrata appetizer and the roasted chicken for two. 

The burrata was one of the best I've had - that's saying lot  considering I've been ordering burrata at every restaurant that has it (most recently, Prospect, A16, Piazza, Metro). This one was a 100% better than Prospect's burrata- the mozzarella was noticeably fresh and creamy.

The arugula salad was standard in that it wasn't particularly unique or special. But that's not to say, it wasn't full of high-quality, fresh ingredients that totally hit the spot.

I'm glad I listened to yelp for our entree choice: The chicken for two (which really could've been chicken for three or four) - was as amazing as everyone said. It totally lived up to expectations.

The service was great- everyone was attentive, respectful, and knowledgable.

All around wonderful evening - Zuni Cafe for the win.
author: Kimya P.

description:
Finally! I made it here after all these years living in the city. Luckily, the weather was bright and sunny which only enhanced the stylish modern interior. I got the famous burger and fries and Aimee I. got some fish dish with potatoes. The burger was juicy and I actually liked it on the focaccia, but the fries were disappointing (like others had mentioned here). Her fish dish was flaky and flavorful though.
For dessert, the peach and raspberry tart with ice cream was fresh and perfect for the warm summer day.

In the end, however, I have to give Zuni 3.5 stars. The food is great (except for the fries), the service was excellent, and the atmosphere is one of the best in the city, but it didn't seem like much of a value. I don't mind spending money on a good meal whenever I have the extra cash, but a $70 lunch (before tip) including dessert, no alchohol, and one meal being a burger and fries is pretty steep. They charged a bunch extra for the grilled onions and tomoatoes - not too cool.

I'd like to come back for dinner one of these days and try other items on the menu. I'm sure I'll be more impressed but for now, I was a little underwhelmed.
author: Art O.

description:
The chicken here is 'out-of-this-world' delicious. It may look like the most boring item on the menu -- but I assure you -- it isn't. It does take 45 minutes to get the aforementioned chicken, but I assure you, it's well worth the wait. 

While you wait, check out the Oyster Bar. My recommendations: Hog's Island, and Drake's Bay -- and surprisingly their Caesar salad is pretty damn delicious as well.

TL;DR -- Get the boring items on the menu: caesar salad and the roasted chicken. They'll blow your mind.
author: Gabriel S.

description:
Still my favorite place in the city. Consistently delicious. I had to roshambo for the tables they leave open at the bar, but I was determined! So delicious, the wait staff has attitude, but if i worked in a place like that I think I would too. I mean I don't work in a place like that and I do. 
But I started with Kumamoto oysters, then this fantastic Portobello  soup, fried zucchini blossoms with tiny delicate fried peppers. I had the sea bass, phenomenal. Finished with the flour less chocolate cake and a glass of port. Phenomenal meal in awesomeness.
author: kristen l.

description:
Chicken was terrific but do they really have to make you wait an hour?  This restaurant has been in business for decades - can't they figure out how many chickens to cook?
Food was good but service lousy - the wine came after the oysters were served, etc.
author: S.K. R.

description: I think this (aside possibly from chez panisse) was one of the best dining experiences I've ever had. I'll get to the food but first I have to laud my server. I can't recall his name unfortunately but it was the best service experience of all time. This man should open up a training school for servers! He would make a killing because before him I had started to think that service was dead, that mediocrity was an industry standard; it was like he was sent from Valhalla just to pour me water! And the tables are so close in Zuni ( not unbearably close, just think almost communal) that I even got to sit rapt as he worked his service magic over others. If that man is not head waiter he should at least be made part owner because he is selling the shit out of that menu! I will freely admit that he hustled me into buying an extra drink but was so charismatic,  and attentive, and good at his damn job that I didn't give a damn. I was like, "yes sir, lead me into the glory of your outstanding service. Dessert? Another drink? Of course, anything you say sir, anything to view once more the care and tenderness with which you fluorish my plate before me." It was that real!  And of course everything was delicious.  He made sure to make sure my ceasar dressing was anchovy free and he complimented my choices giving suggestions along the way.  I don't even remember what my husband had; I was too caught up lol.  Perhaps I've been going to shitty restaurants and this is actually normal but I was floored and so appreciative after a string of abominable dining experiences.  Oh yeah so I had polenta, ceasar, a pizza with nettles, and some dessert lol. I will return. This is where I want to be when the rapture comes and I'm left behind lmao.
author: Sasha G.

description:
San Francisco is a good place to escape to in the middle of January, especially for 4 days of interesting algorithms and combinatorics talks.  I'd actually be happy if SODA just stayed in San Francisco, though Kyoto is intriguing.

Anyway, Zuni Cafe came highly recommended by a wise individual, so I stopped in for lunch on the way to the suburban hellhole of Silicon Valley the day after my conference ended.  My salad and balsamic bloody mary were both really good, and I'll definitely go back next time I'm in the area.
author: Louis T.

description:
I had such a BEAUTIFUL meal here.

A friend came to visit me (and food) this last weekend and we came here for our last dinner after 2 nights of michelin dining(boooring!), and this was by far our favorite restaurant.  We actually didn't plan on coming here, but we were walking along Market Street all night and thought we should have dinner before calling it a night.  

To be honest, I didn't think I would like it.  I thought it would be like Chez Panisse, which would boast high quality ingredients, but have no flavor.  But I was wrong.  My partner and I ordered oysters and clams, the Zuni Cesar salad, seafood fritters, and onion soup.  We weren't really that hungry, so we didn't plan on ordering dinner.  But they sat us right next to the kitchen.  My friend is a cook (and soon to be chef), and I used to cook, so we just watched and watched ... and we decided we had to get the chicken for 2.

Everything was SO delicious!  Honestly, do yourself a favor and get this Cesar salad.  It is such a huge salad, and the dressing is to die for.  The romaine leaves are so crisp.  I joked to my friend and said "You think I can do salad boy's job?" and he goes "No."

The food was so good.  And it had so much soul.  I am just really glad I went.  I liked our waiter, he seemed very nice, but even though he always looked at our table, he never actually stopped by and asked if we wanted anything while we were waiting for our main course.

Do yourself a favor and eat here!  I am definitely going to come back here with my boyfriend. =)
author: Biqi C.

description:
My only "complaint" about Zuni would be the roast chicken is so supernaturally and confusingly delicious you kind of lose interest in anything else you try to eat with it.  Forget the roast beef and other main courses (really, there's no point).  The gnocci is really good, too, so order it first.  

God knows what they do to a chicken to make it taste like THAT, though I can say with absolute certainty I have never tasted its equal.  For me it's up there with -- dare I say better than? -- Peter Luger's steak.  People complain about the price, but for $50 the roast chicken at Zuni feeds more than "Steak for Two" at Luger at nearly half the cost.  I went with my dad (he was visiting from New York) who paid for everything, including the $30 glass of Glenfarclas I drank just to try something new.  That sweetened the deal.
author: Isaac C.

description:
I'm not sure what the hype about for Zuni Cafe is! This was another restaurant that people were raving about, but I wasn't as impressed with the chicken and bread dish that takes an hour to cook that everyone was so quick to suggest I order. Yes, the chicken came out tender, but it needed more juice or it needed to come with more salad. Something was missing.

I also ordered the mussels. I LOVE mussels but there was NO sauce underneath the mussels! I thought the whole point was to be able to dip your bread in it?! It was good however, that there were breadcrumbs as a topping over them. That made it interesting.

I'm not sure I'd go back to Zuni. I'd rather eat at Park Tavern which I frequent often.
author: caitlin k.

description: outdoor lunch on a rare sunny and blistering saturday.
author: Long C.

description:
Ok, so I've been to this restaurant several times and do enjoy their burger. However, I went to Zuni for dinner and wow. Not a great experience and will never go back.

The service was terrible. The waitress was clearly somewhere else. Our cocktails took about 20 minutes to arrive and that was just the start of it.

I ordered the lamb and sausage, only to learn about 15 minutes later they were out of lamb. I don't understand restaurants that have a short menu and run out of an item. Instead, I had to jump to the halibut - it's really hard to go from a lamb mood to a halibut. No steak on the menu, no pork. Just a lot of fish and the rotisserie chicken (which was not an option since it's for 2 and my friend already ordered something else). What a waste of money.

My friends meal arrived about 20 minutes before mine so she got to eat alone. Then my halibut dish arrived. Halibut was covered with peppers. The peppers were really spicy and that halibut NEEDED the peppers to have any flavor. BLAND, BLAND, BLAND.

Drinks were boring, so was the appetizer. I hoped to recover with the dessert. Bread pudding with berries. I asked the waitress if the berries included strawberries, since I was allergic. She was once again in a different world, thinking that I WANTED strawberries and trying to find them. Finally we got the dish without strawberries (which was actually never part of the pudding) and well. It was BLAND.

Net, my share of the meal was $95... if this was a great meal, fine. Fair enough. But it was bland and boring. I even had to eat more once I got home to get something a bit more flavorful in my mouth.
author: Ghazaleh K.

description: Their Burger was ranked #23 out of 100 in the country!!! It was Amazing!!! Come for the burger...Stay for Teddy!!! Best server Ever!!
author: Louise L.

description:
No wonder Zuni is such a classic SF establishment.  The menu might look not as hip or tintriguing as your Korean tacos or foam gelees or whatever your fad du jour is, but there is a reason why it's hard to find a table on a random weekend for lunch.  

Fortunately a friend rushed there when it first opened at 11:30 and scored us a table.  Despite not having the full party present, we were seated.  It felt sadistically satisfying to see people trickling in, jammed at the small door way.  They can see and smell our delicious food, but the wait for an available table will be long. 

This long wait is partly due to the small space---long and narrow, perched on a rather random part of Market, not a lot of shops near by but nevertheless difficult to score a parking.  It is also exacebated by the famous roasted chicken.  I know it's $48 and it'll take an hour, but if it's your first time at Zuni, it's kind of a must to order.  Our lunch ended up being 2 hours.

While waiting for our slowly roasting chicken, five of us ordered some plates to share.  The Zuni caesar salad was beautiful.  I have always hated caesar salad for its soggy leaves and over powering garlic dressing.  But this is different.  The lettuce crisp, croutons flavorful.  And you can really taste the anchovies. 

Pizza with ricotta was delicious.  Healthy? No.  The paper-thin dough is drenched in olive oil.  But it sure was tasty.  

The fettucine was equally simple and delicious.  It seemed like nothing but noodles and peas, but I very much enjoyed it. 

Duck was excellent as well.  Flavorful meat, not too fatty or greasy. 

Finally, the chicken arrives!  I can't believe it's for two.  Five of us dug in, and managed to finish a little over half.  I must say, I have never been a huge fan of roasted chicken, and Zuni didn't manage to convert me.  The meat didn't seem to be that flavorful or interesting.  What I did love, was the bread salad hidden underneath the chicken.  Did the bread cook with the chicken and therefore soaked in chicken fat?  Or did they just smear a ton of butter?  I don't know, but it sure was delicious.  With the right amount of dried currents and pine nuts and mustardy greens, I couldn't stop eating it.  

I wish they would sell just the chicken bread for like $10 or something.  Or I will need to put up a craiglist listing asking for some counterpart who only wants to eat the chicken.  Then I'd be there all the time.

Service was fantastic.  Price, for the quantity and quality, was very fair.  This would be a good place to take out-of-towners to, as a good embodiment of SF food.
author: Candice B.

description:
I'm going to break this down very concisely, since there are so many reviews of this place:

The Space:  cramped, awkward, overly crowded.  Seating is only comfortable if you have a very small butt.

The Servers:  polite, but scarce, hard to flag down.

Noise Level:  deafening.  It's hard to hear the person on the other side of the really tiny table you're sitting at.

The Crowd:  definitely yuppie, as close to the Marina crowd as this neighborhood gets.  One guesses many opera/ballet/symphony goers stop here before catching their performance.  Maybe cruise-y if you're a gay male, but otherwise, just claustrophobic.

The Food:  splendid.  Perfectly cooked fish that isn't fishy.  Sauces are flavorful, interesting, and there is just enough on your plate to make your mouth happy.  Shoe-string potatoes shouldn't be missed.  Vegetables are appetizing, even for me, which is impressive, since many restaurants make their veggies wholey unappetizing.  Portion size is just right, unless you have a very big appetite.  I don't, and I finished almost all of my entree.

The Price:  Pricey, but given the calibre of the food, you don't get the feeling that this place is a clip joint...in face, my fish dish felt like it was worth the $25 or so I paid for it.  I rarely feel that way about fish dishes at restaurants.  Wine is very pricey, luckily I don't usually drink much of it.  Appetizer of shoestring potatoes felt overpriced for what it was, but then, it was in line with the other prices.

Overall:  I'd go back here.  Not often, but once in a while, when I'm on my way to the ballet and making it a special night.  Otherwise, I'd generally prefer to go somewhere less expensive where I know I'd get an equally delicious meal, but without the slight aura of pretentious restauranteurship that this place exudes.  Zuni Cafe wants so very badly to be taken seriously as a gourmet restaurant...I personally don't buy into places with pervasive hype.  However, I cannot ignore the fact this place serves good food.  So, if you're like me, leave your cynicism home, dress waaaay up, and enjoy!
author: Amy L.

description:
Do you LOVE chicken? Do you not mind waiting nearly an hour for your food? If not, then head over to Zuni's for their famous 7x7 bread salad stuffed chicken.

The chicken is so moist and delicious...totally worth the wait. And I loved the vinegar-esque bread salad that it sat upon. We also started with some oysters that were tasty, and our server made a great wine reccomendation.

Got a special occassion coming up, or someone else is picking up up the tab? Then pick Zuni's.
author: Misha F.

description: A must visit. We had the roast chicken and it was a plate of perfection! It's really large enough for four people to share, especially if you've had an appetizer. The atmosphere was very calming and the acoustics were great as we could actually hear everyone at our table of four without having to strain our voices. Service was exquisite. Highly recommend and can hardly wait to go back.
author: B. T.

description: Great chicken! Extremely rude waitress. I'm not sure what's up with the bread salad. It's full of oil and didn't compliment the chicken! Won't be back!
author: James T.

description: Yep, another fan of the roasted chicken with bread salad. This places is definitely worth checking out for that dish alone. I'm looking forward to trying some of their other dishes when i return.
author: Diana G.

description:
This was on my list to try for at least two years. Everyone has raved about the chicken but to be honest, chicken is chicken. I have had Jonathan Waxman's chicken in NY and found that to be a little overrated. Therefore, I err on the side of caution when getting hyped up about chicken.

So, a place with this type of reputation, I assume there must be something else good besides the chicken. Came for lunch/brunch. Had the rabbit salad, french toast, oysters, cocktails, egg and asparagus, and onion soup. 

None of this was exceptional. It was very forgettable. Not one dish surprised me with a taste or complexity that a restaurant like this should showcase. Maybe I ordered the wrong dishes, or maybe this place is just a chicken factory. Even the cocktails were very ho hum. Service was nothing special. Polite, helpful, but not attentive. 

I will give it another shot for dinner. It is deserving of a second review, but in general, I was left with little to go back for and a good amount of money out of pocket.
author: Adam W.

description:
I have no idea how I have not been here until now.  It's always been highly recommended, the reviews are great, the food looks delicious, the atmosphere is fun.  I've even recommended it without having even been there myself.

So did it live up to the hype?  Well...I'm not sure.  Let's check out some ever so helpful bullet points.  Once again, featuring "bullet points."

* The hosts, very nice and inviting. 
* The atmosphere is indeed a lot of fun.  Great layout.
* Our server, really nice and did a great job.
* Had a margarita.  Solid, but nothing crazy memorable.
* Same for the Zuni Caesar Salad.  
* The Brick Oven Roasted Chicken, warm bread salad with red mustard greens, scallions, currants, and pine nuts...this is a main dish for which they are well known.  It was really good.  And I will feel guilty for seven and half minutes after saying this, but I just didn't think it was that insanely memorable.  

So yes, there is a lot to love about this place.  And I was a bit torn on the star rating to give it . The food unfortunately did not warrant a four star rating.  Having said that, because of everything else though, I would give it another shot.  There is plenty on the menu, I'm confident my next experience could turn out different.

But, finally, the biggest highlight of the night.  Quick flashback.  When I arrived, sitting on a bench right outside the main entrance was this hilarious Dachsund.  He didn't do anything but stare blankly at me.  But if Zuni Cafe claims him as their own, I'd up this review to four stars.  That hilarious Dachsund made my weekend!
author: John R.

description:
I hit up Zuni on Sunday for a long brunch, outside on a beautiful day and it once again cemented it's position (alongside Bix) as my favorite dining spot in SF. The service is impeccable, the food is delectable, and the elegance-meets-Market St. ambiance brings it home. 

The chicken for two is well worth the 40 minute wait, and when you add the burger and a caesar salad, it's pretty much perfection. Top it off with the incredible-ness that is the chocolate Gateau Victoire (GLUTEN-FREE!!) and a bottle of prosecco, and it's simply magic.
author: Nissa A.

description: BEST BLOODY MARY IN THE WHOLE DAMN CITY. I order a Bloody Mary everywhere, and almost any time of day. I must say their special (I think it was balsamic) Bloody Mary was the best I have ever had. Every single thing was delicious. We ordered the burgers (which they oddly only serve after 10 PM), the lamb, and the oven-roasted chicken. We ordered every single desert on the menu because it was just... out of this world. Super expensive, so save this for a special occasion or date.
author: Nasrin M.

description:
With all the hype and being an iconic SF dining spot, I expected to walk away pleasantly satisfied. Instead, it felt very average.

The copper tones and glass-filled location are charming if you happen to be perched up on the second floor loft level. Uncommon these days to have live music at a dining venue, the piano in the bar is a nice touch,  albeit, a bit too loud for the acoustics of the space.

Service was fair and the bread disappeared faster than your unlocked bike in the Mission. You can only imagine...

The starter of clams with harissa, kale and chickpeas was a gold star. If only there was some bread to soak up the rest of the sauce, every last drop would have been enjoyed.

The much lauded chicken under a brick was indeed succulent and flavorful and the 'bread salad' (ie. giant croutons) managed to absorb all the juices and fats possible so as to result is nothing but deliciousness. Then again, it's only a chicken, and it wasn't really anything that special in the end. To wait the hour for this bird-on-bread was tolerable but I wouldn't send my friends here for this dish.

And while you wait for your chicken, grab a cocktail or some oysters, not one but three glasses of red wine were flops. Of the five or six offered by the glass, the three tried (Pinot Noir, Zinfandel and Syrah) were all mellow and mild, uncharacteristic of these varietals. The waiter seemed a bit put off when I said how mellow they were and I wanted a little boldness. I could have said the three tasted nearly identical and I do indeed like grape juice but not for $10 a glass.

So grab a date, a drink at the bar, sling a few oysters (or clams) and enjoy the music. The rest can stay under a brick.
author: Alissa A.

description:
Finally I got try Zuni....the awesome looking restaurant that I always see on my way home from work. It's always poppin, it's always happening.  It always looks like the people who eat there have "Made-It" in life.  Yeah, so now you know how much hype I gave this place before trying it. 

Best way to describe my visit is in chronological order. 

The day after I made reservations, I read a blog that said Hillary Clinton went there and was pounding back whiskey sours.  So while I waited for my table I got a "Hillary" at the bar (same bartender from when Hilz was there too) + One Star.

Then when we were seated, we got to go upstairs through uber snooty, uber art-gallery type of feng shui spacing that was the upstairs dining area. It was nice, I thoroughly enjoyed walking through the each to half level to reach our table on the mezzanine.  Exciting!  + One Star.

Then then we ordered food.  First we started with wine glasses, then went for a bottle.  Ordered a ton of starters and sides.  Most of the appetizers were just alright.  Good, but not up to expectations of a place run by Chez Panisse Alumni.  The ricotta gnocchi was the stand-out.  It was like just cheese rolled and baked in a light potato starchy crust. Awesome.  The rest was just - eh (I had high hopes) - One Star.

Then we got our Warm Bread Salad Roasted Chicken.  If you have read the reviews, then you know that you have to order this. What I didn't know until now is this fact;  the chicken is all you should order. Easily the highlight of my meal.  The chicken had a delicious vinegrette flavor all throughout.  The bread was warm and crusty in some parts, warm and oh-so-comforting in others.  We should have just ordered two of these, no joke.  + Two Stars. 

So here we stand at 4 stars.   Not quite out of this world, but i would come back.  Also I saw the late night menu on my way out, something to think about for next time I am out past 10.
author: Beef E.

description: We've been here three times last many years.  Zuni has certainly stood the test of time.  Great to go to after visiting the Asian Art Museum, it's a short walk.  Last visit in Nov 2013 was for a weekday lunch.  We got to sit at the top of the stairs on the second floor, a very cool spot.  We ate light, had Caesar and Frisee salads and an antipasto plate and shoestring potatoes.  Great bread!  Service is always excellent.  Very well dressed, good-looking crowd there.  Will always come back if there's an opportunity.
author: Dan L.

description:
I have been to Zuni three or four times. My experience prior to this week has been 5 stars all the way. Their chicken is the bomb. Pork chop, excellent. Desserts - yum. Their salads are great. The service has always been perfect and friendly. There is neighborhood parking or valet. The place is crowded in the evenings but my experiences have largely been mid-day or late-afternoon during the week. 

Then my sister-in-law came to town and we took her to lunch there on Sunday. She specifically asked for details about a salad, was assured it was one way, then it was served as another. She put it aside, did not complain, did not send it back. Our meal continued and her burger came rare instead of medium. When she politely complained to our waitress (who has been terrific - just perfect - in the past), the response was cool. Waitress disappeared and another server came to our table. He took over for the rest of our meal, made everything right by removing her burger and sald - neither of which she ate. She declined another meal. 

It was just so odd and unexpected. Certainly, we will return again at least once. Our previous experience being what it was, I would really hate to write this place off. But what a disappointment.
author: Judith B.

description: Zuni is always a classic choice for a stylish bistro meal. Great selection of oysters and farm to table (I think) menu. We had excellent pea soup with mint - very fresh, and probably the best home-made sausage I ever tasted - really took sausage to a new level, lots of fennel. My only complaint is that some of the tables are "weird". They first tried to seat us a a "lovers' table" with two seats both facing outward, and we were not lovers. You need to specify a table "facing each other" when making a reservation and that is not possible online.
author: Brian G.

description:
Attention all yelp readers: Please be advised that some of who review food restaurants have never WORKED in a restaurant before and therefore do not know how to properly review a restaurant. 

With that said, I loved this restaurant! 
We walked in and got a table for two. The feel of the room was very romantic and upper-scale. The host seated us in the back, no problem. The server (Started with an A sorry!! ) was always asking us how we were doing and making sure we were alright, awesome job dude. Our food came out promptly and the busser always filled up our glasses when they were empty. I would definitely come here again and will recommend it!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: Although the food was tasty, I thought it was too little for the amount of money it costs. I left the restaurant hungry; probably it only worths for their special chicken dish to go there; that is only if you are willing to pay 50 for a chicken.
author: Duygu U.

description:
I think this is a great representation of SF cuisine -- food whose focus is on very fresh, organic ingredients and not based on bold sauces and other flavorings.

Their oyster bar has an excellent selection -- a bit pricey, but very fresh and it's a great way to sample a variety. Our favorite was the Summer Ice -- a very sweet oyster. Oooh I could eat 2 dozens of those!

Fried halibut with onion rings -- The fish was very flaky and delicious. I don't know what type of oil/batter they used to fry these, but it was very light and crisp. I loved it!

The oven-baked chicken with bread salad -- It was good, but not wait-an-hour-and-pay-$50 good. I think I've had juicier chicken for 1/5 of the cost (Back-A-Yard in East Palo Alto, Il Pollaio in North Beach). If it cost maybe $20-25, I could recommend it, but not for $50.

Service was good and you can really tell that every ingredient in the dishes are fresh -- unfortunately, the overhyped/overpriced chicken brought it down a star rating.
author: Kazu O.

description:
WOWW!!!!.. my mom and I come to san fran about twice a year every year.. we have many favorites here (the slanted door, ikes place) 
Anyways.. when we arrived we were reminded of the great aroma which greets you. 
As they set up our table we had a drink at the bar..

then came our roasted chicken that we have so long prepared for!!! basically it was GREAT FOOD and mediocre service... but the food makes up for that aspect..
author: Andy G.

description: PSA: Zuni is open L A T E. The food is a San Francisco Staple of course, and make sure to sit upstairs where the cool kids sit and not on the 'main' balcony but in the funky little back rooms upstairs. There are so many accurate food reviews here but just to add one, the Salmon in good. I pretty much hate that vile fish and whatever they do to it it's like a new fish...started with a forced bite by a friend and now I'm hooked. Also, as noted in several reviews, the fries are like 'crack', the Burger is top notch and the Oyster selection is also notable. The only bad thing I can think of is that sometimes the 1-hour chicken can be unseasoned...occasionally and the bathrooms need a remodel or at least a 30-min staff check.
author: Stephen S.

description:
The roasted chicken is uh-mazing.  Almost better than bacon.  Some will find that the price point is a bit high, but how do you put a price on magic, love, or roasted chicken that is equal parts love and magic?  And you needn't go hungry waiting for the roasted chicken, which takes 45 minutes to cook, because the gnocchi is divine.  Delicate bite sized pillows.  Also, the oysters are a must, because that's how we do.  All deserving of five stars!  

I'm also a fan of the brunch, which I had a chance to enjoy today.  Due to being on meds, I did not partake on the bloodies, but they looked delicious and I definitely coveted.  The bakes eggs were yum although I wish I had ordered the eggs with the chorizo sausage.  One of the ladies that brunched with us ordered the "mandarin oranges and dates" dish.  Please interpret that literally because she was delivered a plate with six unpeeled mandarin oranges and six medjool dates for...you guessed it, six dollars.  The least they could have done was to make the dates and oranges look pretty, but unless it was an installment of post modern art, it's deserving of a negative star.  Yep, I giveth and I taketh away.  You do the math.
author: Uyen N.

description:
Okay, what everyone says about the roast chicken is true: it's delicious and it really does take an hour to make.

You should definitely order the roast chicken if you have the time. Before you sit down, before you get water or bread, tell your server/seater you want the roast chicken so they can put it in the oven.

I'll update this review when I go back again and try some of the other dishes!
author: Arcee X.

description: Relevant info.   We met our guests there.  They were four ladies- and then my husband and myself - total group of six.  My husband and i were arriving separately from our jobs. When I arrived I ordered a cocktail (the four of them already had cocktails). My guests were on a time limit so in the interest of time we placed our orders. Two ladies ordered the chicken dish to share and the other two each ordered steaks and the four of them also ordered starters. I knew my husband would be late so I said "my husband and I will share the chicken dish for two".  There was clearly a spot saved for him.   Fast forward- my husband arrives and orders a drink while we share the appetizers.  the food arrives but not the chicken I had ordered.  We ask and the waiter if the chicken is a double order and he says he didn't place the order.  What? Even if you didnt hear what I said- what did you think we would be eating ? Did you think we would come and just watch other people eat?? It made no sense.  He tried to make up for it and brought us a small app and gave us complimentary desserts- but overall it wasn't a great experience for us.  $50 for a roasted chicken- I want an attentive waiter.  The food was good but for a $350 tab I expect the waiter to take care of all of the guests.
author: Madhuri K.

description:
I'm giving this place 3 stars because: 

- I would and have gone here multiple times and I would recommend this place to someone else. 
- However, I don't feel that this place is mind blowing,
- And for the cost you could probably find more interesting food. (Although they are pretty generous with their portions)
- Service was okay and we also had a cramped table. 

It should really be more like 3.75 stars.

Conceptually this place does not offer anything new. But in terms of execution, it's fairly impeccable. The first time we went, we had a burger which tasted good but the bun was so oily and completely took away from the flavor of the burger. 
We also had oysters which were fresh and tasty. 

The second time we came here with my mother in law and ordered the chicken and the pork. Both were fantastic and we had plenty to take home for leftovers. 

Their fries are killer and they give you plenty of them.
author: Liliana A.

description:
4.5 stars.

i came here expecting the famous roast chicken to be a let down.  how can it be thaaaat good?  $48 for a roast chicken and an hour wait?!?!! i can get one at costco for $5!  i was expecting it to be so overhyped for me that my friend and i were jokingly lowering expectations for each other the week before saying "this is gonna be the worst meals of our lives!"

let me tell you, it didn't disappoint.  we ordered the chicken right as we sat down before we even glanced at the menu.  got the clams in white wine sauce to share to pass the time.  

a little over an hour passes an alas, the famous roast chicken and bread salad.  chicken was what you'd expect from a $48 dish, chicken done at its best...moist meat, crispy skin, just salty enough.  

what really made this dish a winner for me was the bread salad.  at the end of the day, the chicken is just....a chicken, no matter how beautifully roasted it was.  the bread salad was soaked in the chicken juices but still had a crispiness to it.  pine nuts and currants were good accompaniments and i really enjoyed the vinaigrette.

i left full, happy, and thankful the roast chicken wasn't a disappointment.
author: Helen T.

description:
Let's just get one thing straight, the chicken for 2 is really chicken for 4! There is no way 2 people can or should eat that portion of chicken and butter soaked bread! Let's get one thing straight though - it was pretty darn good. The chicken was moist, especially the drumsticks and was very well seasoned and tasty for being chicken. The middle of our chicken mound contained a heaping serving of dressing that tasted like it may have 2 sticks of butter in it. I love buttery goodness but eating too much of this would definitely give me a tummy ache. 

Anyways, go ahead and order the chicken but be prepared to wait 1 hour for it. To fill in our 1 hour period of time we drank a bottle of wine, and ordered snacks - we were hungry, and didn't realize the chicken would feed a family. We ordered the heaping plate of fries, every single table seemed to have an order of this so I couldn't resist, plus I love me some fries and ketchup! They were standard, but still satisfied a french fry lover. We also ordered the ricotta gnocchi, I really really liked this and could have eaten a whole bowl of it. Unlike the other food this was super light and simple only dressed in olive oil and salt and pepper. The ricotta gnocchi were like little melty clouds on your tongue, mmm. Overall, I left satisfied and we had a doggie bag that was enough for the 2 of us for lunch the next day (still tasted good the next day plus I put the bread dressing in the oven to get toasty and I was much less soggy!).
author: Nicole L.

description: Delicious and worth the hype. One of my friends is a vegetarian and though the menu that day focused mostly on carnivores, the chef whipped up a custom dish for her consumption. Can't comment on how it tasted, but the plate full of various vegetables--most of which I didn't recognize--certainly looked appetizing.
author: Tony S.

description:
It's been more than 12 years since i've been to Zuni.  The last time I visited I was on a business trip to SF.  I remember thinking it was a good but not great meal back then.  Since 7x7 recommended the Zuni burger, I wanted to check it out... 

It was definitely an expensive burger.  At $13 it would be comparable in price to other restaurant premium burgers in the city (i.e. grass-fed beef from one of the ranches in Marin county).  However, the burger came with nothing but a meat patty and 2 buns.  Literally everything else was extra - the cheese, fries, tomatoes, onions.  So, with cheese, onions, tomatoes and fries, you're looking at ~$20 something bucks for a burger.  Now, that's even expensive for SF!

Price aside, I would be delighted if it were a great burger, but it was extremely mediocre.  The cold and somewhat dry Foccacia used as buns just didn't really work well with the burger (it was not good Foccacia).  

The Arugula salad we ordered at $9 (under salads and apps) was so small that it would even be considered tiny if it were a side salad that came with a sandwich or burger.... And there was nothing to the salad except Arugula, olive oil and vinegar... now that's a pricey, mini-sized and rather boring/plain salad. 

Perhaps their burger and their salads are not what one should order at Zuni, but I am definitely not rushing back anytime soon....
author: Paul K.

description: The food here is great but if you're not white, affluent and look it, don't go, you'll get terrible service.
author: Drink C.

description:
i was looking forward to the food at Zuni Cafe, being that the reviews were so great here...1K+ reviews with a 4.5 star rating? should be amazing right? wrong....

being that we were all starved and hungover from the night before, brunch was just the thing to get us going...

ordered a couple glasses of wine and a couple apple juices and fresh squeezed OJ to start and eventually ordered up 5 dishes for all of us to share...

french toast....BOMB! so friggin good...smothered in a sweet cream/glaze and topped with blueberries...definitely the best dish of the meal...

after that dish...everything was not good at all...

had some spaghetti dish with perfectly cooked al dente noodles, topped with bread crumbs and some type of butter sauce and veggies...at least put salt in it...better yet, throw in some marinara please...

the pork chop dish was overcooked and oversalted...maybe we shouldve chopped up the pork chop and tossed it into the spaghetti...

the sausage with egg was just...one cooked sausage with a side of scrambled eggs and topped with a tomato relish of some sort...eggs also needed salt...the sausage was average.

the caesar salad was 3 or 4 leaves of uncut lettuce...drizzled with dressing....i dunno, but any time a salad is served to me and i need to go at it with a fork and knife, is usually pretty irritating to me...if im paying 10 bucks for a few pieces of lettuce, at least have the decency to cut it for me please...

all in all the meal was overpriced and the food was either too salty OR bland...

the "organic" apple juice (although great for a hangover) was just too expensive at 3.25 per small glass and 5.50 for squeezed OJ is definitely overpriced as well...

the one regret other than eating there was not being able to order their FAMOUS CHICKEN...apparently this chicken is all the rage and having had several of their dishes...MUST be the only reason why this place has so many great reviews...next time i will opt for the chicken (we didnt order it because it takes forever to cook and serve and they wont let you "preorder" it as soon as you walk in)

maybe another time...or not.
author: Kyu L.

description:
I got the pork chop and a glass of coffee. It's pretty pricy and the options are not that many. My vegetables were burnt so they were bitter and my pork chop was not worth to be talked about.

ps: Waiters were attentive. And dress nicely. I wasn't aware that this place is pretty formal
author: Cliff T.

description:
Took my parents out for their 33rd anniversary and my fiance here for a dinner before the symphony. Definitely was the right choice, and while the stars might have been aligned perfectly for the evening, I don't care and still give Zuni 5 stars for delivering:

1) Excellent oysters and gnocchi for appetizers
2) Delicious hen (need to get the chicken next time because the hen, which is baked in the same oven, was some of the best fowl I've ever had)
3) Petrale Sol with really nice spice/flavor
4) Probably the best overall waiter experience I've ever had. He was professional, friendly (and not in a forced way), casual, attentive, smart on his recommendations, etc.
5) Best flourless cake my mom has ever had. At intermission, my mom was still talking about how good it was.

Mom (in line with my fiance at the bathroom): "That was so good."
My fiance: "Oh yeah, Yo Yo ma was great!"
Mom: "No, I meant that chocolate cake at dinner!"

There's a reason Zuni Cafe has been around for such a long time. Thanks Zuni for making my parents' 33rd anniversary such a memorable one.
author: Stephen H.

description:
OMFC(hicken)!!

5 stars for the delicious chicken alone. the atmosphere, service and wine were all great as well (solid 4 stars), but that crispy, juicy little chicken gets his own star.

it's called "chicken for two", but it's more like "chicken for 8". we contemplated selling our uneaten half on craigslist, but decided leftovers would be a better option.
author: Kristen A.

description:
Hadn't been to Zuni in ages...Recently got reacquainted since my little sis (aka xtreme foodie) from NYC actually heard about the "famed Zuni Cafe" and had to check it out this weekend.

With the towering floor-to-ceiling windows...the beams of sun flowing into the restaurant created a perfect setting for some good grub.  We sampled the pizza, halibut cheeks, spaghetti, legendary hamburger, and the shoestring potato fries (of course!).

Dishes were all very well-prepared with a good balance of flavor.  Service was attentive and highly efficient. 

BOTTOM LINE:  Picky little sis was impressed and I guess that's all that matters.
author: Justin L.

description:
I think the word cafe is misleading. It's not really a cafe. It should be called, "zuni rather-expensive-restaurant"

Zuni is a great spot, especially if you have people from out of town. It's hip and trendy with a great selection of food and wines. We didn't have a reservation but were able to get a small table in the bar area at 6:30 on a sunday. The place was packed! 

We were a bit full so we ordered small things and shared. We started with some oysters (they have a big selection here) and a half bottle of Pouille-Fuisse wine. mmmm...We then decided to order only things that start with "P" The polenta, penne, and pork tenderloin were all impressive. Even more impressive, was that our waiter asked if we were sharing and made sure that all our plates were pre-split so we didn't have to deal with it. That's really thoughtful. 

The staff that brought us our food was attentive and thoughtful as well...one person asked if we wanted to eliminate the platters under our bowls to save space since the table was small. But she still used the platters to bring the food to us, knowing we wouldn't be keeping them. Kinda nice! I also appreciated that when i was chilly, they got a pole to shut the window almost immediately. 

I want to come back for the 1 hour wood-oven chicken! mmmmm...but $48 for a chicken for two?? It better be good!
author: Nikki M.

description:
Went again for lunch and this place is still going strong.  

Its very pleasant, all around.  A classic.

My one comment is its hard for zuni to stand out in the complex dinning eco system of SF.  The food is stand up, but at the same time perhaps a bit too familiar.

But still most restaurants can still learn many things about the casual perfection of the food and service of Zuni.
author: Ken p.

description:
Summary: Reasonable, but overpriced. 

Came w/ family and friends for my second visit here. Got oysters, clams, shoestring fries, roast chicken, steak, and pork chop.

Food was generally good, but portions were small. Also was quite expensive.

The only thing really memorable (besides the unnecessarily high price tag) was the bread salad.

Wouldn't come back again myself.
author: Gary Y.

description:
My friend and I came into Zuni on a Sunday, fairly close to closing.  The server said it would be no problem to order the chicken.  Since it was my first time at Zuni, I wanted to try that most of all.  We started with the Caesar salad and the scallops with little gems.  Both of these were rather tasty.  I found the scallops dish flavorful, but lacking.  I would have even appreciated 5 little gem lettuce leaves, opposed to the 3 that were on the plate.  However, when the chicken came, I was glad I was not full of lettuce.  The chicken is a radiant dish.  It has optimal flavor.  I was hooked.  I loved the toasted bread salad tossed in frissee, currants, pine nuts, and drippings.  It was a great combination with the crispy skinned chicken.  My friend and I were complimenting this dish with every bite.
  
We had a bottle of beaujolais with the meal, which was rather lovely as well.  I will definitely come to Zuni again, but I will order some other dishes next time.  Two gentlemen sitting next to us swore that you can easily recreate the chicken dish at home, using the Zuni cookbook.  I will be trying this at my next dinner party.  I really appreciated the patience the staff had, especially because we were the last to leave the restaurant that night.  We were not rushed by any means.  I understand why Zuni has the reputation it has and I look forward to returning sometime soon.
author: Ashley W.

description: Have been to Zuni for many times in so many years. I have never had a bad experience that i must admit but the food is just fine, nothing to rave about for the given price and the reservation craziness. That infamous chicken dish keeps making me wonder why in the world it takes like an hour for a mediocre rotisserie chicken, it's a shame at least it should taste better than the one sold at whole foods or a grocery store!
author: Beril Y.

description: The quail was incredible, tender and paired with a well balanced fava bean risotto. Although the place was packed, the manager graciously accepted to move us to a better table.
author: Alina B.

description: This place was really good but I'm not sure it's entirely worth the buzz. We had to order the two main dishes, of course - caesar salad and roasted chicken - and they were quite yummy. However, i think I prefer the chicken at Wayfare Tavern just a little more (though this chicken was good for leftovers!). The fried vegetable appetizer was bland and boring. The most surprising dish (in a good way) was the gnocci, because it was made with ricotta. A very pleasing flavor and creative take on a fairly standard dish.
author: Amy F.

description: So good. The chicken and the caesar salad were YUMMY! The cocktails were nice. The service was wonderful. The dessert was delightful. The hostesses can definitely be more friendly though-- a bit flustered and almost unwelcoming on the phone and in person. Would love to have the introduction match the lovely food and service.
author: Maryam M.

description:
OK, so the more I think about it, the more I am losing faith in the "2010 Big Eat SF: 100 Things to Try Before You Die" list. #1 on the list: roast chicken and bread salad at Zuni.

We show up on a late Saturday morning/early afternoon, mentally and emotionally prepared to wait an hour for the roast chicken (per the menu and other Yelpers' reviews). When it comes to me and food, I should never have to wait for more than half an hour. So, the fact that I was purposely waiting for an hour for a chicken to show up in front of me says a lot. Expectations were high, people. Very high.

To tie us down, we started off with the house-cured anchovies with celery, Parmesan, and niçoise olives. It was good, but not "blow my mind away" good. The olive oil drizzled over it was my favorite part. It had a nice fresh taste and finish...yum.

An hour of eavesdropping on the next table's conversation later (*snore*), the chicken finally showed up. Sadly, the chicken was just OK. I've had better. In terms of quality, it was up there. But so is an organic chicken from Costco for $6.99 if you know how to cook it. The chicken was tender, but not super juicy (which is how I usually prefer my chicken to be). It could have been better seasoned, but whatever. The wings on the chicken were a little burnt, so the meat was like jerky that I would feed a dog. A dog I'm not too fond of...

Best part of the meal...the bread salad. There must be crack in that bread because, boy was it good. Is it worth coming back again? Probably not. There's really no value in spending $75 on a chicken and four pieces of anchovies in my mind....especially when I can do it for a fraction of the price.
author: Blenda L.

description: I love places like this. It is very classy, excellent service and food. Definitely pricey, so be prepared to shell out the big bucks. All restaurants should aim to be more like Zuni - consistent, welcoming, elegant, delicious.
author: Ariadne R.

description:
Not knowing the prestigeous history, we strolled in at the end of a long Holiday shopping walk through downtown San Francisco. The long welcoming copper bar gave us a chance to rest and refresh with a glass of wine and the best oysters I've eaten in years. The locally farmed Hog Island Kumumotos were so good I ordered another round. 

We definitely plan to return for a full meal.
author: Ryan M.

description:
I was so excited to try this San Francisco institution for brunch, I've been wanting to visit for years and finally got around to it. 

Sunny day, friendly service, nice wines, decent, but not show-stopping food. 

My main concern: half portions at double prices. Nice, but insubstantial food.  I went home hungry and disappointed. Maybe I just didn't select the right entree. I'm perfectly happy to pay more for a nicer meal, but I didn't have it here. Perhaps I'd come back for a drink, but I just don't see the allure of this place in terms of the food.
author: Jeremy B.

description:
I really wasn't all that impressed with Zuni, but to be fair this isn't my type of place; yuppyish, expensive and a very, very limited menu.

Zuni has this fantastic wood burning oven right in the center of the restaurant...really beautiful.  So why do they offer only two pizzas?  One was a plain cheese the other some foo foo pizza with corn and peppers on it.  If they have that oven stoked all day what is it doing?

Sorry I don't get it.
author: G L.

description:
There were high expectations leading to my meal at Zuni Cafe.  Many people have raved about their roast chicken with bread salad and I have seen many renditions of this recipe online as well as borrowed for a recipe book compilation for a bride.  Unfortunately, my expectations were not really met after trying their legendary dish.  

I had Saturday lunch reservations here with a couple of friends.  I arrived early with a friend and ordered the roast chicken dish at 11:45am (my other friend was scheduled to arrive at noon) since we knew that it would take an hour for the chicken to be ready (as per their menu).  The roast chicken with bread salad is more than enough for 2 people so we decided to order tagliatelle pasta and the shoe string potatoes.  We ordered the shoe string potatoes because we (as well as the table next to us) were mesmerized by the dish when the waiter brought one out for another table.  The pasta was ok but the shoe string potatoes were good. The roast chicken came out around 1:15 or so, so it took about 1.5 hours for the dish.  The chicken was moist, but I found the underlying taste of the chicken breast I was eating a bit weird. I couldn't really put my finger on it, it was almost like they brined the chicken in white wine? I didn't think the chicken breast was seasoned well enough.  The bread pieces in the bread salad were also a bit too greasy for my preference.  The roasted salad was nice though.  I don't think I would try their roast chicken again.

On a side note, I must say that the space and architecture of the place is beautiful. There are a lot of windows allowing in lots of natural lighting.  The building of the restaurant is also in a strange angle, almost like the famous Flatiron building in NYC, so as a result, a lot of the tables were set in angles perhaps to play off of that.  Perhaps not the most efficiently arranged tables...
author: Kai C.

description:
Zuni Cafe looks so small from the outside but it is actually huge with a relatively large upstairs area.  The interior of the restaurant is beautiful with lots of large windows and exposed beams and brick; the place just generally has a great, positive open vibe.  There is a small bar area where you can stand and eat (which seems awkward but I saw some people doing it) or have a drink while you're waiting for your table. 

Everybody says that the chicken is the entree to get, so that's what one of my friends and I got.  As it says on the menu, it takes an hour, so definitely order appetizers (or don't come super hungry) if you're going to get the chicken.  I don't typically order chicken at restaurants because I think chicken is relatively boring and fundamentally not a very flavorful meat.  The chicken for two at Zuni Cafe is delicious, juicy and aromatic - the chicken was very tender and full of all of the flavor of the seasonings.  It is a pretty significant amount of food, and we had more than enough for the two of us - you could probably split it among three people (especially if you are getting appetizers).

We had a couple of different appetizers including the salad with heirloom tomatoes and "avocado toasts" (toasted bread with sliced avocado on top) and the lamb sausage.  Both were fine but not really standouts.  Most of the other people at the table got seafood dishes - sandabs and bass were on the menu that night, and people loved the sandabs.  The only complaint about the sandabs was that there were lots of bones in the sandabs but that's just how it goes with such a small fish.  We were absolutely stuffed so didn't get dessert.

The service was a little odd - our waiter seemed very nice but a little out of it.  When people asked him for recommendations, he seemed to be at a loss; similarly, when people asked him more detailed questions about the fish (texture, what kind of flavors are similar, etc.), he didn't seem to know how to answer the question.  Also, we were missing one dish at our table, and he said that the kitchen "had an accident" and were frying up a new fish; my friends who have worked at restaurants before said that's code for "I forgot to put in your order".  The other person at the table had to wait ~10 minutes for his fish to come out - not a huge deal but just a bit of a downer.
author: Wendy L.

description:
The food, superb.  The service, a little bit rough.  The misto with brussels sprouts was excellent and broke my rule that all brussels sprouts dishes must be made with bacon.  I've now learned that deep-fried with paprika works too.  My wife's rocket salad with pomegranates and pistachios was very good as were my oysters, nicely chosen by the staff.  And the roast chicken and bread salad, exactly as good as we remember it from our honeymoon %$^# years ago.

The service started a bit rough as to timing.  No fun to have oysters without the Quincy.  It showed eventually, but... The service got on track later, but for what a night at Zuni costs, and for a couple ordering bar drinks, bar appetizer, starters, the chicken, desert , tea and a bottle of wine, a feeling of being taken for granted is not what one should leave with.

A few words about the cookbook.  In the past year since moving to LA (after 15 in SF) and picking the book off our shelf on a whim to try my hand at a once a week meal that even I can cook, I've probably made 30 chickens. And, while not every chicken I roast at home using Judy's recipe from the book has come out as well as this one, I can remember a few that have been better, and about 3/4s were equally as tasty.  The key to her recipe is a great 3.25 lb. bird. Whole Foods birds (from any purveyor) don't cut it.  Get to a farmer's market and buy one from the source.  The other key is the salting and peppering the bird 2 days before cooking.  Do these two things, combine with an oven that can hold a decent high temp, and you can make Zuni birds, if not the bread salad, at home quite easily.  And, if you're cooking for two, the leftovers are enough for a second meal.
author: Joe N.

description:
Haven't eaten at Zuni for years -- like over 20.  No particular reason why not.  Just didn't think it was that good and the location was inconvenient.  Visited it again at the invitation of friends and still think it's just ok.

The place is noisy when full because of all the brick, glass and stainless steel in the narrow space.  The entrance is no longer on Market but off the alley in back, where they offer valet service.  I never let anyone valet park my car, so that's not worth anything to me.

There's very little room to stand in the miniscule lobby.  There's a bar near the entrance and stairs to the upper level.  We were seated near the rear of the 1st floor in an alcove close to the kitchen.  It's probably one of the better places to be seated in the restaurant because it was out of the way and less noisy and crowded as a result.

Our host loves the chicken there and ordered 2.  The chicken takes an hour to cook in the wood oven which we could see from our table.  The other guests chose to share a variety of dishes that I did not try.  I chose a sardine appetizer, arugula salad and grilled salmon entree.  Each of these dishes was very good.  When the chicken came out, I had a drumstick and thigh, which I also thought was very good.  We also all shared a couple bottles of Roederer Brut which was fine too.  All in all a very good meal.

However, the service was not quite up to par.  The waitress did not know how to pour champagne, pick up of dishes was spotty and had to ask for refills of water but the food was served promptly.

All in all an ok experience but not a place that I would go to again unless someone invited me to go there again.
author: Martin C.

description:
I should mention two facts first: 1. that I've only eaten at Zuni Cafe once. 2. that my meal was free to me via a gift certificate. Neither of these facts prevented me from having what I felt was a genuine experience there, I just thought I should mention them up front. 

Qualifiers aside, this was one of the better meals I've had at a restaurant in a long time. I don't normally order chicken but listened to what friends and yelp people had raved about and ordered the roast chicken for two. I thought it was great; moist, flavorful and sitting on top of a delicious bread salad. For those of you who are confused by the sound of bread salad (like I was before it came to our table), it contains bread, pine nuts, currants and some greens (arugula, I think), all under the deliciously roasted chicken. The bread soaks up the juices. 

I've seen some comments on here questioning $50 for a chicken dish and, like I said, I didn't pay for the chicken myself, but it's the WHOLE chicken--definitely enough for two people and probably leftovers. That's $25 an entree (per person), which isn't exorbitant at all for a nicer restaurant. You just have to agree to get the same thing with another person. I'd go back and pay the $50 myself (for a special occasion)! 

My dining companion and I also split another recommendation, the Caesar Salad. I'm  not a seafood fan so tend to order Caesar salads sparingly. This one was really good, right on the cusp of tasting too fishy for me, but then too good to stop eating. 

We also got a few glasses of wine. I don't remember which ones but we asked the waitress for recommendations based on what we were eating and all of them were great. The service in general was spot on--attentive but low key. The wait for the chicken didn't feel too long with the wine and salad to keep us company. We sat upstairs, which felt like it might have been a little more quiet than other spots by the kitchen or bar---something to think about if you have a strong preference. All of the seating looked appealing though. 

We finished the meal with two desserts: a chocolate pot de creme and a kumquat and orange glazed cake with a cardamom sauce. The pot de creme was nice in that it wasn't too sweet, the cake was also subtle (in a good way). 

If you eat at pricier places on a regular basis, I could see where Zuni might warrant a 3-4 star rating, depending on the night or dish ordered but my experience was top notch.
author: Kiersten Y.

description:
Hip setting perfect for a romantic date with amazing oysters. 
BEST BITES:
ricotta gnocchi w/ brussels sprouts are divine
roasted brick oven chicken for two is ideal romantic evening
braised oxtails and short ribs are luscious
author: Bren B.

description:
I must have passed by a few thousand times in all the years I've lived in SF and each time I would look at those yellow awnings and think "I should try some day".

Why did I wait for so long? This place is great!
I love the decor and the huge open kitchen. I think next time (yes, there will be a next time) I am going to ask and be seated on the mezzanine.
Also I don't know if they have that everyday, but the guy playing the piano with a Martini glass on it was a classy touch :)

Service was impeccable. Period.

Food was awesome as well. We had fish and beef, but what was amazing is that I enjoyed the accompaniments as much as the dish itself!
I almost wanted to order the chicken for 2 and reading other reviews now, I regret not getting it. But I was really hungry and the 1 hour preparation mentioned on the menu scared me away.
So instead we got oysters (logical, but it only makes sense in my head).
They have a great wine selection as well.

I will definitely go back and try the chicken.
A friend of mine also mentioned their carrot soup which I have to try as well.
author: Vithiet L.

description: Liked the food and the service. I had the fish which was delicious. Will have to go back for the chicken.
author: Wildeflower M.

description:
Pros: 

Good cocktails, the entree I ordered (pork tender loin) was very good, and the live piano was nice.

Cons:

The price of food/drinks was, in my opinion, more than what should have been charged. The quality of the restaurant did not match up to the hype. 


I went with my family to celebrate graduating from my master's program, and my partner's graduation from her B.A.  It had received good accolades from friends of my family, so it was decided upon that was where we would go. 

People enjoyed their food well enough, but I swear if they (the restaurant) could have added more tiny chopped onions into the dishes, including my water, they would have. There comes a time where tiny chopped onions becomes gratuitous. I saw that time. It was crunchy. And overly onion-y.

I would return for cocktails and happy hour, but probably not for another full meal. For that price, I would rather go to Chapeau! or Incanto.
author: Megan L.

description:
Excellent. 

If it's your first time, get the whole chicken with bread salad. It's well worth it. 

If it's your second time, try out the pork with chorizo. Very unique smoky/cajun-like seasoning, and an Awesome corn salsa/salad accouterment. 

Very accommodating to kids, and would be a great place for a group if you're all willing to pay for an expensive (But great!) meal.

Also, great bar scene
author: Alex L.

description:
Service was good, the bread was tasty. The salad was also good. Entrees were definitely not impressive. I had a burger, nothing special at all. Actually it was quite bland. You'd think a 15 dollar burger is top notch, well cafe zuni is exact opposite. 

The check comes and there is a 4 dollar charge for every single soft drink refill!! 
GTFOH!!!! ITS 2012 AND NO ONE CHARGES FOR REFILLS OF FOUNTAIN SODA ANYMORE. 

I wanted to like this place but frankly the food wasn't all that good and the charges for soda were quite ridiculous. I mean come on!
author: Noora T.

description:
This is the second time I've reviewed the Zuni Cafe.  Actually, the quality of the food and the service is fine and I ordinarily would have given it four stars except for the fact that the value isn't there.  To me, a good value is a huge thing.  A good example of a good value is Gary Danko.  Yes, a good meal there does not come cheap but the quality of the food, the service, the ambience etc. make it an exceptional value.  Now back to the Zuni.  One example was my caesar salad.  There was no problem with the taste or even the portion but I was charged an extra $2.50 for anchovies.  Well, a "real" caesar salad should come with anchovies!  Look it up!  Just like chow mein comes with noodles or fried rice comes with rice!!!  The other negative was the $15.00 hamburger my wife ordered.  It was prepared perfectly and was very tasty, but it basically came with nothing else.  Grilled onions was an extra $1.25, cheese was even more and the whole thing came on a salad plate.  No fries came with it, so we had to order a side of shoestring potato fries which was $3.50.  Those should have accompanied the hamburger at no extra charge.  So an ordinary hamburger was, without tax or tip, $19.75!  Really????  How the hell do you get away with that???  Oh, I forgot that yuppies basically don't give a shit.  They don't mind be over charged.  Keep in mind, that hamburger could have been over $22.00 if my wife had ordered cheese with it.  Is any grilled hamburger worth that???

Anyway, Zuni, the previous time I dined at your establishment was about three or four years ago.  That was only because the group I was with chose it.  I dined there today because our son, who is here from London, chose it.  I would never elect to dine here on my own.

To summarize:

Service - 4.5 stars
Food     - 3.5 stars
Value -    0 stars
author: geoff k.

description: Man i thought the chicken was going to be played out but nope. Lived up to all the hype. Best chicken ever and I'm not even a huge chicken fan.
author: Hope K.

description:
I've been dying to try this place for the longest time! 

I came here for a lunch for one, one Friday afternoon after a gig. The service is very nice, and I liked that the menu wasn't huge and overwhelming.. I don't even usually like pork.. but I saw it on another table and had to order! I'm so glad I did.  The pork chops (came with polenta and spinach, and a mushroom reduction on top. yum) were soo juicy and flavorful.. I felt like a big porker for practically finishing the entire thing. Yea, a girl.. eating a giant pork chop for lunch by herself. Imagine that! ha. For dessert, I ordered the pistachio praline ice cream. It was good.. but not amazing.. I probably wouldn't order or recommend it again. 

I thought the pricing was a bit more than it should be.. I paid about $50 just for myself (pork chop, glass of wine, and scoop of ice cream).. 

Parking would probably suck here (doesn't it everywhere in SF?).. but I paid $10 for the valet.. I'm all about convenience. Gee.. I just added that all up.. Lunch for one == $60? Baller! Yea, I'm totally not. 

BUT, I still can't wait to come back with people so I can try more dishes -- the chicken for two, huge caesar salad, etc.. Everything looked soo good!!
author: Tammy S.

description:
Zuni has a lot going for them, but in the end it isn't enough for me to want to go back.  We got there before our reservation and hung out at the bar.  The wedged building makes for an interesting layout and I think they did a nice job with the space they had.

I didn't have any cocktails, but this doesn't seem like a place you would stop by just for a drink.  We were seated upstairs on the balcony/loft area.  The openness and huge windows makes for great ambiance, but unfortunately terrible acoustics.  It's a bit loud and not the easiest place to have a conversation with more than 4 people (we had 6 and and resorted to generally splitting into 2 or 3 different conversations)

The service was very attentive and friendly.  My water was constantly being filled and drinks were well attended.  I ordered the pork, which was recommended by the waiter.  It was very tender -- but very sadly lacked flavor.  The best part of the meal by far were the carrots.  I will give them credit for having fresh horseradish on hand -- but the horseradish wasn't strong, even after dumping it all over my food -- I still craved more flavor!

If it were a 15 dollar meal I would give them a higher rating, but for a $30 dish it was disappointing and unfortunately, not worth the money.  Corey didn't share his salmon, but he had the same conclusion.  Fish, bad.  Carrots, good.
author: Van W.

description:
Soggy bread.

I did end up returning for the signature chicken. Wanted to love. Just liked.

The space remains the highlight. Still love the open windows. Amused by tables up the stairs and down the stairs and in little rooms off to the side.

Waiter was pleasant, welcoming and genuinely interested in making our visit enjoyable. 

Food started strong. House-cured anchovies was an interesting build your own "sandwich" with cheese, celery, and the anchovies. Unique and enjoyable.

Second starter was a blood orange and Cara Cara orange combo. The two get along rather nicely.

Last and unfortunately least was the roasted chicken with warm bread salad. $48 for two.

I wish I could say the chicken set a new precedent for taste . . . but it tasted more like what I can cook at home. Bread salad base was unique but drenched from the chicken juice and dressing. Each bite was less a revelation and more a soggy disappointment.

Three stars for the windows and the very good starters despite the underwhelming finale. Zuni is loved by most. But not by all.
author: Jason B.

description: I wish I liked it. I really do but another disappointment but I checked it off my list. The caesar salad was good but nothing too special. We ordered the chicken and I would have to say it isn't worth the wait or the price tag. I do have to admit, the flavor does go all way down to the bone and it was tender but eh, wasn't impressed enough. I guess I am just picky.  The bread salad that came with the chicken had kicks of tartness from the dressing but then another bite there wouldn't be any flavoring at all. The halibut needed more salt and flavoring in general. The food was good and it's a beautiful restaurant but I don't think I would come back.
author: Eve C.

description: This place is just down the street from my work and I've been here at least 4+ times for work meetings/lunch, or just with friends.  It's nice and intimate, and has a nice ambiance for groups. The food is really pretty good, I've had better that's cheaper and with bigger potions.  But you do have to try the chicken if you have time, I believe it's like a 30-45 min wait.  For lunch I do the pizza or the caesar salad (which they are known for).  This place is a must go if you live or visit San Francisco. It's like a San Francisco staple.
author: Joanne D.

description:
Yah, if you are a chicken fan, it is a good joint. (no double entendre intended).

Having lunched (is that a word?) here a few times (on biz).....

The Zuni hype..... the cookbooks....the chef...the food ........  overated.

Service is arrogant "yah, I work at Zuni....get over it"

Come on, itsa decent place, visable location (seen & be seen).

Great food..... ahhhh no, service is spotty, seen & be seen factor is high (hey I had lunch at Zuni...woooowhoooo).
author: Matsuo U.

description:
Went for the first time after receiving a reco from a number of people.

Unfortunately it was our most disappointing meal in the city- the chicken that everyone raves about was good but not worth the wait! The other appetizers were fine but again nothing special. It was very high priced for the quality and compared to all the other places in the city.
author: Amanda M.

description:
I've eaten here 6 times over the past 20 years.  Again on 01-19-2008.

Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco version of a Paris Brasserie.  In that:  the menu has a focused small number of selections, the waiters wear white shirts, ties and vests. The tables are covered in crisp white butcher paper,  the food can be middling to great,  the prices are over the top too high for what you get.

Yet, I like the food most of the time here.  Last night the house salad was skimpy in size and a little too vinegar-ed-up with the balsamic.  My white pizza was okay, if a little too chewy. Bambie' fish was delicious but the portion, again, was too skimpy. Caramel creme was rich & tasty, the espresso is top notch.

We had one pre-meal cocktail each and a glass of wine each with the food.

Was our 4:00PM "between meals" snack worth $128 with tip - No way!   But the ground floor was packed with good looking rich folks, & the buzz was lively.  The service was cheerful & efficient.   I paid dearly to be part of the spectacle.

I'll come back again in another 6 years, it's my SF civic duty.
author: Tom S.

description:
Wish I had read the reviews before making reservations.  I've had dinner here before and loved it so I made reservations for 3 on Saturday night.  We ended up being 4 and apologized when we got there and then it went south from there.

We waited almost 40 minutes for a table while it was clearly slowing down and it looked like there were tables available.  When we were seated the very hairy waiter ( long, fuzzy beard) acted like he'd rather be anywhere else than waiting on us.  We ended up walking out after an order of fries and a few glasses of wine and no one seemed to care that much.  We couldn't get anyone to come to the table except the busboy who was FANTASTIC and clearly understood what our waiter was all about.

Won't be going back or recommending until they fix what looks like an obvious lapse in service over the past year or so.
author: G. P.

description: The famous chicken dish lived up to the hype! Great oysters, cocktails, atmosphere, servers, and wine list!
author: Kirsten B.

description: We really enjoyed our meal here.  Ordered a salad and then the roast chicken.  Kids ate the chicken also and enjoyed a plate of pasta.  Server couldn't have been nicer and the space was lovely.  I would definately go again.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Forty eight dolla chicken!!
Good Lord...
How about if I give you two dollars and let me get a wing?!

Ok... gotta admit... the roasted chicken here is pretty finger licking good. Yes, I will smack my lips in public... I paid forty eight dolla for a chicken. If I was a sugar daddy this would be my KFC.

Throw in a side of Kumamoto oysters.... will ya!

You know why you aren't getting any Zuni roast chicken, son? Because you don't have a job! If you had a job you'd have Zuni chicken. So, you better enjoy your 99 cent Popeye's Tuesday Special.

Whoa... I sound like my parents.... scary.
author: Sam T.

description:
I consider Zuni my "special place" in the city- the ambiance, food, and people are always exactly what I want when I seek a totally fulfilling dining experience. You should try:

1. The oysters: fresh, delicious, and perfect to start the evening
2. The famous chicken: the bread salad underneath is just as good as the chicken itself
3. Any wine made especially for Zuni- once they had the Hirsch pinot and it was soooooo good. All other wines that are Zuni specialties have been really scrumptious

Everything else is good too- the salads, the pastas... very fresh and sized well. You will not be disappointed with Zuni :)
author: crystala t.
