description:
Food: 
I had the potato and corn soup with bits of zuccini in it. DIVINE. Slightly creamy, warm and comforting, but still light. A brilliant blend of flavors and textures. 
Then I split a pizza with my friend that involved nettles and lamb sausage. The pizza is very thin crust and cooked to perfection. The lamb sausage was the most delicious sausage I have ever bitten in to (and my friend who can't eat pork was delighted at the pork-free sausage-ness of it). Absolutely delish!
For dessert, we split a raspberry gratin - sweet, fresh, cool, with an amazing depth of raspberry goodness flavor. It was accompanied by two small truely perfect shortbread cookies. 

Service: 
Our waiter was friendly, attentive, and clearly knew and understood the menu exceptionally well. He was able to advise my friend on a few different drink options and answered all of my pain-staking questions about the dishes with clear knowledge not only of the ingredients, but of the flavors. 

Price: 
Three dishes, alcoholic beverage, and a dessert ran us $50. 

Ambiance:
Open, bright, clean, and fresh inside. However, it seems like almost all the seating is next to a window, so I think the ambiance would be strongly influenced by what it looked like outside.
author: Kat S.

description: You cant go wrong with the ceasar salad and the baked chicken, it was delish.  I will put zuni in my top 10 restaurants. Oh almost forgot, try the espresso granita for dessert, delish!!!
author: Sally A.

description:
PROS
- OYSTERS & CAESAR: Their oysters and caesar salad are still excellent.
- LOCATION: Beautiful building is probably what lets them get away with awful entrees and cheating on the wine.

CONS
- PROBLEM 1: BLAND DISAPPOINTING ENTREES
Their entree menu has devolved. Last night my friend's pork dish was swimming in a bland, grey-brown sauce, and the pork cut and pork sausage themselves were completely underseasoned. My ziti with tuna and eggplant was disappointing enough that I sent it back. The ziti were swimming in orange-colored oil and there was no concept of cohesion to this dish. Even sprinkling it with lemon and some salt could have made it come together. Nope, it was ziti in vegetable oil. Really gross. The waiter was courteous and allowed me to replace it with the ricotta gnocchi. That was slightly better but beware, it's actually a plate of cheese in gnocchi shapes swimming in white sauce, like baby food. 
- PROBLEM 2: WINE CHEATERS 
Zuni used to serve their wine in normal size wine glasses using the appropriate shape for the wine. Or maybe they only did so when accompanying a bottle? Last night they served us 4-ounce pours in sherry glasses for every wine style: rose, pinot noir and cabernet. It was a tiny sherry glass! Cost-wise they are cheating the customer. $12 for 4 ounces is what I'd pay at a tasting bar for 4 ounces of a fine wine, not the house cabernet at Zuni. 

I hope someone else takes over this gorgeous space and makes it into a real restaurant!
author: Heirloom Z.

description: as lways, service was excellent and food ...oh well, a bit pricey but hey still good a always.
author: Betty A.

description: This place was so so. Heard really good things about this place so decided to check it out with the gf. The verdict: not impressed. Super expensive meal for chicken and in all honesty, both my gf and I felt that Limon's chicken was much superior than this. The ambiance was nice and service was great, but food, save the big tab for another place like house of prime rib where you actually feel like the food was worth worth the cost. Sorry Zuni, nothing personal.
author: Dixiee N.

description:
I came here about a year ago with my boyfriend and from what I recall, we ordered the skinny fries, polenta, and pizza with anchovies on it. Nothing really stood out for me then. 

I came here again with my friend recently on a 96 degree day in SF. What brought us here was the Roasted Chicken with Bread Salad for Two that's featured on the 7x7 list. 

When we got there, we weren't seated right away so we had to order drinks at the bar and wait. I asked a number of waiters if it was possible to put our order in ahead of time since the chicken does take one hour to make, but I had no luck. They all gave me some lame excuse with a snobby attitude which pissed me off. 

We were finally seated after about 30 minutes and what do ya know! We're seated right next to the firepit inside the non-airconditioned room. Just perfect! Even after we were seated, no one even acknowledged us for about 10 minutes so I had to wave one of them down to go find our server. After waiting, and waiting, and more waiting, we finally got our chicken. 

The dish was MEH. The chicken was juicy, but not worth the 1 hour wait. The bread part of the bread salad was the tastiest component of the dish. It was soaked in something that my friend and I couldn't figure out but tasted oddly familiar.

Zuni, I would've given you more stars, but your service STINKS! Goodbye
author: Olivia T.

description: This might be one of the best meals I've ever had. If you're into wine, try the Riesling for white or the Burgundy for red. You'll find yourself ordering two or three glasses. Simply irresistible.
author: I G.

description: Food was good, but not amazing. They have a lamb sausage appetizer that is 1 small sausage for $12 (avoid) Shoestring potatoes are excellent as is Caesar salad. Roasted Chicken is good, not great. Fog City has the best roasted chicken I have tasted in SF.  I was really hoping chicken would be more moist and the presentation wasn't that great either. I would definitely go back but its not on the top of my list.
author: Macmall M.

description:
Not gonna lie, when I was told to go here and order the "chicken," I was a little skeptical. 

Really? Roasted chicken?

REALLY.

GET THE ROASTED CHICKEN.

I don't know what it is, I mean, it tastes like it's just seasoned with seasoning salt, but holy.hell.it's.delicious. Perhaps it's something to do with the brick oven? The tangy stuffing? Who knows, but it's DELISH.

We started off with an assortment of Oysters (which are my total fave). I still haven't gotten the different kinds down pat, but I'm learning. Slowly.

The Caesar salad is delicious, too.

Fantastic spin on a classic meal.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Mmmm...Roast Chicken. There's something so warm and comforting about roast chicken. As far as roast chicken goes, Zuni has the best by far. Their Chicken for two seems to actually be able to feed your inner soul. The whole chicken is roasted in their brick oven and served with the perfect accompaniment - warm bread salad with red mustard greens, scallions, currants, and pine nuts. I am still baffled at how the chefs are able to cook such a succulent and flavorful roast chicken. All the natural juices are contained within the chicken as it's roasted which results in the most flavorful and juicy chicken I have ever tasted. Even the white meat is juicy and flavorful. The dark meat is even better! The only thing that can make the roast chicken even better is their amazing bread salad. The bitterness from the frisee or mustard greens adds depth to the dish while the tangy vinaigrette and currants add a high acidic note to balance the entire dish. It's absolutely mind blowing! A glass of pinot noir and you'll be in heaven. 

The house-cured anchovies with celery, parmesan, and niçoise olives is a great starter to prep your palate for the rock-n-roll ride that is to come an hour later when your chicken is ready. The marinated beets and avocado salad is also exquisitely prepared and subtly refined. The lamb sausage and squid crostini, however, was not as great. The flavors were a bit muddled and too heavy IMO. The arugula wasn't strong enough to add any balance to the gaminess or brininess from the sausage and squid. 

I have also noticed that there seems to be mixed reviews about Zuni. I've come to realize that it really depends on the chicken that you get. Which can vary even on the same night that you're there. Case in point, we ordered 2 orders of the roast chicken as soon as we were seated for our dinner reservation. An hour later, our server shows up with only 1 order. *Gasp* Needless to say we were extremely disappointed since it was already 10pm by this time and we were all starving even after sharing 3 appetizers. Our server was sincerely apologetic about the mix up and managed to switch things around with the kitchen so that we wouldn't have to wait another hour for our other chicken. We went about devouring our first chicken hoping that it would satiate our appetites until the second one arrived. I noticed that this first chicken was not as good as what I remembered from the first time dining here. It was still juicy but not as juicy and flavorful as the first time. There also wasn't much greens that came with the bread salad which also seemed to have not been dressed with enough vinaigrette. Perhaps this one didn't get the loving care and attention it deserved and came out not so spectacular. 

We mentioned the skimpiness of the bread salad to our server and he surprised us with a whole side plate of bread salad topped with greens when he came with our second chicken. This one was divine. Back to the roast chicken that I had so fondly remembered. Perhaps it was the extra care that went into this second chicken since they wanted to provide superb service. All I know is, when it's spot-on, it's spot-on. Nothing short of amazing. On a side note, our server even waived our corkage fee because of the mix up. How awesome is that!
author: Diana H.

description:
Came here on Sunday bc it was still open after 10pm. We were trying to find a good restaurant to eat drink and mingle for a bit before hitting the town.

Its a nice place w pretty good service. Everyone was very friendly. Started off with the rabbit as an appetizer. Tasted just like chicken so pretty tasty. Also ordered an order of fries since we ordered the 1 hour chicken. Fries are always fries. Nothing too special about them. The $50 dollar chicken was good but not great and maybe it was bc of the price. Who pays $50 dollars for chicken? Apparently we do and alot of other people too. Supposedly i heard the recipe is online...I think I will take that route next time. After dinner we just werent excited to go out anymore...maybe it was the food, the drinks or maybe the 10 hours of walking we did all day touring the city?
author: Thao N.

description: I feel like chicken tonight! Well this is the perfect place to get an amazing brick oven roasted chicken- it takes an hour so make sure you let them know as soon as you arrive. Delicious! The appetizers were light and perfect- we had lamb rocca, raw porcini mushrooms and clams. Restaurant is huge and open, looks like alot of regulars go to this resto too. So if you want chicken, this is THE place.
author: Ennie L.

description:
I had heard a lot about zuni before (finally) trying it out.  Here's the low down from my perspective:

(1) Refined food, subtle tastes but small portions

(2) Expensive, but classy enough to pull off burgers and pizza at those kind of prices.

(3) The layout of the place is weird - there are three doors and the main door is actually the side street entrance.  (huh).

(4)  Would I go back?  Sure, but not often. The meat of my foccacia burger was pretty darn good - I don't think I've ever had burger meat quite so good.
author: Shinny L.

description:
Came here post cheese plate and wine at Hôtel Biron.  Place about an hour and a half away from closing.  Always love coming here and because of the location and design, feel as if I'm boarding a large ship (whatever, right?)  

We ordered ceviche and an English pea risotto (Risi e Bisi).  Wines, service and ceviche were all on par.  Risotto was not.  Not creamy and rich, but runny and soup like with rice that was al dente.  I make killer risotto, so from experience this was rushed.  The key to making risotto is patience and allowing liquid to slowly thicken.  Needless to say, we sent the dish back.

Noticed a woman at a nearby table eating the same thing.  Liquid was dripping from her spoonful of risotto.  Poor lady ate it up, no complaints.  Like fingernails across a chalk board.  All we could do was cringe.  

Had a panna cotta for dessert that was nice, but not make-you-forget-the-horrible-risotto nice.  No worries, I often have off nights myself.  But on my worse ones, I'd still make a better risotto.
author: Kalani C.

description: Always something ridiculous at this place. Went there yesterday for cocktails and some appetizers, asked the waiter for an order of fries: "We Don't Have Them This Time Of Year Due To The High Sugar Content In The Potatoes Which Makes Them Burn Easily In The Frying Process" OOOOKKKK...Got our fries at Absinthe, crispy, tasty and not burned!
author: ray m.

description: Dissapointing.  The service was mediocre, the chicken did NOT live up to any of their reviews..  Yes it was tender and juicy, but it was also bland and not at all worth the price!!  I've had way better like Good Frickin Chicken or Front Porch.  This is one of those hyped up places that is over priced and definitely overrated.
author: irene u.

description:
Zuni Cafe is simply amazing. Let's skip past how cool the triangular building is and get right to the food...

Whenever my mom visits, my uncles and I head over to Zuni because we can all eat our favorite food - chicken. If you haven't tried it yet, try the chicken with bread salad. It really does take an hour, so order it as soon as you sit down if you're in the market for a short evening, but if you've got the time, it's sooooo worth it.

Everything else on the menu is pretty damn good, too. If you're an oyster person, Zuni always has a great selection of fresh oysters. All of their ingredients are always local and incredibly fresh, and the menu changes regularly, something I always love at a restaurant with a great chef. I'd also recommend the caesar salad - big hearts of romaine, excellent croutons and great homemade dressing - and the chocolate dessert (unfortunately can't remember what it's called). 

There is valet parking (but it's pretty damn expensive), and I'd recommend calling ahead and making a reservation since the space is small.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Overrated. 

Went here for the alleged best burger in SF. Untrue. The burger was overcooked. The bun wasn't that great, it's uneven texture threw me off a bit. The homemade pickles were good. Grilled onions weren't anything special but the burger wouldn't have been as good without them, so plan on spending more for those guys. 

Props for using my favorite gruyere Roth's Private Reserve. 

Bottom line: overpriced burger that wasn't worth its cost.
author: Mike I.

description:
I still love eating here! Finally tried the chicken and yes it was very juicy, even some of the white pieces that look like they could be dry. It's great with the rose they recommend that has a beautiful golden hue. 

Also worth mentioning was the lamb- so succulent and flavorful. 

Service is consistently good, I just wish they heated their complimentary bread.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Good food, overpriced. This sums up my whole review of dinner at Zuni Cafe.
Dinner for 3 persons consisted of a dozen oysters, 2 salads, one rotisserie chicken and 4 drinks.  Final tab: $170 before tip.
The service and the ambiance were pleasant enough, and it makes one feel very special to pay $50 for what is basically a roasted chicken, not very far from Costco's own rotisserie.
It puzzles me that people are willing to pay that much for some very basic ingredients and preparation style, however the meal itself was overall satisfying.
author: Laura S.

description:
INTRO:

Key words: It's all they say it is. 

It was my birthday and I was at the JCC listening to a reading from Ruth Reichl. One of the people in the audience asked her where she ate when she was in San Francisco. She said Zuni Cafe, and this made me realize that I had never been to Zuni. I don't know why I never went to Zuni, all I can say now is that I was missing out all those years. 


FOOD:

Frisée salad with sultana raisins in anisette, Manchego, hazelnuts, and shallot vinaigrette 8.25

Red wine braised oxtails and short ribs with a poached egg and chard 16.50

Above are some items that my BF and I ate during our two visits. The first time we had a duck dish with some sort of hearty grain and capers that was just completely fabulous (but it wasn't on the  menu so I can't tell you what it's called). It was a bit oily, but in this irresistable way. The meat was slivered and was a red pinkish color. It had such a range of textures and taste that in the end all blended amazingly together. God, I loved those grains whatever they were!

On our second visit we started out with a tray of oysters, two of which were the miyagi and the pacific. The pacific are by far the best oysters I've had. They are briney and have this velvet milky soft finish that I've never had before. I ordered more. 

The frissee salad is fresh and light, but I wouldn't recommend it compared to some of Zuni's other dishes. 

The oxtail was our entree for that visit and it was so tender! One bite was as soft as milky mash potatoes. It came out beautifully decorateed with orange flowers and the dark red wine sauce.

BOOZE:

The wine here is great. When you say you like light bodied juicy wines they bring you the perfect strawberry scented pinot with a spice. Their cocktails are also great, featuring not so girly tasting drinks that might have otherwise appeared to be girly (Anytime someone mentions citrus you could be in for trouble, remember). 

SERVICE:

Excellent. Especially on my birthday. The staff is a mix of friendly and professional. It's never hard to get a hold of them, even when you're on a time budget.
author: Alexandra M.

description:
The ambiance here is the best feature - classy, quiet, urban and sophisticated, with a touch of "french country" a-la stacks of firewood for the wood-fired pizza oven.  

The food is so-so, frankly I was not tremendously impressed with the polenta...but a lovely place for lunch none the less!
author: Josh T.

description:
Wanted to love it but was very disappointed.  Way too expensive, the seating is too tight and thus no privacy.  The food was boring. 

Some restaurants exist on a reputation earned from past performance.  Save your money and your precious time..
author: jenUwine G.

description: I die for their roasted chicken and bread salad. ZOMG.
author: Charlene S.

description:
I've been here a few times now and I just love how reliably good everything about Zuni is. Servers are so friendly and they have a great selection of drinks, appetizers, entrees, desserts...  It's perfect for a full meal or just to grab a drink and dessert (which I am often in the mood for). 

I think the prices are incredibly reasonable for what you're getting... I don't feel like they surprise you with small portions which is often the case at nicer places. And of course it's all delicious.

I had their piccola meringata last night, but it looks like they change up their menus pretty often. This time it came with almonds, chocolate sauce, and some kind of coffee cream layered in between.... incredibly good.

Also can't beat the space. Easily one of the coziest, most interesting dining spaces in SF.
author: Richa A.

description: You know I have to confess. Eating the much hyped, acclaimed, fêted baked chicken was worth the wait (one hour). It did not disappoint at 11pm, otherwise the angry beast in my stomach would have stuck its head out and roared like an elephant stumping around with its trunk in the air. What was I saying? Ah yes something about being very hungry and a moment later very pleased at cutting into that golden chicken (crispy skin so good I forgot all things fat and cholesterol related) and biting into a most succulent and juicy bird. It's about $50 for the chicken. But it is a whole damn chicken and given just how good it looks and tastes it's well worth it. Also, unless you're completely famished the portion is more than enough for you and your two best friends. Seriously, the menu says "for two" but it should say "for two plus a third unless that third person is really a hungry Bengal tiger." I hope that conveys what I saw and what I relished. I had leftovers for lunch (I made a quick sandwich - bread from Rustic Bakery, the deservedly famous chicken (remnants thereof), some lettuce and a dash of vinegar). I inhaled that Zuni chicken as if I was about to ship off for Mars and had to subsist on those meals in a bag for the next two to three years. Every bite, every act of chomping down and noshing on that sandwich was savored. This is as good as chicken gets. The food by itself would be a five but given other considerations (service, plating, wait time etc) four stars it is. There is no fault in these stars and no shame in four big ones.
author: Jahan T.

description: If you have Zuni Cafe's famous roast chicken, then order the minute you sit down! Ours clocked in at 1 hour 20 minutes. It certainly is moist and good (though not excellent in my opinion), but it's debatable if it's worth the wait. I might be biased, because I find that roast chicken overall doesn't have a lot of nuance.
author: Simon T.

description:
It's a sad day when I have to give ANOTHER 7x7 restaurant a 2-star rating. This was me and Olivia's last lunch stop before she had to head back to school. 

We arrived at 12:30PM, and had to wait for 20 minutes at a bar with NO SEATS, NO AC/FAN on a scorching hot day, and NO SERVICE. When they finally handed us a menu, I was appalled by the paper menu. PAPER MENUS!? The "nice paper" showed remnants of various water stains made by people who weren't provided with coasters.

We wanted to make efficient use of our time by ordering the roast chicken (which takes at least an hour) in advance, but after asking multiple workers, they all told us it was just too inefficient for their kitchen to take our order when we haven't been seated. UGH!

After seating me near a fireplace, 10 minutes of waiting for someone to ask us what we'd like to drink, and another hour and ten minutes for the chicken to be served, I was set on giving them a 1 star.

The additional star is for the my favorite part of our dish:

(MEH!) TUSCAN BREAD SALAD w/ roast chicken [$48]: This dish is meant to serve 2, but could probably serve 3 as well. The salad had a hint of wasabi/mustard flavor, and the soggy tuscan bread dipped in all that oil was YUM! The roast chicken...was not up to par. It was juicy, yet flavorless. You could find better at Limon Rotisserie, which is on the 7x7 AND a lot cheaper than this place.

Trust me yelpers, you deserve better.
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
I went here with a group of 5 friends the other day, just before a piano recital across the street.

Our reservation was messed up and the hostess and manager were not very helpful.  When we finally got it sorted out we were treated with respect, but not until.  

I would go with a close friend or two, but wouldn't risk going with a business prospect or partner.
author: David H.

description: Yummy. :) I enjoyed the roasted chicken and clams!
author: Marian H.

description:
3.5 to 4ish

went in with a high expectation for their famous chicken. it was juicy and tender, but overall pretty mediocre.  not sure if it's worth the hour long wait or the $50 price tag... went back once more to see if i was there on a off-night but i stay true to my verdict. 

Other dishes (lamb especially) were solid. Salads were good. Extensive wine/cocktail selection. Just felt like their chicken was way too hyped up.
author: Miri Kwon R.

description: We were full for six hours following a late lunch here yesterday.  Four of us shared burgers, pizza, fries, Caesar salad and downed them with margaritas.  All were fantastic!  Everyone left happy and satisfied.  This was my third time here, and just love it!
author: Susan B.

description: This is a true San Francisco institution.  Delicious food, very friendly staff and the locaiton is central to so many entertainment venues.
author: Brian P.

description:
Horrible service! I thought this
 place had some rep to uphold?...guess I was mistaken...easily one of the worst waiters in the world!...ouch zuni!
author: Kevin Q.

description:
A decent meal, but with a city full of amazing restaurants I don't know if I would go back. The seating is awkward in some areas of the restaurant, we asked to be moved when we were first placed in a funky corner area. But we were easily accommodated to a traditional table right next to the fire place.
I had a duck dish and my date had a pasta dish, both pretty tasty but not mind-blowing. The cheese plate left something to be desired. The wait staff were incredible and the highlight to this establishment: professional, attentive, but not too much.
author: Nicole M.

description:
My hubby and I popped into Zuni Cafe for lunch on our latest trip to SF.  I liked the space--very open, bright..  We sat in the back room against the brick wall.  

I was a bit underwhelmed by the brunch menu since I wanted to share whatever I got with Hub and he doesn't eat eggs.  Yes, no eggs, ever.  Almost settled on the burger, but we decided to split the chicken for 2.  So we ordered a bottle of wine and settled in for the wait.  Hub stared with a sampling of oysters (which he liked--tried some kinds that he hadn't tried before) and the anchovy salad.  Ok, so he didn't want to share, since I don't really eat oysters or anchovies.  Hmmmm.  I ordered the house-made salami with green bean salad.  The green beans were great but nothing special; I can get cute little green beans from the farmer's market here.  I really enjoyed the salami, though.

We did have to ask the waitress about the "Zuni pickles", since we're both pickle buffs.  She brought us a little plate of the pickles and the onions.  I like when servers do that.  

So finally, the chicken.  I thought it was excellent.  It was moist and juicy and falling off the bone.  It was salty, but I love salty.  I also liked the "bread salad"--I can't complain about buttery, balsamic, crunchy on the outside, chewy on the inside croutons.

I don't think I'd bother going back, but it was worth the visit.
author: Kelly T.

description:
I know some chefs who think Zuni is overrated.  

They are dismissive of the infamous chicken, saying that it's something they could make at home.  Well, the chicken is not something I could make at home, probably not even if I had Zuni's amazing ovens.  And I have my doubts about my chef companions too.

The service is stellar, the space is beautiful.  The chicken rocks.
author: Jane F.

description: Excited for a celebration dinner before a play.  Service was terrific!  Oysters were awesome the lamb was not, more like a brown turkey roll, for $30??? Not ok!
author: Carlanne F.

description:
Not many things live up to the hype, but the chicken does.  The bread salad on the bottom soaks up all the chicken goodness and is simply divine.  Wow. 

Great ambiance, awesome service and an extensive wine list top it all off.  This place is a must go.
author: David L.

description:
I've been to Zuni's a couple of times (it's right in that comfortable middle-ground for our staff lunches: better than the burritos and crap we'd buy for ourselves, but not so upscale that we seem like greedy wankers, fleecing our employer, who shall remain nameless), and really it's a 3.5 star place.

Buuuut... there seem to be a lot of missteps.  The wrong foods are oily, flavor is absent in unfortunate places, and the pricing is a little off, given the imperfection in the food.

Anyway, I've had me the pork chop, and the burger, as well as the fries, salad of one stripe or another, and a couple of desserts.  Oh, and the anchovies.

The worst of this group is the burger.  Flavorless, wet, and altogether mediocre; forgettable.  The accompanying pickled... I dunno, radish or whatever, was sweet and a poor accompaniment to the burger (which gets the pickles as a side, not fries).  Also: the burger has this yellow-y, bland mayonnaise stuff on it which thick, fatty, and also flavorless.  If I'm going to consume fat, it better taste good or there isn't a satisfactory quid pro quo.

The best is the pork chop. Thick, moist, well flavored , and the little potatoes with a tasty garlic oil is top notch.

I notice that they lean heavily on oils in the foodstuffs.  My garden salad--which one orders because one would like something light and, well, green--was absolutely sodden with olive oil.  Once I'd finished I could tilt the plate and a thick pool of the stuff gathered at the edge.  Again, olive oil need not be ladled on one's food, it's unnecessary.

The sides/appetizers were all good, although one (minor) complaint I had about the anchovies was that you're just using the same bread that's already on the table.  It'd be nice to have, say, some little toasted things for the cheese and anchovies, rather than a plate of communal bread.

Desserts were boring, but good entries in the realm of predictable:  chocolate cake (Gateau Victoire, i.e., chocolate cake) is thick (as indense) but the a slight bitterness and ever so dry texture is quite tasty--the whipped cream is nice, too.

A $20 corkage for wine at lunchtime is sort of a gyp.

Finally, they have a note on the menu:  "Please note that a"4% Health Surcharge" will be added to your bill to support San Francisco's universal health care program."

My advice?  Raise your prices 4% and take that junk off of there. I, as a customer, do not like to be bombarded with how the restaurant plans to nickel & dime me, whilst taking passive-aggressive shots at the social service intentions of San Francisco.  Take that off the menu, you've already got the obligatory "18% gratuity for parties of 6 or more" muddying the menu, why add to the unwelcoming tone with another report of a 4% surcharge? It's just annoying to the customer, IMHO.

All in all, an adequate experience.  Would I go back? Sure, on someone else's dime.  Would I ever buy a meal there myself?

No.
author: Martin W.

description:
When I place has this many reviews I generally don't review it unless I disagree with the star rating.  I saw lots of folks getting the whole chicken, it looked good but I didn't have an hour to kill.  Plus it's roasted chicken, eh.

This meal was a late sunday lunch, nothing stood out.  I had green beans with poached eggs and "bacon vinagrette," it was nothing to write home about.  Wife had french toast, soggy but tasty.  The fettucine with morel mushrooms were apparently good, but my friend didn't seem to enjoy the egg and rapini dish.

I probably would try Zuni for dinner, but I'm not having brunch/lunch there again.  My guess is that the "B" team cooks sunday brunch.  The drinks were good.
author: Shen J.

description:
I love Zuni. I just do. And no matter what the experience I have, I will not be a hater. My visiting friend and I popped into Zuni for a quick dinner. Impossible you say? No such thing as a quick dinner at Zuni? Well, I am here to tell you that it can be done! By ordering the roast chicken with panzanella salad even. I made reservations for 830 Wednesday. We were seated promptly and were both a little tired from booze and cheese at the cliff house . We just had a whirlwind tour of SF. So we were tired. We immediately ordered the roast chicken from a server that was annoyed that her up selling did not work. Just bring us the chicken!!! Stat!
We had the chicken by 910. The thought of undercooked chicken scared me. The thought that some other table was now waiting longer for their chicken made me a little dismayed but the overwhelming smell of deliciousness engulfed me. We dived in and were done with the dish at 940. Ok, so we were a little unladylike and might have scared off the 4 Ambercrombie and Fitch queens next to us but, I like chicken.
We were in the car by 950. That's a quick dinner at Zuni.
author: Amanda T.

description:
Came here to celebrate a friend's birthday, we ventured out to this area after we saw that the Roasted Chicken for two was featured on the 7 x 7 list.  It normally takes 45 minutes to an hour to prepare, so we told the person at the front when we arrived prior to our reservations.  We also tried the polenta, which was warm and filling, but didn't seem that different from other polenta's that I've sampled.  Shortly thereafter, we got the Roasted Chicken, and at first bite, it was good, it was a roast chicken, the execution of the dish was good, the chicken wasn't overcooked, and pretty moist.  

The skin had a nice flavor to it, but it was accompanied by a bread salad, which I initially thought was going to be similar to a dressing, and while the mustard greens, scallions, currants, and pine nuts offered a nice nutty aroma, tartness with the greens lightly wilted and were very good.  But the bread soaked up the oil from the chicken and rather then being roasted and caramelized by it, it was little bits of greasy and soggy bread.  The rest of the dish wasn't bad, but because it was on the 7x7 list, I guess I had my hopes up.  I think I would have been even more disappointed if I had to wait the full amount of time for it.  Still the service here was extremely attentive, and I did like the sheik trendy atmosphere with many little nooks to sit down and have a meal.  But considering the attention that they got for their house specialty, it left me desiring for a little more.
author: Chris T.

description:
This San Francisco staple is still quite good after all these years. You won't really come to be blown away with the culinary bleeding edge, you come for a good satisfying meal. The menu is without a bad dish, at least not one that I've ever tried. Service is pretty good as well. Friendly and helpful good people.

I would certainly return.
author: Marcus F.

description: I thought the chicken was pretty good. Nothing else was that memorable.
author: Michael E.

description:
I eat at Zuni once every few years, for some reason it's not on my radar (probably the location/parking), and it's consistent: good but not great, solid, dependable, good place to bring out of town guests for those reasons.

I dined there very recently, and my feeling was that the place has gone downhill. Two things stand out:

1. I ordered a glass of wine to start, and my friend the same. The waiter said, "Would you like to order a bottle instead?"

Yes, I get the upsell, but I've never ever had this particular upsell before. If we wanted a bottle we'd've ordered a bottle, not two glasses. A full bottle is a committment for two people, not only monetarily but alcoholicly. We needed to drive afterwards, and one glass was fine, which is why we ordered one glass apiece.

"Can I get the grilled chicken breast please?"
"Are you sure you don't want a WHOLE ROAST CHICKEN?"
"Yes, I'm pretty damn sure I don't want a whole roast chicken: it's 4x the price, more than I can eat, and if that's what I wanted I would've ordered it. Why ask the question except to make yourself look both greedy and stupid?"

2. I had the grilled salmon with roast potatoes/fava beans. The salmon was fine, the whole dish a bit too room temp, but the potatoes/beans were cold. I don't mean room temp cold, I mean refrigerator cold. So cold that I asked whether it was intentional. Now they weren't bad mind you, but they were at odds with the warm salmon. They were not supposed to be cold, and the waiter offered to bring a side of the same. I realized that this meant most probably that Zuni stores the pre-cut potatoes/beans in the fridge, and sautes them per order. Except someone forgot with this order.

What came was a side of roasted potatoes with no beans, and I didn't even comment. Without the beans, the potatoes were boring.

We ended with a completely forgettable dessert, and my share of the bill was $80.

Really?
$80 for what I had was twice what the meal was worth.
I'll not be back unless someone else is paying.
author: Rob C.

description:
Chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken.

A long-standing establishment in SF, it is classy, elegant, and absolutely not to be missed for their roast chicken with bread salad. Make sure you arrive with over an hour to spare to allow enough time to wait for it (and eat it on-site), as well as at least $48 to afford it (number doesn't include add'l needed for tax and tip). The ricotta gnocchi are also the best heavenly soft pillows of delight I've ever tasted. But it's still all about the roast chicken.

Mmm. Chicken.

Chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken, chicken.
author: ChiYan T.

description: I have been a customer for 20 years. It used to be so wonderful.  The chicken.  Everything else. It was all good.  It's still very good. However,  prices are now too high. Portions are now too small.  I am not planning on going back and I am sad about it.
author: Patale M.

description:
Woo I'm the 1000th review!

So I ate here yesterday. They have an amazing selection of oysters. My fave were the Marin Miyagi. Pricing seems about the same as Hog Island but you have more selection here. 

We didn't get the roast chicken since we were hung over and needed something to fill our tummies now. Lol. So we both got the burgers. I think both of our burgers were a bit overcooked. I asked for medium rare and saw no red and barely any pink in the burger. The pickels and onions that came with it were definitely different. The garlic aioli added some wonderful tasting to the burger. But I did wish my burger was a bit more juicy and not as overcooked. Oh and those fries are AWESOME! I love crispy fries. I just wished they had mayo for me to dip it in! :) 

I'll definitely be back to try out the chicken. Til next time though!
author: Helen V.

description:
Great food and drinks, and yet this is expected in San Francisco.   So when a premium is charged, you have to really excel.  Yet, Zuni did not really do so.  Nothing wrong mind you, but you can save $100 and go someplace with just as good of food and service.

$48 chicken that takes an hour, really?  Not 10x better than a Costco roasted Chicken for $4.99.

Bottomline, over rated and over priced.
author: Jas S.

description:
I recently visited Zuni on a Friday night for dinner.  The restaurant was packed (as to be expected) and our reservation didn't make much of a difference (we had to wait ~45 minutes to be seated). I ordered the ricotta gnocchi with brussel sprouts, which was absolutely delicious.  Portions are on the smaller side (even for SF), so Zuni is arguably overpriced.

The main drawback to Zuni was the awful service (as measured by (i) wait time, (ii) time required to place an order, (iii) the fact that the plates that we got were a bit dirty (as were their replacements - but 3rd time's the charm), and (iv) the overall inattentiveness of the wait staff. I had been told to visit Zuni by several folks and was surprised that none of them had mentioned any service issues. I wish my experience would have been better, but it wasn't, and in a city with as many great restaurants as SF, it doesn't make the grade as a "must visit" restaurant.
author: Rishi N.

description:
We love it here.  

Fresh local ingredients.  Great service. Great food. Best roast chicken. Yummy seafood bar. What more can you ask for? 

Highly recommend for anyone. Even the finicky eaters because there is something for everyone.

Oh, and do yourself a favor and make a reservation. The wait can be loooong. Especially when you're in a cramped area. And it's cold outside.
author: Mai M.

description: A lovely restaurant where I hope to be eating the roasted chicken with bread salad for at least the next 20 years.  Everything is simple and thoughtful that keeps you wondering why something so basic is so beautiful.  I love the airy feel of the restaurant and how it feels elegant yet comfortable.  One of my favorite SF standbys.  Never miss dessert here, it is always fabulous.
author: Jenn N.

description: Still great after decades.  Make sure you don't plan anything else after dinner as there will be a long wait for the chicken to be prepared and cooked.  Well worth the wait though. Great burger and excellent Cesar salad!  Nice open and airy atmosphere.  Highly recommended.
author: Calvin J.

description: Ambiance and setting makes up a portion of the experience - so I was terribly disappointed with Zuni Cafe from the moment we arrived.  The host was dismissive and unfriendly.  I've been and experienced some of the most amazing restaurants from San Fran to Paris and even in these other qualifying areas the hosts are always pleasant.  I noticed the culture in here came from the top when I witnessed the manager being rude and dismissive to the guest sitting across from us.  They were celebrating a family reunion and he asked them to not take photos as they were bothering us.  Which was totally inaccurate - suddenly the folks looked at us cross eyed as if we had complained.  We clarified with them and  we carried on.  The food: chicken was not worth the 75 minute wait and I guarantee you can get a better quality and savory from Hillstone. Everything else we had was meh, by far the favorite was there fries.  Won't be coming back here again, unless these people get their perspective right and stop... Playing like they're in Beverly Hills or Manhattan.
author: JC K.

description: Zuni is a San Francisco icon and my Favorite on all scales of Food, Service, Ambiance.  Its always a treat.
author: David C.

description: I was excited to eat here. I've only had brunch prior to tonight's dinner.  Unfortunately, the food and service was subpar. My friend ordered the spaghetti, but why did it taste like chow mein and the plating of it was very amateur. My other friend had the gnocchi and it seemed like it was overcooked and sitting in water for a long time. I had the rib eye. It was ok but not $30 worth. I never got a refill of my water. Most likely will not be coming back to this restaurant and will not recommend to anyone.
author: R R.

description: One of my all time FAVORITE restaurants. Best chichen on planet earth...... whenver I can splurge, I think of Zuni.....Not that it's over priced.... it's worth every penny.... I just love to splurge when I eat there...... Chicken, Caesar Salad, Wine, Martinis..... such a great ambiance & polite staff... Love it....
author: Valerie M.

description: Sit at the bar, order oysters, sardines, soups or the chicken woth bread salad and champagne. You cannot go wrong here. One of my favorite restaurants and in SF hands down. :)
author: Robert K.

description: I wanted to give more but just can't get myself to review them better. For the price I was expecting better service and the food was good, but not to justify the pricing. We got the roast chicken for two, yes it was good, the stuffing was tasty (way too buttery) but for $50 no way!!! They forgot to bring our shoestring fries, I had to remind them to bring it...and we started off with a soup and salad. Bottom-line not very memorable food.
author: Misha Z.

description:
**3.5 stars**

Visited on a Saturday night with reservations made 3 weeks prior.

We were seated upstairs probably one of the worst tables in the house. Under the retrofit beams. They have such a beautiful open kitchen and in my opinion, that is the best place to dine, where the action is. The girl who showed us to our table offered to speak to the hostess and try to get us a better table, I declined...did not want to cause a problem for them as this place is extremely buisy. 
**My suggestion would be to make a special request at the time you make your reservation, to be seated in the kitchen area.**

Our server was friendly and helpful, but not over-bearing.

We started with manilla clams, while waiting for our roasted chicken. The clams were delicious, dipping the rustic Acme bread into the broth, we finished off two servings off bread!

The chicken came after about 45 min. (our waiter put in our order a few minutes after we were seated while getting our drinks.) This is where my anticipated 5 stars drops to 4 stars. This skin was nice and crispy, overall the chicken was extremely salty, the breast was very dry, thigh was nice. Over cooked and too salty. The stuffing under the chicken was tasty, but we could not manage to consume more than a couple of small bites. It was soaked in chicken grease and loads of butter. Just too much. Hard to believe coming from someone like me who's favorite food is french fries!! It does not have to be greasy to taste good. 

For desert we had the Gateaux Victoire (flourless chocolate cake)- this drops my rating down further. Fell apart into a crumbly mess when putting your fork into it. Lacked richness and chocolate flavour. 

Clams, Chicken, sparkling water-NOT mineral water- they do their own in house which is simply CO2 infused into tap water, one glass of sauv. blanc and chocolate cake = $110 

We expected so much more from them, considering the prices we paid, and the hype.
author: Linda V.

description: I've been dying to try this place forever, but have not been able to get reservations last couple of times in SF.  What a disappointment.  My husband had the salmon, which was lackluster.  I had the gnocchi, which was very good.  My arugula salad was ok, my husband's Caesar very good.  Desserts were just ok.  Service was competent, they were obviously busy.  Most uncomfortable chairs I've evert sat in.  The most astounding thing was the condition of their bathroom, at 8:30 the waste bins were overflowing with used hand towels and they were all over the floor.  The room was just plain dirty.  Sorry, but I do judge a restaurant in part by how clean and neat their bathrooms are, they don't have to be new.......but they do need to be clean.  I've just heard so many wonderful things about this restaurant; everyone has a bad night, but I don't think I'd chance going back, too expensive for that gamble.
author: Dodie E.

description: A bit on the pricier side, but that's what you'd note before going somewhere like this. The quality of the food however was well worth it. The chicken was amazing (expect it to take a while and they'll tell you that upfront). I'd definitely visit again.
author: Chloe B.

description:
The food was delicious. We started with marinated olives, about what you'd expect. Then I had spinach soup, which was creamy and hearty and tasty. Husband enjoyed his grapefruit/avocado salad, which was a small portion. Then I had gnocci for my entree--the ricotta made it soft and creamy. Husband had the pork, which was buttery and tender. The waitress was very attentive and friendly. 

Note: this place is in a ROUGH neighborhood. Do NOT walk here from Nob Hill as we did--take a cab. A local admonished me to do so, but I forgot until it was too late. Eek!
author: Kate P.

description: It was not as good as I thought! We went there for dinner. Very small portions and so pricey!! The tastes were good but not so yummy. Did not like the ambiance either. There are many good fancy restaurants in SF that I would recommend way more than this one.
author: Sara K.

description:
Very disappointed !
It was supposed to be one of our best dinner in SF and we chose this place because of the good reviews it has on the net . How is it possible ?
We were 3 people from different nationalities and age, all of us traveling a lot and with a good experience of food and wine. And we unfortunately agree that it was our worst value for money dinner in SF. Sorry to say that but nothing was good : small portion, not tasty, not well cooked, service very average ( nobody asked us if we liked our dishes , no greetings when leaving, poor wine service ) and we paid 200 dollars with no dessert and only one bottle of wine concerning the drinks.
May be we should have ordered the chicken. The pasta was a joke for 17 dollars ( not valued more than 5 dollars , really ) , the porchetta was just ok but it costs almost 30 dollars and the lamb was not well cooked ( one piece was rare and the over medium ). At the end of the dinner , we were still hungry but too disappointed to try a dessert.
Either we were very unlucky or there is a change of management or chef but the dinner we had don't deserve more than one star on yelp. Sorry for that , I know it is very hard to run a restaurant and we don't like to be so rude but not possible to say good things on this evening. I hope it was just an accident , it could happen but we try 5 different items on the menu.
author: Cyril P.

description:
Yep it's 10 stars all around. My wife and I made reservations to come here on a late night to enjoy some wining and dining. As we were led through the different dining rooms up and down stairs we noticed that most patrons were knifing at the 1 hour roasted chicken. I'll admit it looked awesome and big enough for two but we had already decided that we will not give into this foolishness because ordering chicken at a famous spot is not the most adventurous approach rather it is a more cost effective and safe approach.

For wine we brought our own bottle of Vincent Arroyo Petite Sirah and paid a $20 corkage fee.

We started with a wild arugula salad and it was a perfect balance of oil, vinegar, and cheese. The arugula is so fresh they must be growing it on the rooftop.

Appetizer numero dos was a show stopper and was recommended by our awesome very attentive waiter. The clams with squid covered in ancho chile sauce was 10 stars. These teeny tiny claims were creamy tender and the squid had a little crunch. The bar has been raised for squid texture for sure. I don't know if I will ever want to order squid anywhere else.

Main Course for Moi was the beef tenderloin rubbed in pepper with a side of spinach and sweet potatoes. Everything was perfect the meat was so soft I could cut it with my fork. The greens were charred crispy, a new technique to me, and they were awesome. Well done on an extraordinary way to enjoy spinach greens. The potatoes were sweet little roasted cubes of goodness.

Main Course for Le Madame was duck leg with fennel sausage. The duck was juicy soft with a delicate duck flavor. In contrast the sausage had powerful fennel freshness to it. The manager noted the sausage arriving a little late so we ended up getting a free desert. What a fresh breath of exceptional service.

For desert we had buckwheat crepes with orange and vanilla ice cream. We didn't exactly fall in love with wheat crepes because we are so used to white flour crepes but seriously once it was smothered in melting ice cream with sweet orange sauce and little pieces of orange on top, Who Cares!

We had a 10 star night at Zuni for $120 and we look forward to doing it again. Thanks Zuni!
author: R J.

description: Great evening ambiance. Get the roasted chicken to share, and sit by the kitchen for a unique view.
author: Anthony A.

description:
We had a 2:30 reservation so were given the afternoon menu-- not sure if that was a good or bad thing.  Maybe we should've ordered the roast chicken, but we were too hungry to wait an hour.  The polenta was bland and the pork chop was dry.  However, the fish of the day was really good.  For dessert we shared a caramel custard which was good, but not mind blowing.

Service was excellent.  The host and our waiter were friendly and attentive.  The restaurant itself feels open and inviting. Seating is a little strange though.  And I think we overpaid for what we got.  

I wish I could've loved it, but I didn't.
author: K V.

description: Everything is excellent- particularly the chicken for two (really it's for about four), the ceasar salad, the cocktails, and the service. Love this place!!
author: Lindsay K.

description: Impeccable service.  The chicken is an hour wait but worth it.  Wine selection and knowledge of services is amazing.  The fries are the best.  Salads inventive.
author: Caroline P.

description:
Finally got a chance to try Zuni for the first time the other night, and I have to say...it did live up to the hype.

That chicken is the best, most succulent and moist chicken I think I've ever had.  The "bread salad" that accompanies it is an offbeat choice, but I'm into it.  Provided a nice, acidic punch that complimented the chicken.  It was a slight bummer having to wait for the hour long cook time though..but worth it, I'll admit.

Also, I was very pleased with their oysters.  So much so that I've been craving oysters since having them, and I've gone for oysters twice since Zuni!  

The cocktail menu was unenthusiastic...as was the dessert menu.  But, I think the food stands strong enough to make up for that.  

Clintons favorite didn't disappoint.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
The Burger at Zuni Cafe....The grind was fine as polenta, and the flavor was pure, fishy skank.  It was also remarkably firm, which suggested that they took puréed ground round, added dashinomoto  (bonito flakes) or fish food, and an egg--whizzed it up in a food processor while going out back to smoke, and then caught up with an old friend for ten minutes before realizing the mixture was nearly liquified, and then saying "fuck it, let's serve it anyway.". The cooked burger ended up being a meatloaf made with Gerber baby food with the flavor of overly "ripe" salmon.  I assume that they did not bother trimming the beef deeply enough and handed us a burger made from the bacteria-rich rind of the dry-aged beef.

The worst burger that I have ever tried to eat--I could not finish half of it. 2 days later, and my insides are still not the same.
author: Pete N.

description: Very nice anniversary dinner. Everything was fresh and prepared well. I didn't love the gnocchi, but the salad was bright and the garlic crouton was terrific. I had the hanger steak with roasted marrow: lovely and very well cooked, though the waiter was worried it was too rare (it was close). They were also great about making sure we had enough time to make our 8 p.m. show and advised the best way to get a cab from there. The space is very inviting, with a wall of windows, but we were tucked away in the back, so we didn't get to experience it as much as we'd have wanted to. I'd say overall I agree with some of the other reviews here. The food was very good --I'd do a 3.5 if I could -- but it didn't feel as special as I wanted it to. I guess we should have had the chicken.
author: Melanie B.

description:
Go. Just.... go. Now. 

A few of my reasons:
1) It's been over a week and I still haven't shut up about this meal. 
2) Aperol cocktails.
3) Wonderfully charming and helpful server. The kind that, even though you know he doesn't play for your team, you still have a bit of a schoolgirl crush on. C'mon... don't tell me I'm the only one who feels this way.
4) The roast chicken. Order it. Enjoy. Or get the steak... the house preparation is pretty damn close to rare. Yep, it's that good of a steak.
5) Blood orange upside down cake: my dreams are now made of it.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
I love Zuni Cafe because of the laid back atmosphere and great food. 
Their roasted chicken salad is delicious and they have really awesome bloody mary. Intend to go back and to try rest of the menu :)
author: Catherine T.

description:
I hate to change my review for Zuni Cafe to 2-stars...and I want to believe that my recent (bad) experience there was a fluke...but it's been a few days since my dinner there and I'm still annoyed. I also looked on their website to see if I could email someone at the restaurant and (privately) let them know about my sub-par night, but there is no way to contact them other than the main reservation line, which I'd rather not deal with. So, unfortunately, I'm voicing my disappointment on yelp.

Summary: Made reservations for dinner Zuni Cafe. Party of 5, Friday night, 9:00 pm. A friend was in town from the East Coast and wanted Zuni for her one night in town. We arrived at 8:55 and were told that our table was still being readied. Ok, fine -- no problem. 15 minutes later I went back to the host's podium and was told "the party who is sitting at your table has paid and it *looks* like they're getting their coats." Wait, what? I thought the table was getting "readied"? 15 minutes after that we were finally sat -- except that no one acknowledged our THIRTY MINUTE wait. I realize that Friday nights are busy, that we were 5 -- not two, or 4 -- but the fact that neither of the hostesses or our server (who perhaps didn't know?) acknowledged OR apologized for us waiting 30 minutes after our reservation really got the meal off to a bad start. It continued from there -- normally the service I've had at Cafe Zuni is impeccable, but our server was incredibly awkward and erratic. I didn't expect anyone to fall all over themselves about the wait -- but what's the point of making reservations if we have to wait a half an hour afterwards? Following the lack of acknowledgement (I seriously would have been ok with someone -- anyone -- saying "sorry for the wait" and could have let it go at that) for our 30 min wait, the weird/uncomfortable service made the experience laughable.  It would have been different if our reservations had been during a peak time -- but by 9:00 the restaurant was slowing down and by the time we sat it was nearly empty in our section. My friends at least liked their chicken. And while we're on the subject of the chicken,  I really wish Zuni would round out their menu with a vegetarian entree. I get that their specialty isn't vegetarian fare, and I'm normally ok with slapping some sides together for myself while my friends go to town on the famous chicken -- but the ungracious evening made me more inclined to go somewhere else when a friend who's craving good food comes to town.
author: M M.

description:
A very BIG disappointment. We arrived for a 9pm reservation on Sunday and it looked like the chefs have already left for the day: A $28 tuna dish was pale and tasteless! The plate was filled with oil and very unattractive gray looking fish and side veggies was laid on it. A meal unpleasant for the eye almost as it was unpleasant for our taste buds. I hoped our server would ask how we like the food so I could let her know, but she never did. It was already 10pm by the time we got our main courses so we decided not to send it back... didn't seem like anything good could have come out of it at that time. 

To end a very disappointing and very expensive meal, we found that my friend's bike was stolen from out side the restaurant as we were having dinner. Right in front of the large windows -- no one saw it! What a loss this night was.
author: Dr. S.

description: Definitely a San Francisco staple! The food in general is well-down but you have to go here for the roast chicken. It's DIVINE. Don't go too hungry though because the chicken takes an hour (at least it's fresh to order!) It's juicy, flavorful and really honors those that are carnivores. I also love their wine selection, shoestring fries and wonderful appetizers (and oysters). You really can't go wrong with this place so chicken lovers, get on board!
author: Lianne Z.

description:
Had the one hour chicken, ordered it right away. Fantastic, have this if anything. The Cesar salad was chatted up quite a lot, but disappointing. It was ok, but not the marvel it was sold as. 

Good ambiance and we had good service.
author: Jim T.

description:
It has very good food and good service although it is a bit spendy .It's not the best for big party's but it is good for 5 or fewer people


-M
author: Maudie G.

description: This Cafe is a Beautiful Restaurant  on Market Street in  San Francisco, CA.  A leftover  from  the hey deys of  affluent  silicon valley  credit card lunchers..Cafe Zuni is situated  on Market street near by some old Art Deco antque centers and  very close to Noe Valley and Castro area. Zuni Cafe's walls are usually filled with local artist's paintings..hopefully always will be... and the bar in front always has an empty seat for  people on the run. Not to be missed...good food, lots to see...
author: Carol T.

description: The food and service were both excellent. Staff was very attentive without being overbearing. Their bread is marvelous as was the flourless chocolate cake. The bartender made an excellent Cosmo and good selections of wine. I would definitely go back or recommend them to a friend.
author: Charles S.

description:
We've been here multiple times and always leave full and satisfied.  The one dish that we've had that has ever just a *tad* disappointed us was the ricotta gnocchi, but I think it's because we're so used to heavy potato gnocchi.

As many reviewers have mentioned, you HAVE to order the roast chicken.  They salt it the day before so that it is moist, but the skin is super crispy.  And the bread salad... *drool*....  Grilled bread, toasted pine nuts, currants, a little bit of greens, and champagne vinegar--so good.

Other dishes you must try: oysters (yes, they are raw, but c'mon!), shoestring fries, any fideo dish (not a regular item, but a must try when it is), espresso granita, any of the cheese selections, and any ice cream.

We have not tried the burger (we're always there for dinner), so we can't vouch for or against them.  My husband tried the Caesar once and said that it is very good.
author: Melissa S.

description:
If there is only one thing you do at Zunni.... order the one hour chicken right when you get there and wait patiently.

Or you could order the starters and have the time fly by while you enjoy the delicious food: Caesar Salad, Corn and Potato Soup, Sardines - Parmesan - Celery - Oil, Oysters, Fried onion rings - Fried Grapes.

Great service with waiters on point at every moment.  The bus boys were a little to on point and cleared my dish before I was done on a few occasions.

Next time I'll be here for their burgers that start at 10 PM.
author: Po L.

description:
Been going there since '93.

5-stars for quality, consistency, staying-power, and above all ~ an example for other restaurants to follow (and know, for a fact, it became the model for Zefiro's, in Portland, OR.).

Roast Chicken, Caesar Salad,oysters, martinis . . . All-Good.
author: Peter B.

description:
FINALLY got to Zuni for dinner. I am a huge roast chicken fan, and I had to sample their famous version. In a word: perfect. The chicken is moist with a crisp skin and the bread salad - oh, that bread salad. If I could make something half as good at Thanksgiving this year, I'd be a legend among my friends and family.

We also enjoyed a lovely selection of cheeses, the famed caesar salad, ricotta gnocchi and a wheat cake with brown sugar creme fraiche ice cream. All were delicious and well balanced. Zuni's not cheap, but it's worth the occasional indulgence.
author: Beth T.

description:
Let me start by saying that I love roast chicken in general.  It's just a thing.  I've been meaning to try Zuni Cafe for a while now but 1) it's usually very busy and 2) being on the pricier side, been meaning to do it on more of a "special occasion" event.  So of course yesterday as the fiancee and I finished spending the day in the city, I had a craving for some roast chicken.  It was 6PM, we called the restaurant and was told we could take the chance in trying to get a table at the bar.  We chanced it.  

Am I glad we did!  The roast chicken is what everyone else has said - very good.  Not much I can add to what other yelpers have said.  Since it'd take about an hour to make, we ordered a plate of shoestring fries - good pile of fries, well fried & well seasoned.  Just the thing we needed to go along with drinks while we waited for the chicken!  Dessert was also good - we went with the recommendation by our waiter on the Espresso Granita.  Never had it before, never even heard of it - but boy was it good.  Basically an espresso sorbet with a bit of cream.  

4-stars.  Definitely very good!
author: Francis S.

description:
Caesar salad was good, but nothing different about it.

Crostini with avocado and blood orange was ok, not bad, but not great. 

Pork tenderloin was good, but it came with 2 pieces of pork tenderloin and a pork sausage with potatoes. The sausage was really good and very flavorful and the potatoes tasted more like a sweet potato. Good, but not really worth it considering the portions were really small and it was suppose to be a main entree. 

Chicken is a must get! It's completely worth the hour wait. If you know your going to order it, tell them you'd like for it to get started while you look over the menu. (That way it doesn't seem as long of a wait and you can order some appetizers that will hold you over until the chicken is done). Chicken was extremely moist and tender (even for white meat) and the Bread salad was better than what I had expected. It's basically bread broken up with a light balsamic vinaigrette mixed into the bread with pine nuts, currant and scallions. The red mustard greens was pretty spicy, but very good. It went well with the chicken. I went with 4 people and the dish was large enough to feed all of us and we had left overs, so even though it says for 2, I'd say it's more for 3 and 4 max.

While your at it, you should try their proseco with elderflower. Pretty good.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Who doesn't enjoy a summer stroll through the Tenderloin?  After watching a man cook up his crack on the street about a block away, I needed my own fix- a very strong cocktail.  We bellied up to the gorgeous copper bar where the lovely bartender obliged my special request- Grey Goose up with a splash of grapefruit juice and a splash of Cointreau.  It was mixed perfectly and came with a little sidecar.  My husband's Woodford on the rocks was generous.
The restaurant itself is lovely.  Our server was perfect in his mix of kindness, unobtrusiveness, and perfect timing.  
Yes, we ordered the chicken.  Yes, it takes an hour.  I have made this chicken at home many times following the Zuni cookbook's instruction to the letter.  It is a testament to Judi's recipe writing skills that the chicken itself is almost as good made at home.  However the bread salad is another story.  Oh, the bread salad.  It is truly one of the best things I've ever put in my mouth.  Do it.
We also had the pork chop with wax beans.  It was okay, but I really don't like pork chops so I'm certainly not the one to judge.
We enjoyed loads of yummy hors d'ouevres while our chicken roasted.  We started with the burrata, then moved to clams with delicious charred peppers and then on to a delicious chitarra with corn, chilis and pancetta.  All were delicious.
Zuni is an institution for a reason.
author: Amber H.

description:
I've been here 10 years ago. I never can get a reservation until last Friday. I guess it's a sign if you can get reservations at 7:45pm on a Friday there's something wrong. 
We got seated right away but our waiter wasn't very nice. He's greeting was " oh you are the girls that almost ran me over down stairs" Huh? What are you talking about? I also ordered wine and it took so long to get. He didn't even apologize for the wait. He said a drunk lady at the bar took it. Really? 

Anyway, our server John was either having a bad day or he's just a DB. Our chicken was good but it's not worth $48. I can make it at home with the toasted bread, throw some greens, sprinkle some miniature raisins and balasamic/vinaigrette dressing. The rabbit was good but the serving is tiny and the Caesar salad had too much dressing but the croutons were delicious. 

I will probably not come back for another 10 years if they are still around.
author: Sheila D.

description:
Zuni Burger- unique tasting, fancy-smanchy looking, seriously delicious!

Cesar Salad- fresh/crispy, homemade croutons, tangy/peppery/pungent.
*I get an odd satisfaction in slicing and bursting open the long leaves*

Shoestring Fries- might be too much even for you & your friends to share

Creme Brulee- how can you mess up this dish? YUM

The reason wanted to come in the first place. - Oysters! Nice selection.

I dock one star because I'm not a fan of the location (not the most convenient) and at times it can feel a little stuffy. I def prefer the more casual atmosphere of the day time here over the dinner experience. The staff are helpful and friendly, but I wouldn't call the warmest, sun-shiniest people around. I doubt that's what the dinner crowd prefer anyway. *shrugs* Xp
author: Roxanne Q.

description:
We were visiting San Francisco for the weekend and had heard good things about Zuni....they were all right on!!  We started with delish anchovies served with celery and pecorino (yum!).  I had the sand dabs and my husband had the squab.  Both were very tasty (the server even deboned mine at our table).  The service was fabulous.  My only complaint is that we had a 9:00 reservation and still had to wait a while for our table.  Otherwise everything was great!!  

We also stopped over at Pause Wine Bar for a glass of wine and snack before dinner (right down the street from Zuni).  We only had the figs but it left me wanting more!!
author: Jessi G.

description: I LOVED this place!  We had reservations before seeing a show.  Our waiter was fabulous in letting us know what to order so we would be on time for our show.  Very attentive.  The food was amazing.  I had the tomato soup and gnocchi.  The soup was so tasty I wished I had ordered another bowl. The gnocchi was so rich and creamy.  I also had the balsamic Bloody Mary which was very tasty.  We had a wonderful meal and our waiter got us out in plenty of time for our show.
author: Cassy H.

description:
Zuni Cafe was on my hit list when I visited SF last year - for the selection of fresh west coast oysters. Since I didn't  make it the first time I came here last week with Jenn C. and had a stellar meal. For those who know me, I don't like chicken. Well I'd prefer any other meat before I'd choose chicken off a menu. Jenn insisted we that we had the roast chicken and I had very high expectations of this magical dish. 

As soon as our waitress (Karina?) heard we wanted chicken she promptly put the order in as it takes an hour to prepare. We started off with a dozen of the most perfectly shucked, clean, fresh oysters of the waitress' choice. The favorites that stood out were the Marin Miyagi,  Kusshi, & Pearl Point (Though I believe that West Coast oysters are far superior than their East Coast cousins..) Nicely chilled, these oysters tasted as if they just fished from the ocean!

We also ordered the house cured anchovies and the infamous caesar salad. The romaine had a surprising sweetness that paired well with the not too creamy nor salty dressing. 

Out came the chicken, skin glistening and all - I was totally WOWed. Crisp skin, moist tender skin atop a bed of bread salad tossed in a vinaigrette with the perfect amount of acid that didn't compete with the delicate flavor of the chicken. The serving was so huge for two that after having a few pieces, we felt a bit wimpy leaving a ton of delicious bird on the plate. 

The appeal of this place is the selection of simple, non-fussy dishes made with the freshest ingredients available. Pair this with a fantastic waitress who was friendly and helpful in providing us tasty suggestions. The venue is casual and fun suitable for many occasions. I will definitely be coming here again on my next visit.
author: Lizz K.

description:
I have been here a number of times and have forgiven their poor customer service skills because the food was fabulous and the decor welcoming and cozy. Attempting to celebrate a special occasion however, is not recommended. They don't take "large party" reservations of more than 4 on line. They only take phone reservations 30 days in advance and only if those 30 days falls on a day they are not closed. They only have one table available for "large" parties. They don't necessarily have reliable staff answering the phone, as we called to get a reservation of 8 and were told their one table was booked. The next day, a friend called to reserve for a party of 7 and was given a reservation for the same time. I have decided that an important part of the dining experience means that the staff not treat you as though they were doing you the favor. 
We will be celebrating from now on at one of the many other fabulous eateries in San Francisco!
author: Jane T.

description:
Went to this restaurant on May 4th to celebrate a day of me being "Fabulous", (kidding).  However, if you are craving any of the following: 

Oysters (Check)
Shoestring fries (Check)
Roasted, scrumptious chicken dinner for two (Check) 
Frisee salad (Check)
And drum roll please for the obvious.....PROSECCO!! (Double Check)

Then go to Zuni Cafe!!! 

 I honestly dislike writing "Awesome" reviews because I'm afraid places like this will become overcrowded due to Yelpers!   WAAAH for me & YAAY for Zuni.  

And now for my signature mark....

FIN
author: Em A.

description: I love love love this place!!!! Best chicken I ever had......of course you have to wait awhile for it (1hour and no calling ahead) but it is soooooo worth it! Lovely ambiance and polite staff.
author: Kyle L.

description:
Judy Rogers wrote a bible of culinary knowledge in her "Zuni Cafe Cookbook."  Even before eating there, me and my culinary-minded roommate decided to attempt her much acclaimed recipe for roast chicken with a warm bread salad.  "DAMN" is all I got to say.  I think we both passed out that night with chicken grease all over our faces.  I'll spare you the graphic details but it was the most delicious roast chicken either of us had ever made.  With all that said, when I first went to Zuni with my lovely girlfriend I couldn't help but walk in with some high expectations.

We got some staple lunch items, the Caesar and Zuni burger, and some extras like raw oysters and a bloody mary.  O' man, you can see chef Rogers' love affair with A+ ingredients in each of the menu items.  The Caesar was crunchy with the perfect balance of anchovy-dressing and yumtastic croutons.  The burger sat on a focaccia bun with a harmonious arrangement of pickled accompaniments.  The oyster selection was wonderfully varied, a perfect precursor for me getting all antsy in my pantsy (you know what I mean), and fries were hot and crunchy.  If I could get those fries at 2am after coming back from the bars, I'd easily be a good 10+ lbs heavier this holiday season.  Make that 20+ heavier if I could get their bloody marys just as often along with the fries.  

It's good.  The service staff is knowledgeable and on their game.  The prices  are probably the only downside, but if you read Judy Rogers' tome on cooking, you see where all the extra money goes -- into the ingredients, and it shows.
author: M K.

description: I have heard so much about Zuni Cafe that we finally broke down & went. Everyone told us "we must have the chicken" & so thats what we ordered. I would definately agree, its some of the best we have ever had, but for $48 for 2 people?? Thats some pricey chicken & a definate money-maker for the restaurant. The bread stuffing underneath was really the show stealer, as well as the cocktails we had. I'd go back for sure, but would order something different next time, so I can maybe rate the place a little higher. Fun, energetic atmosphere, will be back.
author: Jen S.

description:
The girlfriend took me here for my birthday this past May and it was a real treat. We started with a dozen oysters which were nothing short of amazing. The pizza we ordered would probably have been delicious had we really been in the mood for it, but the chicken for two is DEFINITELY where it's at. 

Too bad we were full after the oysters and half the pizza. We ended up taking the chicken to go, but I must admit there's a certain deliciousness to eating the chicken cold too.

The atmosphere during lunch seemed to be business casual with many people dropping by from the financial district. Parking is as much an issue as you would expect it to be driving around the city, so bring change to feed the meter (all the meters have a 1 hr limit). If you can afford it, valet parking wouldn't be a bad idea.
author: Ed D.

description:
There is a reason the chicken is the first on the "100 things you must eat in SF before you die list"... and I don't even really like chicken! Seriously, it was the combination of the bread goodness, some kind of spicing/nut thing, and the falling off the bone chicken... just amazing. 

We also got calamari which was excellent and my Martini was perfectly made. My friend and I didn't make reservations, but they have a pretty big bar area, that has normal tables, so if you are lucky you can snatch one of those without having to plan ahead or wait for hours. I actually prefer that area, because they have really big windows and it also provides a nice view of the restaurant. 

The negatives - small, but worth mentioning. For a place as fancy as this, I would have expected better bread and butter. Sure its free, so I can't complain that much, but it would not be difficult to provide less crusty bread and to warm up the butter. Additionally, there is only one bathroom stall per sex.. for a place as big as this, thats weird. I had to wait a good 10ish minutes. Basically, if you are thinking about coming here for a first date, just don't be one of those people that has to pee all the time, you'll just be standing in line.
author: Rona Y.

description:
Great oysters, great French leaning wine list, and an akward history. This spot evolved unlike most but somehow turned into a pretty sweet spot! Love the brass, the mid 80's floor plan and decor, and the piano man? Perfect!

Definitely returning.
author: Corey H.

description:
Knocked off #1 on The Big Eat SF list: Roast chicken and Bread Salad.  Wish I could say I was more impressed. 

I had been looking forward to the meal.  Don't get me wrong - the chicken is quite good.  However, it's a little crispier on the outside than I like it and it does take an entire hour to make.  The spit roast chicken at Cafe Rouge is more special (may not be an entirely apples to apples compariso to be fair). Also, at Zuni, it's $48 for two people.
