I tried to call and see if I could order it a half hour earlier to arriving to minimize the wait but they wouldn't do that (perhaps understandably - what if I didn't show). 

Although the lady at the front desk is very nice - the wait staff is not super friendly - professional but more of a "I am so much cooler than you" attitude rathen than a warm welcome is received.
author: Abhi S.

description: Perfection - and the bartenders aren't bad to look at either!
author: Rebecca P.

description: The rotisserie chicken here is great! This is a must try if you are in San Francisco. They really know how to do chicken. This is called "the perfect roast chicken from the legendary chef Judy Rodgers"! It is very tender and moisture inside, crispy inside. Meat is flavorful. All seasonings inside and out are just working right. Chicken for two is $48. But you have to wait for a whole hour. It is made to order. And they don't take order before you are seated.
author: Emmy P.

description:
The Roasted Chicken might just be the best chicken dish I have ever eaten. Savory and rich with the bread salad. The mustard greens add some bitterness, while the currants and pine nuts add sweetness and a little crunch.  It's all worth the hour wait.

The Zuni burger is nice and fancy if that's your thing. The fries are thin and crispy.

Loft seating area, exposed brick, wood beams and a copper bar all make for a cool rustic ambiance throughout the restaurant.
author: charles t.

description:
I resisted going to Zuni  Cafe for years as I did not want to pay $48 for chicken (even if it is for two).  I have now been to Zuni twice, once for brunch with a friend and once for dinner with people from work.  The food was consistently fabulous.

Yes, the chicken is extremely pricey, but you really can't find that chicken anywhere else. We also ordered a pork chop that was tasty and succulent.  Desserts were also great.
author: Rachel M.

description: This restaurant has a really cute interior with a non-traditional floor layout. As someone who usually thinks salad is a waste of stomach space (I'd much rather consume meat), I thought the Caesar salad was really delicious. The dressing was not too creamy and not too thin, it was just right. We also ordered the roast chicken, which was very tender and had tasty skin. Come hungry, because it's a ton of chicken! The portion size is suggested for 2 people, but I think it could feed 3 girls comfortably if you also order an appetizer. I would definitely come back again as this is the best chicken I've had in the city thus far.
author: Cathy L.

description:
I usually feel that if the review is strictly on just the food, it can be anything from 1 -5. Everyone has different expectations on the taste of food.
This review is not about the food, but about the service received.
I made a reservation for this evening. I then called a few hours ahead to preorder the chicken because it usually takes an hour. A gentleman answered the phone and promptly told me they don't take preorders for the chicken. I informed him that just a few months ago, I was able to do so. He then told me they no longer do so. I then asked him when did this start. His only answer was ever since he started.
OK, so far, bad news, but nothing terrible.
What was shocking was that this guy did not offer any explanations or alternatives. What does that mean, "Ever since I started here". Who knows when he started. It could have been yesterday or 10 years ago. His explanation gave me the feeling that he could have made that up while on the phone with me. It wasn't like, "I'm sorry, but our management has made this decision". His answer was so short and very unprofessional. For a place that charges $31-50 for a plate, I expect more professionalism from the staff.
Obviously, Zuni has made a decision to not accept preorders for the chicken. So for those of you planning to go and enjoy the infamous chicken, you must now order when you arrive and must wait at least an hour.
I also agree with many reviewers that Zuni's quality has gone down. It's evident from the person who answered my phone call. They obviously don't think a phone conversation is important to making a good impression on new and old customers.
author: S K.

description:
More of a wine and dine place, but they didn't turn their noses up at us for keeping our drinks to just sparkling water. Had the late lunch menu round 5:30pm (dinner menu begins at 6pm) and my husband and I each ordered the house burgers. Very simply served with choice of cheese on foccacia bread with a small portion of pickled veggies, but oh my Lord in heaven...one of the best burgers we've ever had! Really good ground beef seasoned to perfection. Super flavorful and cooked to order (Mine - medium well; His - medium rare). 

We're thinking of heading back another time for another round of burgers and add in the roast chicken. The couple at the next table were raving about how delicious it was.
author: Elaine W.

description: ....Zuni and Slanted Door...two very popular, expensive and overrated places...if you like paying $50 for a chicken, go for it.  The service varies all over the ballpark...personally I don't much care for a place that has established a reputation and is now living off it...
author: jim b.

description:
The chicken is worth the wait....just order it as soon as you sit down...the decide on the rest of the menu.

The gnocchi...to DIE for!  Pillows of buttery goodness in your mouth.  

Service was impeccable.  

Would definitely go back again and again...and again.
author: Missy W.

description:
Wow, I'm the 1,000th review for Zuni!  How apropos ... as it is my favorite destination in town for casual fine dining.  And always the first to come to mind people ask which restaurant I think best represents SF.

I've been here several times over the years and have never been disappointed.  In short, I would say the roasted chicken for two is one of the best dishes I've ever had (so succulent, especially with the bread salad that soaks up the juices but somehow also retains a crunchiness).

Other stand-out dishes (which may or may not be around the next time I'm there):
- The ricotta gnocchi: literally melts in your mouth 
- The risotto - good size app with tons of flavor
- The Alaskan halibut - amazingly flaky and tender
- The burger (for lunch) - on focaccia bread with pickled onions - one of the best in the city

I also love their Bloody Mary (with their small bits of jalapeno peppers and onions) that fit through your straw so you get a nice crunchy contrast to the spicy drink (I only wish they would upgrade their Vodka from Smirnoff).

Zuni is one of those places where somehow it has managed to strike a perfect balance of comfort and creative foods, casual but upscale feel,  and refined service that does not feel at all stuffy. It's obvious they've succeeded in maintain this careful equilibrium just by looking around at the diverse patrons (a group of  boisterous 20-somethings celebrating a birthday, a culinary destination for out-of-town guests, a couple on a romantic intimate date, a pair of foodie friends out for a late-night bite, older companions having a quiet, intimate meal).

It's no wonder it's been at the top of its game for over 30 years.  Looking forward to the next 30.  Cheers (raising my second Bloody Mary)!
author: F. P.

description:
I came here for lunch (around 1:30 PM) on Sunday and it was packed and for those who didn't have a reservation, they had to wait for at least 40 minutes. 

ATMOSPHERE 
The cafe itself is very cute and cozy, but it's not in the best neighborhood and it sticks out like a sore thumb. There's valet parking but there was actually a ton of free parking around the area, so that's a plus. 

Zuni Cafe is small but there's seating all over the restaurant: outside, near the bar, in a separate dining room near the ovens, and even an upstairs deck. There are large glass windows everywhere and a fully stocked bar, so you can see the alcohol bottles lined up from outside as you pass by the cafe. 

The service was good: our waitress was very attentive and friendly. There were also busboys who came by and cleaned our tables after we finished our entrees. 

FOOD 
Zuni's oven roasted chicken with Tuscan bread salad is featured on the 7x7 Big Eat Scavenger Hunt, so that's exactly what we ordered. 

The menu says that it's "chicken for two," but unless you can eat a whole chicken, expect to bring home a heavy box of leftovers. There were 3 of us and we ordered 2 plates of the roasted chicken and an order of shoestring fries. We went home with two boxes of chicken and salad. 

The shoestring fries were very skinny and crispy. I enjoyed them because the ketchup was unique; it was sweeter and had a thicker consistency than traditional ketchup. The portions were big but since they're so skinny it doesn't feel like you're eating that much. 

We waited an hour for the coveted chicken but unfortunately it was just roasted chicken-- nothing too special. I must admit that it's the BEST roasted chicken I've ever had (very juicy and tender), but it's not worth $48 and the hour-long wait. My brother compared it to Costco's rotisserie chicken. 

What made the dish stand out was the Tuscan bread salad. It came with pine nuts, corn, and what looked like dried fruit. The dressing was divine and the bread was spongy and flavorful. It got a little soggy towards the end of the meal but overall it was a good complement to the chicken. 

Overall, the chicken is tasty but overpriced. There wasn't anything particularly unique about the dish and for $48 (plus an hour wait time), you're better off eating somewhere else.
author: Krystie M.

description: I love sitting outside on Market on a warm day and watching the trolley cars and crazies walk by while drinking a nice white wine and having their chicken. THEIR CHICKEN! Amazing. Just order it right away, it takes an hour.
author: Rich R.

description:
I have given some outstanding restaurants 4 stars, and only French Laundy has 5, so this will be 3.5 stars. 
Having said that, all our dishes were good (except the caesars salad that tasted a bit too much of anchovies), and the roasted chicken was worth waiting for. The suggested wine pairing (2007 Joseph Swan Pinot Noir) worked very well with the chicken. Both my lamb starter and the crepes (dessert) were good. 
Service was very good, too and we all liked the way the place looks.
author: Kaj HeGe H.

description: The only reason I am giving 1 star is because I'm loyal and have loved Zuni Cafe for years, not anymore. I treated my partner to an early dinner here following an afternoon wedding a few weeks ago. Our sever was clearly not happy to have had to be at work that day. He could not have been more distracted and unattentive. We asked if we could have the table closest to the window but were told it was for a party of 1, when there were only 2 other people in the entire restaurant. Ok...? the beloved Caesar salad dressing was watery and the burger and fries were cold. I have never written a bad review anywhere and am disappointed to feel the need to write this about Zuni...what happened there? Bummer :(
author: Lisa W.

description: This has been on my radar since it moved into the old Red Desert spot (and that's a long, long time). Picked it for a quiet birthday brunch. A little disappointed they could not add one to the reservation when we requested, but all else was beyond expectation. Space is large-ish and a bit cold (which I like) and the small menu interesting. We settled on some bread soaked in olive oil to begin (way pricey, but delicious) and then had fried eggs with fennel and french toast with some herbs. Each dish had lots of interesting things going on and it was difficult to order dessert; however, we managed a lemon tart-ish affair and a chocolate/carmel pot. Very pleased with the whole experience.
author: Robert M.

description: Is this the world's best chicken? Perhaps. While waiting the 40 minutes for the amazing chicken to cook, we had ample time to sample other items from the bar and menu including 2 dozen oysters, bread, cocktails and wine (all fabulous). Back to the chicken. It really is all that. Really.
author: Jon W.

description:
I had not eaten here for about 15 years & went here when we had a relative in from out of town.  I was pleased that the restaurant was as delicious a few weeks ago as it was years ago.  Steak was perfectly cooked.  Caesar salad was tangy & creamy.  Portions were extremely generous.  Meal was also a great value.  In these lean times I didn't feel completely indulgent eating here.

Restaurant is not too far from the Orpheum and other B'way on Tour theatre which is nice, although it's a bit of a skanky walk.  Zuni is in an ok neighborhood, but the theatres aren't.
author: Dina J.

description:
For a taste of the Mediterranean, try the variety on their dinner menu.  You can't miss the brick oven and quaint decor.  Start with the oysters and their house Caesar's salad with slices of lettuce dressed in garlic.  Then, indulge in their fish or chicken for two.  Finally, end on a delectable note with their flourless chocolate cake or creme.

The staff is impeccable in providing descriptions and recommendations for the delightful dishes and desserts.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Zuni is classic San Francisco.  I always feel comfortable eating here.

1) Raw bar is always good.   I love oysters and Zuni always have a good selection.  
2) Yes, the Roast Chicken takes an hour.  Yes, it IS worth it.  I love the fact that it comes with wilted greens and a yummy bread salad. 
3) Creamy Polenta as an appetizer is the ultimate comfort food.
3) Caesar salad is amazing.  It is very garlicky.  Stay away if you are on a date or do not like garlic.
author: Katharine A.

description:
I have been a very long time fan of Zuni Cafe, ever since I lived in San Francisco in the early 90's.  This previous weekend I asked friends to meet there Saturday morning for their famous bloody marys to ward off what i knew would be post-wedding hangovers.  The bloody marys did not disappoint, but the food certainly did.

My dining partner had the burger on foccacia, which looked delectable  but was unfortunately characterized as the oiliest burger ever known to man.  The veggies that came with the burger looked and tasted beautiful, but I think the slightly oily nature of foccacia coupled with the fact that it was unnecessarily buttered was just a problem.  Another companion ordered the penne with tuna confit.  I had informed him that to "confit" anything means to cure or preserve it in some form of fat, (in this case ahi tuna in olive oil) but for some reason the waiter was able to convince him the dish would not be as overly fatty as, say, a duck confit.  He was wrong.  That dish was a reservoir of olive oil.  It was not even nice to look at.

The only foods that did not disappoint were the stellar bay oysters...out of this world.  The best oysters I have possibly ever had.  Medium in size and creaminess, they were a huge hit.  And of course, the pomme frites.  As usual, these were of perfect texture, crunch and saltiness.

I was sad to have had a bad meal there when I have had so many good ones in the past, and I don't San Francisco as often as I would like.
author: Lizzie S.

description: Loved the bread salad and roasted chicken. Made to order . Great for late night sf dining. Great service as well , perfect for after a long night at work.
author: bd ..

description:
Just to note, this review will be more geared toward their burger as Andrei Z, Gene X and I continue to tackle 7x7's Best Burgers in SF list (this is #9).  However, I don't want to discount the fact that I've been to Zuni a few times and really loved it, so here's my rating:

Restaurant - 4 stars (service, food, ambiance is very good.  Nathan is a wonderful and attentive server so you should ask for him if he's there!)

Burger - 3 stars

This burger came out on a square focaccia roll and the first thing I really noticed was the lack of much on the burger itself.  I ordered it with grilled onions so that was on the burger and it also came with an aioli which was quite tasty as well as greens and on the side, pickled onions and pickles.

The meat itself was good, not great.  And compared to #10 (Namu), it didn't stand a chance.  But don't let that stop you from ordering it because it IS a good burger.  One positive against Namu's burger was the fact that the bun itself held up better than the Namu bun (although my cohorts were complaining about the squareness of it). The pickles and the pickled onions really helped flavor up the burger so I really enjoyed those.  I found the "greens" to be a bit wilted...which maybe is how they're supposed to come, but I prefer mine to be fresh.  It's a decent sized burger but not too much.  If you're hungry, you'll be able to finish it all.

We shared an order of fries (it's really quite big so even if you're 3-4 people, you could share one order) that were very skinny fries.  Not my favorite only because I prefer my fries to still have some bit of potato in them (these were too crispy for my tasty).

Overall I would rate Namu's burger over Zuni's....however, I'd definitely choose Zuni over Namu to eat.  Just be sure to get a reservation if you're going there for dinner or expect a wait.  I was shocked that on a Saturday afternoon, there was still quite a crowd!
author: Melanie N.

description:
A co-worker and I were in the neighborhood when we decided to have lunch at Zuni Cafe. 

I was born and raised in the city and my dad has always told me that I should eat there (even though he never has!) so I was eager to have a good experience to report back to him. My co-worker and I both went for the burger since we didn't have the time to wait for the chicken. We both loved our burgers (mine with cheese and hers with the portobello mushroom.) Of course you can't have any kind of burger (fancy or fast) without a coke so we ordered a coke each and a couple of refills later..we got our bill charging $3+ per glass of coke!!!! Ahhh! Who does that? 

I will definitely return for the food but next time I will not get conned into paying for refills.
author: Valerie A.

description: Don't bother telling your waiter or waitress what temperature you want your burger cooked, because the Chef will only cook them medium, even if you tell them you want it "well done". Every single burger that was ordered at our table was a bloody medium. What pissed me off about this is we had a very long conversation with our waitress that even though the chef prefers to cook his burgers medium, we wanted them "well done" anyways. When we got the burgers and saw that they still were not cooked according to order I again stated that we had been very adamant that we didn't want medium burgers. She said she could take them back and have them cooked longer, but my question is why? Why the hell do I have to send all the burgers back a second time?. As for the Beecher's Flagship cheese on the burger, it was completely tasteless. Another annoying thing they only give you ketsup in a small metal serving cup, and you can only dip one tiny shoesting french fry in it at a time. They give you so little ketsup, you'd need 8-9 cups to make it through an order of fries. Before we ever went there, I asked the people that had invitied us if they truly served a $15.00 dollar burger and was told absolutely YES! Well after adding the tasteless cheese and inch thick cut under grilled onions, and the fries it was well over $20.00 per person. Truth of the matter, I wouldn't pay two cents for what I was served. Nothing pisses me off more than a restaurant that plays these stupid games. I don't care if you think you have the greatest burger in the world, and that it shouldn't be cooked "well done", Damn it! I'm a paying customer! Christ I can go to Burger King and get it my way, why can't you follow a simple customer request? There's nothing worse when a restaurant has a pretentious chef in the kitchen. The next thing you know, they'll come out of the kitchen to tell you how you should eat what they cooked. This place is pathetic. I would never recommend it to anyone and will never return. Save your money and hit a McDonalds, at least you won't leave feeling like someone just screwed you while they picked your pocket
author: Mark T.

description: What can I say that hasn't been said already? This is a very special place where drinks and food are crafted with care. We got there early to pre-prder the roast chicken (takes an hr and you can't do it over phone). While we waited for our table, we sidled onto the bar for a couple of glasses of wine. Zuni has its own chardonnay. 15 mins after our reservation time, they took us upstairs to a nice corner table and we had appetizers (marinated olives and fried onions and broccoli). Our chicken finally came and it was divine. So moist and flavorful, and accompanied by this out-of-world bread salad. If only my stomach were bigger.
author: Susan H.

description:
Everyone, just everyone talks about the Roasted Chicken here. Out of the 858 current reviews, 454 of them make a reference to the chicken. So I HAD to get it. In retrospect, I really don't get all the hype. Don't get me wrong. It was good. And I may have gone in expecting too much. But in terms of the chicken alone, I've had comparable ones from Whole Foods where I did not have to wait an hour and did not pay $48. I've got to say that the warm bread salad sauced with a balsamic vinegar concoction bumped up the dish a notch, but I'll still defer to Whole Foods Rotisserie Chicken and 2 Sides for $9.99. 

Please stop calling me frugal... thank you very much.
author: Al L.

description:
Sunday night..   no reservations... 930pm
James was awesome, he was attentive, friendly, smiled, and had a great sense of humor.
Food was nice, I liked it...  House cured anchovies with celery, parmesan, and nicoise olives.....     Braised lamb shanks.....
Drinks were also above par... Fresh Lime Margarita & Mas des Capitelles  Faugères "Cuvée Vielles Vignes" 2005 Mourvèdre-Syrah-Cinsault blend.
Overall experience--  very good..  
Will I return?  Yes, I will.
author: Stacy C.

description: My fiancee took me to Zuni Cafe over a year ago for our second date  and since then this has become my ultimate favorite place for oysters. If you can't get a reservation here then go to the bar and get some oysters you won't be sorry!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
When I worked for the City (isn't San Francisco the ONLY City?), I lunched at local restaurants close to my office which was located on Van Ness Avenue at McAllister Streets.  I was one of the founders and the Deputy Director of the San Francisco Mayor's Office on Disability (I opened the office for Willie Brown).

Although one of my favorites, until recently I wouldn't go to the Zuni Cafe because it wasn't accessible (I use a wheelchair for mobility).  

Recently, because I wanted to again enjoy the great food and service at Zuni, I contacted the owners and told them about the access violations in their restaurant.  To my surprise, they not only reacted positively, but actually took action to correct all of the access violations.  I can now go to the Zuni with friends or former co-workers and sit at the accessible lowered section of the bar or find an accessible table to eat our lunch and enjoy my meal and the accessible surroundings.

I can't tell you how great it feels to be able to go into a business, in this case, the Zuni Cafe, and not only be able to get in the front door, but feel welcome because the place is accessible, including their bathroom!!!

By the way, the burgers and oysters are to die for!

Thanks, Zuni.  I'll be back and tell my friends all about you.  See you soon.

Back soon with more reviews that include access for persons with disabilities.
author: Richard S.

description:
been here twice. once for dinner and once for brunch. 

i honestly think the chicken is way over rated. it's good but way too overhyped. perhaps lower your expectations and you'll be impressed. 

place is a bit cramped and not sure if the other dishes are worth getting. i got the fish my first time here and it wasn't that great for the price i was paying. warning: i did not try the oysters but i heard they're good. 

i think zuni is one of those place everyone has to go to once just to say they've been when theyre foodie friends are raving about it.
author: Janet Y.

description:
Was early for reservation so decided to have a drink at the bar.
No stools at the bar. Sat at small windown table..
Ordered an Appletini.  They don't have that.
Ordered blended drink.  They don't have a blender.
Ordered bourbon and water.
 Served a small glass with ice and straight bourbon and a bigger  glass with water and ice.  Huh?
 I took a sip of the bourbon and then immediately a sip of water and sloshed it in my mouth then swolled..viola...bourbon and water ala Zuni.   Strange.

Dinner:
-Caesar Salad. Scrumptious
-House cured sardines with hard cheese/olives. Sardines were tasteless.
-Spaghetti with olive oil and sparce mixed greens.  Bland.

For the reputation and price, I was unimpressed.  Last time I was there was 1988, probably wait that long to go again.
author: William G.

description:
Seriously, if I had to choose my last meal before I am to be administered lethal injection, I'd order a Kir Royale, the ricotta gnocchi, the blood orange and beet salad, THE ROAST CHICKEN and about 3 dozen oysters and the Gateau Victoire and whatever flavor profile they have at the moment for their picola meringata and their espresso granita.  

My tastebuds can recall on demand the vinegary-goodness that is their panzanella, served with the roast chicken.  I love the smokiness of the toasted bread chunks soaked in sherry vinegar and extra virgin olive oil.  I love the crispy, salty chicken skin and the succulent chicken mean underneath.  This is the ONE TIME that I allow myself to eat with my hands at the table in front of others.

Is it wrong to want to order the roast chicken (for two) just for  myself?  

The staff are lovely lovely lovely people. Everyone is professional and warm.  I love that about them.  They treat everyone like guests, as we should be treated.  I'm not saying I have entitlement issues about how I'm treated in a restaurant; I'm just saying the staff really know how to make us feel welcome and taken care of.  So nice.  So genuine are their smiles, hellos, thank-yous and good-byes.  

I love going to Zuni Cafe.  I wish I could go more often!
author: Terri D.

description: The chicken is really delicious and that's what people come to Zuni's for :) the process is long to cook it but they forewarn you about that and its best to order appetizers that which they have quite a bit to choose from :) I loved their fries that come on a plate. The only thing I didn't like so much is it gets really loud in there due to they are really popular that which I understand. Definitely should go to this place at least once :)
author: Ashley P.

description:
I ate here back in December of 05. The staff wasn't very warm or friendly. The waiter was very...er... French waiter. He rolled his eyes at us and was kinda rude. BUT...it made the experience more authentic. ; )  I really like the look and feel of the restaurant though...
We were able to see the kitchen and watch the cooks at work!

The food made it worth the whole trek out there....
We ordered a whole roast chicken and it was absolutely delicious & juicy. Served with a bread salad that was wonderful. I remember the fries we ate were addicting as well and that the salad was fresh & full of flavor.

The dessert here still stands out in my mind as the tastiest lemon dessert I've ever had. Made with Meyer lemons and just the perfect balance of tart and sweet. Absolutely delicious!

I'd like to go back and try it out again and hope it does not disappoint!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
Roasted chicken was a highlight.  Great service, wonderful building and ambiance.

Pleasant.  Elegant.  Wonderful.
author: Andrew H.

description: Favorite is always the brick oven roasted chicken for two. Grilled King Salmon and the braised local sea bass are also very good. Check the daily specials for other ideas.
author: Frank S.

description: The chicken is to die for as always. But the fennel sausage,  much to our dismay, was only one sausage on the plate with a little salad and a half grilled zucchini. It really should've been offered as a small plate.
author: Donna M.

description:
The GF and I went here for an anniversary dinner and we were not disappointed.  We had to go with the roasted chicken as everybody (including our awesome waitress) mentioned it was the thing to get.  I have to say, it wasn't bad. The chicken itself wasn't dry and had a great flavor, what made the entire meal worthwhile was the bread stuffing. I could eat that on its own day in and day out.  

The atmosphere is great, a little cramped at sometimes as we were right on top of a rather drunk woman, who made sure the entire restaurant heard her, but everything was worth it. :)
author: Aaron G.

description:
Overview:
Charming, vibrant, lively, unique restaurant in the heart of San Francisco. This was my first visit to Zuni and I was very impressed. The food was exceptionally fresh, seasonal and so delectable. The restaurant itself is divided into several cool areas -- there's the main dining, the upstairs dining and the bar area. All very cool! Next time I'd love to sit in the main dining as you can see the chefs creating in the kitchen from that vantage point.  I dined here on a Tuesday evening, the restaurant was packed! I will definitely be back.

Food:
Polenta: We ordered this for our appetizer and it was simply amazing... or simple AND amazing... either way it was delish! We had both the mascarpone and Parmesan cheese on top, which made it so incredible. Maybe not the lightest app, but so worth it!

Caesar Salad: Very good. Crisp, fresh romaine with just the right amount of dressing served with homemade croutons (which were amazing!).

Filet: Compared to everything else this was a petite portion, which by this point I was quite pleased with! The filet was served sliced, and perfectly cooked. Along side the steak was fresh baby artichokes with morels. Surprisingly the dish was really light and amazing.

Ricotta Fritters: When my dinner date ordered this, I was thinking, "what the heck are you ordering?!" Boy was I so happy he did! these were light pillows of ricotta battered and deep fried. They were so light and airy, but the best part was the Meyer lemon topping. Wow! This was amazing. Order these!!

Bread: 
Simple crusty bread. Simply good. Period.

Drinks:
Full bar and wine list.

Service:
Fantastic. Attentive, but not over the top. Class act.
author: Christy J.

description:
Love the ambience and decor.  The soups and pizza's are fresh and change according to seasonal availablity.  It's my favorite go to restaurant when I attend the symphony or ballet.

The wait staff is there when you need them then they disappear and let you savor the moment of that first bite.
author: Kathleen C.

description: Went for my first time last friday. The service, ambiance, food all exceptional. However, the bathroom situation is bush league. Two single bathroom units--male and female. Each time i tried to go to the washroom there was a minimum two person line, for the mens room. I even went back to my table to "hold it in" because the lineup was so long. Once i got into the bathroom it looked worse than  starbucks. This needs improvement and is really holding the restaurant back
author: Ben K.

description:
We came here, of course, for the roast chicken.  It came highly recommended and we wanted to knock off another item from the 7x7 list.  

So was it worth a spot on the list?  Definitely.  The first bite of that roasted chicken was fabulous.  The chicken was perfectly moist and tender.  The seasoning was delicious.  The bread salad was also absolutely fantastic.  As we dug in more, the chicken started to get pretty dry.  This is something you can easily remedy by eating it with the bread salad.  Mmm legit.  As amazing as the chicken was, however, I do not believe that it was worth the $50 we paid for it.  It was very good, but there was nothing that set it apart to make that good.  

If you are coming for the roasted chicken, be careful about coming on an empty stomach.  You have to wait about an hour to get your chicken. Our table faced the kitchen.  While it was fun watching them cook and prepare the food, it certainly made us hungrier.  Granted, there are a lot of other great offerings on the menu to hold you over while you're waiting, but we were certainly eying those pizzas and hamburgers.  

We tried the Zuni Ceasar Salad while we waited.  The cheese was delicious as were the croutons.  The salad itself was good, too, but those croutons man.  It's pretty big.  We split it and it was the perfect amount.  

The décor was great!  The restaurant is absolutely adorable.  I am a big fan of natural lighting and Zuni uses it to their advantage. The service was fantastic.  We'll definitely be coming back here again.
author: Alea G.

description:
I was here for lunch with my family. 

In a few words: on a positive side, unique feel and location with large windows facing Market St, great service; on a negative: only few dishes on the menu are good, the rest are just average, and everything is EXTREMELY OVERPRICED.  The only dish worth mentioning is chicken, at $50 it is worth it: cooked just right, juicy and tender... I'd say, if you find yourself at Zuni with a date (or a friend) share the chicken - don't bother with anything else.

I do not think this place is bad, I just don't think it's worth it.
author: Leon G.

description:
A friend suggested this place for Sunday brunch.  I would call the food more lunch than brunch though.
I ordered chickpea soup and an arugula salad.  The soup was a bit on the unexpected sweet side but mighty tasty.  I was pleased to find it hot but not so hot I couldn't eat it, or taste it.  The salad had the perfect amount of dressing: just enough to coat the leaves but not saturate them. My grapefruit juice was fresh squeezed, yum!  My friend ordered the eggs and sausage with a side salad.
The presentation was lovely. The service was attentive; a nice balance between coming around often but not too often. I like the set up of the restaurant too, with the partial second level.
author: Hillary J.

description: I haven't been to Zuni Cafe in almost 7 years since I have been living in London . I was back in town visiting friends and managed to snag a reservation. For 4 people on a Friday night last minute. I was so excited because the Roast Chicken over the bread salad was always my favorite dish along with the Cesar salad. The Cesar salad is still fabulous but I'm sad to say the chicken was very disappointing. It was dried and the bread salad was missing the currants and the frisée was burned.
author: May C.

description:
For the price this place is pretty ridiculous.  They don't even give you plates for bread, which is cheap bread.  Butter was ice cold and hard to spread.

The steak was okay but heavy on lime and their plates were drenched in butter and olive oil.  It's like my food was swimming in citrus Pam.

I tried the gnocchi and it was soggy and tasted more like buttery polenta.  Just sad.

The Caesar salad was soggy and limp.

I think this place was overpriced and the food was forgettable and amateurish.  I think people who love this place either have no clue what good food is or just like talking to their friends about how they ate at an expensive trendy place where it's hard to get a table.

Skip this place.  I'd rather eat a juicy burger at Pearl's.
author: Michael M.

description:
This restaurant has very delicious food. The waiter was attentive and knowledgeable. 

My major problem was that the portion sizes varied greatly. The chicken for two is delicious, but could feed 4. The other entrees are much much smaller. Despite this problem, everything tasted great.

They have a good wine selection.

Ambiance is impressive. The restaurant is big, but feels cozy because of all the little hidden corners and the unique floor plan.
author: Caitlin H.

description: There isn't much more to say about Zuni that hasn't been said in the thousand other ratings. I had the roast chicken with the bread salad and it was delish. Maybe a bit overrated, though. It is quite expensive for what it is. It's still worth trying, and I had a pleasant experience overall in this restaurant. Friendly service and a beautiful place. If anything, it's cool because Hillary Clinton ate here once. :)
author: Annie C.

description: What a great evening! I Love introducing my daughters to great food and this will set the bar high.
author: Marc A.

description:
I was really disappointed in this place, even after hearing countless raves about their food and quality. I wanted to love it, but there were so many flaws with the meal that I won't go back or recommend it.

When we arrived a few minutes before our reservation, the hostess very curtly told us to wait at the bar, where we had good but pricey cocktails (the bartender even refused to make my friend her favorite drink, how pretentious).

We were seated upstairs at a nice table with a warm atmosophere perfect for the season. As more older wealthy Caucasians were being seated though, I started to feel the societal stares ("who let them in here?").
The waiter was great at describing the dishes and answering questions, but he seemed a little condescending, especially when he corrected the way we ordered food and drinks. But I accepted it, and it made for a funny conversation amongst us.

- Ricotta gnocchi (literally just ricotta balls posing as gnocchi), was merely decent.
- $48 chicken and bread salad - the bread salad was yummy, but the CHICKEN WAS EXTREMELY UNDERWHELMING. I totally agree with another reviewer that Costco rotisserie chicken tastes pretty much the same. Yes it was tender and somewhat juicy, but it was lacking flavor and anything extraordinary. Some pieces also had quite a bit of redness still. I cannot believe so many people have hyped this gimmick.
- Duck confit with breadcrumb stuffing was good, but not nearly the best I've had. The leg was really moist, but they didn't render the skin enough and the meat tasted exactly like chicken, no game flavor at all. The stuffing was like a knockoff of Thanksgiving, but in the worst way possible.
- Pork chop was eaten entirely by my friend, but he left the grainy polenta cake alone
- Gateau victoire and Espresso granita desserts were once again UNDERWHELMING AND PRICEY. The chocolate cake was pretty dry and lacked sweetness. The granita barely satisfied my sweet tooth, but the table didn't even finish them because they weren't true "desserts"

Maybe Zuni is all about bringing the natural flavors and elements out of their ingredients? After the dinner, that translated to me as bland, unimaginative cooking costing way too much.

There are so many better places to eat in the city, don't waste your time or money here.

** The next day - my friend tells me they had food poisoning, almost positive that it was the undercooked pieces of chicken **
author: Jeffrey Y.

description: Came here years ago and boy has it gone downhill! The waiter said pizza would take 30 minutes then it came right away and had obviously been sitting out a while. Trout had bland sauce and was so tiny for the price. The staff tried to take my plate when I was still finishing up eating (had a utensil in my hand) then gave me dirty look when I said no....seriously!
author: Karin D.

description:
Went to this restaurant based upon a Delta Flight magazine article.
Overall, the restaurant had really good food, a nice wine list, and good service.  I had a nice red burgundy, some oysters, and the signature chicken.  Definitely worth a visit!
author: Johm H.

description:
Zuni Cafe has been our list for quite some time and well worth the wait!

Parking was a bit hard to find and with the weather so chilly, we decided to use the very convenient valet service right outside the front door ($10). We went on a Wednesday evening with no reservations and were pleasantly surprised to be seated within 15 minutes of our arrival considering how busy the restaurant was. While we waited for a table, we enjoyed a glass of Zuni's Pinot Noir blend which was absolutely delish (if you love wine, you must try this!!). 

Once seated we ordered a roast chicken right away before even looking at the menu. We enjoyed more wine, olives, and gnocchi  which tasted like "little pillows of heaven" as we waited for the chicken to arrive. And when the chicken arrived, it was more of heaven. The combination of the pine nuts, currants, frisee (although I'm usually not a fan), warm bread, and roasted chicken was divine. The bread salad was so good that I may just order that as a starter next time. The portion is quite large --- there were two of us and we couldn't finish the dish. We're big on the sweet tooth, so we tried the Gâteau Victorie for dessert and thought it was just okay, hence the reason I wanted to give four stars but everything else more than made up for it. Next time we'll skip dessert and just have an extra glass of wine. : )

Overall the ambiance, the service, and the food were very lovely!
author: Komal P.

description:
A good rule of thumb, gentlemen, is that when you knock an entire carafe of water on your date, don't just yell at her, "IT'S NOT MY FAULT. IT'S THIS TABLE'S FAULT! THIS RESTAURANT IS TERRIBLE!"

Cool your jets, sir, and clean up the mess you made. And when you're done, thank the waitstaff for being so patient as you saddle your fannypacked ass with complimentary bread and butter. 

So the diners at the next table aside, the food at Zuni is excellent, though with as many reviews having said the same, that shouldn't be a surprise. I loved my heirloom tomato soup appetizer, my roommate loved her faro salad, and we shared a mutual adoration of the roast chicken. I'm not really a fan of eating things off bone (I'm at the top of the food chain for a reason, and that reason is because I can use a fork) but the chicken was so tender that it required little effort on my part to get a mouthful. The tart bread salad underneath offset the salty sweet flavor of the meat nicely. 

But it's the service that really impresses. From our uncouth dining partners to us being silly twenty-somethings asking for the cheapest bottle of wine available, they handled everything with charm and grace. And they fixed the wobbly table.
author: Devon S.

description:
A bit let down based on all the rave reviews we've heard - and read - about this place. Our first disappointment was that they weren't serving their famous burger...they serve it for lunch and then begin serving it again at 10 pm. It was 6:15 pm and our last night in the city. 

My $28 rabbit...ehhh. Not nearly enough balsamic reduction sauce to give it flavor and too much work for me. (I was hoping for a repeat of some amazing rabbit I had in Quebec, but it wasn't to be.) My husband said his salmon was good, but nothing to knock his socks off. My teenage son, who is a gnocchi fiend, wasn't so crazy about his ricotta gnocchi...I confirmed his opinion that they were kinda mushy. Our Parmasan cheese plate and Meyer lemon tart were inhaled in seconds in a family-wide feeding frenzy. 

Service was good...nothing to complain about, but not over the top either. The atmosphere is great...love the open kitchen. 

We'll go back...at lunch or after 10 pm to try out this burger (supposedly rated by some important culinary person or publication as one of the top 30 dishes to travel for). I'll let you know if it lives up to that lofty reputation...
author: Janet D.

description: Trend,Classic,Cutting Edge there's only one Zuni it's here to stay....Thank you Judy for all the great food you serve and your standards... We miss you VINCE.........
author: Flexington S.

description:
Reasons why I DON'T consider this place worthwhile at this time:
- $48 for a roasted chicken, PLUS taxes.
- Waiting more than an hour for a just average meal.
- Charging 4% for the Healthy San Francisco program.

I do appreciate that all this information is provided on the menu when ordering, so nothing is hidden, no surprises. So I accept that we chose to go ahead and spend this money, and wait for the chicken.

I know that friends from SoCal that get to enjoy really good Peruvian roasted chicken are gonna be laughing at me for paying that much.

Well, my brother paid for the meal so I shouldn't be fuming about the price, other than it wasn't worth it. The dark meat was fine, the white meat was a bit dry. The table next to us said they didn't have that problem, so I guess we got the odd one (or maybe they were lying to me, who knows). I can make better roasted chicken at home. Any good crispy skin chicken at a Chinese restaurant is way better and cheaper. And I even consider the Costco roasted chicken to be better.

Friends that like this place say that the burger is great, and a few told me that I would have had a better meal if we ordered other menu items instead. I respect their opinions, so if I ever decide to come back and experience a better meal, I'll revise this review.

My other issue is the "Health Surcharge". I'm aware of the HSF program and support providing health benefits to all employees (should be operating costs, instead of passing costs onto customers). But the amount charged is higher than other places. Somehow Delfina manages to do fine by charging $1.25, and Zazie in Cole Valley charges $1. Those are fine dining restaurants. What's so different about Zuni's health plan, that they need to charge so much more? What, not enough profit with the $48 chicken? For me it doesn't seem right to charge more than what they need from customers, under the ruse of providing benefits for employees. The ironic part is that the SF Restaurant Association is suing the city to eliminate the HSF program requirement. Restaurants say they support benefits for employees, while at the same time try to eliminate the program, that's funny. In the meantime they just want someone else to pay for the cost. LOL!
author: Luis C.

description: I've been here a few times in the past few years.  It has always been good food, if a little pricey.  The place itself is interesting with its little rooms and nooks and crannies.  The ceasar salad was good, and I had some ricotta gnocchi that were very good.  Service was good.  The bar area is small and has no seating, but it's also fun to hang out there.  I've gone to dinner with groups, met a group at the bar, and had a dinner with my mom and her boyfriend here, and each of those visits was really nice.  I love that it's close to Hotel Biron, makes for a nice evening :)
author: Andrea T.

description: This restaurant has been one that I have wanted to try for a while now so on our last trip to San Francisco we were finally able to try it.  The menu had a lot of good things on it so I asked our waitress what was best.  She said the hamburgers were amazing but that usually people want to try something more special.  I decided that sounded good and I was glad I ordered it.  It was so incredibly good.  They cooked it perfectly and they had it seasoned so well that it was honestly the best burger I have ever had.  The skinny fries were also good.  I would highly recommend this restaurant and look forward to eating here again.
author: Nicole W.

description:
If you're looking to check out one of SF's best restaurants, Zuni is a must. Their signature dish, roasted chicken over bread salad is nothing short of a miracle.  I never order chicken at restaurants - boring.  Zuni changed that. This is the most moist and flavorful chicken you will ever taste. 100% worth the @ 1 hour wait - just order it as soon as you sit down - they're used to that. Then order an appetizer and a drink (I recommend the balsamic bloody mary) and sit back and relax, cuz I haven't even told you about the best part, yet. The bread salad. Big chunks of toasted, butter coated sourdough bread, tossed with herbs and greens and toasted pine nuts. Absolutely my very favorite dish ever.  

Everything else on their menu is excellent as well, from their extensive oyster selection to the polenta appetizer. You can't make a bad choice here and you won't leave disappointed.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I came here with my boss and coworker for lunch. The environment is cute, the place seem big but the way they use their space made it seem small but inviting.

They change their menu daily.  We ordered 

1. shoestring potato (love it) once you start munching on it, it's hard to stop; 
2. pork chop with brussels sprouts and bread crumbs on top (the pork chop was cooked just right); 
3. olive oil and lemon dressing with greens salad
4. cheese thin pizza. 

I have to say the pizza really made my day, the cheese was strong but just right for my taste. It had pecorino, onions, radicchio in it. Imagine biting into it then close your eyes. The aroma and taste of the cheese will melt in your mouth. It can be a bit overwhelming for non cheese lovers. heart.
author: Christina W.

description: I hereby define a "Zuni" as the one good thing in a selection that is nearly impossible to get.  Much like the chicken.  Example: "All of our poisons are on sale this week.  We also have shvitz and massage, but it is $10,000 and the soonest reservation is in 2019.  Kind of a Zuni."
author: JJJJJ M.

description:
I went to Zuni Cafe on the second evening of a long-weekend in San Fran. Overall it was pretty good, but unmemorable.  

I enjoyed grabbing a drink at the bar as we were waiting for our table more than the actual meal and dining experience itself.  If I were to go back I would be more inclined to enjoy a cocktail and apps at the bar.

In hindsight I should of ordered the roast chicken; it is for two and takes extra time to prepare, but it looked worth the wait;  I stared at it creepily after arriving at a nearby table ;)
author: Ryan B.

description:
I can FINALLY say that I've been to Zuni Cafe.

After it had been bookmarked on my list for over a year, we made reservations for dinner at Zuni on a Saturday night (it IS possible, btw). Zuni is usually so overbooked that we had to find out what all the hype was about. 

Okay, the real reason is this: after Yelp did that piece on Michael Mina's all-time favorite eats in SF- Zuni's "Chicken for Two" being one of them, I just had to go! Can't be helped- I'm easily influenced. The yelp gods tell me where I should eat, and I go (armed with a reservation, of course).

Alright kids, Zuni IS as fantastic as they say. Their bartenders (even though I only had an orange juice) are as talented as others have raved about in the past. So why only four stars, Elaine (queen of the five star rating, which I tend to distribute out like candy on Halloween)? Oh, I'll tell you why:

$48 CHICKEN.

Star docked. I'm probably going to get a lot of flack for saying this, but I hope everyone is aware that you can get an entire rotisserie chicken at Costco for $4.99. Mmm Hmm, and it's pretty darn good too. 

AND, on top of the price, their damn chicken is soooo special that it requires an hour to prepare, and is ONLY prepared fresh to order. To be fair, the waitstaff and kitchen are trained to carefully space out any starters or small plates ordered so that the hour it takes to prepare this precious poultry doesn't seem so excruciatingly long. We ordered some salads or whatever, I don't remember. What I DO remember is that we each timed the chicken, giving them a very generous 5 minute grace period, in case they were late. They came in at 63 minutes from the time we ordered it. Not bad.

Keep in mind, you might be able to scoop up a late-night reservation to Zuni on OpenTable. And if you can, you probably should. Even a 9PM or 10PM reservation isn't so bad! They close at midnight on Fri/Sat, so you'd still have time to order the magical "chicken for two" dish that has made Zuni (in)famous.

The chicken dish WAS very good- over-priced!- but delicious. It was the most juicy and tender I have ever eaten (but it's still just chicken). Also, we were stationed by the window- nice view, but the seating was wack. The table was at an incline, which can be reeeally annoying if you have OCD like I do. Request a table upstairs, if possible.
author: Elaine T.

description:
I can't believe I haven't been here yet.  When I was in college - I remember my much more experienced food-loving coworkers raving about how delicious (and how definitively San Francisco) this place was and thinking to myself I have to go here one day!  Now that my visits to San Francisco restaurant establishments are well into the hundreds (if not two or three hundreds - jeez San Francisco, why do your restaurants have to be so good?) - I can't believe it took me so long to go.

So I finally find an excuse to go (not like I ever really need an excuse) - to see a friend for our last San Francisco brunch before she moved.  So I make my reservation way in advance (as I've been tipped to do many moons ago) and on the day of - I find myself running way behind thanks to having to scurry through 3 forms of transportation (thanks Muni).  I tell my friend to go ahead and tell the hostess that I was running late and was expecting disgruntled waitstaff when I got there.  To my surprise - I was completely wrong!  They were way cool about me being late and even sympathized with my Muni failure moment.  They seated us quickly and with a smile.  

As soon as we sat - I awed at the high ceilings, floor to ceiling windows, and large/open space where they don't cram their patrons like sardines.  This restaurant oozes of well-established San Francisco restaurant ambiance.  

As for food - we had the salmon, the burger, and the honey ice cream.   While I wouldn't exactly give them style points for being creative - fresh ingredients and simple California-style creations are an A in my book.  Delighted to have finally crossed this one off my list!
author: Jean A.

description:
"A fool is soon parted with his money." I remember seeing this quote in a fortune cookie once & didn't know what it meant until I set foot in Zuni Cafe.

Zuni gets a pat on the back for pulling off a scam that only exists because of San Francisco's "foodie" & "epicurean" environment: people happily & eagerly part with their $48 for CHICKEN, even in our time of recession, just to see what the hype is all about. The bf & I gave into the hype & our curiosity led us to Zuni this past Thursday for dinner. 

We arrive 20 minutes after our reservation time (oops) due to traffic & circling the block for parking. When we arrived, the hostess led us to an upstairs table with fantastic views of Market street. The soothing melody of a piano plays in the background of all the laughter & conversation. The decor was simple & almost rustic: exposed bricks & beams, minimal wall decorations. Right away, we placed our "chicken for two" order.

In the hour it took for our chicken to arrive, the bf & I enjoyed:
- an appetizer of Serrano ham, peppers & walnuts, a limonata (san pellegrino, cute bottle, tastes like a million bucks) & a mountain of shoestring fries, which were salty & crispy & "what fries should taste like," as my bf observed.

Finally, the piece de resistance arrives in an unceremonious, anti-climatic way. This is the chicken we've been waiting an hour for? This is the chicken, with a few sprigs of greens sticking out the bottom, that's breaking our bank? After our initial few bites, the bf & I look at one another, almost embarrassed that we'd been duped. It's freakin chicken- moist, salted, yummy chicken with light crispy skin and a bread salad that was a perfect compliment. It was delicious chicken, but not "$48 chicken." This isnt the end all, be all chicken that some reviewers paint it to be. This chicken isnt going to change your life or your perception about chicken. I just can't say it was worth the price.

The food at Zuni is certainly top notch & the bustling atmosphere is a joy to be a part of, which means I will be returning, but just not for $48 chicken. How would I ever face my Filipino family ever again, who buys chicken from Safeway & Costco for a fraction of what Zuni charges? And, as if to mock me & the $104 we spent, when I got home that night, there was a bucket of KFC sitting on my kitchen table...
author: Fancypants X.

description:
This is a good place to take a first date if your primary intent is to convey the following message:  

"I like you but I'm not going to try too hard to impress you on this first date.  I'm going to spend a decent amount of money for overpriced food to show you that I'm not poor.  I'm not boring but I'm not super exciting.  You should go on a second date with me, because I am basically providing you with no information other than the foregoing on this first date."

Seriously, that's what you're saying.  This place is just....very safe.  Decent food, good atmosphere (but feels, honestly, a bit dated to me).  It's so not memorable that it's memorable.  That's not a good thing, by the way.
author: Chris H.

description:
Thank you to the many, many people who recommended this place to me - from my partner's mom to my hair stylist to my friend from high school in Idaho. Such a lovely place, with warm ambiance filled with sunlight and white tablecloths. Everything that passed on the trays looked delectable, making the down-select process nearly impossible. Everything was great, from burgers to oysters, but I gotta say the stand out was my onion leek soup with a buttered crostini floater.   

And I must give props to the staff. They were very accommodating when I called the day before for brunch reservations. Service was friendly, speedy, and they even remembered our deadline to shove off for a show after the meal. Bravo, Zuni! Bravo!
author: Veronica L.

description:
After a alcohol drenched week this place was like an oasis in the desert for my liver. 

I got the avocado and mandarin salad to start, it was like dipping my head in iced water, my liver started dancing up and down with happiness.

For my main I got the sole with sweet potatoes on the side. It was cooked perfectly and the server was so attentive, he even de-boned the fish for my friend.

I finished with some crème brulée which was divine. Everyone at the table loved their dishes, the service was excellent, the atmosphere was warm and quintessentially American with the piano playing below.

Bring someone on a date here and you have scored!
author: Annie L.

description:
Best roast chicken? evah? Tough billing. How good can roast chicken get?

So we came  in on a beautiful mid-afternoon, sun shining through the restaurant, a bustling kitchen, great scene.

Takes an hour for this roasted chicken with warm bread salad for two, so we put the order down and then slowed picked at our caesar salad. Fresh, crisp greens, just the right dusting of anchovies and caesar. Nice.

So the roast chicken arrives, (finally) and it is essentially quartered, tossed with greens and crispy, slightly sour chunks of warm bread with currants and onions.

Not bad....moist, even the white meat parts, small but tasty. But, it's still roasted chicken....tastes like chicken, good chicken, but chicken nonetheless. $48 dollars worth? Not likely. Costco and Swiss Chalet can make it just as moist and crispy, $5 bucks....so would I try it again? No. If you're in the mood for roasted chicken though...good meal.

The atmosphere and salad made the meal noteworthy. Still, much ado about chicken.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
I came here for a Saturday Lunch.
Well...the location is a little scary but the place itself is great. The architecture of the little building and the inside decor is really unique and nice.
We had to wait at the bar for a seat - which is no problem as you can start with a drink.
I wasn't excited about the menu...being a non-meat eater, the options are very limited (yes, even people that do not eat meat, eat more then a salad). At the end I had grilled fish with veggies on the side. It was good but not outstanding...very salty and over seasoned for my taste.

The service was great - attentive and fun but not too pushy. Nice experience.

Pretty pricey but I guess if you choose to come here, you are aware of that...

Friends are raving abot the roasted chicken and the Bloody Mary.
author: Konstanze W.

description: My husband and I really enjoyed our dinner at Zuni. Our server was very pleasant and helpful. My husband had the polenta appetizer and I had a red lentil soup. Both very delicious. We had the roasted chicken for two and it did not disappoint! So moist and the bread salad underneath was heavenly. The pluot sorbet was hands down one of the best fresh sorbet desserts I've ever had.
author: Nicole C.

description: I really like Zuni (minus the location). Beautiful decor and friendly staff. If you go, order the chicken - it is to die for. Be prepared to be stuffed beyond belief. I also like their fries, which I have no shame stuffing my face with (using my fork of course). Something about the inside is a bit stifling, I can't put my finger on it... but it may just be the tights I wore both nights. Go in comfortable clothing so you can breath while you roll yourself home. Smorgasbord, on the ground, all around.
author: Melanie S.

description: I've eaten here many times. But have to revise my review to reflect tonight's meal. Almost all of our dishes were brought to us lukewarm. The first time it happened I figured it was a timing thing. The second time I started to wonder. But when our main course of quail (we were sharing) showed up tepid and looking kind of pale (fully cooked but not crispy in any way, and with a few anemic grill marks), I became alarmed. Is Zuni slipping!?? Are they coasting on their past reputation?  Probably. But still, I expected more. We mentioned this to the waiter, and the host came over to apologize in a minute. A very nice gesture. But I wish we hadn't had to mention it at all. Moral of story, if we want Zuni to stay up to its reputation, you need to let them know!
author: Priscilla C.

description:
This is a great place that's good for a special occasion or out-of-town guests.  The chicken with bread salad is a must.  Their caesar salad is solid, and their other salads / starters are fresh and well-prepared, so I would definitely recommend trying those out.  When coming with groups (e.g. 3-6 people), I find that ordering family style, and sharing several starters and the chicken is the way to go.  As a rule of thumb, if ordering a few starters, one chicken is enough for 3 people.

The cocktails are also great.  If you sit down at a table you sometimes have to ask for the cocktail menu.

I've also tried the duck confit main, which was very tasty, but no Zuni Chicken, and my fiancé has tried the fish there maybe once or twice and found it to be OK.
author: Eytan B.

description:
Zuni Cafe is a wonderful mainstay in our dinning rotation.  We go here every few months for lunch, and about once a year for dinner.  The food is well done, the atmosphere is amazing (great light during lunch), and the cocktails are wonderful. 

In the negative side, we have found the service over the years to be a bit spotty, and the presentation for the oysters has gone way downhill.   

In sum, a great place for a casual lunch, and overall a place that everyone should hit.
author: Brian M.

description:
Believe the hype!  This chicken is the shiz!  Juiciest breasts of chicken I've had outside of chicken soup.  Only thing I wasnt digging on was the bitter leaves of salad that comes along with it, but the bread soaking in chicken juice made up for that.  

Atmosphere is great on a sunny day like today.  You can grab a drink and sit outside and eat or wait for your table.  

4 stars for food and atmosphere.
-1 for price and spilling a beer on myself (top heavy beer glasses, but still my fault)
author: dion c.

description: I met up with my cousin to grab lunch and we came to Zuni. It's kind of hard to get to if you want to drive here, but they do have valet tucked away on the side of the restaurant. I've been waiting to try the burger here for quite some time and it was oustanding! I ordered it with caramlized onions and white cheddar and it came on grilled rosemary fococcia with garlic aioli and sweet pickles. I also got the shoestring fries. I wasn't a fan of the fries because they were a little too fried and thin so that the consistency was more chip-like than a fry, The fresh lemonade that I ordered was superb and the service was great. I'm definitely bringing my boyfriend here to try this awesome burger!
author: Sheeva G.

description:
My Chinese mother would freak out if she knew I paid $48 for a roast chicken. "Costco only $5 dollars". Mama, let me justify why paying $48 for a mere roast chicken alone was so worth it: 

1.) I got to share 2 orders of roast chicken with 3 wonderful friends over wine, a side of thin crispy shoestring fries, and the creamiest, freshest oysters I've had to date--all enjoyed at a table overlooking the oyster bar and kitchen. Did I mention they have a live pianist playing music while you enjoy your dinner? 

2.) Now, let's start with the chicken skin. It was perfectly crispy, paper thin, and tasted like the chicken had been brining in salt and bathing in butter and herbs from birth. How great it would be to eat an entire plate of this crispy skin...but, alas, there is the meat...

3.) Ah, the meat. I honestly could not differentiate between the white and dark meat because every piece of chicken I had was like dark meat -- smooth, juicy, and bursting with flavor. 

4.) And the bread salad stuffing? Let's just say this girl ate all her salad. The stuffing was crispy yet moist and tasty. It accompanied the chicken very well. Next time I have a salad, it'll have to be a bread salad where the stuffing is proportionately greater than lettuce and you have to move chicken aside to get to the greens...

So, Mama, I hope you understand now why I paid $48 for chicken. I was being a good Chinese daughter by investing in making my belly happy so one day I could give you chubby grandchildren. Okay...hmmm...that last statement was a tad of a stretch...
author: Sue L.

description:
Arrived here a little than expected, about 2ish for lunch. We had a glass of Lillet at the bar (so what if it's Sunday...can always drink) while we waited for an outside table to open up. It was a nice atmosphere and today was such a warm day in the city! Too bad the guy standing kinda next to us had play dough skin sticking out as he leaned over the bar while he chatted up his date. Gross! I seriously almost lost all my appetite. 

Finally made it outside! Minus the homeless walking pass, it was a great time. I always feel a bit guilty eating when someone less fortunate is going pass us...
On our menu:
-Littleneck Clams
-Sand Isle Kumamoto
-Caesar Salad
-Pizza w/ ricotta and oregano
-Special of the day was Sea Bass I think. Had this too...yummers

I've never been much of a raw oyster fan, but I was more than impressed with theirs! I'm definitely coming back just for the oysters!
author: Lola D.

description:
Meal: Roast Chicken, String fries, gnocchi, oysters

I think the best part of the meal tastewise were the gnocchi.  They were diffferent and the mushrooms in the dish really brought out the flavors of the cheese gnocchi well.

The chicken was pretty good.  Was it $50 good?  No.  Glad i tried it, but i'll probably never order it again.
author: Lawrence C.

description: I stick by my guns: my favorite restaurant in all of America.
author: K E.

description:
The two of us came here for the first time on a Sunday afternoon, 2-13-2011, ready to have brunch... and then I remembered I had heard so many good things about the Roast Chicken... so the brunch idea was dismissed, we ordered the Roast and started the 1-hour wait for it to arrive.

We decided to keep the brunch spirit anyway and had two mimosas to start with and wash away the morning from the mouth. Since the wait seemed a bit long and we hadn't had anything, we asked for a french toast, a white bean salad and the shoestring potatoes. It might seem surprising to praise the french toast before I even talk about the roast chicken, but well, that's what we had first and it was GOOD!!! The blood orange cuts on the toast made it heavenly and everything just melt in the mouth. The salad was pretty good too with a  very nice light dressing. The potatoes were ok, as mentioned here not as crunchy as expected, but delicious. By this time, we had two bloody marys as well, which had set the right mood for the roast to arrive.

And then the roast arrived... I had stuffed myself enough up to this point to confidently state that my love for it was not because I was simply hungry... it was fantastic!!! and everything I had heard was so true! The moist seasoned chicken with the moist bread crumbs... This is something which we will go back to, repeatedly.

The whole experience was nice overall, with the service being pleasant.
author: Tara H.

description: The roasted chicken here is as good as the reviews say. No overstatement. Enough said. Go and eat the chicken & bread salad. (But apparently, order it when you arrive- it takes an hour to prepare.)
author: Sarah K.

description:
It's rare when one can ever rave about a restaurant for a chicken dish.  Normally places can fry it to add a little excitement, maybe add some sauce to cover up the dryness, but not at Zuni Cafe.  The roast chicken for two is moist, tender, and totally off the hook!  I don't know when I've ever enjoyed chicken as much in my entire life.  My mouth is watering just thinking about it.  It comes with this totally awesome bread salad too (think best stuffing ever!)  The bread totally soaks up the juices of the bird and has this great, almost subtle, dare I say slight vinegary quality to it?

Here's my tip:  The chicken takes an hour to cook, so make sure to order it right away when you sit down.  One of the guys in our group actually told the hostess that we were ordering the chicken and the order was placed as soon as we sat down.  

We also ordered some clams (decent) and other appetizers, which I remember as being good, but the chicken was so incredibly good, it erased all the other dishes from my memory.

They also have some decent cocktails.  The bloody mary is really unique and tastes a lot fresher than your standard bloddy mary.  It definitely has a strong, rich tomato flavor.  I kind of wished I had ordered mine spicy, but it was a pretty decent cocktail.

So yeah, I'm heading back to SF on business again in 3 weeks and I'm making sure to stop by Zuni Cafe for chicken.  Get there and order it!  You won't regret it.
author: Michael S.

description:
Had a lunch date on one of the most beautiful days in San Francisco. My lady friend was late, so I ordered one of the best mimosas I've ever had and took in the scenery. This is the kind of place I imagined when I think of brunch in San Francisco. I ordered the eggs fried in rapini with black lentils and harissa, not knowing what half the items in the title were but sure I would google them the instant I got home. It was absolutely delicious. The service was top notch. I'll definitely schedule another lunch date here (it's busy, make a reservation).

On a funnier note, while I was standing in line for the bathroom a gentlemen tried a pick up line on me that started with... "Being one of the only straight guys here..." A true San Francisco moment.
author: Beth K.

description: Fried chicken for two. Two (or more) brilliant Manhattans, excellent service. Pure bliss. Enough said. Eat here!
author: Nicolas E.

description: One of my absolutely favorite places to splurge for a great meal in SF! As you know for the numerous reviews, you can't go wrong with the roasted chicken! Yes, it is that good and yes is is worth the hour long wait! The clams here are also really enjoyable as an appetizer as are the seasonal salads. The wine and dessert selection has also never let me down. I found the service to be attentive and always enjoy a leisurely meal here.
author: Marissa P.

description:
After years of living in the city, we finally made it here. We arrived on time and were going to be seated immediately, but I didn't realize they have a lot of upstairs seating and due to some temporary medical issues, I can't go upstairs. They were very accommodating but we had to wait about 20 minutes for a table downstairs. There is a nice bar area, but no stools. Luckily they had some chairs by the piano so I was able to sit down.

We were able to get our order in for the chicken as soon as we sat down and then our waiter returned for our drinks and apps order. my husband started with the caesar salad which looked good - not too much dressing, and I decided on the rabbit sausage. I was expecting something heavy, but it was a smaller sausage with really delicate flavor, very delicious. My husband also ordered oysters which he enjoyed. The half bottle of wine was not his favorite though.

They kept our sparkling water refilled and the bread they serve is very good. It is quite a wait for the chicken, even when having appetizers, but it turned out to be okay. We also ordered the matchstick fries which were delicious. It looks like a massive amount of chicken when it arrives, but we were able to finish just about all the chicken (we didn't eat all the greens or bread salad though). Overall, we enjoyed the chicken and it was perfectly cooked, but it wasn't necessarily something I'd go raving about. Maybe it's just chicken that's not that exciting to me. We thought it was good, but not necessarily something that either of us would be running back for. If chicken is your thing though, definitely check it out. The other food we had was good as well, and service was also solid so I'd definitely recommend the place.
author: Lauren M.

description:
I went here for my sister's birthday dinner. 

Love the atmosphere here. It's lively and fun and not so loud that you can't have a decent conversation. 

Our server was extremely friendly....although that friendliness went down a little after my father came into the picture. Even with my father being slightly rude our server was professional and courteous.

I have heard tons of great things about the chicken and if I had to wait an hour (yes an hour!) then so be it. I am very happy to say I was not disappointed! The best rotisserie chicken I've ever had and the bread salad that came along with it was fantastic. The chicken was tender and moist and the bread salad had tons of flavor. Also, if you order the chicken skip the bread basket because it's a lot of food! I felt like I could have split it between three if not four people! 

If you're going to make the trip here you have to try the chicken at least once!
author: Jessica F.

description: I've been going to Zuni's since the mid 80s, every time I visit SF I go to Zuni's and this time I was disappointed, not in the wine or oysters, but in the service and other dishes. The poor presentation of the anchovies was laughable, and the waitress forgot our pasta which came out at the end of the meal and it was not very good. We wanted to order the famous chicken dish but she said it would take over an hour, meanwhile the other tables who arrived after us had their chicken within 30 minutes ... and it wasn't a busy evening. Something has changed and it's a pity. Next time I visit I probably won't go there unless improvements are made.
author: Annee E.

description:
My parents used to bring me to Zuni when I was a child. I have many fond memories of punctuating small and big moments in my life with a meal at Zuni. 

Zuni never disappoints after all these years. The quality and consistency are still stellar.
author: Jeannie G.

description:
I had seen and heard about this place for awhile before actually trying it, so when my parents came in town, I thought it was as good a time as any to try it out.

We were seated promptly upon arrival and had a wonderful waiter who was both very helpful and very attentive. Not sure of what to order other than the famous chicken and bread salad, we decided on fried flounder for an appetizer, shoestring fries, bread and chicken salad and the baked halibut. Over ambitious? Yes. We ordered way too much food. The chicken and bread salad could EASILY feed 3 people (opposed to the 2 that the menu suggests). I mean WOW, we did not know what we were getting ourselves into.

To start, we had the fried flounder which was very good. The fish tasted fresh and it wasn't overly greasy. The shoestring fries were actually served almost as an appetizer, which we thought would just come with our entrees, but since the chicken and bread salad takes an hour to cook, they brought them out early. The fries were good, I think I just prefer a little more substantial fry as opposed to super thin straws. But nonetheless they were good.

While we waited we enjoyed a bottle of Sauvignon Blanc that was delicious and refreshing. After salivating over other table's chicken and bread salads, ours finally arrived. Let me tell you, it is most definitely worth the wait. The roasted chicken is OUT of this world. I think roasted chicken might be on my top five favorite foods list. The chicken is so moist and juicy and the french bread is drenched in the roasting liquids that contains quite a bit of vinegar which is what made me fall so deeply in love with it. The flavors were just incredible. The halibut was very good, but it definitely didn't hold a candle to the chicken and bread which was hands down the star of the meal.

To finish we chose something on the lighter side, I believe it was the honey ice cream with a crunchy natural brittle. It was a very good and very light ending to this fabulous meal.
author: Emily S.

description:
I am going to say in advance that I cannot afford to regularly have dinner in places like Zuni, so I might just sound too enthusiastic just because of a lack of comparison, but Zuni is one of the best place I have ever eaten. In the world. 

I went there tonight with my best friend her sister, her mom gave me her ticket to go see the nutcracker, so I was already happy and in a very good mood. We had quite an early dinner [5pm] but the place was already full. 

First of all Zuni is just nice. The service is impeccable. The restaurant layout and light perfect. 

We sat upstairs on a balcony over the kitchen area. I liked it but it was definitely too warm [we were wearing our stripeless evening gowns and were feeling a little hot] and, whenever they opened the oven where they cooked the chicken, I could smell it. I had the feeling I would smell like that all night. But the waiter notice himself without us having to say a word and I think he kinda did something because after that you couldn't smell it anymore. 

We order a bottle of champagne which was great, and my glass was never empty. 
I had the prosciutto crostini and the risotto with mushroom and pecorino.
My friend and her sister had both one of their salads, now I am forgetting which one, and my friend got  mussles, while her sister ordered oysters.
