we didn't have time for dessert because the ballet was about to start, but their capuccino granita with creamed sounded really interesting. 

If I had a special occasion or wanted to impress someone, I would go back there. It's definitely worth the money spent. 

It's not a 5 stars, because the food was good but not as impressive at could have been. The crostini were exceptional, but the risotto was just good. I know risotto, and I know it could have been much better.
author: Elena A.

description:
What a great traditional restaurant.  The service is top notch, and I loved the atmosphere.  Our table was in a nook upstairs, a little removed from the rest of the restaurant.

We ordered several oysters-  I particularly enjoyed the Nookas (sp?).  We also get the polenta, the chicken, and gnocchi.  This was more than enough between 3 people.  The polenta was standard, and the gnocchi was amazingly soft and juicy.  The chicken exceeded everything we ate!! My gosh is the chicken and bread good!  

Remember to order chicken right when you get there because it takes an entire hour!

Next time I go I'll probably just order a half dozen oysters and a chicken to split between myself and my girl friend.. maybe Ellie too if she comes!
author: Peter G.

description:
Simply Beautiful. 

Deliciously superb food.

Wait staff is professional and friendly.

Bar staff is knowledgeable and amazing.

A+ stuff.

Spendy, but you can do lunch on a budget without regretting it.
author: Roger C.

description: Wow wow wow - another bucket list item checked off in spectacular fashion. Went here for my girlfriend's birthday dinner, and it turned out to be Zuni's 36th birthday too - that very night! Our server Chris was outstanding. He brought over no fewer than 3 different tastes of wine before we settled on a bottle. He was very patient with our indecision. The chicken lived up to it's billing and more. We did remember to order it the moment we sat down, and the wine and appetizers did a great job of tiding us over until the chicken arrived. It didn't feel anything like a full hour. (I don't know how long it actually took) The chicken was very moist with crispy, but not too crispy skin. Lightly seasoned, you actually taste the chicken - not just a ton of seasoning on chicken. What else can I say? Best chicken of your life! Amazing service! Bring your parents! Bring your colleagues! Bring a date! Can't wait to go back again.
author: Nico O.

description: Um, wow. Where to begin? This was definitely one of the best meals I have had in San Francisco, and I've been here 3 years. The service was incredibly professional. These folks are clearly well trained, and the communication between the waitress, servers, and kitchen is streamlined to the point where you wonder how they do it. No detail was neglected throughout our entire time at Zuni. We started with a pre-dinner cocktail at the bar, then moved to our table. Our waitress helped us choose a bottle of wine in our price range, even suggesting one a bit cheaper. When my partner's oysters came she knew the names of each one by its shell shape and told us shes an oyster fanatic when I asked how she could possibly remember all those fancy names. Our mascarpone salad was divine. My partner loved his rabbit dish. I loved my gnocchi - they were lighter than most gnocchi I've had, almost reminiscent of an Asian style dumpling. Now the standout dish, surprisingly, was the periwinkle clams which were accompanied by tiny tomatoes and tiny peppers - forget the names. How funny that the tomatoes and peppers were the stars of this entire show - they were seriously bursting with flavor, and the peppers were lightly grilled. The sauce was a bit tangy and spicy. Yum. What an awesome anniversary dinner indeed!
author: Mark S.

description:
I'll be the first to admit it - I totally poo-pooed the fifty-dollar chicken when I first heard about it.  I mean, come on.  It's chicken.  
But people would not shut up about it!  They kept raving and oohing and aahing  about it - their eyes rolling back in ecstasy, even drooling with just the thought of tasting this succulent bird again.

So, after much arm twisting, I finally caved and I went to Zuni.  Of course I was totally skeptical and actually a little pissed that I was about to blow fifty bucks on something as mundane as roasted chicken.

So while we waited for the chicken, we sipped on cocktails and munched on some appetizers which were quite good, especially the creamy polenta and the shoestring fries.  The restaurant is in a really cool, open space so with some good friends and good convo, the wait actually flies by.

After about an hour, the world famous chicken finally arrives at our table and admittedly, it looked pretty tasty.  But still, it was just chicken...right?  

OH.
MY.
GOD.

THE best chicken I've ever had.  

I didn't know chicken could taste so good.  I will have dreams about this chicken, and all future chicken dishes will be held up against the Zuni chicken.  And I will have to return to Zuni again and again, for more fifty dollar chicken.

Damn.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Maybe they were having an off day, but I had a pretty disappointing lunch:

- The fettunta gave new meaning to the term "garlic rubbed"- my throat was burning from the intensity.  It was comparable to smoking a bitter cigar.  My date tried some and had the same reaction.

- The sausage was cold and raw on the inside, and they had to take it back to cook it some more.

The presentation was nice, and so was the lemongrass tea, but the difficulties with the food negated any positive experience.
author: Rego S.

description:
For the price, yes Meh, I've experienced better.
It's not that the food is not delicious, but it's just not that amazing for the price.  I've had brunch here a few times, and dinner once.

My last meal there last Friday:
oysters: good
gem lettuce salad: really a waste of money, no exciting flavors or textures, weird creme fraiche drizzled over it, and so small...kind of overdressed and slimy too
ricotta gnocchi w/ peas and mint: really too wet for me, partner liked the flavor, it was subtle
pork chop: good, but kind of like a REALLY nice DINER porkchop, nothing too special.  I feel like I could've made it at home.

The oysters are really good here, and I'm pretty sure they serve Tartine bread, because the bread is delicious.  The butter is delicious too.

The ambiance is nice and the location is convenient.
But honestly, it's pricey and the food is not memorable.
author: YJ P.

description: One of my favorite restaurants on the planet!  A special SF ambiance, warm and friendly...and food and drink that is out of this world!  I've discovered more delectable treats here for the first time than I can count.  For example...Zuni did Cosmos before there WERE Cosmos!  Not to be missed...eat everything!   ....mmmm, the burger, the roasted currant chicken and bread, the FRIES....mmmmmmmmmmmmmDOH!
author: Howard B.

description:
I've lived in San Francisco since 1995 and it took me 14 years to finally make it to Zuni. They're known for their roast chicken. I thought, meh... you can roast a chicken at home. And then I tasted it...

(The light pops on... the choir sings...)

Juicy, well-seasoned, delicious... something magical happens in their brick oven. The chicken sits on top of a warm bread salad, delicious on its own, but even more so as it sits soaking up some of the juices from that chicken.

We came here recently for a return visit, and we enjoyed the chicken and warm bread salad just as much as the first time.
author: Joel A.

description:
Unbelievably Amazing.

I went with my friend's uncles a few nights ago. Great food-Great wine-Great fun.

The chicken is entirely worth it. Slow cooked for an hour, stunningly flavored, and simply delicious. The bread salad with the chicken was equally phenomenal. 

The bread given to everyone was great. The oysters were spot on. The caesar was fresh and crisp. The Lemon Panna Cotta was to die for. The service was unbelievable. The interior was refreshingly airy, while being equally sophisticated. The crowd was chic, posh, and down to Earth in that oh-so-San Francisco way. 

A must for anyone who wants the best in San Francisco dining.
author: Thom S.

description:
Ahhh Zuni Roast Chicken. How I have missed you. Crisp and delicious, soaking your lovely juices into a pile of carbs, I cannot resist your unctuous self. 

I've tried making this Roast Chicken myself (it deserves to be capitalized, that's just how good it is) and it never really tastes the same. So I'll be back time and again, blissfully tucking in.

Oh also when they have polenta on the menu it is seriously the best gruel dish ever. Order it.
author: Poonam S.

description:
Outstanding! All oysters are extremely good. Roast Chicken is incredible, even though it;s an hour and a half wait. Service is very good as well. I don't like caesar salad, but I recommend the caesar salad for sure. It has an amazing freshness to it. I can only say what I have had, which has been the caesar salad, all of the oysters and the chicken. It was all outstanding. 

Be ready to cough up cash before going, I would recommend spending around $150 for 2 people if just having a glass of wine, of you are gong for bottle or two of wine and full 3-4 courses with desert, be ready to spend $300 or more. Really, it is worth it, so don't go unless you are ready to have the full experience.
author: Jordan P.

description:
Zuni is on the Chronicle's list of Top 100 restaurants.  I went there for lunch for the first time today.

It's hard to know what to say.  The atmosphere and service are what you'd expect from such a highly regarded restaurant.  I can't give them very many stars, though, since there is hardly anything there a vegetarian can eat...but what I was able to eat, was delicious.

I enjoyed a bowl of polenta with mascarpone cheese (after asking if the pea soup was veggie-based, and finding out it was not).  My main dish was the tagliatelle with asparagus and lemon zest.  It was a little bit too al dente for me, but very tasty otherwise.  My wine was a glass of Sauvignon Blanc.

My companions and I split a Gateau Victoire, which was very good.  I had green tea with a local honey from Marin -- which was warmed up in the bottle so it couldn't possibly crystallize.

So I will definitely be back, and I'll bring my honey, but I can't award Zuni Cafe the kind of stars I reserve for Greens and Millennium.
author: Polly M.

description:
Way way way overrated.  We ordered the la fettunta to start, the pork chop, and a hamburger with blue cheese, carmelized onions, and portobellos.

The la fettunta was a piece of their too crispy house bread, doused in salt and covered in olive oil.  This was a huge disappointment and was $11.  The pork chop was moist and had some kind of tomato relish served with it.  The hamburger ended up being roughly $20 and was good, but wasn't the best I've ever had.

Our seat was facing the kitchen and I watched a million workers stand around and perform one function each.  This would make sense if each dish was executed to mind blowing levels.  However, these were the only options for entrees the night I ate here and they weren't mind blowing:

- pork chop
- chicken for two
- salmon
- hamburger
The appetizer menu was nearly as limited.

And that's it!  While the food here tasted fine, the options are so limited that it's kind of a bummer.  I don't mind a small menu based on what's available at the local market, but this place pushes it a bit.  I would probably not return again.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
I had a gift certificate for Zuni Cafe and, though I knew it wouldn't cover dinner for two, but I decided to go for it.  

The ambiance was nice and the service was great, not constantly bothering you but attentive and courteous.  No one was on the piano when we came in but when leaving we noticed there was pleasant music coming from the front.  Unfortunately, it seems you can't hear the piano from much of the restaurant. If interested you might want to ask in advance to get one of the few tables closer to the bar where you might be able to hear.

We split one of the salads (the one with avocado and beets) but was a little disappointed.  Seemed small and somewhat plain, despite my love for avocado and beets.  However, I never knew that a $50 chicken could taste so good.  Definitely on the pricey side (at least for me) but I must say it was some of the best chicken I have ever had. Not to mention the bread salad it comes with is fantastic.  

All in all, I will go back.  I won't be a regular but that is simply because it is way out of my budget. Probably will pass on the salad next time but would definitely get the chicken again.
author: Brian T.

description: Overall: Ehhh, food does not justify the price. Nothing too atrocious, but felt a little embarrassed bringing out of town guests to a top "San Francisco" spot. Our small plates of porcini mushrooms and house cured anchovies seemed like a dish of leftovers from the back of the refrigerator. We were served unopened cooked clams in our Catalan noodle dish, poor form indeed. The famous chicken is well... chicken roasted and served, quite under seasoned and unevenly cooked...equivalent to a grocery store rotisserie chicken. The skin was well cooked but beyond that, nothing justifying the $48 price. I recently had a much better version from a local food truck parked outside of SFGH, crispy salty roasted skin, juicy flavorful meat that fell off the bone with a fork, would recommend that instead. Service was uneven; when discussing a glass of wine that was a bit on the sweet side for one of our guests, the server replied "Well that wine is only good when drunk while eating food", hmmm. $300 down the drain.
author: Mary P.

description:
The menu is a little limited in the appetizer area.  Drinks are pricey.

I had the roast chicken, and it was really delicious.  Not delicious, as in "That was a good piece of chicken", but more like "Wow! That's as good as a Fillet Mignon!".
author: Jay E.

description:
We were shopping downtown and randomly decided to check out Zuni on a Saturday evening... like we were seriously expecting to get a reservation?  The hostess said we can try to walk-in and grab a seat in the bar area, so we figured we'd give it a shot.  And good thing we did!  We were super lucky and snagged a table right by the piano.  No wait, great seat, perfect!

I've heard from many about their roast chicken and caesar salad, so those were a must!  We also got the anchovies and clams.

House cured anchovies - Pretty good anchovies, but not the best I've had.  

Clams in saffron mint broth - The broth was really unique and the clams were excellent!

Zuni Caesar Salad - Very fresh, not heavy on the dressing and good flavor.  I'm not a huge fan of caesar in general, but this was pretty good.

Roast Chicken for 2 -  This is definitely the star of the menu!  I almost never order chicken at a restaurant because it's bland, dry and I prefer all other meats over chicken.  And not to mention we both have to get Chicken!  But we had to order it because so many people talk about it, and I'm so glad we did!  I never knew chicken to be this good!  So juicy, so flavorful.  Absolutely fantastic!  The bread salad was a little weird... not sure if I really liked that, but overall a very good dish.  It was so good that we went to the library to get the Zuni cookbook, and have been making the roast chicken at home!  Love it!

Overall a great meal.  Even though we were sitting in the bar area, the service was great and we really had no complaints!  If you enjoy cooking, I would highly recommend getting their cookbook.  Lots of great recipes in there!  We've tried their caesar salad recipe which is much better than any other recipe we've tried at home, and also been making the strawberry balsamic sorbet - YUM!
author: Mai S.

description:
Absolutely nothing puts me in a better mood.

Decor, vibe, drink, food -- is all excellent.  While maintaining their status as a San Francisco "classic", Zuni keeps fresh by selectively adding "trendy" and buzz-worthy things that are being talked about in the foodie community.... Never stale.  It's the kind of place where you could take your parents or you could go with friends before heading out for the night.  The menu is accessible to all and they cater to all kinds of drinkers (full bar + beer + wine).  The only real downside to Zuni is that you have to choose between equally great options.

For first-timers....
-Roast Chicken is outstanding
-Gnocchi, while rich, is also a standout
-If you're ok paying for a great burger, theirs is worth trying. 

i love you zuni.  don't ever change.
author: Gracie L.

description:
OK, two things to start....our waiter, Teddy, was one of the best we have ever had. My man even put our appetizer back under the lamp, cause my wife went to the restroom the same time someone brought it out... The other is that I am not really sure I need to leave a review for a place that has so many already..., but...

That said, I would recommend not to get the chicken. It is nothing to write home about, and I have no idea why we agreed to order it. I can make a juicer one on the grill, and I think you can buy one with similar skin at the local supermarket for 1/10 of the price. 

OK, now the good stuff. Lots of great oysters....came with a kind of vinegar ponzu (w/o soy), so we asked for cocktail sauce. Got some fresh-grated horseradish and ketchup and made our own.....very nice!! 

The ricotta gnocchi were fantastic!!! They were very light and cloud-like, with a gentle zucchini and lemon zest flavored-oil dressing. That was the highlight of dinner. 

Drinks, art and atmosphere were all good and we will be back for sure. Next time a review w/o the signature chicken though...
author: Andrew A.

description:
Zuni Cafe is one of those restaurants I can keep coming back to again and again. The food, service and atmosphere is constantly spot on.  Friendly staff starts your meal off right every time and Zuni was able to accommodate our 6 person late reservation party with ease.  We all had drinks down at the bar and then were lead upstairs to the perfect table in the corner.

Our waiter was extremely informative and had the menu down (which is always nice when you have people who are not quite sure what they want to eat --- that was me this night!).  I made the decision to have the skirt steak with whipped potatoes and I can say is the steak really did melt in my mouth!!  Fresh and cooked perfectly.  Myself and my entire party loved their meals.  I was able to taste the ahi tuna as well as the roasted chicken (which is a staple for Zuni) were perfection.  The chicken is a wait be warned, but my friend was so in love with the flavor she was ok with the wait.

I would recommend this restaurant to the harshest of critics because honestly there is little to complain about!  Zuni you are a gem in SF - truly!!
author: Heidi S.

description: Caesar salad is practically orgasmic at Zuni.  I would imagine the pork loin is too.  The "person" who brought me here, and I question his humanity now, was too busy trying to plan his escape route to avoid paying our tab to actually let me enjoy my food.  I think I tasted marinaded pork with a side of sausage on a bed of fava beans.  I cannot be certain.  The "person" raced us out of there, leaving a bum credit card behind.  The waiters had every right to flag him down to get their money.  Unfortunately, he gave them, I don't know, a library card or something equally as ridiculous that didn't pass for payment.  The "person" eventually settled the bill but not without help from the valet attendant.  That killed our relationship, as it should have.  Thank you, Zuni for helping me see through a snake.  Please have me back someday.
author: Camille K.

description:
I worked here for two years as the Floor Manager.

Everything they sell is the highest quality you can find. Read any other review on here to know what you should get. My recommendation... Show up with no expectations and just enjoy the experience for what it is. 

Definitely a must if you are into seasonal, sustainable, local and organic.
author: Joel V.

description:
Terrible service!  Just terrible. I called to place a reservation for Monday night. She asked me to hold......hold....hold....hold....hold....hold....hold....
10 minutes later she comes back to the line to tell me that they are closed on Mondays.
Really? You couldn't say that 10 minutes ago when I asked for a reservation for Monday?
Girl, you are a hostess. Your "job" is to make the guests that come to Zunni feel welcome and well treated. You fell miserably. Maybe you should take a class on "how to become a great hostess for dummies" . You really can use all the help you can get.
author: alex s.

description: Excellent! From the wait staff to the food.  2nd attempt for a reso and I'm glad I waited. Oysters were perfect. I asked for fish grilled how I wanted and they were happy to accommodate. I will come back next time in SF. A++
author: Lisa A.

description:
We ordered the sea bass braised in white wine and marjoram and the grilled quail.  Both dishes  were with average quality.  The sea bass was a little overcooked, leaving the fish a bit dry and tight in texture.  Flavor was subtle; you could call it a light dish but you could also call it a non-impressive dish without any distinctive characteristic.

The quail was good, with flavorful sauteed veggie at the side.  The quail was done just right, with the meat was still tender and juicy.  Flavor of the quail was tasty, with exotic taste of combined garlic and hints of peppers.  

For desserts, we had Gâteau Victoire with whipped cream and Espresso granita.  Gâteau Victoire brought less surprise.  It was like a densed chocolate cake, very rich in cocoa though.  Espresso granita was a pleasant ending to our dinner.  Light, rich and icy carried away all the grease brought by the meal.  We liked this a lot.  

Service was above average.  Our server was very attentive and pleasant even though he (and the others, too) was extremely busy.  There wasn't long wait during our dinner, even though the restaurant was really packed and all tables were full.
author: Charcoal B.

description:
"Cafe" would be the understatement of the century. Don't be fooled by its name..Rose is a road half-blocked off JUST for this place's valet. Baller. 

Take Aways: 
- Roast chicken and bread salad is on the SF's Big Eat 2010 List, fyi. Takes an hour, and it's for two. Prepare like-wise. 
- White cloth tables, live music...wow, not. A. Cafe. 

Fancy, a bit pricey, but the pacing was nice, and you should order an entree while you wait for that chicken.
author: Abel L.

description:
The famed roast chicken was nicely cooked, pretty moist. Surprisingly not as salty for being brined, or maybe the brines I do at home are too strong. Nice balance though, and the bread salad had a crispiness and slight acidic note that complemented it. Currants and frisee rounded off the dish. I'm still debating on whether it's worth the $48 price tag though.

The gnocchi was as delicate as can be, filled with light ricotta cheese.

The ceasar salad was also nice, very balanced seasoning with fresh hearts of romaine. Croutons were exceptionally good.

Service was great and the glasses of Pinot we had were excellent, at a fair price.
author: Derrick V.

description:
This was the second stop (and thus #9 ranked burger) on the burger fest tour that Gene X., Melanie N. and I are making through the 7x7 Best Burgers list. It was also my first time at Zuni Cafe. I'd been looking forward to checking it out so was glad for the opportunity.

Zuni is located in the corner space of a building on Market St and the acute angle leads to some interesting architectural elements. I liked the long bar along the Market St window because the light filters in through the array of bottles on the backbar. I also didn't realize they had 2 levels there.

We got seated next to the fireplace and proceeded to order. The options for the burger are not extensive, but we split them again: I chose a Roth Käse cheese, Gene got a blue cheese, and Melanie opted for the grilled onions on her burger. We also got a plate of fries to share.

The food arrived fairly quickly. The only thing on the side was the pickled stuff: red onion slices and thin strips of cucumber. The pickling was pretty interesting, judging by a piece of cinnamon stick that was on Melanie's plate, and tasted very good, so I put both cukes and onions on my burger and took a bite. First thing I noticed was that my burger was overcooked. I ordered it medium rare and it came out as medium or even more than that, since there was barely any pink inside. Still, it was juicy and tasty. The other thing that disappointed me was the bun. Zuni uses a square focaccia-like bun and for me this simply does not work with a round burger. The geometry is wrong: you start eating just bread and end with the same. It also didn't exactly hold up to the burger juices and started to come apart. The pickled stuff was good though and helped cut through the richness of the meat. The fries were shoestring-style and, while tasty, too thin for my liking.

Overall, it's a pretty decent burger, but right now it's in the second place after Namu's. Looking forward to trying the other 8 and making my own ranking. I also hope to visit Zuni again and try its famous roasted chicken.
author: Andrei Z.

description:
Food is really solid, but what sold me was the departing words of the hostess: "Good night, Inbae". 

!?

She remembered my name from two hours ago when I checked in. She said so naturally as though I was a regular or she knew me outside of her work for a long time. (I'm certain she didn't look down to read it off from anything.) Maybe my name stuck because it was an uncommon one, or maybe she has photographic memory. If I were a regular, which I wasn't, since it's only been twice or thrice I visited up to that point. In any case, I've never been to a restaurant and received such personal hospitality. That added detail adds so much to the overall impression, looking back, and it will continue to serve them well as long as I am in this town.

Oh, yeah, and the roasted chicken is divine. As in, I'd be 95% certain they don't use bacon, yet the meat tastes like bacon. And it tastes exactly the same every time I go back. Consistency is the word.

Other things I recommend: very solid caesar salad, house-made anchovies, and shoestring fries.
author: Inbae L.

description:
I have compared every roast chicken I have EVER eaten to the one here at Zuni Cafe. Even those folks who call SF "San Fran"... that is, not locals, rave about this chicken.

I love it so much... 

I tried to make it here in my new home - LA. To be honest, it was still good. Of course, I lack the culinary skills of the chefs at Zuni, but their recipe isn't crazy hard. It's totally possible to make it at home! Even the bread salad.

Zuni = my gold standard in roast chicken.
author: Hannah K.

description:
We came after 2pm to miss the Sunday crowd. The waitress was very nice. However, the food was ok, the servings were quite small for the price they charge. The watercress soup had a few pieces of watercress floating in it with a poach egg. The broth was quite tasty. Yet, nothing too special. The clams with white beans and broccolini was fine. The clams was so small you can barely see and some of the broccolini was charred and burnt. The rabbit kale salad was pretty good but for the prince thought you'll get a bigger portion. The servings are really snack portions. 
Makes me feel they are running out of food!
author: Mary Y.

description: I just saw Judy rocking a red & navy stripe skinny maxi with a bright pink top - she so pretty!
author: J. R.

description: The Caesar salad is honestly the best I've had. I give the Caesar salad alone five stars! However I was really disappointed in the rest of the meal! The gnocchi was horrible and I had to send It back. Then I ordered something else... The mahi mahi ...and it also wasn't very good. It came with nothing else just some peppers and parsnips on the plate. My friends ordered the chicken and it look great, though I don't eat chicken. My friends said it was fabulous! So go for the chicken and Caesar! Everything else wasn't so great in my opinion. They do have valet parking which was nice!
author: Julie C.

description:
Burger update.

Stopped by for a quick bite on a rainy weekday close to 10PM. Zuni isn't normally on my list of quick and cheap eats, but I decided to splurge a bit.

I figured that I'd get the grass fed beef burger that's only available after 10PM during dinner service.

Customized it with Gruyere cheese and grilled onions. The beef patty was grilled to rare as requested and was served on good, focaccia bread. The pickles and pickled red onions on the side added a nice, tart briny kick to the proceedings.

Accompanied by a side order of their famous shoestring fries, it was a satisfying meal.

While the Zuni burger was good, I still think the burger at Nopa is a better deal. I also think it has the edge in terms of taste as well, at least for me. Nopa's patties are seasoned better and seem like they have a richer, more buttery taste. Nopa's burgers also include fries, although they're not as awesome as Zuni's shoestring fries.

In any event, I'd definitely rate the Zuni burger higher than what you can get at Burger Bar.
author: Bono B.

description:
This review is not going to be popular. 


About 15 years ago when I was married and I lived closer I used to come here from time to time. I always thought the food was overrated, decent but not good enough for what it costs. When you're married sometimes it's best to just go where you're told. I do remember that they had THE BEST bloody marys. 

My life has changed quite a bit, I moved out of town with a wife and moved back without one. I live in the Mission and I don't really care for fancy food. I only came back to Zuni for two reasons, bloody marys and a cheeseburger. 

I don't do a lot of daytime drinking anymore and had kind of forgotten about bloody marys but lately The Delicate Viking 
http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=Sw4e9geYXjwG8-JgsuZTSw has got me obsessed with them. 

I could have gone back to Zeitgeist if I felt like being verbally abused by the staff and choked with second hand Parliament smoke but I didn't and I remembered how awesome the bloodys were at Zuni back in the day. I can report that the Zuni bloody marys are not good any more. For some reason they pour in vinegar. Sure it's very fancy vinegar but it still makes the whole drink taste like salad dressing. At $9.50 each they weren't worth the money. They weren't very strong either, I had three in an hour and barely felt it. 

Zuni, please go back to the way you made them 15 years ago 

I've had a lively debate with another of my yelp friends http://www.yelp.com/user_details?userid=i9kZ0lDHXNyoPLH67hJ2bg over who makes the best burger in town. I say it's The Rotunda and Ace say's it's Zuni, since I hadn't had a Zuni burger I figured in all fairness I should give it a try before I judge conclusively. 

Zuni's burger is $15; if you want cheese it's another $1.75 and if you want grilled onions it's another $1.25. My burger was $18 before tax and tip and it didn't come with anything else. I ordered it Medium rare and it came very rare, in fact the middle was raw. It was a tasty burger but it was small and nowhere near good enough to justify that price even if it were cooked properly. The Burger at Rotunda is definitely better. 

If someone else is paying I'll go back for oysters and something other than a bloody mary but otherwise I would never choose to come back here.
author: Manny F.

description:
Finally! 

For years, I've been reading about Zuni in Gourmet magazine. "The chicken! The burger! The fries!" the food critics would shout from the rooftops. 

After RENT (which was so awesome), we decided to see if we could get into Zuni without a reservation. Yeah, we totally did and we didn't even have to wait! 

We ordered  the heirloom tomato and arugula salad, the shoestring fries, and the chicken! 

The salad was really refreshing - with an extremely light, flavorful olive oil. The shoestring fries were fried in peanut oil and salted juuust right. Oh, and I LOVE homemade ketchup!

Okay, so was the $50 chicken that took an hour to make worth it? 

Wow. Yes. I mean, I think everyone should order it for the experience. And then, just be really, really happy because it's, well, the most perfectly cooked chicken you will ever have. It's melt-in-your-mouth juicy, brined in salt for 24 hours but not salty, and the bread salad is where the wow factor comes in. The best stuffing ever - vinegar-y, crunchy, moist, sprinkled with pine nuts and currants. I want to figure out how to make it for Thanksgiving. 

Service was polite, but aloof and the mojito was bland, but those are really the only cons. Sure, $50 is a ton of money for chicken, but you can feed 3-4 people with it.
author: Christine N.

description:
A few days ago, I received a letter from my wife's family 
saying my mom collapsed due to a stroke and she barely regains
her awareness. 

"Oh, that's miserably weak. I don't want that in my life." I murmured and tried to forget what I just knew. My reaction could've been totally different if she was the person I could respect. 

My mom is the most conscientious secular woman you will ever meet. She never did the slightest thing immoral. But I do not have any respect for her for one reason. She did not protect me when I was a child. She did not even try to save me from the horrible domestic violence I was receiving every day and every night. She did not care when I got sexually abused and got my brain shrunk by too many hits.

Well, there are 2 places in the city you can go to free yourself from weak thoughts. Good strip club with young good looking blonds and good restaurant with nice quality servers. 

On a rainy Sunday morning, I went to Zuni Cafe for the first time. I was seated in between girls' parties and it was a situation I haven't found myself in for a long long time. They were all young gentle white girls who never yell or howl when they talk, but use subtle facial expressions to decorate the sentences they say, a totally different type of female crowd I am used to being with. I felt pretty comfortable and ordered my food. 

I had a 15 dollar hamburger and great tasting fresh orange juice. Why hamburger? Because their menu says I have to wait an hour to get near-50-dollar roast chicken and next meat choice was rabit that I care more than my dying mom's life. 

Good treat to myself and I left the restaurant delighted.  

I'll save my trip to a high end strip club for the day they let me know Mom's death. Should I go now because I may die before her...who knows?
author: yota L.

description:
I wasn't particularly impressed during my dinner at Zuni Café several years ago, but I also didn't have their 'famous brick over chicken' (made to order, it requires a 1 hour wait!). So when my hubby surprised me with dinner at Zuni Café and tickets to Wicked, I made sure to have their roasted chicken this time. We had a tight schedule (5:30pm reservations and 7:30pm show time) but thanks to their efficient staff, we were able to enjoy our meal (including dessert!) without feeling too rushed or stressed about time. Since they don't take orders for the chicken in advance, we asked the host to place our order as soon as we were seated.  

Kusshi Oysters from British Columbia - What an impressive oyster selection! They had an extensive list of oysters, including kumamotos (my favorite) from 3 different regions. Our waiter suggested that I try the kusshi oysters since they are similar to the kumamotos but slightly larger and creamier...I fell in love! The kusshis were sweet and refreshing with a luscious creaminess.

House-cured Anchovies with Celery, Parmesan, and Niçoise Olives - simple, yet sublime. A perfectly balanced dish with really high quality ingredients. The anchovies were rich and oily, but not too overpowering or fishy. The parmesan provided a sharp flavor contrast, while the crunchy celery provided texture contrast. Not liking the taste of celery, I appreciated how the paper thin slices kept the flavor subtle enough for me to enjoy it.

Bellwether Farms Ricotta Gnocchi with Leeks - Heavenly pillows! The gnocchi had such an extraordinarily light and fluffy consistency - it was almost like they dissolved in my mouth. The leeks added a delicate, sweet onion flavor. The dish was buttery and rich yet also surprisingly light - needless to say, it was gobbled up in mere seconds! 

Brick Oven Roasted Chicken for Two with Tuscan Warm Bread Salad - very tasty chicken...the skin was deliciously seasoned and the meat was extremely moist and tender. The warm bread salad added to the rustic and hearty feel of the dish, while the mustard greens, currants, and pine nuts rounded out the flavors and textures. I only wish the chicken had been served at a warmer temperature - not sure why it wasn't since it was made to order

Crème Fraîche Panna Cotta with Wild Huckleberry Sauce - a great way to end a delicious meal. I was originally worried that the crème fraîche would give the panna cotta a sour tone, but instead it actually added a creamy complexity while keeping the panna cotta remarkably light. The sweet huckleberry sauce was a perfect complement. 

I would definitely go back to Zuni Café again. This experience more than made up for my last one - this is why I believe you really have to dine at a restaurant more than once to get a true sense of a place. Although I thought the chicken was very good, I wouldn't wait an hour for it again nor do I think it's worth $48 (hubby disagrees) - I'd rather order some of the other entrees next time...or just feast on their incredible oysters!

For pics of each course, go to my personal blog (link under my profile).
author: Karin V.

description: The food is always excellent but I was there for lunch today and was embarrassed by the service.  I had taken a business associate from NY there and had bragged about the place only to end up having to apologize for the service.  I asked for sweetener for my tea and the server said "ask and you shall receive".  I never received.  I asked the guy cleaning away the plates; again no sweetener.  Finally the waiter came by and I complained.  He brought some right away.  Later I asked him for more tea; he plopped down another glass without taking away the empty or saying anything.  This place serves such great food, its' a shame to sully the experience with poor service.
author: Jaime A.

description:
Zuni is good but it shows its age.  For a restaurant with such a long run, it is remarkably inconsistent.  

For me, the mainstays:  marinated olives, shoestring potatoes, the aioli, the caesar salad.  Waiting for a table at the beautiful brass bar.  The view from the window at the first-come tables.

The rest of the food has varied for me.  Sometimes the beef is unctuous and rich and sauced well.  Sometimes the fish is under-seasoned, presently clumsily in a baking dish with odd wilted vegetables.  The chicken's reputation precedes it, but I found it over-salty and heavy.  It was probably the best chicken in town ten years ago, but the youngsters (e.g. Range) have Zuni beat with more refined offerings.  There's the burger which is kind of a guilty pleasure; but I feel the same way about it as the chicken, and I don't much like the cured-meat texture of it that's apparently deliberate (I understand it's seasoned the night before, usually a no-no with ground meat).

The desserts are always good but they're presented with obscure names.  I guess that's a way of sparking conversation.  There's always a granita or two, and I always wonder who pays $8 for the equivalent of a sno-cone.

For its ups and downs, though, I can't really imagine the city without Zuni.  Its time will come, of course; for me it's not as elemental as it used to be.  But it's a great spot, and everybody should go at least once.
author: J W.

description:
I  really like Zuni.  It would get four stars but here is why...

I went there with a friend we had reservations, for some reason we looked like we did not have reservations because the hostess chased us down as we were being seated to tell us we needed to put our name on the list.  She then sheepishly walk away realizing that we were the party of two that the table was being held for... I  looked at my friend confused and just chuckled and we nervously shuffled into our seats in fear of another Pearl Harbor like attack  for the table.  But whateve's we are at Zuni... excited.

We went on to order... our server looked at me puzzled, " you do understand that comes medium rare"  I look at him puzzled yes I do. That;s the way I like it.... "are you sure"? Yes I am pretty damn sure that is how I want my meat...  

Still shuffling through the menu to find out what else we wanted to share I felt like I was getting taught by a school teacher, WTF?  I do understand basic  "foodie" terms, and If I am having trouble I will ask.

The food itself, 2 meat dishes, couple of fancy salads, nothing to scream home to mom about but,  But BIG Kudos to the RAW BAR love it.... 

The service is not terrible but my server may have just thought that I looked like a dining idiot, or needed help...lol..  

No worries, after he realized that I am a serious cocktail with dinner kind of person, he backed off and I ended up charming him with my ridiculously sweet smile. 

It's OK we are friends now.
author: Eva M.

description:
A good meal on a perfect day.

It's not everyday that you get your marriage license and say your civil vows.  And especially on days like this, a good meal is in order.

San Francisco has loads of great food for special occasions.  We were specifically looking for one such meal VERY VERY close to City Hall.  We had a 1:30 appointment at the City Clerk and we were not interested in pushing the time envelope.

After Yelping a bunch of spots, we narrowed it down to three (including Absinthe and Jardiniere), and in the end chose Zuni.

It was second time there, and it was consistently good.  I cannot say, like last time (and I did have the chicken), that our dishes (Caesar, veggie pasta, and wood oven pizza) were particularly amazing.  However, the overall dining experience in a sunlit open space, a fresh and tasty meal, friendly waitstaff, sharing with people you love were just what we were looking for... and we made it to our appointment on time.
author: Mars O.

description:
I risked it and went for the $15 burger knowing it would have to be damn good for me to find it worth it. It was pretty flavorless, which I guess is a tad unfair, since I didn't put any of the "fix 'uns" on it. The pickled vegetables looked good, but the live WORM crawling around in them did not. I pointed this out to my waitress, who proceeded to explain to me how awesomely organic all their produce. It's cool that everything is so locally grown, organic and well-loved, but for $15, I expect my burger to come without anything writhing on it. Is that asking too much? 

To be fair, the manager offered to bring it back to the kitchen, but I didn't want to waste food, so I just told him they need to do a better job on food prep, which he laughed at (for reasons I'm not sure of). I'll give this place 2 stars because he comped my fries (although not the worm-nest of a burger).
author: Aaron G.

description:
My friend told me this place would be wonderfully terrific, I should've known otherwise when we walked inside. The decor still looked amazingly appetizing and the aromas being emitted from the kitchen was making me salivate.

After a lot of deliberation I settled on a plate of shrimp that sounded wonderful, while the rest of the party went for the steak. When the food arrived, we were immensely surprised by the extremely small portions. My two tiger prawns cost about $20. My friend's steaks were in the $30 range and about 3 oz of meat. The taste did not offset the cost whatsoever. The taste of it was endearing, I would continue eating it had it been mine, but it's not $30 good. We're looking at maybe $20 good. Normally I can pay a larger amount for food if I was satisfied by the quality of the food. However Zuni's, I wasn't happy. To top it off, the build up led to disappointment, which also resounds when you anticipate good food. Good try but I prefer to never come back. Maybe for drinks at the most.

I normally don't plan to be starving after a hundred something dollars worth of dinner, but I went home and had to make myself something else to eat...
author: Winè C.

description: I haven't been here in over a decade so spending a day with my sister and enjoying a good meal together=happiness.  After 10 years, the roasted chicken with warm bread salad (which you have to order 40 minutes in advance) is still all that. We ordered the spinach and green garlic soup and I have no idea what they put in it but OMFG!
author: Leslie L.

description: We had a wonderful meal at this SF institution starting with the champagne and elderflower cocktails. Then we split the following among multiple people: caesar salad, mixed chickories salad, gnocchi, and the famous roast chicken with bread salad. Everything was as good as you'd expect for a restaurant with this kind of reputation. Service was great as well.
author: Angela P.

description: Good service, but don't dine here if you're hungry and you're after a hearty brunch. Our entrees were smaller than appetizer size, which was hugely disappointing, as we'd heard Zuni served a great brunch menu. The oysters are great, but next time I'll only stop here for a drink. Their portion sizes are just far too small for the prices they charge. Do yourself a favour and take a stroll up to Brenda's on Polk St instead!
author: Rose B.

description:
Normally, I would typically never advise on ordering chicken. I mean, it's chicken! You can order it at virtually any restaurant and make it at home any night of the week for cheap. I am changing the rules here because the chicken at Zuni is like none other I've had at a restaurant. 

It takes an hour to bake (and notes it on the menu) so as soon as you say that you're interested in having it, the waiter will leave you mid sentence to go put the order in. They bake a whole chicken, chop it up and put it in greens over this scrumptious stuffing. It was DAMN good and definitely worth the wait. 

We also ordered the gnocchi as an appetizer which my friend complained tasted too egg-like. I liked it that way as I prefer food to be less dense but I could see her point - it wasn't exactly traditional. 

I love the facilities here. There's lots of windows overlooking the action on Market Street and and has a beautiful spacious bar when you first walk in that you can chill at while you wait. 

Overall, a great experience. I would definitely recommend to tourists and SF foodies a like.
author: Julia N.

description:
Even if Zuni Cafe served up amazing food 364 out of 365 nights, I wouldn't give this place 5 stars. When you're a San Francisco institution, consistency is the name of the game, and Zuni Cafe: FAIL.

If your cell service was perfect 99% of the time, but that one time you got lost in a strange city and you didn't have WiFi or cell signals to access gMaps and your lifeline calls to friends kept getting dropped, you would still hate AT&T.

The Caesar salad was pretty decent but way too big, and the famous chicken for 2 is a lot more famous than it deserves to be. It's good, but not that good (that's what she said).
author: Gloria L.

description: Zuni is consistently good. You know if you there you will get the same tasty dish time and time again. The steak are always cooked perfectly. The chicken is actually okay but still consistent. The oysters are the best in the city and the wine list is always excellent with much to choose from from. Classic
author: Annie A.

description: The service was outstanding at Zuni Cafe.  Perhaps it was because it was a rainy Wednesday evening, but we were seated fairly promptly, our drinks thoughtfully carried from the bar to our table by the hostess (always will get major prompts from me for this service).  Our Waiter was fantastic, promptly putting in our Roast Chicken order and bring another round of drinks.  My friend ordered the Caesar Salad and I got the Chicory Greens, both were good.  We noshed on ACME bread and shoestring fries until the Roasted Chicken came out (it did take 71 minutes - close to their promised 75min).  The chicken was fantastic, seasoned nicely, and very juicy.  I wasn't a big fan of the warm bread salad but did enjoy the dressed mustard greens.  Gateau Victoire (flourless chocolate cake) was a lovely end to the meal ... not overly sweet and having a lovely crumb texture.  I eat out quite a bit and found my dining experience at Zuni Cafe to be excellent.  Thank You Zuni Cafe!  Keep up the good work!
author: Mark F.

description: I'm only writing this review now (four years after the fact) because I started compiling a Best Chicken list on Yelp, and apparently you need to have reviewed the place to start the list.  Honestly speaking, I remember very little about the experience, except for the roast chicken.  Sometimes in life, you have those rare moments you remember forever-- your first kiss, feeling the upper deck at Yankee Stadium shake during the playoffs, being best man at your friend's wedding... and Zuni Cafe roast chicken?!  Yes.  Zuni Cafe Roast Chicken... I think about you often.
author: Jeff J.

description:
Seriously. GO TO THIS PLACE.
Amazing from beginning to end, my girlfriend and I were so happy when we left that we felt sedated.
Great coffee, which is not important to some, but I don't care to know those kinds of people...
Great service.
Great ambiance; not pretentious but classy, LOVE the copper bar and the huge woodfire oven in the middle of the floor.
We got the scrambled eggs with house-made fennel sausage (to die for), the soup of the day (nom nom), and then finished up with the french toast with huckleberries. 
Seriously. GO TO THIS PLACE.
author: Jeni E.

description:
Solid and delicious food at reasonable price. We had oysters, green salad, strip steak, and lamb stew on our last visit. Everything was nicely seasoned, fresh, and yummy. And the dessert piccola meringata is really something special.

Would love to try the burger and roast chicken next time.
author: CS L.

description: I have loved the Zuni Cafe for years and was so excited to start off 50th birthday weekend there with friends from out of town. However, we were seated upstairs in a quiet room with just a couple of other tables and there was something off-putting and unenthusiastic about our waiter, who seemed put out and failed to make eye contact or to demonstrate any warmth about our celebration. In fact, each time we asked a question or made a request he seemed to smirk and scoff with a less than positive attitude. Needless to say, we didn't appreciate his haughty attitude, but the final straw was when I asked that he reverse the charges to my friend's credit card as I wanted to treat since they had flown in for my birthday. Instead of graciously saying he would take care of this for me, he could barely contain his annoyance and proceeded to berate me and tell me more than once that it was "against policy" but he would "do it just this once" (as if I were going to come back and do it again). To top it off, I had made the reservation and given my credit card preemptively so it was his mistake for failing to follow my request as the host of the party. I still have him a healthy tip, but all of us agreed that had we not had a fantastic show to see and a terrific weekend in Wine Country planned this would have been a terrible way to remember a 50th birthday. The following night we dined at Thomas Keller's pop up restaurant Ad Lib, and from the moment we were seated the service was warm, inviting and so gracious. Not only did they have. Menu ready with a birthday salutation, the GM attended to us and Chef Keller came and sat at our table to sign menus. To top it off they stuck an exploding roman type of candle in our cake and toasted us with champagne. This, we all remarked, far exceeded our expectations and highlighted for us the stark contrast in service and attention. Too bad, because the food continues to be  wonderful at Zuni. I did speak to a manager who said she would talk to the waiter, and I hope she does as it really did seem to be a training issue.
author: Gadget G.

description:
Went here with my foodie sister and her boyfriend on their visit to SF -- truly a treat! The fare is expensive, but for a special occasion it was worth it. Everything tasted unique, simple (as in not overwhelmed by complicated flavors or decadence) and delicious. My favorite was probably the gnocchi -- they tasted like mini-omelettes floating in cream. My sister and her bf tried the oysters and said they were pretty yummy. Between the three of us we tried the following:

Piccolo fritto (glorified onion rings with a hint of honey and orange zest - yum)
La fettunta (I would never normally spend $11 on a piece of toast doused with olive oil, but that peppery tone left quite an impression)
Mixed chicory salad (not much to it, but the dressing was delish)
Gnocchi with ricotta and chard (or was it spinach?)
Marinated olives
Rum ice cream (not too sweet, a nice light end to the meal)

The only thing really "off" was the waiter brought us the wrong wine. It was still good wine...and less expensive than what we ordered. All in all, a fine place to splurge!
author: Jelly F.

description: Great food, especially the chicken. Just beware its going to be a long meal!
author: Hilda V.

description:
I went to Zuni for lunch and I was excited to try their chicken and bread salad.  We were extremely hungry and learned it would take an hour or so for it to be ready so we decided to order their hamburger and shoe string fries to share while we waited.  I thought everything we ordered was very good.  I really enjoyed their hamburger which was prepared very different from an ordinary burger.  It was served on a rosemary focaccia garnished with fresh lettuce, pickles, aioli and cheese.  I'm not a huge burger type of girl but I sure enjoyed theirs!  I probably will have Zuni burger cravings one of these days.  The shoe strings were crispy and yummy.  I'm all about the crispy fries so I liked 'em a lot. 

By the time the chicken came, I was getting full but the chicken was so juicy and flavorful I had to eat it!  The great thing about the chicken was that it was moist but wasn't greasy!  You could really tell they use fresh, high quality ingredients in all of their dishes.

In addition to the food, I really liked the open kitchen.  I will definitely be visiting again soon.
author: Jessica T.

description: I've had a few consistently good meals here. Personally, it doesn't "wow" me, it's just good, fresh food. I have had the famous chicken, which was very moist and tender, but very simple- nothing I don't think you couldn't make at home for cheaper, but worth a try. The shoestring potatoes are awesome though! And the balsamic bloody Mary...I'd walk miles across town just to sip one of those.
author: T. Y.

description:
One of the poorest dining experiences I have had in a very long time.   Waited for 22 min btw being served beverages and had our order taken.
Burger was tasteless and served on a bread plate with no side whatsoever not even a piece of lettuce.
I was extemely dissapointed with Zuni's  -- it was my second time and though I for sure consider myself a "foodie" I am sure I am completely missing something here - its neither delicious nor warm of a welcoming/service interaction.   snobby. somewhat entitled. forgetful......
author: SF C.

description:
Lunch last Saturday. 
Nice ambience
The chicken really is excellent. The rest of the selections were good.
Much like I remember from a few years ago.
Service excellent, except for bartendress with a bad attitude.
I'll go back again someday...
author: Frank D.

description: Chicken, pork chops and most their salads are tasty.  Kinda pricey but worth it.
author: Suz L.

description:
We had a group of friends coming in from NY & wanted to take them to a place with good food & great SF vibe.  We had an amazing waiter & our friends loved Zuni Cafe.  Word to the warning...reservations go fast so book early.  They also can accommodate larger groups (ours was 7), but it's much more difficult because the restaurant is somewhat limited in space.

We had the waiter pick his favorites for appetizers & he brought the fries, citrus salad, & gnocchi.  All were great.  For entrees, the group had steak, halibut, & duck with sausage.  We enjoyed them all, although portions were a little small.    This spot is definitely worth a visit.

The only downside is there is absolutely no parking in this part of town.  We had to wait a bit to catch a cab out as well.
author: Kim D.

description:
I went for brunch after hearing it was a nice place to try. 

I wasn't too thrilled about the location. The food wasn't bad but a little overpriced for the portions served. I ordered a mimosa, salad, an entree and the clams and oysters. I was expecting something more spectacular but it turned out to be overpriced gourmet American food. 

Good ambiance and service. Definitely worth trying at least once but I'll probably only return for a special occasion.
author: Tina J.

description:
we came here strictly for the burger because i was looking for good places in san francisco for burgers. for a fancy $15 grass fed burger, it was good, but it wasnt great. i think i prefer my burgers the good old fashion way with burger buns instead of fancy foccacia bread. the meat was soft and juicy and had great texture but wasnt super tasty. we both ordered the burger and asked for medium and mine came medium rare while the other came medium well.

the crispcut fries were good but it takes a while to eat it since theyre cut so thin and small.

the decor and layout of the place was really cool though and i would go back to try something else but definitely not the burger again.
author: Alex H.

description:
I've been on a bit of a burger binge lately (and from scanning the reviews, I'm apparently not the only one) and it just so happens that I now work a block away from Zuni Cafe. This geographic blessing has lead me on two trips to Zuni in two days. Both times I went with the burger, and I think this gave me a pretty good sense of the sort of variation you can get from the kitchen in terms of quality.

The first day, I went with the blue cheese. The second, with the gruyere. Although I love to pair blue cheese with beef, you walk a fine line with blue because too much can easily overwhelm the flavor of the entier thing. But there was no danger of that at Zuni. To be honest, I couldn't really taste the flavor of the blue. It most definitely could've benefited from a larger piece, or just maybe something stronger. The burger with the gruyere was definitely better, but part of that might've had to do more with other factors.

In both instances, I ordered my burger medium rare. This is what I mean by variation in the kitchen. The first burger came out noticeably bloodier, and the second was almost cooked medium. Normally I'm not a fan of beef that's cooked past medium rare, but I found that at Zuni, I preferred the slightly more medium burger. It t gave the fat a chance to melt, making the burger unbelievably juicy. I should note that the first time I went, I was with a group of 7 so the wait times may have affected the taste.

Overall the burger was pretty damn good, good enough to have for lunch regularly, but there's no way I would go so far as to say it's the best or in my top 3 of burgers in served in the city.

On a side note: the persimmon salad was incredible. It's probably seasonal but definitely check it out if when it's on the menu. The shoestring fries weren't much of anything. I found them a little too thinly sliced to be much of anything to me.

PS. The service here is phenomenal. First-class all the way. I was impressed both times I went.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
I've read all the good and the bad about this place and now I guess it's my turn. 

The first thing I have to say is that from the beginning it is apparent that this place is just trying to do something right, not different. So, if you are looking for something to blow you away with it's fresh newness, this is definitely not the place. However, I would recommend everyone come here once. Maybe twice. 

This is definitely the place to come if you want to know what's on the menu. You could bring your Grandma here and she would recognize most of the ingredients. The restaurant itself is a clean, beautiful space that starts out narrow and gets more comfortable in the back where it opens up a little. There is a some back up in the bar area, but the cocktails are worth the pushing and shoving. The only real problem is that if they seat you upstairs it's pretty warm. There are some fans, but even on the evening we were there which was a typical cold, foggy night, it was stuffy and my shirt was sticking to my back by the end of the meal. 

As far as the food goes, if you don't order the chicken you might as well not go. It's pretty much one of the best things I've ever had. How they can make something so basic taste so superb is a wonder. It has just enough of  a hint of citrus and fresh herbs and the bread salad with currants and pine nuts is perfect for soaking up all of that divine chicken flavor. But some dishes are a waste. Two people ordered dishes that were boring and bland, don't worry they are no longer on the ever-changing menu. 

The brightest spot at this restaurant is the service. Our server was perfect. He was completely knowledgeable and patient while being completely charming. This would probably be the sole reason I would come back, that and the chicken. 

What else can I say? It was good and expensive. Not great. But I invite everyone to find out on their own.
author: Andrew D.

description:
Man, I hate to break the 5-star thread, but I've got to stay legit. Zuni has so many good qualities and has the potential to be amazing, but "inconsistent" is the key word here. 

First of all, I'm not one of those people that believes in under-salting something with the attitude that "if it's not salty enough, the customer can salt it to their liking." I understand the concept, but I am really not down with the practice. The last time I was here we got 3 different appetizers, one of which was really tasty (the corn soup), and 2 that were just mediocre (the fried cauliflower/onion dish, and the prosciutto crostini). They were quite simply too bland, and a little bit of salt would've gone a very long way. The flourless chocolate cake was good, but not memorable. I mean, really, it's hard to make flourless chocolate cake taste bad.

I know they are fairly known for the roast chicken with bread salad, and I'm not going to say it was bad. It was good. Was it $24/person and a 1 hour wait good? No. There wasn't anything about it to make me say "Wow, chicken has been taken to a new level!" 

On the plus side, it is a great place to people watch and have a cocktail. If you're looking for atmosphere and location over the quality of the food, then this is definitely a great spot. But again, in terms of food, I think the menu is really hit-and-miss.
author: Kelsey E.

description: Sad indeed when a institution falls off its standard when the founding flame dies...hence was our experience recently there at one of my all time go-to foodie establishments.   Bar service was friendlier than before with big rim-filled Martinis but regular mix drunks very weak.  Oysters were some if the best in the city now pale to places like Saltwater.  Skinny fries still greaseless but pieces so small it's like eating broken bag of chips.  Fritto was nothing but pile of nondescript things.  The sides lack any distinguishable yearnings and most left uneaten.  The star attraction the Roast Chicken was still good but tasted of wet brine too much.  I remember when it was moist but I could not tell whether it was brined of not.  The bread salad and greens were sloppily placed on too small a plate and most spilled onto the table.  The plates for all courses were the size of saucers...making enjoying this food difficult.  Great wine list as it is small but very well selected and prices excellent.  The bathrooms were a complete mess as they are unisex and this utilitarian approach does not befit a fine dining place as urine and paper towels strewn about the place.  A dirty bathroom is my #1 turnoff for a restaurant.  Sad indeed when a place is living off its legacy!
author: Gregory C.

description:
#8 out of Top #100 Restaurant.

Is the whole chicken worth $48?  If you don't think so, order the chicken entree which comes with a whole breast sliced accompanied with some some greens with bacon and avocado.   The people next to me were eating it and it looked quite good.  I was wondering why I waited 1 hour for a whole chicken when I could have eaten chicken that came with bacon in 20 minutes.
author: Wakako U.

description:
Hum, so I wanted to really like Zuni, but they kinda fell short. I think I may have ordered the wrong thing, cause the "chicken dinners for 2" around me looked pretty delish. The shrimp were not very meaty and there were only 2 on the plate! Left much to be desired. The feta gnocchi were among the best gnocchi I've had (and I think I'm a gnocchi snob). The bruschetta was pretty decent and the olive oil sauce made for a good dipping sauce for the bread. 

Now onto the wine... it was HORRIBLE! Definitely it had turned, so we sent it back and were brought another bottle of the same wine, which was still not completely great. 

Closing thoughts: over priced and under proportioned.
author: Kelly N.

description:
My boyfriend brought me to Zuni for our very first Valentine's Day.  I'm going to be honest and say that I'd never even heard of it.  But apparently it's so good that Elizabeth Falkner would choose Zuni to celebrate her Valentine's Day as well!  This was my first brush with a celebrity chef and just the beginning of my quest for excellent food.

We started with the creamy polenta with mascarpone and shoestring potatoes.  Wow, that was incredibly rich polenta!  It was nice to have that richness since we ordered the chicken for two, which takes an hour to roast in the brick oven.  It was well worth the wait, for this was the exact moment that I fell in love with bread salad.  We loved it so much that my boyfriend has made roasted chicken a la Zuni several times for a special treat!  (He found the recipe online http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/9123872)

I would most certainly return to Zuni.
author: Teena O.

description:
Zuni apparently is a bit of a SF landmark restaurant.  The atmosphere of the restaurant is warm and inviting and service is friendly.  Their menu is pretty small, so it may be worthwhile to check it out before making a reservation.  When I dined there recently, none of the entrees really appealed to me.  I settled on a white chicory salad and the beef entree.  Their famous roasted chicken seemed like the best item on the menu, but the parenthetical statement "(approx. 1 hour)" was a big turn-off.  I asked the waiter if that meant that we'd have to wait an hour for the entree.  He replied, smartly, "Only if you want it cooked!".  Ha, ha...Ok, wiseguy.  It may be worth the wait, but I felt an hour was excessive.  
Nevertheless, the salad was very basic but well-dressed.  The beef entree came with excellent mashed potatoes and a few pieces of baby carrots and a grilled scallion. The beef itself was so tender that you could cut it with a fork.  Note that it only comes cooked one way - rare-med. rare and very pink.  Although the jus was a bit too salty for my taste, the dish was very good overall.  Others ordered the pasta alla chitarra - supposedly pasta like guitar strings.  However, this looked like nothing more than regular spaghetti.
Our table also ordered a cheese plate, olives, and shoestring fries.  All were fine.
Zuni serves solid food in a lovely atmosphere, but I'm not sure why there's so much hype about the place.
author: Amelia S.

description: Amazes me each and every time! Can't wait to go to SF just to eat at Zuni. The staff, the ambiance, and atmosphere is perfect.
author: O P.

description:
This restaurant is a refreshing contrast against the current trend of complex plates. If you are looking for a ahi tuna tartare tower showered in caviar with drippings of the finest olive oil, you won't find it here. Instead, standing as an iconoclast, this restaurant celebrates simplicity--the execution is simple yet the effect is a focused and elegant meal. 

Having dined here twice, I have had the caesar salad, the zuni roast chicken, oysters and mimosas. The simple yet elegant caesar salad embodies the spirit of this restaurant. The salad was carried by the potent but smooth made-from-scratch dressing. The oysters were extremely fresh. The mimosas was made from freshly squeezed OJ. As a testament to the quality of the service, when my friend accidentally spilled his mimosa, the staff came back and gave us another mimosa. This stands in contrast to more avant garde places where such an act would warrant dirty stares and the judgmental wait staff. 

The only disappointment was zuni chicken (for two). As a very pricey plate, I was expecting something magical. The chicken was done very well and the chicken breast was juicier than some chicken thighs I've had at other places. However, the skin could have been crispier and I felt that the chicken overall was over-salted. And for the price, it's really hard to argue that was $30 better than a costco rotisserie chicken. The interesting thing is that this very cost analysis I am doing here could be the reason why restaurants like this do not always flourish (esp. at these prices). While making the best chicken possible is a hard ordeal, our ability to create food has evolved in such a way that a place like Costco can deliver 70% of the enjoyment at less than a quarter of the price. It's this tension that may actually cause restaurants to move towards complexity--the more 'avant garde' my menu looks, the harder it is to compare this against a less complex commodified plate that can be had at cheaper fares.
author: Andrew H.

description: After $50 and an hour wait for the chicken with bread salad I was disappointed. I was expecting something extraordinary.  I went on a blind date here and ordering this chicken is not a good idea for a first meeting.  The lunch took freakin 2 hours.  Fat people like me are dumb.  The bread salad was oily and the chicken was just ok.  In fact it was so good I forgot I actually came here to eat.  I had to scroll through my bookmarks to remember.  I may come back to try the burger.
author: Fatty A.

description: When they say it tastes like chicken. ... nothing in the world tastes like this chicken!  Every dish is phenomenal...
author: Vern G.

description:
I love this place!  So.................so.............so...........glad I went there with my favorite people. We all fell in love and now Zuni Cafe is our favorite place! 

The oysters, the steak, the salad, the duck the every was amazing! 
There was nothing that made it a bad experience at all. Well maybe if the bread was like hot, but yeah who cares the other food was beyond compare.
author: Juju H.

description:
It's places like this that make people say that SF is the sister city to Paris.  Stuffy, pretentious - and fabulous!

It's a perennial, I have been enjoying Champagne and oysters here since the golden age of venture capital and I love that it has never felt the need to re-invent itself.
author: Teresa L.

description:
very nice stuff.  Zuni is a classic and has retained its status as one of the most impressive dining establishments in San Francisco for as long as i can remember (which is an embarrassingly long period of time) - to do this, a place really needs to stand out among the noise of all the newest/hottest restaurants in town.  

i haven't been here since i was commuting from SF while living in LA.  at that time. i was working in the FiDi and staying just a few blocks aways 2-4 nights per week so i didn't often get out of the immediate neighborhood. this was one of my crew's favorite places so we frequented the joint often.  dinner at Zuni was just where we used to meet after work. but since moving here, i don't live right there anymore and have been exploring other parts of the city.  years later, i made it back here upon the request of the cutest girl i've ever seen that wears a lip piercing.  
 
one complaint on the appetizer menu... it was a bit of a trick to pick an appetizer.  the dinner menu wasn't infested with tantalizing appetizer options and we ended up with a basic caesar salad which was good, i suppose.  my pork shoulder was excellent, the design of the place is very dot-comy even though i guess it's been around a lot longer than that.  the pierced-lip had the salmon and there didn't seem to be any complaints from that side of the table. Zuni is actually even more attractive now than it was before since a couple wine bars and various secondary spots to go before/after dinner have now popped up in the immediate area, particularly noteworthy being Hotel Biron, the hardest working wine bar in SF, which is little just 1-2 doors down.  
 
downsides were not numerous nor serious but minor issues were: didn't get seated till 10:20p (from a 10p reservation), slightly slow service.  combine both those issues and we decided to skip dessert and get it at tart-n-tart in the sunset instead... lastly: lack of appetizer selection noted above.  the wine suggestion from the server was quite good as well so that's one more on the positive side. 
 
all in all, the downsides were tiny in the face of what is basically a landmark restaurant in the city.  it's a must-go type of place for anyone doing any serious eating in the city.  although i didn't have them this time around, the roast chicken and the shellfish are the signatures here that stand the test of time from when this place was opened in 1979. despite my nit-picking, i think it's as good as it was when i was eating here like it was my own kitchen.  more like a 4.5 star review.
author: dan h.

description:
We had the roasted chicken for two, preceded by the Caesar Salad. We needed a bit of an appetizer, given the hour-long wait for the chicken (yes, you're told about this in advance). 

Gracious me, that was tasty. And unlike the meals you usually get in restaurants in this price range, there was alot of food. ALOT. Lots of good food. Oh, that's the way to my heart. The bread salad, which is moister than plain ol' bread, yet not quite to the level of Thanksgiving-style stuffing, complimented the chicken very well. The mustard greens gave the whole dish a nice dash of color. Maybe a bit of flavor too....but I can't be sure; I was too busy munching on the chicken to pay alot of attention to it.

We had the table that's almost directly over the kitchen, and we had a birds-eye view of the guy who handles the oven and, hence the roast chicken dishes (HA! get it? birds eye...chicken? hee hee hee...oh shut up, it was funny). Anyways...the dude was busy. At least half the dishes he was making were the roast chicken. It appears that the word has gotten out.

Service is acceptable. The waiter dude did his job. Not particularly fantastic. Although I will say that he was knowledgeable about the cocktails, which I appreciate.

I'll be returning here, as I'd like to explore some of the other items that frequent the menu.
author: Tim B.

description: My husband and just had dinner here again on Thursday night--and once again we loved every moment and every bite.  The skate appetizer was beyond tasty and creative.  The chicken and bread salad dinner was too good to be true!  We've had it before and every time were just as blown away as the first.  Can't wait to have it again.  Unfortunately, we didn't have room for dessert---hopefully next time and yes, we will be back!
author: Lupe R.

description:
4.5 stars. You'll understand after the cocktail story.

Decor:
Lovely. The restaurant is deeper than it looks, and there's a second level which, while a bit squashed if you're next to the wall, affords a nice view of the rest of the restaurant and outside the windows (the walls are mostly window). Feels refined yet cozy.

Food:
Selection of oysters - very fresh
Chicken - simply seasoned and cooked, but so delicious. The bread underneath soaks up the juices and they were a bit vinegary/winey too, which made them oh so good with the chicken. Raisins, pine nuts, and arugula balanced out this dish.
There was more, I can't remember what, though. Rest assured, the food was all good.

Drinks: 
We liked them.
I ordered a hibiscus punch, only to realize I got a cocktail when the bill came (I had an inkling, but hibiscus is strong and my company didn't think it was alcoholic either). This explains the tiredness. And the ensuing giggles. The staff left a new cocktail off the menu, and mistakenly thought that's what I'd ordered. Our waiter mentioned it's a good thing they didn't serve it to a child. 

Service:
Our waiter was excellent the entire evening, and apologized profusely for the cocktail mix up (pun not intended). He comped the drink and also the desserts. The check kept going back and forth, and in the end we got charged for the desserts anyway, but we didn't want to wait for it to be fixed.

Desserts:
I had the pavolva. Thin meringue cookies with raspberries. So good. I don't remember what my friends got but their desserts were delicious too.

I will definitely come here again. From their menu it looks like they're family friendly, but you could also come a little dressier and not feel out of place. Yep, definitely coming back here.
author: Amy N.

description: Nice atmosphere, nice waiters and very good chicken. The chicken takes an hour but it's worth waiting. We had some oysters while waiting. We all really enjoyed our dinner. The only downside was the overpriced corkage fee of 20 per bottle.
author: Chris S.

description: After years of 5 stars from me, we had our first so-so experience at Zuni. Is it slipping now?  I hope not. But the buzz was gone. The service was halting and off. Let's hope that it was just an off-night, but maybe the time has come to move on??
author: Carl A.

description: Zuni is always popular and always has a great ambiance - lots of windows, good but not amazing food, and friendly service.  The roasted chicken and bread salad - also on the 7x7 Big Eat list - is, by far, the most popular dish.  It's good, but the hour wait for the dish almost forces you to try random things of the menu.  Zuni isn't exciting for appetizers so we rely on the shoestring potatoes which are pretty good and a drink or two.  I wish Zuni was cheaper and more casual because it exists in such a great spot.
author: Chad S.
