description: Little underwhelmed. Shoestring fries are great. Caesar salad and burger good. Chicken is roasted perfectly but the bread was soaked in cheap olive oil and felt heavy and greasy.
author: Tessa B.

description: This place is amazing, check your coat at the door and please enjoy the ride. Do not bring children under the age of 12. This is not burger king, it is not about having it YOUR way. Don't get me wrong, you can have it your way, just be prepared to pay for it. They way they do things at Zuni is that- their way. Which if you can appreciate it, is well thought out and very beautiful. Also if you want something super private make sure you have reservations for upstairs. This is a loud fish bowl of a bar and main floor dining room.  The chicken is legendary and yes it is off the hook.  If its not- you should tell them.  Make sure to try the gateau victoire, its one of the best chocolate cake I've ever had which says something. ( I order chocolate cake off every desert menu). Zuni has classic simple tastes prepared with thought and care.
author: Misanthrope O.

description:
I had to review someplace special for my 100th review, so here goes:

Zuni, I have a huge crush on you. The frisee salad was probably the best salad that I've ever had (So fresh! The dressing so perfectly balanced!), and the penne pasta was light and seasoned to perfection. Pure poetry on a plate. I didn't want to be too forward during our first meeting, but I was feeling so giddy from the delicious meal and it being Friday night and all that I had to go for the dessert, too. And it was fantastic. The presentation (and of course, the taste) of the piccola meringata was heavenly - so well thought out and a delightful way to end an incredible meal. 

You've cast a spell on me, Zuni. I shall shout praises for you from the highest hills of San Francisco (at least the ones I'm not too scared to drive up) and across the ocean. I hope that we shall soon meet again because I'm dying to try your roasted chicken and your burger. But, not during the same meal because that would just be greedy. And I'm not that kind of girl, as I'm sure you can appreciate. Until next time, keep on being fabulous you!
author: Rachel G.

description:
Now Zuni.....Zuni is one restaurant that lives up to its hype.  Ive been wanting to dine here for years.  Ive driven passed countless times and always thought "oooh i need to try the food one day"......and finally, i did.  

The menu was not as extensive as i was anticipating, but the food did not disappoint.  Appetizers were a tad lackluster so we split a caesar salad.  Caesar is caesar so i wasnt falling out of my seat for it but our white wine, which was a recommendation from our server, was perfect and paired nicely with my salmon entree.  Wonderfully moist piece of fish.  I want to tell you more about it and what else adorned my plate....but sadly, i suffer from alcoholnesia.  This is what happens when i drink multiple glasses of wine right before dinner and during.....i love what im eating but i dont really know what im eating.  All i know is it was so good i kept placing forkfuls in my mouth even when my stomach was screaming "the buttons on your dress are about to burst!"

We decided to skip dessert and honestly i wouldnt have remembered eating it anyway.  Sad stuff.  Despite my alcoholnesia, i very much enjoyed Zuni.   Nice attractive space, very open with high ceilings and a long bar downstairs.  Food was really tasty (i promise you i remember that much) and i believe service was good too.  Im making it a point to return soon, i really want to try their roast chicken.  But second time around, i'll be saving my wine consumption for AFTER my meal.
author: Juv C.

description: One of my favorite eateries in the bay area.  Every time i come to Zuni Cafe i feel like i am in good hands :-).  The ceasar salad is the best i've had, but everything i ever tried was perfectly cooked and seasoned.  The ingredient is always top notch.  The food at Zuni Cafe doesn't have a fancy presentation but always nice and wholesome to the eyes, showing that the kitchen really cares about what they offer.  The wonderful part is the ability to use accompaniments to bring out the best of the featured ingredient without overpowering.   Another reason that i enjoy eating at Zuni Cafe is the attention to products that are grown locally in a healthy, organic, and sustainable manner.
author: Lien P.

description:
zuni cafe has slipped my mind, and i've failed to review it.  yet this doesn't mean that the meal was unmemorable, actually far from it...

we shared an array of oysters from both the east and west coats, which names are beyond me.  all were fresh and tasty, albeit pricey, but worth it.
we also shared the infamous roasted chicken.  the chicken itself was so juicy and flavorful, and the bread salad was to die for.  i normally do not order chicken entrees when i'm dining out, but this is a cut above the rest and a stellar exception.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Q:  What do you request at Zuni when you want to get a burger so rare it's blue?

A:  Order a burger cooked medium

Three long-time SF residents walk into Zuni for lunch today trying to remind ourselves why we really never go to this landmark (except for an occasional cocktail). On a brilliantly warm sunny day, we decided to try Zuni again - and while we were at it, order their critically acclaimed burger.

We were all sorry we decided to spend our lunch there. Two of the three of us requested our burgers cooked medium. I even mentioned that I wanted it cooked on the medium-well-ish side of medium. Our two burgers were rare all the way to the edge of the patty. Where I come from, that's blue.

But that's okay... I peeled off the 1/8" of cooked meat from the top of the patty and removed the raw remains. I guess it became a skinny burger. Yeah right.

My other friend ordered her burger rare, which was blue of course, and that wouldn't have been so bad for her if only the meat were seasoned.

Really... for $15 couldn't they put at least a little salt and pepper on the meat before they cook it?

Don't mention the side salads. Really, don't. You practically won't see them anyway... they're so small. But you'll pay for them. They're about $8 each.

I'm no cheapskate, mind you. I'm all about forking over cash for good food. But when I feel like all I'm getting for my hard-earned dime is a long-standing reputation that's not followed through with a quality product, I'll be sure to carve out time within four hours of my experience to yelp about it. That's what just happened here.

My advice:  Take your $120 and your two friends to Zazie or Nopa for a life-changing burger-and-wine lunch in a great setting. Leave Zuni for the tourists... or for an occasional cocktail.
author: Lorna M.

description: Average is about the best I can say. I didn't have the legendary chicken, but a place that charges this much should have more than 1 good dish. Not sure why all the hype.  It was way overpriced ($300+) for 4 people, only 1 of which ordered an actual entree. Portions were tiny for the high prices as well. The dessert was good, but nothing to write home about. Good service is the only thing that saved them from a 2-star in my book.
author: Kate K.

description:
I really wanted to like Zuni better.  It's close to my apartment, it often looks friendly and sparkly and I've heard some good things about it.  

Having heard good things about them, I took my aunt.  They start out by seating you near the bar in uncomfortable window seats.  When we were moved to our table upstairs, it was more comfortable, but cramped.  The service was fine, but the food was just eh.  Nothing special, nothing different and the Caesar Salad I tried had awkwardly big pieces.

Sunday night left me far more unimpressed.  A friend and I were wandering around trying to find a place to eat and went into Zuni at about 4:45, having wandered through much of Hayes Valley only to find that it's almost impossible to get an early dinner there on a Sunday. 

My friend told the hostess that we were starving and she said that seating would begin in 20 minutes and dinner in 15, yet two separate parties near us were being brought food.  Maybe it wasn't "dinner" but we didn't appreciate the inconsistency and went elsewhere.
author: Alex K.

description: An old favorite, and just as good as I remembered! Hamburger with heirloom & bleu cheese is amazing, and also had an eggplant & kale soup. Delish!
author: Kanani M.

description: On Market Street.  Great Burgers.   A little pricey for 4:00 PM.  Had to wait for table about 8 minutes
author: Bob L.

description: Good food, friendly & attentive service, and nice set up.  I ordered a pork chop and two others at the table shared the famous oven roasted chicken.  Generally I thought the food was good and I believe we all enjoyed our meals.  I guess with all the reviews I was expecting just a little more in terms of the overall food experience.  I've dined here several times and will probably go again in the future.
author: Kent W.

description:
Happy 30th Birthday!

Always delicious, fresh and memorable.
   
Sauvignon Blanc, Medium-Bodied Complex Minerals(sorry, can't remember the winery)
Beau Soleil (New Brunswick) Oysters with Mignonette 
Caesar Salad with Perfectly Toasted Garlicky Croutons
Creamy Jerusalem Artichoke Soup

Whether after a long day at work, a special occasion, a lazy-me and the Sunday paper day or an evening out with beloved friends/family, Zuni consistently delivers incredible food.  Easily one of the best in San Francisco.

Oh yes, their Bloody Mary's are magnificent.
author: michelle s.

description: Cool spot for drinks! We came by at  5pm on a week night and had some delicious wine and some small bite snacks.  We expected a little more appetizer options but what we had was pretty tasty! Super skinny crunchy fries and clams with some amazing boccolini and beans.  They were cooked in THE most delicious real deal quality olive oil!!  Next time, would love to try that burger! Definitely would come back
author: Emi G.

description:
yums. 

Their oysters were okay. I was thinking about giving it 4 stars because of their oysters but the other food bumped it up. 
Thier argula salad was delicious. 
Their burger was delicious. 
Their roast chicken with bread pudding.... I dunno what to say except try it. :) 
Their water was also delicious.
author: Hae A.

description:
I could probably die happy if my last meal included the roasted chicken and bowl of polenta from Zuni. It was that good. The wine-and-butter drenched stuffing underneath might have even been better than the chicken itself. It's hard to say. 

We sat upstairs in an intimate space in one of the small nook dining areas. Our waiter was very much on top of things - gave good recommendations, filled our glasses on several occasions and was timely with each course. He put in our chicken order right away so we weren't waiting hungry during the 1 hour it takes to roast each bird.

Started with a few Drake and Kumamoto oysters and a $30 or so bottle of Sauvingon Blanc (it was really an economical choice since wines by the glass start at 12 and 14 each.) Can't beat the Kumamotos...while they're small they are consistently the best. 

We split the Caesar salad which was ok...not really sure why they call it the "Zuni Caesar" since there wasn't anything particularly special about it. 

The roasted chicken, however, was deliciously special. Big enough for 2 and a few bites the next day, it was roasted with toasted bread stuffing, pine nuts, mustard greens, currants, garlic, pepper, wine vinegar - and small slices of heaven. Our side of polenta was the best I've had in a restaurant (my mom's is still pretty darn good) and not overwhelmingly rich from too much butter and cheese (you can only take so much--sorry Delfina.)

For dessert we tried the lemony cream "deconstructed lemon-meringue" pie dish, which was light and refreshing. Nice way to end a great meal. I'd come back and try the pastas or burger for a special weekend lunch. Or perhaps find a reason to celebrate so we can justify spending a lot of cash on dinner here again soon.
author: Kelly R.

description: The roast chicken is on par with the golden gate and fog as an institution in this town.  Impeccable.
author: Jesse H.

description: I've been to Zuni several times - it's one of my favorite SF restaurants, but the Sunday brunch that we had we particularly good - Corrina, our server was amazing. As one of my friends said, she was not taking orders, but creating an experience! The food was brilliant - best oysters in town. We shared the famous roasted chicken at the table, and all four of us were impressed by the chicken, but blown away by the bread salad that the chicken is resting on top of. I also had a burger, which I've had before, and it continues to be perfect. The cappuccino was the only thing in the meal that was just so-so. All in all, awesome!
author: Jake B.

description:
I came for Zuni's signature roast chicken, and it did not disappoint!  I've not much to add regarding this salty bit of deliciousness with crispy skin and juicy flesh throughout.  The crouton-like bread salad was also amazing.  It's way more crouton than stuffing really as the bread is crispy and browned, not moist like stuffing.  Its contrast to stuffing really made it as delicious to pick at as was the chicken itself that the two of us completely scarfed down.

So props on the signature dish (and the caesar salad and fava been appetizer)!  But what really made the evening a five star experience was the service!   I haven't been in a restaurant with such an excellent waiter in a very long time I realized.  His every move was pitch perfect.  Dining with a friend I'd only recently caught up with he approached us a few times before we'd even glanced at our menus.  When he ultimately took our order and we asked about wine he explained how every wine on the short list of wines by the glass have been chosen because they complement the signature dish.  Every white and every red were explained in detail by someone who clearly knew the wines personally.  I didn't feel like he was pushing anything in particular and our decision was entirely up to us.  Needless to say I look forward to going back Zuni on future visits to the Bay Area if only there weren't so many other places to try!
author: Sean M.

description:
My sweet baby and I decided we were gonna do at least one fun and fancy thing with our tax return money. We decided that since we looooove going out to dinner that that's what our one splurge would be. She had never been to Zuni, and being a fan who had never actually had THE roast chicken, I decided this was the place!

We arrived 15 minutes early for our 715 reservation and were surprisingly seated immediately. The bar and the restaurant was in full effect, but luckily we were taken to one of the smaller little alcoves upstairs where it wasnt too loud. 

Our server was very nice, and was always on top of our beverage refilling and bread (mmmmm) replacing. We had a reasonably priced bottle of prosecco (not that we needed it after our post martini fest at Olive) and proceeded to order our dishes:

Since it was a romantic evening, we decided to get in the mood and order some oysters! We selected 2 oysters each off the extensive oyster list: 2 baby skookums and 2 Humboldt kumamotos. The skookums were so-so, but the Humboldt kumomotos were so delicious that we ended up ordering one more each! 

We also shared another Zuni classic, the Caesar salad. My sweet baby loooves Caesars, and having had this dish several times in the past, it was a logical choice. It was just as good as I remember, with the beautiful uncut leaves of romaine tossed with that infamous dressing, house-made croutons, and shaved parmesan. YUUUUM, and it is the perfect size to share for 2 people, and very reasonably priced at $10.

For the main dish, we had to order the Roast Chicken for 2. My sweet baby loves chicken, and I needed to see for myself what all the hype was about. Well my friends, there's no hype here. This chicken is unbelievable. It comes with the warm bread salad, greens, and topped with pine nuts and currants. The little currants add a unique and delicious sweetness to the unbelievably moist chicken. The crackly skin....sorry...started drooling.....what was I saying again? Oh right. The chicken definitely lived up to its reputation. We even had some left to bring home, which my sweet baby was disappointed to learn that I had generously shared our wealth and given it to her roomates! That just mean another trip back!

The desserts sounded delish, but we just couldn't fit any more it our happy tummies. 

All in all, our Zuni experience was fantastic on every level, and I highly recommend all their signature dishes...even though we didn't get to order their yummerific shoestring potatoes. Like I said,  another trip back!
author: Audrey K.

description:
walking up and down market is very hard work, especially when you're lost ... due to ... i won't even go there.

Anyhow, I saw a couple of old .. couples sitting outside having mimosas and it made me want some.  I don't like mimosas but at that moment ... i felt like a kid wanting what another kid was eating.

So we went in and got a table before it got packed.  I'm tellin ya's .. everytime i go to a restaurant it's dead, but after I get settled in, ppl show up!  I need to get paid to show up to a restaurant just to eat so more customers appear ... hmm. srry, daydreaming.

Anyhow, since it was my first time and it was lunch time, I got the burger and fries.  Burger was good but the fries were EPIC!  The fries were skinny and it made it really fun to eat and believe you me, I'm soooo not a fry guy but I will order them at Zuni.

If ya'll have time, go have some fries and mimosas but gluck in finding parking :)

Oh yeah, the main reason I went into the cafe was because of the unusual shape of the bldg.
author: Sam K.

description:
Food:Seasonal local cuisine. Most of the dishes seemed simple and were executed well. Presentation was so so. 

Vibe: Zuni is quite representative of San Francisco and epitomizes the city's atmosphere of casual and cosmopolitan. 

Decor: Narrow and small with a nice little fire place. 

Value: Pretty average bordering on the side of pricey.

Returnability: Possibly.
author: Roger H.

description: Spent some time at the cocktail lounge at Zuni on Market. Went there with a few friends from the philosophy department. It was a good time and an interesting place to reconnect. Introduced scotch (glenmorangie) to one of the guys - liked it. Good service.
author: Claude C.

description:
Food is simple, fresh and delicious.
Service is attentive but not overwhelming.
Zuni is the type of place where you could sit for hours and not feel rushed to leave (waiting for the chicken is worth it).
Wine list is exceptional.
Desserts are yummy.
A bit spendy, but we never regret it.
author: Rebeca R.

description:
Meh. 

After seeing Wicked, friends and I roamed around Hayes Valley hoping for a small coffee shop and with very few options still open, we ended up at Zuni cafe.

The hot chocolate was not hot...tasted like hot cocoa. The kumamoto oysters were okay but prices were steep! $3.00 a pop. Hello Hog Island!

Lastly there was a wood fire oven. We were happy to see that but no pizza on the menu!  Meh. Nuff said.
author: S. V.

description: Great food, wonderful atmosphere and an excellent selection of wine, beer, and cocktails.  I'd give 5 stars, however, some dishes are just a bit too pricey.  With that said, you do get what you pay for.  We really enjoyed Zuni and will definitely be coming back.
author: Alex K.

description:
Food was bland and certainly not up to San Francisco standards.

Beef filet was under seasoned, and the chicken had little flavor, the bread salad was the only redeeming grace of that dish. My brothers first pork chop was served raw, cold pink center.

My comment last night was Costco makes a better roast chicken and sure enough several other postings have alluded to this as well.
author: Tim Y.

description:
The first time I went to Zuni I was overwhelmed by the prices.  So I ordered the cheapest things I could find, skipped the appetizers and had one class of the $9 wine. This made all of $4 difference to the final check and I left aggrieved.  
For years I heard people raving about the famous chicken with bread salad.  Despite living in the neighborhood, I didn't go back for almost three years.  After this time it was just embarrassing to live so close and not have tried the famous chicken.  So my husband and I did go back just under three years later and we had one of the best meals we'd had all year. 
We got the appetizers, cocktails, of course the renowned chicken, and the chocolate cake.  It was one of the best meals we've had in San Francisco.  We waited the full hour for our chicken (we arrived at 7.30pm) but it seemed like if you arrived later in the night you didn't need to wait as long...the couple on the table next to us arrived around 9pm ordered the chicken and were eating it 20 minutes later.  
There is one really rubbish table at Zuni, you'll see it if you walk by the front of the restaurant on Market Street.  It's a long stretch of copper against a wall.  This table is always available, and the staff will say that it's a table where you sit next to each other (because of the it being hard to get a table and them only taking walk-ins if you try for a reservation the same day, you'll be tempted by this).  They neglect to mention that the table doesn't have a cover like all the others, you're facing a wall, and it's basically a shelf, not a table.  That table contributed to us having a bad time on our first trip too. 
So, get the chicken; you'll leave happy!
author: Rebecca N.

description:
*Amazing* moist Roast Chicken with a toasted bread salad for two.  The hour wait is worth it - as long as you have good company ;-P    You can also quickly fill the void snacking on apps and enjoying a cocktail.
This place quickly climbed the ladder to a favorite great date spot.  I'd even rank it to a top V-day spot if I knew this was on the menu.  The dessert (mascarpone tart w/ huckleberry sauce) screamed for me to return w/in a 1 week!   Excellent attentive service.  My one suggestion:  take a shawl or wrap as this place can be very chilly due to the not-so-insulated windows...
author: Kerri L.

description:
Now that's a beautiful bird!

Had (one of) my birthday dinner here last saturday. I've always been curious to what the roasted chicken dinner for two is like.

The menu states that it takes about an hour so we ordered the chicken even before our server poured water in our glasses. She promptly placed our order then came back for our next order.

First of, they have a good selection of oysters. Had the kumamoto, marin miyagi, and drake's. All in this region. Very fresh. They dont give you a side of marinara but instead, it's vinegar with garlic.

Cocktails were stiff but it comes in small glasses.

Then came the salad. King Farm garden lettuce salad with garlic chapons and Banyuls vinaigrette. Decent.

The sommelier recommended a really good wine to go with the chicken. A red from the Savoie region of France. Pretty different from what I'm used to drinking. Great half bottle price too!

Now, for the star of the night. Coming from Modesto Farm (as our server told me), as my friend who took me there said "it's the most beautiful chicken I have ever seen and eaten." The chicken is simple and perfectly seasoned. Juicy, tender, and even the breast is moist. The bed of warm flatbread soaked up some of the juices and the dressing of the salad it came with. Loved it.

The bad: shoestring potatoes were a tad salty.

We were so full from the chicken but we just had to try the dessert. Piccola meringata. Merengue wafers layered with cream. Plum sauce on the side. That was a great way to end the meal. Light and not too sweet. Merengue melts in you mouth and I love the way it kinda sticks to your teeth.

Overall, I'd like to give it 4.5 stars. Service was really awesome. +0.5 stars. The food was great but not enough to merit a 5 star.
author: Ryan B.

description:
My wife and I came here as an escape to reality; actually, we just want to get away and relax a bit without kids. 

we came here for lunch and ordered few of the oysters, which by the way, they were all amazing.  totally fresh and we love them!

My wife ordered the Meatballs braised i nspicy tomato sauce with polenta and garden lettuces.  Those 3 meatballs were really good.  Tender, not sour/sweet or salty.  They were just perfect for my wife's taste.

I ordered the house-ground grass-fed beef hamburger on grilled rosemary focaccia with aioli and zuni pickle.  I love the focaccia, it goes really well with my burger!

As for desserts, grapes meringata, and you know what, best dessert we ever tasted.  I have no idea what's included it, but it's not too sweet and fit perfectly for our taste bud.

https://sphotos.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-snc7/480782_10150907971311121_1059902074_n.jpg
author: James L.

description:
The only limiting factor of Zuni is price, which makes it a restaurant for special occasions. If you don't mind spending a premium for excellent food, however, you should not hesitate to come here. 

Zuni has an extensive wine list, and their sommelier is not afraid to assist in pairing suggestions. Their waitstaff is also extraordinarily friendly and attentive, despite the enormous number of customers they have to assist. 

We had the Caesar salad, spaghetti with eggplant and zucchini (of course the noodles were hand-made), and roasted chicken. The star of the show was the roasted chicken, which the menu claimed served two but I'd say it could actually serve four! Probably the best chicken I've had in my life, and the other dishes weren't too shabby either. 

If Zuni could find a way to make their offerings slightly more affordable and accessible, I'd give them 5 stars. However, their sky-high prices make this review fall just short of perfect.
author: Seth F.

description:
Roasted Chicken so good, it will make you want to slap yo' mamma!

A friend and I went to eat at Zuni on a Saturday night.  We had the roasted chicken for 2 (~$50), a fried asparagus/onions/lemon slice appetizer, bottle of Napa Valley Sauv Blanc, Caesar Salad, and two desserts.  Yes, the ordering was heavily influenced by the other reviews here.  Yes, the chicken is as good as they say.  

The Chicken was served in a bed of greens and pieces of bread to soak up the chicken goodness.  Moist and clean tasting.  I tried looking for a dry spot, and couldn't find any.  I really think this is the best roasted chicken I've had in my life.  Maybe not dollar for dollar, but for the taste, yes.  The Sauv Blanc didn't have much character (compared to other Sauv Blancs)... actually kinda sucked, but I don't put the blame on the restaurant.  The fried veggie appetizer was very tasty and seemingly light, to my surprise.  Desserts were nicely presented.but too sweet for my taste.    

Service at this joint was above average, even for these fancy-schmancy restaurants.  They set the expectation at 1 hour wait for the Chicken, but I think it only took about 30 minutes to arrive.  When the Maitre d' came around and asked how our meal was, I told him that we never got our Caesar Salad, but can just cancel it since we're onto the tasty chicken.  He then swiftly offered to bring it anyway and comp it, if we wouldn't mind.  We took him up on the offer and had a fresh Caesar Salad with the chicken.  

Overall I would recommend that people come checkout the roasted chicken at least.  It is definitely fantastic and lives up to the hype.
author: Leo C.

description:
Great spot.

Food was awesome (esp the chicken and the salmon) and the space had a good vibe.

Reception and bar tenders had a bit of an attitude which was the only knock on the place.
author: Greg A.

description:
I've always wanted to go to this place.  For years I passed and passed the corner spot with glass windows and only imaged that this place was good and boy was it.

I went here on July 11th 2008.  I was in the city with my aunt, and we were making our way to santa rosa/cloverdale area (I had to shoot a wedding).  

She asked where I wanted to go and this place instantly popped into my head.  I HAD TO EAT THERE I told her,so we went.  I got really lucky and got a park a few feet from the door.  We went around 4ish and it was not busy at all.  A few people at the bar and a few at tables through out the place.  We go to sit right by the kitchen which was great for the both of us (I'm aunt is a chef in the making and well I just like to see who's cooking my food).

We both had the burgers which were OUT OF THIS WORLD.  I'm usually not a big beef/hamburger fan but wow!!!  Next time I'll order the shoe string fries to go with it.

I ended up being too full to try their chocolate cake (another fancy french name I can not remember).

I will be going back soon as in this weekend!  I might get the burger again or try their chicken for two.

You have to go, great place.
author: m l.

description:
We didn't have the chicken, we got there sort of late on a Wednesday night and didn't want to do the 1 hr wait.  Maybe we will go back and check that out.

There were 4 of us and overall we thought it was fine.  To start we got the House-cured anchovies & Bowl of polenta.  Anchovies were plain and under whelmed us, polenta was good though.

Dinner we got the quail, pork chop and two risottos.  Risotto was good but nothing like any risotto any of the 4 of us have had before.  We don't know why its a risotto.  Pork chop and the quail were good though.

We were all still hungry after apps and entrees and were forced to try the desserts.   We got Gateau Victoire (ie chocolate cake) and mint ice-cream.  The chocolate cake was just like chocolate cake else where, just refined looking in name and stature.  The mint ice cream was very good.  You could take real mint and real cream the whole way though it.  YUMMY 

Overall, not a bad meal but in my opinion not worth the hype
author: ORLA L.

description: I have been here twice in 20 years.  It's just not good enough to justify the prices or to tempt me to return more often.  The last roast chicken I had here was kind of dried out, and it costs close to $50 IIRC.  And it's so easy to make a great roast chicken at home.  The best things about Zuni are the vibe and the building.  Without those elements it would never have survived as long as it has.
author: Tom N.

description:
Who knew going to Zuni last night (a Sunday) would provide not only a great meal, but an ego boost as well. 

I came home all scrubby from shooting photos in China Town all day and got on FaceBook to see it was my friend Daniel's birthday. He hits me up to go out to dinner. He says Zuni at 9pm. Awesome, as I'd never been there before. 

We get there slightly tardy for our reservation, but it's ok because there aren't very many people there. Nice for a Sunday night. They seat us in a cozy corner upstairs. The first ego-boosting moment of the evening is when the lovely hostess said she LOVED my new red wool coat. Being as I'm totally jazzed about it, that was pretty cool. 

Since Daniel had requested the company of a beautiful woman for his birthday (I told him it would be a stretch, as it was ME who he was going out with), I put on a retro 40's style dress that is quite low cut and really shows off the girls. When I took my coat off when we sat down, every guy that was seated looking towards us stopped and stared. Daniel got the nod from a few of them. It was hilarious. 

Now, on to the real review... Our cocktails were fabulous (I got D to try a Sazerac despite the fact he doesn't normally like whiskey) and I had the Elderflower/Champagne cocktail. It was more than delightful. Our server was a bit scattered it seemed, but actually worked out OK in the end due to the fact that he was very knowledgeable about the bottle of wine I requested. This is always a plus! 

We ordered the Cesar Salad (which was a little overdressed for my liking. If the amount of oil in something you're eating can remove the very nearly unremoveable lipstick from your lips after three bites, there might be a problem!) and then I saw a plate of the shoestring potatoes go by. Had to have some of those. They came promptly and was a nice thing to nibble on before the main course. 

I ordered the skirt steak and Daniel had the pot roast. both dishes were super yummy and the fact that mine came with an artichoke was super great. 

The desert we had (apple torte with molasses ice cream and booze-soaked currants) sounded WAY better than it actually was, so that was a bit disappointing. 

All in all, the dining experience was lovely, the wine (2005 Swan something or other from Russian River Valley - help me out - anyone...?) was exactly as promised and fun was had by all.
author: MoMo D.

description:
You just gotta love this quintessential San Francisco spot! Always a lively, crowded spot, so reservations are a good idea!  The must haves list here has the Roasted Chicken in the starring role - don't expect a quick dinner for this one -- relax, enjoy your company and the scene - you've got one of the most luscious, tender, flavorful chicken coming your way.  Trust me. The bread salad served with is chicken drippings good.  The menu is seasonal and varies, but frankly, I've never had a bad dish here.  The pastas are great - perfectly cooked and amazing sauces.  Steaks are fantastic. and the burger..... YUM!  One of the best, with the best fries attached!

I think I need to make reservations now for lunch... I am dreaming of the chicken!
author: Danielle R.

description: So good I almost cried!  We were starving when we arrived and although the dining room was full, we were seated quickly, waited upon promptly and the food was amazing.  Service was great too.
author: E J.

description:
great ambience both for brunch or a romantic dinner for two, granted the neighborhood isn't great at night.
who doesn't like brined chicken? worth the wait to do try it at least once. 
the fries were awesome, but also salty. probably why i enjoyed them so much.
beer and cocktail selection was fun and delicious.

brunch menu not as well known, but also pretty good.  also brought along 2 kids (11 and 7) here for brunch and the waiter brought them crayons which was pretty cool.

would definitely recommend for either meal.
author: Sandy K.

description:
I was really excited about going to this San Francisco institution for the first time.  Unfortunately, I was disappointed, especially for the prices they charge!

The tuna appetizer was gross, really gross.  The tuna was grey and brown, and looked (and tasted) like the stuff that comes out of the can.  I ate it because I was hungry, but I actually had a hard time getting it down.  

My husband ordered the ricotta gnocci, which was quite good.

Our friends had ordered the roasted chicken (which is why I ate that yucky tuna thing, because I knew I wouldn't be eating anything else for at least an hour!), and, though it was tasty, I could tell my friends were disappointed.  Bad sign, since one of them is a chef and has quite a discerning palate.

My grouper was very basic, it was served in a butter sauce with carrots and onions.  California Cuisine 101, anybody?

The waitstaff was very good, and the space was nice.  But the food was a huge disappointment.  Our bill was $350.  Ouch.  I won't be back.
author: Jessica H.

description:
Zuni Cafe has a great summer beach atmosphere in the middle of downtown SF.  The oyster selection was amazing but my favorite ones were definitely summer ice and the kumamotos.  They were very sweet and flavorful.  The one hour baked chicken didn't really meet my expectations (thought costco chicken for 6 dollars is better).  50 dollars for one chicken, I was totally expecting better.  Overall, I would go here again for oysters and drinks only!

Pros: great oysters, great service.

Cons: chicken was a little too dry for my taste.
author: Amy C.

description:
The seasonal menu at this place is pretty impressive, so anything you order is going to be super fresh, cooked with amazing skills, and just hellua good. However, my top two recommendations are the Chicken for Two, and the hamburger. Oh yeah, the balsamic bloody mary is totally awesome. And the shoe string potatoes rock! Oh! and if the butter beans are on the menu you must order them, you must!

The chicken takes forever, at least an hour wait, but it is so worth it. The simple, yet utterly delicious warm bread salad really makes the dish extra special. Next time I'm ordering extra bread salad. It's made like a simple stuffing with torn bread, toasted in the brick oven, tossed with clarified butter and olive oil, mixed with currants, pine nuts, and garlic. They put that in the bowl first, then add red mustard greens drizzled with olive oil, then the roast chicken cut into pieces and placed on top of all with the pan juices. OMFG! It is the best chicken Jerry, the best!

And the hamburger. Seriously, you'll never taste a better burger. They offer some fine cheeses to go on top, and some other jazz if you want it, but just the plain ol' burger is aces. The taste of the meat is incredible. Gotta be grass fed. I think the shoe string potatoes comes with the burger (not sure). If they don't, please order them as a side. They are crispy and yummy and plentiful, and come with a side of home-made ketchup. So damn good.

My one complaint about this place is the lack of appetizers. I mean, they offer great olives, but other than that, the app choices are not really appealing to me. Also, the dessert menu is a little bland. BUT, having said that, I still had to give Zuni 5 stars for the service and the amazingness of the dinner menu, and drink selection.
author: Shannon B.

description:
Pricey and worth it.  You can't here once a week or even once a month but you can be confident that when you do make a reservation at Zuni that the food will be great.  

THe building is small and odd shaped, but it somehow works.
author: Chad S.

description:
Went with my parents on a Saturday night; ordered everything BUT the chicken. Drinks were great, fish was great, beef was great, oysters, polenta, tomato soup, pimiento salad was fantastic. 

Unfortunately, our waiter disappeared half way through the meal. Served dinner, left for 30 minutes. Dropped dessert menus, gone for 20 minutes. 30 minutes after dessert was served I let the hostess know that we needed our check. Sad that spotty service added an annoying edge to an otherwise great (and pricey) meal.
author: Laura B.

description:
You'd be surprised how many hidden rooms are within Zuni Cafe. The multilevel restaurant has a lot of neat tables in random spots, so you kinda get a different dining experience each time you come in. 

Off the bat, before we even looked through the menu, we ordered the roast chicken. If you plan on ordering this, might as well order it through the host if you want to shave off your time here. 

The gnocchi is a must try. It's not your traditional Italian grandmother's heavy potato nuggets. Zuni makes them out of the softest, puffiest ricotta cheese swimming in a delicate pool of butter and light herbs. It was one of those savored dining experiences I'll never forget. You cut into the smooth cheese and it melts like ice cream once you put it in your mouth. It just falls apart and the butter sauce melds perfectly with the subtle cheese. 

Their famed roasted chicken was pretty good, but we kept saying it tasted familiar. Like Limon? CostCo rotisserie? It didn't taste spectacular... sure, it was brined well, moist, crispy skin, but when it comes down to it, it's just roast chicken! It's a hefty portion... made for two? More like made for four! Along with the chicken was a bed of toasted bread soaked in a vinegary sauce. Now, that was unique, but ultimately too heavy as an accompaniment with the chicken.

Service was impeccable!  Very courteous, but not in that fake voice I often hear when someone wants to overly please you.  I like a casual dive most of the time where the staff wears their own style, but I really do get impressed if I see service people in a clean white shirt and pressed pants.  Adds to the togetherness and cleanliness of an establishment.
author: Chris T.

description: Hard to believe I've never reviewed this place.  Zuni is by far the most reliable restaurant we frequent in the city.  Up front, reservations are tough like any good restaurant in SF.   Hit up Opentable or risk a small wait at the front.  Then, take advantage of the dishes they are known for:  The roast chicken is amazing and feeds four.  The burger (only available @ lunch or after 10) is excellent.  Pair that with their shoe string fries and its downright divine.   If they're serving the pot d'creme, it is the bomb.  Otherwise, anything with in-season fruit will rock for desert.   For an appetizer, I swear by any soup they make.  They've got it down.  My wife rolls with the caesar salad and swears by it as well.  On top of that, solid Acme bread for starters.  Overall, a great place for a relaxing dinner. Pro tip: Get a reservation @ 9:45 & order the burger.  You won't regret it!
author: Brian L.

description: Chicken was really juicy!  All food was good, except portions are modest.
author: Yvonne H.

description:
I'm still a little bummed about my experience at Zuni, pre-theatre, on Friday evening. We had a reservation for 6:15 and were promptly sat. Though the hostess and person who called to confirm the reservation both knew we were heading to the theatre, our server was not informed. 

I was so excited to share Zuni with my mom, who is a chef. We planned to order the chicken, but after waiting 10 minutes for our server, were informed it would be cutting it too close (ordering at 6:25, chicken wouldn't arrive til 7:25- show at 8). So a note to theatre goers: maybe try to order the chicken when you first walk in, if possible? 

We ordered the pork chop and halibut, as well as the Zuni Caesar. The pork chop was fatty, and nothing special. I've had better. Especially for $26.50- way overpriced. My mom's halibut was luke warm and flavorless, she should have sent it back. 

As far as dessert, our waitor suggested the "Gateau" which is like a flourless chocolate cake. The cake tasted anything BUT flourless- not rich, not dense, not warm. I was shocked that they are "famous" for this. However, the blood orange upside down cake was absolutely Delicious. 

I will return to Zuni because their chicken and burger is THAT GOOD. And our server was very nice. But I must say, that I was very disappointed in their food after our experience on friday; for the amount people are paying, it needs to be better. It's just ridiculous if it is not.
author: Laura D.

description:
Came here with a few friends and we ordered three entrees: Grilled Yellow fin Tuna, Pork Chops and their Chicken for Two (takes 40min to make).  We all decided to share the entrees so we can get a feel of what Zuni is all about.  Our first entree is the yellow fin tuna and this dish tasted more like a cured meat.  The outside of the fish was grilled perfectly with some crispy texture and some saltiness to the palette.  This is cooked pretty much medium-rare so be prepared! The second dish was the pork chops and it was good but a little salty to my taste.  I thought the pork chops were a little overcooked but it was still juicy.  I was expecting it to be a little bit pink but it was thoroughly cooked.  Then, last but not least was their well-known rotisserie chicken with bread salad.  I was more amazed with the bread salad than the chicken because honestly, Costco's rotisserie chicken is way better than Zuni's chicken.  Zuni's chicken had a great balance of salt and juiciness but the flavor wasn't completely there.  As 10 min passed by, I thought the chicken tasted dry already.  Anyways, wow, their bread salad is soo damn good!   I wonder if you could order this a la carte.

I don't like the bus boy because it seemed like he was slamming our drinks on the table and also seemed unfriendly.  Our waiter was super nice and got us whatever we needed.  We sat upstairs and it was a great view of the restaurant and Market Street.

For three people ordering three entrees, we all paid about $45/person.
author: Irene L.

description: Great food. I went simple as I often do and wasn't disappointed. I had polenta with parmigiano reggiano. I found it grand. We sat next a couple who profiled us as "wholesome". I was really unsure what to make of the comment. However, no harm was done as they chatted us up till the left with me swearing up and down that they were famous. Pretty pricey but San Fran tended to be.
author: Matt B.

description:
Went for roommie's bday and to try #1 on the "Big Eat SF" list...

The Chicken and bread salad, from what I tasted, was pretty awesome (and HUGE, much more than for 2 people as it boasts).... 

but also expensive (already has the correct $$$). Cocktails are about 10 bucks and up. Fresh squeezed orange juice was good! Personally had one of the appetizer pastas; good size, so can easily get by with an appetizer if you're on a budget =)
author: S V.

description: Came here for holiday work dinner. We sat upstairs by the window and it was nice to be able to look out of the window. Our server was very knowledgeable and helpful. Would def revisit again!
author: Lily Z.

description: Really amazing. Went for lunch and enjoyed every course. Deliciously simple panna cotta. Great carrot soup. Wonderful casual atmosphere. Not to miss.
author: Laura S.

description:
The Roasted Chicken is the bomb.  Like tick, tick.  

But for the life of me, I can't replicate Zuni's roasted chicken at home.  I think it may have something to do with the wood-fired brick oven.  My poor little bosch doesn't stand a chance.  I usually don't order chicken when I dine out.  I'd much rather have a money meat like duck, lamb, beef.  

My advice: 
Do not wear heels- those stairs are murder.  
Order the roasted chicken the moment you are seated cause it really does take an hour.
Save room for the amazing gateau victoire - so light yet so rich.
author: Monica L.

description:
A bit of a let down based on all the rave and the challenges of successfully booking a table.  The bread they give you to start is awesome and as hard as it'll be don't order seconds if you're getting their famous roast chicken; it comes with a big bread salad.  The chicken was good but not $48 good, and yes I knew that it was meant for two.  We also got their ragu pasta and that was eh.  Not sure what kind of a restaurant that they're trying to portray but their ethnic dishes were all over the board.  What did impress me was their wine list, which gave them the fourth star.
  
Improvements:  wish they posted their menu daily.  Its so hard to get a table and in addition not knowing whats on the menu makes it a gamble...unless you're getting their chicken; which is a good fallback if nothing else seems appetizing.  Only problem with checking the menu first, is that its best to request the roast chicken as you sit since it takes 45mins.-hour.  

Its worth a try if you like doing the "SF to-do's" but won't wow you.
author: LIVE to E.

description:
Just good ole' food. If you are interested I would pick up the owner's book. She goes into detail about her time staging in Europe. It's more like cook stories than just a cookbook. I read the whole thing before coming to Zuni's. Which I recommend if you have the ambition. 

Zuni's is on Market (Financial District) so you get some of the suit crowd. It was funny that when I went there at the table next to us was this suit with his girlfriend. She was pretty but she didn't eat anything! He kept on looking over at me as I was oohing and ahhing over everything on my plate and my Aunt's plate. I got the Braised Oxtails. I think it came with polenta but it's a little fuzzy. All I know is that if they would have let me lick it off of my plate. I would have. This is a place where you eat your food, not pick at it! If you like to play it safe I would get the roast Chicken for 2. I think it is the dish they are associated with the most.
author: Amanda R.

description:
What's a trip to SF without a stop at zuni café for a balsámic bloody mary topped with onions and a selection of oysters that's bound to have the walrus in all of us ask for more. The classic zuni bloody....
Perfectly paired with some miyagis and Pacific hog island oysters. The oyster and wine selection is extensive. A wood fired oven warms up the backroom, while the bar upfront overlooks market street. 

The chucking of oysters with some champagne was a classic sunday. The chive and scallion mignionette is always fantastic. 

The legendary chicken, which takes an hour to prepare is what brings the crowds out. You can only order this from the restaurant, you cannot call ahead and pre-order. It is perfection presented on a plate mixed with greens. The little exposed bones come out toasted!

The grass fed burger on buttered foccacia, sauteed red onions and pickled cucumber, with shoestring fries was finger licking good. Mouth watering grass fed local farm beef is complemented with the tangy sweet vinegary onions. The mountain of shoestring fries is addicatively good. Sprinkle some sea salt and cracked pepper or ask for some herbs du provence for an added flavor. 

love this place!
author: omar p.

description: We came here for a late night reservation and spend a few wonderful hours enjoying Zuni Cafe. We ordered the Chicken for two (which my boyfriend was almost insisting on after reviewing the menu prior to our visit), at first I was a bit skeptical, but when it arrived I was not disappointed. Probably the best chicken I've had and the bread pieces and the rest of it were delightful. It actually felt like a very economical option as  named (chicken for 2), but we took home leftovers and were able to have it for dinner the next night as well! We also had a salad and another appetizer which I believe I enjoyed a lot as well, but my most memorable part is the chicken which blew it all away. Our wine selections were very good, especially the Mt. Eden Pinot Noir, and our cocktails were good but not super memorable. I can't wait to make a return trip someday
author: Kelly B.

description:
I don't know why they only had Red Chimay, and not Blue
bread was cold, when they could easily warm it there big ole brick oven
mojito to watery, the whole balance was off
their pizza, sauce, basil flakes, and, crumbled ricotta, ehhh
portobello mushroom sandwhich w/ swiss on focaccia was good but isn't better than the shittake mushroom burger at Cafe Flore
the caesar & arugula salad were the best thing, but if you don't want anchovies then it takes ten minutes for it to come out and then its still dry

won't be going back there anytime soon.
author: og c.

description: We came here to recreate our first date 22 years ago. At that time, they served what we called $20 chicken. It's now $50 chicken. The food is delicious. We started with oysters, which were lovely. I had a margarita which was served in a martini glass. It was potent but medicinal. I would have preferred a pint glass and more lime. The bread and butter they serve is unbelievably good. We had an anchovy appetizer which came with shaved parmesan, olives, and olive oil. Very tasty and small for $9. We also shared a Ceasar salad which was very flavorful. The chicken is roasted to perfection and comes with a bread stuffing with currents and pine nuts. There are fresh greens and vinagrette on top. It's amazing. My reason for 3 stars is the pricing is just over the top. $12 for a martini sized cocktail. $50 for a chicken plus tax can't really be rationalized. Also, the chairs are really uncomfortable. We had an incident where my husband spilled my wine so I ordered another glass. I was surprised that we were charged for that. The food is prepared meticulously and you feel that you are somewhere special. I do recommend it for a special occasion. Make a reservation. I guess it's like the in crowd in high school. It's cool to be there, but it's not really comfortable. I think there should be much more effort to be warm and welcoming and they really need new chairs.
author: Lisa S.

description: I have been a customer since Zuni opened in the early 80's.  I must have come here hundreds of times.  The place has totally lost its edge.  Recently I was asked to leave because I complained that the Cafe Latte was too hot and tasted bad.  The waiter came and asked me if I knew that Cafe Latte had more milk than foam. I told her that I didn't need her to tell me what a Cafe Latte was.  Then the manager (Mark Simmons) came and asked me if there was a problem. So I shared with him the experience with sweet sincerity. I told him that the place had lost its edge. The bathroom's sink faucet didn't work (had not worked for months), the chicken (signature dish) had come burned last 2 times I was there. And the Cafe Latte just tasted bad. I told him I would go there because I love the place and wanted to support it as an iconic restaurant in San Francisco. He then asked me to leave and told me they wouldn't serve me because I was belligerent.  I tried to calm him down to at least serve my two boys their burgers. He was insitent that we had to leave and that he wouldn't serve us. So we left. Not cool. Not nice. Bad place. Would urge people to boycott this place. Gone too far.  Sad to see an icon go this far south into the dregs.  Take the critique.  Give us a good new Cafe Latte and go on with business.  No need for all this unless Mark Simmons got a chip on his shoulder.
author: Arman P.

description:
Well, after the fandango around making our late night reservations last week, it seemed everything was in place for us to dine at Zuni at 10pm. I did have one more guest and called them the day before feeling great trepidation because of my previous experience with a reservationist. This time they just said "no problem at all; you just might need to wait 10 or 15 minutes." Which was fine.

So we arrived (late) and they were able to sit six of us with no problems. I'm not sure why they said they could only seat four when I called last week, but winging it at the last minute seemed to go just fine.

I have lived in in SF for the past 25 years, but until this point I had only actually been to Zuni twice; once, to try their margarita and another time to try their roast chicken. So I had never really had a dining adventure with their menu or seen their full service in action.

It was fun getting there so late and I'm so glad they could accomodate us. We had been to the theatre so had lots to talk about with one of the actors at the table with us. They let us take it slow even at that hour which is also much appreciated. 

Everything on the menu except for just a few items was available. 

We started with the Fettunta. I am sure many have heard of that, but the way the Waiter explained it was, "Well it's a vehicle really... see in Italy they cold press this green green olive oil and in less than two days it's flown here and we serve it at the table. It's like the beaujolais nouveaux of olive oil." That last part really got our San Francisco Muppie hearts pounding. Then he said, "So well actually it's toast."

Anyway, the Fettunta arrived in the form of a nice toasted slab of tuscan-style bread soaked with this Olio Verde, which we cut up into many small bits. Also some raw raddicchio leaves, carrot curls, and tender baby celery stalks. We all took a bite of the fettunta and simultaneously our eyes got wide and that's when our heads exploded and the waiters had to tell the bus boys to mop the ceilings.

I have since looked up the word Fettunta online, and despite the fact that it sounds kind of like a lewd name for a body part in Italian, it's really basically the purest form of garlic bread, heavy on the Olio. My theory is that some of the spiciness may have been a garlic kick although perhaps there was no garlic included - there was just a very grassy, then spicy, then nutty progression over about 15 seconds; I'm going to get a bottle of that Olio Verde at Zuni this week for the holidays, and I plan to ask them if there is garlic in their Fettunta (not a euphemism).

We also enjoyed their frites by the handful. Worth stopping by for the frites and I'd love to try their other fried veggie appetizer.

I had the grouper with capers and shallots alongside another toast which had chard, meyer lemon, and boiled egg on top of it. It was all really soulful and delicious, and maybe I was dreaming but it tasted like it had yet more of the wonderful Olio Verde on it. My immediate dining companion enjoyed a bowl of polenta, which was another dimension in comfort food. Others had the whole wheat spaghetti with veggies and the conigio appetizer. Their wine selection was nice and the cocktails were good, and we shared a floating island at the end - a delicate white creme anglaise dotted with pistachios and pomegranate seeds, with a sweet little white meringue in the center.

I also appreciated the hot toddy the waiter brought when I said I had a cold. It was like theraflu only much better :-)

We stayed til after 12:30 and there were still guests in the place. The restaurant business can be hard on the body and mind, and I'm impressed that a place like Zuni can maintain such great comfort and decorum after such an intensely long day. I wish I had the means to make it a point to go there a lot more often. Actually I may stop in tomorrow for a couple of bottles of that Olive Oil as Christmas gifts. And I might also have a burger while I'm there :-)
author: Roxmarie M.

description:
De-lish

I always enjoy bringing people here... the ambience is great, the bar setup is elegant, and just the whole structure of the restaurant makes for a unique experience... the building itself is in the shape of a cake wedge, so there are interesting corners to situate yourself if you're on a romantic date (be careful with the stairs though)

the food here is simple, organic... and I think thats what sets it apart from other dining establishments... its not overdone or overembellished... 
it's entrees are delicious without the need to be adorned with superfluous garnishments

their signature dish is the roasted chicken, which is what I usually get...
perfect for splitting with a friend or a date

one of the owners goes to my gym ... he calls himself  'playboy del mundo'... haha... he's a great guy and is very passionate about what he does...
author: Ryan K.

description: I'm not a huge chicken fan.  Period.  BUT, I have to say, their chicken is as good as it is famous.  Oh, and you know how on Thanksgiving everyone fights over the last spoonful of stuffing (well, at least we do it in my family), because it's so damn good?  Well, there were some elbow jabbing done at our table once we discovered the divine butter soaked bread underneath the chicken.
author: Mary T.

description:
Just had lunch at Zuni Cafe - love all the natural lighting, open airy space and feel to the place...the stone/concrete staircase was interesting, as was the rustic hardwood flooring. 

I was a bit nervous when the hostess led me upstairs because it seemed to be full of people and I didn't want to be sitting at a table for four in the middle of a full dining area. I was pleasantly surprised that they led me to a little nook with a table set for one with bench seating. (Makes me wonder if they change up the seating arrangements for dinner service.) I got to be a part of "the action" while still having privacy to savor my lunch (there was savoring going on, eventhough I finished my meal quickly - I enjoyed every bite) and listen to my news podcast/daydream.

Bread: Mmmm...baked in wood/stone oven?

Beverage: I was sad that they didn't have regular sparkling San Pellegrino since it would've paired perfectly with the food I was going to order - and the ambiance - but their orange juice was fantastic - pulpy and naturally sweet. Just looking at the vibrant orange color made me feel like I was drinking in the Spring season.

Entree: Crostini with kale something something and a poached egg...YUM! I finished it in less than five minutes - hit the spot. Not super filling. Not recommended for those who want a heavy meal. I wanted to pick up the bowl plate and drink the rest of the "juices" but refrained. For a split second I wished I had more of that wood/stone oven baked bread but something told me to hold off.

Dessert: Gateau Victoire with whipped cream...DELISH! I'm so glad I didn't ask for extra bread (aside from looking a little ridiculous and indulgent - no having a slice of flourless chocolate cake doused with whipped cream is not indulgent... =P). Can't put my finger on what made it so good...the cake had a crumbly texture to it so it felt like a regular chocolate cake but the taste was so purely cocoa...like when you are making hot chocolate and you scoop that spoonful of cocoa powder into your mouth, rather than the cup - two for the cup, one for me)...or was it the smooth light and fluffy whipped cream that held pieces of cake together while it sat on my fork but melted away instantly on my tongue...? 

Simply perfect - recommended for solo dining or even for groups. Looks like quite a few people were enjoying lunch with friends, family and even coworkers. The waitstaff was fantastic as well. I hope to try their brunch sometime or even just a pizza and some wine - yes, it's one of those types of places. And yes, several tables around me ordered the pizza - made me want to stay for a second lunch but alas, I needed to return to work.
author: Cat T.

description:
THE best roast chicken with bread salad. though it does take 1 hour!
it is brined, so make sure you drink water or later you might get salt-rebound headache.

Kid friendly! we got the bench seat so my daughter could roam around a bit and lay down for a nap (not that she napped, wah)

We got the tagliatelle with corn. oh. so good!!  the corn was fresh and not over cooked. felt healthy...

hamburger came with "asian-ish" pickles. yummy. and I added the heirloom tomatoes. yum!

Caesar salad was delish! and enough to split for two. a little on the fishier side. but still divine with croutons.

free bread - also divine

OJ - fresh and pulpy

only gripe was $48 for the chicken which serves 2 but seems a little on the pricey side given the economy?
author: Sophia Y.

description:
Oh hello Bread Salad!
We had delicious cocktails while waiting for our dinner reservations at the super cool copper/ brass bar. Nice bartenders! Gave me a taste of a Chardonnay that was really nice.
We also had a platter of oysters to start, which were opened nicely and not mutilated like some places tend to serve oysters. Honestly I don't like my oysters to look previously chewed in the shell as if the shucker was momma bird feeding its baby. 
We didn't have any entrees instead we had a salad that was dressed perfectly, and a manila clam dish and the fresh house cured anchovy small plate. My date is a pescetarian vegetarian so no chicken for two :( BUT FYI, we were able to order the bread salad that comes with the chicken on the side :) It is more delicious than the chicken.
I would recommend this place for a date, it is pretty classy.
author: Suzy M.

description: The gnocchi is the slippery boiled kind as opposed to the chewy sauteed kind that Bouchon serves.
author: Erich V.

description:
The food was ok

But be careful of how they calculate your tip.  I mean, seriously, 2 people spent about $34.XX for lunch, and so, I gave a 17%+ tip and made an even $40 on the receipt.  What do I see on my bill?  $40.XX instead of $40.  Seriously?  You're going to take advantage of all your customers like this?  $1 is not much, but I know, $1 skivvied from every customer does make a difference to you, but seriously, that's wrong.

I recommended this place to a business coworker who takes people out to lunch all the time, but this will be the last time I recommend this place.  I just see no need to be so stingy.
author: Cathy U.

description:
Our first experience was good. We started with oysters, which were wonderfully fresh. We had cranberry bean soup, which was ok. Caesar salad, which was also ok. Fritz were amazing and burger, which was very disappointing. Although we asked for medium, it came more well done and quite dry and lacking flavor.

My second visit there was better: we had steamed clams, cesar salad, frites, and they made pasta for my son (which was so good, my husband and I were eating off his plate).
author: Ali A.

description:
Who waits an hour for roast chicken? When it is from Zuni, I DO! It is really worth the wait. 

So last night we started off the meal with half a dozen oysters ( I forget which ones) there were fresh and tasty, and went so well with our Peroni beers. 

Then we moved to splitting a Cesar salad which was yummy too. We didn't notice how well the spaced the meal so waiting the hour for the chicken went by fast. Plus the location of the restaurant is a perfect place to stare out the window and day dream. 

On to the main event. THE ROAST CHICKEN WITH BREAD SALAD! It lives up to all the hype. The chicken is moist and well seasoned. After eating a couple bits your lips will be lightly coated in the juice from the chicken creating a "chicken lipgloss"...delcious delicious lip gloss! hahahaaha. 

On to dessert. Try the caramel pot de creme. Enough said.

My only grip is that service is on the tad slow side.  Maybe they get so used to trying to fill the time that they forget to come back.  By the end of the evening we just wanted to get the check but it took a while to find our waitress.
author: MOJO X.

description: Service was good and he got us out on time for our show.  Food was less than great and I was disappointed as I've eaten there before but it had been a couple of years and remembered it was much better.  Maybe a bad night?   Not sure.
author: Jeanne K.

description: I haven't been here in 20 years but came because we won a gift certificate at an auction. The food was good and the atmosphere was fun but the place is living off its reputation from long ago. It's totally overrated. very few choices in food and far less amazing than lots of other sf places. how long can you keep charging a ton of money for chicken? It 's just chicken. Oysters were the best part and ra bbit was good. But $250 for 2 for an OK meal? Seriously?
author: Gabriela O.

description:
This has been one of my favorite restaurants for over 20 years. The menu changes daily but I almost always order the fritto misto appetizer. Most of the dishes I've loved most there were daily specials that I've never seen twice, for example grilled pork kidneys skewered with rosemary branches.

Go before 6pm (5pm Sunday) or after 10 for the best burger ever.

The wine list has good values but is currently short of less expensive bottles: cheapest white is $30, cheapest red is $34.
author: Robert L.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF.  Get the chicken, which is enough for 2-3 and worth the wait, and a side of extra bread salad!
author: Jason T.

description:
This place is perfect. Their house burger is amazing, the pizza we had was awesome, and the setting is great. Check it out.

For an inside look at the restaurant check out this video review.
http://freakingdelicious.blogspot.com/2009/04/fd-zuni.html
author: Patrick B.

description:
So I had a blind date with a gay man last night. No no, you're not going crazy. I really did say I had a blind date with a gay man. And boy oh boy was he hot. Like one of the hottest men (gay or straight) that I have ever met. Oh yes. I'm going on too long about my blind date huh? 

Ok, moving on... 

I come in and I am politely greeted. My really hot date hasn't arrived yet, so I grab a spot at the bar and sip my Anchor Steam while I wait for my aforementioned hot date. 

Let's play a game ok? You the reader and me the writer. Let's see how many times I mention my really hot gay blind date.

So I'm drinking my beer and chatting with the bartender. He recently also relocated from NYC, so we chatted about the differences between the two cities and had a laugh. And in walks my really hot date. Before my really hot date arrived though, along with chatting with the bartender, I enjoyed the live music being pumped out of the baby grand piano by the handsome, smiling piano player. 

So me and my really hot date are seated and since he knows this place really well (*cough* he's one of the managers *cough*), I let him do all of the ordering. 

One thing he mentions is that Zuni Cafe is basically the epitome of California dining. Everything on the menu is locally grown, raised, bred, sold, whatever you want to call it. And almost everything on the menu is organic. Another highlight of the Zuni Cafe menu is that it changes D-A-I-L-Y, except for the roasted chicken, which is an every day feature on the menu. 

To start me and my hot date had:

Crostini with duck sugo and wild mushrooms - I am a new found lover of duck, thanks to Ad Hoc's Easter Brunch, and this duck was no exception. It was GREAT! Flavorful, a little salty, nice crunch to the crostini. Just yummmmmy... 

Asparagus with toasted breadcrumbs salsa, chervil and hard cooked egg - The breadcrumb salsa was tangy and had a nice bite to it. The asparagus was lightly cooked, so it was soft, yet still had quite a bit of crunch.

Polenta with parmesan - I grew up in the south where grits was part of my daily menu. I heard that polenta is slightly different, but overall, the closest thing to grits. To me, polenta tastes exactly like grits. I like the parmesan in this dish. Gave it a nice salty flavor. 

Whole wheat spaghetti with puntarelle, garlic, capers, red onions and hot pepper - Seriously, this dish was fuckin awesome! I love capers and until last night, I didn't realize how much I missed eating them. I've never been a big fan of whole wheat pasta, but with all these tangy and spicy spices, this pasta did packed a lot of flavor. (The menu item actually contained tuna confit, but me and my hot date asked to leave off the tuna due to my allergy to fish)

For the main course:

Chicken for two: Brick oven roasted chicken that comes with a warm bread salad with scallions, currants and pine nuts. This dish is roasted fresh and individually, so no over cooked chicken here. This was by far, the best chicken dish that I have ever had, outside of my very own kitchen. It's easy to see why this is an every day menu item. 

For wine, me and my hot date had a slightly chilled Grenache blend from Domaine La Milliere in France. Fragrant, a little spicy and beefy and actually really good with chicken. 

This meal was perfection thanks to my really hot date. ;)
author: Jen D.

description: This is my second review on this place. The place sucks!!! The seats in the first floor is too close. I felt like I was suffocating. And the Risotto was watery, salty, and half raw. Though ,the desert is good, can't dismissed the bad risotto. I have no idea why the good reviews. Anyways, I won't be back.
author: Jenny W.

description:
I suspect this is a 4, but for now it's a 3 given my situation.

I've definitely heard great things of this place.  I was in town for business and walking from the toronado to my hotel when I was presently surprised to stumble across this well know establishiment.  I wasn't starving, but I could eat so I stopped in.  It was late lunch so the options were limited, and I was the only person in th place.

I had the anchovie with parmesan and celery app.  It was good, but nothing all that special.  For my main, I had the burger and a side of fries (I thoug this came with it, but apparently they were an a la carte side that the waitress talked me into without my knowledge...could be a function of my visit to the toronado).  The burger was good but not great.

I'd enjoyed everything, but I reserve more stars for a more fomal dinner.  I have a feeling this is a 4-5, but for now it's a solid 3.
author: Mike R.

description:
All I wanted was arguably the best cheeseburger in the city.  Even though it's 15 dollars.

I used to work near Zuni so I used to grab a burger at lunch every now and again and honestly, that burger is amazing.  Pair that burger with a caesar salad and BOOM, perfect little 28 dollar lunch.  

I hadn't been to Zuni in a long time and I was craving a burger so I made the trip into the city to give it a try.  I was a little disappointed to hear they don't serve burgers between 5 and 10 pm.  Which is fine, but dammit I really wanted a burger.  Had we gone in at 10 or anytime before they close at 11, I could have had a burger, but not at 8:30 when we were there.  It seemed silly and had I been managing that joint last night, I would have made every attempt to accommodate the customer.  After all, it is just a burger, and not an exotic whitefish in low quantity.  

Anyways, I am done griping.  I guess that is my own fault for wanting a burger at a swanky place like this.  We ended up ordering the salmon instead and it was very good.  We were on a tight budget this weekend, so we shared, and the server even asked that our plates be split.  That's a great gesture.  

Zuni is consistently good - service is consistently very good - burgers are consistently AWESOME, between the hours of 11-5 and 10-11.  If you haven't tried a burger, go for it, man.  It will be the best 15 dollar burger you will ever have and I am being serious.
author: Sean O.

description:
I've frequented Zuni a few times before I returned for brunch yesterday, and I hate to say it, but it's really gone downhill in my book....

To begin, our server was nice but quirky.  He popped up at random times and was really quiet.  While I can't stand it when the waiter ruins your meal by becoming a permanent fixture at your table by talking your ear off, I would have preferred a little more face time with ours so that he could help explain the menu to us a bit.  Things like "lonza" and "garganelli" and "garlic chapons" aren't necessarily a part of my daily jargon.  It felt like Zuni was trying too hard and they just came off as being pretentious.

While the food was decent, it wasn't great or anything spectacular, and the portions were TEENSY WEENSY - for a fifteen-dollar egg scramble, I expect a damn delicious scramble that will leave me satisfied, but alas I was not.  My fried eggs were ok but, again, not anything noteworthy, and the fennel sausage that came on the side was not hot, and if you know me, I find any sausage less than piping hot unacceptable.  The bread was the saving grace of the meal because without it, we would have left hungry.  

We started with the house-cured anchovies with celery, nicoise olives, and parmesan, and while this was tasty, one could hardly call this a dish.  Yes, I realize it was an app, but there were literally 4 thin slices of cheese, 5 tiny anchovies, and celery slices the size of my pinky nail...This thing was $8??

To end, we had the Piccola Meringata - this was delicious.  The light merengue discs atop fluffy creme fraiche, huckleberry sauce, and candied tangerine bits is not to be missed.  I also really love the atmosphere and the open, airy feel to Zuni.  Great use of the space.

Unfortunately, the dessert and design of the restaurant don't completely redeem Zuni, so I probably won't be coming back until I've tried every other fabulous brunch spot in the city!
author: Kira K.

description:
Only in SF (or possibly NYC) can you go out for a late lunch consisting of a couple of burgers, 2 iced teas and a shared order of fries and pay $48. We had to laugh... even though, OUCH, that hurt.

It took us over a year to get to that burger at Zuni that came so highly recommended as a top contender for SF's finest beef. Problem with Zuni is they only serve their burger at lunch or after 10pm. Being the geriatric peeps we seem to be these days as well as not sharing a lunch hour any day of the week, the hubby and I took months and months to get this burger tried out.

But alas it finally did happen. And this burger was delicious. It was top quality, it was finely made... 

Couple of issues... First? It was definitely on the wrong bread - focaccia. Um, no, that is just wrong. Focaccia does not make a good burger bun no matter how fancy pants your burger is. Also, the burgers were ordered medium and came to the table oozing red juice and were red in the middle, not pink but red. When we pointed it out our server told us that is their "version" of medium. Since when is this Argentina? Rare, medium-rare, medium and well done are universal terms in the food industry and I don't appreciate that term being twisted around unnecessarily.

After sending them back to finish them a bit more they arrived cooked perfectly but unfortunately the cook had forgotten the garlic aioli on the bottom bun (as he had re-bunned us after the first ones were soaked through with meat drippings). So now we needed to ask for more aioli. It was almost starting to get comical but then the rest of the meal just started to flow. Great burger despite the lame bun. Fries - pomme frites - whatever... were out of this world. Thank God we had those to chow down on while the burger fiasco was unfolding. 

It was all good in the end though. If you want to consider a $50 burger lunch "good"...

 I love the interior feel of Zuni like it was my own home but better. It's so warm and welcoming inside, and service was top notch. It's pretty damn pricy though. We'll be back when we're feeling rich again to try the roast chicken.
author: margot b.

description:
Temporary Boycott.

Zuni could have been the prized and archetypal restaurant of downtown San Francisco. But they failed miserably, thanks to the haughty and childish demeanor of many of its staff. A well-known verdict in the food scene around the Bay: Zuni's staff is littered with undeserving, pretentious snobs who taint the otherwise impressive menu that is served here.

My friends and I do not enter this restaurant to be smeared with cliquish behavior. I come to enjoy the food, particulary the vast oyster menu. But twice in 2007, my dinner mates and I got the smear, and finally today, yet another bad experience set me off to discuss the matter with the co-owner, Mr. Pilgram. 

The first time, our arrogant and inattentive waitress blew it at the table, and after I posted a Yelp review, she sent me a nasty message, only compounding the situation. I mentioned this to a host by the name of Ren, yet he did nothing about my compaint (of course you shouldn't bother complaining to hosts, since they just do not give a shit). 

Our second experience wasn't much better. Though our salads and soups were hearty and comforting, again the waiter (David) was NOT. He wore a cold scowl that made the flowers wilt at our table, and he never changed that empty face. My dinner mate whispered to me several times, "So what's his problem, are they all like that?" This was my boss, and I was embarrassed for even recommending that we eat here. I decided to boycott the restaurant after this and to not return until Zuni lost over $3,000 of my business. 

Finally, a third incident today is what prompted me to speak to Mr. Pilgram directly.
