The incident happened as I was walking by the glass-walled restaurant, as I must do at least once per day (I walk straight down Market St. to do business downtown).  As I passed, I noticed that the same waiter from the second experience (David) and the host (Ren) were both there.  This "David" guy quickly drifted over to Ren, and David uttered something to him not realizing that one of the big glass-wall windows was open.  "Your nemesis is walking by," and Ren turned around and glared at me, responding to David with a childish insult. 

That was it. It was time that the co-owners of Zuni did something about this unprofessional and ridiculous conduct that erodes Zuni's image (and their bottom line). I immediately called the place and asked to speak with a general manager. Of course, the host was reluctant, so I had to specifically tell him that I want to speak with Mr. Pilgram or Ms. Rodgers NOW.  

I spoke to Mr. Pilgram, mentioning the slew of bad experiences with Zuni staff. I also mentioned that it's unfortunate since I really enjoy the food. Mr. Pilgram impressed me. He was very attentive and listened to my whole complaint, after which he apologized and promised to rectify this mess. It was apparent to me that he has fielded many such complaints about his staff, and I bet he's sick of having to deal with such childish employees. But I ended the call thinking that Zuni may be able to redeem itself, however the atonement process will be a rather slow one.  

Over the last 18 months, since my friends and I no longer give Zuni our business, and since I discourage everyone from sinking money into this place, the revenue that Zuni has lost has topped $8,000 at the very least, thanks to this staff conduct. It is unfortunate that Ren and David choose such a spunky and childish path while trying to move ahead in restaurant management. Their presence will taint any restaurant who hires them, until they learn to improve their character and take their careers more seriously. They can learn plenty of this from Mr. Pilgram. 

It will now be interesting to see what everyone mentioned above does to resolve this blemish. So far, Ren and David are reacting just as I expected... like arrogant brats, which only makes everything worse for them. I have also received two offensive emails from their messed-up bipolar friend, Andrew L.  At this rate, the mess they created here will follow them wherever they go. Yes, through all this snot-rag behavior, they forgot just how small the world can be...
 
* The preceding is my personal opinion, protected by California's anti-SLAPP statute, Code of Civil Procedure 425.1
author: Daniel C.

description:
Zuni is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  And by "one of my favorites" I really mean "one of my two or three favorites" by which I really mean "Zuni is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco."

I just don't want the place to get a big head.

Great food, great service, great wine list, great decor, comfy seating, and this was the first time in a long time I ate something other than the burger (I had the halibut, to be precise, among other things . . . .)

I heart Zuni.  I really do!  :-*
author: Joe C.

description: If a restaurant survives and gets high traffic in this particular neighborhood, you better believe the food is fantastic. Not a single complaint on the food, and it may be one of the best brunch places in the city. We had a ledge seat, facing a wall. Nwho needs a view with this food?
author: Ichor B.

description: Great service. Food was good, but the chicken everyone raves about is still just good roasted chicken. Comforting, but nothing out of this world.
author: Dana L.

description:
4.5 stars.

When you dine at *the* quintessential SF restaurant there are bound to be expectations. I've been breezing through Zuni's doors since '94, and I've learned that even with the loveliest of the lovely, most popular-for-a-reason restaurants that are "institutions" in SF, you need to check your expectations at the door... especially when it comes to service.

With that said, we had a *really* nice server who gave us great suggestions and took good care of us... despite his apparent busy-ness which resulted in some lag-time in service here and there. Admittedly, in the past, I've had some pretty crappy service at Zuni, so our guy was super great!

But you don't go to Zuni for service. You go for the beautiful high-ceilings, the warm brick walls and natural lighting, the fine and elegant wine list, the fantastic open kitchen and standing-room-only bar, the pianist tickling the ivories. Fabulousness galore!

You *stay* at Zuni for the food. 

Oh, and the bloody mary's, but that's for another time.

Case in point, yesterday was my birthday, so a friend brought me in for a late afternoon glass of champagne... Being seduced by Zuni's ambiance (& the gorgeous bubbles!) I thought, why not stay for dinner! So after checking with the hosts to see about a table (something fabulous, please!), then confirming with the BF that it was okay with him (he reminded me that it *was* my b-day, so of course!), dinner was on.

Our table was cozy and by a window at the top of the stairs. Just as fabulous as I'd requested, plus perfect for, um, you know, sharing food. (Among other things *wink*)

We started with a dozen freshly-shucked oysters (and some little periwinkle-snail things that, unless they're drowning in butter and garlic, I ain't eatin' 'em!). The miyagi's were by far the best, though all were amazing!

For the next course, we opted for a simple spaghetti with butter, lemon zest, crushed red peppers, and a green that could have been either from the onion family, or the kelp family. *shrug* I don't know, but whatever it was, it was delicious... the pasta perfectly al dente, and they were kind enough to spit the dish for us. 

As for the entree, we ordered the chicken. So, I've been making that "Zuni chicken" forever, but have never actually had it there. Be sure to order it as soon as you know you want it, as it takes an hour to roast... and is completely well-worth it!

Succulent roasted chicken (my favorite comfort food!) a-top a bread salad of red-leaf lettuce (or was it a baby romaine?) with big chunks of crunchy bread, tossed in a red-wine vinaigrette with toasted pine nuts and currants. A whole chicken. Roasted to perfection. For two!

There were no left overs. We were stuffed and opted out on dessert... boy! were we happy! A perfect way to spend my birthday with my favorite fella, eating my favorite food!

Yesterday was definitely proof that you go to Zuni for _____ (insert something fabulous) but you stay for the food.
author: Tiffinie T.

description:
I found myself at Zuni recently because it was super late and Lime shut down their kitchen early (Ugh! Lime, why do you do that to me?! You are promise to serve food until "at least midnight 7 days a week".  You really have to work on follow through Lime.) At first I was just grateful that someone was going to feed me at 11:30pm but then I starting looking around and taking it all in.

So this is Zuni? Really?  The place so many people are crazy about?  
Ummmm....... I don't get it.  

Seriously, its drafty,  the lighting is bad, the colors used in the decor are not nice either      and don't even get me started on the worn pleather seating.  

The menu was not inspiring. Not. At. All.  I had trouble finding something I wanted despite how hungry I was.  So I order a bunch of things.  I didn't eat more than 25% of any of the plates that came out.  Really, the dishes were that insipid.

I consoled myself with the thought of the fries.  Everyone raves about these fries, right? I love fries.  At least I will get some good fries out of this experience.

The fries finally came after all the other plates and.......  Really?  
These are the fries that people say they like better than the fries at Absinthe or Oola?  Really?
Look, I love fries.  All kinds of fries.  I like haystack fries.  (ooooh, Tom Douglas's Dahlia Lounge in Seattle makes some haystack fries that are heavenly. I miss those fries. I really I miss those fries).
I don't know if I ever meet a serving of fries I didn't find at least somewhat appealing and tasty (including Ore Ida frozen fries) but these things.....   Sigh.   

Not so impressed with the whole Zuni thing.

So why did I give it 3 stars and not 2?  The staff was great.  Really great.
From my (admittedly limited) experience I figure the food and atmosphere is worth about 1.5 stars and the staff is worth another 1.5.
author: lisa g.

description:
"Lovely. Ecstatic. Invigorating" said Stanley K of Yelp.

Came here after a few wine from the Hotel Biron. The company was astonishing and beautiful. The food was impeccable. The service was to the tee. The wait for the bathroom was my only complaint. Only one men stall.

To start the dinner, we had a Caesar salad, followed by the ricotta gnocchi ,and finish with the crepe dessert. The crepe could of been warm instead it was cold, the marmalade was thinly spread and scarce. 

My only wish was that, whenever anyone has the final bite, it should be the one that makes the "mmmm" sound, I didn't make the "mmmm" sound. Too bad.
author: Stanley K.

description:
Like Jimi Hendrix said to the usher at the Filmore. "Living in the Past!!" 
I guess when you have a bunch of old reliables you can treat the newbies like @$%@Q&*. 
I may not look like the typical Zuni Grill customer but my cash is green. They wont get any more. 
I had Oysters and one of them was STINKY STINKY. I told the server and asked him to smell it if he liked. He didn't offer to remove or replace it and then billed me for it. 
I guess someone told him they were the only place in town. 
NOT!!
author: Manuel G.

description:
There's nothing that makes me feel better about life than getting really dressed up and spending a lot of money on food and drinks. Zuni is definitely the place to blow a hole in your wallet. 

The decor has a few nice touches. The irregular stairs leading to the upper seating area are charming, although tricky once you've had a few cocktails. NOTE: You'll need to have a few, the size of one cocktail here equates 1/2 of a normal drink for twice the price. 

The building is at the corner of a triangular block (think flatiron building) and has windows surrounding the exterior of the building. The integration of exposed steel support columns and wood make this place look industrial and expensive. I really liked the view into the kitchen from the back of the upper dinning room. Really nothing like watching your food being made. 

The eats were YUMMY... 

House-cured anchovies with celery, Parmesan, and niçoise olives Really fresh anchovies. The Parmesan was nicely sliced and really tasty. 

Zuni Caesar salad. Crisp and flavorful. Although usually I consider croutons to be carb bombs, I had 3. MMMm 

Bellwether Farms ricotta gnocchi with Brussels sprouts, sage, and fresh walnuts. One of the best gnocchi dishes I've ever had. The gnocchi melted in my mouth. 

Quail Entree... DEeeee-Lious 

Although the drinks are small, they are well made. I really recommend getting a bottle of wine since Zuni does have a great listing. We ordered a bottle of the Paolo Scavino Barbera d'Alba Piedmont which was one of the best wines I've had this year. 

The deserts were also really freggin great as well as the Grappa I had ;the Moscato di Poli Veneto. 


We ended up being at Zuni for a little over 2 hours and really had a blast. Definitely worth trying out, but be prepared... It ain't cheap.
author: Mister G.

description: Good option for brunch ( just don't bring a huge appetite --or  be a Russian bodybuilder--portions tend to be a bit teensy). Perfect for me, not so much for the still hungry fella beside me.MUST TRY ITEMS: WOLF RANCH QUAIL( menu choices  routinely gets updated)
author: aj s.

description:
It astonishes me that folks would stick to the chicken at this restaurant. The menu changes, and many of the dishes influenced by southwest France cooking are superb. I've been going to Zuni since 1980 (in the beginning) and there are occasional bumps in the road, but it is incredibly consistent.
The Fries, the chocolate cate, the Ceasar salad, anything with aioli, anything new it is all good!  I've had the chicken once, and couldn't figure out why everyone ordered the chicken until I saw these reviews.  Lighten up folks and expand--you are missing very good cooking.
author: maria B.

description: Slow Service we entered at 9 pm and left at 10:48pm all we had was just an app and one entree. It took them so long to bring food. And the food had no taste what so every.a big waste of time. Also we had to bring our check to the desk. For what we paid I would expect the best
author: Joseph S.

description:
I can't believe I haven't reviewed Zuni before.  WTF is wrong with me?  Ok, don't answer that.

Saturday was the perfect day to gather some friends at Zuni for some bloody mary's and burgers.  First things first, the bloody mary's kick ass but the straws that come with it are a joke.  They are cool looking as all hell and biodegradable, good for the environment, blah blah blah.  Our problem was that they would fall apart after a couple of good sips.  We even had to ask for extra straws at one point.  So Zuni, get some new straws.

On to the burgers...at Zuni you're paying $13 for a burger plus another $1.75 for cheese, onions, etc.  Is it worth it?  Hell yeah.  I ordered my burger MR and it looked a bit overcooked to me but when I bit into it it was moist and juicy and perfectly seasoned.  The homemade focaccia buns were fantastic as well.  Fries aren't included but one side order ($6) was enough to feed the four of us (although we did lick the plate clean.  I'm not naming names but I could)

Four solid stars.  Prices are a tad high and our pre burger oysters were just ok (at $2.75 a pop they should be fantastic)  Plus the straws suck (or don't suck)

Word to the wise-if you are going to Zuni for a burger they only serve them at lunch time or after 10pm.
author: phil h.

description:
Those five stars are for the burger. The BEST damn burger I have ever had in my life. It's organic beef on a foccacia bread bun, served only at lunch and on the late night menu. Juiciest, most flavorful thing in a bun you'll ever sink your teeth into (get your mind out of the gutter already). Get it with a pile of shoestring fries, a beer or a tasty cocktail from the awesome bartender downstairs (we were tucked away in a little nook upstairs...I loved the space!) 

You will not be disappointed!
author: Virg Y.

description:
This review was inspired by a recent email from an old flame. I will do my best to not spit, vomit, or break things in the process of 4-starring this fine establishment, but if you knew the jerk, you'd understand if I couldn't help myself. 

Much like the jerk who inspired this review, Zuni comes off as polished, laid-back, and refined all at the same time. Unlike said man (and I use that term loosely), Zuni manages to consistently be all of those things and more. The other main difference between Zuni and the jerk is that while both claim to offer delicious food fresh from their kitchens, only Zuni actually comes through (stick with the burger and the caesar salad if you're not sure what to get). Also, Zuni won't talk about other girls it wants to bang while you're having dinner and once you make a reservation at Zuni, Zuni won't cancel on you OVER and OVER again only to come crawling back for YEARS ON END. Oh! And Zuni doesn't fib or tell you lies because "it sounded good at the time". What you see is what you get (yet another marked difference between Zuni and jerk).

So yeah, try Zuni. Unfortunately, it's just one more awesome SF establishment that's been ruined for me by some peter-pan-syndrome afflicted douche who's too old for me anyway. Like I said- the burgers and the ceasars are tops- eat up!
author: Autumn K.

description:
Jumping on the band wagon, the roast chicken and bread salad is easily one of my favorite meals in the city.  The chicken is perfectly roasted, with the lovely crackly skin and fall of the bone meat.  Bread salad with that vinegary tang that is just so perfect with the chicken.  Mmm salivating just thinking about it.  

Service is friendly and attentive.  Love the light airy interior, the large windows looking out onto Market make for amazing people watching.   Pricey yes, but it's an indulgence I was more than happy to pay for.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Frances L.

description:
So... given that there are over 700 reviews for Zuni at this point, It's not really necessary to wax poetic on the quality of the food, the heavenly wine, the deep roots of the long-standing Ultimate San Franciscan Dining Experience or any of that crap.  

This is a wonderful restaurant, and that's not news to anyone.  Big friggin whoop.  There are like, 6 million 5-star reviews and a famous cookbook.  

What I think is really special about Zuni is not just the food (which is wonderful), but the service, the wine, the atmosphere, and the fact that the people who work here REALLY seem to care about meeting the expectaions set forth by all of those 5-star reviews and the cookbook fame.  

For the BF's 29th, we were seated in a little tucked-away room on the second floor, which was really cool-- it was like eating in someone's bustly little dining room.  Our waiter (Nathan?  Nathaniel?) was really excited to tell us all about his favortie dishes, which is something that I always appreciate:  I'm not shelling out this kind of dough on a regular basis, so I don't want to order the wrong thing.  He steered us in the perfect direction:  oysters, ceasar, chicken.  He hooked us up with a divine bottle of reasonably priced zinfandel, and poof!  GREAT dinner.

If you've gone here and been non-plussed, go again.  Sit in Nathan-or-Nathaniel's section, and let him drive.  I promise you'll be happy.
author: Laura F.

description:
For years I have enjoyed the sleek decor, beautiful upscale crowd, effortlessly professional service, and impenetrable food lover's menu.

But until last night I had never really been to Zuni.  

There are two things you can order.  There is everything else, and there is chicken for two.  Zuni serves the definitive chicken.

Is it brined?  Yes, like a shaker has salt.  Crisp?  Yes, burnt as the sun is warm.  Moist?  Flesh oozes like a rotting pumpkin.  Eight clean-cleaved pieces mounded over pan-fried herbed bread with olive oil, tangy vinegar, currants and a sage-like spice I cannot identify but associate with the most rustic restaurants of Napa Valley, roast for an hour in a clay pot in a thousand degree oven until the chicken becomes a museum piece and the bread stuffing is better than Grandma's Thanksgiving.  You cannot possibly recreate this in your home.  Never.  Forget it.  Only for the Zuni chicken pilgrim.

Generous too.  Everyone who orders takes half home.

The balsamic bloody Mary is a surprise standout.  It's on the dinner menu (for goodness sake!) and they know what they're doing.  It is the perfect accompaniment to one of their three very vinegary salads.  The Caesar here is stupid good, and to sip a crunchy fresh veggie bloody Mary while munching hot homemade garlic croutons and fresh shaved parmesan and crispy local romaine?  Heaven.
author: Gil S.

description:
Beef tenderloin salad - 13.75
chocolate pot de creme - 8.25
The rest of the meal - God knows how much

Lunch on your dad who you haven't seen since June - Priceless (and price free)

I really don't care how food whore this makes me. Lunch with the 'rents is the best thing EVAR.
author: Alexis B.

description:
Being Canadian one thing that still blows my mind about the US is that you can order burgers medium rare.  I think America is the only place where you can order a bloody piece of highly processed meat.

My last experience at Zuni cafe reminded me of this.  I ordered the burger because I was too late at ordering the roast chicken (which I hear is pretty awesome).  The burger arrive with a healthy amount of fries on the side.  It also arrived bloody as hell for medium rare.  But after diving into it I have to say its was a pretty awesome damn burger.

The service is great.  The atmosphere is wicked.  The neighborhood is crap (what do you expect for something on Market) and I'm generally fearful of my life when the leave the restaurant.  But otherwise I would highly recommend this place to anybody.
author: Peter C.

description:
This place is lovely, but if your famished and want large portions then keep walking. The plates are served with the idea that quality trumps quantity. It's a great place to meet someone for a quick bite or brief meeting; upstairs there are tables if you're rolling as a larger group.

Menus change through out the day and from time to time so what you see on the website might not be what available on the day. Worth checking out at least once - take some one special or someone that you'd like to become special ;-)
author: Ross s.

description:
I'd like to write a review about the food here, as the other reviews seem to indicate that it is pretty good.  However, my customer service was so bad that  I won't be able to comment on their food.  

So, to be brief: a friend calls me Sunday to arrange a brunch with two other friends.  He suggests Zuni, says he will call them about a reservation and let me know.  Two seconds later he calls me back and tells me they they aren't doing reservations at the moment and that she said to come on in and we should be able get a table immediately.  Pleasantly surprised, we settle on brunch at Zuni.

Five minutes after that, I arrive at Zuni with a friend and approach the hostess about seating.  She tells us it will be an hour and a half before we will be able to get a table for four.

"An hour and a half?"
"Yes, we're very busy."
"My friend just called here and said that we should be able to get seats immediately.  What is that about?"
"Oh well, we do have a bar seating area where customers can seat themselves", she said, gesturing toward a tiny mosh pit with no available seating (especially for a group of four).

I decide to wait a minute to see if my friend can show up and clear things up.  Not two seconds later an affluent looking MILF steps in and asks about getting a table.  The hostess tells her it will be THIRTY minutes before she can get a table.

Ok!  It's like that!

To be perfectly clear, I am not awarding one star because brunch was busy at Zuni on Sunday.  I *expected* that.

Zuni gets one half star for playing the bait-and-switch on the phone.  The other half star is for giving me a bullshit estimate on the wait time to DISCOURAGE me from eating there. 

Mission accomplished Zuni.  I am discouraged.  

The only thing positive about this experience was that it took me about 7 minutes to figure out that I will never ever be dining there.

Goodbye, Zuni.
author: joe b.

description:
I understand why Zuni's roast chicken for 2 is a defined standard.  When chowhounders talk about the difference in texture and flavor -- they aren't hyping it up.
Succulent, aromatic, juicy, thoroughly flavorful from skin to bone, paired with a bed of broken crusty bread soaked with the delicious chicken juice, light frisee, sprinkled with raisins and pine nuts.  the combination is perfect.  Well worth the 1 hr wait (which is why you see everyone just sitting there waiting for their chicken -- low turnover = long waits, explaining difficult weekend opentable ressie).  So if you want the inside kitchen info...
the wood oven has room for only 17 chickens...each chicken takes exactly 40 min to roast, they are salted 24 hrs ahead of time and have marjarom and thyme under the skin.
all there is to talk about is the chicken!
author: Rob C.

description: Need to come back to try the roast chicken! Otherwise good oysters! Yum! Fresh!
author: Sophie L.

description:
I had a lovely ladies' brunch here yesterday. It was a particularly warm day in the city, so it was a little stuffy in the loft where we were seated. We had a nice view of the restaurant below and the live piano was actually really pleasant. I was surprised that it didn't feel like we were at a cheesy piano bar or in a Nordstrom at all. 

I ordered the fried eggs with hanger steak, which was good, but my dish was doused in extra olive oil. Instead of getting grossed out by it, I dabbed bread in it, along with the runny eggs. It was pretty good! We all shared a caesar salad, which was very good. 

I'd like to go back and try their famous roasted chicken for two and see if it's worth the hour wait!
author: Connie C.

description:
Wow is this place pretentious or what? So we went here for my mother's birthday. It was my mom's parents, my parents, my sister and myself. We get here about 5:20pm and the host takes our name. Um ok this place is empty downstairs and empty upstairs, yet we still wait 15 minutes for a table. Ok fine. We are seated on a  cushioned bench and hard wooden chairs. I would have loved a back to my seat during dinner but I gave the chairs with backs to my parents and grandparents, while I took the cushioned bench.

We are given paper menu's and we see that there are only four entrees on the menu. We are then told that this is the "late lunch" menu and the dinner menu doesn't start until 6. We ask for a copy of the dinner menu seeing that it is already 5:40pm and by the time we get our food it will be 6. Their response is that it isn't printed yet. 

Whadafuxup with that. Ok whatever.

The waittress comes to our table with no hospitality whatsoever. We get bread and butter with no individual plates to put the bread on. I guess we'll eat off the butcher paper you have over the tablecloth? She then takes our drink order and returns 5 minutes later for our "late lunch order" without our drinks. So we order our food: 4 burgers, pork chops and my grandfather got polenta. He asked for marinara sauce on his polenta and the waittress gives him a hard time. He's an 80 year old WWII and he wants some marinara sauce on his polenta and she says that she can't do it? You guys make pizza with marinara sauce, why can't you put a scoop of sauce on top of his polenta? That made me upset that they couldn't alter their "sacred paper menus" for my grandfather's simple request.  

Anyways after our order we get our drinks and our food comes. The burger's were ok except for the fact that my father and I ordered ours medium and they came well done. If your cooks can't cook a burger correctly, why are they in the kitchen? My grandfather's polenta did come with a scoop of marinara sauce on top, which is the sole reason for the one star (other than the fact that you can't give 0 stars on yelp). My mom also said that she liked her pork chops. We received our check and quickly left. We didn't get the chicked because we didn't want to be in the restaurant any longer than we had to.

Now I don't mind shelling out a good amount of money for dinner but I do expect to get quality service in return. I can cook a hamburger at my house. I can also make polenta and pork chops. I go out to eat for the service, experience and ambiance. Zuni lacked all of this. I expected much more than I received. I will not pay to go to Zuni again. This was the worst experience I ever had in a restaurant, I've had worse food before but overall I was uncomfortable and couldn't wait to get out of the restaurant.

Also I was amazed by the amount of people that worked there. It seemed they had a lot of bussers and servers. Also all of the staff seemed uptight and stale. They all seemed to hate their job and just were there for the money, not because they enjoyed their jobs. I work in the foodservice industry and even if you feel like crap that day, you have to put a smile on your face when you go to work and serve your customers.
author: D J.

description:
Tickets for Avenue Q in hand, dining at Zuni Cafe prior to an 8am curtain call at the Orpheum theater was the BEST IDEA EVER.    For two reasons:

1) Although it was a friday night, we were able to walk in and be seated without reservations because we arrived just prior to 6pm.  The kitchen doesn't even open until 6:30pm or something.  

2) The food and service were very good and I left fully satisfied.

To expand upon reason #1, I have to also add that we were seated in one of the tables for two that face the open kitchen.  We had a great view of the giant wood burning oven and various plating stations.   Even though we were seated right next to that gigantic fireplace/oven, we could not feel the heat from it at all which was awesome.  Not awesome was salivating while watching half a dozen roasted chickens come out of it that weren't mine.

What we ordered:   The famous roasted chicken, polenta with parmesan, a dozen assorted oysters, a cosmo, and a mojito.   

The chicken was well seasoned, it tasted like they had brined the shit out of it which is exactly the way I like it.  The bread salad with pine nuts and currants that accompanied it was inspiring, I am going to make my own version at home.  The polenta was good, although they skimped on the cheese.  The oysters were amazing and fresh.  The cocktails were tasty but small considering they were $10 each and mostly ice.  Eff you, bartender.  I can get 3 times the booze for $10 at Martunis up the street!

Food:    I spent a lot of money on simple rustic food that would have cost me far less to make at home.    Unfortunately, although I can't complain about the food, I feel that the cost isn't justified.   $41 for a small roasted chicken!    Ok, maybe I'm just cheap.  But for $41, I want that chicken stuffed with an octopus and truffles and gold or something.  

Drinks:  Good, but if you are on a budget I would suggest skipping the skimpy drinks and splurge on a nice wine or raw oysters instead.

Service:  I had great friendly and efficient service!  Love that we were able to be seated without reservations.  The person who served us last friday night was Evyn.  She rocked.

Ambience:  Try to get a seat facing the kitchen if you are at all interested in how your food is prepared.  It's fascinating and gives you and your date something to talk about.
author: Courtney Y.

description: The person in our group who liked it the most said "if I lived here I wouldn't go back". There is no reason you should waste your time or money at a place like this in a town with so many good restaurants. One of those places that thinks its soooo much more special than it is. An hour wait for a table when we had a reservation and we watched it "being set up" for 45 minutes. The waiter just reiterated the menu, the entire menu, when we asked him for what was good. Food was mediocre. If u screw up polenta u have real problems. The 1-hour chicken for 2 was good, nothing to justify the hype. A group of 5 and not one of us liked this place. One dinner I will never get back.
author: Benny K.

description:
Gnocchi like no other, but in a good way.  Imagine Peeps, but without the pink and yellow food coloring and made of smooth ricotta.  Smother it in the most perfect lemon-y butter-y sauce, and serve it piping hot.  Now that's culinary genius accompanied by flawless execution.   I would go to Zuni cafe and dine alone at the bar just so I could order it again.

5 stars!
author: Audrey T.

description:
We went here last night after making reservations, and were seated relatively quickly.  After being seated, the waiter came by asking us if we wanted wine and gave us some suggestions based on what type of wine we liked.  A few minutes later, the server (not the waiter) brought us some bread. I asked the server for some balsamic vinegar. Before I was able to finish my sentence, he quickly turned around and walked away.  Personally, I thought he had an attitude or some "air" about him.  My partner thought he had a language barrier, and didn't understand my request. If someone truly didn't understand a customer's request, he should ask the customer to repeat the request, and most certainly should not walk away.  We noticed that the server was walking around the restaurant helping others, and not returning to our table. We assumed he forgot about us.  Eventually, the waiter brought us some vinegar.

The food itself was just ok. I ordered the fennel sausage and polenta entree, which was small in portion and not nearly hot enough.  My partner and friend thought their food was just average as well.  After our food came, the waiter barely came back to our table to check in or to see if we needed anything else.  Coincidentally, my friend knew the people sitting at the table next to us. After dinner, we all chatted and agreed that the food was average and service was poor.  In fact, one of them had the same dish I ordered, and felt the same way.  We also felt the menu was very limited.

Based on a good experience I had when I last came a few years ago, I feel this restaurant has gone downhil.  For the price that this restaurant charges, I expected much more in terms of food quality and level of service.  I am more than happy to pay higher prices that warrant it, and this is certainly not the case with Zuni.
author: E H.

description:
We've frequented Zuni for at least 15, maybe 20 years. Is that possible? Yikes! And for me it feels like a soft, comfy, favorite t-shirt. Something that is so dependable and good that one would never consider getting rid of it. 

The food at Zuni is both as well as fresh and creative with superior quality. It doesn't matter which 'food mood' we're into, Zuni fits the bill.

And their space is so Santa Fe meets New York loft, I always feel optimistic eating there. I hate oppressive restaurants.

Peace and good eating!
author: Usay A.

description: Holy roasted half chicken!! and the bread salad yum! I don't need to go into much details because you're just going to find out yourself :) Overall it's pretty good experience at the zuni consider my friend and I waited for 10 mins with a last minute decision to come to zuni. It was packed. I especially love the lofty design of the restaurant I feel like I'm at someone's house for dinner. Service was lacking and the servers looked hella busy and gone half the time. Oh I can understand because it's service industry. Server was pretty knowledgeable and nice so I will take that over some snotty server who's using big vocabs and a fake European accent hehe
author: Chingy W.

description:
It's been years since I have been schooled. YEARS!

It was my birthday, so a few days before  I reserve. a table for 8. The morning of, some people say they can attend. I call ahead and change it to 12. 16 show up. 

The hostess was pissed. She actually pulled me aside and schooled me. This is unacceptable, we can't provide adequate service, etc. Yes, yes, I know. But people don't RSVP anymore! I slip her a Grant to procure more chairs and my entire party is allowed to stay. 

We weren't an easy party. Some people just ordered oysters, some ordered a full three courses. Others would get up, leave and change seats. But our server (blondish brown haired guy with facial hair) was incredible. All smiles, knew the oyster list, never appeared impatient towards us. Honestly, I should have slipped him the fifty. 

For the most part. Zuni was incredibly gracious. The bloody mary's were excellent, as were the oysters. But this review is mainly about the service, and they definitely did their best to make the most of a less than ideal situation.
author: Leslie Ann R.

description:
I have been eating at Zuni for at least a decade and it is awesome every time. I am one of those people who tries something and if it is good will consistently order it and Zuni is no exception. Their chicken is AMAZING and besides enchiladas, I NEVER order chicken at restaurants.  My go to meal which has yet to disappoint starts with oysters (always a fresh selection), caesar salad, and then the chicken. Be prepared because the love that goes into making this chicken delicious takes an hour...but is well worth the wait. It is served on a bed of bred croutons that have soaked up all of the spices and juices of the whole chicken and then toped with a little friese. 

Not only is the food always good but the ambiance is great for any occasion. It is clean with one side of the restaurant all windows. There is an upstairs which is a little quieter but I prefer downstairs. The tables are a little small as the restaurant is not huge and you should definitely make reservations.
author: Ahna B.

description:
If one thing is amazing and everything else is very good, that's five stars to me. 

And my friend's french toast, with perfectly carmelized in-season plums, was to-die-for.

The burger was very good, although nothing amazing.

Sadly, the latter is in the Zuni Cafe cookbook but not the former.
author: Mark A.

description:
I second Peter G. (I may or may not be his actual girlfriend).

I had a wonderful experience at Zuni Cafe!!!

The wine (by the glass - Cabernet blend) was phenomenal.  The service was perfect (if not a little over-vigilant).  The food was plentiful, well-seasoned (but not in the show-off way some SF restaurants do...) and just plain delicious.

I NEVER order chicken in restaurants, but it's the MUST HAVE at Zuni.  I have dreams about the bread salad with currants.  The polenta with marscapone and parmesan cheese was delicious, but not necessarily a must-order.  The gnocchi with butternut squash was like mini egg-souffle "pillows of perfection" (to quote a dear friend).

I give it 4, rather than 5, because the restaurant wasn't full when we were eating there and my party was put at a table without a view.

I'll be back : )
author: Elizabeth H.

description: An SF institution I don't quite get.  It's a bright, sunny place for lunch and they have a great bar, but I thought the food and price didn't compare to the hype.   Haven't tried the burger, so maybe there's a revision in my future.
author: P J.

description: The luckiest homeless man alive was sitting outside Zuni when I gave him my left over roast chicken with bread salad.
author: Jenny R.

description:
We love Zuni Cafe but can really only comment on their whole roasted chicken with frisee,  toasted bread, currents, and pine nuts in a vinaigrette ($48) ... we get it every time.  But while we wait the hour for the chicken to be cooked, we usually try some other dishes.  This time we had their shoestring fries ($6) and a persimmon and shaved fennel salad ($8).  The fries were nice and crisp but a little over salted ... but we still ate the whole plate.  The salad was fresh, delicate, and a nice balance of flavors.  In the past we've had other salads, soup, polenta, and desserts but the true star, the dish that makes our taste buds do the happy dance, is the roasted chicken.  

Service is usually average.  They do all the right things - knowledgeable about ingredients, polite, ask how your dish is, refill water, etc, but it always seems a little cold.  Otherwise, we like the feel of the restaurant, the casual environment, great food, and reasonable prices.  It was a bit cold last night - every time the doors opened a chilly draft would sweep through the restaurant so bring a sweater.  But we still love coming here, especially before going to see a show.
author: Laura F.

description: This is the perfect San Francisco restaurant.  Elegant and casual at the same time. Excellent French wines. Understated yet always present service. The chicken is heaven.  It is the best way to spend a Sunday afternoon...  We get there a couple times a year usually the day before we head home, always looking forward to being there.
author: Mike T.

description:
I enjoyed Zuni...
Great wine and appitiziers with great company...
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
LULU'S CHICKEN IS BY FAR SUPERIOR.

'nuff said, but ill continue.

zuni is not a bad place.  youre not going to get a bad meal there.  but you will be overpaying for boring, unoriginal, unimaginative, underwhelming and overrated food.  and the decor and atmosphere dont overcome the foods weaknesses.  nice staff though.  some tasty dishes, but with so many other restaurants that are better overall and cheaper, theres really no reason to visit zuni - especially since lulu's chicken is better, and quicker!
author: Junglist S.

description:
when its just one of dem days at work and the sun is shining outside, Zuni Cafe is a great pick-me-up... a reminder that "it's just work."

i had a super delicious perfectly made spaghetti with clams, leeks, flat leaf cilantro cooked in a white wine and olive oil with some olives. MMMM! I can't even describe it but drool. the pasta was cooked perfectly, the clams were so sweet, the olive oil was so fragrant, the leeks added a sweet-mild-onion-like taste complimenting the freshly chopped flat leaf cilantro and bits of olive gave hints of squishy tartness. 

friendly service, pleasant atmosphere with busy bodies, especially on a sunny day with the huge windows. sit by one and people watch. 

thumbs up: all smiles when leaving and while eating. always changing menu but keeps famous staples (like the juicy burger and a side of fries). FAST too, .. perfect for lunch.

thumbs down: kinda pricey but worth it.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
Whole roaster-chicken. Every time!

I mean they slow roast a chicken...for you! It's well worth the wait and after a couple glasses of wine I'm starving and when it comes, its that much more succulent and enjoyable.

Their appetizers are great too! Good selection of small seafood eats (i.e. local sardines, sea snails and oysters). Yum yum yum.

The atmosphere is great! Its very relaxing, and enjoyable. The staff was friendly and accommodating. Great place for a date.
author: Drew M.

description: Let me start by saying that during 30 years of marriage, I have never seen my husband NOT leave a tip. The service at Zuni Cafe was terrible. We were a party of three. We ordered a dozen oysters and a salad to split, as well as entrees for each of us (not the chicken, which takes an hour). That, in hindsight, would have been quicker. We received our drinks and oysters timely, but that was it.  After we finished our oysters. we waited a half hour for our salad and water refills. At this point, we were there for an hour and 20 minutes. As we watched several tables around us being served their entrees after arriving after us, we decided to get our entrees to go (we had a long drive ahead of us). My husband went inside to arrange for our food to go, only to be told that "we are backed up and the entree order has not been placed". WHAT?  We asked for our check, only to be greeted by the curt manager. He informed us that WE should have told them we were in a hurry.
author: Cathy B.

description: This place is great for a nice dinner with friends. I got the rabbit with a mustard sauce and it was very tasty. I don't know that it quite lives up to its hype, but its still a great restaurant.
author: Heather C.

description: Great place.  Love the Ceaser Salad.  Avoid the bar if you don't like deaf-inducing noise.  But the seating is comfortable, good quite good, prices high but expectable, and staff have always been friendly and attentive.
author: Steve S.

description:
Damn those fries were good. 
Definitely try the hanger steak. Polenta was yummy, but I think part of the reason I was so into it was because I wanted the Good Eats Polenta episode earlier in the day. 
Drinks are not cheap here. . . but it's still worth every penny.
By the glass wine list was just ok. Bottles had a decent range, but most were on the higher side... twas expected.
The ambiance is fantastic. I should have tried the oyster bar. I'm almost positive it would have been amazing. 

... they need more than one bathroom per gender.
author: Annie T.

description:
I love oysters and good service so I like to come to Zuni with my special friend on our lunch/dinner dates.  The service is always great, the food can be anywhere from great to okay.  But the reason I come here is to relax and have a glass of wine and oysters.

Today will be the last time i will go there.  They have joined the group of restaurants that has tacked on a 4% fee to cover restaurant worker health care.  This is disclosed in an italic font in the middle of the menu, probably so you will skip over it.

I believe employers should provide health care for their full time staff but it's absurd that a restaurant of that nature would do that.  They should just raise their prices 20 cents if they can't afford to pay into the health care fund.  

Think about it.  The customer pays for their food and at a restaurant like that you tip 18%-20%, which attracts people to work there.  So the employer can  get by paying min wage or slightly higher.  Then they tack on another 4% to the customer because they don't want to pay health care expenses?  Can you imagine if they did this each time you buy jeans or go grocery shopping?  

I am happy to pay the 4% to my struggling neighborhood cafe (which actually doesn't charge it), but I hope you think twice before eating there.
author: A K.

description:
I came here on a Friday night with reservations, and was seated promptly. We were seated upstairs in a semi-private section. The upstairs seating is designed into separate  rooms, which feels like a maze when you walk through. But I think that creates a better ambiance as all the diners aren't talking over each other. The service was excellent! The staff constantly checked-in on my table and were very professional. The waiter knew all the menu items and was able to explain all the ingredients in the dish. 

We started off with the cesar salad and polenta. The Zuni cesar salad was delish! They really do use fresh greens. The polenta was a tad disappointing because it could be creamier. Of course we ordered the chicken because it's at the top of the SF's 7x7 list.  However, I didn't think the chicken was anything special compared to other restaurants. The meat was very tender/juicy and the crispy skin added an extra kick. The bread salad totally saves the dish. Pieces of bread were soaked with all the oils and juices from the chicken, which makes it extra tasty. I think the chicken is worth trying, but not a major incentive to come back for. 

For dessert, we ordered the Piccola meringata. The dessert was layered with creme and huckleberry sauce. It was disappointing as it was served as mini-size version. I was expecting more quantity. But the huckleberry sauce was fabulous!
author: Wendy L.

description: This place is pure magic.  Maybe it's partly the aromas wafting from the wood fired oven.  The chicken is so amazingly good it seems to melt away all our troubles in life, if just for a few moments.  We tried the fried zuccini blossoms for the first time and were delighted.  Thank you once again Zuni!
author: Darrel S.

description:
After reading the decidedly mixed reviews, I wasn't sure what to expect. I'd give it 3.5 stars, giving points for service and taking them away for the food.

The service was excellent -- super friendly, attentive, and not stuffy at all. We had a reservation and we're seated immediately. I can't imagine anyone we encountered rolling their eyes at a customer as was mentioned in previous reviews. 

The food was good, but not amazing. Maybe it was just what we ordered -- oysters, caesar salad, halibut--but I thought the flavors were bland. For the price, I think there are better, more interesting restaurants in the city (heck, even in that neighborhood).
author: Leigh M.

description:
Love the food, hate the attitude of the cooler than thou staff.  People - it's just food, albeit wonderful hamburgers, caeser salads, chicken, oysters - why are you so snooty about it?  

Don't get the hype.
author: .Hon H.

description:
Unusually good food, spot on service, excellent decor and expensive as hell.

My group almost to the man ordered burgers. We had some beers and a few other drinks. Two plates of fries. 6 people, $190. At this point you are probably logging off and heading to BK. But you may be curious about the high rating.

So why do I give it 4 stars? (I almost gave it 5) Well, these burgers are wonderful. Not necessarily the best I've ever had, but different enough that even though it is still a burger, it's a burger that is exceptional in it's own unique way. Let me explain:

1. Focaccia bread. Huh? Yeah. It's different, but goes surprisingly well. It tasted fresh baked. 2. Pickles. Two types. Yummy! Some of my coworkers said these made the burger, I would tend to agree. 3. Meat. Top notch, cooked to perfection. 4. A nice set of condiments, garlic aioli, mustard and ketchup. 5. The fries are a pile of comically thin shavings that make you want to grab them by the handful.

What else? Well, the parking sucks. 1 hour meters and a bunch of one way or tiny alleys to try and park in. Luckily I drive a car that isn't much longer than I am tall so I found a place without much trouble.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Zuni has been a fav of mine throughout the years and had a chance to come back there to introduce a neighbor of mine who's never been there before and have her try their signature "chicken for two."  I think the last 3 out of 5 times I've been to Zuni I've had their chicken and it never disappoints.  If you want good, flavorful, moist, cooked-to-perfection chicken that doesn't come in a bucket (heheh), Zuni is the place!  

The other 2 staple items that never disappoints are the kumamoto oysters and ceasar salad.  Hmmm...perhaps I should venture out and try other items on their menu...well, can't help it, when I want good chicken I just head to Zuni.
author: Rick P.

description:
Yay! I am a fan!
This is a place that serves my ideal kind of meal, simple yet elegant and impressive.  The sauces not overpowering and thick, just enough to provide great flavor.  

The menu is printed daily.  I had the rabbit; it was juicy and delicious.  Also ordered couple dozen oysters from the shellfish menu, absolutley scrumptious. Desserts were ok, nothing memorable.
And also have to mention that we received some the of the best service i've had in a long time.

Overall we had a great experience here!  Will take a chunk out of your wallet though.  Still, I will definitely be back!
author: j h.

description: My partner and I have gone to The Zuni Cafe since its inception. It was one of our mainstays. However, recently, the Zuni has changed and not for the better. The portions are smaller, the prices are higher and the choices are not as high quality or as varied. An endive salad with 2 different kinds of foodie olive oil came with about 6 small leaves of endive drenched in the oil. We are very sad about this but we will not be returning. For that kind of money there are many restaurants in SF that provide you with wonderful meals. One good thing, though, the service is always very good at Zuni.
author: Maria B.

description:
zuni is a classic. 

they had good french fries in 1998, and the have good french fries now.

plus i like the art inside. very inspirational!
author: Kenna T.

description: Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco staple - a great restaurant that has been around for a while (in restaurant time). The food is solid - last time I was there, I enjoyed a lamb dish with lots of lamb done different ways, and a really tasty and comforting clam starter with breadcrumbs. My only real gripes are that the menu is a little too small (I felt kinda forced into the lamb because I didn't want fish or oxtails, or to wait an hour for the chicken) and the desserts leave you wanting more from such a good restaurant. But I do thank them for not frowning on the fact that two of the four of us were 1/2 hour late for our 8:00 reservation - not rushed at all. Much appreciated.
author: Kiesha R.

description:
Folks -- there's a reason this place has been around since the early 1990s.  Zuni serves the basics extremely well.  Oysters, Cesar Salad, Burger, "The Chicken" (one of the best in SF), ACME Bread, Great Cocktails, Fabulous Wine List -- all of it is extraordinary well executed.

FIVE stars with ease...
author: J. SOMA S.

description:
I love Zuni for its amazing consistency over the years.

I love the unusual space, and the three floors of light airiness.  It's most wonderful sitting at brunch amidst the filtered natural light, the open beams, the white-draped tables.  

I love their crazy addicting shoestring fries and the various accoutrements (vinegar, aioli, catsup).

I love their Bloody Marys - all tangy and spicy and biting.

I love that you can go upscale and go with their pricier offerings (the seafood platter, the chicken for two), or order the burger, which, simply, is fabulous.

I love that you can go after a dance workout wearing baggy pants and a puffy jacket and you'll still be welcomed and seated without anyone batting an eyelash.

We visited most recently after Judy Rodgers had left the restaurant.  The food is still excellent.
author: Claudine C.

description: I have been here a number of times and first heard about it when it got rated by Michael Bauer as "a place to eat before you die".  It does have a very cool location and a very fun atmosphere.  The chicken dish is what they are famous for and one of the best chicken dishes I have ever had.  I went back when I was vegan and there still were plenty of choices on the menu that were great.
author: Lisa V.

description:
I have been coming to Zuni Cafe for years, it truly has become a big staple in my life and my family's. 

The ambiance is very cool- modern, sleek, and very artsy! They rotate their beautiful selection on a regular basis so there is always something new and exciting hanging on the 30ft walls. The scaling of the restaurant is amazing- open rooms, high ceilings, raw edges, and of course the open kitchen and wood burning fireplace. The bar is incredible- copper and stretching down one entire side of the front room. Floor to ceiling windows line this happy space and its always great people watching out on Market Street! 

The food is amazing- if you haven't tried the famous chicken- DO IT! 
They prepare nightly specials that tickle anyone's fancy and their cocktails are amazing- personally I recommend their house margarita on the rocks with salt.

The oysters- HEAVEN- if you are an oyster fan this is as good as it gets- they have about a dozen varieties on any given evening and their mignonette dipping sauce is incredible. Also goes great with the margarita :)

The wine list is also something to write home about and if you are unsure the wait staff is very knowledgeable and ready to lend a hand, or a taste at any time.

Finally there is the service- over the top. Not only are they prompt, educated on EVERYTHING, and super friendly; but they treat you like total VIP all the time. 

All in all, its my favorite place in the city and I always refer my closest friends to try it if they haven't already. 9 times out of 10 those referrals turn into returning customers who wind up falling in love, just as I did.

Cheers Zuni- Here's to you!
author: Blair H.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in SF, period. Lemon Drops, Oysters, Cesear Salad and Zuni Roast Chicken, your welcome.
author: Joshua S.

description:
I can't really add anything to the reviews of the restaurant.  People know that Zuni is a SF institution.  The chicken is, of course, the draw.

I would like to add that some friends of mine have been cooking from the Zuni cookbook and, if you don't want to break the bank, that is THE way to go.  Their porkchops recipe is absolutely killer.
author: Tim G.

description:
"Order the chicken- it is amaaaaaaaazing, orgasmic, out-of-this world".....AND completely overrated.  After reading the Yelp reviews, I thought eating the Zuni chicken would be an otherworldy experience.  I figured that the $48 and hour long wait for it would be worth every last dollar, but yelpers you gave me chicken blue balls!  

To me the chicken was a glorified Safeway rotisserie chicken atop an amazing bread salad.  Definitely I find that the yelp reviews overrate the chicken and underrate the bread salad.  

While waiting, we had the caesar salad which I highly recommend if just for the croutons.  We also had the shoestring potatoes which at $6 are the best value on the menu.  The all ricotta gnocchi were quite different and delicious as an appetizer. 

They will charge you $1.50 for the aged balsamic if you ask for it with your bread.  If people are buying your chicken for $50 do you really need to charge them a buck fifty for balsamic vinegar????  

I am glad I experienced Zuni but I don't think I will go back....next to see how the chicken at Il Pollaio compares...I hope the price tag doesn't!
author: Christina F.

description: I've only been here once and the thing to get here is their chicken and bread salad. Yes, it's expensive, but well worth it. Also, you should make a reservation and be prepared to wait. It was totally worth it and the chicken was divine. It was nicely seasoned and very moist. The bread salad that it comes with was so good. We took some out-of-town guests here and they even loved it. I would definitely come back here again.
author: Caroline L.

description: Had a light dinner at Zuni over the weekend and loved it! Excellent food/ambiance, and a wonderful wine selection! Will be back again soon for a full meal!
author: Mindy C.

description:
I can't believe I'm giving Zuni four stars after they overcooked the famed burger TWICE for my poor visiting Little Bro.  

Yes, that's right.  First go: medium-rare request arrives sad and gray.  New one brought: even grayer than the first.   At this point Little Bro requests it removed from the bill and we leave.  But not before the manager challenges his burger doneness specifications: "I'm sorry sir, but we're confused on your definition of medium-rare.  This (holds dry, deathly-pallored burger up to light) is medium-rare to us."

That's when I had to put the smack down and tell him I've eaten a half-dozen Zuni burgers and they've never looked like that.  He shuts up, scurries away, and returns with the profuse apologies that they have a new grill cook (who is clearly not up to par - surely he was responsible for my similarly cooked-to-death pork chop) that's learning the ropes.   Little Bro tacks a big tip on to my miserly mom's 10% (yes, there are people who really do tip that low), because it wasn't the waiter's fault, and we exit.  I'm just sorry he had to go hungry.

So why, pray tell, the four stars?  Because the other dozen or so other times I've eaten here have been excellent (yes, I know that's a lot of Zuni-ing in only a year and a half of living here, but it was a somewhat regular brunch place for me and the ex-pseudo-bf).   It's one of those restaurants where I'm incredibly comfortable, where I know the food will be clean and interesting and exquisitely seasonal (and up until this point, reliably well-executed), and it's timeless.  I love walking in and sitting at the odd corner bar table in between the windows and surveying the now-classic space.   I like the crowd, the energy, everything.

So maybe choosing a 3:30pm lunch time during that odd week between Christmas and New Years was a bad move.  Maybe it wasn't the right place for Mom, who is all about value ("$12 for a tiny salad I can make at home?") and options ("This is the whole menu?  What if I don't want any of this?").   Next time, Mom, Cheesecake Factory for you.

And I'd like to hope that next time, that grill cook will be trained and my burger will arrive pleasantly pink.  Because I want to keep loving this place, despite the occasional gaffe.
author: Melissa B.

description:
When you go on a spree, go the whole hog.  A very wise man once said this.

Finally did it up, in style.  I mean, I've been here before, but never gone all out.  You know, the real deal.

Well, I did it, and it was fantastic.  Everything was cooked to perfection.  The flavors melted and jelled on my palate, sending me into fits of epicurean ecstasy.

Had some local oysters and white shrimp.  The braesola with beets.  The arugula salad.  The white bean soup.  The lamb.

Try the caramel pot de creme.
author: Abendigo R.

description:
Not as good as to be expected for the price. $15.00 for fried eggs? Right.

The drinks were good (mimosa was fresh, latte was rich) but the food was slow and not memorable.  Ordered eggs with breadcrumb salsa which tasted a lot like eggs with deep fried crumbs.  Decent.  The "shoestring potatoes" tasted a lot like piknik sticks and the ketchup tasted like Hunts tomato sauce.  

The decor was very nice, airy and light.  Chairs were uncomfortable but I could overlook that if the food was better.  But it wasn't so I'm adding a two star review to Zuni Cafe's collection of low ratings.
author: Adrienne J.

description:
I visited for the first time last week and, of course, ordered the caesar salad and roast chicken with bread salad.  Also ordered the gnocchi appetizer.  First, the salad -- very good, but kind of disappointing for $10 (although it is a very large portion, perfect for 2 to share).  The chicken was also very good, but I thought the bread salad totally stole the show (in a good way).  I'm in love with the bread salad!  Is there a way to order just the bread salad?  I should find out.

The gnocchi was strange, it was really light and fluffy but tasted a lot like egg.  Not quite what we were expecting.  Gateau Victoire for dessert was pretty good, too, but not excellent.

Overall, great food and great service.  Try to get a seat with a view of the kitchen since it really sets the mood.
author: D S.

description:
HOLY. COW.

The chicken for two.  MELTS IN YOUR MOUTH.

Their chicken is unrivaled in excellence.  This alone makes the visit worthwhile.  WHAT ARE YOU DOING STILL READING!?

Go go GO!

(-1 star for their portions being kind of smallish and the eternal wait, even with reservations)
author: Daddy O.

description:
Is roast chicken worth $50? Maybe when it is slowly cooked in a brick oven and sitting on a bed of bread salad with pine nuts. I had been waiting a month or two to finally come to Zuni. Make no mistake, it gets crowded, so make a reservation at least a week or two before. I came here with my friend and her visiting sister and we had a blast! We sipped on chartreuse champagne cocktails and shared the roast chicken and the spaghetti dish. The spaghetti dish is not a normal red sauce dish, but spaghetti with a very light sauce with nettles, pancetta, and a sprinkle of cheese. But, onto the piece d' resistance--the roast chicken! It was DIVINE. Sure, the roast chicken isn't the most complicated dish, but the pairing with the bread salad made it extra special. You have to just try it yourself. Just think of a roast chicken you buy at Costco, 1000x better, with little bites of tangy bread salad.

The atmosphere is lively, yet sophisticated in its own way. Our service was quick, but not rushed. Overall a great experience. I don't think I'd come every single week, but definitely will be back soon!
author: Angela L.

description:
I have to say, I have no idea what the fuss is all about. I've been to Zuni twice with my parents. They are foodies and love a trip to the city for something delicious. My mom had heard about Zuni, so we trotted over after an afternoon of Union Square shopping for a late lunch. I was so underwhelmed. My mom had the burger, I had something that I can't even remember. But my sweet sweet mother gave me half of her burger because I was not satisfied. 

We decided to go back when my sister was in town to give it another chance. We went the benefit-of-the-doubt route and decided that dinner would be a better yardstick. Well, it wasn't. We had the raw plate, It was fresh, but not particularly amazing. 

All in all. I have no idea what the big deal is when it comes to Zuni. The menu is small and unimaginative. The food is ok, nothing special, and not worth the price. Definitely skippable.
author: Roseanne W.

description:
Finally decided to try the chicken.  After waiting so many years to do it, found it to be a  bit of let down.  The presentation was wonderful but the chicken wasn't exceptionally juicy or tender.  Don't think I will repeat this.  The gnocchi on the other hand were incredible, like clouds melting in your mouth.  The peach dessert was so disappointing. A dry scone sliced in half with a thin layer of whipping cream in the middle and a few sliced raw peaches and blackberries on the side. It lacked creativity, moisture and favor.  They did take it off the bill when I shared my disappointment with it.

The service was odd and lacking.  After ordering the chicken which takes an hour we were in no hurry to order the apps, but, he would return every 5 minutes to see if we had decided on something.  He was adamant about the gnocchi even though we inquired about the salads and veggie dishes.   Finally, he recommended the kumquat salad and gnocchi, but, only the gnocchi came, as he decided we didn't need both appetizers.  Strange for a restaurant to discourage you from ordering more dishes.  

When he was given feedback on the food or order mix up he was laissez faire about it as if he didn't care.  

It won't be at the top of my list for restaurant recommendations.
author: Joan M.

description:
Can I give ZERO Stars?  This place is a disaster.  I have been here 3 or 4 times in the last 10 years.  The most recent was over this past weekend and I will NEVER go back.  Why?  The usual reasons/complaints.  First, $48 for a whole chicken for two.  That's criminal.  Two, complete a-hole bartender who was rude, surly and literally knew NOTHING about the wines by the glass.  I mean if you sleep all day and have no other responsibilities in life other than bartending, wouldn't you learn a little bit about the 4 or 5 white wines by the glass?  I mean a little bit? Like what it tastes like, whether you like it or even better where it's from?  I mean the varietal and geographic origin are on the fricking bottle you moron!  You are a bartender, what are you distracted by, the stockmarket ticker.  

This place is such a fraud that it pisses me off that the SF Gate and every other food knob in this City continues to call this a "can't miss" San Francisco classic.   It really isn't.  The kitchen and front of house are on automatic pilot.
author: Nick S.

description:
Brunchtime bloody mary done right, for one. 
Deliciously delicate linguette with citrus, leeks, and mascarpone, for another. 
And a lovely little caramel pot de creme to end the bright and happy afternoon. 
Now, if only I hadn't left Zuni to find my car broken into...but that's just called sour grapes.
author: Purnima M.

description:
It's been open for 30 years. Our server had been there for 23 of those 30. Do I really need to elaborate on this? A San Francisco staple that I have longed wanted to try. With family in tow, what better excuse to sample good food than to have it expensed on the parents. (What? We all do it don't we?)

The place is much larger inside then what you can see of the place from Market Street. The main floor is an open plan that ties the bar, first floor dining area and display kitchen together. The upstairs is compartmentalized into a labyrinth like layout which was unique to say the least. The storefront window / liquor display wall of the bar was probably the most appealing part of the whole joint and I wish we were sat in this area (or at least the mezzanine area overlooking the bar) rather then the rabbit hole in the back. 

So while I enjoyed the meal and have heard a ton about Zuni, I must admit there were a few snags to the meal; most of which can be chalked up to a first timers experience to the menu and can probably be avoided in the next round. 

1. The chicken IS good. Flavorful and savory. It also takes an hour to cook so be prepared to a.) order it as soon as you sit at your table and b.) wait. After devouring the meal, I asked if you could pre-order the chicken before being seated to avoid the long wait but apparently that's not an option. Sorry folks, you want chicken you gotta pay your dues I guess. As advertised, it does serve 2 (and probably more) but doesn't come with much except a bread pudding sort of thing under the chicken. Go for extra sides / dishes to split for the entire table so you get some sort of variety.

2. The place is busy and it took a good few minutes to even hear from our server which unfortunately affects #1. 

3. The ceasar salad was delicious.

3. I believe the menu rotates daily with basically the chicken holding it down consistently. There wasn't much on our menu that day that struck my fancy but maybe that's because I was dead set on the chicken. 

4. The Gataeu Victoire is a very rich flourless chocolate cake. Skip it. 

Happy eating!
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
I stopped by on a Saturday afternoon on a whim. I was seated immediately, downstairs. Wow, ok, I'm actually sitting at the famous Zuni. Great vibe. Cool walls. Good people watching. Let's order!

A few minutes go by, and the waiter arrives. Seems a bit aloof, perhaps hungover? Ok, I'll start with a salad and glass of wine, and some ice water please. I know that your famous chicken is "for two" and as I'm flying solo today, I'll try the burger with a side of fries. 

What, I can't have fries?? Why not? Oh, because the order of fries, like the chicken, is not really meant for one person to consume. "Don't order that - it'll be too much," the waiter advised. "I'll bring you some bread instead".

Dude, how about you bring me my damn fries. "The fries are meant for two or more people to share." Then how about a half order of fries, I plead ? "Our kitchen cannot do that." 

Umm, ok. Cold bread sounds fine, I guess. 

Salad and burger were fine, not fantastic. Burger was a bit tasteless, really, though the meat was prepared as ordered (medium rare) and the bun was appropriately done (crispy outside, soft inside). Wine was appropriately overpriced.

Upon inquiring about the check, I was served my bread and water. 

Next time (hopefully there is one, as I still have high hopes for this SF institution), I'm bringing the wife so I can try the chicken and, perhaps, the fries...for two.
author: Ricky S.

description:
Its not often that i chose to eat at a Bay Area Top 100 restaurant. I generally find them overpriced, with classy ambiance, serving good food though at a hefty price tag. I love to eat wheat spaghetti by its ordinary name and not with a fancy name which i cant understand. So i am not this fine dining / gourmet food critic!

But on a saturday night when i had 2 hours to spend before a show at The Orpheum, i found myself heading towards Zuni. Though without a reservation, i was lucky to get seating at the small tables near the bar (which was crowded). They seem to have proper dining areas upstairs as well as near the kitchen, but i opted for the cafe near the bar since there was no waiting time for that. Prompt with the menu (which i believe changes daily), help with choosing the items, served food on time, with occasional "are you doing okay". Service commands 5 

Would give a 4 stars for the cafe ambiance as well, though i am not sure how the main dining area looks like since i was seated in the cafe area

Now the Food. I had a bread toast doused with olive oil (It was a fancy name) as appetizer. Nothing great for a $11 starter. The wheat spaghetti (another fancy name i cant remember) was very tasty, with fresh ingredients, tasty vegetables. Pricey for $18. The dessert called "floating island" with fresh cream, pistachio nuts, chocolate flakes floating on a baileys kind of liquid was very good. With coffee and a glass of wine added, the bill touched $48. Very pricey, but good food. Did not have too many vegetarian options, hence a 4 star

May not go there again just for the price, but it is a good once a while experience. Overall 4 stars
author: Sankar B.

description:
Driven by this place more than a dozen times.  Finally decided to go in for lunch.  We didn't have a reservation and it was going to be a 20 minute wait so we got one of the tables near the entrance/bar.

The food and service is excellent.
We had the crostini with tuna and artichoke (almost in a confit style)
,the house made burger on focaccia and shoestring fries.
Every dish was excellent.  There was literally nothing left on the tuna plate.  The burger was well cooked although the focaccia made it slightly difficult to eat.  I loved their touch of picked onions on the side.
The fries are addictive.  All the tables around us got them.

The only drawback about this place is the price.  It was a bit expensive for a brunch meal.  You can tell that they're catering to a slightly older crowd.

Would go here again to try out the roast chicken.  It takes one hour but its supposed to be amazing.
author: Joy G.

description: I love the look of the place and the kitchen is integrated uniquely into the middle of the restaurant. Prices on entrees are about $10 beyond where they should be. Food was good, wine tasty, desserts small but lovely. Seems ideally suited to a more formal evening (going to a show, big date, etc.). Check out Hotel Biron around the corner if you have some time to kill before or after your meal.
author: Jeremy S.

description:
I used to eat at Zuni fairly often between the ages of 7 and 15 (obviously I didn't pay), every time my parents would go art deco furniture shopping on Market street, we would finish it off with lunch at Zuni. I hadn't been back since and the only thing that I remembered eating there were the shoestring fries; probably also the only thing I actually ate.

9 years later, Zuni still has a lasting impression in my book. I recently went back for dinner and appreciated it way more than I did in my younger days.

For appetizers we ordered the polenta (delicious), which could have been a meal in itself, it was freaking huge; I didn't finish my half of it. We also got the ricotta gnocchi for an appetizer, which was not traditional gnocchi that you would expect. It tasted like it was made from eggs (not flour/potatoes) and it was extremely light & fluffy, I think I would have preferred regular gnocchi. After eating the appetizers I was not even hungry for the main course.

For the main course we ordered the roasted chicken for 2, which takes an hour to make, so if you are in a hurry do not order it. The chicken was fantastic, I was not expecting too much since after all, it's just chicken! It was served with bread salad, which tasted like really good stuffing and had crunchy parts to it, mmmmmmm. Definitely order the chicken, it's worth it!

Great atmosphere, great service and great food, what more can you ask for!?
author: Elaine S.

description: I am not going to compete with the other reviews as having over 700 is way too much. But the roasted chicken with bread salad is really good. Nuff said.
author: Marck N.

description:
Shatangi has only had the best service there. The best burger in town. The pickled onion and zuch make it that way. Awesome selection of Oysters and good drinks. The best part is that the last time I went I split the check with my guest and they charged his card twice instead of charging both of ours. (Sukka!!!!) lol. I paid him back

Shatangi told you
author: Njon W.

description:
PROS

1. On Market Street.
2. Fast and good service.
3. Superb ambiance from the chatting patrons.
4. Food is good to very good.
5. Elegant and visually pleasing as far as the setting goes for restaurants.
6. Its been around for a while and keeps coming through.  Hooray!


CONS

1. Parking.
2. Sometimes too crowded.
3. Some things are really pricey.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Went for brunch on a recent Sunday. The BEST thing about this place is the space. It occupies a triangular building off Market, and the whole interior embraces this idiosyncratic shape. Walking around feels like walking in a cool alternative space that's a welcome breather from the square-filled nastiness that is the rest of Market St.

The staff is very professional and on top of their game. The food is great, if only vaguely Mediterranean-inspired. (Dinner must be different, I'm speaking to brunch). My wife and I had a range of their food, from the cocktails to appetizers, soups, and entrees, and must say it all was excellent. The portions are just a bit on the small side, so be prepared.

The most irksome thing is the 4% surcharge for SF's universal health care system. Like, WTF??? I appreciate the cause, but not this sort of means for getting there. It made me feel bad to complain about it, and I just paid. Certainly, if I went again I'd ask for it to be waived on account of the shoddiness of such an approach to (albeit needed) political change.

Off my soapbox, get the shoestring fries to help on the skimpiness of the portion sizes. The ketchup is housemade and DELISH! (What Heinz would taste like if America weren't slave to oligopolistic neoliberal capitalism)
author: Kevvy K.

description:
We were walking by on Friday night and we decided on the off-chance to see if we could do a walk-in. I wasnt optimistic, but the hostess said we could get seated in 45 minutes. Much better than I expected.

May have been a cunning Zuni tactic, however. We went and stood at the bar and had some excellent margaritas. Very enjoyable, watching the activity on Market St and the buzz of the restaurant around us, and the bartender was wonderful and friendly. However, we seemed to be there a *lot* longer than 45 minutes, and consumed several of the delicious margaritas.

We eventually got seated (upstairs, in a little nook in the surprisingly big back area, to my disappointment -- I had been hoping for one of the more stylish tables in the main downstairs area at the tall windows.) There's a real buzz of fun and a convivial party feel in the place on a Friday (probably helped by the generous way they ply the alcohol!) Sure enough, our waiter soon tempted us into getting a bottle of the Zuni-labeled Pinot Noir to go with our Caesar Salad and gnocchi appetizers. The wine and the appetizers were very good (and essential - we had a one-hour wait ahead of us while the famous Zuni roast chicken was being prepared for us.)

The chicken was very flavorful and tasty, if a little monotonous. (It is served with bread and herbs, but no side vegetables.) Nevertheless, at this stage, we were having a very enjoyable time (even bantering with some of the other guests at the restaurant -- something that's *very* rare for me). We eventually made out way out of the restaurant, quite a lot poorer (the drinks bill, in particular, was shocking) but extremely satisfied.   

My recommendation: for a thoroughly enjoyable Friday evening meal, Zuni is an excellent choice.
author: donal c.

description:
Let me just tell you straight off that though it's a dressy place, by no means do you _need_ to dress up.  We went here after I had spent the day in Golden Gate Park for Tour de Fat under the sun.  I changed my t-shirt and took a rockstar shower (i.e. put on deoderant.  Hopefully my date won't read this...).  I was wearing shorts as well and the waiting staff was still very kind and helpful.

Food was DELICIOUS.  I had the California white bass and it was devine!  My date had the pasta, which was quite hardy and filling.  The necterine and boysonberry dessert was a little sweet to my tastes but darn good as well.
author: Chris M.

description:
Why is Zuni so friggin awesome?
