Why are they open during that weird break in the day when nobody else is serving food?  
Why is it that the restaurant looks small from the outside, yet there's always a big crowd packed inside? 
Why is it that their bread and butter is so much better than everyone elses?
Why does the guy making the ceasar salads look like he's gently caressing every leaf before it goes on a plate? 
Why is the salmon so tender and flavorfull that it makes me want to tell all the other salmon out there to go to hell?
Why is the chicken and bread salad so good that it makes me want to weep when I finish the last of the leftovers?
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Indeed, the food here is very good. The goat sausage I quite enjoyed. 

The problem here is the staff and moreover the owners. The problem stems from the owners, they are HIDEOUS!!! They put all their effort into the food, this would be a good thing if they spread their attention to other things. They simply could care less about their patrons. They have a massive ego and concentrate on the financial gains.

With such horrible owners, of course the staff will be somewhat off. Customer service starts at the top, with the top being completely uncaring of it, why should their staff care all that much? Their retention of staff is notoriously short. 

In the end, there is great food all over this city, I simply would prefer not to encourage such miserable ownership.
author: Christopher N.

description: Everything fresh and innovative- they achieve a delicate balance between ingredients that are simple just what you are in the mood for. I bought their cookbook and have tried some of the recipes, each one is a mini-tutorial and I learn a little more about the overall art of cooking with each recipe I make. Besides the delicious food, don't overlook their fantastic Bloody Mary, it's made with organic tomato juice and a touch of balsamic vinegar. There is a super finely chopped spoonful of salsa-like garnish that is put onto the top and sinks to the bottom of the glass once you stir it up. Once you get to the bottom of the drink, don't forget to munch on these little gems, frozen and also gazpacho-ish.....delicious!
author: Kathleen G.

description:
Elegant.  Clean.  Rustic.  (Lunch Review)

I went to Zuni Cafe with false hopes of getting a Roasted Chicken SALAD.  For some reason or another, there were rave reviews online about this SALAD.  Come time to order, I was utterly confused, and then politely informed that the roast CHICKEN was it's claim to fame- and that it took an hour to prepare.  Doesn't work for my hour lunch break.

Despite my disappointment, I ordered two beautiful oysters (very large!) and the polenta.  The lunch menu wasn't too exciting or diverse.  Polenta was ...polenta - would have been nice to be wow'ed by this simple dish - although the marscapone on top was quite creamy.  A glance at my adjacent dining neighbor: caesar salad = practically naked, long stems of romaine.  I felt sorry for the lettuce leaves - it wanted to be doused in dressing.

My server, with slicked back hair and the face of a high school delinquent, was belittling, calling me sweetheart and "hun" in the most saccharine voice.  

Unfortunately, the most captivating thing about this restaurant is the decor - two stories of elegant but rustic wood floors and a banister lined with romantic white lights.  

If you're looking for good eats, my guess is that the roasted chicken really IS that good, but if you're not in the mood for slow cooked poultry, look elsewhere.  

Know Before You Go:
1. The famous roasted chicken takes an hour to prepare.
2. If you want chicken in a salad, they can mix it in the Caesar for you.
author: Jane L.

description:
I came here for dinner Saturday and left satisfied.  

I had the infamous roasted chicken for two but I wasn't wowed by it.  It was good, but not THAT good.  Ya know what I mean?  It was juicy and very flavorful (too flavorful in some parts) but I don't think it's worth the wait and money.  I think I'll stick to getting my $5 Costco chicken the next time I want my fix of chicken.  Ooooo, Zuni fans must hate me now because I've compared the beloved dish to the likes of Costco!

We also got the spinach soup and shoestring potatoes... and the soup was pretty bad.  Maybe I'm not used to that taste bc other diners slurped that shit up, but I wanted to spit it out.  Thankfully, our wonderful server, Shannon, noticed our adverse reaction and whisked that dish away (and took it off our bill).

I would definitely come back to try their other dishes though.  Plus, the main reason this place is awesome is because of the people who work there.  The servers know how to make you comfortable and cater to your needs.  Go Shannon! =)
author: Michelle W.

description:
I took my Mom here for a special Easter Brunch and it delivered. The space is open, sunny and sophisticated. I love all the small rooms, the big oven in the middle and watching them shuck the oysters. It's definitely an SF establishment.

The oyster selection was impressive, better than Foreign Cinema I believe. The menu is truly an equal mix of bfast and lunch, v. more on the bfast side. The egg dishes were fantastic, including the french toast. 

The only reason I can't give it the full 5 stars is that while the space is amazing, the atmosphere wasn't incredibly infectious, it was as little sterile, especially when compared to Foreign Cinema. But that wouldn't stop me from coming back if I'm ready to splurge on another fancy brunch.
author: Kim M.

description:
I echo the sentiments of an earlier Yelper - this place sucks if you're a vegetarian. they've got very little to choose from and it's simply not worth the price of the meal imo. the chicken is supposedly really good tho.

a few things that  stood out:

- we got a plate of roasted veggies (16$) and everything was swimming in oil. most of the dishes we noticed (tomato soup/salad) had a *ton* of oil all over it.  

- $4.50 for a nectarine on a plate for dessert. just a nectarine rolling around on a white bread plate. no garnish/no presentation/no nothing. pretty chintzy if you ask me. the guy handed it to our table and we all had a nice laugh about it. (he could have just as easily thrown it to us from across the room we thought)

- $12 for a bloody mary? cmon. it was pretty tasty, but there were so many chopped up onions in there they clogged the straw and made it pretty tough to drink. (i didn't finish it)

- the polenta was tasty.

just kind of an overall weak dining experience considering I've walked by the place 1000x. i'd maybe hang out @ the bar to drink, but as a veggie I'd never recommend it to any of my friends.
author: Justin H.

description:
Used to go here for business meals a long time ago, and it never stood out. Time for another visit.

Make reservations weeks in advance if dining on a Saturday evening at peak times.  We arrived on time, but had to head to the bar before the table was ready.  

Food: 2.5 stars. Service: 3.5 to 4 stars.

Returned here for dinner, and while the service was impeccable, friendly, and patient, the food left something to be desired, especially for a $360 bill for five people pre-tip.

Avoid the hardly cooked risotto.  Hard and difficult to eat. Proof that executing a simple dish may prove challenging.

Oysters were fantastic.  Sampled a variety and they were all good.

Steak and duck did not stand out.  Just one of the two salads tickled our palates. Skip the classic Caesar.  

Desserts and cheese plates were average.
author: Ye W.

description:
Ah, yes, the one and only world-famous Zuni.  You'd expect it to be the best restaurant in the city, right? I've been here a handful of times with different experiences.  Here is my most recent:

Don't get me wrong.  My $25 guinea hen was rich and delicious, as was my $9 salad, but not worth the price.  This place is always busy so don't expect the fastest service.

Open, spacious decor but nothing I'd slit my wrists for. Just kidding.

People visiting from out of town? There are so many other places to have an expensive dinner out in the city.
author: Scott G.

description:
Zuni is my perfect dream-lunch spot!  I would never believe that my favorite dish from a weekend getaway would be a bowl of lentil soup, but it truly was that good.  The hint of lemon from the sorrel, just the right amount of yogurt swirled on top - perfection! 

The decor of the restaurant is sunny and relaxing.  Our waiter was attentive and helpful.  This place is just excellent!
author: Andrea D.

description:
Not quite 3 not quite 4 stars.  The food itself was wonderful.  I liked the Caesar salad and the panna cotta.  Thought the chicken was really good but outrageously overpriced.  (Nearly $50 for ONE chicken?!?)  Fried Radiccio was good but it fell into the "just because you can do it, doesn't mean it needs to be done" category of food for me.  

Service was attentive to the little details (not pouring coffee until the recipient was there to keep it warm) but missed bigger details - keeping parties standing because we were there 5 minutes early despite an empty restaurant; clearing one person's plate when another was still eating, etc.  The food was perfectly spaced.

I'll be back.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
One Saturday night when I was visiting home, my sister, parents and I decided, spur of the moment, to go to Zuni Cafe for dinner.  This, of course, proved not to be such a smart idea since we did not have a reservation.  We called to see of the possibility of a same day reservation. Of course it was not a possibility but there was a 1 1/2 hrs wait for walk-ins. 

Since none of us were starving we decided to go to the bar at Zuni and wait, It actually worked out quite well. We stood at the BEATUFUL bar and played card games and drank cocktails while waiting for the table. The bartender (Aaron) got a kick out of my family's playing cards at the bar and joined us for a few hands. He also recommended some unbelievably wonderful oysters.  Surprisingly, time passed quickly and before we knew it we were seated.

The food and service was incredible, but what truly made the evening was waiting at the bar with my family and playing cards with the staff. I appreciate the lack of pretension of a famous San Francisco restaurant and their employee's ability to have fun while providing excellent service.

Also: I had the best olives of my life in my dirty martini here!
author: Erin P.

description:
So after reading quite a few good reviews of this place, I thought I'd try it.  My rating is only on the quality of food (b/c the service was just fine), but I was definitely disappointed.  I read rave reviews of the Caesar salad and pastas, so I thought I'd try both.  The Caesar salad was totally eh, and the pasta was nothing to be desired.  My friend got a pizza, and the dough tasted like a Boboli with some tomato sauce spread across the top.  I'm a total foodie and am pretty open-minded to new places, but I doubt I'll ever go back to Zuni again.  

The Caesar salad was about 6 leafs of romaine lettuce with a tiny bit of mediocre caesar dressing (very strong anchovy taste) spread across the leafs, some sprinkles of Parmesan cheese, and 4 croutons.  Granted, the croutons were good because they were baked fresh with their bread.  In addition, I got their pasta with butter sauce, broccoli, & mushrooms.  No flavor, the mushrooms tasted like paper, and the butter was just too much.  My chin was greasy from the thing and I'm a pretty polite eater.  

Idk....I think there are other places with much, much better food for half the price.  Maybe I went in with high expectations so my view is skewed, but I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Naomi P.

description:
I am sad to report that we will NEVER go back to this restaurant!
On 2/28, we had a res for 6:15pm for 3 people. We arrived and checked in at the podium at 5:50pm and requested a seat on the main floor as I use a cane. We were told by the hostess that they seat the 6pm res first and we would be seated after them and to hang at the bar and she would come and get us. There was a small  table in the bar area and we ordered a cocktail . People were coming in and getting seated and when at 6:25pm we had not been seated, I went back to the podium to inquire as to when our table would be available. The hostess gave me a blank stare, said wait right here and disappeared into the back of the restaurant. She did not return and then another woman went to the podium. After explaining my situation, she said that we had NOT been checked in, was sorry and said the only table available was upstairs. This was very difficult for me in my present condition.. The waiter had been informed of our situation and was sorry . He was the only bright spot in this experience. Food was just OK, nothing special. The bill came and no one had made any attempt to remedy this bad situation by "comping" us for any item.
It is quite obvious that management just doesn't care . Certainly times have changed at this place .
author: Norma B.

description: I actually gave 4 stars only for special menu of that day RABBIT PAPARDELLE!!!! I've been here twice. The second time I came back because of that dish, but they did not have it anymore. So, curious about the chicken...........really???? U kidding me!!!! I cook better chicken at home or I preferred Peruvian Limon Roasted chicken better in South Van Ness. GUYS DO NOT GET THE FAMOUS CHICKEN.........blekkkk.......Maybe if you come from Fargo, Minnesota or any small cities, you will like the chicken. But, after living in SF, LA, NYC, Honolulu........I know what great food are!
author: Clemencia S.

description:
8.3.06 UPDATE:  Ate dinner at Zuni last night and had an excellent experience.  Everything was great; food, service, seating etc.  Had the most insane Hanger Steak on the menu that was mouth watering.  Yum.  I'll be back.

After reading some not so great reviews, I feel I need to jump in here for a moment.  

I have blacklisted Zuni so many times b/c the attitude at times is comical.  You think, "Did they just roll their eyes at me?  We're not even in Paris!".  I totally get what everyone is saying.  That said, I have a love/hate relationship with the place.  First of all, to those of you loving that Zuni chicken salad, go out and  buy the cookbook.  I've had the salad many times made at home and it's great and people love it when you invite them over for dinner.  The short ribs and Chimay recipe is also great to make at home and easy...(it seemed easy but I guess my ex would know better since he was the chef, and an excellent one at that, good job Jeff!)...anyway...

Zuni is NOT the place to go for dinner b/c it's always crazy and too busy and when it's crazy and too busy, the staff get agro (agro=eye-rolling and attitude).  Nobody likes agro when they're about to drop $100 on dinner.  At least not me.  

Zuni has great ambiance and some good items on the menu.  A good time to go is off hours.  I have had many great experiences there when I go for a later afternoon lunch after the rush.  Or, on a Saturday, get started early and be the first to show up.  I'm talking right when they open.  Sure it's not the see and be scene place that it is around 8pm but you can go someplace post nosh for that.  

Just so it's not ridiculously expensive, share some wine and some apps instead of having a full meal.  Like I said, many of the recipes there are also in the cookbook and can be made at home.

All I'm saying is that yes, Zuni can be a pain in the bum sometimes.  It's been around forever, the space is great and if you can work around the busy times, it can be a nice experience.  

That's all.  Just some ideas...
author: James M.

description:
Zuni is a San Francisco institution and over-rated by Michael Bauer, San Francisco Chronicle's holy food critic. For many of MB's reviews, I respect. But I can not believe this place made San Francisco's top 100 restaurants, 8 years in a row?!?! This gives no justice to many great restaurants.

The menu rarely changes, and the stale food quality is down right dismal, oftentimes lukewarm and tasteless. The only way I can see why people keep bombarding this place is to bask in the sun, watch the amazing people dynamics on Market Street from any seat in the fishbowl restaurant, or take an ethanol hit from the well-stocked full bar. Oh and quite an attraction for upper bourgeois for its lack of obvious diversity. * Ahem * Zuni is not my cup of tea.
author: Cathy H.

description: Don't quite understand what all the rave is about. The service was good and the food was alright, but it wasn't incredibly amazing by a long shot. The orecchiette were not just aldente, they were still raw when cut through. The waiter told us that it was because the pasta is so thick. Yes, we know that, but then the cook should have looked at the cooking time on the package. Ordered a side of polenta instead, and got a bowl that would have fed three as a main course. It was a very overpriced for what we got. I would not recommend this restaurant.
author: Miriam B.

description:
I've gone up to five stars after revisiting, only because Zuni has never let me down.  Always a beautiful restaurant with tasty treats.  For some reason I have never tried dessert here until tonight, and all three things we ordered were wonderful.

I may only eat here the rest of the time I am in SF.
author: Amme P.

description:
I had a dinner last night.. and guys and girls you have to try the gnocchi at zuni it s a signature.  realy light and soft stuffed with ricotta cheese. The oysters and the salad were good.

The final sweet touch was the coffee granita, really fresh to finish a dinner. The only C is the staff.. our waitress was nice but the host and the bartender really cold and not really into it .

Overall good experience..
author: gilles P.

description:
Ok ok, yeah I know Zuni's been reviewed a ridonkulous amount of times- what more can be said...bla bla bla...slow food originator....bla bla bla...chicken=orgasm....bla bla tasty late night food....

buuuuuuuuuut I gotta say, it lived up to the hype! Me and Neha S (see her review for the flipside version of this writeup) and I was floored by the service! Even though they were all booked up, they  happily upped the reservation from the original Trilogy of peeps to a Posse (5). Not only that, but when two of the krew ordered something that apparently ran out- the waiter appologized profusely and comped their replacement entrees (!) I was like WTF? This service is insane. seriously, i felt like I needed to assume some diva personality to accept this celeb level of treatment (ahem, they could have done a better job to hire some paparazzi to make me feel like Britney and no, i wasn't going commando to dinner).

Oh the food? DAMN GOOD! The polenta was creamy and cheesy, the burger was to die for- literally one of the best i've had- in the same boat as front porch, slow club and Liverpool lils. Damn. tasty. nuff. said.
author: Tim V.

description:
This modestly elegant glass-walled haven from the bustling Market street scene bears a private joke between an ex boyfriend and I:  The few times we've tried to dine here, we could not avoid having a public spat .  By any means, I am not a public person.  I instinctively shy away from leering eyes and inquisitive ears.  Especially negative attention.  

For us, Zuni was the luminous, white table clothed thorne on the Castro-market scene.  Always beckoning with it's quiet charm, we would gaze hungrily for a second in its direction before both agreeing "no" with a head shake and affirmative glance. Through the succession of well dressed crowds flooding its doors, Zuni became a beacon of insatiable wonder.  

Looking back, I'm sure we both know our avoidance of Zuni was silly, even childish.  I remember all of the places that carry sentiment of  time and place for me: Chinatown's courtyard full of old chess and backgammon players evokes a sense of discovery and wonder every time I stumble into it;  the Buena Vista for the pink sunsets that slink quietly down into the pacific and the taste of hot Irish coffee.  

Anyway, I digress.  Being the half way point between a girlfriend's house and mine, Zuni was the indisputable place to satiate our craving for oysters.  Michael Baur raves, as do most I hear.  I knew, Zuni was the perfect place for me to reconcile the past and present through my palate and good conversation.  

The perfect Thursday dinner consisted of seamless service by a staff who actually knew the menu, a glass of prosecco, Effingham and Miyagi oysters, as well as the anchovy plate.  

I'm looking forward to coming back and building our future together.  I got an oyster and Prosecco high that I gotta maintain.
author: Xandria S.

description:
This is a good local restaurant - someplace I could eat regularly if I had a fat wallet.  The ingredients are very fresh and very freshly done.  But there was nothing "WOW" about the preparation.  It was good and clean, but note worth the price tag.

We started with the anchovies/cheese/olives (okay, fresh tasting), oysters/clams (awesome, one of the best raw bars), salami (okay).

For the main course, we had the striped bass (the Chinese long beans just didn't match the Striped Bass flavor) and the lamb (the beans and sauce flavors didn't meld with the mild flavor).    

Do not order the watermelon granita - for $7, it was just shaved ice with watermelon juice.  

I think the food is good (not out of this world), but not quite worth the price (about 30% over priced).
author: Madison W.

description:
Classic new american cuisine in a modern but warm atmosphere.  I planned my most recent visit for a weekend lunch so I could try the famous hamburger which is only available at lunch or after 10 pm in the evening.

We started with the ceasar salad, which was a traditional rendition with great ingredients - whole leafs of lettuce with parmesan, anchovies etc.

The burger was served on a foccacia bun.  An interesting touch that was rather tasty.  I thought the burger patty itself was good but not worth the hype about it.

Shared an order of shoestring fries.  The plate of fries was enough for 6 people to share.  The two of us barely made a dent in it.

The ketchup appeared homemade.  I prefer more traditional ketchup to the variety the Zuni provides but I appreciate the effort to make it from scratch.

Service was good.  Our waitress came by to check on us but did not intrude.  Water glasses were refilled continuously.  They also seated us promptly for our reservation.

The couple next to us ordered the famous roast chicken for two, which is on my list.  It looked delicious but a lot of food.  Next time....
author: Aaron T.

description:
I'm usually optimistic when it comes to food and I don't want to ruin the Zuni party, but this place blows. After reading so many positive reviews before going, I was sure it would be a fantastic experience. I went for the oysters... I left feeling ripped off. Yes, I made reservations and my friends and I were promptly seated. The decor was modern and our waiter was kind and entertaining-the bread was okay. 

However, that's where the goodness ends. The prices were ridiculous and the quality was below poor. I had a pasta dish that not only needed to be cooked for a much longer period of time, but it also was way bland and salty. One of my friends had the burger... a $10 burger that oddly enough didn't even come with fries. Is this America? The oysters ended up being not that bad, but I've had better and cheaper. Oh, and the corking fee for wine was basically rape so we didn't even bother. 

And just to let everyone know, we weren't the only ones disappointed that night. Two well-to-do men were at a table next to us and it was easy to hear their negative comments and see the disappointment on their faces. They had the "renowned" chicken that takes like an hour to bake. A wasted hour that was.

Please, if you value good food and your money, try another place.
author: Michelle B.

description:
A friend recommended this place as a great lunch location while visiting San Francisco. I immediately liked it upon walking in. The triangular corner building is adorable and the loft architecture makes for a really cool dining environment. I really liked how crisp, clean and airy everything felt. 

The food really was delightful. We ordered the prosciutto appetizer which was heavenly. The shoestring fries were also cooked just right and were perfect to nibble on while waiting for our rotisserie chicken for two. The chicken was delicccccious and the bread stuffing it came with was also great - I'd never tasted anything like it and completely loved every bite. 

Although the food was amazing and totally worth it cause we were on vacation, this place is pretty pricey for lunch. We spent about $100 for two people.
author: Marina P.

description:
Okay - I almost never order chicken as a main course at a nice restaurant, but the friend I was here with HIGHLY recommended the chicken for two.  So fine... I'll humor her.  It takes a while to prepare, so we ordered it as soon as the waitress came to take our order.

As we sat there drinking our wine and noshing on the (really good) bread while we waited on the chicken, I got a chance to look around at the restaurant.  The design of the place with it's huge windows gives the place a bright feel during the day, while the wood, the beams and the fireplace create warmth when the sun goes down.

The chicken came out, and I gotta say - it was REALLY good.  I can safely say that it's the best chicken I've ever had at a restaurant.  (But as I said - I never order chicken at a restaurant, so that's not saying much.)  But seriously - I was impressed, and I would very much recommend the chicken.  But I'd also like to go back and try some of the other things on the menu.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I wish I could post negative stars.  After choosing Zuni to Spend my Valentines day, I and my partner of 18 years had one of the worst meals and service we have ever had.  
Spoke to the management and we were invited back so they could make it up to us.  We took them up on that offer last weekend and WOW! It was worse and they only compensated us for the $48 roast chicken.  The Chicken still had what looked and tasted like boiled chicken skin.  Our invitation ended up costing us $150.  I should have known that when I had the Hendricks Gin on the rock and asked for a few olives and was charged $6.  I say "STAY AWAY" from zuni!
author: Eric S.

description: Great food, friendly service, and a beautiful ambiance (you can observe the kitchen!). The roast chicken is delicious and definitely worth the wait. The caesar salad is also amazing and comes in a generous portion.
author: Julia W.

description:
I had heard a lot about the chicken dish before coming.  It takes an hour to make, so place your order early and be prepared to order some drinks and appetizers.   They have a great selection of fresh seafood - frutas del mar - to start with.  An impressive array of oysters, clams, etc. and a nice wine selection.   The chicken dish ($48 for two people) is pretty large; perhaps can be shared by three who are also enjoying appetizers and dessert.   The chicken was juicy, the skin crispy and delicious.  It is served with frisee and a bread salad with a flavorful vinagrette.  Pretty comforting.   For dessert, we shared a marscapone tart with berries, which was sweet (but not too sweet) and refreshing.  

The only critique I can offer is that the menu is somewhat limited.  There were maybe a handful of entrees, of which, did not include a beef option (pretty unusual.) Instead, they had rabbit, squab, duck and pork chops.  Being an adventurous eater, I would have been happy with any of these.  However, if I was not in the mood for game, I would have been restricted to only one or two dishes.   

The ambience is very nice; classy and understated with live piano music to accompany your meal. Nice place for a date or drink at the bar.
author: Nicole S.

description:
OK, I would have given it one extra star if it weren't for my last meal there.  Take my advice, don't order a hamburger.  I was excited to see that they were serving Neiman Ranch meat, but I think they failed to flavor it with anything. Nuff said about that.

HOWEVER, the roast chicken is dreamy.  Although you have to wait an hour while it cooks, it's worth the wait.  Order some shoe string fries in the meantime and you'll be amazed how quickly you can work through a mountain of potatoes!

Overall, attentive service, rustic, yet elegant ambiance and good food.
author: Lauren T.

description: Overpriced and overrated.  Staff friendly.  I have been here twice and been sadly disappointed both times.  The first time, we ordered their famous roast chicken for 2.  It came out with one half raw.  They blamed their oven, gave us a free dessert which was appreciated.  So we tried again. This time, I paid $16.50 for a  dish that was in the "entrée" section of the brunch menu.  It was one small sausage, a handful of fresh peas that were past their prime, and a few pieces of fingerling potatoes and radish slices.  The waiter said their dishes were on the small side but that was ridiculous.  People (friends plus other diners we overheard) seem to love their oysters.  I would stick with those and the pizza.  The asparagus pizza was tasty.  The Bloody Mary is sweet but nicely spicy so I would recommend that.
author: Rosanne W.

description: Amazing food.  Tried the squab (oh yeah).  Didn't like it, but I think that has nothing to do with the preparation. Turns out I just don't like pigeon.  But this is a spot.  AM = anything on the brunch menu, bloodies. PM = oysters, martinis.  A must visit in SF spot.
author: Isa L.

description: SF's best - excellent food, great wine list, the best place to watch the SF parade of personae - be it nerdish geeks, leatherfolk, elegant old SF money types, the movers and shakers of the LGBT community, etc. etc. Their hamburger is one of the best worldwide.
author: Ayala K.

description: Blecccch! Years later I can still taste the bad fish taste from something NAHSTAY I ate at Zuni. I've tried a few times for Zuni to redeem itself, but every time I go I feel more underwhelmed than the time previous. And it kinda smells funny in here. And the staff borders on too-cool hipster. Seriously, you may have awesome, thick-rimmed rectangular glasses (congratulations), but you're still my server. Get a grip. Cocktails are pretty good.
author: Mekhala I.

description:
Update, June 2006:

Downgrading to 3 stars on the basis of a meal we had here recently where the service was unforgivably bad, and the food quality off the mark in several ways. We're eaten here happily 3 or 4 times since the first review, and I would chalk it up to a bad night, except that 2 separate groups of friends recently told me a nearly identical story. Suffice to say that I now understand why some people loathe this place.

The service was really dreadful. As in two appetizers coming to the table well after everyone else had finished. As in having to ask for the wine list three times to order a glass of wine. As in emptying a full bottle of wine by filling four people's glasses to the brim, when there were 6 wine drinkers at the table (hence my needing to order a glass). As in never checking how entrees were, whether we needed more bread, or if anyone wanted coffee refills. And, note to our waiter: Unless you are my husband, a southern gentleman, or a waitress in a Baltimore diner, please don't call me Hon.

The food, too, was pretty sad. There were some amazing standout dishes -- the fresh oysters in the plateau de mer, and a glorious small-plate dish of halibut cheeks -- but there were at least as many downright clunkers, including an inedibly bad coconut cake and a pair of pork chops: one a lovely medium-rare but served on a stone-cold plate with (unintentionally) room-temperature sides, the other overdone to a tough, dry mess. Even dishes that I have enjoyed in the past weren't anything to write home about: The bite I had of Squeat's pasta carbonara was really average, and the mushroom soup was lackluster -- and I normally adore the soups at Zuni.

So, mea culpa to anyone whose opinion I have questioned in the past: I now totally understand how you could see Zuni as an overrated, boring, has-been of a restaurant. I'm just glad it wasn't my first visit, or it certainly would have been my last.

----

We had dinner at Zuni for the first time recently -- a long standing joke in our house, as we've lived in SF, off and on, for nigh on 15 years -- and we loved it. We bought a copy of the cookbook about 3 years ago when we left SF for Seattle, and have enjoyed cooking out of it regularly.

Everything we ate was good, some of it was even great, but the highlight of the evening (and this is coming from me, a non-dessert fan) was a caramel pot de creme that was sooooo super-caramelized. My husband had a dozen oysters, I started with an amazing carrot soup that highlighted the garden-grown taste of the vegetables and made me glad I had skipped the salad I was toying with ordering. My entree has slipped my mind -- which is just as well, as I it didn't wow me -- but my husband had an amazing fish braised in a cazuela. 

Service was gracious but not quite as attentive as we might have liked, due to 2 adjacent parties of 6+ with small children. We loved the atmosphere of the balcony; we were in the front one, closest to the bar and the host stand. 

In short, it was the kind of place that we could see ourselves making the effort to become regulars at, even if that meant making a reservation. It's the sort of place we'd love to just drop into casually, if such a thing were ever possible.
author: anita c.

description:
It was so nice to be back in CA where the fish is fresh and the people are polite! I'm glad my first meal back in SF was Zuni. 

I know everyone raves about the chicken, but I can get chicken in Chicago - I had the halibut and it was fantastic. I tried just a couple of oysters (to ease myself in) and wished I had ordered more because they were the tastiest I'd ever had. 

The atmosphere and service were lovely. Our server gets extra points because she complimented my outfit :) AND cleaned up the wine I spilled all over the floor. 

I will most definitely recommend Zuni (to all my Chicago friends when they visit) for a pleasant meal off the tourist-beaten path!
author: Esme W.

description:
I fell in love with this restaurant on my very first visit, and time after time I have been satisfied. 

I recommend going right before sundown to get some nice light to enjoy the atmosphere at its optimal time..

The pork chops are amazing. Perfect blend of flavor and texture make this my favorite. The fish is always fresh, and flavorful.

My favorite dessert is there version of strawberry shortcake.  I tried all the desserts, and if you love chocolate, try the Victoria Chocolate Cake.

Bon Appetit.
author: David K.

description: Nom nom nom roasted Zuni Chicken has to be last meal material. It's beyond delicious and the crusty rustic bread salad and handful of greens the perfect accessory. I crave this madness and several rounds of Oysters are a fabulous way to kill time while the Roman God tends the briny beast until perfectly golden and then rested. It's simple yes but not easy to arrive at consistent perfection and Zuni has it nailed.
author: Karen W.

description:
Zuni is like a fly-ass pair of limited edition sneakers. Dress it up in a tux and dress it down in jeans and this place is still bangin'. Less of a destination restaurant and more like a local's old faithful, I keep Zuni on deck like a precious titanium arrow that I pull out of my quiver when I need to hit a bulls eye.  For any reason. The food is always very good, refreshingly simple in presentation, and it always hits the spot. And the unique but unpretentious atmosphere contributes again to a super-welcoming, relaxed, yet celebratory mood.

I've never had bad service at this place so for the few folks in here who complain about "attitude" at Zuni, maybe you oughta chiggy-check yourselves.  Everyone has always been very friendly to me and my guests. Certainly this place is a bit more expensive than the vegan burrito place where some of you may have been chillin'. When it's called for, I just don't mind paying a premium for food and an experience that I can always depend on to be "top gear".  

Go Zuni! Oh and I second the motion to get oysters!!!
author: Brian S.

description:
I went to Zuni Cafe for the first time tonight after reading it as one of the top 50 in Gourmet Magazines listing of best restaurants in the US (at number 37).  And after having eaten there, I wish I could give 3.5 stars.

First what I ordered: some fried fig stuff as an appetizer, a few oysters, a sea bass, the oh-so-famous-chicken, and the chocolate cake.

All in all, the food was tasty, but it was very straighforward.  There was nothing particular complex or interesting about the dishes.  The figs were excellent, the oysters were good, the sea bass was a bit on the tough side although the sauce was great, and the chicken...yes, why get chicken in a nice restaurant.  It is one of the best chickens I've had, but again it was kind of straightforward.

So in terms of taste, yeah, it was good in a straightforward, familiar way.  No suprises or complexities to be told.  Add in the cost, which isn't crazy as far as expensive restaurants, and you end up with the 3.5 stars which in this case I'll round down to 3.

Why #37 from Gourmet Magazine?  I have no clue!
author: Clarence K.

description:
I didn't have time to order the chicken, so I went with the Ahi.  I enjoyed it a lot.  Caesar's salad = good (not amazing but very good).  

If you can't get a reservation, they keep 1/3 of their seats available for walk-ins.  The wait was about 25 min for a table.

UPDATE:  I recently returned for oysters and wine before a girls night out.  I love this place.   The oysters were great.  The staff is great.  It's a wonderful place to start of a nice night out.  

I still need to come back and try their bloody mary.  I hear it's one of the best in the city.
author: Angie C.

description:
Excellent, excellent food. This is a solidly European place, so expect European-style service. Prompt, not overly friendly, not overly in your face. But prompt, efficient, courteous, and *respectful of your privacy*!! I actually very much dislike the way many American restaurants sell a whole social experience with the service staff - I come to a restaurant to EAT and to spend quality time with whomever I bring, not to make some sort of new relationship with everyone who is serving me (perhaps so I feel better about being served, I don't know?!). Anyway, Zuni Cafe delivers the experience of privacy and efficient service  effortlessly.

The chicken on top of bread salad was absolutely phenomenal, worth every penny. Oysters were fabulous, as was the Caesar salad. Shoestring fries, delicious - and the Gateu Victoire desert, drop-dead mouth-watering.
author: Ryan B.

description:
It's hard to go wrong with Zuni, but you do have to be ready to drop some cash.  That said, I have never left there feeling ripped off.  

Years ago, I had the chicken and thought it was as delicious as the hype would have you believe.  More recently, I've sampled their burger, pizza, caesar salad, arugula salad, sardine appetizer, gateau victoire, and pork chop and all were excellent.  The pizza might be slightly less exciting than excellent implies, but everything else was wonderful.  The pork chop in particular was extraordinary, like the best pork chop I've ever ever had, it ruined the very decent (and much cheaper) pork chop at Chow for me.  Very classy service gilds the lily.  My friend and I got a heartfelt apology and some comped olives when the pizza was a little slow coming out of the kitchen, (we hadn't actually noticed the wait, but were pleased to have the olives).  If I had the money to eat here once a month, I'd probably do it.  Remember, pizza is served at lunch time only, burgers at lunch or late night.
author: Erin b.

description: If you want to make me happy, start me off with a great cocktail.  Ding.  Zuni was off to a great start with an Aperol concoction.  So good.  Then the appetizers: anchovies and a delicious soup.  Then the sea bass main dish for hubby and a vegetarian pasta small plate for me.  Delicious tangerine + prosecco granite to clean to palate.  Yummmm, everything.  We were fully content and ready to return!  Soon!  (Later on a Sunday evening was a nice time to go... not as hectic as Saturday restaurant nights can be.)
author: Linda R.

description:
What Brassarie Balzaar is to Paris, Zuni is to San Francisco. for me, this institution is defined by 4 dishes, which I heartily recommend and rate as 5 stars (the rest of the menu is 3-4 stars):
Perfect Order:
1. Oysters
2. Cesar Salad
3. Chicken (45 min wait and they will rudely say "no" if you try to order in advance of arrival)
4. Pot de Creme
author: Peter F.

description:
Walked in without reservations on a Saturday night at 7:30 and was able to get a table 15 minutes later.  Surprising that the wait was so short, since I've tried once before unsuccessfully (1 hour wait - ugh).  This time, my companion and I ordered the much talked about roast chicken with bread salad for two & an appetizer to tie us over for the 45 minute wait.  It was well-worth the wait.   

Additionally, our server was great - very pleasant, checked up on us the right number of times, etc.  Seems like a great restaurant - pleasant decor, relatively friendly staff, good ambiance, and reasonably priced, for a slightly upscale/casual restaurant... I'd definitely return again.
author: Rose R.

description: Ordered their famous chicken and fries. When we wait for the chicken get ready, we ate the Casar Salad and French Fries. Couldn't remember the salad. Fries got cut very very thin which is very interesting but not that juicy and I don't think that potato's quality is top notch. Chicken delivered to the table half an hour earlier than the one hour waiting on the menu. The wings and legs and thighs are very tasty. However, the breast still tasteless slightly better than KFC. Based on the breast, I don't believe the chicken they used is that good quality. For only wings and legs and thighs I give 8.5 out of 10. Overall I would give 7.5. Very gay friendly vibe. Waitors very friendly. Have a very cool oven and open kicthen. On the pricy side.
author: Vicki Z.

description:
$60 for a roasted chicken? Tell me how that works, exactly? I can see paying $8 at a Chinese take-away, but I just don't get how this place gets away with it. I guess a lot of people will pay big bucks since the place is "famous" for roasting a damn chicken. They must love the profit margin. I've been here for lunch a couple of times. Pizza and burgers? Fine - so why do they charge more than some places charge for a proper dinner entre? The food is OK, but I think the only people eating here are either having the client pay or on an expense account.
I think this place just coasts now on the fact that it is an "institution."
Don't care much for the faux-yuppie atmosphere, either. The location is in the the Deco Ghetto, but the vibe is like some revolting Marina place - the worst of both worlds!
author: David C.

description:
very good food with great service. the roast chicken is seriously the BEST roasted chicken I've ever had. I thought it was good at Range, but this tops it. crisp and juicy, the most simple, yet delicious recipe. i want to go back just to eat it again. it takes almost an hour if you order it, so be prepared to wait if you do. it also says it serves 2 on the menu, but we shared it between 3 of us and it was plenty. the skin is my favorite part because it's crispy, but you don't feel guilty cuz it's not fried. 

the ricotta gnocci was very disappointing - just too cheesy and not the right consistency of gnocci - that is why i gave it 4 stars. i also didn't like that they add 4% to your bill due to the health insurance they now have to provide for all people who don't have it in the industry in SF. i'd prefer that they just add 4% to their menu items and not even tell me that because I already am paying for my meal, the last thing I want is to have to pay for someone else's insurance. Even if I am in way doing so by dining there, I'd prefer it was hidden in the cost of the food.
author: Pumakat K.

description:
Judy Rogers is one of my heroes. Truly San Francisco's beloved restaurant. Take your mom, take your boss, take anyone you remotely like here.

Almost every great restaurant in San Francisco has a Zuni recipe in their menu. The food is simply delicious.
author: Danny E.

description: This is my celebratory/birthday/indulgence go to spot. I love their chicken. My dad makes it at home to bribe me to come to his house. I had the best burger of my life there for lunch on foccacia. I f-ing love foccacia. Shoestring potatoes, excellent. Cool atmosphere. Maybe I will eat here tonight....
author: Emily H.

description:
All of the times I have eaten at Zuni have been for Brunch so I can't speak to the dinner service. 

Brunch! what a lovely meal. 

I usually start by fighting my way to the copper bar and ordering bloody marys which come with the expected vegetation including a huge stalk of celery. Seasoned perfectly the cocktail is salty with pepper and spice.

The oysters are a mainstay from local oyster farms up the pacific coast.

Now, you may have heard of the amazing chicken or the $15 fried egg but you may not have heard that Zuni has THE BEST BURGER IN SAN FRANCISCO. 

Imagine the most perfectly succulent foccacia bread you have ever experienced then take it up a notch. Served with gruyere or other choices of cheese and pickled onions. The burger is perfectly grilled to your liking and made from the happiest nitrous oxide killed cows in California. I think the cow must be taken on a date with Orlando Bloom and then roofied. I'm not kidding the cow is sweet.

The restaurant is part of the slow food movement which is taking the business of food to a new level. Seasonal ingredients, locally grown, and usually organic.  

The large open kitchen is a testament to the translucency and pride displayed by a truly great restauranteur.
author: Johnny H.

description: Love the ambiance.  The citrus infused mahi mahi was amazing. Very fresh.  Yummy.
author: Cheri B.

description:
4.9 stars would be more accurate. 

Everything nearly perfect at Zuni-- Have been 6-7 times for lunches, dinner and drinks.  

Chicken is fantastic and worth the $48 and 1 hour wait (order from your server as soon as you sit down! and get something else to tide you over in the meantime); every pizza is perfectly crisp, chewy, hot and covered with fresh, seasonal ingredients (a close second best this crust in SF: Delfina); the burger is also excellent on a focaccia roll though gets 2nd to the Spruce burger ($1 more expensive and does not come with fries unlike Spruce); Caesar salad is a healthy serving and maybe the best in SF.  

Ask your server to check out the kitchen if you're inclined--They are extremely friendly and knowledgeable and happy to demo the beautiful brick ovens if its not too busy. 

Service overall: 5 stars with knowledgeable staff that virtually anticipate your every need.  HOWever, have had 1-2 experiences where the hosts were not as welcoming as they could be-- un-flexible with requests and downright unfriendly.  Benefit of the doubt goes to them as they were very busy. 

Still a must visit for anyone seeking one of the best dining experiences in SF!
author: Matt S.

description:
4.5 star. 
I highly recommend to make a reservation.  We went there without reservation, and learned it would take them 45 mins to prepare the famous chicken for 2 with warm bread salad.  The chicken tasted so good, crispy skin, juicy meat, just enough seasoning, and oh boy, the warm bread salad is the bomb!  if you are going there reservationless like us, order some oysters while you are waiting for the chicken, they are the freshest oysters you can get!
author: Sophia L.

description:
Arrived early for our Sunday 2:15 ressie, had a cute little private table upstairs in the corner ready and waiting.  

Heard the burger was fabulous, so that was what I planned to order...have to admit, was taken back by the price of $15...BEFORE additions.    Considered another option, just on principle that it was a burger, but ordered it anyway.  Glad I did!  It was absolutely delish!  Juicy, salted beautifully.  Foccacio it was on was very light and almost sponge-like.  Appeared to be a homemade aoli on it.  I ordered the roquefort addition, BF ordered grilled onion.  Both came with pickled onions, sweet pickles and pepper.  Seriously, 5 stars.   Shoestring fries and bloody mary (house infused pepper vodka) also excellent.  What a Sunday lunch!
author: Elle S.

description: As soon as they sat us at our table I knew we were going to have an awesome lunch. They sat us literally right next to the kitchen..... I love cooking so I just kept watching the cooks prepare dish after dish after dish... also i was very impressed how impeccably clean they kept it too. We came here for lunch because Food and Wine put Zuni Cafe on their list of Best Burgers in the US. Boy were they right. The burger was served on rosemary focaccia bread and spread with aioli sauce which actually makes it a bit salty... lucky for them i love salt. The meat is cooked just right to whatever you ordered it... i got mine medium... and they serve zuni pickles on the side which are this delicious combination of sweet and sour. we also ordered a side of their shoe string fries which came out on a plate as a mountain of fries. it was definitely impressive. the fries were quite delicious too. whenever i see shoe string fries i think that they are just crispy with none of the softness inside that differ fries from chips but surprisingly they still managed somehow in that thin shoe string fry to get the crispy outside and soft inside. my only complaint is that the lemonade was not free refills... come on zuni... who doesn't do free refills these days???
author: Lesley H.

description:
Wow, what can I say that really already hasn't. Oh, how about our server was pretty rude.

An ex-girlfriend of mine worked here for many years before moving to Austin where we met. It was always Zuni this and Zuni that. Well, I am in town for family stuff and out tonight hanging with an old friend and we decided to go for my first time and it was certainly everything I'd imagined it would be. 

The food was simply great. I've never seen a pork chop so large prepared so perfectly throughout...and I've seen thousands of variations on this preparation of  "pork verde"  this was pork perfection. I went with my ex's favorites: The Cesar salad with fresh prepared Cesar dressing (grrrrreat) and the Zuni burger. In my travels this last week I've had no less than 3 amazing cheese plates, so I opted not to go with the two wonderful types of cheeses offered to be put on top and instead went with heirloom tomatoes (soon to be gone for the season).  The burger was simply wonderful and I could have eaten two (not because they were small, but just tasted that good).

Ok, so my beef with our server. First and foremost she completely ignored my guest. Seriously, to the extent that she took my order, grabbed the menus and after two steps decided/remembered to take his order. Then later she flipped the check presenter onto the table TOWARD him after paying and never said one word of thanks as she rushed off to other tables. There were a few more things that made it obvious that either we or someone else had shit in her cheerios. 

Whatever, the food was too good for me to not go back at some point. Strap it on a donkey, train a monkey, I don't care just give me the good stuff.  Oh, if they do train monkeys I will be back sooner!
author: Tom C.

description:
I used to love Zuni Cafe.  I took a friend from Switzerland there recently.  He is quite an excellent chef, so I promsied him a good meal. 

The meal was really terrible.  My guest had a hamburger which he described as 'a piece of steak on a piece of bread.'  My husband had pork which was extremely tough (we almost sent it back, and would have if we did not have a guest with us.)  There were no vegetables with the pork - ridiculous given the prices.   My fish was OK, but undistinguished.  Although we had a late lunch (2:30 pm), the food was very slow in coming.  The service was 'smarmy' - too much 'can I get you something to drink' and  'is everything OK' after the food came, but nothing during the more than 30 minutes we waited to be served.

I won't be going back any time soon.  Too bad - this place used to be terrific.
author: Karen N.

description:
This past Saturday my friend and I dropped into Zuni's for brunch. 

The Good:  Service,  Wait time for Meals, Cesar Salad

The Bad:  Table (We were sat upstairs in the corner at this rickety table overlooking the alley), Bloody Mary (Tasted Like a V-8 Splash & The Paper Straws Are A Mess), Tomato Soup (Terribly Bland), Price
author: Johnnie T.

description:
Let's just get to it and say that that the caesar is honestly the only real reason to go to Zuni's now.   So they have a seasonal menu.  Meh.  So does everybody else nowadays.  And they don't give you a snooty attitude about it.  Meh for service.  But, my god, that caesar!  That perfect caesar with that amazing balance of anchovies, garlic, lemon and cheese...drool.

In the past year, I finally got over my shame and just go ahead and ASK for extra croutons on my caesar.  It's shameful to ask for changes to what the chef intended, I know.  But it's what will really, truly make me happy, and don't I deserve happiness?
author: Lorin Y.

description:
1 star for service. 
1 star for space. 
1 star for food. 
I enjoyed dinner at Zuni, but it was not so blow me away fantastic that I would wait weeks for a Saturday reservation, or pay 100 bucks a person for dinner. There was not anything bad about the experience, but it was just average. I do not see a reason why I would have to go back. I have heard great things about lunch so maybe that's the meal to have there.
author: Jaime C.

description: Very good, but the chicken for two is overhyped and overpriced. Some of the appetizers were very tasty as was our pork dish. The espresso granita was very good but the chocolate cake was dry. Waiter was very helpful.
author: Michael L.

description:
I am amazed that this place is still as great as ever!  Rarely do you find a place that has been around for as long as Zuni has (Judy R. joined the venture in 1987), that has not needed to "re-invent" it self at least a couple of times.  Not only does the menu still boast the classic favorites without change, but the interior has been relatively the same for over 20 years.  

Every time I have a meal here I feel like I am coming home again.  I rarely venture from my favorite items because they never disappoint. 

If you want to experience a SF Institution, with an urban feel and a typically chic crowd, this is your place!
author: Michael A.

description:
I feel like my experience at Zuni didn't necessarily match up with the other Yelpers who got a lot of attitude from the staff.

I made a reservation on a Saturday for later that night, showed up on time, but my date was late. I spoke to the host - no problem! After ordering a glass of wine (that turned out to be completely unremarkable) at the bar, my date arrived and we were seated at a nice table in an interesting spot - sort of in the middle of the downstairs.

Our waiter was friendly and the food arrived quickly. Sadly nothing we ordered, save one dish, was very interesting.

The star of the evening was the halibut cheeks. My god this dish is amazing! I seriously think I'd go back for this dish alone. I mean, where else in the city can you get halibut cheeks?

I've also heard they have a good burger, but was upset that it wasn't on the menu when I was there. Is this just a brunch item? Can anyone confirm?

I wonder if I can get halibut cheeks and a burger for brunch.  ;-)
author: Brad L.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the City. The bar is classic and some of the best people watching in town, they mix a great cocktail here. A former roommate used to tend bar here and she is an artist with a martini. Over the years I have gone through most of the menu. But the chicken is classic. You can judge how good a kitchen a restaurant has by their chicken and Zuni does it very well. 

But it is the burgers that keep me coming back, I often work late and a burger at the bar here is a real treat. I have only had impeccable service but I don't usually have many service issues.
author: Seamus M.

description:
Prepare to wait, and wait, and wait some more.  I highly suggest you make reservations like a year in advance.  Well maybe not, but rsvps are highly recommended.   Otherwise you'll be waiting 1.5 hours standing by the bar in strappy stilettos, complaining about how much your feet is hurting, how this is soooo not worth it, and it really wasn't .

Everyone knows that the Zuni Chicken with currant bread stuffing is their signature dish, but it was just standard for me. The chicken was dry & bland. Even the dark meat was hard to swallow.  We also ordered an appetizer of Nicose olives, and the Caesar salad.  Again, it tasted standard.  It was nothing out of the ordinary. 

In short, food is ok. Great customer service. Cozy ambiance,  and KILLER Navarro Grape Juice!  I would of had similar results at home with a Costco Rotisserie chicken and Kedem's kosher grape juice.
author: Nancy G.

description:
Could someone please explain the hype to me about this place?  We got at 11:30 right when they opened.  There was already a line and because we didn't have reservations we could only sit at the cafe.  Fine, not a big deal.

First we ordered the Caesar Salad.  This is a decent size and we split this.  However, I took about two bites and realized it was VERY strong on the anchovy side.  I couldn't eat anymore of it.  My boyfriend got lucky and he really enjoyed it.  I, however, would prefer to pay the same price for a salad 3 times the size at Za.  But that's just me.

Next we decided to split the famous $13 hamburger and an additional $6 fries.  Ridiculous I know.  The hamburger was good.  Definitely could taste the quality.  It came on Focaccia bread.  The aoli was garlicky and very good.  But the size wasn't worth $13.  It came with gourmet pickles and pickled onions and a little field greens lettuce on the burger.  Nothing else.  In fact you could have more things, but they cost an additional $2+.

Next came our shoe string fries.  I personally prefer them a little thicker.  Just my taste.  You do get quite a few, but then I hope since you're paying an additional $6.

All in all, i never plan on going back here again, unless my imaginary rich friend takes me here and money isn't an object and even then I would prefer somewhere else.  Not worth the money for the food at all.  Atmosphere was nice, slightly chilly but they had wonderful Christmas decorations up.  The service was OK.  Really I would give this place 2 1/2 stars but am feeling generous with 3.

Once again, I still am trying to figure out the hype on this place.
author: Rachel S.

description:
Zuni fully deserves it reputation as a San Francisco institution. Great, bustling atmosphere, fantastic service, and the food...can I say amazing?

We started with a dozen oysters, which were extremely fresh and really buttery. They were out of kumamoto oysters, but our kick ass server was able to suggest something that was just as good, if not better. She also suggested a fantastic (albeit expensive) Chardonnay. Worth every penny.

For those of you who gave Zuni anything less than four or five stars, go back, and try the chicken for two. That alone should change your mind on Zuni. Best chicken I've EVER had...I make roast chicken all the time, and I suddenly feel ashamed for what I'm putting on the table.

We finished with a lovely lemon tart...the crust was perfect. Loved it.

Oh, and if you ever go for brunch, try a bloody mary. Best in the city.
author: Brianne K.

description:
It was very good. Wasn't the best meal I had, but still overall tasty. A group of us went this morning at noon. I ordered the lamb crostini and it wasn't bad. We had four of their hour long wait chicken. It was worth the wait I'd have to say but I didn't eat much of it because by then we had so much food. We also ordered one of every dessert, 2 of Gâteau Victoire with whipped cream. 

The design of the restuarant was simple but great. I love brick walls in a place. It makes it look rustic. 

Service was great. The 2 gentlemen that help us were very nice and smiled. Always refilled my water which is always a plus for me.
author: Josephine S.

description: great oysters, best caesar, great ambiance, service is perfect, best martinis + my son really likes the bread - just a special place
author: Sarkis S.

description:
I've dreamed of going to Zuni for a really long time.  Twelve years ago, when I first moved here as a penniless young music store employee, I read that Zuni had the best burger in the world.   I'm a HUGE fan of a good burger, so that really go my attention.  Unfortunately, I didn't have the money for that kind of food.

A few years later, I read an article about Zuni's "perfect" roast chicken. I am also a HUGE fan of roasted chiecken.  I still didn't have any money.

A few more years passed and I read about their stellar caesar salad. As I'm sure you can guess, I'm a HUGE fan of a caesar salad.  Unfortunately, I heard that their service was snooty.  I can't stand snooty service.

A couple of weeks ago, I decided it was time to finally head out to Zuni - to unravel the mystery and eat some of this perfect food.  I didn't have the burger or the chicken.  I had a special appetizer highlighting fresh pressed olive oil, the truly perfect caesar, ricotta gnocchi and the hanger steak.  The food lived up to the hype and the service was AMAZING.  It can't be easy to run such a tight ship in that warren of little rooms, but the do an outstanding job.  I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Robyn H.

description:
I had the Zuni hamburger for lunch today.  I truly think it may have been the best burger I've ever eaten.  The shoestring fries (which, to be honest, should simply come with the burger, not as a side to be purchased) were underwhelming.  

But, oh, that burger.  Worth the $13.

4.5 stars
author: Todd X.

description:
This place is mediocre at best...

The steak I ordered was overcooked and dry...  The service was passable but not good enough for a somewhat pricey restaurant.  I will say that I liked the specialty cocktails they offered.  In the end, I just wasn't satisfied.    I don't see how Zuni has been around so long.
author: Alexander T.

description:
Delish!

Dinner here was totally awesome. Started off with some fresh oysters because well - it is Zuni after all. 

We had a great bottle of wine, although i can't remember what it was which is too bad cuz it rocked!

For dinner i had a beef tagine thing with chicpeas - delicious, meat fell apart on my fork. one of the people i went with had the pork chop - that might even have been better!

Great place, you should definitely go (although don't order a jack and coke - the bartender will make fun of you)
author: Adam W.

description:
The roasted chicken and bread salad is one of the best dishes I've eaten anywhere.  You will lay awake at night fantasizing about that dish and drool all over yourself.  You will be compelled to try and recreate it at home.  You will not succeed.  You will have to return to have it again and the wait time is more excruciating with every visit.  It is more addictive than heroine.
Oh, and the lunch time burger is the best in town.
author: C. W.

description: $12.50 for a glass of wine (least expensive), so expectations are running high.  I was 15 minutes too early for the dinner menu, so got the late-lunch menu with maybe 3 things to choose from.  Got the burger, way overcooked, served with toasted focaccia?  No way to eat that elegantly, other than open-face.  Also there is some 4% surcharge for some charity.  I guess you really need to have some first good experiences at Zuni to keep you coming back.   Pretentious.
author: Jonathon C.

description: I really enjoyed this place. The burger was amazing, oysters were fantastic...I def want to get the cookbook!
author: J D.

description: Zuni's is probably the best restaurant in San Francisco you can go to without the feeling that the staff is looking down on you. I feel comfortable here and the people watching is an added attraction. The pace can be really leisurely if you want it. The food is always excellent. This is where I go to splurge. The valet service is virtually 4 feet away. The 5 star rating is my impression of say 5 visits. Only one of those visits was the service so leisurely and uncomfortable that we almost missed a theater curtain.
author: Gasper S.

description:
Zuni Cafe, 
    The chicken for two is very tasty, worth every cent that they charge. However everything else seems overpriced for the quality, $15 for a hamburger? If you want fries another $6 for a large plate? If you want cheese or onion's another $1.50-$2 for each topping? $25 dollar hamburger seems pretty overpriced for a casual overly hyped place. 

With these high prices the service would be expected to be better than what it was.
author: Seth D.

description: The Zuni chicken is all that, super succulent foul at it's finest, hot f'ing damn it's the best chick you'll ever have. Yes, it does take an hour but well worth it. The Zuni pizza on the other hand, which is only served during lunch, not so great. Sorry Judy, can't win em all.
author: casey c.

description: I love italian food and this was pretty good. I have been twice. I like the atmosphere, oven and bar is really cool, always nice to start with a prosecco there. Roast chicken is one of their speciality, go for it, I think chicken is a bit "common", but they make it good, almost as good as delfina. The plates are not overful, like in Italy, but food prepared with care, some desserts were surpisingly yummy too. Much better than A16, not quite as good as delfina.
author: Jef C.

description:
I heart Zuni!  Roasted chicken w/bread salad - are you kidding me?!?   When we go, usually with another couple, we all order an entree and the roasted chicken to share with the table.....a MUST have.  Oysters, yum! Caesar salad, ummm yes please!  Polenta with mascarpone - sure, why not!  The waiters are delightful and the decor is urban chic.

I feel sorry for the other restaurants in the City - because if you are like me - you have a million places to choose from but then it always ends up "do we want to chance having a so-so experience, I think not - let's go to Zuni".  You will not and never be disappointed!
author: Mrs. S.

description:
Question- Does God have a recipe book?
Answer- Yes
Question- Who has it?
Answer- Zuni Cafe!

The roasted chicken and fries will shift your paradigm and your expectations from having those things anywhere else again.

The chicken comes out in this ginormous bowl on top of the most simply delicious bread salad. So perfect, tender, and moist with amazingly crispy thin skin.Ours was salted perfectly and the tangy buttery goodness of the bread salad was the perfect balance. 

The fries defy nature in that they stayed warm the entire time they were on our table! Given how thin and delicate they are that is amazing. They are so flavor full with no hint of oiliness at all. 

We also had a great salad and anchovy/parm/olive appetizer that were very good but I only have the chicken on my mind.

The service was very nice and well paced we were there later on a Sunday night and never felt rushed at the end. Yes the chicken does take an hour and they make no exceptions to letting you order it earlier but it is totally worth the wait  and not a place you would want to rush dinner anyway.

All I can say in the end is that this dinner was worthy of the perfect day I had preceding it and my date and I had a finger licking good time.

If you don't try this place you are truly missing out.
author: Trixxi T.

description:
Zuni is like your bi-polar friend.  When it's good, it's very, very good, but when it's bad, duck and cover.  And you never know what you're going to get.

Strike 1: I took the family from out of town.  My brother got stung by a bee (yes, the small yellow and black striped creatures that pollinate flowers) in the dead of winter.  I don't blame the insect.  I blame Zuni for not doing a thing about it except giving us a free salad.  And yes, we asked to speak to the manager.  

Strike 2: Friends and I went for brunch.  The bloody maries that are supposed to be great were anything but.  The minced scallion dollop made the "ketchup" in my glass potable....barely.  The wait staff was extremely inattentive and questioned our order.  We initially ordered 3 bloody maries, one for each member of the party.  When we were brought ONE bloody mary (this was before we had tasted them) we told the server that we ordered 3, explaining that every memeber of the party wanted a drink at brunch.  She told us she would have to check with our real server.  

Redeeming factor: the chicken.  Seriously.  The ridiculously priced ($48 for a cut-up chicken) meal is ridiculously good and has saved Zuni, in my mind, from a single star.  (Note: I did not have the chicken at either occasion listed above.)
author: elizabeth b.

description: Rude service. We called ahead of time for an open table and were told it would take a half hour. We get there and told a table would take an hour and half. Meanwhile if u went on open table a reservation was available ahead of their estimated wait time.  We confronted the hostess on this issue and she just shrugged her shoulders. Never coming here.
author: Hoai N.

description:
Some of the best chicken I've ever had!!!

As many others have mentioned make sure to order it the moment you get in the door! I have even asked if I can order it over the phone before coming in but they won't let you.
author: yoni s.

description: I came here with my boss who highly recommended this place.  I wanted to like this place more than I did.  I would like to contributed my dissatisfaction to what I ordered; spaghetti with chickpeas: just okay.  The brick chicken dish looked delightful.  In short, happy with experience at Zuni Cafe and would recommend Brick Chicken, which they suggest you share with companion.  BTW: there a 4% health insurance surcharge on the top of the  bill.
author: ira b.

description:
Lovely place for dinner on a warm spring/summer night with friends and loved ones. The lighting comes through on all floors of this eclectically shaped restaurant, and the white wide windows and white tables/walls make the place seem very light and airy, despite the seemingly haphazard seating as this place is more tall than wide. There is a large bar downstairs as well, for those just wanting to enjoy a break.

Our table of three showed up today around 5 or so and were seated right away, no need to wait. We immediately ordered the roast chicken so that the hour wait would fly by. Our table ordered bloody marys and they were unique - diced onions and peppers in the drink itself! Don't see that very often!

Next, we ordered Hog Island Kumamoto oysters, the shoestring fries (in honor of Adam Savage, who supposedly likes the fries here), the lamb shoulder, and the caesar salad. The salad was alright, nothing special. Oysters were fresh and as expected. The shoestring fries were great - a mountain of fries with just the right amount of salt. The lamb shoulder was tender and fell apart and came with deliciously cooked cauliflower and some sort of green mush that was probably beans at some point. 

Now, the chicken - the leg was super tender and the flavor of the skin rich. But even more than the chicken, I LOVED the bread salad - think of thick chunks of the inside of breads, covered in balsamic and oil and cooked/baked to perfection. Ahh. I will continue to dream of this bread salad.

Loved the experience, I can see why it's a top restaurant.
author: Katherine P.

description:
I hate feeling ripped off. I hate spending $170 on dinner and leaving a restaurant STILL hungry. I hate restaurants that don't live up to all the hype. I hate when everyone tells you, "You gotta try the burger," and when you try to order it, the waitress tell you no...sorry...we're just stopped serving it 5 minutes ago...then I look at a nearby table and see a woman chowing down on said burger.  "But she's eating one.  Why can't I order one, too?"  Computer says "no."

So, instead, I ordered the beef with root vegetables for $31.  When it came, I thought it was an appetizer. It was tiny...small...only 4 small, silver-dollar-sized medallions with maybe a half cup of roasted veggies on a huge plate. Each medallion was one single bite - 4 bites for $31???  I felt so ripped off, cheated, let down, kicked in the gut. 

This is one of those places that's always so crowded that the owners feel like they can get away with charging whatever they want.  I suppose they can. Zuni has been open for years and it's as popular as ever.  But, there are MUCH better restaurants in the City that cost less and serve better food than Zuni (try Salt House or 2223 or Mecca or Home, for that matter). If you are going to spend this much money on dinner, heck, go to Jardiniere.

When we arrived, we had to wait a few minutes, so I ordered a couple drinks from the bar. Damn, were those bartenders mean...rude...angry. No smiles, no thank you's, no "what can I get you"...nothing. Just dirty looks, like they hated their jobs.

I only give Zuni two stars because our waitress was helpful and nice and apologetic about not being able to serve us a burger. And she turned me on to a decent sparkling, lemon infused cocktail.  

NEVER AGAIN!
author: Bubbles S.

description:
I went to see a small private improv show tonight with a couple of friends at a place up the street.  My friends decided to call it an evening and head home to watch some movies.  I declined the offer to join them because my brain was primed for something a little more spontaneous.  If I am going to watch a movie, I am going to do that at a movie theatre or curled up on my own sofa with sweats or pjs on.  

So, I parted ways with my friends and meandered toward Van Ness, along Market Street, and came upon Zuni.  I haven't been there in about 6 months so I decided I would go in and have a little bite and see what the evening had in store for food and maybe some interesting people.  

The hosts' at the door were super friendly and very helpful.  I would say Rob was the shining personality of the evening of all the staff I encountered.  He was just super real.  He didn't seem to have to try hard to be helpful - he just was.  He suggested I sit in the dining room even though I was alone because there might be more to watch since the bar was pretty slow.  He was right.  (And when I left he made sure to wish me a great evening).

The dining room proved to be the perfect spot.  After a few minutes two gentlemen were seated at a table very close - Ken and Lawrence - Graphic artist and writer.  Lawrence was the more gregarious of the two, yet Ken was still very friendly as well.   They were a couple of really nice guys that made dinner much more enjoyable.  It's always nice to have a little company for dinner.  But when you don't, try being friendly to the people around you.  You just might meet some nice interesting people.  

I was really hoping that tonight Zuni's would have something that would just kick my taste buds ass.  I had some oysters (Discovery Bay), a little green salad and the lamb.  The oysters were good and fresh.  Everything was prepared well and tasted good.  Unfortunately, my taste buds were so ready for a taste sensation that just didn't occur.  It was good!!!  Good in the way that you would expect it should be for the amount of money you are spending.  Of course I'll go back - I always do.  The quality is consistent and you know you will get a good meal.  I won't go back when my taste buds are screaming for something exciting.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Chef Judi Rodgers rocks my world. Why?
1. The ricotta gnocci. Little pillows of goodness. Amazing.
2. Pots de Creme.
3. Oysters.
4. Chicken for 2.
5. Check out her cookbook, the woman has theories and WAYs of doing things - salt early, for example, how to roast. Her menu shows her way.
author: Paige B.

description:
Finally had the chance to try #1 on the Big Eat SF 2009 list on Cinco de Mayo:

#1: Roast chicken and bread salad from Zuni Café.  After reading multiple Yelp reviews and taking a brief glance at the menu, we ordered the chicken immediately after being seated, knowing it was going to take an hour to arrive.  Ok, so maybe $48 for  of a roasted chicken is a bit steep, but this chicken is one of the most spectacular roasted chickens I've ever had at a restaurant.   My cousin and I split it, but I'm pretty sure I could also easily be split between 3 people.  It was so juicy and tender...and I roast a lot of chickens and know it's hard to keep the white meat tneder; you barely even had to use your knife!  The bread salad was kind of hidden underneath the chicken, but that was definitely fine with me.  Those moist, delicious, delicate pieces of bread tasted soooo yummy, they must have been baking inside the chicken while soaking up all the juices and flavor.  I'm still not sure it was worth $48 though, when I know a 3-4 lb chicken at Safeway costs less than $10.  

We started off with 12 oysters from 3 different regions and our other diner ordered the quail, which was quite good!  The timing with the quail and chicken was a bit off, but our server profusely apologized and gave us free risotto while we waited and free dessert at the finish of our meal, so that definitely made up for it.  

In general, the ambiance and service was great!  I loved sitting upstairs listening to the piano and gazing outside onto Market street through the wine/liquor bottles that line the windows.   I have to say Zuni Café is definitely foodie heaven and I can't wait to take my parents here during their next visit to San Francisco!
author: Jenny W.

description:
Zuni rotisserie chicken: Noah, after loading all the animals onto the arc.

"Let me introduce you to my wife Dolores. Animals, this is Dolores.  Dolores, the animals. First, a  few rules. Animals, no eating each other. Except chickens. They are delicious, I brought extras."

Sorry, a comedy routine I heard on Marc Maron's WTF podcast.

Well, the chicken is okay at Zunis. But you can't bet your menu on it. Took my crew there today, my 5th xmas lunch at Zunis. Yawn.
author: k m.

description:
My all time favourite restaurant in san fran - the food is consistently great, so I love bringing people here - even if I always order the roasted chicken. 

This is also a great place for a late Sunday hamburger - very mellow and relaxed.  And it's open late - what a treat in San Francisco
author: Wasim A.
