description: Get the oysters and the roasted chicken.  Mmmm so good!  And the service was excellent!  Reservations are and must, and remember that the chicken takes a while to cook.
author: Chanida A.

description:
$40 for Chicken?  I don't know about that.  I generally never order chicken.  Chicken?  $40 for what can be potentially very dry, bland, and well banal?    I didn't really want to do it, but my brother raves about this place.  My boyfriend and I were hesitant, but did it anyway, a little nervous about spending that much money on chicken.  

The menu is rather small...but it seems that everyone orders the same thing.  Oysters, Caesar Salad, and Chicken.  

It's funny.  We were starving by the time we got there so we were a bit hesitant to wait so long for the chicken.  We ordered the oysters, caesar salad, and chicken.  We were getting antsy, especially since everyone orders the same thing!  Everytime the waiter walked by, we were convinced that he was carrying our food!  

Okay, I'm all over the place.  Forgive me, I have a terrible cold and apparently it's affecting my attention span.  Okay!   

So we finally get the food.  Oysters?  Delectactable!!!!  The Caesar?  Unlike any creamy Caesar crap you've ever had.  It hits the spot.  Really.  And finally the chicken...the $40, 45 minute chicken.  And wow, it's the best chicken I've ever had.  It was moist and juicy, and well marinated.  It was extremely satisfying and well worth the wait.  Oh...and the fries.  Oh the fries.  

We finished the meal off with a white nectarine tart with vanilla bean ice cream...and wow...it blew my mind.  My boyfriend left to use the restroom and there was nothing left by the time he got back.  He literally had one small bite.  I don't know what happened, but i couldn't control myself.  I may have licked the plate, i don't know.  Luckily he's known me for some time, and loves me dearly--or else i think he may of throttled me.  

The waitress thought it was amusing, and gave us free coffee to round out our meal.  thanks! 

I honestly don't have a bad thing to say about this place.  I've read a few reviews that complain about the customer service, but i found it outstanding.  My water glass was never empty and they checked on us frequently.  I thought everyone was just lovely.  

It's really just an adorable establishment.  The loft layout is just charming.  and I must say, i had a great time just people watching. The crowd is so well dressed and chic.  

I make a point to eat at Zuni Cafe everytime i make a trip up north.  Try it...just once and you'll love it!
author: Angela T.

description:
Zuni is by far one of my favorite restaurants in the city. 

You must order the chicken with bread salad. Just try it. Just once. You'll thank me. And if you don't like it, you'll never have to get it again, but I bet you will love it. 

The warm bread salad is amazing. The burger is delicious. Pot de creme is my favorite desert of theirs. Try to make a reservation (may be very hard to get a table) but you can try to sit at the bar. 

I love the bustling open kitchen and the various levels and seating nooks/tables in the restaurant. Lots of windows, amazing food, changing but consistent menu. Great place to go with 3-5 people. Get the chicken people. Get the chicken!
author: Lily M.

description:
I was debating whether to give Zuni three stars or four stars when I realized that (a) I've not been there in quite a while, and (b) I'd rather go to Nopa than Zuni Cafe. I think Nopa is doing a better job than Zuni Cafe with a similar menu and concept. Maybe if prices were lower or the restaurant was closer, I'd think differently.

Having said that, I do think the food is good here. It's also a good place to meet for drinks and appetizers because of their Market Street location (provided no one in your group is driving).
author: Timothy O.

description:
So, I had a reservation for three and by the time 8:45PM had rolled around, my group had become five.  The host smiled, explained it would take a few extra minutes, but that would accommodate us.  That was the beginning of a great dining experience.

Two of the five of us had ordered a dish that unfortunately had sold out by the time our waiter put our order in.  To appease, they offered us two entrees on the house.

The food was delicious.  The polenta was the best that I've had and my friend mentioned that his burger (off the menu) was the best he's had in the city and another friend was equally pleased with his sea bass.

When I stepped away from my espresso (to have a moment), the host offered to make me a new one, in case mine had become cold!  I didn't think they had service like this in the U.S. anymore.

Very pleasant experience.  Inexpensive for the level of food & service and it's been in business for about 27 years (which I learned from the very proud bartender).
author: Neha S.

description:
I appreciate all the details such as the copper bar, and just the way the restaurant is situated.  I also appreciate it's location as it is conveniently located on Market Street so it allows you to soak in the love of Downtown SF.  

Let's be short and succinct:

Reginald, who took care of us, sang a one-of-a-kind, improv, birthday song for the birthday girl.  He was also attentive; he brought a fresh Iced tea to my friend before she even had the chance to order another.  You've got to love that.  

The staff, in general, was attentive, as our plates were cleared, and our utensils replaced when it was appropriate to do so.  Our glasses were refilled as needed.  

I, personally, had the steelhead salmon.  Delicious, fresh, cooked to perfection; I don't like my salmon overcooked.  

The chicken, which we all shared, was moist, seasoned and cooked to perfection, and I LOVE the bread sitting under the chicken, which ends up being drenched in all the juicy goodness.  I can see, and taste, why it ended up on the 7X7 list of things to try before you die.  

I'd love to visit again for brunch, and try the oysters.
author: Desiree V.

description: WAYYY OVERRATED. Well made food and good staff, but nothing special. Didn't taste anything I would order again. Tons of places I'd rather go. Terrible beer selection. If it wasn't really expensive, would have at least given it 3 stars, but at these prices I should at least want to go there again.
author: Garrett G.

description:
Delicious. My first trip to Zuni completely lived up to my expectations. Went on a weekday evening around 10pm and got a table for two with less than a ten minute wait. We sat upstairs- warm and charming interior- romantic without being overly formal or stuffy. 

Our server was friendly and helpful. The wine was tasty and went well with our entree- the chicken of course. The ceasar salad to start was the best Caesar I have ever had- crispy and perfectly dressed.  Gnocchi puffs were heavenly and the chicken still makes me drool just thinking about it. 

If you want a nice meal in the city, this is one of the best out there. Prices are reasonable for the quality of food and service. 

I can't wait to go back soon.
author: Mindy S.

description:
A solid 4 to 4.5 stars. I recently had dinner here and enjoyed a truly excellent meal.

We went all out and ordered the items that Zuni is famous for: the bloody mary, Caesar salad, shoe string french fries, and the Zuni roast chicken with bread salad. 

The bloody mary was bloody delicious. The flavor was so fresh, spicy, and flavorful. I enjoyed it immensely. My fiance was a little put off by the minced red onion in the drink but I loved this drink. 

The Caesar salad was fantastic. The dressing was very good, the romaine lettuce fresh, the croutons crunchy and tasty. 

The shoe string potatoes were like crack: we couldn't stop eating them! The fries are very thin and crispy. 

The roast chicken...my god the roast chicken...Incredibly delectable. The chicken is so moist and juicy, perfectly roasted. The bread salad complements it very nicely and the bread chunks soak up the delicious dressing and chicken juices. The pine nuts and currants are surprisingly mild in flavor. This is probably the best roast chicken I've ever eaten. It truly lived up to its hype and was absolutely worth the one hour wait.

Though we were thoroughly stuffed, we had to try a dessert and ordered the caramel pot de creme. This dessert was richly flavored but not too heavy. Loved it.

The atmosphere is casual and lively. The service was friendly and efficient.

Fantastic!
author: Jenny K.

description: I don't typically order chicken when I go out but there is something almost magical about how Zuni makes their chicken, served whole and over a bed of greens and croutons. I usually review a restaurant only after I try a few items on a menu, but I have ordered the chicken every time without fail. So, yes I am giving five stars to Zuni based solely on one dish which seems ridiculous.
author: Chanthi L.

description:
You're right again, Yelpers.  Could a roast chicken be THAT good?  I've had roast chicken from Costco that was pretty good for $12.  But the roast chicken from Zuni is THAT GOOD.  My wife who normally considers eating chicken breast akin to eating glass shards happily devoured a piece of breast.  The grilled bread was great too.  We also liked the ricotta gnocchi: soft and flavorful.  The shoestring fries was super yummy and I couldn't help myself from eating a fry every 20 seconds.  We had a party of 3 and ordered the anchovies, gnocchi, fries and roast chicken.  That was definitely enough food! 

One note: we knew we HAD to try the roast chicken and it's an hour wait, so we called ahead to see if we could "preorder" it.  The girl laughed uncontrollably.  Geeze, can blame a guy for trying!  However, first thing we did when we sat down was to order that damn tasty bird!!!
author: Tim L.

description:
Our family has been going to Zuni's since the 1990's. We went for the oysters, Caesar Salad and roasted chicken. Pricey but good. Over the years, we tried other things, and its been hit or miss. But I would not rate it a 4 star even at its best in recent years.

Last week, our party had the usual Caesar Salad, which was good but not outstanding. We've had better-at less pricey establishments. For the entrees, the steak was tough, although prepared as we ordered, medium rare. The tuna was fishy. The only good thing was the rabbit leg. 

I give this experience two stars because of the desserts-the date ice cream and the biscotti. 

I think our family will give Zuni a rest for a while.
author: L G.

description:
It would be 3.5 stars really.

Had lunch there on a Friday outside because it was a beautiful day.  Service was perfect and very friendly.  Several servers participated in our meal, which could be expected since we began our lunch at around 2:30pm.  It's a pretty restaurant with "good" tables in a few places which is hard for many places.

We started with Oysters - kumamoto, hog island and a Washington state oyster recommended by the server.  The kumamoto was okay, the hog island was salty for an oyster, and the Washington was VERY good.

The burger was perfectly cooked, the pickles that come with unique and perfect for the meat.  I had gruyere added - it definitely worked.

My date had the Mozzarella, Prociutto pizza - it was very flavorful and filling - but not too much. 
We passed on dessert, enjoyed our Bloody Mary's (the minced onions were a very nice touch).
It's not cheap, but it's pretty good and fairly consistent so I hear.  I'll probably go back before year's end.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
With 479 reviews already posted at the time of writing this review, I'm wondering what other nuggets of information I can contribute that hasn't yet been discussed.  

--  Half hour waiting time for a super duper early Saturday 5pm dinner leads my mind to thought such as "That roasted chicken better be good!"
--  Admirably good usage of space for table placements in a rather awkwardly shaped area.  There are two seaters tables right next to each other and even single tables with unobstructed views to Market.
--  The view to the open kitchen gives the feeling of dining at the comfort of your own home without having to cook or wash afterwards.
--  The first floor's wall partition from the bar area is great as it keeps the noise and pressure of a crowd away from the line of vision for the diner.

I know that they're known for the 1-hour roasted chicken.  But, I personally loved the burger which was cooked medium rare.  It was juicy and just delicious.

$52 for a couple appetizers, two entrees (including the big chicken that took 1 hour to cook,) dessert (Gateau Victoire,) and a bottle of wine.  I'm not complaining especially when I'm leaving the place with a full stomach!
author: Ginni S.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city. People write a lot about the chicken, and anything hyped too much makes it hard to live up to expectations, but personally it is one of those dishes in SF that I actually remember and want to have again and makes me go back. That said, if the restaurant were otherwise bad, this wouldn't be enough to make me go back. But, every time we've been here the service has been great, attentive, and we've had a great time. This is a place that my wife and I love to go to later in the evening when other restaurants are closed (after 9) and we want a fun dinner. Also, at that time, it is easier to get in and is more relaxed. There's also a wine bar down the street that's nice to go to if you have to wait for your table. 

Honestly, this is one of my all-around favorite restaurants in SF and I've probably been to a few hundred at this point after living here a while. Zuni Cafe is a great option that is unlikely to disappoint.
author: Alex R.

description:
The definitive SF dining experience. I've loved Zuni for the wood-burning oven, the zinc bar and the food, of course, since my first visit a few years back. Praise of the roast chicken is a cliché but I can say with certainty that this dish will be my last meal if I ever have to leave SF. My girlfriend feels the same way. Good thing the chicken comes for two. 

My second favorite tradition at Zuni is going for the famous Zuni burger just a shade after 10pm on Sunday nights. I make my ritual journey for the burger this late because the burger is only served after 10pm and at brunch. 

The Zuni burger is made with chuck that is salt cured and chilled for 24 hours to retain juiciness. I've yet to have another burger as juicy. My hat goes off to Judy Rodgers for making such a commanding burger pop with the use of the simplest seasoning, salt. The focaccia bun sops up the juices from the burger well and the pickled onions are a masterful touch. One of the true pleasures in life is this morsel of meat.

The polenta, Caesar salad, oysters and shoestring fries are also good fare. I almost always opt to finish my meal with the pot de creme. 

If you'd like to experience the best classic California dining SF has to offer, Zuni is the way to go.
author: Adam L.

description: Zuni Cafe is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I've been coming here for years and the food is always consistently fantastic!!! Service is alway impecable. Please don't ever change anything.
author: Jerry O.

description:
Great atmosphere.

great place to sit and have drinks while you wait for a table.

Always great service even though they are generally very busy.

Do yourself a favor and get the Brick Oven Roasted Chicken for 2. It takes a long time for them to cook but its so worth it.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Blaaaaah.

I came here moderately drunk after the fillmore jazz fest to meet up with my mom and 6 of her lady friends for dinner... obviously not the most ideal saturday night dinner plans I could imagine, but I gave it my best shot.

Zuni cafe on the other hand... did not.  It took a solid 30 minutes after our reservation to actually get seated.  The food was pretty mediocre for the price and the hype.  What's with the 6 hour wait for the chicken by the way... I could go over to pollo loco for the same quality at 1/15th the cost in about 2 minutes.  By far the most overrated restaurant I've been to.  Even my sober mom and her friends weren't impressed... and that was after their high of seeing jersey boys.

I would never go there again... unless they dropped their prices and improved their dishes.  

The only real positives were the atmosphere and the waitstaff who were great.... but not worth the experience at all.
author: Jeff G.

description:
Seriously. GO TO THIS PLACE.
Amazing from beginning to end, my girlfriend and I were so happy when we left that we felt sedated.
Great coffee, which is not important to some, but I don't care to know those kinds of people...
Great service.
Great ambiance; not pretentious but classy, LOVE the copper bar and the huge woodfire oven in the middle of the floor.
We got the scrambled eggs with house-made fennel sausage (to die for), the soup of the day (nom nom), and then finished up with the french toast with huckleberries. 
Seriously. GO TO THIS PLACE.
author: Jeni E.

description: Just go and order the darn chicken like everyone says!  You won't regret it!  And if someone at the table starts to talk about how pricey it is compared to roasted chickens you can buy at the grocery store, you have my full permission to slap them!
author: Tammy S.

description: a late night must- a little cold inside but consistently good food!
author: Sarah A.

description:
I am a San Francisco girl, and I fell in love with Zuni Cafe all over again tonight...

Let me just say that my CURRENT favorite place to eat and drink in the whole world is a few blocks from where I live, in the Mission - Range.  But tonight I ventured OUTSIDE of the Mission with my fabulous life partner and our fabulous friends from Austin, Texas, and we went to Zuni Cafe.

From the moment we arrived, it was good SF energy all over.  A fabulous bar, with my favorite Vodka (Hangar One), and a surprisingly friendly hostess who was more than ok with things when our friends were a bit late...even though they were clearly busy.

It got even BETTER when we got to our table, which was in a fantastic private room that I didn't even know existed (how lucky were we???)

The SERVICE was AMAZING...friendly, down-to-earth, and yet professional... Christopher, with his fabulous sense of humor and his equally fabulous and sharp tie are hard to beat, even in this town, and even with a Range fanatic....! Truly fabulous! Great food recommendations, great timing, and he just seemed to know what we needed and when we needed it, right down to our San Pelligrino H2O moments (yes, silly  and perhaps pretentious to say, but TRUE, and you know it!)

The food was GREAT - we had the Skate (oh my god - have you ever had SKATE before?) We also had the famous Caesar of course, and these amazing gnocchi and fava beans that I can't even begin to describe (you just had to be there...)

The wine was SO reasonably priced and so yummy...Roche Carneros Pinot...and what a value. It was so reasonably priced we were almost afraid to order it, but  when it arrived we were MORE than seriously pleasantly surprised...it was fantastic!  So fantastic that we ordered a second bottle... that good...really!

Desserts were fun (we highly recommend going with Christopher's excellent recommendation of the Espresso Granita- wow!), but our favorite part of the entire evening was when Christopher spent a few minutes at our table and shared a bit about his story and how he arrived in San Francisco. It is these moments that make us PROUD to be SF residents, and THRILLED to be in a fabulous and classy restaurant where being human actually still matters!

So - to sum it all up... we HIGHLY recommend Zuni Cafe, and if you are lucky enough to get a reservation, we hope you are able to at least meet FANTASTIC Christopher, and if you are EXTREMELY lucky, you might get to be his customers.

We loved every minute of it and can't wait to go back! And we're asking for Christopher to be our server and hoping they don't mind!!   If we were Michael Bauer, we'd give it 4 stars... if we were Michelin, I think it would be 5 stars, but we're just two lesbians from the Mission (who've been together for close to 10 years and been to more SF restaurants than we can count) and for that, we give it 2 thumbs up, and then some!!  Do not miss the Zuni experience... it is SO worth it...!
author: K. B.

description:
Consistent food.  Consistent crowd.  Service?  Can I get some service?

Neil already said it, but I waited 20 minutes for a diet coke because there was a new bartender at the bar.  Now if a diet coke presents a challenge for the bartender, God help the poor bastard who orders a Madras!?  If I were the server I would have reached over the bar and used the soda gun myself... or at least told my table something like "We are changing over the tank, sorry for the delay....you want some water or iced tea?"  Anyways....

The food is always excellent and the atmosphere is nice.  Great for lunch!
author: Bradford S.

description:
From A to Zuni

It's been awhile since I dined here, and without dating myself too much, it's as fabulous as the first time I visited back in the 80s.  Zuni's winning formula of ambiance, food, wine and service, all adds up to an enjoyable evening from start to finish.  Dinner for two around $150.  Go back?  Surely.

Place: This is probably one of the first light-industrial-zone-turned-restaurants in SF, and it has weathered surprisingly well.  The big glass windows face Market St., now more interesting since the return of the retro streetcars; the exposed brick, the copper-topped bar, the fantastic floral arrangement -- now a classic look.  Despite the high ceilings, the warren of "rooms" feels intimate, although the place tends to buzz quite loudly.  It's always interesting watching the comings and goings of the casual but well-monied crowd (although I must mention that for anyone sitting on the backless benches to beware of wearing low-cut jeans unless you want to reveal your plumber's behind to the world).

Food: Obviously the secret to the long running success is a simple menu, excellent ingredients, expert execution and beautiful presentation.  Although we didn't have time to wait for the famous brick-oven chicken (takes 1 hour to prepare), we did enjoy the renowned caesar salad -- the best in town! with perfectly crisp leaves and balanced dressing -- and the prosciutto, so flavorful but a little strange with the accompanying fresh ricotta .  For entrees, the halibut was perfectly prepared, firm and moist, and the white fish was artfully paired with spring green peeled asparagus and yellow fingerling potatoes; the Liberty Farm duck was tender and earthy, accompanied by fresh gigante beans.  The Victoire cake was a dense, dry concoction of intense cocoa, moistened by freshly whipped cream.  Even the house coffee was good.

Wine:  I recall perhaps having my first bottle of Veuve Clicquot here way back when...  They still serve the bubbly, along with a decent but pricey wine list.  After starting with flutes of champagne -- it always seems like the right starter at Zuni (especially if you order oysters on the half shell) -- we moved on to glasses of wine recommended by the waiter.   

Service:  On this recent visit, service was nice, perhaps due to our earlier reservation (6:30 pm) ahead of the crush of prime time.  The reception was pleasant, a nice change from previously experienced snooty factor.  Our waiter and servers were low-keyed and efficient -- just the way they should be.  And, yes, that 4% additional "tax" for employee healthcare -- annoying but I guess it's the price to pay to live and work in this fantastic (albeit expensive) town.
author: Yan L.

description:
roasted chicken w/ bread salad.. perfect cook on the chicken, but not a fan of how the chicken sits on the bread salad and makes the croutons mushy and wet

burger with beecher's flagship cheese, grilled onions and aioli on rosemary focaccia.. beef patty is one of the best ive ever had but i did not enjoy the focaccia
author: jo jo j.

description: On a quick trip to the City we decided on lunch at Zuni Cafe - WOW, what a great choice. The food was fabulous! We had the burger and the brick chicken as our main course. The chicken took an hour as they note on the menu which gave us time for some oysters and the house cured olives along with enjoying some great French wine.  Everything was excellent.  My wife commented that the meal at Zuni Cafe was in the top 3 meals ever! Now that's a recommendation.
author: Paul K.

description:
Solid good food and spotty service.

We're having lunch and EVERYTHING takes FOREVER!! The server says that because there's anew bartender, the refill on the diet coke (which took 20 min) would be "on her" instead of paying another $3.25 or $3.50 which ever it was.... Um they expect customers to pay over $3 every time they refill diet coke!!??? Are you F-----g kidding me??!!!

The pizza was yummy (wood-fired oven) and the burger was good (not as good as Slow Club though).  The crowd skews to the sorta-pretentious, hipper-than-thou side but over all a good mix of SF/Tourist/wacky-local.

Great bread and nice open space with view into the kitchen.  Easy to get to on Market St.
author: Neil S.

description:
Well, here is my 2 cents...along with all 480 other opinions.

Ambience: We decided last minute to head to Zuni on a Saturday night without a reservation. Fortunately, we had the option to sit in the cafe area near the bar without having to wait 45 minutes for a dining area table. It was a bit chilly by the door, a little more informal and not the ideal spot to bring a first date, but I wasn't on a first date and I was hungry. The best part about sitting here is that the wait staff is always easy to flag down (so to speak). Overall, the restaurant is clean, personable, and nicely lit.

Service: Great, quick, not snooty at all, but that always depends on your server I guess. They were attentive, and made it a point to clear table of empty plates and unused silverware. The waiter was not afraid to give his honest opinion when asked, which I always appreciate. In fact, their service was ahead of me sometimes, which isn't a bad thing.

Food: The Monterey Sardine with the citrus salad was great to start out with. The fries were really stringy and delicious. A bit greasy for my liking though. My fiance and I shared the famous chicken and were thoroughly pleased with it. It had amazing flavor in the skin and perfect crispiness. The meat was tender and moist within. It almost tasted like a great fried chicken, but clearly was not. The stuffing and greens beneath it were really tasty and perfectly compliment the chicken. All in all, we were very satisfied.
author: Michael M.

description: Zuni Cafe has a lovely ambience about it. Despite the interesting dining rooms setup it wasn't claustrophobic-feeling. Service was not amazing by any means, but the food was pretty good - I will warn against ordering the pasta dishes as a main, because despite being well-prepared the portion size was extremely small. Two of us ordered the fabled roast chicken and it really was as good as everyone says. Be sure to try the Aperol cocktail - unique and refreshing.
author: Lisa P.

description: Went do dinner here over the holidays and it was AWESOME!!!  The service was OK, but the food was amazing!  If the service was a bit better, I would have given it 5 stars.  I tried the duck breast pesto appetizer and the roasted rabbit leg since I was feeling a bit adventurous, and they were both perfectly cooked.  Both dishes were moist and flavorful, and it was just the right amount to keep you wanting a bit more but satisfied.  Just the way I like it.  I will definitely be returning to this place again.  I hear they have a daily changing menu so I'll look forward to some more interesting dishes the next time I come!
author: Johnny L.

description: Heavenly roast chicken.  Probably best chicken experience I've had in a long long time.  you'll never regret the one hour slow cooking for this.
author: Woosung A.

description: Very pretentious, service was okay. Do you feel you are important? The staff doesn't.
author: Barbara B.

description:
Best chicken ever.  Hands down.  The Colonel himself would probably find a guilty pleasure in eating this chicken.  I've had a lot of chicken in my life, as a result of which I've mostly stopped eating chicken.  But a highly regarded friend recommended Zuni's oven roasted preparation, and my dry spell became drenched in succulent moistness! 

I had a salad too, which was very good.  And I've heard their fries are amazing, too.  Well, I'm going back, that's for sure.
author: Derek M.

description:
A staple San Franciscan eating experience - what else is there to say?  Great ambiance (particularly downstairs) especially if you are trolling for a nice bite late night SF-style (Zuni's one of the few places that I like who serves real dinners until midnight Tues - Sat) or a late lunch (11:30 - 6pm).  

Their seasonal specials can be mixed.  I always ask my server's for his or her recs before ordering and I haven't been steered wrong yet.  However, some of my dining companions have left disappointed with their culinary combos given their expectations built upon Zuni's reputation and price point.  In my opinion you're never lose out if you have their famed caesar salad, burger or roasted chicken for two!!
author: Cynthia S.

description:
Super hard to get into, we booked our brunch reservation 3 weeks in advance (brunch was the soonest slot available).

We came for the chicken. I wish there was a way to expedite the cooking process a bit, but I'd conclude that it was ultimately worth the wait. The chicken is absolutely lovely, as is the bread salad accompaniment. I started with the frisée salad app, which is also highly recommended.

Our waitress was manicured, polite and attentive. 

We had a grand time watching the 2008 SF Leather Walk procession as it thundered down Market outside our window. How often do you get a delicious meal and a free show?! Our ultra-conservative neighbors one table over were squirming in their seats. It was great.

Great experience all around.
author: Matthew H.

description:
I was told that "I had to get the whole chicken because it was fabulous".  Sorry, but it was just chicken with shoestring french fries.  We made reservations way in advance.  Our table was cramped, even for just 2 people, right next ot the kitchen.  Much of the evening was spent watching the caesar salads being prepared because carrying on a conversation was impossible with the volume of the crowd.

I will go back one more time...only because I trust those who recommended this place originally and every place can have an off night.
author: Mackenzie O.

description:
I dined here while visiting SF from Washington, DC.  Traveling in that direction, I was fully prepared to enjoy excellent food.  The lunch, unfortunately, underwhelmed: my $15 hamburger, after paying $2 extra each for such luxuries as cheese and onions, came out to about $20, which puts it into some pretty rarefied space -- and Zuni didn't deliver.

The service, meanwhile, was atrocious, with us spending a precious hour and a half before my flight to essentially get two thin-crust pizzas and a burger.  I agree with "Trick C." -- I won't be recommending Zuni, given the plethora of alternatives in the city.
author: david h.

description:
7x7's 100 things to eat & drink before you die. [2009].

1.) Roast Chicken and Bread Salad at Zuni

We made a reservation for 8:45pm. The place was busy. Came early. Had a drink at the bar. Bartender-- Fabulous. We had irish coffees and she topped it with fresh whipped cream.

Dinner. We sat upstairs and were all set on this chicken. Chicken for 2 ($48). We heard it takes an hour to cook so ask for it once you're seated. More people were joining us last minute and the staff kindly accommodated us. During the anticipation of the chicken, we had oysters. There was short list on a separate menu of different types of oysters and we had no clue what was what but our server happily made recommendations and it was wonderful.

The server also had wine pairing recommendations to go with our chicken.. also, WONDERFUL. The chicken was worth the wait.. we killed it. The meat just slid off the bone. The bread salad underneath complimented it.. It all vanished.

We had a great time, great food, great service.. 5 stars! And I know what it pain it is to collect several cards for the bill and we caught no flack for it. Everything was perfect.
author: O M G.

description: I recently visited this restaurant on a trip to San Francisco.  I asked all my Facebook friends where I should go to eat and lots of responders said Zuni.  Since everyone was raving about the chicken,  I was very excited to visit the restaurant and eat chicken.  I ordered the chicken and was reminded that it takes an hour.  After looking over the four appetizer options, I didn't find anything I wanted.  So, just to hold us over, I ordered fries.  I had to ask the server if that was ok, because he looked at me like "That's it?"  From that moment on, he was acting completely over it.  That just put a bad taste in my mouth, and it only brewed for the next hour waiting for our chicken.  Despite the service, the chicken was really good. I just wish we had a better server.  If we got a decent server, this review would have at least been 4 star for sure.
author: Meredith K.

description: $47 for a tiny, mediocre hamburger, fries & a salad!! Are you kidding me? And I had to put up w/ a slow, very bitchy waiter. all around unpleasant experience. it used to be good, but Zuni has gone to hell in an uppity handbasket! one star for the nice interior, but I'll never go back.
author: Cricket X.

description: Looks like i should have ordered the Roast Chicken. I had lunch here on Friday with friends, but unfortunately, we were thinking of brunch. This place is in a terrible area (we made the mistake of walking east on Market Street to get there), but the restaurant itself is goregous. Two stories of open windows, really nice setting on a sunny warm day. The staff was attentive, and I loved my prosecco with elderflower cocktail. However, for lunch I had the pizza with ricotta salada, which was really just a crust, tomato sauce, and a spinkling of ricotta cheese, like a giant thin pizza bagel. Between that and the location, I can't say I'd return.
author: Tricia K.

description:
I love their Espresso Granita. 
I love their Oyster selection.
I really like the french fries. 
I really like their Caesar salad. 

But then Zuni's has broken heart one too many times.

Their famous 1-hour roast chicken is not worth the wait.
Their waitstaff is nice but unorganized or operating without a pulled together GM.  I chalked it up to fluke experiences, but after 3 times...
Their burgers have fallen way down. WHAT the heck happened???

Unfortunately, I will not return. I usually go when craving oysters, since it's close to us, but now I'll go to Absinthe or ALL the way to the Ferry Building to Hog Island.  If I'm craving a burger, I'll go to Slow Club or even Barney's, yes, I said it, in Noe.
author: Pixie M.

description:
Tuesday lunch with friends.  The pizzas were done in the uber-thin European style.  They were tasty, but not particularly filling and, to my mind, not worth the $11 and $13 price tags.  My friend's burger was not bad, according to him.  The burger cost $15 and didn't have a side to accompany.  For me, there was clearly a value issue at Zuni.  I'm okay with $13 pizza or a $15 burger, so long as it excels.  These dishes didn't.

Furthermore, we waited an hour for a burger and two pizzas.  To add a wee bit of insult to injury, we were obviously sitting next to some "friend of the restaurant", because multiple servers swung by to make small talk with them (as we patiently waited for our food).  By the time our food had arrived, tables on both sides, seated after us, were well into their meals.

Zuni isn't a disaster, but with so many better choices in SF, I certainly won't be recommending to anyone.
author: Trick C.

description:
When I think back about the best parts of San Francisco, I think about Zuni Cafe. First, the restaurant is beautiful. It's like eating in a really nice treehouse. Some guy told me that he and his wife's first date was at Zuni Cafe. I was jealous--that's how beautiful the restaurant is.

The food is expensive. It's best to eat there on someone else's tab. A law firm paid for my first meal there so I could sit back and enjoy. The second time I ate there, I paid for my dining companion expecting that he'd pay me back later. That bastard still owes me $75. My second Zuni experience was not as pleasant as my first.

If you think of broad swaths of the SF dining scene as a bunch of replicants of Chez Panisse with tiny variations on the general theme, I think it's fair to say that Zuni (founded by Chez Panisse alums) do one of the best and most faithful jobs of that. I dined out three times a day for 2 months in SF, and it ended up amounting to eating much of the same food/flavor profiles/ideologies over and over. But doing it well makes it special and even memorable.
author: Ziggy Y.

description:
I wish I would have written a better review right after I dined there with my 3 out of town guests in early April.

This was one of the best meals I have had in San Francisco, and it was the perfect place to take my guests, especially since one was here for her bachelorette weekend (with the guys).  

We all started with a garden salad, which was perfectly dressed--not too overpowering on the dressing.  Being a big ol' family, we then split the gnocchi (exactly how they got them so fluffy boggles my mind to this very day), the spaghetti (ample portion, was great to split), and the fish (cooked to perfection).  I think we ordered some different entrees, but I can't remember because one of those was the chicken which was out of this world amazing.  W-o-w.  Definitely worth the wait, which didn't seem that long since we ordered the salads and the other items to split.  We also ordered wine, and a friend who was back in Rochester remotely ordered us a bottle of Prosecco to celebrate (apparently it wasn't a problem for her to phone in the request and pay over the phone).

The service was great.  Warm, friendly, accommodating and not all up in our business every minute.  I can't wait to make it back to Zuni.
author: Jason S.

description:
Am I allowed to write a Bloody Mary only rating? Well, no one is stopping me, so I guess I can. While some people are looking for wisdom or enlightenment, I (admittedly as superficial as this sounds) am looking for the perfect Bloody Mary (which, as it turns out, is as hard to find as the perfect man... a completely different, long, sordid story). So when I read that Zuni is known for its Bloody, I had to make a trip down Market to see what the hype was about.

First, though may I ask one random question? Why have a long, gorgeous, copper covered bar, with no bar stools? But that may be as esoteric a wondering why someone made "Herbie Fully Loaded" ... and likely it is best we never know. 

Back to the Bloody. So clearly what they bank on is the sweetness of Balsamic and the spice of finely chopped onion, with a touch of bell pepper. The Balsamic I thought was a bit cloying, for lack of a better word. And the onion? It took me about 3 days to sweat out that onion. If they are going to put that amount of straw clogging, East River (NYC reference) floaters in a drink, then they should serve it with a straw that does not collapse when it comes in contact with liquid (another musing that is just under my Herbie Fully Loaded cogitation). I'm sure the food is good at Zuni, and the fries looked great, but it may take me years of therapy to understand their Bloody Mary and their lack of bar stools.
author: Courtney P.

description:
Went here for a beautiful lunch with great company..;)  I started with the sardine app and he went with the house salad.  My sardines came with a Parm Reg type cheese and olives and instead of using bread I replaced that with the cheese.  It was simple but perfect!  I then went with their Caesar and it was above average with amazing croutons (being a crouton connoisseur).  My dining partner ordered the burger with cheese and onions...YUM!  I loved the focacia and the meat was prepared perfectly.  
We were seated upstairs next to the window with the sun shining in.  Service was not obtrusive, but also not non-existent.  They respected the fact that we were going to sit for awhile (about two hours) and my iced mocha was pleasantly wonderful (being a Seattle coffee snob).  I can't wait when I move to SF to eat here at least once a month for a quiet lunch or perhaps a romantic dinner.
author: Sheila Y.

description: I came here for my birthday and it was a great experience! I had an excellent caesar salad and the best roast chicken I've had in a long time. For desert they brought me delicious chocolate ice cream with a candle in it - no singing of course.
author: Tiffany B.

description:
My friend Jenn and I got the "Luvah's Table" (2-top, with us seated next to each other).  It had a great view of the kitchen, which was great to see.  There is one guy whose sole job is preparing the chickens.  He worked those things like magic, I should definitely order it next time 'round as I am now entranced.

Have you ever had halibut cheeks?  Umalicious!  I don't even remember what else we had, but man, our waiter promised, and those cheeks delivered.
author: Karen C.

description: Choices are limited but all are great! Menu will vary over days, which is another part of the charm. Will go again if there is chance.
author: Ryan C.

description: Enjoyed the ambiance and the food. Great list of Oysters and the brick chicken was delicious!
author: Mike C.

description:
I was hoping that I would love this place, but it didn't quite turn out that way. We had tried to get in on a bunch of occasions, but it seems that you need a reservation.

When we finally planned ahead (a whole three days), we got there about 15 minutes early. We couldn't get seated quite yet, so we ordered drinks at the bar. The selection wasn't fantastic, but they had some interesting beers (I had a Samuel Smith).

We were finally seated upstairs, at a table overlooking the street. I have walked by Zuni literally hundreds of times - it was interesting to get the birds eye view.

The bread was good - the entrees weren't really so much. I had the sand dabs (small bony fish), which were tasty, but the potatoes that came with them left something to be desired. My companion's food wasn't that good (she had bland pasta), and the dessert really wasn't exceptional. The prices were kind of high for what you got.

I would have hoped for a bit more.
author: Dana L.

description:
Zuni. Oh how disappointed I am at thee. 
You have let me down so much, I feel robbed.

So we arrive at the restaurant promptly at about 7pm for our 7:15 reservation. We're told that it'll be about a half hour, great. Bolting towards the bar, I study the wine list and appetizer menu.Order a Redbull Vodka to perk me up... however the bartender hasn't ever heard of such a drink, never the less, serve it. So I order a Martini straight up, with a twist. Pick up the wine list, it's just fine... it's your average pretentious restaurant who likes to order a lot of well known labels both Bordeaux and Californian - and severely overpriced. But then a platter comes our way. Apparently the oyster/shellfish appetizer was ordered for me, so I indulge. It's fantastic.

45 minutes later, we're escorted to our table and I embark on my gastronomic trials of Zuni. Staring with a Lobster Bisque that was more of a chowder than anything else, I hope for something better from a Ceasar Salad. The dressing was far too salty and had a funky tang to it that I wasn't prone to liking in the least. Third course. Hopefully this should be at least satisfactory. We order the Roasted Chicken Dinner for Two. Takes an hour. A full hour. And it's chicken... double you tee eff. 

An hour later it arrives. Mind you after the waitress forgets to come back to refill our wine glasses not once, twice, but three times. The chicken was moist but had no flavor. Basically it tasted like they took a chicken breast, tossed it on the grill, took the skin off, then baked it for another 20 minutes... nothing special. The ambience is cool in Zuni though but definately not worth the $225 bill for two people. Definitely not. I will not be coming back unless it's for just a Martini and some oysters.
author: Anthony B.

description: A great place for superb Italian/mediterranean food, the atmosphere is just amazing with incredible Service and awesome dishes that makes your mouth reached to a state of orgasm. The thing you should really try in Zuni is definitely their famous roast chicken! Is one of their most popular dish and the one hour wait is oh-so worth it
author: Mei Kim P.

description: Diana T's 12/12/2013 review perfectly reflected our (3 person) expectation and experience. The only difference was the new owners moved the "appetizer" duck to a main course...it should have stayed as an appetizer; we searched the nearest bakery cafe after dinner to get something filling that didn't cost $30. each ($195. tab)!
author: Jim M.

description:
You know, I can't really say all that much bad about this place. Everyone's food was good (albeit expensive) and the service was excellent. However, it really just wasn't my scene. It was a total yuppieville, and I think we were the only people under 30 there (except for the precocious children at the table next to me).

Nice to bring your parents to, but I won't be going there again any time soon.
author: Veronica B.

description:
4/5 SERVICE: Nice
4/5 AMBIANCE: Relaxed, Bistro-ish place. 
4/5 FOOD: Pork chop was seasoned to perfection. 
4/5 VALUE: Great place to have excellent service, great atmosphere, and an exceptional meal - the prefect trifecta. 

I give Zuni Cafe 4 strong stars. Why? Because I like to be different from the plethora of reviews this place already has. Plus, it gives me a good reason to re-visit and experience more of their menu. :) This is a great place to relax and have a great meal. A definite winner. 

Eat and Enjoy!
author: Harvey C.

description:
This is a nice looking restaurant on Market Street that serves great food, but a little pricey! The chicken is baked fresh from the oven and you usually have to wait at least an hour for the roasted chicken to be served.. 

We were invited to try this restaurant by the nice mailman at my office (he moonlights as a bartender at Zuni's:)) He even gave us some treats while my friends & I were there..An extra star for the ambience and good service.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Like Laura D. says, just get the chicken! 

Came here for a girls night dinner with some girls (duh.) and had a lovely dinner. We started off with crostini with roasted red peppers, onions and sausage, the caesar salad and the shoestring potatoes. All were pretty good but not amazing. The caesar didn't feel like it was fully dressed and it was off balance as well for me. Like the egg wasn't full incorporated and the anchovy was a  bit strong on a few bites.

The famed roast chicken however was divine. Be patient, it takes an hour if you order it but it's well worth the wait. The meat is succulent and flavorful and the bread salad is AMAZING. I couldn't get enough of it, the chicken comes tossed with the bread salad so the bread soaks up the yummy chicken juices and is tossed with currants and pine nuts, two of my favorite ingredients. I was in heaven. 

To finish, we had a pie budino and an apple tart. The budino was more cakey than pudding but was still delish and came with super fresh peaches and a huckleberry sauce. The tarte was delicious and it came with a vanilla ice cream that was delicious. I'd heard they take great care with the ice cream and you could really tell.

Overall a really great experience with stellar service. Beware the stairs though! Is it me or do they seem to pitch you forward? I'm not that coordinate to begin with so I was clutching the railing to ensure I wouldn't fall.
author: Cathy T.

description: Sorry, Zuni. We love to come over and throw down a bunch of oysters, and we've been doing it for years,  but when you are charging THREE DOLLARS AND FIFTY CENTS EACH for Kumamotos, we're outta there. Just came back from the Northwest and they are a buck everywhere you go.  We are happy to pay good money for good food, but this is highway robbery, plain and simple.
author: Dexter N.

description:
I had a great dining experience here & the food was fabulous. It is pricey, most people know that but I also think it is kinda cool that they reserve some of their tables for walk ins. So, you don't necessarily have to have a reservation to have dinner here! 

I had the chicken bread salad. WHOA. I dont' normally order chicken in restaurants, but this was truly worth it!
author: Ingrid K.

description:
What a scene on pride weekend!  Even so, Zuni managed to handle the crowd which was out to the street.  With some pressure, we managed to get seated.  Everything we ordered was absolutely fantastic!!

Nice wines, pricey but fantastic chicken which, yes, was the absolutely best chicken I've had (& I'm married to someone who makes awesome roast chicken so i don't make this comment lightly). 

The chicken sits on a bread salad, delicious pieces of bread, lightly soaked in apple cider vinegar then quickly grilled & mixed with a scattering of greens (arugula I believe).

We also ordered a fantastic wild mushroom pasta dish & a tasty clams/sausage dish.
author: Cheryl B.

description:
I finally went to Zuni! I moved to SF about 6 months ago and knew that this was a must do San Francisco staple. 

I was browsing through their cookbook  at books inc.(another great ) and found an English Berry Bread Pudding, not your typical sloppy bread pudding-that i had been trying to figure out. The book was full of interesting creative yummy treats.  I didn't get the book but I did make a mental note to get to the Zuni.

We had the roasted chicken, persimmon salad, the arugula salad, deserts coffee. It was all excellent. The service was perfect.

It is nice, excellent homey warm food. Not pretentous. Not a scene, relaxing and fun. 

My only critisim is the art on the walls. For all that good food, nice ambiance, brick oven goodness they should think about what is  up on the walls. Bla abstract paintings are just Bla and uninspiring. 

But i can't knock a star for that because they arn't in the art business they are in business of chickens and they are great at oven roasted chickens.
author: Deva G.

description:
This restaurant definitely qualifies to have one of the best burger in the city. Ghosh, so good! I love their fries too. The drinks too are well made especially the bloody mary.
Their interiors are pretty unique/well done and everything else about this place is pretty darn good including the service. Definitely going back!
author: sandhya ..

description: Very nice place, service is good, enough wine choice, starters are good too. Then main dishes are too oily and rich so you don't feel the real taste of the food. Globally a good place for European people who just arrive in SF.
author: Benjamin O.

description:
STILL AWESOME ...  we lived in SF for years and were Zuni regulars, but hadn't been there since moving to NYC in 2004.  

We went for all our old favorites ... the  roasted chicken for 2, raw bar, polenta, house-cured anchovies ... everything was as good or better than we remembered.  Staff still great, still BIG FANS.
author: Mike M.

description: This is my favorite restaurant. Anywhere. Ever. It is perfect and satisfies all the senses it's possible for a restaurant to satisfy: sights, sounds, tastes, smells, even the rough textures of the southwestern fabrics.... I love coming here. I love just SITTING in here, watching the people and the traffic going by on Market St. through the gigantic windows.
author: Sandra C.

description:
7x7 list - http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

# 1 - Roast chicken and bread salad: it was a good roasted whole chicken and the bread salad was good with the tart vinegar flavors but it wasn't worth $48 AND an hour wait.

BUT...their Shoestring Fries and Caesar Salad is a must order. They also have a great variety of oysters to help kill time waiting for the bird.
author: Katie K.

description:
Went with a group of four for a birthday dinner 7:00 pm on a Sat night with open table reservations. Sat down at our upstairs table and the waiter asked if we wanted cocktails. We ordered drinks and right away they removed the wine glasses. How did they know we did not want wine with our meal? 
We placed the orders immediately as 1/2 the group wanted the chicken, one hour... as per menu. We ordered soups and salad along with minuscule bruschetta type appetizer which was very good, but not much way over prices for two slices of bread with I think ricotta/marscapone cheese. 
The soup was spinach and very good as was the Cesar salad. We finished these and munched on bread and had another drink as the chicken was still being prepared. After 1.5 hours the waiter appeared and said it would be another five minutes. What happened to 1 hour? During this time no one came by and asked if we wanted anything and I think the chicken was late because the order was not placed when we gave it. 
Well they brought all the entrees out at once and mine was cold. I sent it back right away and was presented with a new serving. It was roast lamb that was delicious. My wife had salmon which was excellent, and the kids eating the chicken raved. The bread salad is killer. Maybe it was all so good because we were starving...... 
We were served two gratis desserts to make up for the cold dinner, and we ordered coffees. We asked for sweetener and the waiter said OK and never brought it. 
All in all the food was good, very expensive for what you are served, but very tasty. If it was mediocre than I would really be upset. The service was not good at all. Due to this, I don't think it's worth a drive from the peninsula for the value.
author: David L.

description:
Another SF institution, famous for their Roasted Chicken for Two.

4 Stars for the Food. We came here for a business lunch and had a pleasant meal of the Roasted Beet Salad & their Burger. Both dishes were delicious. Order both, and you won't be disappointed.

3 Stars for the Slow Service. The waitress walked by our table countless times before she would actually provide actual service for our table. Requests to order, refill our beverages, get a new straw, and finally our bill totaled a good 20 minutes. 

Parking may be difficult during the day, so be ready to hike a bit up and down or around Market.
author: Kat C.

description:
Great gourmet burgers, very nice with the gorgonzola.  Note: burgers are on the rarer side (e.g. medium rare was very pink/red) which might slightly worry the e.coli / mad cow concerned.  Hey we only live once and there are so many carcinogens in the world anyway so might as well enjoy it.  The focaccia bun was something to get used to; it absorbed too much of the burger oil.

Outdoor seating is great on sunny SF days.  I can't believe this counts as SoMa.  It's more Civic Center/Tenderloin in my mind.  There's valet parking but street parking is totally do-able.  Service was excellent.
author: Chris P.

description:
Who knew that one bottle of wine, one roast chicken, and one tiny slice of peach tart could make such a good meal? I agree with many of the other reviewers that Zuni is 100% comfortable with a dash of high end attitude (only really with the hosts, I noticed). The big plate windows were beautiful. I would have love out at the passersby all dinner long...if we were anywhere near a big plate glass window. No, we were tucked into a quiet nook somewhere upstairs, which was nice for conversation but felt like a closet. 

The service more than made up for the location as our server kindly allowed us to try some of the wines before we picked our bottle. The bread kept coming as we waited for the chicken. 

Here's the thing about the chicken. It's damn good. It's also $48. It's also chicken... Now, is this chicken 8 times better than Costco chicken? What if I butchered a Costco chicken and put it on top of some bread salad? This is a tough call. I liked the chicken a lot and split between two at a high-end restaurant, $48 could be reasonable. But by your second glass of wine, it really doesn't matter that much anymore. So yes, get the chicken! Order it when you get seated though, it takes up to an hour. 

The peach tart was delicious but small. This was maybe the simplest meal I've had in a long time at a nice restaurant, but it was pleasantly satisfying. I think that sentiment fits Zuni well.
author: Lydia C.

description: A friend suggested I go here when I told him I was going to San Fran for business. This place has THE BEST ROAST CHICKEN and I never like to order roast chicken in restaurants but it was delicious! Love this place, Love the views!
author: Darcy M.

description:
There are those select places that you cant wait to get back to.  This is indeed one of those great SF bright spots.  Though I am not a resident the bay, I really enjoy finding those spots that arent quite as well known...hard to say that about a place that has near 1300 reviews but I consider it one of those spots.  I am tardy in this review as I have been with all my reviews.  I've been here a handful of times and each time has been fantastic.  Post golf beers and oysters....check.  Romantic night in the corner stuffing our faces with their as good as advertised chicken.....check.  Solo wine infused "working lunch"....triple check.  No matter where you sit, be surrounded by a good vibe and a place that just feels comfortable.  The place is "cute" and it takes a big man to say that in a high traffic public forum.  The wine list is fairly priced and the selection by the glass is decent.  Zuni is right there with bar crudo, nopa and the house for my go to spots in the city.  

Rated from 1-10: 
Taste - 9
Presentation - 7
Vibe - 10
Service - 9
Wine - 7

I will go back for sure.
author: Dustin S.

description:
The chicken at Zuni is soo god that I'm mad that I don't have a woodburning over at home so that I can try it myself. 

The downside is that it will take an hour for you to eat said chicken, and it's $50 for a whole chicken, which is a huge mark up for a yard bird, however, a glass or two of wine, veggie soup in chicken broth, fresh bread will keep your belly busy while you wait. 

Zuni would get 5 stars from me but $50 for a chicken still stings, although it is the best damn chicken in town, hands down!
author: Nisa A.

description: My recent trip to Zuni Cafe in SF, CA, was not just a meal, it was an outstanding, memorable dining experience.  While they are known for their roast chicken (allow 1 hour for that), the chef had taken days to prepare delightful, thick pork chops, just to prepare upon order.  I couldn't resist and was not disappointed.  The wait staff was attentive and made me feel comfortable.  Thanks to my friend for recommending this restaurant - it was well worth the visit!
author: Deanna S.

description:
$48 for a whole chicken. I generally have a problem with this. I eat a roast chicken at least once every two weeks - i would never consider ordering one(for two) for $48....  but in the moment, hype overwhelms logic, rational is gone, curiousity takes over... and afterwards, no regrets - the roast chicken at Zuni Cafe is the best godamn chicken i've ever tasted - fuck it - its one of the best dishes ive ever had. 

In front of the wood oven, i watch: golden, crispy chickens are removed from the oven by the dozen; laid out on a massive cutting board, juices collecting; the bread salads are dressed and casually popped back in the inferno; then, a cleaver weilding virtuoso, goes loco cuts my bird in 8 in like a second; i blackout... come to,  and our Chicken arrives at our table, atop a bread salad, lightly dressed balasamic vinaigrette, pine nuts, currants and dandelion greens, soaked with chicken juice;  the textures are amazing from the crusty browned bread to the juiced softened interiors to the toasted pine nuts and chewy currants; and the meat is, amazing - imagine a full bird where every single bite is perfectly season.  Perfect

That is what this place is all about.  Excellent product and somewhat humble preparation coupled with supreme execution.  Love me Zuni Cafe.
author: Michael W.

description:
I was at the Zuni last night, what a pleasure. My wife and I have been dining there since the corner of the flat iron bulding was the Red Desert
cactus store.  the food was amazing: rabbit sausage, spaghetti with califlower, squab with brusslel sprouts, wild salmon & a lamb mixed grill that was from heaven. Judy Rodgers is amazing.
author: Randy D.

description:
This was very fine dining.  It was quite a treat for my boyfriend and I to eat at such a ritzy place like this.  

The food was excellent.  The burgers and pizza were great.  It was a long dinning session. The string potato's were classic!  

It was a little close dinning but very charming and we had a great view for people watching the crowd.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Haven't been here for a while but still consistently good.
Food went well with glass of syrah.

While waiting, I ate some some yummi butter with a little bread.

I decided on a light and healthy lunch, so I had the chicpea soup (veggie) which was tasty, and an okay pizza (ricotta, tomato sauce, oregano).  The pizza was wafer thin and crunchy.  

I still prefer the pizza at a16 and pizzeria delfina, but zuni is close to work.

On the heavier side, I love there burgers, nice and juice with great bread.  

Will definantly have a burger next time.
author: David L.

description:
this space is so neat! loft-like with exposed brick, copper bar top, beautiful floral arrangements, tons of seating among separate spaces within the larger space. this gets 5 stars!

they are known for their ceasar salad, which is justified. they make some special anchovy dressing that tastes amazing! 5 stars!

i got the quail and got to taste the pork chop. the flavor was pretty good and the dishes were cooked well, but both dishes were super salty! funny because they put a salt shaker on every table. just salt, no pepper. 3 stars :(

i forget what the dessert was called, but it was like 8 mini mini, cylinder shaped choco cakes all next to each other, drizzled with caramel, and sprinkled with chopped walnuts... .oh! AND it was warm! 5 STARS!!

menu changes all the time, so maybe you'll have better luck with the salty mains.
author: Tea Lyves ..

description:
To me, Zuni IS San Francisco.  The casual elegant airy space, the huge mix of people, the Cal-Med clean flavored food... I will never get sick of it.  Whether for oysters and a glass of wonderful white Burgundy, or a long drawn-out night-out meal with family or friends, I always go back again and again going on over 10 years now.  

Note that they save a good number of tables for walk-ins, so as long as you are willing to while away some time drinking wonderful cocktails or wine at the long copper bar, you can almost always get seated without any reservations.
author: Celeste S.

description:
Boy, Zuni has legs.  They have been doing the same thing for how long now -10, 20, 50 years, but it still works.

I'm a big believer in find the best and stick with it.  While Zuni does a bunch of stuff well, they do a few things top notch, so I tend to eat the same meal over and over here.

Lunch is their fresh ground hamburger, house made katchup, and fries.  Just a taste sensation.

Dinner?  Well, after quaffing a few cocktails - their bar makes some great drinks including about as good a cosmo as you will find in the City - I wait to get seat. Even as I park my butt, I let out the magic words "Well split a chicken."  It takes about 40 minutes for them to cook a chicken in their pizza oven, so an early order keeps the meal flowing as it should.

About that chicken.  Holy Hens Batman!!!  It is simply the best roast chicken I have ever had.  After raising backyard chickens in the Castro for a few years we have largely moved away from commercially grown birds, in favor of more humane/organic.

But at Zuni, I dont'  inquire because I don't want to know.  Don't ask, don't tell, thats my policy, and I'm sticking to it.

The chickens come out juicy, salty, herbacious, crispy....mmmmm  There is also a tasty bread stuffign that must have a pound of butter roasted in, and God bless them I say.  It is also studded with currants or some other dried fruit.  Really great.

So, with the chicken pre-ordered and safely in its 500 degree temporary home, I usually order a dozen oysters (kummumoto if they are good) and  caesar salad (splitin half for two)  The oyster selection is great, if a tad pricy, and a great way to kick off the meal and finish off the cocktail we've usually taken to the table.  The caesar is just fab, with super-fresh speers of romaine, flecks of anchovies, shaved cheese and a light dressing.  An order splits well for two (they bring it on two plates) and leaves enough room for the bird.

The only remaining question is whether to order the shoestring potatoes which vary from nice to awesome.  I can't get a handle on why they are so much better sometimes than others. The downside of getting the fries is that you eat less of the great fresh bread and butter.  On the upside...the fries.

Anyway, thats pretty much it.  cocktail, oysters, caesar, bird with dressing and maybe a glass of wine along the way. I can honestly say I've had this meal no fewer than 25 times, and if money and cholesteral were no issue I'd gladly eat it twice a month.
author: hOWARD y.

description:
This is a truly fun place to go to dinner. It's a place where the beautiful people go to hang out and be seen.

The best dish on the menu is their chicken dish, which can be ordered the minute you walk in the door.

The rest of the food is average, but the see and be seen atmosphere is worth the average food. Every time I come here, I always meet new people and make friends. It's a great place ot come if you are new to the city, and want to meet young professionals.

I would recommend this place for drinks and appetizers, but head off to another great restaurant in Hayes Valley (i.e. Jardineire) for better food.

Energetic atmosphere, blah food, but a fun place to hang out.

The only other draw back is getting in. Sometime the wait can be lengthy, and it can be overcrowded on the weekends.
author: Stephen D.

description:
Went there for a small work luncheon! Everyone raved about how good it was...so I ask what they're known for someone suggest their burger! Maybe it's just not my flavor or cup of tea, but I didn't finish it and have no desire to eat it again. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing??

The waitress was nice, but hardly there for us. The two gentlemen who helped her were not friendly. We tried to friendly and joke with them when they were placing our meals in from of us, with no avail, not even a half a smile!

When we got our check, they charged us for the employees health benefits!?! We have never seen such a thing? Is this new? Couldn't they increase the prices a bit to cover it rather than blatantly putting on the check? I think people who eat there can well afford to pay for it, but it just seemed tacky to have it right there in front of your face and definitely doesn't help you want to tip generously since you're paying for their health benefits!
author: M R.

description:
I like this place, the location is Great, the Drinks were amazing and  the Gnocci was like eating baby angels. (yummm - - Homer style) 

Friends have told me that Zuni Salads are out of this world... I thought they were just OK. The price is astronomic... so be smart about what you order.
author: Moy A.

description:
Our experience here is actually what made us move out to SF. So, thanks, Zuni, for the excellent advice. Our waiter that day was amazing.

THIS is a restaurant that solidifies San Francisco's dining scene. Rocks on all counts. Eat here before you leave...or when you come back.
author: Elle N M.

description: It was okay... I thought if I had a to wait an hour for some chicken it better be the best chicken I ever had. Sorry to say it wasn't, it was just okay. It just seemed like it was missing some flavor.
author: Reggie S.

description:
Small, pricey portions of very delicious food.  

We had the caesar salad, gnocchi and mint ice cream - each dish was perfectly prepared with care.  The server took several minutes to rearrange the salad onto two plates, the presentation was not necessarily a work of art, but they definitely get points for effort.  The salad was fresh with anchovies, the gnocchi was so tender it melted in your mouth and the ice cream was made with fresh mint, a perfect ending to a wonderful meal.

Suggestions: go and share a meal with a friend or someone special, it will cut the price in half and you will not regret the delicious meal.
author: Suzie Y.

description: Just thinking about their famous rotisserie chicken (that you have to order ahead of time) and pasta dishes just makes my mouth water.  This is one of my favourite one time stops whenever I'm passing by the city.  No doubt about it!
author: Travelling E.

description:
I am not sure how many stars to give since we didn't actually eat here...they wouldn't serve us what we wanted.  LOL

5 stars for the wait staff...
0 stars for the brilliant idea to not serve the burger for dinner...

I had heard such great things about their burger that on our way through town we decided to make a detour and stop in for a burger.  After being seated and asking to have the burger (I didn't even bother to look at the menu) we were informed that they don't serve the burger at dinner time otherwise the grill would be overwhelmed with orders.  They only serve it for lunch and after 10pm.  Seriously???  How have you guys stayed in business this long with this kind of thinking.

Well Zuni, let me learn on you a bit of economics...it would be better to offer it, even if you have to charge more at dinner time (so that the grill doesn't get overwhelmed with too many orders), then to tell me I can't get one at all.  If you charge $15 at lunch go ahead and mark it up to $20 or $25 for dinner so only those that are really interested will buy it.  I would have gladly paid upwards of $30.  So, instead of having us stay and spend over $200 for food and drinks you allowed us to leave and go somewhere else...which we did...and ended up finding my favorite burger in town.  I guess I could have asked to talk to the manager and offered to pay double for the burger if they made it special for me (being that I am was just passing through and might not get another chance to try it for quite a while) but I shouldn't have to.  If you are going to make something that everyone raves about then figure out how to make it all the time.  Heck, you could offer it as sliders for appetizers and charge a bundle while still keeping the grill from getting too slammed.  

I would like to say that I would come back to try yours but with the best burger in town being so close, more affordable, and them serving it whenever I want it I am going to have a hard time not visiting them again when we are in the neighborhood looking for lunch.  I like to try new burgers but when I know such a great one is so close I just can't see a good reason to pass them up.

I do have to mention that the wait staff at Zuni was great and although shocked that we got up to leave when we found out there was no burger, they held no grudge towards us.  I felt they were so courteous that I left a tip even though we didn't eat or drink anything and were in fact freeing a much wanted table.
author: houston '.

description:
[PRO]
-Roasted Chicken for Two with Warm Bread Salad (takes one hour)
-Oysters

[CON]
-1 hour wait (although expected, was a little too long)
author: Annie K.

description:
This was my second time at Zuni Cafe as my first experience was late-nite for dessert only. I can hardly remember what I had only because it was well over 6 years ago. 

We came for the chicken and placed an order immediately upon being seated upstairs. Who in their right mind waits an hour for chicken? We did and when it finally arrived an hour later, it was not the chicken-gasmic experience we had hoped for. The only redeeming quality was that fact it was not salty which other reviews seems to indicate its tendency to be. It was plain chicken which costs $41 for two people. Yes, it feed the five (5) of us and left a few of us scratching our heads as to why we spent that much time and money on chicken for a lunchtime meal.  

While waiting for our "chicken" course, we ordered a caesar salad, lamb lettuce with rabbit, and herb tomato soup which rounded out our appetizers. Oh yeah, one order of fine julienned fries to share which reminded me of the kind you get in the tin cans. 

The food was good but wasn't quite worth the hype. However, our side entrees of sirloin burgers on focaccia were spot on. A little pricey but worth every penny. Try it with the Gruyere and onions.

The rabbit salad was really oily and the tiny brioche with fork separated rabbit (part of the salad) as well. The brioche was like were eating a slab of butter as you could not even taste the actual rabbit. 

The caesar salad was flavorful and robust. You could taste the anchovies but I never saw any bits as they must have incorporated it into the dressing. Very well done.

Service was okay and I don't think I'll be back. There are a lot better restaurants in San Francisco and I'm staying away from chicken unless fried.
author: S L.

description:
My hubby and I went here in 2002 after a classical guitar concert at the Presidio. The organizers invited us to join them for dinner at Zuni Cafe and I wanted to go since I've heard about their reputation for being an acclaimed restaurant and I've never been there. So we ordered our food and I'm assuming they had a reservation since we got seated right away (the place was packed that night). Some went straight to the bar. We were so hungry that we wanted to order our food right away. The place had a pretentious vibe, but we were willing to give it a try.

When the food arrived, they were in very small portions much to our dismay. But hey, we figured it must be good right? Unfortunately, the food disappointed us. I don't remember much of it, but I do remember it being bland. I also remembered vowing to never come back there.

Not only is the place super pricey, the portions aren't even worth the price. Good thing my hubby and I didn't have to pay for it.
author: Cindy S.

description:
Not so much.

I went here about 14 years ago and there is a reason I haven't been back.  

Boring menu, non-exciting food, cramped, pretentious....

There are much more interesting places to go in this city.
author: Jay L.

description:
I just went here the first tim today.  Let's start with the good things.  The restaurant itself is beautiful inside.  I loved the bar and the oysters on display.  The kitchen feels like it is part of the restaurant.  Our waiter was very attentive, kind, and efficient.

The one real problem is the food.  We ate lunch and my tiny thin crust pizza with a few toppings was $13.  My wife had a soup which was good and polenta which was quite bland.  It consisted entirely of corn and a small amount of cheese but no other flavors.  For what they charge for everything I expected a lot more for the food.  It may have just been the dishes that we choose.
author: Ken F.

description: The food is pretty much always solid.  The building is sweet to watch the streetcars go by.  Nice spot for a date.  Just wish the prices were more in line with what they're selling.
author: Henry A.

description:
I have to change this to a 5.  I come here way too often to give it a 4.  I obviously love the place.  :D  Did I mention the burger's are the bomb?  ;)  And the fries?  I can't stop eating those little shoe strings!!!  

I'm always looking forward to going back.  That said, they get bumped up to a 5.
author: Delilah B.

description: Over rated restaurant.  The boutique cocktails are yummy but pricey,  ceasar salad was wilted, nothing special, and the guinea hen  entree was too salty and over priced at $28.  We did enjoy the lemmon tart.
author: Jane k.

description:
Took clients here for lunch the other day.  This place is great, I've never had a bad meal.  Though I would tend to slightly agree with some of the recent posts about the service maybe being a little "too big for their britches", the food is still great.  Their roast chicken (for two) dish is easily the best chicken you will have in the city limits.  It is worth going just to try it.  The burger is also spot on.  One person at the table didn't like it, but they also didn't put the accompanying money garnish on theirs (the pickled onions and pickles are awesome and make the burger).  My only issue with the burger is that I felt like I had bathed in it by the end of the meal, but since there were others equally coated in burger juice, I didn't feel too bad.  =)

Can't relate to any hate on this place, it is a great spot.
author: Andrew M.

description: Pretty boring. The dishes are without any creativity.. The cooking is adequate and the food quality and service is good, but it's hard to know why anyone would go out to eat like this. Hotel dining room, semi-hip vibe, w/o hotel. Best days are long long past, and those days were when there was little good near.
author: bob o.

description:
I just moved to SF and have been pumped to try out Zuni.  Unfortunately, after a month of build up and excitement I found out that it's definitely not worth the hype.

I thought that the menu here was very small, not a lot of choice, and sort of boring.  When our food came out it was pretty bland, and seemingly nothing too special.

On a positive note, I will say that our waiter was excellent, and I was very impressed with all of the staff at the restaurant.  

All in all though, Zuni was a total let down :-(
author: J P.

description:
I like this place because I love the bread salad that comes with the roast chicken (chickenfat chickenfat chickenfat, SCHMALTZ!!) the raw mollusks, mmmm, mollusks, and the fucking BALSAMIC BLOODY MARYS. 

jizzy chrizzy,  those balsamic bloody marys are good. i'm twitching on the floor with my eyes rolled back cuz i'm writing this review from a cube in an office bldg and all iwant to do is bomb out on some of that bbm-goodness.

i didn't like their polenta or even their famous foccacia salted burger thing and am ambivalent about their caesar salad. but just cuz of how good the stuff is up there that i mentioned (oh and yes the chicken itself is delicieux), i say yay!
