don't like sitting in any of the windows or at the bar, just too much activity and crampiness.  and this is really simply food done well, so although i've said this about chez panisse, it's even more true here, don't be expecting any weird towers, shot glasses filled with suspended savory things en gelee or with odd espuma stuff everwhere. it ain't like that. (and thank god!)

cookbook is good too.

hahaha, funny ass story, so i ate their cockles on a shellfish platter with my bf. it was a lot of fun. i loved it all (see above for my mini mollusk reverie), but bf doesn't like chewy things v much so he only ate the little soft tail things of the periwinkle... and i looked up stuff, and guess what! that was winkle poo! 

yeah that's right. my boyfriend was savoring the WINKLE POO. 

zuni deserves all those stars for the extremely high amusement level i got out of that.
author: Julia K.

description:
I think back, and every time I've been here I've left feeling... meh.

One time, on a date, we ordered the shellfish appetizer with oysters, littlenecks, escargot, etc. Sounds interesting, no? Well it was served in what looked like a tray from a middle-school cafeteria in a slightly icey puddle of cloudy water (I'm assuming from the oysters).

The lattes here are served in bowls. Did you run out of mugs? You're killing me here.

Also, the host yelled at my friend for getting up to move tables in front of all the customers. C'mon now.

However, to his credit, he scaled a fence of a construction site and climbed up a ladder to turn off a light that had fallen and was pointing into the restaurant. That's dedication.. deserves two stars in itself. For now though, I'll pass on returning. Though Hotel Biron is right next store... I wonder if they serve wine in bowls.
author: Kevin S.

description: This over-hyped restaurant is long over due for another review from Michael Bauer. I went there for brunch and ordered the rabbit with a poached egg. When my food arrived, everyone at our table started laughing the plate was so skimpy. There was about an ounce of rabbit, a poached egg and 3 small slivers of nectarine. I sent it back and ordered a burger, medium, which arrived rare and already soaked through the bun. Pleasant waitstaff and location, but with so many great restaurants in SF, there is no reason to go back.
author: Hannah S.

description:
There's not a whole lot of things left to say about a restaurant that is as well established as Zuni. It is however interesting to see how different people feel about the service at this place.

I had to count but I think I've been to Zuni four times. 
Three of the times I had the chicken (and yes it IS worth waiting the 50 minutes for it. I personally think their chicken is excellent).
None of the times I've been there have I had ANY sign of bad service - actually quite the opposite to it. The staff may not be too well read up on 'the wines of the world' but as long as you know what you like who cares.

I've dined both upstairs and downstairs (near the bar and further in to the kitchen area) and I prefer downstairs to the sort of cramped upstairs area.

Haven't been there in months. Maybe time to go back. Hey, they already killed those chickens - someone's gotta eat 'em!  :)
author: Rich S.

description:
When I think of Zuni, I think of FRESH.
The margaritas are amazing. The food is excellent. The layout is beautiful.
author: Monika M.

description:
Chicken for two.
Oh my god.
I would seriously put a dating ad out on craigslist for a date to Zuni if it involved their chicken.
I've made it at home from the cookbook as well, and it's almost as good. 
The stuffing alone is worth it.

Ghod, I need to stop writing reviews while hungry.
author: Amelia P.

description:
Atmosphere : A+
Food: B+
Servers: C+
Hostess/Host: D-

This pretty much sums up Zuni.

Truly unique space on an awkward stretch of Market (half deco ghetto, half homeless crack whore) and the crowd is always a curious mix of hipsters and grunge folk, guppies, and movers n' shakers. They, like me, must brave the sometimes brusque service here to graze on the fierce burger. 

The staff can really be annoying sometimes. Some of them display a certain swagger and bravado, like they are part of the 30-year Judy Rodgers-revolution or something. Get over yourselves! Especially the power-trip host staff (mostly 23 year old queened out gay men) who once actually LAUGHED at me after inquiring about a reservation one evening. Hubris isn't flattering, babe. Sorry. And take your faux Hermes fashions back to Nordstrom Rack while you're at it. Two snaps! 

ANYWAY, the servers are generally nice, especially if you ask them how their day is going. They actually level with you: "I'm exhausted" or "Somebody just spilled beer on me" or "I'm SUPER thanks for asking!!!"  They're always a little out of sorts, but generally knowledgeable and seem to be into food, all things considered.

About that burger: don't order it at night when it's an absurd 18.00. Yep, you read that right. I much prefer the 12.00 burger at lunch which tastes and looks exactly the same. 

3.5 stars, but I give you 4 for atmosphere and late night dining!
author: BroSauce J.

description:
Super-Fantastic Hamburgers!

...but go on an expense account.  No one should buy food this expensive for themself.
author: Nick T.

description: We went in just for drinks. I had to flag down the server to even take our drink orders. We did have a second round of drinks, but had to wait a significant amount of time for the server to bother to ask us if we wanted another round. For 10-15$ a cocktail, it shouldn't be a struggle to order drinks. Server was not very friendly and didn't really add to the experience.
author: Stephanie E.

description:
I think 3 stars may be generous.  
I was not impressed, but then again I didn't get the chicken.  The people sitting next to us got the chicken and it looked amazing, but we came in 45 minutes before closing and the menu noted that the chicken takes 1 hour to prepare.  I agree with other comments in that the food is OK, but overpriced for the quality.  I have many meals that cost half as much but tasted twice as good. 

I don't think we'll be back anytime soon, too many other good places to eat in the city.  Oh yeah, the service isn't the greatest either.  No one came back to check on our food until after we had finished eating.  I would have like another glass of wine too...
author: Rachel R.

description: Still the best bloody ever! and the roasted chicken is to die for, as always. Zuni, please never close!
author: Jo D.

description:
Went here for the first time last night.

Walked in and was immediately hit on by a couple of rice-queens. You know the type, "Excuse me, miss ... where are you originally from?" Bait for the answer, "Philippines," and then they reply, "Maganda ka."

bullshit. I'm from Salinas, fool. 

Anyway, so the crowd was very "financial district," which made me wary but I stayed because my girl was treating me to fancy fancy dinner that night.

What lured us in was the buzz about the burgers but it was still too early for us to order them. 

Waited at the bar for a little bit and was served by the friendly bartender. Very strong lemon drop, thank you, sir.

Not too bad of a wait considering it was very busy. The hostess was friendly and accomodating. The waiter was very attentive. Noise level is extremely high here. 

on to the food:

- Leeks ... good but not worth the price tag.

- Ceasar salad ... perfect (and I normally hate salad)

- Chicken for 2 (the bed of bread it was laying on was scrumptious, the chicken was tender ... but there was one point where I almost compared the marinade taste to the smell of pine sol ... yeah.)

- Fries (fun to eat ... reminded me of those potato stick things that you can get from pak n save or whatever that place was called)

- Flourless chocolate cake was heavenly.

Overall, probably not the spot I'd run back to. 

Would possibly come back to try the infamous burger ...
author: Joyce S.

description:
Service: 
Impeccable. Our server was great, friendly, and very helpful. He even was able to fend off the most ridiculous questions from my boyfriend's grandpa, who was drunk out of his mind and feeling like giving someone a hard time. 

Food:
All the starters were excellent. I had the little gem salad which I would have been happy with for my main meal as well. The caesar was good too. As for the oysters, I don't do oysters, but I heard they were quite good. Not as good as Washington oysters (says the drunken grandpa), but pretty good. 

The quail would have been tasty, I'm sure, if my boyfriend had let me have any. My main was pretty disappointing actually. I had the bream/clam chowder. It was not what I was expecting at all. Thin soup, clams still in their shells, and the bream was just sort of laying on top of everything. It still tasted alright, but the presentation was really off-putting. 

Go here: for groups of 4 or under. It's too loud for a big group. 

Tip o' the day: The roast chicken for two is amazing, but it needs an hour to prepare. Try ordering it when you first get seated.
author: Ali L.

description:
I'm always a little wary of reviewing places having only eaten there once, but I wanted to give this place kudos because of the nice experience I had here. 

I love the ambiance, as the interior was bright and homey on a Sunday afternoon, although I will have to agree with others that the tables are packed a weee bit close together. 

The bloody mary is bloody fantastic! Not spicy enough for my taste, but great, fresh, tangy flavors. I drank it up and ate the little pieces of onion and bell pepper at the bottom, plus the celery stick. SO good. Nice oyster selection, and our friendly waiter made some phenomenal picks for us. The burger is good, mostly because I LOVED the bread and pickled onion it came with, not because the patty is anything extraordinary. The shoestring fries are a must for lovers of the shoestring variety. And the ceasar salad was beautiful and tasty. Such pretty hearts of romaine! The anchovy bits were delicious and I fished around my salad plate for more. I didn't think the food was overly expensive as the total bill was $60 to split all the above and leave happy and full. 

I will have to come back and try the roast chicken and re-review.
author: Maian T.

description:
Zuni, as you'll read many times here, earns raves from all kinds of foodie sources.  I've dined here four times over the last two years and will share some observations:

- Host staff:  eternally friendly if you have a reservation.  Oddly aloof if you don't

- Room:  I'm a fan of some of the untraditional seating arrangements (side by side, three in a corner, etc), but when it's a traditional arrangement, you feel very far away from your fellow diner.  That said, there's enough room for all the plates, etc, you'll need.  Functional.  (Side note - I've been seated at the same table 3 of the 4 times I've dined here - odd).  The lighting is wonderful, daytime or evening, and the artwork (most of the time) is very nice.  I love the exposed brick walls where they have them.

- Waitstaff:  Always friendly, but I get the feeling they'd rather be somewhere else.  Not anti-patron, just distracted.  

- Food:  Always good, but never outstanding.  I've had some dynamite oysters here, but the chicken that everyone else raves about was dry (though flavorful).  The goat sausage tasty, but the accompanying chard filled with way too many onions.  The smoked sardines bursting with flavor, but drowned in olive oil.  In other words, Zuni gets the 'meat' of it right, but the details seem to slip.

I get here about every six months, and I won't be rushing back, but I don't mind going back to give it a whirl again.  I always have good company (and, thus, a good time).
author: Evan G.

description: Had a lovely meal here last week.  We didn't have a reservation at 7:00pm on a Friday night but as soon as we asked if there was any availability the hostesses let us know that a couple had just cancelled so we could be seated immediately!  We had the chicken that is delectable - - every bit worth the sixty minute wait.  Looking forward to returning!
author: Ashley C.

description:
We stopped by here last weekend after one of our group was forcibly removed from Zeitgeist for being a yuppie (more on that in my review for Zeitgeist.) I guess we were sorta proving that burger griller right, but when you need a burger, well, you need a burger.  We arrived about 2 minutes before the end of the lunch menu and the waiter was sweet enough to rush our order in, and I have to say, the burgers at Zuni Cafe kick the shit outta the burgers at Zeitgeist.  It was pure heaven sitting in the bar,  looking out the window at the people walking by in the wind and the cold, eating our burger and trying to figure out why we had wanted to sit in the wind and the cold at Zeitgeist in the first place. 

Then we got the bill and it was about 10 times as expensive as Zeitgeist and we were all left wondering how much we really like our friend.  Luckily, we do like him AND we like Zuni AND we had full bellies, so it's all good.
author: Cosmolicious L.

description: Atmosphere nice, food good taste...but tiny portions for the price...Short Ribs should have read "Short Rib" for $29.  Did not like the 4% socialized Health subsidy charged!!!
author: Kim S.

description:
very clean environment with a view of the streets of SF.  service is a bit slow and not completely knowledgeable.  excellent selection of oysters in a half-shell.  otherwise i have only had the roasted chicken and bread salad.  this was great, but you have to wait an hour for it and they will not let you call in early and leave a credit card.

the chicken was very tender and juicy.  the toasted bread between the greens and chicken was soaked with the roasted chicken drippings and had drizzled balsamic.  the pine nuts and raisins went great with the chicken and bread.  individually, the pieces were good, but when you combine all the parts it is a great dish.
author: Wayne L.

description:
I had been wanting to eat at Zuni for a while and got a little teaser of it's atmosphere when I stopped in for drinks in december.

I finally went there for dinner last night with a friend and I wouldn't have changed a thing in their quality, ambiance or service. The Serrano ham appetizer we ordered was delicious, my friend loved her chicken and the salmon I had was perfect as were the veggies that came with it... the desert was so sweet and light!

I can't wait to go back!
author: Alex W.

description:
It's been a while since I wrote a yelp review, but I've been taking down names and I sure intend to use them... starting with you, Zuni!

Zuni is one of those places that is always busy, always filled with beautiful looking people, and always the sort of place liable to impress. If, for the sake of argument, you were to bring a date here, lavish her with a wide variety of Oysters, fines wines and a few well picked dishes, all from the comfort of a hand picked corner seat kindly reserved for you by understanding and discreet staff, then, just possibly, you might have a good evening ahead of you. 

I suggest you go out and try - it beats taking her out to Burger King again.
author: Kevin R.

description:
The space for Zuni Cafe is fabulous especially during Sunday brunch where you can expect to hear live music. With the soothing piano in the background and warm sun streaming in, it is such a fantastic way to either catch up with your friends or as quality time with you other half.

The burger was amazing. I had two recommendations from two friends to try it and one of them knows her meat. My bf tried it and I have to say even the grease from the burger was flavorful. The meat is tender and as you bite into it, the flavor of the meat itself requires no condiments. I had the pasta with clams and enjoyed it. It's not the best pasta around, but next time I plan to try  the chicken as it takes an hour to cook and tastes amazing. 

Overall, if you are in no rush and just want a fun, easy dining experience on a Sunday, this is the place to be! And a great way to burn off the food is to go shopping in Union Sq!
author: Sophie C.

description:
With 278 reviews and counting there probably isn't much I can say that hasn't already been said. But seriously this is a superb joint(+ open late) and probably along with Firefly one of my favorite restaurants in the city. The service and food(most important) are marvelous, although the decor and neighborhood I find a little lacking(oh well). Just for the food alone it deserves 5 stars.

I feel like I should just go out and buy the Zuni Cookbook, and look at the pictures(cause I can't cook anything in it anyway) , and then get hungry and go eat at Zuni. I've tried all sorts of stuff here: the house cured pork chop(~$23) and the world famous caesar are great, but my favorite dish is probably the Zuni Burger(~$16): secret ingredient = crack.  I mean seriously it doesn't even taste like a burger, it just tastes like a whole of of delicious. I mean they make their own pickles! Just do yourself a favor and go get one now. Thank you Judy Rodgers for creating such a great restaurant.
author: Artur R.

description:
So overrated. 

Sure, the food isn't bad, but it really isn't exceptional. 

Except maybe the wood-roasted chicken. That might be exceptional. But I don't know. Because I've never been able to get it. 

See, it takes 50 minutes, and Zuni has a policy of not allowing you to order it while you wait for a table. 

So you get to Zuni and wait for 40 minutes for a table, getting hungrier and hungrier. You ask if you can order the chicken in advance so it will be ready 10 or 15 minutes after you sit down.

But they say no. Sorry. No can do.

Then you sit down and are too hungry to wait another 50 minutes. 

So maybe what's great is the chicken and I just will never know. But otherwise, it's not worth a special trip, or a wait.
author: Jacob L.

description:
The food and drinks are fine.  The service is slow, particularly if it is busy.  I don't just mean a little slow, I mean painful slow.

So my friends and I were on the second floor overlooking the bar area.  Our drink order was made over twenty-five minutes ago.  I asked the waiter if he would check on our drink.  He looked over the railing at the bar and said, "It looks like they're busy."  I almost fell out of my seat laughing.  I asked if he could see the kitchen so he could check on our food!  He didn't laugh.
author: Ted G.

description:
Came here before seeing Wicked mid week.   I love the fact that I could valet my car while going to the theater, although I wouldn't want to walk back by myself after the show.   We walked back pretty quickly!

I got here a bit early since there was no traffic and ran into a friend.  They have a decent wine list and the waitress was super friendly.  My friend was meeting 3 others and didn't have a reservation but gone one.  It was weird that they wanted to seat them before we got our table.  We had made a reservation.   

The food was really good. I had the tuna appetizer and liked it better without the bread.  The ricotta gnocchi was really nice but a bit rich.   The waiters were a bit odd in the service; a bit over the top.

We got back after the valet closed but they were cleaning up and had our keys with the hostess.   The manager was super nice.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
I am a rad uncle.

So my 19 year old niece was making her first solo visit to San Francisco.  She's done the touristy spots before, so we wanted to spoil her with a variety of good eats.  Zuni was our choice for Sunday brunch, and was an instant hit.  The fresh baked bread, the fresh squeezed OJ, the pizzas and, above all, the burger, were well worth it.  Yuppy paradise dining at its finest, and it's not a cheap experience, but dammit, it was tasty!

My niece loved it, and for a girl who's used to IHOP and Denny's, this was a slice of pure bliss.
author: Steve G.

description:
I love this place, but not for dinner.  I used to love it for breakfast when they served it. And now I love it for a late afternoon lunch in the bar area.  I love their Cesare Salad, but I think it is  not as good as they once was.  Pork chops are good.  And the real reason to eat here is the cafe granita with whipped cream.  

I have only been here twice for dinner, and both times were disappointing.  I am not sure why this is.
author: Julia G.

description: The service was great and so were the drinks, but the food was not.  I came to dinner with some friends and we left this place super hungry.  Overpriced! Overpriced and may I mention overpriced for our main entree.  The only bright spot was our waiter who was super attentive and made our experience at this restaurant decent.
author: Pam M.

description: Great ambiance and service. Some of the best decor and views of the city streetside I have encountered. Small portions. Food was good but not great. Somewhat bland. Overpriced and overrated.
author: Sam M.

description:
Seated at a window with nowhere to lean back, very uncomfortable!
Waite staff terrible.
Food..DO NOT order tongue or braised ox tail. Shoe sting potatoes excellent. Salmon OK, over cooked..anchovies ordinary
author: z z.

description: salmon was fantastic, tender and moist with excellent sauce
author: Greg B.

description: So, am I actually at the restaurant writing this review... I have been here for 3 hours and still have not received my entree.... Wow. It's 10pm...on a Wednesday. I can't believe this. Whoever has been giving this place more than one star must have a VIP card or something and I am jealous. When we came in the Hostess told us it would be an hour wait, so I asked if it was OK that we just get a drink and some oysters while we waited for our table, she said that as long as we do not order an entree that it would be OK. So, I added our name to the list and sat at a very tiny table in the bar area right by the hostess with our drinks. An hour goes by and the hostess comes up to us to ask if we had ordered our food....I said no, we are waiting for our table. She responds well...I took you off the waiting list and I'm already behind with seating customers. I said but we had a whole conversation that we would not order an entree in the bar area so we could get a table. She told us that if we wanted a table we would have to wait another 30 min minimum because she was too busy (THE MOST RUDE PERSON I HAVE EVER ENCOUNTERED AT A RESTAURANT BTW). Since we went there for my boyfriends birthday we ended up talking to the manager who said that he would get us the next table available. Well.... we did get the next table but we are still sitting here with no food. This is most definitely the worst customer service I have ever experienced in the city so far. In fact I think its the worst I have experienced EVER. I guess we will get our food to go....Would not recommend this place, would not come back.
author: Robin C.

description: I finally went to Zuni.......for lunch.......I had the burger. I think I may have misfired, I don't think I like burgers on focaccia, I spelled focaccia so wrong the first time that there were not even any spelling suggestions, had to google it.....I knew the shoestrings were an extra six bucks on top of the fifteen dollar burger and when the waitress asked I said yes......I always cave in these types of situations. Not a big fan of shoe strings, they do seem fancier than most french fries but they just don't do it for me, I can never get enough of them to line up to really have a successful vessel for the ketchup. I do like when restaurants serve the ketchup in those little stainless steel  bowls. The caesar salad was good, it seemed like everyone had one at their table.  Oh well I guess thats all I've got......maybe it's not Zuni but me......is the rating on yelp meant to evaluate how I felt at the restaurant or how I feel about the restaurant.
author: Josh F.

description:
The food was well prepared. Indeed, the chicken takes an hour to get to the table. I was happy because this was a treat to eat. It is not for the everyday as I think it is quite expensive. Well, I guess it has to be since everything is organic and wholesome.

The chicken tasted great the following day too. If I wasn't such a cheapo, I would give it five stars. I wasn't floored enough to pull out my wallet happily.
author: Jade H.

description: Roast Chicken with Bread Salad may have been one of my favorite dishes I've ever had! Large enough to feed 3-4, order it upon being seated, and enjoy a few cocktails and some oysters while you wait!
author: Allison M.

description: Please have the chicken even though it takes an hour to prepare.  Walked in without reservations but it's usually only two of us but would recommend you make reservations.  Nice after work spot.
author: Arcelia G.

description: Excellent place to eat and drink. Haven't been here for over 10 years but on Thursday met a few old friends for a catch up bevvy and snack. Fully booked but taking walk ins...ok..the wait is 1 and a half to 2 hours for a walk in. We got a table in 20 mins and had the smoothest cocktails, best shoestring french fries, fresh caesar salad and of course the chicken for 2...GREAT!!!...Can't go wrong here...Highly recommend for groups of 4 or less unless you make a reservation
author: Adrian L.

description: TOURIST TRAP! DO NOT COME HUNGRY. They tell you the chicken takes 1 hour to cook, so you'll have to order a bunch of overpriced appetizers that are REALLY not good. The eggplant and onion soup had no flavor, the Polenta was just crushed corn with no seasoning. The chips were not bad. And then came the chicken.. what can I say, it was good. but that's about it. definitely not worth $50 and a 1 hour wait, not in size or quality. The one star is just because the service was good, but really, save your time and money for the many other great restaurants in the area.
author: Uri O.

description:
Ah... Zuni Cafe - Judy, you run an amazing restaurant - your cook book is fantastic and I have had some amazing meals there so just wanted to finally say that its such a pleasure to have you in this City.

Famous chicken or fish, oysters, bloody marys, the chocolate cake, and the wine list etc etc.

Wine bar around the corner is cool for after drinks.
author: Ian M.

description: Just to make it clear, this is a review for lunch, and unlike the zillion other reviewers we did not have the roasted chicken that descended down from heaven. Having seen this place in Gayot.com's top ten burger places we decided to come down here to give it a try. The burger was really unremarkable and rather expensive at $18. I think in many cases, when you have a well decored, fancy restaurant like Zuni it's hard to give the food a low rating but at least from the perspective of their burgers it was rather lack-luster. Also there was something about the forced smile, overly professional, "but doesn't give a heck" 30-something waiter that was slightly off putting. I won't mention how much two burgers, three beers, two order of fries cost.
author: Procter F.

description: This is a very good restaurant.  We came in on a late flight and got here around 9:00 pm on a weekday.  It was still mostly full and full of energy.  The waiter was very attentive and described the specials well.  The wine list was very good, and the food was outstanding.  I will definitely come back to this restaurant again the next time I'm in town.
author: Scott L.

description: 4 of us had dinner at Zuni and we all had felt our meal was a total winner.  From cocktails to Caesar'ssalads  to seabasss to that most amazing chicken - everything was perfectly cooked and seasoned.  There's a reason this restaurant is a SF institution - the quality of the food is top-notch.
author: Craig G.

description:
The roast chicken TOTALLY worth it.  I really think that it is the best chicken I've ever ordered at a restaurant.  We split the chicken, oysters (FABULOUS), caesar salad, and gnocci between 3 people.  The bread salad YUM YUM with the chicken.  Only complaint would be I wish they had more selection of beer and wine.  Maybe some more beer on tap would be nice.
Also I sat on a big cushion with no back which I shared with a guy behind me.  It looked really cool at first but waiting for the chicken (which takes an hour to roast) was a little uncomfortable towards the end.  Overall, will definitely be coming back.
author: Britt B.

description:
Ambience = Wonderful
Service = Attentive
Oysters = Fresh & Good selection
Roast Chicken = AMAZING!!  Enough to serve 4, honestly.

Also highly recommend the pork chop and the rabbit which were both incredibly moist, juicy and full of flavor.  The only thing I wouldn't recommend it the lamb's ear lettuce salad... a little bland and just not very impressive.
author: SnP s.

description:
Want to pay $15.00 for a cocktail? (this does include city taxes)
Want a waiter who really doesn't care about serving you?
Want a small portion of very expensive food?
This is your restaurant!
For me, there are a half dozen other places within walking distance that 
serve good food, care about the customer and are reasonably priced.
author: nancy l.

description: Pricey, but OH-so-worth-it.  Everything I tried was amazing.  The pork roast dish may have changed my life - it was that good.  Yum yum yum.
author: Holly O.

description:
Food: Brilliant! Some of the tastiest, best prepared food I have ever eaten. I had the Halibut with Periwinkles. Delicious!

Service: Top notch. Fast and courteous

Bar Service: Sadly our favourite cocktail mixer Brenna was not on (She makes truly exceptional cocktails), but what we did get was also excellent. Except for my mistake of ordering Ginger Brew, thinking it would be the same as Australian Ginger Beer, turns out it's not.

Atmosphere: Wonderful layout, plenty of people and staff but you don't feel crowded.
author: Melissa R.

description:
Well, things didn't work out so well when I went to Zuni last week with my husband, mainly because the table where they sat us was very small and cramped. I mean, *really* cramped - I had a backache afterwards from sitting askew.

We should have asked to be moved, for sure. I've never had such a bad table at a fine-dining establishment.

If you go to Zuni, know that there are tables there that are not universally comfortable or pleasant, and you may have to advocate for yourself from the get-go, even if the place is packed and it's awkward. The staff apparently isn't all that sensitive to it. Frankly, the whole situation is ridiculous. You shouldn't have to be in agro-mode to get a good table, for these prices.

But I would suggest not going. The food wasn't that great either. One dish was good, the other, kinda not. Bland.  It just didn't cut it. If you are flush with cash and love to check out ritzy places, try your luck. If not, go to a better reviewed restaurant. There's a reason this place gets a lot of detractors. Hit or miss, my friends.
author: Dusty R.

description: Made it here after several years not being here. I had a seabass dish and their satsuma mousse dessert. The food was decent, but I remember it was better. Also, didn't realize they're expensive!
author: Yoko S.

description: Had a late lunch here a few weeks ago. Burger was served over cooked and without an apology. Shame. I had heard good things about this place. Too many better places to try it again.
author: Caroline K.

description: Made reservations for this place about two weeks out from our trip....have been trying to get here for a while. We started with the crispy fries as an app.......followed by the chicken/bread salad for two, for my one daughter and me (could have easily feed the three of us)......my other daughter had the pork chop.......we all felt that we would be having flash-backs back in Pittsburgh of how good this meal was. The chicken didn't disappoint, juicy and so flavorful with the bread sald and herbs on top. The pork chop was also perfectly cooked. This has a great bar, loved the vibe in here............really good, worth the price.
author: Sharon C.

description: Wow - this is one of the best meals I have had in SF so far.  The persimmon salad was so good, I will have to go back for it tomorrow.  The porcini mushroom dish - too delicious.   The chicken with chanterelle mushrooms - same thing.  The portions are not too big, beautifully presented and ridiculously delicious.  The main thing here is food quality - not quantity however.  But at least it won't make you fat!  And you will want more.  The only thing that wasn't good were the house spiced anchovies - these were quite bland, did not taste like high quality anchovies.  What they should do is get some white anchovies from whoever supplies them to Citarella in NYC.
author: Laurence S.

description: Great drinks! I've never had dinner here, but I've stood at the bar several times w/drinks and appetizers. Definitely a fan!
author: Art A.

description:
Zuni well deserves my 201th review.

Get the chicken, basta. 

I hate chickens in US, never order chicken at a restaurant. There's something about the meat texture/taste of chickens here that I just absolutely uninterested. But this is serious chicken. Crispy skin, juicy and tender meat, it's just gorgeous. 

Not sure about the bread salad though...too bready for me, but I do like the texture a lot. 

Drinks are really nice here. 

Unless I'm sharing the chicken with a couple more people, I would just go to Rolti truck at farmer's market and get my chicken/pork knuckle fix there.
author: Yuchi C.

description:
The interior is GORGEOUS.  It's casual but classy, upscale yet cozy.  On a cold, dreary, rainy, day, the heat from the wood burning stove in the middle of the restaurant rising to the tall, exposed-beam lofty ceilings creates the feeling that you're brunching in a converted barn in the countryside.

Tips: 
Certainly get a reservation.  The place is packed, with a line outside the door prior to opening.

This isn't a brunch-in-your-jammies place. This is a trendiest-outfit-in-your-closet place.  At all hours of the day.  Leave the flannels at home.

Trade your normal bloody Mary for the balsamic bloody Mary - it has a very clear difference in taste, though I just can't figure out why.  Trust me - it's worth the upsell.  

If you're a calorie counter, skip the bread.  It has a nice woodiness due to the big wood burning stove the loaves are cooked in, but it's a bit dry and not worth the stomach space in my opinion.

Drinks:
Sazerac  - knocked me off my feet, a great warm-and-fuzzy cocktail for a cold, rainy day.
Aperol cocktail - aperol, vodka, and orange peel, it tasted very citrusy but not strong.
Balsamic bloody Mary - just trust me here.  Have several.

Food:
For brunch, we did what we only reserve for very specific occasions - we ordered the chicken.  Yes, even in its *BEST STATE*, chicken is still just chicken, so I rarely order it, even when it's the dish the restaurant is "famous for".  However, after talking to a few locals and consulting friends, I was talked into the chicken (even the two nice men at the table nexus to us who were obviously eavesdropping our entire conversation had to interject, blow their cover, and reaffirm our choice of meal and drinks).  

It does take up to an hour to prepare, so order it right away if that's what you plan on.  Also, at $48 (it's chicken for two), it's definitely a splurge as far as chicken goes.  

I will say two things about this dish:
1. chicken-aside, just the bread salad it comes served on is nearly worth the $48 on its own.  It's grilled, tangy with balsamic, and oily and buttery.  It's littered with greens and currants, and has a nice sweet/salty/tangy taste going on, and the texture is both crunchy and soft.  Seriously, I may have paid the $50 just to have a big dish of this.

2.  before you burn me at the stake, I KNOW IT'S JUST CHICKEN.  I don't even really like chicken.  HOWEVER, as far as restaurants with chicken as their "specialty dish" go, Zuni has THE BEST chicken dish I have ever eaten, EVER.  Easily.  It's orders of magnitude better than its nearest competitors, at least in my mind.  The skin is crispy and thin and holds a great deal of flavor without tasting fatty.  It also shields the chicken itself from drying out, so the meat is moist and flavorful.

I know I know - it's chicken.  But if you have ever been tempted to "get the chicken" just because it's a restaurant's "most famous dish", here's the place to do it.
author: Heather G.

description:
everything is cyclical much like how fashion is cyclical and these days the trends seem to be in simplification. it's back to the basic. for food, it seems burgers, hotdogs, pizza, and all such foods have received a renewed interest and all of a sudden, you can find them anywhere, from the dingy diner to the swanky five-star restaurant. but even before all that, zuni knew it all along. their menu has always comprised of simple, clean dishes featuring quality, fresh ingredients. the roasted chicken for two w/bread salad is a fail-proof choice, and even the burger is flavorful and appealing to a non-beef eater. or it could be the fresh foccacia and cheese i'm really picking at ;)

amongst the many meals here, my favorite is still sunday brunch. you won't find diner-style bacon and waffles, instead expect seasonal salads, homemade preserves, delicate egg dishes, and pizzas. do try and snag a window view upstairs, despite the scary steep and creaky staircase. it makes a perfect start for any sunday funday.
author: helen l.

description:
Brick oven.
Great wine list.
Versatile setting (meaning it could be romantic or good for a group depending on where you sit or who you bring).
Open late.
Unbelievable cuisine.

I give it 5 stars!
author: Aunny B.

description:
I heard Zuni was the California cuisine of California cuisine.  The hamburgers here are supposed to be the best in the city.  One good thing about the restaurant is that you can come here late at night and get some atmosphere.  If it is late at night, I would definitely recommend over greasy diner.  You can leave here and go to sleep and not feel over full.

During regular hours, I wouldn't bother coming here.  It is large, so you don't get the intimacy of another restaurant where you would pay similar prices.  The fish is consistently overcooked.  The hamburgers are ok.  The oysters were so so.  The salads are nice.  I had some good scallops here, but I haven't had many bad scallops in the bay area.

I wouldn't suggest taking a date here.  The lighting is bright and not cozy.

The food takes a while, which is fine if you like to dine like the french do, but not good if you are in a hurry for a show.  Order some wine and chill with friends for a while.  At least they won't kick you out as the food hasn't arrived yet.
author: apple r.

description: Best anchovies I've ever had. Their oyster selection is enormous and all the ones we tried were outstanding. The cocktails were lovely, we had a wonderful salad with baby fava beans, and some pork confit that blew my mind. All around a great meal. The service was top-notch. My only complaints is the place is too loud to carry on a conversation. Unfortunately, some ladies sat near us who were wearing so much perfume we could no longer taste or smell our food -- disgusting, inconsiderate, and not at all the fault of the establishment.
author: Julie A.

description:
Cool place, great ambiance.
We only got dessert. It was delish!
author: Himani A.

description: We absolutely loved our dinner here.  It was easily the best salmon I have ever eaten and the BF's pork chop was also the best ever.  I tried some oysters, which were the best I had during our stay in SF.  We had some Cowgirl Creamery cheese after dinner with strawberries that was excellent, but we were a bit disappointed to only get two small strawberries with it.  Our biggest regret was eating here during the first night of the trip, because no meal after Zuni's tasted as good.  The service was good enough and we were lucky to be quickly seated in the bar area.
author: Megan C.

description:
My experience at Zuni cafe: We started out with the oysters, which were awesome. I samples about 8 diffferent types of oysters and was in absolute heaven, however all of the entrees we got were AWFUL. My friend Michelle's pasta was undercooked- it was still kind of crunchy!  My boyfriend's burger was bland, and the lamb I ordered was...well, bland, nothing special. However, our bill was RIDICULOUS!!!! The food was awful, with the exception of the oysters, which there was no way anyone could have messed up on them since they were raw.
The waiter was friendly and the ambiance was nice, but I AM NEVER going back there again.
author: Daniela A.

description:
I feel silly writing a review for a place that has already been written about hundreds of times already, but I have to mention one thing:

The raw shellfish appetizer plate is fantasic. We had intended on ordering their seafood appetizer plate, but they were out of crab and low on some other things. Half a dozen different types of oysters and some clams. I'm not even that much into raw oysters, but these were just fantastic. 

I remember the other food being really good, but I can't recall what exactly it was we ate. Everything just ended up being overshadowed by these oysters.
author: Holly T.

description:
The is a reason or two that this is a San Francisco classic.
The food is always great. The one time I wasnt crazy about my dinner, (it was oversalted) the waitperson took it off the bill. I totally appreciated that! We often bring out of town guests here for a taste of authentic SF style.
author: Melissa B.

description: I took my two Australian friends here Wednesday night, although I was unable to get a reservation they have walk in availability and it was great. The chicken as always was tremendous, our waiter was the most excellent that I have seen in some time my drink was never empty. We waited nearly an hour for the chicken and bread salad and in the mean time had nice ceasar salad and great clams and oysters. This place always has the best seafood. I have been going here for over twenty years now and I really love the Zuni it is indeed a unique San Francisco experience, if you haven't been here you need to go.
author: Peter A.

description: Very disappointing.   A small plate of anchovies over $10.  Thank goodness I had the anchovies to put on the bland Caesar salad.  The $30 pork chop was dry, the $40 chicken was dry and took over an hour to cook.  There is no magic to roasting a chicken and if this is their famous dish, they are riding on their past glory days.  The service was fine, the food just not.
author: Ray R.

description: Everyone comes here for the chicken which is amazing but takes 1 hour to prepare.  So you will have to order some apps and that is where the menu is a bit disappointing.  However the service is always excellent and they have some great wines by the glass to enjoy while you wait for your meal.  Value is ok for the price - portions are big.
author: Boris G.

description: Great service and food. Their roast chicken is excellent. Nice relaxed atmosphere, with live piano and very interesting art hung around the restaurant.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I love the ambiance here - very romantic place to go before the symphony or even for a first date.
The decor is really welcoming and the seating (bi-level) is fabulous for people-watching as well as creating a more open (non-claustrophobic) feeling.
The food on the other hand wasn't fabulous, but it was good.  I didn't try the famous chicken, but will re-review once I do.  The steak I had was so-so and everything as a whole was a little too rich/heavy for me.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
This was the 4th? time I've eaten here.  Yet again, perfect service, bleh food.

Bottom line: great for dishes that highlight fresh, organic produce.  Average, or below average (sorry!) for everything else.  A+++ for atmosphere, especially late night.  I think the two absolute hottest gay guys in the city sat next to us at around 11pm.

The baby mustard greens salad may have really been the best I've ever had.  Young, milder peppery greens with a mustard dressing, perfectly cooked new potatoes, shaved hard-boiled egg.  Picked-today freshness, really excellent, gotta say.

But........... as usual, everything else just continues to disappoint.
author: Melanie C.

description:
A very nice setting. The atmosphere is a little "stuffy"... if you know what I mean. If you're into that stuff, that's fine. But I honestly wouldn't come on any ordinary day just because the prices make me feel a little uncomfortable. 

The ordered the rabbit. It was my first time, and it wasn't bad at all. The little "cornbread" triangles served with it were so delicious. And the okra was the best I've ever had. 

There's a hefty wine list and an overpriced cocktail list. 

... enjoy!
author: Aromy X.

description: I have little day dreams about the chicken dinner,  pretty frequently.
author: Bucky M.

description:
i'd move in here if i could.  a great space with beautiful windows with lots of little nooks.  the unusual layout causes for some strange seating so be sure to ask for a table away from the door/stairwell when making reservations.

well, i didn't get to order the chicken (i know, i know...i'll come back for it).

the service at the bar was either non-existant or abrupt.  not a good start despite enjoying the warm copper bar.

but once seated, the service was stellar.

we ended up sharing 2 apps and added a salad.
the ricotta gnocchi - very rich and heavy so best shared.
the kale crostini was 3 small points and very tasty.
the frisee salad with sliced almonds was delicious.

the blue cheese with honey was a good slice and i loved that they cut the bread fresh and in front of you.  

the one oddity and i guessed it's the bistro like charm was the lack of a bread plate.  we sat next to the bread serving table so we helped ourselves to some plates.

the servers must have some solid legs going up and down the stairs.  well, just for that, they got a bit extra in the tip.
author: Anh V.

description: Pretty slim selection, and none of the items were very good. Very overpriced for what it is.
author: Sidharth K.

description:
I'd call it upscale comfort food with the cal-asian twist, killer mixed drinks, and with all the separate rooms, a great spot to reserve for a good sized party.  

Recommendations: Anything from the woodfire stove and the oysters. In fact, it's fun just to hug the bar if you're dining before heading to the theater. 

I'd give it an A-, but you can't dance to it.
author: Ben S.

description:
Waiting an hour for anything is hardly acceptable by my impatient/ADHD standards.  But, would I do it all over again for the oven slow-roasted whole chicken for two?  Oh fuck yeah.

The Chicken for two is so simple, slow-roasted and lightly crispy on the outside, yet juicy and all warm and tender in the mouth - sensual if you must.  It's plated over balsamic glazed bread pieces (a stuffing-like alternative) and currents are up in the mix.  It's finished with mint leaves that really compliment the whole combo-bite style of eating.

I highly recommend ordering this (it has to be for two - it is a whole bird) as soon as you are seated so that they can pop it in and maybe, just maybe you won't have to sit around and wait for it.

We also had the rabbit frisee salad that was superb - a bit hard to grab the nuts and salad on one fork, but eating difficulties aside, it was delicious.

The decor is also pretty posh - a corner building built mostly of glass windows, you get a bustling view of Market Street and all the characters that come along with it.  I saw a guy piss in a trash can, but I kinda liked it :)

It is a more romantic or intimate feel inside, but not inappropriate for business dinners.  Pretty much, the decor is solid.

I came here for a light dinner, so in regards to the bread, the rabbit frisee salad and the whole roasted chicken - this place is damn good.
author: Lauren G.

description:
The perfect spot to people watch.  Zuni's crowd was quite diverse the afternoon I went.

I gobbled up a plate of shoestring fries (perfectly salted) while my friends had a plate of oysters (which looked amazing, but due to my previous evening's festivities, I avoided).

Zuni doesn't have a very big menu, but the food was excellent.  We had a very, very late brunch (read: dinner), so I'll have to go back to see what all the fuss is about their brunch menu.

If it's on par with what I had for dinner (the tuna), then I'm sure I'll be quite happy.
author: Matt Y.

description:
I wish there were more places like Zuni in the city....

I have this theory that if a place can't make descent fries they suck. At least this is my excuse to order fries everywhere I go. It's in my DNA. Zuni's fries are to die for! So is the burger.

Last time we went, we shared some gnocchis. OMG!!! Neither one of us ever had gnocchis so fresh and so amazing. Words are failing me to describe this superlative experience. It's going straight to my Pasta list!
author: Elsa T.

description: Good food in a really cool space.  Actually, a group of spaces.  Because the restaurant has such a unique configuration, each dining experience seems different.  One night you'll sit at a table in an intimate area with just a few other tables, another night you'll dine in a more traditional dining room.  The waiters are knowledgeable and professional.
author: John S.

description: First time at Zuni. Came late for lunch and ended up with the dinner menu. Found the portions to be very small and overpriced.  Would not bother going back.
author: Mark W.

description:
Apparently, 853 reviewers have already weighed in on their Zuni experience, so . . . it really doesn't matter what I say here.  I believe in economics they call this phenomenon "diminishing marginal utility."

Anyway, my friend and I came here last Wednesday.  We showed up 15 minutes early, and the hostess offered us to wait at the bar until they were ready to seat us.  It didn't look as though Zuni was particularly busy, but we did have reservations for 6:30.  So, we waited.  Since neither of us felt like getting a drink, we were, umm, loitering in the bar area, staring at the people and peeking into the open kitchen.  At least four different Zuni employees (a bartender, a kitchen staff member and 2 waiters) asked us if we needed some help.  Boy, that was really nice!   Even if they did mean "get out of my way," they sure phrased it nicely.

Finally, the hostess found us and escorted us to our table.  We followed the hostess blindly, as she led us from one tiny room to another, masterfully maneuvering around people and tables.  Did I mention her outfit reminded me of Mad Men's Peggy Olsen from season one?  Anyway, when she showed us to our table, it was definitely worth the long walk.  We were at a big 2-person table by the window overlooking a dark alley.  There were three other tables in our nook, but our table was by far the most isolated and, therefore, the best.

On the way to the restaurant, we agreed that we would order the chicken.  Our waiter, a tall, soft-spoken gentleman, asked us if we were thinking about the chicken.  Since the chicken takes about an hour to prepare, he put our order in right away and then returned to take the rest of our order.  He was very nice and polite, although he could not seem to offer an opinion on what we should have and in what order we should have it.  I know that the meek shall inherit the earth, but come on, man!

So, we had an hour to kill before our chicken was ready.  Word to the wise: do NOT go to Zuni with someone you don't particularly like or know all that well.  You will need to do a lot better than a few awkward pauses or uncomfortable silences to fill that one-hour wait.  Fortunately, we didn't have that problem.  Besides, we filled those voids with food.

We started with a salad that wasn't memorable at all.  Quite literally, I don't remember what was in that salad besides pomegranate kernels.  Our second appetizer was polenta served with Parmesan cheese.  That was easily my favorite part of the meal.  Delicious, perfectly cooked polenta served with freshly grated Parmesan cheese...yum.  Our third appetizer was ricotta cheese gnocchi.  It was basically balls of ricotta cheese and flour boiled in water.  It wasn't really gnocchi, but it was pretty good nonetheless.  Bonus points for our waiter who, having learned that we were going to split the appetizers, served them on separate plates.  Very nicely done, sir.

When we were done with the appetizers, we still had about 20 minutes to wait for our chicken.  When it arrived, we were relieved to see it was served pre-carved into smaller, more manageable pieces.  6 large pieces of chicken were served on a bed of bread salad.  Bread salad, a Zuni specialty, is a misnomer.  What bread salad is is a few small pieces of sourdough soaked in chicken fat and vinaigrette and mixed with some greens.  Sure, it has the word "salad" in it, but don't you worry: it's not good for you.  The chicken itself, I am sorry to say, was pretty underwhelming.  It was decently roasted organic chicken, but it was not the "OMG-this-is-to-die-for-and-I-don't-care-it's-$48" chicken I expected.  I must be missing something because I thought it was good, but not great.  I rarely order chicken at a restaurant due to the messiness factor, and I don't think I'll be making another exception for Zuni any time soon.

***3 stars for food + 4 stars for service = 3.5 stars, rounded up. ***
author: Yan G.

description:
Zuni, zuni, zuni... 

What can I say, that hasn't already been said.  
This is one of the few S.F. institution that still is in business and has maintained the same owners.  Not many places can say that!
It's lovely to see something great that hasn't become corporatized; a feat these days.   

The pasta's are perfection, the antipasti combo's are unique and delish... the chicken is worth the wait... although once we tried calling them and asked to put in the order, but it was against policy to order unless you're seated.  It takes 40 minutes so...    

I've had dinner and lunch here often over the years, and the only time I had a so-so meal was when it was really packed on the weekend and the time I came with an air-head model I was dating.  I don't think it was Zuni's fault though, as everywhere I went with him turned into a complete debacle.  I'm sorry I was at Zuni as that memory is forever embedded into my head for some reason... 

Come here with great company, and you'll have a great time.  
Ceasar, martini and Kumamoto oysters are a good place to start.  

Also, I've recently been reading the Zuni Cookbook, and it's the Dean & Deluca cookbook of it's time.  It reads like a novel, and has great techniques and tips... simple but avant-garde food  and also the Chicken/bread salad recipe if for some reason you're not in the Bay area and want to re-create it for someone who can't travel to San Francisco....
author: L. K.

description: The 45 minute wait for the roasted chicken was so worth it!! Their strawberry meringata was light, smooth and so full of flavor!!!
author: Karla R.

description:
Our group was excited about spending a nice evening at Zuni Cafe until it was spoiled by a very grumpy bartender (should of got his name but he's older, taller & full of grey hair - wonder why!)  He was robotlike with no expression or sense of warmth.  We felt rushed to decide on what drink to order.  It was like we were doing him an honor ordering from him.  I would of made a scene but did not want to spoil the evening for everyone.  At one point, he flattly stated "What do you want to order" in a stern, unfriendly voice.  There was absolutely nothing we did to provoke such attitude but arrive 15 mins before our reservation to enjoy a cocktail.

On the food side...Zuni Cafe is famous for the Caesar Salad, Oysters and Chicken (which takes about 1 hr to prepare).  It's definitely worth trying.

As a sidenote, all other staff members seemed to enjoy their jobs.
author: Rob T.

description:
Nice place, classy in its casual californian way not to be mistaken with sloppiness.  Food is good, looks and taste as fresh as the west coast sea breeze. The oysters, make sure you try them. The price tags ain't something you would cheez about. Ambiance? Feel the hustle of the staff & bustle of chitter-chatter meandering the tiny spaces between tables and people waiting (& have been waiting) to be seated. Oh yeah, parking's a b!tch. In short, a metropolitan dining ala San Francisco.  
Will I go there again? Sure! But I'm not driving :p
author: Kat S.

description:
I am actually going to give Zuni - 4 and a half stars - because of thier wineglasses. A restaurant of this caliber should have Big Bordeux glasses for thier red wine drinkers and Chardonnay glasses for thier white wine patrons.  CMON Zuni - step it up!!

The food however was top notch!
Zuni Caesar salad was really good - great balance of salty and garlicy flavors - add fresh romaine and parmesan - yum!

Lamb shoulder was tender and delicious - 
Espresso ice cream - was like a piece of cake with some cream - 
Cappucinos - were heavenly!
Server knew the food quite well and was very laid back - no snoots which I hear is a regular trend at this establishment.
author: Christian S.

description:
The burger is the main reason you should try this place and pledge undying love to the people who can put you in a food induced happy coma.  The rest of the food is the reason why you should always come back.  :) 

The Burger here surpasses many. Yes... it is not a cheap burger place but soooooo worth the money.  They season the sirloin overnight and then grind it into chuck.  So, the flavors just go all the way through.  MMmmmmm.....
author: H. Q.

description:
Wow!  I just moved to SF 6 mos. ago and had until recently not been wowed by the "value" of any of the many supposedly great restaurants in this town.  But Zuni Cafe... well, 

We walked over one day for brunch, and ordered a bit of variety -- G had a hamburger and I had french toast; wanted some meat on the side so they gave me some of the skirt steak.  It was fun to sit at one of the tables looking into the kitchen 'cz I'm kinda a foodie.  Everything was excellent, and when the bill came was pleasantly surprised to see how affordable it was..  Less than $40 with tip.... even with the fancy bottled water, plus coffee, etc.  Don't let the white tablecloths fool you; this is extremely affordable for this level of food and service.  Congrats, SF, you are starting to win me over!
author: Steve O.

description:
Really, this is a 4.5 star review, but I just couldn't give it just a 4 star rating.  I FINALLY got over here last weekend, and was a happy camper when I left.

This was the best chicken dish I've ever had.  Needless to say, we had the roast chicken with bread salad, which was cooked to perfection.  The skin is crisp, the chicken is juicy, but well cooked, and it's seasoned flawlessly.  The greens in the salad add a nice bitterness to the rich bread salad, which has all the lovely crunchy bits, and still has the soft elements.  

We also had the Olympia Washington oysters, which were lovely, and gnocchi with brussel sprouts.  

To finish off the meal, I had the creme brulee, and he had the espresso granita. I've never seen my man happier.  It was very flavorful granita, with a perfect texture.  My creme brulee was just the right size, not stuffing you, and not overly custardy.

It's an excellent meal, with very friendly service, though we were upstairs in an area that left our servers with a bit of a challenge to check in on us frequently, so sometimes, the waterglasses needed to be filled a bit longer than I'd prefer.
author: Erin O.

description:
Pretty much amazing.

I like this quaint, chic little spot because the dishes are simple but absolutely delish.  We went for brunch.  Try the french toast with blood oranges and pistachios- yum!  I hear their pizza is delightful also.  

The ambience is very California chic, but without the snob effect.  Try the frozen espresso dessert (and have a caffeine buzz for the next 5 hours!) with a lovely dessert wine...absoutely fantastic.  

A little on the pricey side but well worth it.  Go for an early lunch.

*Tangent: celebrity sighting! - Victor Garber (Eli Stone, Alias, Legally Blonde (the professor), Titanic)
author: Kristen S.

description:
Been here for lunch and had the burger, all that they say and more. Came back last week for dinner, had the famous chicken, again totally lived up to the hype. Had a bloody mary too (weird for dinner but I didn't really want a cocktail and I wanted to kinda hit the Zuni highlights since I was there). MY GOD IT WAS THE BEST BLOODY MARY I HAVE EVER HAD.....GET IT. screw wine with dinner! or do what i do and have both. 

Sat downstairs next to the windows for dinner, I thought it was perfectly fine place to sit, I don't really know why people diss this area...it was lovely. 

Started with oysters, they were very fresh and good, but not as good as I've had elsewhere  - but if you like oysters I wouldn't be deterred to order them. Moved on to Caesar salad, NOT worth the hype. I don't really get that reputation, but then again, I'm not really a Caesar salad girl. The dessert was forgettable. It's all about the meat here. 

The chicken is a lot of food, the man and I couldn't finish it all, that is rare, we can eat a lot. No fear, we brought it home and it really spiced up the mac n cheese we had for lunch the next day (is that sacrilege?). I am one of those people that never orders chicken from a restaurant cause I eat so much of it at home and seriously every night growing up, so it's gotta be extra special for me to order it, and this was worth it. 

We were here for 2.5 hours. that's a long time, the chicken takes at least an hour, it's true. we totally took our time though, it was date night and we didn't want to be rushed so it was actually perfect. the service was great in the beginning and seemingly after they realized we were that couple that hogs the table all night our attentive server abandoned us. seriously.
author: Sarah G.

description:
The downstairs staff had more attitude than a San Francisco institution should.  Come on, this isn't L.A.  We arrived at 5:52 for a 6:00 reservation, but the host considered us too early to be seated and sent to the bar, as were many others.  The thing is, restaurants want you to be on time, and this doesn't really provide the right incentive to do so.  I'll be sure to be 5-10 minutes late if there is a next time.  The drinks at the bar were good but not good enough to justify the high prices.  I overheard the bartender telling the woman to my left something about not having fruity drinks or some such thing.  He did make her something pretty with cassis in it in the end.  It's fine if you want to maintain discerning standards at the bar, but overall it just wasn't friendly.  Plus we couldn't shift the tab to our table.

The food was good though.  Oysters were excellent -- I had scoped out the oyster bar while waiting for the table, and they looked great, and I was glad to get them.  Each type really tasted distinct and extremely fresh, and the mignonnette sauce went with them well.  The prosciutto appetizer was different than expected, with each piece wrapped around some cheese making a little purse, and they were delicious.  The fish I had as a main course was very good as well, though not out of this world.

Also, we got a great table upstairs by the window which was nice.  You could look down below and see the bread being cut and people filling in.  The service upstairs was fine -- friendly and reasonably attentive.

So basically, they're an institution, and while at times it feels like I can get equally fresh and local food elsewhere, it's good to remember the institutions that led the way.  But next time I get dinner before the ballet, I'm heading to Fish & Farm or trying Conduit instead.  Food was 4 star, the experience was 2 star, so we're at 3 star for this review.
author: Leo C.

description:
I love that place. I usually go for the chicken (always p-e-r-f-e-c-t) but tonight I chose the lamb stew served in a saffron sauce with English peas.... sooooo delicious. The Gigondas wine was exactly what it should be: in your face, leathery and muscular... seriously good. Dessert? Oh yeah: a sublime tangerine granita - crisp and fresh. 

Can I give 5.5 stars?
author: Lili G.

description:
This is based on my experience, which was limited to 3 items. I did not have the roast chicken which everyone raves about, but then again Zunni's has a large menu, and it should not be judged solely based on its best item. I went with another person for a light lunch and we ordered a burger, shoestring fries and a wood fired pizza. When the waitress took the order for the burger, she said "medium-rare OK?", and I said "No, I want it rare. Can you do that?" She said "Yes." The burger was served medium. It was OK, nothing great, but for $15 alacarte for a burger, it wasn't even close to rare.
The wood-fired pizza was absolutely the worst wood-fired pizza I have had in the Bay Area, completely bland and flavorless. The only thing preventing this being a one star review were the shoestring fries which were great. I would rate the fries 4 stars, but that is not enough to save the rest of the order.
author: Archie G.

description:
Zuni Cafe was a suggestion from a chef friend, so I did go in with slightly higher expectations than normal.  The restaurant itself was cute, open kitchen, rustic and simple with big windows.  We were celebrating a birthday for a very important & special person - Elizabeth!  It was a nice dinner of 5 and among us all we ordered: the infamous roasted chicken (that later the leftovers were left in the coat check of a comedy club, we mourned the loss of the chicken,) the pork chop, the salmon, spaghetti with porcini mushrooms and for apps, the burratta crostini, clams and the fried squab app.  (which YES I tried it, but just a tiny little piece so I can't really say that I've had it, but kudos to me for being "adventurous!")  I personally had a taste of everything except the pork chop & clams and it all was so good.  The infamous roasted chicken was good - but it didn't blow me away.  I thought that it would have since it takes an hour and it's the one thing that everyone talks about.  The spaghetti with mushrooms was simple, but honestly I think it was my favorite.  The burratta crostini was delicious and I wish I had ordered my own.  They don't have a limit of BYOB and the corkage fee is $20.  We thought that because we shared our wine and cake w/ our waiter AND ordered a bottle of dessert wine that he'd knock off one of the fees (we brought 3 bottles) - but he didn't.  He did give me a tour of the kitchen, but still restaurant/server etiquette would have been to only charge 2 corkage fees.  The menu is simple and changes often because they use seasonal ingredients which is always a plus because if you know that they create great dishes, you can always go back and try something new.  I'd definitely try it again, but considering how many restaurants there are in S.F. there are others I'll need to try before I go back.  If I lived there it would be different.
http://notomatoesplease.wordpress.com/2010/06/28/dont-forget-to-wear-flowers-in-your-hair/
author: Kim N.

description:
I checked out Zuni on a Saturday night with my boyfriend and best friend. Our chef friend Chris Kidder had recommended the spot because he had once been a cook there. We just wanted a light meal before going out for the night, so we ordered several appetizers to get a taste for the place. Here's what we ordered and what we thought about it:
The polenta with marscapone and parmesean cheese was simple and delicious, with a perfectly creamy texture and comforting warmth. 
The ceasar salad, which we heard was a Zuni classic, lived up to its hype. I'm normally not a fan of ceasar salads because I find them too bland and uninspired. This one was an exception to the rule, made with the crispest romaine lettuce, a house-made dressing whose garlic and anchovy flavors shone, and crunchy, zesty house-made croutons. 
A great accompaniment to the salad were the shoestring french fries, which came to our table in a well-salted, heaping portion and were made even better when our waiter brought over some house-made aioli and ketchup.
We also ordered clams stewed with zucchini and tomato, but these were a little disappointing. The clams were good, but some of the zucchini arrived uncooked, and the broth lacked the flavor I expected after tasting their other dishes.
My boyfriend and friend shared the rabbit and mustard greens salad, since I would have no part in the bunny-killing. They didn't seem mind at all, though: "The rabbit, which was a mix of confit and meat, was tender and went well with the greens' natural spiciness. It made for a good salad." 
Zuni is in a beautiful brick flatiron building that has an urban Soho vibe, yet a warm, comfy feel. Our waiter, who appeared to have no qualms with being given the casual bar section on a Saturday night, was patient and welcoming even though it was clear we weren't coming in to spend a lot of money.
If you want to eat at a classic spot in San Francisco, I'd recommend this one. They seem to be best at doing the simple dishes--just really, really well. Hopefully we can go back for a full dinner soon.
author: Sam O.

description: I've only been here once, but I've been dying to go back ever since.  There is no point going into exactly what we had because I would say everything we tried was delicious.  We didn't have a reservation which will be my only correction on my next visit.  The place was bustling and we were unable to sit in the formal dining area without waiting hours. (We sat downstairs near the bar instead, but were seated promptly). I'm really excited to go back for the second time around.  Hopefully, my impression will stay 5 star.
author: Sun M.

description:
My first time at Zuni Cafe.  Maybe I went on an off day, maybe I just didn't order what I was supposed to.  Or did I?

I ordered a lemonade in the bar area while waiting on my friend, and all the while, watched food pass by.  I was so hungry, I ordered a plate of fries that would hopefully arrive when my friend did.  The lemonade was utterly tasteless, mostly thinned out with water.  However, the fries were delectably thin, perfectly crisped, and shattered with every finger licking bite.

I ordered six oysters, all fresh, briny.  However, my friend's shepherd pie was so tiny I could have eaten it in one bite.  It was also bland and boring.

The chicken for two was juicy, but very tasteless.  The skin was somewhat crisp, the bread salad, very under-seasoned.  Currants and pinenuts were a good addition, but the dressing had no acidity, giving the bread and greens a nasty slick which coated the back of my mouth.

Service can be a little absentminded, e.g. one busser and one waitress for about 8 tables in the upstairs seating area.  And it didn't help that our waitress was so tall and her behind got in the way of the two tables.  It was not a pleasant sight.  

I am not returning to Zuni again.
author: Lisa K.

description: Ok so here it is my review: if u are vegetarian avoid this place. Their best dish is the chicken! Everything else is so bland with no flavor at all. We tried their pasta, fish and salads.....nothing special. Even their desert is nothing extraordinarily. But their prices are astonishingly high for tasteless food. (how can they charge $10 for an inch of cake?) The service is not bad, but when your bill comes to $200 then they better have a good service.
author: Paolo D.

description: Ah this place is a bit pricey for the portion size but boy, is it fantastic! We got this delicious garlic potato soup... this mushroom fettuccine that was oh my god. The best. So simple but I was in love. Oh and the shoestring fries are also fabulous.
author: Natasha P.

description:
hit up zuni's last sat with a friend. w/o a reservation, don't even bother. the wait for a table + the extra hour if you order their signature roast chicken w/ bread salad (which you totally should try) means for lots of down time...or a bottle of wine in my case--their selection of reds were all pretty good XP. 

the chicken is tender, moist, and flavorful. sadly, i think i liked the bread salad more. the vinaigrette soaked softness with crunchy toasted crust was just too good to pass up on. they also had an extensive selection of oysters from tomales bay and hog island (always a good sign). too bad they didn't have my kumamoto's. :( finished off the meal with a creme brulee which was light and creamy. thank you big eat SF!
author: Myra C.

description:
This has been reviewed a couple times, eh?  

Casual mid afternoon business lunch on a Thursday.  The atmosphere was incredibly laid back, but the service seemed a bit out of it, or disinterested.  It didn't impact the meal that much... I asked for a fork, it was forgotten.  I asked for tabasco.. it was forgotten.  

My lunchmate's pork loin looked *great*; the presentation was stellar, it looked moist and perfectly cooked, and the accompaniement wasn't only attractive, but functionally deferential to the pork... adding to the depth of the loin without overpowering it's sweet pork taste.  

The Miyagi and Pacific oysters out of Tomales were DREAMY and the mignonette was a perfect, classic arrangement.  I am tired of weird mignonettes.... it's a classic and traditional option for the menu, and that's why it's there.  There is no need to all of a sudden challenge us with something that completely retards the integrity of it's classicism.  So on my charge to rid menus of the played out ahi tartare, I am also of the opinion a mignonette should be a mignonette, and that's that.

I got a burger.. opting to test the stand-by on the menu.  Interesting that the whole experience seemed that clinical that I was viewing it from a reviewer perspective rather than enjoying my meal.

The shoestring potatoes were a bit boring as an addition to my meal - hard and too salty.  The foccacia on my burger was awful, frankly.  It was dry, bland, and crumbled around the burger.  The burger was dusted with little to no blue cheese, albeit that's what I ordered.  I sort of had to hunt and peck for it.  It was there, but you shouldn't have to remove your badly damaged bun to prove that.  The pickles and onions looked great, and tasted delicious.  The server *was* nice, but a bit obsqeqious, overly so... that endless deference that seems like the smile is a bit too tight lipped, and the gracious bow is just too sarcastic. It was a late business lunch tho... maybe they had their off day crew of hungover troglodytes.  I am totally just kidding... 100%.  I just like playing at haughty ostentation.  Seriously... she forgot some stuff, seemed like her act was laid on a bit thick... but everyone has an off day.  It's decently priced, too, for a business outing.  In the end, I also admit to a new addiction -  The bread they bring to the table is awesome.

I have been a couple times, I will go a few more.  I mused giving 3 stars, but until more research is done four it is.  You will likely be happy with your experience here, but hell.. I don't even know you.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: If you have $15 and want to spend it on the best gourmet burger you'll ever have in your entire life, come to Cafe Zuni. I spent the last $15 to my name here getting a medium rare burger with grilled onions and heirloom tomatoes (fancy, yar?) and have zero regrets. Do it.
author: Pam S.

description:
I went back for lunch yesterday for the first time in years.  The service is great and the atmosphere is as fun as always, but the food was disappointing. The beets in my salad were tough and the onion, fennel, tomato soup was watery.  My companion's pizza looked good but she had to send it back to be reheated.

I'd give it another chance but it was disappointing.
author: Elisabeth W.

description: For the price, definitely not worth it. Our salad was a few pieces of arugula. I got the saffron halibut and it was severely lacking in flavor.  It's never a good sign when you leave a 4 course meal feeling hungry. Not recommended
author: Jen M.

description:
Knowing how difficult to be seated without reservation, we still tried this restaurant walk-in.  Luckily, we get a table after 30 min wait with a help of an Asian server.  (He was very friendly and nice.)  But this guy at the entrance (I should have asked for his name) was very mean telling my bf to wait by the door.  Uh, no one was asked to make wait line beside you but my bf.... u prejudice or what?  
Food was good but giving 3 star because of this guy's ignorance.
author: Tomo S.

description:
Decent food, but pricey for the food and portions you get.  The infamous chicken did look yummy but I didn't want to wait an hour + for it.  Maybe next time - though it would still be hard for me to justify $39 for a chicken.  Oyster selection was quite extensive and the server suggested a very good selection.  There are really only about 5 different entrees, so if you're with a picky-eater, you might want to see what is on the menu first. 

We were seated at a roomy and cozy table upstairs but I thought alot of other diners seemed to be crammed into awkward and tight configurations.

Contrary to many reviews, I enjoyed the service and didn't find them pretentious at all.
author: Amina B.

description:
Zuni Caf is one of those restaurants that is unique to its home city. Although of French seafood cafe design, Zuni exudes San Francisco flavor at every turn. The servers are incredibly knowledgeable on wines, their pairings, and most importantly, their oyster selections! If you're a chicken, Caesar-salad, and oyster fan, you've stumbled into a little slice of heaven. Be sure to make a reservation if you plan on loitering with a group, but walking in on a Friday night for a pre-dinner appetizer and drink and plopping down in the wedge shaped bar seats is one of my favorite pastimes.

Chicken for 2 is a must to try at least once, and we usually do so with 3 or 4 people (you're eating the whole bird with a rich, current laden bread-salad stuffing.) As well, their salads are excellent across the boards, and I do love the double-cut pork chop when it's on the menu. If you're into oysters, they have one of the most thorough menus in the city complete with both east and west coast US varieties represented, as well as a few Canadian thrown in for good measure. Our favorite mid-sized, buttery flavored lovelies include the Malpec, Kumamoto, Wellfleet, and many others, and again, the well educated staff can help guide you on your adventures through mollusk town.

With an all brass bar top and fittings, and the striking full glass window behind the bottle shelves make the bar at Zuni very impressive. Test their tenders by ordering an old-school cocktail (Negroni, Manhattan, Side Car, etc.) and be deliciously rewarded for your prodding. As well, the wines by the glass and aperitif menu is well rounded with the usual and some surprising flavors.
