I try to get to Zuni at least once every 3 or 4 weeks, and I've never had a less than perfect meal!
author: Ankarino L.

description:
In the battle of "love it or hate it," I'll have to side with the former.  Though my pocketbook and non-profittering has not given me many opportunities to dine at this fine establishment, I can and will vouch for the sea bass, the quail, and the beef.  Oh and of course the shoestring fries.  The blue nose bass was delicious, if not a tad bit on the salty side (to be expected with salt water-dwelling fish?)  The quail was spectacular and paired ever so perfectly with the chantrelles and polenta.  Maintained a lot of moisture and not in the least bit dry.  Beef was cooked to perfection.  Very simple meals that highlight the ingredients of the food in a very Alice Waters type of way.  

Why so expensive for poultry and everything else at Zuni, you may ask?  Zuni Cafe is a steward in the very respectable Community Alliance with Family Farmers (CAFF: http://www.caff.org/).  Their mission is "...to build a movement of rural and urban people to foster family-scale agriculture that cares for the land, sustains local economies and promotes social justice..."  So you're paying for the local, sustainable, seasonal, small farms food, not the GMO-ed, large corporation technologically enhanced, farmers poisoned by pesticide and/or laid off my huge machines that take over their jobs food that is extensively cheaper. 

Yes, even food is political and I believe Zuni makes a great statement by supporting groups like CAFF.
author: Helen T.

description:
This is really a 3.5

Service was a litte bit above average.  We never had to wait long for anything.

We started off with some oysters.  A couple of them did not taste too fresh.

Next, we had clams in white wine, hot peppers, basil, garlic, and butter.  The sauce was very tasty and went well with the crusty bread they provided.

Third, was the quail.  We split it.  It was tiny.  This was the only low point in the meal.  But this was probably our fault.  We should have gotten the damn chicken.  Our neighbors got it and we kept on looking over at it, drooling. 

Desserts, pretty damn good.  I had an espresso granita and my gf had a caramel custard.  Great.

Dowside is the price.  $27 for a little quail is uncalled for.  The oysters were a little expensive as well.

Overall it was a good experience though.  If given the chance, I might come back to try the chicken.  But other than that, I've had better meals.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I'm sorry but Zuni Cafe seems to be the definition of foo-foo food. All presentation but ZERO taste. Don't get me wrong, I'm happy to pay $40-$80 for small portions if the food tastes great but I've been to Zuni twice now and even if it was all made with exotic ingredients every thing I ordered was the among the most bland tasteless food I've ever eaten.

I get the feeling this is more a place to be seen eating and to pretend you're at a fancy restaurant than to actually be a place to eat great gourmet food
author: Gregg T.

description:
we got there for our early rez and hit the bar for a glass of vino first. ZUNI is a cool, industrial, warm and modern space. immediately upon walking in it hit me how much NOPA had been influenced by ZUNI (or least it seemed so).

when they were finally ready to seat us, the hostess asked if she could take our wine glasses to the table for us. very nice service, i thought. she ushered us to what seemed like the best table in the house. all the way in the corner right next to the giant windows overlooking market street. we were one of the first parties to be seated and so at first we felt like we had the place all to ourselves. in fact they didn't seat anyone down next to us for at least half of our meal, so we had some nice privacy which was relaxing.

i had planned on ordering one of the housemade burgers as our appetizier, but i was dissapointed to learn that they do not serve them at dinner. which was odd as i was pretty sure i had noticed it on the menu at the bar earlier, but the menus vary a bit i suppose. just means i'll have to get back soon for the burger.

instead we started off with some tastey fried calamari, chickpeas and parlsey salad. the calamari had a nice crispy battered exterior and paired wonderfully with the chickpeas and parsley.

we also split their caesar salad which was an excellent version with beautiful whole, little leaves of romaine accompanied by a very bright (meyer lemon perhaps) and sardiney dressing. they split the salad for us without asking which was very thoughtful.

our last appy was an order of their shoestring fries. these are the real deal. these fries are actually the size of shoestrings. not the usual McDonalds style shoestring fries a lot of places serve. amazing that they could be so skinny and still be tender inside. i asked for a side of aioli to eat them with and the most wonderful, garlicky aioli was presented. the ketchup seemed like standard Heinz fare, but i didn't realy care since the aioli was delish.

as it's well known, ZUNI is famous for their roast chicken. a whole roast chicken with bread salad for $39. i must admit i balked at paying so much for roast chicken when i first heard about it, but i'm glad i gave in. it was probably the best roast chicken i've ever had. the legendary chicken takes an hour to prepare, which they warn you. ordered this right away when we arrived. it finally arrived and it was a gorgeous platter of bronze-skinned chicken. started with the thigh which was unctuous and superb. even the breats were super juicy. and the bread salad, which i had never had before, was quite tastey. chunks of bread which had sopped up the chicken juices with cripsy crusty edges almost like grilled cheese (minus the cheese).

btw, we asked and it seems the chickens are supplied by Hoffman.

for dessert we split some meyer lemon ice cream. simple and delicious and an appropriate way to cap off such a delicious meal.
author: Brian J.

description:
It's an institution by now in the restaurant world?  Zuni has been at this location like FOREVER?!?  I remember eating there for the first time like too many years ago...so it can't be that bad if it's still around.

Two things I recall very well - the caesar salad and the upstairs dining.  It has been a long time and sounds like it deserves a revisit sooner than later.
author: Gloria H.

description:
OMG, the roasted chicken is to die for! Granted chicken should not be that pricey but it's quite a culinary experience!

I went because the place is known for its chicken. A whole chicken is slowly baked and roasted in a wood-fired oven. Because of this low process (I had to wait 45-60mins to be served), the skin and ultra crispy, yet ulta lean (all the fat was melted away during the roasting process). The meat was so juicy and aromatic from the marinated herb that they stuffed under the skin. I really never had chicken this lean and healthy. If you're ok with droping $50 for some out-of-this-world-will-still-think-about-it-months-after chicken (enough for 2 people), then you should check out Zuni's.

Other than the chicken, I had their seasonal oyster shoots and it was so-so. So, I really don't recommend anything other than the chicken. The service was pleasant and amiable.
author: My V.

description:
This was one of the first restaurants I came to when I moved to SF 3 1/2 years ago, so I had ZERO expectations. What a great spot! It's crowded, but to me that just makes it more lively. 

What made it really memorable was the power went out. I was expecting the restaurant to turn completely chaotic: glass breaking, people shouting etc... The staff didn't miss a beat. They immediately brought out more candles and proceeded to serve people IN THE DARK! 

The chicken was amazing and the wine list was great. I really should put Zuni back on the list of restaurants I want to revisit as it was a wonderful experience all in all.
author: Carson H.

description:
My husband and I had dinner here a couple weeks ago. Zuni was always one of our favorite SF restraunts, and we hadn't been in quite a while b/c there's always someplace new to check out, but you have to remind yourself to go back to your old standbys every now and again...

We managed to get a table in a relatively short amount of time, with no reservation. Also cool was that they sat us right next to John Waters (the director of Pink Flamingoes, writer/director of the original Hairspray, etc). 

The food was excellent (we had their famous chicken for two- which was truly heaven!), but the WAITRESS was downright TERRIBLE...she made a series of mistakes, one after another, ranging from forgetting my appetizer and then blaming it on the bar, to asking my husband if he wanted pepper on his ceasar salad but then never bringing it, to spilling oyster juice on my fur shoes and not even offering me a napkin to clean it off! I don't even remember all of her other mistakes but  by the end of the meal, I counted 6 different things she screwed up! She was probably the worst waitress I've ever encountered in a fine dining establishment... 

We NEVER leave less than a 20% tip, but in this case we left just 15%... we probably should have left even less just to make our point b/c I'm sure she just assumed we were cheap! Unfortunately, this crappy waitress left a bad taste in our mouth, even though the food was great! Not to say that we won't be ever back, but we'd definitely seek a different waiter...don't know her name but she mentioned her beau is the chef at Azie??
author: BR K.

description:
Finally got over to Zuni last night. We had a delicious meal! Had reservations & we were seated right away. Overall two thumbs up. I do recommend this place. Mmmmm.

The wine was great, the oysters delicious and the chicken really was THAT good. I liked the serving sizes for sharing several plates with the table (arugula salad, sardines, fried zucchini blossom salad w/sweet 100 cherry tomatoes, rabbit salad, gnocchi). 

The service was decent, we had to make sure to flag the server down early to order our chicken, it does take an hour so order it immediately so you can enjoy your dining experience more. No bread plate so my crumbs were all over my paper menu. The server then (purposely) dumped the crumbs in front of my sister in law as she took the menu away, how strange! I thought she might just take the menu and dump the crumbs in the compost or trash in the kitchen...

Dessert was delicious, their signature chocolate cake & also got a crepe w/nectarine & blueberries. 

I agree w/another post, the nectarine for $5 is a little bit silly. We joked about how funny it would be if it was just a nectarine & when we asked they confirmed that's all it was! Yes, everything is pretty much all local, sustainable but I can get several of those bad boys at my local farmer's market for the same price. So we paid a couple of $ more for the crepe that was delish. 

Overall great experience! I am between 4 and 5 stars here only because of the slightly strange service but that may have just been luck of the draw and she wasn't that bad. 

Highly recommend the oysters, gnocchi (we had spinach & ricotta, yum!) and chicken! The menu rotates but I think they generally will have these items more or less. 

Bon appetite!
author: Abby W.

description:
For our last night in San Francisco (boo-hoo!), we had another ridiculously fantastic meal at Zuni.  For four of us, we ordered a starter, 2 caesars (oh how I love their caesar!), a roast chicken, a fish, and a pork chop.  Wow - it was all amazing.  You guys are right about the roast chicken, aren't you?  It was all fabulous, and our service was top-notch, as always.  

I'll miss you Zuni, and hope to visit you again soon. xoxo
author: Jenn K.

description:
A nice (and crowded) restaurant with simple (in a good sense) food.

Their roasted chicken is a must-have.  It goes very well with the bread that's placed underneath the chicken.  Their ceaser salad was also good.

Overall a very pleasant restaurant, although I think they were a bit overpriced.
author: Durif M.

description:
Mom and I had dinner here on a Saturday night at around 7. Mom had already done all the research so we asked for the chicken as soon as we sat down. 

Our table was in a very weird position, hard to explain it, but it looked like it was squeezed into a space that would be left empty on a less busy night. Unfortunately we sat close to a threesome that was persistently annoying -- shrieking voices, stupid political discussions, the works. Mom was visibly distressed but I could handle it just fine until one of the elder diners stretched out her tired foot in my general vicinity. Death stares ensued.

While we waited for the chicken I had a few oysters. They were good -- I'd never pretend to have a great palate for oysters, but I think I prefer the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Station.

Chicken came out and was delicious, but didn't transcend it's chicken-ness. Definitely worth ordering, but it certainly won't change the way you think about chicken. The spongy bread was really good.

Dessert could have blown me away but Mom insisted on the raspberry ice cream profiteroles. Since it was our last meal in SF before she flew back home, I relented despite having an eye for some of the other dishes. 

My mind was already poisoned against the profiteroles, but I'm pretty sure they weren't so great.

An expensive restaurant, but backs it up with some very good food.
author: Nick B.

description: We had a very long wait and the pork was clearly overdone. I heard good things about this place but I will not be returning here. Disappointed.
author: Arthur H.

description: ROAST CHICKEN AND BREAD SALAD BLEW MY MIND!! Zuni was one of the best meals I've had all year! I came across Zuni from the 7x7 list. I've been disappointed with my fair share of restaurants on the list, so I was not sure what to expect at Zuni. From beginning to end, this meal exceeded my expectations. Service was impeccable - attentive and prompt even when we were just sitting at one of the bar tables. The gnocchi appetizer was like eating pillows of cheese and awesomeness. Chicken was to die for!! Desert of Meringue wafers, creme fraiche, and huckleberry sauce was refreshing and light.  There are not enough stars to give to Zuni!
author: Sara A.

description: Went here toe celebrate a major life event for a friend. When you walk in, you realize this place has a great atmosphere.  The Caesar salad with its fresh Romaine lettuce and house dressing was delicious.  The chicken for two is everything that everyone says it is.  I actually think I like the stuffing from it more than the chicken itself.  Great experience.
author: AJ K.

description:
Had a perfect brunch here today.  The menu changes daily, and while the food is consistently good, it was notably so today.  

Our server, Logan, was perky and attentive, and gave us good recommendations.  Note to people eating here- the servers try the food daily and have a lot of knowledge, and are happy to share it if you ask questions.  It was great watching our server as she excitedly guided the table next to us through his first attempt at eating a raw oyster (he loved it).  We asked the oyster shucker to select a couple of his favorites for us, since the oyster list is extensive, and the selection varies daily.  Delicious.  Next- fresh grapefruit in wild honey, and the french toast with fresh strawberries.  This was very exciting because Zuni only serves brunch on Sundays, and the french toast is only an occasional item at that, so my husband had never tried it before.  He quickly declared it the best french toast in the city (maybe tying with Olea).  Next course we split the red lentil soup, so yummy, and lamb's tounge and white beans.  The lamb's tounge was so delicate in texture and flavor... truly delightful.  Julien, the charming wine manager, helped me with wine pairing.  We finished off with oxtails and a poached egg- intensely flavorful and delicious.  If I had room I would have gone for that caramel pot de creme.   Great food, great service.  Overall everything was lovely.
author: Dina A.

description: The last time I went to Zuni, my husband and I decided to finally try the roasted chicken and we were not disappointed.  It definitely lives up to the hype.  Since it takes an hour, we grazed on the polenta, olives, and piccolo fritto while we waited.  Great atmosphere, great service.
author: Addie B.

description: Zuni has been around a long time, and it's one of those rare restaurants that have stood the test of time. It's a quintessential San Francisco spot. Great place to go before the Symphony--if you get there at 6, they will make sure you have a relaxing meal and get to Davies with time to spare. If you're visiting SF, this is one of the places you must have dinner at. If you live in the Bay Area, this is one of the places you should make regular visits to. Staff is super friendly; the ambiance is light and airy without being noisy; the food is totally delicious, and you get enough of it to know you've eaten; great wine list; the service is fast and efficient without being in your face or pushy. The creme brulee is the best I've ever had.
author: Michael C.

description: I know it's been said (almost) 1000 times before, but ZOMG. Zuni chicken . The best piece of meat I've ever had in mouth (that's what she said). Totally worth the price and the wait.
author: Faith A.

description: The chicken was good. It came on a bed of vinaigrette tossed bread and greens which was also good. It is plenty for two. We also ordered the Caesar salad which came in whole pieces of romaine and crispy croutons. The coffee was good, but my cup sat empty for a while and I had to ask for a refill a couple times.
author: Serious F.

description:
must try their chicken for 2, it takes one hour to cook but it is worth it.  it's moist, tasty, crispy skin and worth the wait.  if you never had it, must try it once because you are not going to get that at home or too many restaurants nowadays.  

we sat right in front of the chef that was preparing the chicken.  it was torture watching him for one hour preparing other's chicken and ours from raw to my belly.  

there are many great food in SF, but this one is a must on your list.
author: Samuel C.

description: Stuffed... Went here the other night and ordered the chicken. The hour it took to come out went by really quickly and it was definitely worth the wait. My friend isn't big on bread but she liked the bread salad that came with. The staff was really friendly and attentive. We made reservations via open table and were seated right away even though the place was packed. Will definitely be going there again.
author: Jenny X.

description:
As a food snob from LA, I will never spend time in SF w/o having a meal here.  

Never come here alone. Do the chicken and do the oysters! The gnocci was ok (However, the best like no other on earth is at Angelii Caffe on Melrose in El Lay).

I'm not sure what kind of drugs the SF board of supervisors are on with this socialized medicine thing going on in the SF - there was a 4% surcharge on our bill to faciliate medical insurance for employees. wha?
author: Michael M.

description: The chicken is indeed quite tasty.  I do think the prices are a little high for the quality of preparation.  Ingredients are excellent and my sense is that the prices are a result of using said ingredients.  The only negative at Zuni is the price points on food and wine.  Outside of that, the food and service live up to the hype.
author: John N.

description:
Always look forward to my Zuni fix, especially when I've been away from 
SF for a while. Great place to meet friends, have cocktails or some champagne with FRESH Oysters!!! As always, the service can be a little indifferent, but I don't go there to make friends, I come with my friends. Judy's food is always well thought out and direct.
author: BARI P.

description:
I prefer to write a review of a restaurant after I have eaten there recently, but I just can't stop myself from telling this story.
http://static2.px.yelp.com/photo/hj3Wp7b9_ZkZtBH81iLnSA/l

When I think of the thousands of bottles of wine that I have had the privilege to drink. None have been better than the 1982 Chateau Lafite Rothschild paired with the absolute best Roasted Chicken I ever had at Zuni Cafe in San Francisco!

It was July of 2001 and my brother had made the decision to move back to Los Angeles. For anybody in the wine industry, leaving San Francisco to come to LA would be career suicide, but our Mother was dieing of Lou Gehrig's Disease and my brother wanted to spend the remaining months of her life by her side. In 2001, I was still a novice when it came to understanding "WINE" completely. I had made several trips to San Francisco and the wine country before. Plus, I had already began to collect wines for several years under my brother's guidance of buying the best. This trip would turn out to be the last I ever make to San Francisco with my brother. There have been so many great wine memories in this city with my brother like my birthday dinner party where I insisted on eating Seafood Risotto even though I was drinking 1997 Bryant Family Cabernet. Would I love to get that memory back today and eat the right meal with that wine. An absolute YES! Unfortunately, there is no Bryant Family wine left in our collection.

So we come to that warm summer day in 2001. Where my brother Michael this time would insist that I must have Roasted Chicken from Zuni Cafe. The problem was he also wanted to open 1982 Chateau Lafite. By 2001 I had learned what to do and not to do when it comes to opening a nice bottle of wine, but this was Michael's farewell meal and he insisted that we go to his favorite restaurant in San Francisco of all time.

Zuni Cafe is located at 1658 Market St (between 12th St & Page St) which was walking distance from my brothers loft. When we arrived we quickly ordered the Roasted Chicken being that the dish requires 1 hour of cooking time. The dish is cooked in a brick oven and comes with a warm bread salad with red mustard greens, scallions, currants and pine nuts.

We actually started the meal with a cocktail while the wine opened up. Both our thoughts at the time were of sadness for our mother's health and for my brother leaving San Francisco which I still believe is a much better food city then Los Angeles ever will be.

As for the famous Zuni Roasted Chicken. It was the most succulent bird I ever had. The brick oven gave the chicken a beautiful smoky flavor that worked very well with the wine. The skin was a Utopia of crunchy perfection. The salad is a warm mix of crispy, tender and chewy chunks of bread. It had little slivers of garlic and scallions. Just the right amounts of currants and pine nuts with a handful of greens all moistened with vinaigrette and chicken drippings.

Today my mouth still waters when I think of that dish. It was one of the most memorable food moments I ever had in my life in a city I find so dear to my heart when it comes to both food and wine.

AS FOR THE WINE:

There are just a few words to describe 1982 Chateau Lafite Rothschild. Perfection would be one of them. But I still remember telling my brother as that first sip of wine hit my lips was how much better this wine was than anything I had ever tried before. The wine showed finesse and elegance that I had never seen before in red wine. Plums, Cedar, Liquid Smoke, and Earth are what a remember. Who cares that I had it with Chicken. Yes! it could of benefited from a rack of lamb, but now that I think of it, I would of drank this wine with dessert if I could. It is just that good.

PERFECTION! It has never been duplicated again!

As seen in this photo:
http://static2.px.yelp.com/photo/2GOa7paOTkyq4xsGQaMDqg/l

I own Judy Rodger's Zuni Cafe Cookbook. In the book, is the famous recipe. Temptation has always driven me to try and duplicate that dish.

Why mess with one of my most memorable "Wine Moments" of all time.

Cheers!
author: John R.

description:
5 Stars on the service - waiter was helpful attentive and the water/wine glasses always filled. Bread was replenished once without us asking. Waiter also seemed to be aware of the wine and food to the degree you expect from a well established place.

2 Stars on the appetizers.... Mussels in a light cream sauce with onions and peas? First off, the waiter said 6 mussels - only 5 came out. He said they were big, they were small. Peas undercooked (good for a salad but not in a cooked dish!) and they didn't taste different than frozen ones (I'm assuming they used fresh?). The sauce weak and watery. And why were the peas there in the first place - they didn't really belong? The dish needed some spice or acidity or something to make it sing. And I want my missing mussel back. The fried stuff.... arugula and onions with a honey sauce smeared on the plate. Was interesting, but needed more sauce to dip rather than blot the plate. Perfectly salted though - and appreciated the bitter greens with the sweet honey.

2 Stars on the CHICKEN with BREAD SALAD. (actually 5 stars on the bread part - more on that later). The chicken tasted brined - the breasts too salty and not as succulent as you'd expect with a brined bird. The thighs delicious(can't screw up dark meat that much), the legs tasty but a bit dry. Most parts of the skin were a bit soggy and fatty (i.e. the chicken sat a bit too long after cooking and didn't have time to render all the fat out is my guess). Although the skin parts that were edible were delicious (thank the oven for that). The bird was a bit on the small side for the price - two of us easily at the WHOLE thing. And why was it not really that hot? If it came out of their oven and was quickly cut and plated - it should have been a bit more warm. Not sure if I buy the whole custom cooked chicken thing. Seems like they must just keep putting them in the oven every few minutes and space the service accordingly.

The bread salad/crouton part was exceptionally good. The combination of chicken grease, vinegar and the size and taste of the bread was just about perfect. The pine nuts and other things really not needed and frankly were hard to get off the plate. I'd pay $20 just for a plate of this stuffing alone. 

So... if you're on a budget - buy a grocery store chicken. A good one will be brined and still succulent and have a nice skin on that you can re-crisp in the oven. But if you do want to taste some great stuffing then splurge. 

As for the oysters - as some others noted - the prices are a tad high - especially for the size (walk past the oysters downstairs and see for yourself). Seems like they're priced high for the great variety they keep in stock. I'd suggest - keep a few good types and charge less. The shrimp I saw on another diner's plate didn't seem all that. In fact their whole seafood platter fell a bit flat. 

Wine selections were fine (and the glasses were always refilled diligently).

In summary - great service - hit or miss food items.
author: Dave P.

description:
My VSP and I had dinner at Zuni Cafe last night.  We ordered the roast chicken for two--my reason for wanting to dine here.  It lived up to our respective expectations, as witnessed by our respective eyes rolling back into our heads and twitching in waves of roast-chickengasms.   The bread salad is the perfect accompaniment for this wonder of a bird.  We paired it with the Caesar Salad and risotto with persimmions on the front end (the risotto is surely what they serve in heaven to those who have been very, very good) and caramel pot de creme on the back end (so to speak).  We ordered a Sonoma County pinot noir that was superb, and a split of a sparkling moscato with dessert.  Service was just right--professional without being overly intrusive.

VSP and I agree that this is one of the best meals we've had in a long, long time--maybe ever.
author: Earline A.

description: Over the years I've heard many good things about Zuni, but my first time there will likely be my last. I went there after work for an early happy hour celebration for a coworker who recently wed. They sat us in the window area on Rose and Market Streets and apparently it was a nice experience when the first 4 guests arrived. Then when the full party arrived, there were 8 (!) of us, and the hostess was rude numerous times. She let us know they needed to keep an "aisle" clear so the person in the very corner could be accessed. This person was part of our party so if plate or drink passing occurred, no big deal. She made a point to come by several times if a person crossed the imaginary line into verboten territory and repeated her ever-growing condescending order to keep the path clear. Our waiter was quite chilly at first, too, but eventually warmed to room temperature. Still, we thought we ordered two plates of shoestring fries at his suggestion, but then only one appeared, which was fine in the end as they were too salty. And the only condiment it was served with was ketchup which is surprising because this is supposed to be fine dining and even pubs serve an aioli or mustardy condiment with fries. But my review is more about the attitude than the food. When my friends went out to smoke, they sat on the bench provided by Zuni on Rose St. The rude hostess banged loudly on the window and pointed at the sign agitatedly that stated a certain distance from the door needed to be maintained when smoking. The rude hostess realized her error by the horrified looks on my friends' faces and walked outside to explain, but it was too late, the damage had been done. I've had better service at a McDonald's. And in a city like SF with new restaurants cropping up every day, there are plenty of other places to get overpriced oysters and chicken with far better treatment.
author: K H.

description:
If you are going to treat yourself to one restaurant in San Fran, go to Zuni. The food is first rate. I think the chicken is far and away the best thing on the menu, and easily the best chicken I have ever eaten. Their salads are very fresh and good. 
The space is reason itself to go. Zuni is housed in this cool corner brick building, and the triangular shape makes it so that almost the whole restaurant is made up of windows. It is very light inside. The restaurant is set up very creatively; I have eaten at a different little nook each time I've been, and each offered a different, interesting view of the surrounding area. The architecture is unique, with interesting stairways and flooring. First rate service. 
And a must: good desserts.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
On  my mission to eat at all of the Top 100 in the Bay Area, I finally made it to Zuni. For rustic charm and sheer deliciousness, it can't be beat. In fact, I think it changed my life a little and I'm pretty sure I saw god.

Get the rotisserie chicken and the espresso granita, just like Monsieur Bauer tells you to.  I'd skip the Cesar salad. It was a little too authentic for me and thus tasted like anchovies (not a fan). I also wasn't wowed by the polenta, as it was a bit boring.

But still everything else, particularly the chicken for two, is better than almost anything you've had.

And don't skimp on the wine.  It's loud and fun and a special night.
author: Alison P.

description:
Oldie but a goodie!

It has been some time since I ate here, in fact about seven years to be exact and the service and quality has not changed.

Order the Zuni Caesar and chicken for two and you have a good dinner.  Throw in some oysters, champagne and an awesome date and you have a great night!

Service overall was friendly with fun personalities, except for the hostess who was void of personalty.
author: J S.

description:
4.15.2007
12:00PM

Third times the charm!  I came here relatively early on this alcoholic's day with my girlfriend, having been turned down on two other afternoons; making me cringe when I hear, "Did you make a reservation?".  

I know; the reso is key for busier restaurants in The City but I'm never in a mood to plan for anything on Sunday.  I have never experienced this much traffic for a brunch spot!  Anyways, on this Sunday, same ol' routine:  roll out of bed, walk over to Zuni, yada yada yada.

As I was walking out of the door after being turned down thinking , "...you idiot...why didn't;t you make a damn reso..." a sharply dressed man in his late 20's/early 30's approached me and called us back into the restaraunt.  

"I just remembered a reservation didn't show and we have a table in the main dining room if you would like..."

Thank you sir.

Open, airy, clean interior with exposed brick walls combined with cool stainless steel and Glass's....lots and lots of glass.  If you're seated in the main dining, room, you'll walk past a display of fresh oysters on ice...a must.

Had a fungus salad with poached eggs....awesome.

Spaghetti with clams in a garlic white wine sauce...ok...very oily.

Burger with Gorgonzola queso....awesome....

Shoe string papas....ok....arrived slightly warm.

The waiter informed me that their whole roasted chicken is their 'signature' dish....I'll be back for that.
author: William R.

description:
It's 3.5 stars, really, but I'm in a "benefit of the doubt" kind of mood. This would have been a five-star dining experience if not for the incompetence of our waitress. 

But let's focus on the good:
+balsamic bloody marys (note: the paper straws are whimsical and cute, but useless for sucking up choppped onion)
+creamy polenta
+extensive selection of oysters (although the waitress brought one's that were different from what we ordered without explanation)
+delicious clams
+bright and garlicky caesar (which certainly should have arrived before the entrees)
+unbelievable strawberry ice cream
+intimate upstairs table overlooking the main dining room
-inept waitress
author: Jessica H.

description:
OMG!  We saw Ming Tsai (http://www.ming.com/) eating here!!!!  Just two tables down!  Rad!

My boyfriends rabbit was great, my gnocchi was a little too buttery and almost identical in flavor (sauce aside) as the fabulous (and with a more refreshing sauce) gnocchi I had at Rivoli (http://www.yelp.com/biz/c6zwGcEhlenDxGcDRfXRtA) in February.

Classy joint, but honestly I was expecting a little more oomph.  But seeing Ming adds at least a star!
author: Sarah L.

description:
They may have free range organic chicken, ground to order burger patty, or shoestring potato frites. 
Choosing better ingeridents and different preparation is one thing.  
And.. probably the only thing at Zuni?
author: Angie Y.

description:
I wanna like this place, it's hip and has a great atmosphere but I found the food quite mediocre. 

I went for a business lunch. It was busy as it always is. Our food took an hour to come, an hour! I don't know what the deal was, we ordered pizza, a hamburger and soup, salad and fries.

The fries were good, they taste a lot like In-n-Out fries but a thinner, shoestring version.

I ordered the pizza with ricotta cheese. I was not impressed. The crust was soggy, each slice sagged as I held it in my hand. Is this how pizza is supposed to be? The taste was very bland. I wouldn't recommend it.

My co-worker seemed to like her caesar salad and soup. The salad looked delicious, the croutons looked homemade and delicious.

I don't know that I'd come back to this place.
author: Chili B.

description:
I wanted to love this place. I waited to take my boyfriend here for his birthyday because he had been itching to go to Zuni. 

I thought the food was okay, his pork chop was yummy, but my bass was so-so, not to mention that a hour after lunch we literally had to run home so my lunch could be deposited quickly into the toliet. Yes, I got sick quite quickly but that is how it happens with me. If I get something bad in my system within a hour I find my guts in terrible pain and I have to run to the bathroom...so much for a nice brithday for my boyfriend!
author: Denise L.

description:
One has to thank friends for making you come back to a restaurant that you have not been to in over 5 years.  So so so yummy.  Well I did say I would drive to S.F. if we went somewhere yummy and I got what I wanted!
I was literally one of the first patrons that day.  Though it was a beautiful day in S.F. and I could have waited outside the host put me at a very nice table.  I then perused the menu and then remembered the chicken for 2 that takes one hour to make.  Sooo, since I was there so early I decided to order it!  We also had the delicious Caesar salad and shoestring potatoes and had a wonderful lunch over some nice "catch-up".  I will be back soon Zuni Caf!
author: Frances F.

description:
In anticipation of Administrative Assistant's Day (4/23) fka Secretary's Day, my boss took me here for lunch as a sort of thank you for working for him. I know...so sweet. He chose to come here because he said it was young and sort of fun, like me, I guess.....

There is a beautiful bar right when you walk inside with large windows all around (major bonus). Apparently, there are all kinds of different rooms for seating, but we were escorted straight upstairs where I felt like I was in a tree house. Not the kind you build in your parent's backyard, more like if you were hangin out with Swiss Family Robinson sort of treehouse. 

Food was good, but not great. I will say the mushroom soup was excellent. The pizza's, although quite good, not much more than average even with the chev, fennel, nettles, etc. If you're into big bleeding burgers they might have just that for you. As for me, I have to pass. As for dessert the rubarb tart was beautiful, and not just to look at, but to taste as well. 

I wouldn't go out of my way to come here for dinner, but I do want to go back and take a seat at the bar....and maybe try that roasted chicken that seems to be so popular. Maybe.......
author: Vanessa P.

description:
Zuni's reputation preceded my visit, so my expectations were rather high.  I had the good fortune of enjoying my dinner with visiting family that could expense their business trip to his investment brokerage, so a lovely rare treat for my mom and me.

I was extremely lucky to find a parking space on Gough just as I was about give in to the $10 valet.  We came 15 minutes ahead of our reservation for 4 on, oh, I think it was Thursday evening, and were seated nearly immediately at a Market Street facing window table on the ground floor.

My appetizer, oh golly, I can't remember my appetizer.  I know it was absolutely fabulous, and it wasn't a salad or soup, but I can't for the life of me remember the awesome appetizer that was.  I did manage to peck at my fellow diners' appetizers, and also recall that they were super delish.

On to the main course then, and...oh...what was it?  There was a spicy sausage something and mashed potatoes and I think some other meat...Oh, I am the worst restaurant critic in the world.  It was just all so good!  It wasn't their famed chicken, I know that.

Dessert was a chocolate creme freche.  Excellent.  I was apparently on a chocolate kick at that time, so I had a hot cocoa to go along with it.  Also excellent.  I was also pleasantly pleased that the portions of the previous meal left me very satisfactorily full, but not so full as to make dessert an abhorrent possibility.

Our server was so full of personality that I was amazed it was only her second day at the restaurant.  She only went to her cheat sheet once after a very specific question from us, and it was handled with such grace and elegance.  She's originally from Utah, and she deserves a great tip, again from the investment firm paying for the whole thing.  She totally was keyed to my jokes about my mom and her friend taking forever to decide, and she was right there just when I was thinking it was time to order up another fruity Pellegrino drink.

Our experience there was absolutely superb, and even as I worried about my always lingering family, the staff offered little indication that it was time for us to go.  Definitely exceeds expectations.

I would take a boyfriend here for an anniversary date.
author: Jeremy K.

description:
We were disappointed on our most recent visit (Lovefest day, although we didn't go.)  It turns out that they stop serving the burger in late afternoon until 10PM.  This means you can pay $48 for a chicken (!!!!) or put together some of the snacks for an overpriced meal.  This isn't to knock the food - the halibut cheeks were particularly outstanding - but in today's economy, there need to be options.  And this was clear from looking around - 8PM on a Saturday night and we had no trouble getting a table for four without a reservation.

This economy means restaurants need to wake up.  I know it's not easy being in the restaurant business, but with the real estate signs go up in buildings all over the city, restaurants need to renew their leases and put some pressure on their suppliers.  

The service was a bit slower than we expected also...
author: Spike S.

description:
GET THE ROAST CHICKEN! 

If you're like me, you NEVER order chicken when you go out, but trust me, you have to have it here!

My friend started with a half dozen oysters and she said they were awesome. We split a Caeser and it was delicious. A bit heavy on the anchovies and parm, but still good.

We ordered a $50+ bottle of Pinot Noir, but it was really young and lacked flavor.

We couldn't wait for the chicken though! It didn't disappoint. It was accompanied by rough torn pieces of bread and greens. 

We were so full, we had leftovers for the next night. DELISH!
author: Eva C.

description: I've known about Zuni for years but never tried it.  I had a friend in town who had heard about it so figured now was as good a time as any. The atmosphere and service was fine, but the food was poor.  I had a salad and soup - neither of which was inexpensive.  The soup was ok but under-seasoned. The salad was an abomination. It was ONLY lettuce with a couple of greasy croutons.  Worst yet, there were bits of rotten lettuce in my only lettuce salad.  I had this terrible salad, soup and some green tea and it cost my $30.  I will not be going back.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Absolutely on of the best burgers in SF. A shame they don't serve it on the dinner menu.
author: m t.

description: One of the best places in the city to sit at the bar looking over Market Street thru the bottles of booze. Classic establishment and classy feel. Great fresh Lime Margaritas and one of the best caesar salads in the city, with tiny pieces of anchovies mixed on every lettuce leaf. We also tried the pizza with feta,red onions and eggplant which was good, but I found the burger not be as good as everyone says, I've had much better in the city and a bit pricey for $16.50 with cheese. I will be back for some drinks at the bar...
author: Chris D.

description:
I'm a tough critic... Would have given 3.5 if possible.  

Here's what we had:
Cesar salad:  One of the best I've had. Great anchovy flavor. Very tasty croutons. Crisp lettuce. Highlight of the night.
Quail:  There was a rabbit dish but they ran out of rabbit, so quail was the replacement.  It was a bit too gamey and very small. 
Flat iron steak:  A bit tough but good flavor, with hints of balsamic vinegar and rosemary.  Again, very small portion, but that seems to be the theme here.

Next time (if there is a next time), I suppose I need to try the roast chicken and shoestring potatoes.  

Overall, a pretty good experience and service was fine, but a bit pricey for what you get.
author: Richard K.

description:
We have eaten at Zuni's many times, and enjoyed the friendly atmosphere and the absolutely delicious food. This time, however, the service left a great deal to be desired. We had a 6 PM reservation (as we were going to the symphony).   We arrived around 5:45 and had a glass of wine in the cafe -- at 6 I noticed they were seating restaurant patrons who arrived after we did. I asked the waitress (who brought dinner menus to our cafe table) and she checked with the hostess. She came back and said our reservation was not until 6:45.  When I objected, she said she would check again -- I saw her check, but she didn't come back to tell us anything. Finally, I went up to the hostess, and she acted like she was doing us a big favor to seat us (it was now 6:15). 
The dinner was very good -- and one entree, the duck, was spectacular  -- although I was still bothered by our seating experience. The waiter was very sullen. He didn't even smile when he brought my husband's birthday dessert with a lit candle.  Only the assistant waiter (don't want to call him a busboy, because he was an older man) who brought us bread, refilled our water, and brought an extra cup of coffee --  treated us politely and hospitably.
This was such a disappointing experience on what should have been a very special occasion.
author: Elaine E.

description: The food was okay, the service was okay, the place was freezing cold and very loud, paper table covers -- come on!  Maybe the chicken dinner but an hour wait -- I don't think so! I won't go back.
author: Jane K.

description: After all these years, Zuni's still got it.  I've been in for dinner twice recently, and cleaned my plate both times.  ;-)
author: Kelli G.

description: The food was reasonable, but perhaps I've come to expect the unexpected.  What I mean is this place is wonderful for the traditional diner.  The interior is beautiful - imagine table cloths rather than the bench seating with organic wood communal table.  (I like the communal table.)   But back to food...had the lunch soup...a bit salty.  The salad was pleasant.  I'd say this was a pleasant experience.
author: Becky G.

description: Just get the chicken, you know you want to! It's that good and the bread stuffing/mustard greens were a good side to go with it.  I was certain that the chicken was brined but was informed by our server Dennis that it was only salted! Other things to note were the cocktails, they were great.  The last word was perfect the second time around.  As fir dessert, salted caramel/balsamic ice cream with almond cookies were so good
author: Jim K.

description: our favorite place to go in SF...always get the chicken for 2....takes an hour but well worth it....great cocktails....highly recommend the Aperol cocktail....usually eat at one of the tables at the bar since it shirt come first serve....and if we are there by 5p, we usually get a table....a little early, yes, but give you time to see a show or cruise to another bar, etc...
author: Rikki Y.

description:
Just like everyone else, Love the chicken!

Have been to Zuni many times, since you really need a reservation, it is a perfect place to plan to bring friends and family from out of town. If you've never been, get the chicken, it's their specialty. If you go back, try the other dishes, the food is good.
author: Joshua G.

description: It's all about the chicken!!!!! Great service! Great food and good wine list!!!! Don't stop doing what your doing!!!!
author: WildBill C.

description: Such a classic San Francisco spot. My friend cooks here so I am little bias. We got terrific service, delicious food and great wine!!! I Highly recommend this place. You might need a reservation on the weekends. Also they have a killer bloody mary brunch on Sundays.
author: Ethan S.

description: I hate to do this...but here goes. Let me preface by saying I have been to the Zuni on many occasions, many of them super special, and have always loved and defended this restaurant to nay-sayers. However, I'm ready to move on. The chicken for two, that in the past I have craved, was overcooked and had no zing. The wait staff walked around like they were on quaaludes. Or server, while friendly enough when coaxed, did not even acknowledge the fact that we were celebrating our 27th anniversary at his restaurant! I don't need a ticker tape parade, but maybe you could have comped us the dessert?? Sad to say, I won't be back.....
author: julie c.

description: After walking by this place every day, twice a day, back and forth from home to to Muni (except Monday -- Zuni is not open on Mondays), I finally went in with a friend for dinner.  We have 7:30 reservation and didn't get seated until almost 8:30.  We felt very neglected by our server who rushed us through everything and didn't smile once the whole evening.  The food, I thought, was only just a bit better than average although the shoestring fries are to die for.  Acoustics in this place are awful -- brick and glass walls with no sound dampeners can make for a difficult listening environment.  Also kinda pricey for food that is only just a bet better than average.  It's a popular place and seems to be busy all the time, so it may just be me.
author: Paul N.

description:
Zuni Cafe encompasses a triangular venue.  Enter at the apex and join a clot of people waiting to be seated.  It's inevitable given the shape of the place.  I am taken to the second level, seated, and ignored for a bit.  Eventually, a waiter relents.  My inquiries do not lead to pro-offered information, so I wing it.  

Caesar salad is a mound of fresh romaine, grated cheese, fresh croutons, and a dressing that has some anchovy within it.  Nice.

RIcotta gnocchi are light as air, and accompanied by some ground walnuts, fresh spinach, and a light butter-based sauce.  They've given their secret away.  Use good, fresh, local ingredients, and treat them well.  

My main course is two slices of lamb accompanied by roasted peppers, polenta, and spinach.  The lamb is OK but hasn't any really distinctive taste.  The peppers and polenta are nice, the spinach much to salty.  

Zuni is nice but not really anything particularly special.  Just nice.
author: David D.

description: Excellent food and atmosphere, the pizza was crisp and the drinks were very good. The rabbit salad was worth going back.  Would have been 5 star but the server could not break a $100 for an $81 bill.
author: Drew H.

description:
I walked by Zuni for years... it is always packed and everyone always looks like they are having a good time and eating well.  Each time I would think to myself that I really need to try this place.  I was so excited when my friend Sean asked to go to Zuni for his birthday.

The restaurant has a nice atmosphere and I like that there are multiple dining rooms  and an open kitchen.  There are a plethora of menu choices, which all sound so delicious.

We started with an assortment of oysters, which were absolutely fresh and delicious.  The friendly waitress helped us choose a nice variety and we really enjoyed them all.

I wish I could say the same about our main courses.  I choose the beef filet and my friend a chicken dish.  Both entrees had a lot of potential, but the serving sizes were astoundingly small.  Anyone that knows me will tell you I'm a very light eater, so to hear me complain about portion size is a first.  The worst part is the food was totally cold.  Lukewarm at best.

I didn't hear specifics, but apparently our neighbors at the next table were not happy either.  We didn't complain because it sounded like the next table had it covered for all of us and I didn't want the server and host to feel even worse... but then I wish I would have, because the waitress totally took off and we didn't see her again, or anyone else for what seemed like forever... long after we had both finished our entrees.

Fortunately, we both finally ordered creme brulee for dessert, which was perfect and saved the evening.

I'll give Zuni a second try if I have a chance, but I'm certainly not going to go out of my way to go back.
author: Gregory J.

description: Had the opportunity to dine here Saturday night. What a wonderful little find.... got a perfect seat upstairs overlooking Market Street... our charming server, Kristen, was attentive and helpful in explaining all the dining choices.... we started with a half dozen of oysters that were perfectly salty and delicious.... dinner choices were the beef filet for me and port chop and polent side for the hubby... all was perfectly cooked and seasonsed!!!  Desserts were the panna cotta and the flourless chocolate cake... need I say more.
author: Michelle I.

description:
Yes, okay, the food is good but the service is strictly amateur hour.  I've been a few times and it's always the same thing:  with or without a reservation, the hostess greets you like she really wasn't expecting anyone to show up, especially YOU. There must be some MISTAKE.  I've never encountered this treatment in a restaurant before so the first couple of times I found it strangely amusing.  But the last time we went was definitely the last time.  We got up and left when our 'server' was so engrossed in doing some paper work she couldn't take our order.  She looked like someone trying to finish their tax return at the 11th hour.  No joy here.

UPDATE:  Reluctantly went back with a friend who was visiting from out of town and just 'had' to go to Zuni.  It was as if Zuni had read my review and wanted to make it up to me.  Fantastic service, amazing food, great drinks, a lot of fun.  I'm so glad I went back and have been a couple more times (with and w/o reservations) - all very positive, delicious, fun experiences.
author: Carolyn S.

description:
It's good.  REALLY good.  BUT --- not great. NOT so great that I'd pick it out of a bunch of places to grub when foodies come to town.  NOT a place that I'd go out of the way to wrangle a reservation or two -- just for show.  YES, I know that former folks who ran and cooked at Chez Panisse are the big guns at this establishment --- but there's an awkward coldness --- that I'm NOT a fan of when dining. 

Don't know if it's the ambiance --- the space is oddly unappealing to me.  It's got a feeling of being OFF.  I'm not a feng shui freak --- but I do know that I'm not super comfortable whenever I'm there at Zuni.
author: BrasilPo P.

description:
Nice happening spot right on Market, but that means it is busy on a good night, you should try to make a reservation or be prepared to wait.
 Started off with the oyster sampler, that was a great way to see which ones we wanted, and oh yes we got more. It being a busy night the service was a bit slow, but the bread was crusty and delicious and made the wait a bit less agonizing.
author: Sean W.

description:
I've had my ups and downs with Zuni, and now its on the upswing.

Zuni used to be my favorite restaurant on the planet.. about four years ago, I met my hero Judy Rogers at an oyster charity cooking class up the coast with just 25 people or so attending. Long story short - she was not so great -. rude, arrogant and condescending. I was in SHOCK, horrified and I'll spare you the rest of the details.

So that could have affected my perspective over the last few years of Zuni, as the food and service proceeded to go downhill on my visits soon after that. Was is a self-fufilling prophecy? anyway, back to the review.

I gave up my boycott this past year and have been back 3-4 times and its on the upswing. Nothing beats their sourdough but not really that sour bread dunked in the cold aftermath of salty oysters. great salads, nice wines, and better service. 

Not enough to be 4 or 5 stars, but a solid above average.
author: Sylvie L.

description:
the chicken with bread is a classic.  the service was good.  The space is original, and tight w/o being too crowded.  

I had a special, some kind of morrocan dish that was bland and over cooked.
author: Chad K.

description:
Everytime I go to Zuni's, I'm still amazed by the food. For lunch or dinner, you can't miss out. The Oysters are simply fresh and amazing. The legendary chicken lives up to its hype. I'm not a fan of the shoe string fries though, but it is well done. The deserts are great! A good choice for either romantic or large groups. 

Just be sure to get reservations early and if you are going for a romantic date or during the dinner rush hours! 

Request a nice cozy corner table as the tables are a bit jammed packed and can be noisy if in the wrong location.
author: steve h.

description:
I had lunch at Zuni and it was OK.  Not sure what all the hype is?????  Maybe I will go again and try the chicken and the caesar salad I hear so much about.

The service was very nice.  The food was just OK.  I didn't hate it and I didn't love it.  As far as price, too expensive for what I got which was a fish dish.
author: Christina C.

description:
How many places can remain significant after so many years?  They were great with reservations, provided excellent service (Scrivner), and the food was as advertised.

I went there with a group of friends and we started with the pasta and shoestring fries (and 2 bottles of wine). . . and an hour later we finished with the chicken for two - well actually four.  Best damn chicken I have ever had. . . I would quit my day job for that chicken.

Update:  I still come here once a month.  I adore Zuni's.  The staff is always friendly and courses are fantastic.
author: E L.

description:
Happened into Zuni Cafe on a rainy Sunday w/ my guy .  Without reservations, we waited for about 15 minutes for a table.  Not bad, especially when you can get a head start on your mimosas at the bar while you wait.  The host was a bit snobby tho.  Bummer.

Anywho, we started with the oysters, followed by the burger for me and the pork chop for the mister.  The oysters were on point, as was the burger.  The pork chop, however, was something I could easily have made at home.  I expected more from the Zuni Cafe.

Our server, Sabrina, was frickin' awesome.  If you end up in her section, just give her your wallet when it's time to leave a tip.  She deserves it.
author: Shauna H.

description:
Go to Zuni for atmosphere and fresh dining, but expect to pay a pretty penny without fully understanding why but knowing somewhere deep down you're OK with it.

We had 8pm reservations for a party of four - arrived early - so we waited downstairs and watched the bartender concoct fancy drinks.  She was not off-put by our inquisitive out-of-towners who questioned the onions in the Bloody Mary and the aromatic spritzer in the cocktail.

A waitress escorted us through the labyrinth that is Zuni to a table in the back room.  It wasn't ideal but cozy enough for a little privacy at what was a crowded place.

Our waiter really made the experience - he was witty and charming and tolerable of our not-so-on jokes.  He explained it was very "European" to eat without bread plates - so be sure to request one if you want to be mindful of crumbs.

The menu is ridiculous.  The layout was almost incomprehensible with no organization or order or sense.  My boyfriend and I cringed at first but laughed a good laugh once the waiter arrived to take us through the journey of the menu.

The most notable of our orders included the ceasar salad with its solid stalks and as the waiter said "one of the best in the city;" a beautiful tender gnocchi made from egg as opposed to potato.  Definitely the table favorite; and the rotisserie chicken made for two - it's a one hour wait for a succulent chicken, served on a bed of breading with pine nuts, and thrown together with salad drenched in vinegarette.  This plate is a trademark but it was a little hodge podge-y i.e. salad greens in the breading?

All in all, a generally good experience.  I'd go back but would probably stick to some of the smaller entrée plates and the cocktail menu... that's the one you can read.
author: Amanda C.

description:
I first found Zuni by chance.  My bf and I were driving around the city one late night and decided to find something to eat.  The lights were still on and people still eating so we step inside. This is the first of many, many times I walk through that door.  

I bring every guest, every special occasion, and every oyster craving here. 

I just graduated college so my budget is very tight.  Here is my suggestion on how to eat here without having to panhandle afterward.  

Party of two:
a plate of six Miyagi (or Kumamoto) oysters, raw. 
split the amazing Zuni Cesar salad.
split the yummy chilled carrot and cilantro soup.
bring your own bottle of wine.
and if it's late enough get the burger and fries. 


Also, the chicken is to die for. Just suck it up and wait for it. If you're lucky enough to have great company the time just flies by.
author: Juanita S.

description:
Zuni Cafe is one of those Californian institutions, along with Alice Water's Chez Panisse (the original) and Greens, that has been around in broadly the same form since the 70's and along with showier latecomers such as the French Laundry has put the region on the culinary map. The key to Californian cuisine is quality sourced ingredients cooked simply and well and Zuni has developed a short and stylish Cal-Italian menu based around the brick oven proudly occupying the centre of the room, birthplace of their classic roast chicken. 

A few casual bar tables fit into the tight but light and airy block corner space and the gradual growth into the mezzanine and an adjacent room has given them a more classic dining room with linen cloths to match. It's a wonderfully Californian space. The crowd were well heeled and Cali casual. Hipsters in havianas mixed with dressed down grey hairs. So many things I could have eaten on this menu. The burgers at the next table looked stunning, as did a nearby pizza, and the Tuscan roast chicken will have to be saved for my next visit ($42 for the chicken, but it shares with at least 3 or 4 judging by other reviews, allow an hour or pre-order if you get there before me). 

I opened with Serrano ham served with pimentos de padron, goats cheese and orange zest gremolata. The crunchy zing of the gremolata and the salty spice of the pimentos came in perfectly with the goats cheese. The ham was good, but I've had better, and much closer to home. The main was revelatory. One of the thickest pork chops I've ever had the pleasure of eating. The knowledgable enthusiast serving me gave me the run down of its history. From a farm called Becker Lane, a small Iowa producer apparently, it was an Iowan pork chop as you'd imagine. Like their men, grown on corn, open space and sunshine. Free range to the point of being semi-wild, it had dark open flesh and was meatily juicy to the n'th degree. If I were a pig, I'd want to be this pig (assuming there's no opening for the one in Babe). It came with a semi-raw salad of fresh green beans and thin sliced courgette with the pick me up of purple basil. The two elements were brought together with a Sungold heritage tomato salad in a light dressing, the sweet snap of the tomatoes cutting through the glistening unctuous fat of the heaven sent chop.
author: Rich M.

description:
i had the BEST burger here that i've ever tasted. ever. period.
recently i was looking in their cook book, and it seems that the taste has to do with the quality of meat and preparation (makes sense)..extremely fresh, etc. but dude, this burger was amazing. this thick, perfectly cooked medium rare, juicy, flavorful melt-in-my-mouth orgasm of flavor. no joke.
we also had a simple pasta that was soooooo freakin good. i think it was whole wheat spagheti with pecorino, and mint. urgh, i wanted to lick the plate. 
i saw all the orders or yummy roast chicken on the tables next to me, but we were in a bit of a rush, so didn't get that. i'm sure its amazing as well.
author: Nadia A.

description:
I visit SF a few times a year and was looking forward to dinner at Zuni Cafe.  To start, we ordered quail with white beans and fennel...the quail was perfectly prepared... tender, moist, and full of flavor.  For my entree, I ordered squab with roasted sweet potatoes, cabbage, and horseradish sauce.   In a word:  perfect.  My dining companion ordered the strip steak with mashed potatoes.  The steak was good..not stellar.  It was prepared to order (rare) but lacked the depth of flavor that we were expecting.  For our cheese course, we shared the pecarino with white truffle honey, and finished up by sharing a slice of lemon tart with mascarpone.   True comfort food.

The only disappointment of the night was the average service.  We noticed that at the adjacent table, the waiter explained the time constraints of the roast chicken and asked the group immediately upon seating if he should put in an order before taking their drink order.  We thought this was a great touch since we were aware that the chicken takes close to one hour to prepare and serve.  However, our waiter did not make this offer and we felt she was a bit robotic...just trying to get through the evening.  Maybe she had a migraine...I gave her benefit of the doubt and left a generous tip.  All in all, a great meal.  Can't wait to visit again soon!
author: Diane W.

description:
We were planning to see Wicked on Memorial day weekend, so we wanted to get dinner somewhere walking distance from the Orpheum theatre.  I've always wanted to try this place (and their famous roast chicken) so I got a reservation for our party of 4 (me, my sis, and our hubbies).

They usually open at 6pm, but we lucked out that they open at 5pm on Sundays, which was perfect for our 7:30pm show.  They were all out of reservations at Opentable, but were ok when I called them on the phone.  They also assured me that it would be enough time for us to make it to the show even if we ordered the roast chicken.  Half our party got there a bit before 5, they weren't seating people yet but they were able to get cocktails at the bar (my sis mentioned that it was one of the best bloody marys she's had)...we met them at the bar and we were all seated promptly at 5.  As soon as the server stopped by, we made sure to place our order for the roast chicken right away...the order clocked in at 5:05! :)

For appetizers, we started off with some oysters, then got some assorted sausages and shoestring potatoes.  Everything was great (especially loved one of the little oysters and the shoestring fries) and kept us satisfied while we waited for the roast chicken.  Since we were a party of 4, got two other entrees, the steak and the duck.  Both were pretty good, though I had to admit the roast chicken with bread salad was definitely the star of the show.  I thought it was actually worth the price, since you get the full chicken...my sister and I split it, but we still had enough to give some to the hubbies to try.  I've tried making this at home before (the recipe is everywhere online), but I could not get the skin to be as crisp, and their bread salad was so much better...less soggy and had more of the toasty crunch.  I guess even if you have the exact same recipe at home, it's hard to replicate their brick oven and professional chefs.  

Having just come back from Europe the week before, I was a bit sticker-shocked at the wine list when viewing it online (got too used to most bottles being less than 20 euros...why do they mark up wines so much in the US?).  We decided to bring in our own wines and pay the $20 corkage.  My sis and her hubby brought in a Robert Hunter sparkling wine they got in Sonoma, and my hubby and I brought a Merry Edwards Pinot, also from Sonoma.  The server didn't even bat an eye at us bringing two wines, which was good (some places tend to not like it if you bring your own).  At least we brought really good wines that were not on their list, and cannot be bought at retail...it gave us a chance to sample some of the nicer bottles in our cellars with a professionally cooked meal.  Don't think we could find a $50 retail bottle for $70 or less on their list (probably would be over $100) so I thought it was a great deal to bring in our own.  The bubbly went perfectly with the oysters and other appetizers, and the Pinot, which had the big russian river style, went perfectly with the chicken and duck (and even held up to the steak).

For dessert, we split an order of the blue cheese (came with some honey and walnuts) and the gateau victoire, a flourless chocolate cake with whipped cream.  Both were really good....I loved the blue cheese but I have to admit I have a weakness for flourless chocolate cake...it was very well made and the soft whipped cream went perfectly.  To go with it, I got some madeira, my sis got some tawny port, and the hubbies got some brandy.  

With all this, we managed to get out of the restaurant a little past 7...the servers were very conscious of the fact that we were going to a show, and made sure we made it out on time.  I definitely highly recommend this restaurant for anyone catching a show in the Orpheum, or just in general for the best roast chicken in town.
author: Arlene M.

description: Get the chicken for two. I don't normally order chicken at fancy restaurants but this is pretty damn good! Great spot for a date.
author: Paul M.

description: On the line between three and four stars. A safe bet, nothing truly outstanding or surprising. The pork shoulder was very tender, good balance of flavours. The Chenin Blanc was great. The grapefruit-chartreuse-almond piccolo meringata was genuinely stunning. A nice ambience, and comfortable settings. I'm not knocking it, and I'll probably go again. But this isn't a rave.
author: Alex W.

description: Bright open space, my friends and I had good European food.  Appetizers were excellent, Chicken from oven was good too.
author: Mika I.

description:
Had lunch here.  A wonderfully, airy, bright atmosphere.  The kitchen is very accessible to everyone.  Nice touch.  I'll come here again if I don't have to pay or I'm just gonna have something light.  

The crostini is amazing.  Had the pork chop for my entree.  Juicy and tasty but it was rather incomplete with two. slices of potatoes and a couple leave of lettuce.  For what you get in terms of food, it's a little overpriced.  But it's still a delightful place.
author: V C.

description: We visited for dinner based on a local recommendation to try the Chicken and Oysters.  We were not disappointed.  Both were delicious.  The Chicken is elevated to 'amazing' by the bread salad.  The service was perfect and the atmosphere was relaxed.
author: Kevin B.

description: This place was recommended by a family member and upon strict instructions I was told to order the roast chicken for two.   I was not disappointed.   Chicken took an hour to slowly roast and soak in the flavors of the bread stuffing and sides.   It was well worth the wait.   Absolutely delicious and plenty of food to satisfy three.   The salads and other appetizers we sampled were excellent as well.   I enjoyed the ambiance of Zuni.   Very sleek interior with split levels and a modern feel to it.   Not overly loud.   A good spot to enjoy a quiet evening or take a date.   I want to go back to try out their burger, as people were raving about how good it was.
author: Mike B.

description: We put our name in at 5:15PM last night for a table for 4 and were told it would be 1 hour.  Well, over two hours later, we were seated.  The comped us Caesar salads for waiting which was nice.  It would have been nicer if the Caesar salad had taste, and not been wilted and soggy.  Thank goodness we ordered the anchovies as an appetizer to add flavor to the salad.  However, the anchovy dish was tiny with an unappetizing arrangement of cheese slices, tiny olives and celery?  Then we waited over an hour for the famous chicken which was dry and the bread salad was so saturated in chicken fat I was afraid to eat it.  We had a Catalan noodle dish that was supposed to have lamb sausage.  No one could find the sausage and the serving size was meager.  And, then, came dessert?  We waited for over 1/2 hour for two disappointing desserts.  One was the 3 jewels -  basically 3 dried up dates with some cheese slapped in the middle.  All -in -all a disappointing experience, thank God the company was good.  We were in the place of 4 hours
author: anna e.

description: Bummed by the service.  Dinner for four.  17.50 for a basic margarita? Yikes.  Received wrong salad - completely different from the one I ordered.  We offered to keep it and also receive the appropriate salad.  While it sort of makes sense that we were charged for their mistake - we did eat it - kind of lame that it was on the bill since it wasn't our mistake.  Ordered a second drink.  Never came.  Nobody was checking on us.  Finally when we asked the waiter, he said "Oh, I never confirmed that".  Like, was that OUR fault?  Right.  They auctioned off the entrees all to the wrong people (table-number dyslexia?).  My friend's Caesar salad was hanging off the plate.  Obviously servers had to touch the food to handle the plate.  No tender, romaine leaves; all dark-green outside leaves, too big for the plate,  touching the table, etc.  It was unappealing and unruly.  She ate about 5% of it.  Nobody asked why when they cleared her nearly-full plate and charged full price for it.  She also ordered 1/4 crab.  Silly presentation: 3 legs plopped on a white plate with a ramekin of aioli.  About 20 minutes in, she was able to flag someone for a wedge of lemon. Flimsy little bent steak knife was a surprise.  Disappointed to order oysters and then have to have the waiter come back to tell us they didn't have some of them. Might have know in advance.  Changed the order and oysters were good.  Most of the food tasted good.  All of it was poorly served. Not on our list for a return visit in the near future.  Hope they can pull service back together.
author: Gen d.

description:
An alternate view, in city where there is certainly no dirth of amazing, innovative culinary gems, on Zuni:

Their level of self-love over their chicken is shameful, yet exceeded only by the stupidity of their burger. What asshole serves a burger on 4 inches of foccacia? You know what kind? The kind that only lives in San Francisco. And you know who eats it? The same pork pie hat-wearing-once salivated-over a 20-sided die dungeons and dragons-playing putz who THINKS that because he lives in Potrero, has heard of John Coltrane, and once watched a movie about someone who saw someone else smoking a joint and can't decide whether to buy another pair of Converse Chuck Taylors or a Prius...that he is cool.
author: Lauren D.

description:
I would have given the full 5 stars but I just got my last credit card statement with the total that was charged. They have on several occasions charged me more than I wrote for tip. I always tip 20% or more so it's not like I'm being cheap. I have also received my bill (at the restaurant) with extra charges and caught it in time.
I totally understand the health insurance tax and I don't mind paying a bit more for the excellent service and delicious food but this pisses me off, especially when it has happened several times.
Besides that, yes the roasted chicken is unbelievable and they put some magic ingredient in there. The burger is scrumptious. The drinks always hit the spot. The atmosphere is really easy and doesn't try too hard which is a plus for me.
I hope to review again with 5 stars all the way.
author: Melissa E.

description: Went there for brunch on Saturday. Food was OK, nothing too spectacular. We had the Clams appetizer that came with 8 clams, and a burger. It was not filling enough, so we ordered the caesar salad as well, and some shoe string fries. Wanted to try the chicken but didnt have time. I thought the food was ok but not memorable nor special. I am glad I tried it out but probably wont become a regular.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Wow, what can you say; this place lives up to its reputation, even after all of these years.  The first time I dined here was with my girlfriend back in the 80's.  We had great food and an overall great experience.  At that time, we both worked at an upscale country club in southern California, so we knew good cuisine.  Then years went by.

I returned in the mid-nineties, with my boyfriend.  This time we ate outside.  And it was at night.  I loved Zuni this visit as much as the previous visit so many years before.  Great shellfish! I would have visited Zuni sooner, but I lived in San Diego, so it was a little bit of a drive/flight.
And then more years went by..

Now I live in the bay area and frequent Zuni more often!  The ambiance, the bar, the servers and the food are all top notch quality.  Even though the economy is not so great, this place is still always packed.  On my last visit was with a guy I was dating.  The food was amazing. (Flat Iron Steak, Beat Salad)  I was very happy that they offer a selection of 1/2 bottles, perfect for when you are the only one drinking!

To sum it up, people and things come and go, and that typically applies to restaurants as well, but this place is uniquely special!
author: Informed C.

description:
It's really disappointing to note that I had such a bad experience here.  Zuni Cafe was a place my wife and I had been looking to eat at for a while.  We used my birthday as the appropriate opportunity to finally experience the highly acclaimed Zuni Cafe.

Our main complaint was the seating, which was one of the worst seating arrangements I've ever experienced at any restaurant, let alone at such a fine dining restaurant.

We were seated at a tiny table basically stuffed into a walkway such that we couldn't sit across from each other.  The odd arrangement forces diners to sit right next to each other instead of face to face so that people can walk by.  I could've gotten a better, more comfortable seating at a McDonald's.  This is supposed to be fine dining?

It really tainted the entire experience.  The food?  Ok, I guess.. it's hard to say given we were so annoyed.  When you pay such high prices, there's an certain expectation of quality across all aspects of the dining experience.  It's hard to imagine how the managers at Zuni can think that being stuffed into the side of a walkway would meet those expectations.
author: Ravi T.

description: Zuni's been great for years and is still a favorite.
author: Kate H.

description:
I had read great reviews about this restaurant and so had high hopes but I was very disappointed. The portions were small (of what we ordered, though the chicken at the next table looked great!) and arrived at different times. My "shoe string potatoes" arrived a good 7 minutes before my main and so were cold. I had no side plate for the bread as an appetizer and had to use my hand.... in general the service was very poor.

Though when the mains did arrive they were very well cooked so no complaints on that front!

Perhaps this place has a better lunch menu so I might try it earlier in the day......
author: Anita W.

description:
2.5 Stars = FOOD (Duck with prunes, Yummy)
2.5 Stars = SERVICE (Awesome)
5 Stars = TOTAL
(based on a friday night after watching the phantom of the opera at the orpheum theatre)

'Nuff Said...
author: Lou A.

description:
Always solid.  The space is very welcoming and the food expertly executed.  The menu is a bit limited, but the choices all very tasty.  

The service can be a bit stand-offish. possibly distant, but always professional.
author: Tony A.

description:
I've been to Zuni numerous times and have never failed to have a great time.  Only once have a run into one of these service issues, and that's when we sat outside on a slow Saturday afternoon.  It was a little difficult getting our waitperson's attention but when she WAS there, she was gracious and apologetic.
