I most recently went with my sweetie for Valentine's Day dinner.  I know - Amateur Night, right?  I was terrified of a V-day dinner menu but no - the usual winners were on the menu.  While we were upstairs in one of the little rabbit warren-like rooms, our service was nonetheless superb.  And the meal itself?  Flawless.  My GF mentioned that whenever she goes to Zuni, her fish is cooked perfectly, and I couldn't agree more.  Same goes for the steak.  

I haven't read all the reviews but I will say one thing about the joint that I've never quite understood - their STRAWS are awful.
author: Moira D.

description:
OK, I feel like a jerk writing this because it is somewhat blasphemous to say anything bad about Zuni, but...

A friend and I stopped in for lunch one afternoon. He had a pizza and a salad and I had a burger.

Everything was just so mediocre and I would even venture to say that my burger was on the gross side.

If you want the best burger in the city go to the Tempest Bar during the day (or Darla's out in the avenues).

I'm hoping dinner at Zuni is better, but that burger left such a bad taste in my mouth, I doubt I'll try dinner any time soon.
author: David F.

description:
Love the atmosphere and the food...but our waitress was a..well, you know. She looked like she was going to be fun..cute pixie haircut, big bright eyes...boyish smile...ugh. It was all a show. I tried to joke around a little, get her to loosen up, but no luck. I think it pissed her off more. .. on with the food....

oyster menu? yup. And it's fabulous!! try a few.
Caesar salad was quite possibly the best I ever had. try that too.

2nd trip...waitress was waaaay cooler. kinda like sandra bullock. we got the roasted chicken for two. yea, try four. it was great to have leftovers the next night ... not incredible, but good for the money. 

i think i give this place 4 stars because i just love it's atmosphere. lots of windows, nice long bar with plenty of beautiful beings to gaze upon. fantastic wine list for the money, and always just busy enough. it's a place i will take my girlfriends to when they come to visit.
author: Amy W.

description:
Kudos to our waiter Scott who made this meal perfect. We went in for dinner, sat in the bar and let him guide us through what was good on the menu that night.  We started off with oysters which were excellent.

The ceasar salad was good but had too much anchovy taste for my partner. The polenta was also very good, nice texture, great flavor but like Courtney Y said it could have used more cheese. The pork stew was to die for! Scott gave us the tip for this dish and it did not disappoint. He said to get pork whenever they have it on the menu because they get it from one farmer and generally brine it for 3 days. My partner had the halibut which was good but paled next to the stew.

The dessert - apple tart - super! Scott also paired up great dessert wine for us.

This was a great dinner, I say ask the server their opinion on the dishes, they will steer you the right direction.
author: Ashley T.

description:
The hostesses were straightening up and cleaning the door as we  tried to walk in for our 11:30 lunch reservation.  We couldn't understand why she wouldn't let us in or even acknowledge our presence.  Stop, check watch, it's only 11:23.  Zuni does not open until 11:30, on the dot.  Oh, okay, let's just sit on this bench and wait and laugh at ourselves for a bit for being overly anxious to get in.

We split an appetizer and also had two cheeses off the dessert menu to start.  Later we shared a sea bass entree, stories, and some jokes.  

Sigh....

All of a sudden (truthfully had the company not been so great, as well as the starters, it would've seemed as though an eternity had passed) the chicken appeared.  Succulent and nicely browned, skin crisped just so, sitting atop a bed of bread chunks which smelled of garlic and chicken drippings - this is chicken at its very best!

Sigh....I dream of this chicken.....

Our waiter was awesome, attentive, on the ball, friendly, and knowledgeable.
author: J H.

description:
It was just a few blocks from the symphony hall so it became our dinner place before the performance.  

We were seated in a quirky table according to Michelin's description. The table was right in front of the kitchen and we could see chefs and their work as well as get the first sneak preview of every dish brought out. 

We split the escarole endive salad.  The salad was great and bitter salad has always been my most favorite choice.  For entree, I had the roasted halibut and Bf had the grilled grouper. We both agreed the halibut was perfect with pesto. The dessert was the pumpkin cake and it was light and delicious. 

Everything was great except the portion was a little bit small. For a person with a small appetite, I got hungry before going to bed.
author: Ile F.

description: California cuisine at its best!!! Incredible selection of wine an cheese. Sunday bloody mary's among the best I have tried.
author: Sil V.

description: roasted chicken and bread salad. damn
author: Sahil L.

description: one of my favorite places in san francisco.  sardines, chicken, and burger are all awesome.
author: Oliver C.

description: BF & I ordered the chicken with warm bread salad for 2. It was incredible but after stuffing my face while waiting for an hour for the chicken, it was a bit too much bread in the salad for our liking. Maybe they should have some more chickens cooking in progress so it doesn't take quite as long.
author: Ryan H.

description: I came to this restaurant for a special night with my wife. When I got in, there were all these little rooms and stairways and it seemed a little confusing to navigate. Eventually I found her, and was able to peruse the menu. Seems each night the main dishes change, so there was only one page. We got the chicken for two, as well as a caesar salad and shoestring fries. The fries were not too impressive, but then again they were only six bucks. The good part came from the salad and the chicken. While these items are a bit pricey, I have to say I got my moneys worth. The salad had big thick lettuce leaves, rather then those mini diced square lettuce leaves you see in most restaurants. The cheese topping was tasty, and the croutons were huge and crunchy, some of the best I've tried. However, it was the chicken that was the best part of the meal. They smoke this bird for about an hour, and it came out tasting flavorful and juicy. I am a very simple guy, and can eat chicken at any old place and still be satisfied, like at boston market or even greasy KFC. But I gotta say wow, this chicken was nice. It looks like they really took the time to make this bird flavorful and satisfying. There were more than enough pieces for both me and my wife. Even the skin of the chicken was just right, not too crispy but not too soft. I wouldn't mind eating this again. As the night wore on, we saw more and more people coming in, so you know this place is popular. If they keep cooking the chicken like this, I can imagine they will keep making lots of money. Good job Zuni! Only subtract one star because the server stepped on my shoes three times during the course of the evening. Granted, the tables are very close to each other and a little narrow, but come on! Three times? Oh well, least the food was spectacular.
author: Billy K.

description: Great service, oysters, duck leg , bread and wine!
author: Rus M.

description:
Went to dinner here the other night and loved it. Ordered the gnocchi and the chicken. They were both very delicious. The gnocchi was like eating pillows of cheese, just excellent. The chicken for two was awesome! The combination of the bread salad and the chicken worked well together. Chicken was not dry at all. 

I would definitely recommend trying this place. The chicken might be pricey, but well worth it for the service and the experience.
author: Jason E.

description: Yes, Zuni is fantastic, and yes, you should get the roasted chicken with the bread salad.  The old-school caesar salad is great as well.  Judy Rodgers does an incredible job, and the atmosphere at Zuni is absolutely fantastic.  Try sitting perched upstairs to have a good view of the kitchen, the bar, and the table settings below.  Highly recommended!
author: Alice Y.

description: Great place for weekend brunch.  Don't forget to make reservations and take advantage of valet since street parking is sparse.
author: D. E.

description: I went to lunch at Zuni recently.  Was very disappointed.  Not only was the food mediocre, but the service was a little snotty.  In addition, the amazing bloody mary I use to associate with Zuni, was actually bad.  I was very disappointed by the whole experience because Zuni has always been a stand by for me.  Oh well.
author: Mark G.

description: phenomenal baked chicken dish with bread salad... nuff said.
author: Jason P.

description:
Hmmm. I don't get it. I read the raves about the chicken. Got a taste for chicken (think the Fifth Element's LeeLoo uttering, "Chicken . . . good"). Ordered chicken. One hour later, got underwhelming chicken. It wasn't bad -- it just wasn't anything even remotely special or noteworthy. So I have to wonder, is a properly cooked chicken such a novelty these days that people get excited about it for the mere fact of it not being overcooked? Fortunately, I have found an alternate place, less than a mile away from the Zuni Café, to get a nicely flavored, properly cooked chicken for much less than $48 ($24 pp). Unfortunately, this alternate source is rather exclusive. They require that you join their club and they will check your membership card at the door and upon leaving. But if you aren't already a Costco member you should consider joining so that you, too, can pick up a $5 roasted chicken at the same time you score a gianormous bale of toilet paper or paper towels at low, low warehouse prices. While I found the Zuni Café's chicken meat to be marginally better than its ready-to-eat counterpart at the Costco deli, Costco always delivers on the crispy skin whereas Zuni Café produced something that was, well, one of those words that has the power to ruin a girl's evening . . . limp. Damn. If price were no object, it would be a toss-up between which chicken I liked better. Throw in the price comparison and Costco is the clear winner. I do agree, however, with the other reviewers that the bread salad was simply delicious. (Hooray for carbs to the rescue!) This was a relief given that the bread we were served at the table tended to be overcooked, with one loaf being quite dry with an almost black crust. (Side note: What's up with no bread plates? When you have bread THAT crusty and messy, you really need bread plates . . . especially when you only have one pat of butter for four people to share. It took a Herculean effort for me to resist the urge to take a hunk of the butter pat and stick it on my paper tablecloth so that I'd have butter at the ready to combat the dryness of the bread. Eventually, we all accumulated piles of crumbs on the dishless table and then hypothosized about what should be done to deal with the mess.) 
The meal beyond the chicken was good, but not great. The oysters we started our evening with were delicious. (Query: Does a restaurant get credit for serving something yummy when essentially they have done nothing to prepare that item but clean it and put it on a plate?) The meatballs were tiny (you can insert your own "small balls" joke here), but good. One of our party got the gnocchi as an entrée and shared some because she wanted to see if the rest of us agreed that it tasted less like gnocchi and more like scrambled eggs (it did, but it had a nice finish to it which was probably because the gnocchi was swimming in a virtual butter-soup - tasty but I better wait to get my cholesterol checked for a while). The fourth person in our party had the rabbit and liked it enough that he didn't offer to share . . . or perhaps that was because the portion size wasn't very large. Holding firm to the philosophy that no dinner out is complete without chocolate, two of us shared the only true chocolate item on the menu: the Gateau Victoire. This flourless chocolate cake was also rather moistureless, but for the whipped cream, and tasted overwhelmingly of espresso, which came as an unpleasant surprise to us non-coffee drinkers. This might have been the first time that we have shared a chocolate dessert and left half of it on the plate. Blah. Our server was very pleasant and helpful when she was around. 'nough said.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
finaaally made it to zuni cafe!

i spare the chicken since everyone knows about it...to be honest...you can probably make a VERY similar chicken at home using thomas kellers simple recipe...will save you 35 bucks =)

anyways

everything we had here was DELICIOUS.
started with the gnocchi SO good just the right amount of cheesey goodness inside, melts in your mouth..like buttah!

next we had the lamb sausage...i love lamb so this was again...superb..the portion as a main course..kinda small in my opinion but great as a shared dish

then we finished with the chicken and some pomme frites...even though i didn't think the chicken was all that heavenly, the combo of it the bread and the salad work wonders together...

two thumbs up! definite repeat
author: Arthur T.

description: Famous for good reason. Expertly executed comfort food with just a touch of something special. Will I be back? You better believe it!
author: Jon D.

description:
Zuni is way overrated.  The La Fettunta (essentially a slice of bread dipped in olive oil) was good, but the ricotta gnocchi lacked some punch.  The beef fillet was a big disappointment: fatty, rubbery, and very much in need of seasoning.  It was so bad we left it on the plate.  The margarita was too strong.  And the bill was way too high for the mediocre food.  On the positive side the service was ok.

This is the first time we really disagreed with the average yelp ratings.  Definitely a yelp let-down.  Don't fall for this one.
author: Adi O.

description:
I've worked close by for years but have only eaten here a few times for lunch.  

The ceasar salad is tasty, pretty, and pricy.  The oysters are fine, particularly with the mignonette.  The anchovy appetizer knocked me out, fresh cured fish with olive oil and served with parmesan, celery, and olives.  It was like eating sushi and so good I started making it at home.  I did think the pork chop would be juicier, after reading about the brining, but I think it's more the cut.  It's been so long, I can't remember the burger, but the fries were good.  

One day I had the squid stew, absolutely delicious, reminded me of childhood (although never that good in my childhood), and a great example of slow cooking.
author: John T.

description:
Bad place for families... Especially if you have a baby... So here is the story... It's my wifes birthday, I wanted to take her out for a nice lunch and we always heard that  Zuni is a goo fancy eat. We walk in with our 4 month old baby (great boy, didn't make a sound the entire time).

First thing that sucked was that we waited for like 20 minutes then when the seated us, we were taken upstairs to a weird location that was empty. We were like ok, NP, we have a baby, we understand... Wife went to change diapers in the bathroom, there was no changing table, we asked the waiter where we could change him, he pointed us to some other compltely empty room upstairs. Then Mr. mean Rob came out of no where and started literally yelling and complaining at us for changing the baby on the chair in this room. Not cool Rob.

Wait staff was not all that great either, maybe it was the location. The food was pretty good but the portions are small and we expected much more and better for the price. 

No more Zuni's for us... Too bad for them...
author: Wisam D.

description:
I used to live 8 blocks from Zuni, the last time I went there was for my boyfriend's birthday. 

It's great if you want food that is well prepared, but unfussy. He's a straightforward meat guy, so this was perfect for him. I personally like more fuss, frou-frou and adventurous flavor combos in my expensive dining experiences,  but Zuni is solid american food beautifully prepared and presented. 

There is a see and be seen vibe about the windows and the bar, and that I can always do without... but if you sit upstairs, the vibe is relaxed and elegant.
author: Danger A.

description:
After so many years in SF, I finally had dinner at Zuni.  It was really a treat. Beautiful space, delicious food, but the service was rather awkward.  We ordered a $100 bottle of wine - something we NEVER do (we coinstarred the change jar!) and the waiter was pretty sloppy with his pour.  I'm no wine snob, I even drink boxed wine, but I hoped for something a little more... polished. When telling us about a steak that was also available, he sort of lingered around our table after that... even though there were no more specials to make us aware of.  We were like "Ok, cool, thanks..." and he just sort of stood there.  

I'll go back, want to try the burger and the chicken some time, but we'll spare the wine splurge.
author: Miss M.

description: i guess being a tourist i'm obligated to go to zuni and order the caesar.  i fulfilled my duty.  it was very good.  the rest of the food was ok.  the place is a little full of itself.  i recently watched the owner of zuni on a tv show and she was rolling her eyes at having to keep the caesar salad on the menu because of people like me.  been there, done that, won't be back.
author: Fred F.

description: Always dependable for a Sunday night dinner or date. Start with oysters. Chicken for two never disappoints.
author: Denis L.

description: It goes without saying that this place has the best burger and fries in town.  For that alone, they score in a big way.  Unfortunately the two fish dishes I've tried were nothin' to write home about.  Last Wednesday we celebrated our anniversary at Zuni's. My man got the flank steak and it was amazing.  I decided on the Sea Bass but it was over-cooked and tough.  Then it hit me- I regretted ordering fish the last time we were here. When it's all said and done, bad fish experiences aside, I usually leave this place smiling.
author: Traci E.

description:
The chicken was excellent! As well as the pot de crème dessert.

Very nice atmosphere and layout. The rabbit with Brussel sprouts was excellent.
author: Thomas K.

description: Zuni is actually better than Ever! the roasted chicken for two and the Caesar salad are even yummier that when we tasted them over 20 years ago as tourists. When most places just coast along on their former glory, Zuni has decidedly worked on improving...way to go old gal!
author: Kay H.

description: I can honestly say, this is the best restaurant I have been to in San Francisco, so far. EVERYTHING I had was outstanding. We started with the Caesar salad and an artichoke and string been soup. We kept stealing from each other, they were amazing. Had the roasted chicken, which as far as chicken goes, the best. I finished with the meringue and lemon cream dessert, if you like sour, to die for. For drink I had the Aperole, which is a sweet and sour drink, almost like an appletini. Delicious. Would recommend Zuni to anyone.
author: Mercy G.

description: We were expecting a high quality meal but instead for the price, pretentious service and meager servings we should have gone to State Provisions. The flavoring was bland for the gnocchi, dished were luke warm, portions skimpy, and the vegetables poorly braised. If you take the chance, go for wine!
author: Sacha C.

description: This place is on the 100 places to eat in San Francisco, so we had to try. We had the 1hr long wait  for the roast chicken. If you know what Hawaiian HuliHuli chicken is then this one is the same. The roasted chicken is tasteless, just chicken. The bread salad on the bottom is better. Bread with spinach. There is no gravy or sauce for this and the cost is $48. Save your money and go someplace else. Overrated, over priced, and tastless. this place is all hype. save your money and buy a roasted chicken from Costco for five bucks instead.
author: Kimmy C.

description:
THE Best Chicken. Hands down. 
I've been to Zuni Cafe a couple of times, and it never disappoints.  Zuni is known for their famous "Chicken for Two". And I suggest if your date doesn't like/eat chicken, then go find a new restaurant, because this dish is simply delicious. Even though it is a shared dish, there is more than enough to go around, and you will not regret your choice. The rest of their menu is good too, incase you aren't a chicken-lover. Great wine list. The ambience is nice, its almost rustic-ish, and inviting. The staff is great; very knowledgeable and friendly. One thing to note: if you plan on actually sitting down to get a drink before the meal, then you might want to not make Zuni your first stop, since there's no stools at the bars.
SOME THINGS I FORGOT TO ADD:
It takes an hour from when you order for the chicken done, because it's cooked in a woodburning stove(or some sort of oven), but its totally worth it.
Its made with a currant and mint bread salad, which soaks with the chicken when its cooking. Truely makes it stand above others.
author: Ashley H.

description:
We were seated w/ our menus.  After about 10 mins. our server came over and took the entire order.  I like to order my drink pretty quickly after being seated then I am okay w/ waiting a little to order, I have a drink.
We shared oysters to start and they were delicious.  My app. was a salad w/ baby lettuce, paper thin cucumbers and radishes accompanied by a crouton swathed w/ avocado.  It tasted good, but the portion was very small for what it cost.  My companion had the sardines.  They were served w/ Parmesan cheese, blk. olives and thinly sliced celery.  This was very tasty, but when placed on the avocado crouton it was even better, great perhaps.  This flavor is something meant for a mature palate.  
This however is where things went down hill.  When my companion ordered the salmon she was advised it would be prepared slightly undercooked.  When it arrived it was just the opposite.  What a disappointment.  I ordered the quail which was okay, but not great.  The polenta it was served w/ was flavorless  and the texture of cream of wheat.  I salted it, but it was useless.  The quail was prepared properly, but not seasoned well and served in an over salted jus.  We won't return.
author: David S.

description: Went here for an epic dinner last week.  Epic both because I was dining with a legendary slow eater - and because eating here is always rather a production.  I got the same thing I always get  - the caesar and the chicken (shared) - and I've never been let down.  And I really like their bar - nice ambiance, zinc bar, and a good selection.  Definitely one of the most reliable places in SF.
author: ariel b.

description: I should have reviewed Zuni a long time ago... great food, service and value. Roasted chicken and rabbit are both awesome. Oysters are some of the best you will find in the city.
author: Steve S.

description:
What can i do on a cold rainy day? Get some brunch. In order to complement my new life style of eating healthy, i made my way to Zuni with few friends. Parking was a breeze and i guess mother nature contributed to it :) There was a small wait as they don't take brunch reservations for a group of more than 4 people. Got a table upstairs. 
I am the kind of person who likes pent house and lofts with open floor plans and floor to ceiling windows so the place had rather welcoming appeal to me. The server was friendly and helpful and took good care of our table from beginning to end. Started out with shoe string potato and Potatoes. Must say shoe string potatoes are more fun to eat than fries and potato soup was a definite 4 star. For the main entree i got the fried egg with chick pea. It was delicious. Garbanzo beans cooked in Indian style topped with a friend egg covered in spinach. Damn! why didn't i think of it. Definitely let my south Asian mother down, Lol. Other people in my group had scrambled eggs, pizza, and french toast. Everyone greatly enjoyed the entrees. I must say the portions are not huge. I was ready for a second meal right away :). The food is healthy, flavorful, reasonably priced but in small portions
author: Hasham Y.

description: Saw this place on Food Network Best Thing I Ever Ate and Guy said get the roast chicken. I didn't even look at the menu because that was all I had my mind set on ordering. I ordered the cesar salad which was literally an entire head of romaine with fresh grated parmesan, black pepper, olive oil, and garlic.....the salad was good but if the lettuce were grilled it would have been amazing. My fiance ordered polenta which was creamy and good also. Then came the chicken....1st they ask if you will be ordering chicken as soon as you are seated because it takes up to an hour to cook...when it came out...OH MY GAWD...such a simple plate but sexy ass hell....the ingredients.....black pepper, sea salt, olive oil and love.....with crusty sour dough bread, currants, pine nuts and arugula salad on top The best chicken i have ever had.....ever the only complaint I have is that I didn't want to look like a barbarian by picking up the chicken with my hands. That fork and knife stuff does this chicken a dishonor. Definitely a must when in San Fran...
author: Henry B.

description:
Well, three & a half.  On a recent visit we were seated in their Siberia & I'm pretty sure there were other better non-consigned tables available.  Romantic view of the neighboring construction site & accompanying noise & dust clouds. 

Waiter was OK, not great.  All the staff are very easy on the eye, & that appears to be the sole hiring criteria.  Couple of service mishaps - nothing too major, but I sense it reflected a slight lack of interest on the misguided assumption that we were visiting [lo-tipping] foreigners.

Had the Classic Zuni that has been my staple over the last fifteen years - Oysters, Caesar & Chicken.

3 pairs of oysters - all very good, but we were overcharged on two of them by almost a dollar.  Caesar remains one of the best by which others are compared, though the romain was a little - gasp - wilted.  Excellent dressing though.

Chicken wonderful - came out in about 50-mins against the advertised/forewarned hour.  Stuffing was just OK & not so much of it as I recall.

Reasonably priced wine list.  The crowd remains constant - good cross section of reasonably well-heeled SF in all its vain glory...how lovely.
author: David P.

description:
Very very good food, solid service.

Loss of one star for only having ONE table that can accomodate more than 6.

Loss of another star for being a pain in the ass about making my 10 year old brother a hamburger at 10:40 pm after waiting for 40 minutes with a reservation for said one table (evidently the policy is not to make it until after 11). Clearly, the chef is more than competent - he can't make a kid a burger a few minutes early?
author: Jen A.

description:
We arrived at 6 on a Tuesday night and while the host stand was being maned by 5 people (2 on the phone) no one made contact with us for a good thirty seconds. Not a life time, but a smile and nob would have been nice. 

To avoid the the 20 minute wait we opted for a bar table, while the tables had a great view of market street they were also extremely close together (even by San Francisco standards) and the seat cushions were worn plastic with a very thin pad.  I realize this may sound picky, but this place is a San Francisco Icon and sound be held to a high standard. 

Our server was great.  He struck a great balance between being friendly and professional and he knew his stuff.

The food was a mixed bag.  The Halibut dish my dad had was very good.  I had the blue nose bass.  Not so good.  About a quarter of the fish was that weird dark brown stuff. Not edible and should have been removed. The blue cheese with honey for desert, simply awesome. 

Wine by the glass???? Three whites and three reds???? 

Overall not a bad a experience, but for $150 for two people I think a very good or excellent experience is more in order.
author: Jimmy M.

description:
Excellent service - The bar area staff was incredibly attentive while we waited to be seated.  Great personable service from the staff! Wonderful staff! 

Great Mojitos!

I had the fish and tasted the gratin, and it was delicious.  Not too much deviation from Cali-Med cuisine, but overall, it's one of  my favorite places because of the service. Nice refinement without being stuffy.
author: Shane P.

description:
I legitimately enjoy dining at Zuni Cafe; however, it is a "love - hate" relationship with this restaurant. The food is wonderful, the mixed drinks are generous and the wine list is reasonable. BUT, the host  is so arrogant and insulting that he ruins the experience for me. During my last two attempts to eat at this restaurant, his presence and demeanor has forced me to walk away from the restaurant. The last time it was over lunch. I won't get into the specifics but I find his presence revolting.

That being said, I love the food and ambience of the restaurant. The roasted chicken and the selection of oysters make this a special place, but the restaurant needs to act a little humble from time to time. I understand Zuni's is an institution but you must treat the customer with respect. It is my opinion that a great chef and menu are not the only ingredients necessary to achieve a successful restaurant.  I fear that the restaurant has developed quite an attitude regarding its popularity in the SF dining community. I suggest that it take a moment to reflect upon its early beginnings and maybe act (or at least put on the facade) that they care about the customer.
author: Blake S.

description:
Oh Zuni! Oh Zuni! Oh!! Zuni!!

My favorite cookbook! Rustic and true! What more can you ask for! The chicken from their very own wood burning oven with the bread salad and fabulous San Francisco setting. I'm a huge fan of the open loft space as well as their selection of artwork. 

Hands down, one of my favorite spots. All hale Judy Rodgers!
author: Catsu H.

description:
Two moods can cover you here if you decide to dine at Zuni.

1. A nice dinner in a place that very open, bustling & accompanied with aromas that make your tummy growl.  A place that is good for a date or versatile enough for a group of friends to share wine and entrees like the roasted chicken that can take up to an hour to cook.

2. Great late night food.  

I have been on multiple occasions but what stands out for me is the Cheeseburger that isn't on the menu. Order it and you'll know what I'm sayin'...the shoe string fries that come with this bad boy are definitely a winner.  

I suggest you hit up some bars.  Start at Zietgiest maybe end up at Martuni's across the street and be ready for a great burger!
author: Mateen A.

description: I just don't get this place.  Why do they get so many good reviews?  Are they paying someone off?  The only award this place deserves is - THE most overrated restaurant in San Francisco.  What?  Chicken and hamburger are there big dishes.  Well, you can only get the hamburger at certain times of the day and it's really no big deal.  I try this place every year or so just to see if I'm ordering the wrong thing.  I think it's just living on its own hype.  I'm going to try it again next month and will try the wait for an hour chicken.  We'll see.  Until then, the Emperor has no clothes.
author: Arthur W.

description:
Ordered the chicken for 2.
I have been wanting to try it for ages and so excited to finally try it.

We ordered bloody marys and shoestring fries to make the time go faster.  
The fries were delicious.  I love how thin and crispy they are.

The drinks were peppery and had a great aftertaste of the balsamic.

The chicken came and looked delicious.  I enjoyed it but found it way too salty for my taste.  The smoky flavor was really good, but I couldn't battle through the saltiness.  The bread salad that comes with it was also really delicious, but I won't ever order the dish again. 

I felt like I'd have to hydrate after leaving the place.  I have now a half a chicken for leftovers this week and will enjoy them immensely but only paired with someting bland as it is already over salted.

Fun layout of the restaurant which makes you feel like you are really in a smaller place due to all the nooks and crannies.  

Just not a fan of the neighborhood because I had to park in front of a liquor store where I felt my car was at risk of being urinated on by a bum.
author: Christine L.

description: You will pay $42 for chicken and stuffing, and you will like it. Get fries with that.
author: Matt R.

description:
I've been wanting to go here for years, but could never seem to get a reservation. Finally I decided that I had waited long enough and had to try it. I made a reservation three weeks ago and have been looking forward to it ever since. 
We arrived early and had a drink at the beautiful copper bar. I had been hopping that we would get a table near the kitchen and they must have read my mind because we got a perfect table facing the kitchen....so I could see them making everything! Also see all of the cute chefs. 
I LOVE roast chicken, it's one of my all time favorite foods. So it was a no brainer that we would order that. Knowing it would take an hour, we also ordered the burratta crostini and the Caesar salad. It's pretty hard to have anything not taste amazing when you pair it with decadent burratta and this did not disappoint. 
I seemed to have OD-ed on Caesar salads as a teenager, so have not had one in a long time, but because I could see the guy at the salad station making numerous Caesar salads, I figured I give it another chance. I am glad I did, it was pretty much a perfect Caesar salad (just a tad overdressed). The romaine wasn't cut, which is usually a pet-peeve of mine, but because the leaves were on the smaller side I didn't mind. The dressing was light and perfectly anchovy-ey, garlicky, lemony and peppery. 
Now to the perfect roast chicken and bread salad. It was the epitome of simple food that tastes amazing and way more complex than it appears. Crispy, perfectly seasoned skin. Super moist and flavorful meat. Served on top of a rustic bread salad dressed with champagne vinegar and drippings from the chicken and sprinkled with pine nuts and currants. 
Also our waiter was great, I forget his name, but he was one of the best waiters I've had in a long time. He was very helpful in describing the wines. He personally split up our salad so we each had our own plate. And he wasn't at all pushy to get us to leave at the end of the meal. 
I will definitely be recommending this restaurant to everyone. It was the perfect meal.
author: Rose K.

description: Definitely legit. They have tightly edited menu but that increases the quality of each item. We were late for our reservations and they had to give our table away but were great with accommodating a new table by opening up a closed section of the restaurant. Waitress was a bit of a snooze but she brought the food out quickly so whatev. Their oysters were great!
author: Morin O.

description: I only comment when things are very good or very bad. This place doesnt fail to deliver. The chicken is out of this world. What they are known for and as i write im salivating for it.  Went there for dinner with friends and everything was outstanding. The ambience, the drinks and mostly the food. Definitely coming back soon and highly recommend it!!
author: irina f.

description:
So this is a hard review for me.  Zuni is my favorite restaurant in SF but I always order the same thing.   Tray of oysters, caesar salad and the roast chicken.  Rarely do I order anything else.  I even order the roast chicken when  I go for lunch.  I think the other dishes they serve are good to very good but nothing really matches the chicken.   So this review only applies to my regular order.

When I recommend the chicken to others, the normal reaction is "chicken?!?!? how good could it really be?"  But afterwards, everyone is always amazed how good it actually tastes.  The only one that is comparable is the one served at Bouchon, but even Thomas Keller could not match the one at Zuni.

The oysters are always fresh - much better and more variety than the ones served at hog island.  The caesar salad is nicely balanced and they don't skimp on the anchovy.  A caesar without a distinctive anchovy flavor is not a caesar, IMO. 

Others dishes I can recommend are the polenta, shoe string fried potatoes (crunchy but tender in the middle), and the hamburger.  Also recommend you try the balsamic vinegar bloody mary.  Excellent.  Much better than a traditional bloody mary.   The vinegar complements the tomato flavor better than the traditional Worcestershire sauce.

I've read a lot of complaints about the service but I always felt the service was very good.  Never had an issue.  Zuni is certainly not cheap (even I was a bit taken aback by the $48 price for the chicken for two during my last meal) but its worth the splurge.

So go.  Remember - balsamic bloody mary, oysters, caesar and chicken .
author: chae y.

description: An institution for good reason. Every meal is memorable with even the garnish being as memorable ad the main course.  Great service decor n food and each time I eat here there is at least one dish that sends me over the moon. Judy has perfected to casually elegant restaurant
author: Rick N.

description: Zuni was a total bomb. I mean, boom, bang failure. It was completely uninspired food a child could whip up. The kitchen provided a vegetarian dish that was not fit for a caveman. Now, I'm sure the chicken MIGHT have been tasty, but vegetables at an exorbitant amount was not worth it. Not to mention, the Marsala ice cream, which is seductive in its description, was served blandly in a rocks glass from the bar. The atmosphere is fine. The food is not. A big thumbs down front this bi-coastal (NY/LA) inhabitant.
author: Dani M.

description:
My husband and I went there yesterday for the first time. I had pretty high expectations by seeing the crowd inside.

The place is very beautiful and the atmosphere is pretty good.

Unfortunately  the place lacks of inspiration when it comes to dressing and seasoning their dishes. Absolutely everything we ordered was soaking in oil or butter.

My husband had the Lamb mixed grill with farro salad on the side. The meat was too grisly and the salad too oily.

I had the gnocchi. First of all, they were actually ricotta gnudi (= ravioli without the wrapper) so their appellation is misleading. Second, they were not home-made but store-bought from whatever farm. Finally, although the chef did a good job of microwaving them, he certainly lacked inspiration for the sauce: the gnudi were bathing in a lake of melted butter. There must have been a whole stick of butter  just in my plate. As I was eating the last piece, the butter had time to cool down and solidify...Not appetizing at all! Just a spoon of brown butter would have been enough....

Same thing for the shoestring fries: too thin so of course they get too oily after frying!

In summary if  you go to Zuni you are guaranteed a heart-attack!
author: Anastasia M.

description: I've been here several times over the years and this gem just never gets worn, tired or sloppy.  Go off hours when the restaurant is more relaxed, order a dozen oysters and a small plate or two from the bar menu, and explore their excellent selection of wines by the glass.  Classic San Francisco and my highest possible rating.
author: Disco B.

description:
We've been to Zuni several times for lunch but last night was our first time for dinner.  It was my husband's birthday and he loves hamburgers and Zuni's makes the best.  We had a reservation for 6:15 before going to a play.  When we got there, the restaurant wasn't very crowded but the maitre d' twice tried to give us terrible tables (I wonder if it was our 510 area code?).  Turns out Zuni stops serving the hamburger from 6:00-9:00.  The manager said, that tho four other people had wanted it Zuni "didn't want to become known as a hamburger joint.".   Well, it seems strange to me that when you have six customers before 6:30 who all want something you served half an hour ago, and plan to serve again in two and a half hours, you give them what they want.  But not to be.  I told him to charge $20 at night if that made him feel better, but, no burgers at dinner time.  No toys either.

So, I had polenta.  It was okay, pretty bland.  My husband had the lamb sausage.  Again, just okay, but it helped the polenta!  We shared fries and they were GREAT!  I had a Manhattan, which though small for the price, was quite tasty.  Our waiter was very polite and professional and frustrated at not being able to serve us want we wanted.
author: Patty W.

description: Love this place. Among one of the best burgers I've ever had, great shoestring fries, good bloody mary's (and I don't even like bloody mary's), and excellent kumamoto oysters. Lovely ambiance and central location.
author: Mimi W.

description: Definitely a nice spot! The heirloom tomato soup was delicious and so was the roasted chicken for two! Cool bar and piano downstairs, very interesting layout, nice modern architectural feel. Thanks Zuni!
author: Brian B.

description:
Twas a chilly Sat and for the myriad of holiday happenings a-foot, a warm meal and a playful cocktail seemed as much as was required. We called to see about some rezzies, and while they told us it would be a half hr wait, when we arrived 10 mins later by foot they took us straight-away. Tip: dine early; it filled in readily as the eve went forward. Interesting table where we shared a side and looked outward at other diners (i DID see the winner of the Ugly Holiday Sweater Award.. but i'm not sure she'd gotten the memo.. or even knew she was in the running! ;). My fella might've preferred a standard set-up, but i liked the novelty of the vantage point.
I admit to dashed hopes on the "fresh lime" margarita: didn't find it particularly either of those descriptors and imagine mix was involved. Next time I'll go wine list.. 
The food was rather lovely. Started with the Escarole salad, and i loved walnuts left raw and flavorful. We also had lamb (i know, i know.. sacrelig to skip chicken but warmth was needed in the winter bones!)  Ample portion and roasted garlic (among an array of veggies sorta stewed) was most delicious.. They charmed with a requested side of brus sprouts; flecked into a delicate leaf arrangement with enough flavor to make a unique offering, but not too much to mask seasonality of the ingredient. I love knowing those little cabbages came recently from a stalk :).    
Service as unassuming, but as available and helpful as needed.
A solid Sat eve offering and just a few blocks walk-- all ze betta.
author: Rachel S.

description: A late night dinner at Zuni was the perfect finish to a wonderful night with friends and jazz. The delightful flower martini and excellent wine list were just what  we needed. I enjoyed the perfect vegetarian pasta dish with a shared ceasar salad. The burgers, salmon and creamy polenta also had rave reviews. I have been here several times for both lunch and dinner and Zuni never disappoints
author: Stella N.

description:
Zuni: Where Amazing (Hamburgers) Happens

Zuni Cafe

1658 Market Street
San Francisco, CA 94102-5949
(415) 552-2522

http://www.zunicafe.com/

Price: $15 (+$1.75 for Beecher's Flagship Cheese); + $6.00 for fries

Eater: Charlie and Megan

Date: 10/26/10

Welcome to the most expensive edition of Bread.Meat.Bread yet! In this episode, Megan and Charlie fork over $35 each to a waiter who acted all judgey, as if they didn't  belong there! PSHAW, waiter man! After Megan and Charlie ordered their beers, he even had the audacity to ask whether they would be ordering food.  Imeancomeon, it's not like they looked homeless! Not only did they order burgers, but fries too! What fancy pants these two were wearing! Oh, they'll be back waspy old waiter man!

After their meal, Charlie sits down to write Megan a letter about their evening together.

Megan, did you know Zuni means "delicious ball of cow" in Swahili? I'm lying, it doesn't...but it should (!), because that's what this was: a delicious. Ball. Of cow.  Wouldn't you agree?

Our short visit to Zuni Café left us lighter in the wallet, but heavier in the saddle...isn't that some law of physics or something?

Anyway, I thought the house-ground, 1/3 lb, Marin Sun Farms patty was served up perfectly, medium rare/rare, and with every bite that great burger juice was released. As you know Megan, this is the hallmark of any top-notch burger. The quality and flavor of the beef was exquisite and the accouterments added to - and did not distract from - the flavor. As we've experienced before, this can be a real issue. The grilled rosemary focaccia bun was fresh, moist and served as a great compliment to the garlic aioli and the buttery house - "Zuni" - pickles.  What a rich combination! Megan, I know you thought the rosemary foccaccia bun was delicious too but cumbersome and a bit large for the patty. You should have seen Megan trying to keep that thing together just long enough to shove it in her mouth! While I agree the bun-to-burger ratio was off, I though the bun held the burger with great grace. Personally, I thought the bun could have used a few more seconds on the grill; I really like that crunch, as I reminded you while I was getting no crunch...but now I'm just nitpicking. I know we disagree on this point.

I was expecting the pickles to be intense, but they worked well with the whole construction, wouldn't you say, Megan? I'm glad we splurged for the Beecher's Flagship cheese - a semi-hard cow's milk cheese if for no other reason then to say we ordered the Beecher's Flagship cheese. I thought the side of ketchup and mustard was a nice touch, but wholly and totally unnecessary; this burger needed NO such crutches.

And how can we forget that heaping pile of perfectly salted shoe-string fries!? Honestly, Megan, if it weren't for that six-year-old towhead stuffing her face with fries at the table across from us, we probably would have failed to order the fries....and that would have been a sin. Megan, I know you hoped we wouldn't eat every single fry...good thing the waiter pried the plate from our hands, or else we would have. God bless towheads!

What a delicious overall meal and one of the best burgers to date..

Heaping Mound O' Fries...

Size: 1/3 lbs.

Accouterments: House-ground hamburger on grilled rosemary focaccia with garden lettuces, garlic aïoli, and Zuni pickles and onions.

Type of Meat: Cow

Ranch: Marin Sun Farms

Beer with Burger: Charlie:Sierra Nevada Pal Ale, bottle; $5.50. Megan: Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout, bottle; $7.


Beer Selection: Limited. No Draft beers and about 10 overpriced bottles. I toyed with the idea of getting the $10 Saison Dupont, but I couldn't justify purchasing a $10 beer after purchasing a $20+ burger with fries.

Ambiance: We wondered aloud whether the waiter was snotty or awkward, and then, wait a minute, realized we didn't care! An upscale restaurant on a street corner with lots of windows. The bar isn't for eating but rather for drinking and standing only. The greater bar area consists of a handful of two-tops at the front of the restaurant which are available for walk-ins.


Rating: 1.5 Standard deviations above the mean
author: Charlie R.

description:
I honestly was a bit disappointed by this place. After reading so many amazing reviews and even reading on Chowhound how it's so quintessential SF, I had super high hopes for the place. 

Everything tasted great, but it felt so overpriced and not worth the $$$. In all honesty, $48 for a chicken??? I prefer Nopa's better or even going down to Limon Rotisserie. You can go there and have a whole chicken with two sides for $16. Like I said everything is great, but for the price - I'd rather hop over to a few other places.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
I eat here whenever I can. I've only had the roast chicken for two once. It was good, but not why I love the place. What I love is everything on the menu I haven't seen for a long time, if ever. If you don't know what it is, that's the reason to order it. Even if you do, order it -- whenever they have risotto it will blow you away, and they do have it many days in the winter. As for the foods they almost always have: The Caesar salad is the standard against which every other restaurant has to be measured. The oysters cannot be matched anywhere west of New York. They come with an understated and therefore perfect mignonette. The shoestrings are a must, if you have room for them. The pork chop makes you wish you could buy as good a piece of meat in your local store. And their regular dessert items, the chocolate one and the espresso granita, are the best you will ever taste.  But, after all, I often order the cheeses, which are well selected and presented.  

But as I said, the real secret to finding a great dish is to order what they don't have every day. Often, the soup. Always, any dish they have with nettles. Always, the risotto. The fish is  always good, too. And you can trust the wines by the glass. They are chosen not to wow you with too much flavor, but to go perfectly with your food (though there are plenty of monsters on the list if you order a bottle).
author: oz c.

description:
All right, here's the lowdown.  I get that this place does simple food.  But simple food can be really, really great.  You know how at Chez Panisse, you order something that you think you're familiar with, but when it comes, you realize you've never really had it before? properly?  Or when you buy something at the farmer's market, and it's so fresh and awesome, that you don't even need to mess around with it?  That's the only way you can pull off a restaurant where you're neither innovative nor complex.  If it's going to be simple but earn its price tag, it's got to have impeccable ingredients, impeccable prepared.  Zuni ain't it.

I know everyone raaaaaaaaves about the roast chicken.  But my dad's is better.  Now, my dad is a totally awesome (home) cook, and not everyone is spoiled enough to get to eat his food whenever they want, like I am.  But if I'm waiting an hour for a dish that the restaurant is famous around the country for, it needs to be some of the best I've ever eaten.  Like, really knock my socks off.  And Zuni's just doesn't.  I mean, I'm not a great cook, but I can roast my own chicken with a couple of herbs and manage not to dry it out.  It's just not that hard.  So that's not going to get me to fork over cash and a ton of time for it.

Beyond that... I can't even really remember what else I've eaten here, which says a lot in itself.  I know once I had some kind of pasta dish that I liked, but again, it was super plain - pasta with just some parm and maybe parsley or something.  I could make it myself.  Maybe it's my fault for ordering something so ordinary, but I was hoping that based on Zuni's rep it would be amazing.  But it wasn't.  It was fine, but I don't need to pay $14 for it.  Same goes for the caesar.  I can't name another thing I've had here.  Oh, maybe the shoestring fries, so I must have had a burger or something...?  again, not memorable.  Q.E.D.

I'm giving it two stars instead of one because I like the atmosphere, and because they've never really done anything affirmatively sucky.  But to me, it's just not worth it.
author: Ace P.

description:
This place was great for lunch.  The seats by the entrance and by the piano are self-seating, and while the tables are small, it's a pretty comfortable arrangement on a sunny day.  The many burgers around us looked delicious, but we opted for a small platter of oysters (three pairs) and shellfish (my first time with periwinkles--which are about the size of a calculator key and are scooped out of their tiny shells with toothpicks), the gem salad with picked beets, and the pork loin with Japanese eggplant, beans, and basil.  The service was excellent, and since we were sharing the dishes, the salad and the pork loin were served from the kitchen on two separate plates of equal portions, give or take a quarter of a beet or two.  Next time, shall try the burger, and the apple crisp/ice cream dessert my neighbor seemed to be enjoying but which alas, I had no room for.

Also, valet parking is available, but there is plenty of street parking during the day.  However, beware the hour time limit on the meters, and hope for a benevolent meter-maid (person?).
author: Barley W.

description:
Can you have the perfect dining experience? YES!

The food is DELICIOUS...  richly interesting... good size portions

Whatever you do, try the FIG HONEY TART... shut up... best thing EVER

and the staff is friendly and professional and attentive
author: Chris S.

description:
Hey, what's the big deal?
Overpriced, doesn't stand out
Way overrated
author: Paul T.

description: wednesday night dinner after work..seven pm arrival...odd shaped trapezoid table by corner window waiting...maximizing space with tables fabricated to fit interior shape...before menu, a question by waiter if roasted chicken is desired...limited quantity and an hour to cook....putting in an order first...conversations and wine by the glass to start...$eight to $twelve each...a rose for $eleven, spanish tempranillo the cheaper $eight and syrah for $twelve per...slowly browsing menu and asking for suggestions...whole chicken enough for two or three, but need extra sides for variety....a cheesy grainy gnocchi at $fourteen.fifty...a pseudo-gnocchi with no potato, but appearance and texture only thing slightly similar...good, but little rich to eat too many..an order of caesar salad for greens at $ten...served with whole leaves and chopping required...good flavors, but dressed too heavily in saucing...dressing on the side next time....third, vegetable fritto for $eleven.fifty...nice crisp and flavor...battered and fried...feeling the saturation of the oil in batter overindulging...not a healthy choice....the $forty-eight whole chicken pre-cut and served over a mound of great soft seasoned bread...chicken skin quite crisp and nice..an outer perfection...slightly disappointed by this famous whole chicken...the white dry and a tough chew...the dark better obviously...$sixty-seven per person total for a shared meal with an average of two glasses of wine each...
author: Hen A.

description: Had some great oysters to start and a nice fig and quail dish. As recommended went with the roast chicken for two. Definitely some of the best roast chicken I have had. I am a big fan of roast chicken and the intense flavor was superb. My dining companion noted that the chef who mans the chicken roaster was not working that evening and he thought the dish was dry. I guess I need to go back to verify but I didn't have any problems. Decor was nice, modern farmhouse vibe with exposed wood beams. Overall a very successful restaurant.
author: Scott K.

description:
After several rejections for Valentines Day reservations we decided very last minute to just roll up to Zuni and see whats up. 
We expected a good wait at the least but the hostess gave us a choice of bar room seats and we were seated promptly. They were just as good as the dining room seating with full service and we actually had a live musician playing the piano right in front of us which was very nice.
We browsed through the menu and although there were a few dishes that caught my eye we were both set on ordering their chicken. A solid 1 hour wait time but just as we told the couple that walked in and sat next to us while we were eating- hells yes it's worth the wait.
We had some salmon roe stuffed potatoes to start. It was meh but that, bread, and wine held us over until the chicken arrived. 
I'm not sure if were were both starving after the long wait or if the chicken was just so damn good but we tore it up. Maybe both. It was the best tasting chicken I have ever had in my life. Even the juiciest chicken tends to get dry and a little harder to swallow but not this. I can eat this bad boy for days. I didn't care for the vinegary bread though.. Otherwise a very satisfying meal for two.
The service here is excellent. The wait staff are very attentive and have great attitudes and are welcoming and friendly. 
The chicken here is kinda overpriced when I think about it but I love everything about this place and I won't think twice about coming here next time we're in town.
author: Glenn K.

description: After a dozen years in this city I finally made it to Zuni last night.  We walked in with no resy and got a table immediately in the bar area.  We decided to get baptized with the chicken for two.  Started with the lovely caesar salad and the fava bean crustini with house-cured beef.  Both delicious.  As far as the chicken, yes it is one of the best chickens I've ever tasted.  Now that I've tried it, I would want to try something else next time.  Complimented everything with a great French red.  Perfect service.  Lived up to the hype.
author: e w.

description: Great restaurant! I absolutely love this place. Parking is a bit hard in the area but it's definitly worth the effort to go there.
author: Miss M.

description: It's been a couple years since my last meal at ZUNI and they haven't lost their touch. Superlatives abound. Great oysters (it's fab when someone else pays) EXTRAORDINARY Caesar Salad - hands-down best in the country, everything was great. A must for all San Franciscans.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
I came here on a Friday evening after work and found seating right away in the bar.  As far as I can, there's really no difference between bar seating and the regular table area, except the wait is must shorter in the bar.

We ordered ricotta gnocchi as an appetizer to share and they thoughtfully brought it out pre-split, on two separate plates!  I'm not a huge fan of gnocchi (too starchy), but this was unlike any gnocchi I've ever had.  It's made with ricotta (no potato flour at all), and perhaps egg, rolled in flour, and then sauteed in a light cream and mushroom sauce.  Delicious!

We also ordered the chicken for two with bread salad, and my friend, even though not being a fan of chicken, loved it.  (I know, it's weird that we ordered two dishes that we each could potentially hate.)  The chicken is perfectly seasoned and then roasted, served on greens mixed with bread and currants.  I don't know how they make the bread, but it's crispy and soft and soak up the juices from the chicken perfectly.   It takes an hour to prepare, so you'll have to sustain yourself with bread and appetizers in the meantime.  The next time I decide to get it, I'll just order it right away.

I can't wait to come back!  Our biggest problem will be whether we can branch out and try other stuff.
author: A L.

description: This was my second visit to Zuni for dinner. Seems that ever table is the best table in the house! Great food, amazing wine list, ambiance and great service make every visit perfect.
author: Kathleen B.

description:
so many late nights have been spent here and a place where i have had some really great things to eat. 

the chicken for two is probably in my opinion overrated...i have only had it once so maybe it was a off night but for all the rave it had i guess it just tasted like a darn good chicken and thats about it. 

their desserts aren't killer either but what does zuni have?

THE BEST BURGER. its my favorite in SF... (havent had fish and farm yet) if you get one thing here that should be it. i have ordered two before cuz its that good. 

great beer list. great vibe. kind service....

zuni is allllll good.
author: Mohammad G.

description: I'd give this place a 3.5. To be honest I don't have much to say about this place. The decor was ok, has the potential to be nice but I think the lighting is off. The food was decent, again, not memorable. Plus if you're going to come to the area you're better off going to Espetus next door. That said, it's a solid place to go for a good meal, but there are better places around.
author: Shreya C.

description: This place is perfect for date night or a night out with friends. The roasted chicken and bread salad is amazing. Just make sure you order it as soon as you get there because it takes an hour to prepare. I also tried the gnocchi which was very light and fluffy. Overall service and food were great!
author: Pamela N.

description: I had high expectations for this place. Especially because their chicken is rated #1 on the 7x7 magazine list of 100 things you must eat in San Francisco before you die. First of all, the acoustics in in the restaurant are really bad and it is very difficult to hear the people you are sitting with. I was not a fan of the caesar salad because there were small chunks of slimy sardines in the salad dressing. Normally sardines are well blended into the dressing you shouldn't be able to pick them out. We placed our order for the chicken as soon as we sat down because it takes an hour to cook. It was a good chicken but honestly, chicken is chicken. I was wondering what they would do to the chicken to make it so much better than the roasted chickens I buy at Whole Foods for $10.00. The answer? nothing. I wouldn't pay $50.00 for a chicken again. However, the bread salad they serve it with is amazing. The dressing is wonderfully tangy and parts of the bread retain crispiness. Definitely the highlight of the meal. I'm glad I tried it but don't think I would ever go back.
author: Darah P.

description: The food was good and well prepared, but a little too precious for my taste. I also thought it was overpriced for the overall experience. Our tab for two, including a $40 bottle of wine was $165. For that kind of money I expect flawless service. It took so long to get the main course after the apps that we were about walk out or grab the manager. The miserly portion of butter for the bread ran out quickly and wasn't replaced. By the time the main course did arrive we had nearly lost our appetites because we were so annoyed with the timing of kitchen. I should also add that this occurred at 9 pm, long after the dinner rush, so the delay was really inexcusable.  The Zuni was the most disappointing fine dining experience I've ever had.
author: mister m.

description: Hands down the BEST burger I have ever eaten!! I am craving it right now...the bad news is that this place is always packed and hard to get a reservation at. But, that is because it is sooo good. The caeser salad was great and so was the pizza.
author: Reena C.

description: Fun, cheerful restaurant. Tasty, fresh, mostly healthy dishes. We were there for lunch and it was a lovely experience.
author: REN S.

description: This chicken is sooooo overrated. It took an hour and I could have gotten the same quality (if not better) at a Chinese restaurant in about 20 minutes. The salads were good though. The place is nice. I assume their other dishes are better, but I definitely would not come here for the chicken.
author: Q C.

description:
One of our regular place .The food is always consistent . we started with oysters and champagne ..and then...Chicken for two .....why get anything else....
just a great place ....never disappointed
author: peter a.

description: I had a bad experience at this restaurant this past Sunday. I ordered the Salmon, and did not like the way it was done, so I returned it and asked to have the pork chop, which came dry. I took one bite and returned it immediately. I ordered nothing else. I don't know if it was because it was busy, but the worst part of the whole experience that has prompted me to write this review was the manager's unprofessional handling of the situation. He refused to allow the very nice waitress, Alexandra, to take the pork chop off of the bill. I have never encountered a situation where a manager tried to keep the item on the bill when we did not eat the meal. I did speak with the manager, Julian, about the food, and he was very rude. I will never return to a restaurant where the manager lacks so much customer service. To be fair, The Oysters we requested were delicious. My main problem was Julian, the manager. I think he needs some retraining on customer service.
author: Hugo M.

description: 2nd visit to this restaurant but 1st visit where I ordered the roasted chicken. We had great service. The oysters were really fresh and tasty. The Cesar salad was crisp and the dressing was very good. The chicken was fantastic. It was moist, seasoned to perfection and definitely the best chicken I have ever put in my mouth. I am not a chicken person normally but my date insisted and I was sooooo happy that he did. I can't recommend it higher!
author: Kris K.

description:
i'm a zuniphile, i don't care what you all say.  i've been going to zuni for years, and there's nothing i like better than to dine alfresco on a sunny day on crazy market street eating oysters, sipping champagne, and watching the people walk by...

now today, i varied from the usual and got a pizza and a glass of red while catching up w/ a high school friend i hadn't seen in 20 years.  it was an unusually warm sunny January day, around 3pm, and we sat at the very end outside table, by the alley, Yogi the Chihuahua in lap.  despite being heckled by homeless and potentially drugged out people; )  we had a pleasant catch-up session and got a chuckle out of the fact that the manager had to come shoo these folks away so we could eat and talk in peace (no dude, i ain't got no dime!).  but growing up in SF, i'm used to a little "salt w/ my pepper" so i think it added to our experience.  i especially got a laugh when one said homeless dude came up to me while my friend was in the bathroom and asked "did i mess up your girls' conversation?", and i said "yes, you did!" and he said, "GOOD!" and then stormed away like a defiant child.

so just so you aren't all scared off, they usually have a security guard who works during restaurant hours to do the shooing for you, but he had just taking off for the day, and his relief hadn't arrived yet.  AND if you sit inside, in the beautiful brick and wood interestingly laid out interior, you don't have to worry about it (you can safely watch out the huge floor to ceiling windows instead).

i love that it's also a few blocks from my home, and dogs are welcome there!
author: Suzanne A.

description: I had heard rumors. I had heard rumblings. And until last night, I never ever,' never ever ever?' believed that chicken could taste so good. But food lovers of this great world, let it be known that the creme de la creme of roasted chicken can be found at Zuni and it will ruin you for chicken dishes anywhere else, because yes, it is THAT GOOD!
author: Stephy S.

description: Zuni Cafe is truly one of my favorite restaurants in SF. Great food, fantastic service- I've literally never had a bad experience. This is my go-to spot to take anyone visiting from out of town because it never fails! The chicken is my favorite dish ever- I've literally never had that good of chicken anywhere else, ever. Must try!!!
author: Emily P.

description: Very tasty food!  Always fresh and with a focus on the organic.  The wood fire grilled pizzas are delicious.  The wine selection is great here too.  My favorite part is always the oyster and raw bar which also has an amazing selection.  The staff here are friendly and knowledgable, but the hosts are a little stand offish and have a wait at the bar attitude.  If you don't have a reservation you will be seated at the bar, or maybe outside.  Of course outside you will be asked for change from homeless people frequently.
author: Michael D.

description: This emperor has no clothes, people.  Unbelievably bitchy staff, jacked up prices, and...chicken, really?  Does any self-respecting chef put chicken as the jewel in her/his culinary crown?  Okay, well, I guess it keeps the easily fooled corralled.
author: Mokirobinson M.

description: Great spot.  They have a chicken dish that takes 45 min to make but its worth every minute to wait.
author: P T.

description: i love the little nooks and crannies in the upstairs dining area. guided by our host, it felt like a never ending maze. the service is impeccable. i accidentally dropped my knife on the floor and 3 seconds later i was given a new one. talk about attentiveness! of course we ordered the famous chicken for 2, and it did not disappoint...to a certain extent. the dish was indeed enough for 2 people, with leftovers. accompanied bread salad was uber yummy, drenched in butter with a little acidity. as far as the chicken itself, i felt it was lacking flavor. a notch above costco's rotisserie chicken, but not worth 1+ hour wait.
author: Melissa Y.

description: Very great experience! Got a fun/cool table in a nook/cranny in the corner of the downstairs dining room. As we heard from everybody, the chicken-for-two is the way to go. Amazing dish. Don't count on finishing it. It's not very heavy, but it is a large dish. You will learn that it takes a full hour to prepare - so be ready for a bit of a wait. The menu changes 4 times per day - so note the specifics of the dish before following someone else's recommendation. We got the rabbit to start - which was the highlight of my night. So ridiculously good. Then, we had a spinach gnocchi. We had read about this dish on yelp before. I'm not sure if it is the most commonly served gnocchi - but dang it was good.... Hit it and hit it hard! Great spot!
author: Patrick H.

description:
some of you may disagree, but i believe zuni cafe still has its mojo. the food is still very good here. i am especially fond of the famous and ever reliable zuni burger, even if it costs around $20 with cheese and fries. after all these years, it's still one of the best burgers in town. unfortunately, zuni only serves the burger during lunch hours or late at nights. hence i enjoy coming here alone on late nights. i would grab a table in the bar area and order the burger and just watch who's who in san francisco politics in action. no chris daly though. thank goodness... obviously, zuni cafe has more than a burger, it is also quite known for its chicken dishes although i admit i was less than thrilled when i tried it once a while ago. so i'll stick with my late night rendezvous with the zuni cafe burger.

the service, as always, is impeccable. the staff treats me like i am someone important when i'm just another guy off the street. i like that.
author: frisco j.

description: As good today as twenty years ago. Terrific food, great drinks and wine list, and spot on service. BRAVO!
author: Bill G.

description: It's dumb to charge so much money for a chicken.  I don't eat chicken, but my friends do and they aways order it here.  The other dishes are ok, but still totally overpriced.  It doesn't make any sense to me to spend so much on a meal that's just some chicken.  It's a chicken, that's all.  Please.  And the people are a little too snobby for me.  But that's just me.
author: Honey L.

description:
the prices were high, the portions were small and the food was good, but not great. the waitstaff acted like they were doing us a favor by serving us.

*note: Rymee's coppa and cabbage and the shoestring potatoes are a MUST
author: Valerie N.

description: There is a reason why this place is an establishment. It's just so great and always has been I've been going here for 12 years and am never disappointed. I can't wait for the next time I'm in town - the next time I get to have a bloody and cesar.
author: Jackie H.

description: I so don't love this place. Restaurant proprietors take heed: don't piss off a customer b/c they don't have to go back in a city with this many choices! They've stayed in business this long, so they are making enough people happy, but I was deeply turned off by the fact that I ordered oysters and they wouldn't serve me horseradish with them. The oysters came with some panty-waste champagne vinaigarette, which I quickly put to the side and (nicely) asked for some proper horseradish. The server very snidley said they didn't have any. "Hmm, it looks like you serve bloody marys. You don't have horseradish for the bloody marys that you might be able to give me a little of for my oysters?" The answer was no. So I sulkily sucked down my tasteless barnacles and have never been back.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
The chicken is good but it's $48 and the waiters are too well-dressed. 2.5 stars!

OK, hold on, let's break down this bird. I've roasted a chicken according to the Zuni method before, and that was up with the best chook I've ever had, the white meat quite a bit better than my mother's roast chicken, thanks to the presalting; the dark meat not quite as good, thanks to oversalting. The same applied to the bird I had at Zuni, except more so. The white meat was more moist and flavorful than what I cooked, with the blast of thyme under the breast skin the highlight. The dark meat was also tastier than mine but with a weird almost seafood-like texture I was startled by. The skin was slam dunk better, thanks to the flavour imparted by the wood oven (an unfair advantage if ever there was one). I don't place a high emphasis on the bread salad, but theirs was about as tasty as mine without as much greasiness. In sum, easily the best chicken I've had that wasn't cooked by a member of my nuclear family; maybe the best of all even with nepotism working against it.

So if you're budget-restricted and you can't tell whether the Zuni chicken is worth your cash, try cooking it yourself -- the recipe is easily Googleable. If you don't think it's a significant improvement over the chicken you're used to, then save your forty-eight bucks. But if you think it's near the chicken epitome, you need to try the real thing.

(Oh yeah, other food. Caesar salad and green salad excellent but not as good as I've had at Pizzaiolo and Chez Panisse Cafe respectively, though to be fair, it's tougher to get good lettuce in January. Pear tart and ice cream for dessert good but not transcendent. One of the five best restaurant meals I've had in the last twelve months.)
author: Brad L.

description: It's a 3.5, but it's colder that a witch's boobs in a brass bra as I write this, so I'm rounding down.  I've only done lunch here.  The food was decent, the service was decent, but I felt kinda like a sardine.  The tables were too close together for my comfort.  I've been here for business lunches, and our conversation was limited because it was clear that others would overhear what we were saying.  However, if this was in a smaller city with less competition, it would be a 4.5, but this is SF, and competition is fierce baby!
author: Nikki c.

description:
5/6/07 update*****


This place really blows.  Came here for an impromptu weekend lunch, and the experience was so horrid that I would never return.  Although the prior experience was very memorable, but mostly because the pack of businessmen that took us there.  To start off the meal, we ordered mint juleps in honor of the Kentucky Derby that we being held that day.  Took our server a long time to bring them and then it seemed like an afterthought to check to see if we wanted food.  We each ordered a starter salad and then a pizza to follow.  Several minutes elapsed and several other diners were seated around us.  Noticeably a cute daddy who had his car valeted out front.  Yes, the server was busy...and we weren't in a terrible hurry...  However I was slightly pissed when I saw taht the cute daddy and son were finishing off a wood fired pizza when we hadn't even been brought our salads.    I was boiling when I noticed that they were being served their 2nd course when we still didn't have our salads and brought it to everyones attention.  Obviously, they skipped placing our order, but no apologies followed and the salads were served to us.  When my friend dug into her salad, she noticed a BLACK HAIR nestled among the lettuce leaves.  She pointed it out to me and I dropped my fork.  We tried to discreetly point it out to the server, and he demanded to see it close up.  As if we would make up such a gross thing!  What an ass!  I mean if I was charging $13 for a lousy burger, I would show a little more class.  Did the server really want us advertising to the other tables that my friend found a hair in our salad?  I mean we were trying to be discreet so that we didn't disturb the other diners.  I was already grossed out.   Of course at this point we were both thoroughy pissed and ready to venture somewhere else.    The assholes (manager included) didn't even have the courtesy to apologize, but they were gracious enough not to charge us for our drinks.  How big of them.  Like I said I will never return.
author: Amy Z.

description: i went here with a group of co workers.  i tried a couple entrees, but ordered the halibut for myself which was excellent!  they have a great rose, Borcal, which was a decent price point and we ordered a few bottles.  also, very good oysters and a neat layout to the restaurant
author: Joel F.

description: This  place is one my favorite restaurants to go to in SF.  The oven roasted chicken takes one hour but it is worth it!!
author: Jane K.

description: One of the traditional hangout spots in San Francisco. Even though I don't eat oysters, I've been told that they sell some of the freshest in San Francisco. Nice bar where you will probably get at least two drinks before you get to your table. The food will be always irremediably good, although quite limited in vegetarian options.
author: Ato B.

description: Maybe it was a matter of hearing too much hype for too many years, but when I finally made it here, I was underwhelmed by the experience. A very attractive space, although the atrium-like architecture creates a loud echo-chamber effect when the place is crowded, as I hear it usually is. Lots of pretty people in Pucci and Gucci posing at the bar, their Fendi bags artfully placed so there was no mistaking their heritage. Everyone swore I couldn't go wrong by ordering the chicken for two, but in the end, it was nothing more than a highly overpriced chicken that was tasty but really not worth the wait. I actually enjoyed the Caesar salad preceding it far more. Service was indifferent, possibly because we didn't order cocktails, appetizers, or wine. Considering we left hungry, it was a disappointing and expensive meal, and not one I would consider repeating in the near or distant future.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
That one star is only because I actually enjoy some of the food. There are not that many places in SF that I hate, this is one of them. This is one of those few places that i veto when someone suggests to go to. One of the few that I tell my friends not to go to just just based on principles. I find these guys soo arrogant, more than any restaurant in the city and I can't figure out why. Before, they used to just be rude and obnoxious if you sat down and everyone at the table was not eating. I mean, perhaps if it is 11:30 pm, some people at the table may only want dessert or drinks cause they have likely eaten.
