And I would understand if you had to hold those tables because you are busy, BUT THE RESTAURANT WAS 90% EMPTY.
Well, the last time I went (and it will be the last time period), they refused to seat us at a table unless everyone in our party was eating. It is past 11 pm, there are so many tables open, and we had to make do with these tiny little tables in the corner by the bar, and we barely got those. And then the food. No plates, obvi. that is too much to ask for and our red wine was freezing. Literally, may be my number one choice for worse restaurant in the city.
Try walking in and ordering anything less than a full meal past 10 pm and see what happens. If I can walk into La Folie or Aqua, sit at the bar or a table and order drinks and dessert and a few apps and they still serve me with the same graciousness that one would expect from a good restaurant, I don't know why anyone would put up with the people at Zuni.
author: shadi m.

description: One of the more expensive + less satisfying meals I've had at Zuni.  I wish it's more of a wine bar since they do carry an impressive list of selection.  The portion's small, and very light.  For the same price, I'd recommend Bar Tartine. (maybe my taste palettes are more french than Mediterranean.)  But service is great, and usually you can always get a table at the bar area.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
Good food, not-bad prices, more upscale than Home.  I'd been to Zuni once a fair number of years ago, and recalled it being good but more expensive than I could afford.  'Course I was a low-wage sales clerk back then and a meal at Zuni's was the equivalent of 30-50 cup-o-noodles in my eyes.
Now I'm a less-low-wage Accounts Payable Clerk and stopped eating rehydrated carbs (well, except the lazy occasion) I can see Zuni for it's value - consistently good quality w/par price.  $22 for huge grilled pork chop + veggies + polenta sides? Yah. Halibut tartare w/avo & crostini $9? Worth every tasty morsel. $14 for fresh fettucine & portobello slices & parmesan shreds? MMM. Drinks were somewhat overpriced though - $8.50 for a margarita in a martini glass? Phhtthth.
It's a beautiful restaurant but methinks sound ricochets off all the glass - I could barely hear my cousin & dining companion speak, and the waitress was a bit spacey - she brought us two different menus.  Apparently one was from LAST week err something - at least we now know they change things up a bit from time to time.
Zuni will work for you for most any night.  But it hasn't changed much in the last 7yrs, and it probably won't in the next 7. Don't feel any need to get your panties in a knot to try it.
author: CINDY K.

description:
Loved this place.  The vibe is busy, hip, bright and airy and the restaurant is an odd shaped triangle, someone was creative enough to take an oddly shaped space and make it work into this multi level restaurant known for it's roasted $41 chicken, and fabulous hamburgers.  The service also was very good. 

It was Easter Sunday, and amazingly at 11am we were able to get a table for 3 without a wait.  This is not to say the restaurant was empty, it was far from that, every table was filled.  But we came right at the perfect time when a party of 4 was leaving.............

So because we didn't want to wait an hour for the chicken, Brian and I  were starving and hungover, and my dad had to get back to work as it is tax season..........we all ordered a selection of about 12 oysters on the half shell, 2 orders of fries (piled mountain high) and  hamburgers.  

The oysters were delicious, yummy and fresh.  The french fries were amazing, super skinny, and the perfect amount of salt.  We ate the first plate of fries so fast, that we had to order the second plate for our burgers.  And then, the hamburgers:  AAH, they were divine. The basic hamburger comes on foccacia bread with lettuce and an aoili.  There is then a list of extras you can add, which in our case we did.  We  garnished our patties with Gorgonzola cheese and mushrooms.  But in reality, the cheese diminished the taste of the burger as it was super super strong.  The mushroom was good though.  Oh but the burger itself was amazing!  Juicy, melt in your mouth........something about that meat just put it in a different ranking from all other burgers in San Francisco--I think because it was from Niman Ranch and probably perfectly seasoned!  It was the best burger I've had in a long time, and for sure in San Francisco.   (San Diego is a different story.) 

I am definitely coming back to try that chicken one day when I'm not hungover and tired.   Oh but one thing to know about this place: they charge drinks by the glass- there are no free refills.  3 Cokes were $10!........and that didn't include my iced tea, or my father's wine.
author: Denise B.

description: The menu doesn't change much here -- Judy Rogers has been cooking the same Cal-Med, ingredient-driven food for years -- but I think that's why I love Zuni so much.  Everything is well executed, whether its the freshly ground burger on herb foccacia (off the late night menu) or the roast chicken over bread salad (worth the one hour wait... its Zuni's signature dish for a reason).  Zuni is also a GREAT spot for brunch.  For my money, the best Bloody Mary in SF.
author: Andrew E.

description:
I have been a long time fan of Zuni, I've been three times in the past two months, and the experience has been the same, they are living off the name....I will not be back....

1.  Place looks the same and still has a great feel to it, you want to eat there, drink good wine and so on....

2.  Service, possibly an off night, but three times with three different wait staff that from just reading the menus I knew more about the food and wine than they did.  Leave the attitude at the door and it's o.k. to say, I don't know, let me find out for you.
3.  Menu/Food, this is the end of summer, menu's should be exploding with possibilities, flat, boring, often struggled to find something to order.  Food was under seasoned all three times, Squab was a touch past medium rare, closer to rare but that was one breast, the other was medium, leave one in the pan, this should never happen... Lamb, Steak, all flat, tasteless and the fish, is it possible to have it in one piece instead of four pieces on one plate!  
4.  Price, well, for the above to have a price like it does, sadly I will not return.  As for my client who demanded we go there, he wrote an email to me apologizing for their short comings....positive note, he's taking me to Gary D's in a month to make up for this meal that was anything but what one would expect...
5.  Take a note from Ms. Keller at COCO's, revamp, adjust and explode back into the scene, Zuni's is so far out of the game, it's sad....

Judy, get back in your kitchen, stop writing books......
author: Skip L.

description:
hmm....what can i say about zuni cafe that has not already been said in the course of  242 reviews?...

on any given evening, if you sit near the windows facing market street, you are in primo seating to view the odds and ends of san francisco culture stumble/ swagger/ stroll by.

friday night, we witnessed the aftermath of st. patricks day celebrants gone wild.  one girl practically tumbling out of a taxi (likely, kicked out) followed by 3 bewildered friends.  they stumbled around supporting her in a group hug reminiscent of interprative dance.  some creative projectile puking occurs.  friends one and two hug and kiss her goodbye shortly after (ewww was our reaction).  lone girlfriend, torn paper barfbag in hand, surrenders allowing drunk girl to rest leaning against a light pole on the pavement floor.

zuni staff quietly closes adjacent window.  by dessert the girls have dissappeared.

-meat trio which included ribs and beef tongue, and something that looked to me like sausage/ fancy spam was delicious, albeit portion was rather small for $33.
-lemon ricotta gnocchi was smooth with lovely texture
-shoestring french fries a no brainer.

i'll definitely be back to try the roast chicken (it was too late for the 1 hour required wait.)
author: Josie M.

description: Went there for the first time last night.  Tuesday night, and the place was packed!  Fortunately, they have a good number of tables in the bar area, where they serve the full menu.  We sat out at the "point" surrounded by windows.   The roast chicken for two was superb.  The Caesar salad was huge and delicious.   My only issues were that the prices were a little high in my opinion and my martini was small and had pitted olives speared with a cheap wooden toothpick.  But then again, I had two, so who am I to complain?  A great night out, and I'm sure I will be back again soon.
author: Bob H.

description:
this was my second time back at zuni, and it was..... ok.   we had a gift certificate and weren't spending our own money, but even so, the ups and downs pretty much averaged out to a 3-star meal.  

the good:  the hostess was super nice and accommodating
the bad:   we had to wait 15 minutes for our table
the ugly:  after our wait, they tried to seat us at the exact same horrible table as last time (right across from the waiter station where they refill the bread baskets. why are they determined to seat me here?)

the good:  the wine was delicious 
the bad:  the bartender asked us to pay the bar bill at the bar instead of transferring it to the table
the ugly:  after we explained we had a gift certificate and would prefer to transfer the bill (making us feel like a couple of cheapskates), he said, "yeah, i'd *really* rather you guys pay me here. i'm really busy and i might forget to add the bill to your table." (insert rolling of bartender eyes in my direction. grrr.)

the good:  the apps were great:  the Caesar salad was delicious as were blood oranges with creme fraiche and honey
the bad:   the waiter forgot what we'd ordered and had to come back to clarify
the ugly:   our entrees came out stone cold.  i am pretty sure halibut is supposed to be at least lukewarm.  ditto for lamb.

the good: due to freezing cold entrees, our waiter graciously comped our desserts (a gateau and a delicious espresso granite) AND was nice enough to stick a candle in it for hubby's bday.

i'll leave on a high note and stop here.  let's just say while i enjoyed dinner, i won't be going back on my own dime anytime soon.
author: Eryn K.

description: My classmates and I ended up here one night after class. I wasn't that hungry so I ended up ordering one of their smaller plates. I ordered the Gnocchi and it was delicious! That was the first time that I had tried Gnocchi and have been hooked ever since!
author: Diane M.

description: Order your chicken when you make your reservation.   Yup, the chicken is  that good.   I don't know why it took me so long to make it out here, but I wasn't disappointed at all after all the hype I was told of this place.  The place is a little on the pricey side, although it was well worth every penny.
author: Jason A.

description: Why do we come to Zuni? I come for the shoe string potato fries. That is all you need to know. Dishes may come and dishes may go, but yes, I come for the crispy crunchy light as air shoe string fries. Delicieax. Ahh, and that zupa isn't so bad either.
author: Aleyna S.

description:
I was so not impressed with Zuni. I went with a friend on what I consider to be  a perfect date..... oysters and bloody marys. I was sooo  looking forward to it all week! Anyways we decided to go early "happy hour", so ordering from the dinner menu was not on our agenda. We ordered 2 dozen mixed oysters ..some I have heard of and tried before and some new..we let the waiter choose for us..he was extremely nice and gave us great service but as we were there his shift was ending and our new waiter took over..he wasn't nearly as friendly and made some rude comment to my friend in his french accent! As the dinner crowd rolled in I started to feel really out of place in this restaurant and just wanted out of there..I felt like I should have had my "daddy" there to make me legit.    Anyways.... back to the oysters, out of the 24 that we got 8 of them were good! some were to "earthy" tasting for me.    Usually when I have oysters I want to scream(in my head of course) in pleasure after each one but this was not the case here! what a dissapointment.  Oh and we also ordered the ceasar salad which was dripping in anchovies WAY too much with the dressing it just tasted like I was eating mushy anchovies, we both couldn't even get it down. The bloody marys were okay so many places in the city that make better ones. 
so here is the break down of the stars  Its actually a 21/2 star review but as we all know we can't do half stars on the roll over
1 for our first waiter
1/2 for the 8 oysters we did like
1 star for the big windows ..its fun to people watch on market street.
author: kelly p.

description: Good food and wine and nice atmosphere, but meh. I wasn't impressed. With all the rave reviews, I wanted to be WOW'd. But I wasn't. Probably because I'm not the demographic (socially or monetarily) for this cafe. So give me 10 more years and $25,000 more a year, and I'll eat here again.
author: Viv C.

description: Zuni has been a favorite of mine for years.  Sure, the chicken is phenomenal, and they make one hell of a burger, but my God, the fruits de mer almost made me cry.  I haven't enjoyed a raw platter this side of the Atlantic since a visit to Balthazar years ago.
author: Vanessa C.

description: Fantastic food, service and ambiance...not usually something you can find in ONE restaurant. Went here for a birthday lunch and was delighted by the chefs ability to select and serve some unique foods which aren't typically found on a menu. Will certainly dine here again!
author: Dahlia S.

description: Great spot, verging on sketchy location if walking along Market street from downtown. Food was good, although found brunch menu limiting. Burger was juicy, but with extra costs for cheese and shoestring fries, was $23! Yikes.
author: Katherine V.

description: The chicken, the caesar salad, the brunch on Sundays and the oysters will rock your world and your palate, and change you forever.
author: Julie H.

description: Service is so crummy we walked out.  There are so many restaurants in the city with really great food, why would anyone settle for crappy service?
author: Lola Z.

description:
Came here for brunch and the bloodies here were completely unique (and $9.50..hmm), i cant recall the name specifically, but something involving vinagrette, and had a lot of relish (minced red onions; even more than usual in mine since i wanted extra spicy and not via tabasco)...they didnt taste like any bloodies ive ever had (my boyfriend described it as tasting like a blended up salad--which was somewhat true), and i was literally stuffed after 2 of them, but still highly recommended! 

the place itself was adorable, very open, bright and loftish, and i had wanted to come here after driving by and thinking it looked cute, and totally glad we came! With a party of 6 we got a nice upstairs table near the window, our service was good (4 of our party were running late and they didnt seem to mind; that said, they charged $120 to save the reservation...), and other than the 4% health surcharge zuni (and random restaurants it seems at this point..i'm sure theyll all implement it eventually) charges, i cant say i have many complaints!
the food looked fairly overpriced (at least the burgers, which had upcharges for most garnishes, ending up to around $25 per burger depending on what you put on it,), and my boyfriend wasnt a fan of the caesar salad (due to the fact that he had to cut it up himself/lazy, although it was $10, so for a basic caesar my expectations would also be high), but the shoestring fries ($6) are apparently amazing.  I'd say you're really paying more for the ambiance than for the food, although I will say that for $9.50, I feel like I had a meal in each bloody! 

also, they have valet, but parking was pretty easy in the area (although metered), so i'd skip that and park yourself behind zuni! They appear to stay open pretty late, and as their cocktail list included lemon drops, margaritas, and an elderflower cocktail, I hope to come back and try something else!
author: Danielle J.

description:
Zuni is one of the most popular restaurants in the city and one of my personal favorites, which is why I chose to have one of my 30th birthday celebrations there (it pays to have different groups of friends).   

Food:  4 stars.   I like to come here for the roast chicken - it's the best chicken I've ever had - it's juicy, tender and infused with flavor - well worth the one hour preparation time.  The dish is actually prepared for two people, which had me worried because I went with four other people who were somewhat opposed to the dish:  two of my friends are seafood-vegetarians, one friend is allergic to gluten (the chicken comes with a Tuscan-style bread salad) and another friend gave meat up for lent (how selfish of her).  I finally convinced the gluten friend to do the chicken with me, only because the restaurant accommodated us by putting the bread salad on the side.  The majority of the appetizers and entrees we had were excellent:  the crisp Zuni Caesar salad, vegetable soup, beautiful bite-sized seared scallops, sea bream in a delicious broth with shellfish, and scrumptious "blue nose" bass.  The only dish I was not fond of was the risotto, which seemed undercooked, bland and runny.  For dessert, we had the espresso granita, chocolate pot de crme, and chocolate cake.  All were slightly above average.

Service:  4 stars.  This place could easily be pretentious, but fortunately the staff is not.  Our server seemed friendly and down-to-earth, although he did not appear amused by the gag gift that my friends had brought with them, which we placed on the table.  Otherwise, service was smooth and consistent throughout the night.  The front of the house was also accommodating, especially when one of my really good friends notified me at the last minute to add another person to the table AND made us late for our reservation.  

Atmosphere:  5 stars.  The restaurant's design is fascinating.  Tables are nipped and tucked in various spaces throughout.  There is a maze of rooms on the second floor, with the prime dining spots overlooking the bustling activity in the standing-room only bar or the beautiful main dining area.  The kitchen is also open for all to see.   The single-use restrooms are mislabeled "Men" and "Women."  The patrons (both sexes) don't seem to care what's on the door.  The crowd, although an eclectic mix, is generally beautiful and decked out in their most stylish attire.  

Hits:  Roast chicken for two, Zuni Caesar salad, blue nose bass.

Misses:  Risotto, desserts could be better.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Nopa, Range, Myth, Spruce, Town Hall
author: Keith C.

description: This is a classic SF place.  I have never had a bad meal or service here, so I can't speak for the others' bad experiences, just my own.  THE best chicken - I hadn't ordered it, but when I smelled it going by, I changed my order right away.  Highly recommended.
author: Greg R.

description: Zuni feels like a place I should love.  Stars-like in feel (or Chez Panisse-y) (I've fallen to new lows with the adjectives here), it is pleasant and open-style American.  But I can't get into it.  Even its much-yelped-about burger was pedestrian last time I had it.  A French friend had a bbq and made the burgers from the Zuni cookbook, and THEY were fantastic.  But mine was not made with love.  I'm all about the love.  A certain group of my friends go here all the time for drinks and a nosh (which has something to do with a cute bartender or waiter that someone has his eyes on), but I like it best when I stick to the drinks.  I've always tended toward the lower Haight in my sensibilities, later transferred to the Mission and Dogpatch, with an occasional fancy jaunt, so maybe I'm not to be trusted.
author: Laurel B.

description: After years of hearing about this place finally made my way in on a Tuesday lunch (today) along with my honey, looking forward to a satisfying lunch experience and boy was I disappointed. Here are the pluses: Beautiful restaurant with tons of windows and great people watching! Nice staff. But here are the misses: My hamburger was ordinary at best. No exciting accompaniments, when I asked for a slice of tomato the waitress told me they don't have any! So I went on with eating my bland burger. The side of fries had way too much salt. The water glass was filled with Luke warm water and all the subsequent refills were filled with more warm water. And to top it off, our OK desert was followed by a lousy cappuccino. What's up with that Zuni???
author: r t.

description: Apparently this is a well-known spot. I had an excellent late night dinner in the bar area. The service was excellent as was the roast pork, and the dessert - thin meringue-like discs with creme freche and pomegranate was light and just sweet enough.
author: Chris B.

description:
What a place for food, wine, and good company. I absolutely love the layout and the views which make this place truly feel like an SF institution...that and that the fact it's been open for 30 years. The old-school long wooden bar, the brick oven, a little oyster bar in the corner, the open kitchen - all while hiking and up and down stairs to find your table nestled in a cozy room. 
We started out with a variety of Washington and local oysters - all were amazingly sweet and delicious. (usually when you get a variety, there's always that big, briney, salty guy that ruins your palate) We then had the roast chicken and bread salad, per the 7x7 list of items to get in SF - and yes, it is simply wonderful - with an emphasis on the simply. (a mild, delicate taste - so don't expect a circus in your mouth, it's elegant.) We also had the pepper-covered rare beef and sweet potatoes - very good down to the last drop. And a polenta with marscapone, which was wonderful to have as well. 
Dessert topped it off perfectly - some amazing grappa, a creme fraiche panna cotta - a perfect giggly custard, and the straciatella ice cream made with what looked like milk chocolate shavings. 
To boot, the wine was amazing too.
So, why the 4 stars? It sounds pretty close to a perfect place, doesn't it? 
Well, the service was a bit harried. Our server was running around and it took him a while to get to our table so we could order. And when all you can think about it getting in that chicken order, they need to make sure they snap to it. Finally, should anyone really have to miss 13 minutes of dinner because there was a line for the bathroom? No. Please get another lou in there. This is not a night club.

Advice to future patrons - before the server even offers you water, put that chicken order in. Also, use the toilet before you're seated...or at least a good amount of time before the chicken comes out. Finally, savor the food  it is after all, delicious.
author: Erin M.

description:
aside from all the other yelper accolades, i want to also add that i chose zuni as the place i treated my family to with the very first paycheck i earned as a 15.5 year old (with a worker's permit, of course). 

of course, nothing was left over from that paycheck. yup, used it up completely. but, damn-- it was well worth it.

that meal sparked my own interest in cooking and creating. a journey from obsession to art form . since then, this place remains a solid choice for san francisco's truer signature bistro eating.
author: Vanessa D.

description:
This place is solid. Good ambiance, nice service, perfect roasted chicken, and awesome fries.
But 48$$$ for a chicken? That's ridiculously expansive. (Don't get me wrong. I am willing to spend 300+ for a meal.) Go to Costco, folks. You can get almost perfect roasted chicken for only $4.99.
author: Richard L.

description: On a recent weekend spent in the City I was fortunate enough to get to try Zuni. Of course I made reservations too. So, I have read here about three things to try here. The burger, the fries, and the chicken. So, we ordered all three!! No complaints about any of it. The fries were crispy and not greasy. The burger was fantastic. It melted in your mouth. The chicken for two over the bread salad was very good and well worth the wait. For those snobs who complain about a place having chicken as their specialty.....stop and eat, and quit being snobby. The bread salad was delicious with toasted pieces of bread that weren't soggy at all. The chicken was worth the wait. The service was prompt and our server was a delight. I don't understand why people can't enjoy a meal sometimes. As for Zuni Cafe two thumbs up.
author: Johnny J.

description:
so this was the last sf restaurant on my visit to the bay area. i  originally had reservations at canteen, but chef roy whom i worked with gave me a call and told me he got me reservations at zuni cafe. so i meet "ren" the floor manager and tell him i'm chef roy's friend. he whisks me off to a table, which happens to be the best seat in the whole restaurant. it overlooks the open kitchen and has a nice view of market st as well. to start, we have  the complimentary asparagus appetizer which was amazing. simple, clean, and o so good. a simple vinegarette, with chopped egg, and toasted breadcrumbs is all you need with the asparagus. i start seeing the difference between la and san francisco food philosophy as i dined here at zuni. the next course was the caesar salad as recommended by "ren" and our waiter. no doubt its the best caesar i have ever had. i can taste everything in the dressing (anchovy, lemon, cheese, pepper, olive oil, garlic, egg yolk). as i mentioned earlier, so simple but so good. had some oysters and realized that i'm all about the west coast oysters. the east coast oysters taste like crap. too salty for my taste. the pacific ocean is the  perfect place to grow oysters. and then the famous roast chicken for two. i went into the kitchen and dylan (the poultry cook) showed me how he works their wood fired oven. as i bit into the juicy bird i gave dylan a thumbs up for his job well done. he gave me a big smile and continued to quarter countless number of birds for the rest of the night. finished off our meal with a espresso granita. this was my last meal of my trip to sf and it was definitely a great way to end.




i learned one thing on this trip to sf: simple = better
author: Daniel K.

description:
oh my god... this is such a good place it reminds me of europe...
interior consist of exposed-brick walls and a coppertop bar... and there's an open kitchen with an old-fashioned brick oven as well.

tables are tightly packed... i mean, really.. you will sit elbow to elbow with your fellow diners... but i like this kind of vibe... and you will forget everything once you taste the food!

they serve sour dough bread... its heavenly! i tried the ricotta gnocchi for my appetizer.. um... just not expecting the ricotta is in the gnocchi.. that is kind of.. surprising...

then my burger came...in a focaccia bun? very 'gourmet'! haha... but... i'm not disappointed.. perfectly medium-well done just like i ordered.. meat was coarsely grounded you can feel the texture... comes with marinated onions as well... very delicious! 

overall i was not disappointed... kudos for the very attentive service for the busy night!
author: Ken L.

description: This place reminded me a little of Chez Panisse because of the really fresh ingredients.  Elderberry/champagne cocktail - couldn't get enough!, Potato/Leek/Corn soup - yum!, Roast Chicken - worth the wait!, Blackberry sorbet - perfectly light and not too sweet!  I'll definitely come back, especially to try the brunch.
author: Julie D.

description: Without a doubt my favorite restaurant in the Bay Area.   The chicken is phenomenal!   The Oyster service is among the best around.  Staff is great.   I can't find a single thing to complain about, except maybe that's it's hard to get a table sometimes.   But that's expected with such a good restaurant.
author: Raj M.

description: Zuni was an overall nice dining experience. Brunch on Easter Sunday was full of reservations, but it was easy to walk-in and eat the same menu in the bar area. The service was honest and attentive. Scrambled eggs with fennel sausage and salad was simple and pleasing. My partner loved the burger. The ingredients tasted fresh, organic and delicious without too much fussing over them. Drinks, coffee, and dessert were all very tasty. can't wait to go for dinner!
author: Mary P.

description:
Wow!!!!!

Made a reservation for lunch, got there 5 minutes late because of the big storm. Trees down etc.
MD said "it will be 5 minutes" great no problem . Well 30 minutes later we still did not have a table. I suggested to go upstairs where dinners were. "No , we are closing that station" but it will only be another 5 minutes he said. Now its 2:30 pm and I said "just as long as you are still open for lunch. "no problem" well we finally decided to sit in the bar where a friendly waitress helped us and handed us a menu. We would like to order lunch please , Waitress " I am sorry we only have the bar menu as of 2:30 pm.    You can see where this is going.

During our partial lunch we had to witness the training of a new employee. This lasted for 20 minutes in front of us. All 4 of us where impressed at the attention to this new applicant received. If only we could have had the same attention was our comment.
Our Pizza was totally burned underneath, the waitress took it off the bill. We ordered to burgers from the menu, kind of reminded me of the silver dollar size in the 50s but with fancy paper thin garnish. ($13) three bytes size.Our french Fries showed up after we all had finished eating. We were so hungry that we all attacked the pommes allumette in no time ($6) for a shredded potato.

Bla bla bla     we will never go back.
We have owned many restaurants and still have 3 now with a staff of 180 employees 
The Zuni staff is well trained and informed about employee policy and yet have bimbos at the front door who don't have a clue!. We had two of the best.

I have never taken time to write a review in my life but this had to be done.
author: walter g.

description:
as suggested by many yelpers, we ordered the roasted chicken with bread pudding as soon as we sat down.  we were prepared to wait an hour, and were gratefully surprised when it arrived in about 40 minutes.  funny how that works---in almost any other circumstance if you had to wait 40 minutes for your entree you'd flip out!

anyway, the chicken was very good.  i would not say it was "divine" or "THE BEST" roasted chicken i have ever had in my life, but, if someone has/had never before had a good roasted chicken, then i can completely see how that might be one's opinion and they wouldn't find it wrong (at some level) to pay $48 for it.

i'd say that it is as good as my mother in law's roasted chicken, an amazing midwesteren housewife-food channel-watching, Julia Child's-loving and Ina Garten-cookbook-reading-kinda-woman.

**the atmosphere and service were excellent, a solid four stars**
author: TC C.

description: For years I never thought much of Zuni, big plates and good food, but nothing pushing it over the edge.  Then I realised that I found myself going back there again and again.  Granted the food is good but the staff and service are top notch.
author: Dean F.

description: I was really hoping to love my zuni experience on Friday night but I thought it was just okay. Good service, which is always important, but my dinner was so-so.  It was the grouper and it was truly unremarkable and in fact, really not that good.  The desserts were amazing and to die for and our appetizers were good.
author: Cynthia K.

description: I don't know if it is fair for me to review this place I haven't eaten here in a couple years, well I had brunch a few months back, but you can't judge a place on brunch. When I used to go to Zuni the food was pretty amazing it was simple and clean, Judy Rogers is an amazing chef, maybe a little crazy but an amazing chef and person, with the menu changing daily it's hard to comment on one thing, but the ricotta gnocchi, the first time I had that I thought I had died and gone to heaven, little cheese dumplings, mmmm so good. and the roasted chicken for two is well worth the wait, and they always have an amazing selection at the raw bar, and the bloodymary's don't even get me started, I really need to go eat there soon.
author: JIll H.

description: Great place for out of towners who want to classic Cal cuisine, but do not want to make the drive over to Chez Panisse .  Zuni has been a trendy spot for over 20 years and that certainly an easy thing to do in this city.  The roast chicken is "all that and bag of chips" and is worthy of the hype.  The pasta always seems light and fresh with a hint of some exotic flavor that you just cannot quite hit.  Excellent bar that pours some of the best drinks in town.  Zuni is one of those rare spots where you can just simply be entertained by people watching while having some of the best food that is creative in it's design.
author: Anne J.

description: Everyone says the service here is bad but I never really experienced that here.  If you don't fall completely head over heels in love with their caesar salad and roast chicken for 2 then I don't know what to tell you.  This place is a SF institution for a reason and it will always be one of my favorite places to eat in the city.
author: Emily C.

description: We just happened upon Zuni on Saturday afternoon while strolling down Market St.  We were hungry, it looked good, so we stopped in.  The thought of $48 for a chicken that would take an hour to prepare didn't appeal to us, so we opted for other entree's.  The Fideus (noodles) and Aioli with clams and shrimp were unbelieveably delicious!  My fiance' had a beautiful piece of salmon that was perfectly prepared.  Two entree's, two Mimosa's and two glasses of wine = $85 but worth it.  Service was stellar and we went on our way happy and content with our new find.
author: D A.

description:
If you haven't been to the Zuni Cafe recently save your money.  It takes 1 hour to roast your chicken for 48 dollars for a mandatory two persons.
It actually takes closer to 80 minutes.  Why don't they offer you the chicken while they make you wait for your table, which in my experience takes 20 minutes at least.  I had dinner there 1/2/09 and I have eaten here 4 times.  I asked the waiter if I could get a burger and he said I would have to wait until 10pm.  It was already 9:30pm, couldn't he just ask the cooks if they could throw a burger on the range for me?  I expect more from any restaurant.
author: don p.

description: I had dinner on Friday October 26th. My party and I arrived around 9;30 and was sat a table on the second level facing the side street. Around the time that our entrees arrives I  glanced out the window and saw several rats darting back and forth between the restaurant and a construction site across the street. When I mentioned this to the manager, his reply was " we are aware of the problem and it's been like that since they started building" I was shocked. So he sat me a table knowing that I wouldn't miss the rat show across the street?.No apologies nothing.
author: adam m.

description:
I am kicking myself for not reading Yelp before going to Zuni for the first time and finding out about the roast chicken goodness and Caesar salad that we'll now have to go back and try. I've been told the hamburger for lunch is also to die for. But that doesn't mean that everything else we had wasn't wonderful. Zuni definitely deserves its place on the SF Chronicle's Top 100 list.

I loved the open-air atmosphere. Our table was on a landing that overlooked the kitchen, and we could watch the staff shucking oysters and taking roast chickens out of the oven. Fun!

We needed some help picking our selection of oysters and our wine, and our waiter made great, affordable recommendations. It's definitely worth starting with a plate of fresh oysters!

The food was all-around excellent, and the portions are a little bit on the smaller side (to me, that's actually a good thing, because you don't walk out of there feeling overly stuffed). After the oysters I had an orange salad with a pomegranate salsa which was wonderfully light, sweet and tasty. I snagged a taste of the squab on bruschetta appetizer, which was also very tasty. My main course was the New York strip steak. I am not a huge steak eater, but I was really pleased with the paper-thin cuts and that it was cooked rare/medium-rare, so it just melted in your mouth and didn't feel like a brick in your belly. Other members of our party all remarked that their main course dishes were equally good - one had the sea bass and another had the other chicken dish (wrapped in smoked bacon). For dessert I had a lemon semifreddo layered with orange sponge cake surrounded by a huckleberry sauce which was also very tasty. I snagged a bite of my boyfriend's apple tart which was equally good. 

The service was excellent; I always find the sign of a good restaurant to be when your water glass keeps getting filled to the top and you don't even realize they're doing it.

The only drawbacks I would say are that they only have single-occupancy restrooms, which generally means a line for the bathroom. And the number of entrees to select from on the menu is on the smaller side. I realize that follows a more European theme, but I think it can be a bit harder to find the entree that speaks to you. There were only five or six to choose from.

There seems to be a theme among some reviews that Zuni is pretentious or has lousy service, but I didn't find either to be true. Our waiter was great and the hostess had no problem seating us early when our party arrived a little bit before our reservation time. This was on a Saturday night, too. So not sure what those complaints are about. Worth noting, however, that we did make our reservations for Zuni about three weeks in advance. It's a hard spot to get into.

Looking forward to going back to try that roast chicken!
author: Rebekah T.

description: Siting outside on a sunny day in Jan I thought how lovely SF is.  Even when  a man walked by and yelled at both me and my friend about who knows what..that's Market st for ya.  The service is very friendly and the food very timely as it was lunch time on Friday and the restaurant was busy.  I didn't really get to enjoy the menu as I was in the mood for a burger of all things. I'm sure I will be back but will choose something else.  The french fries were frustrating and the burger served on focaccia was not my favorite.
author: Stephanie E.

description:
Sad to say that I had to give the famous "ZUNI" only 2 stars...
We spent 80 bucks. 
I had an appetizer and a salad (I was in the mood for a large salad and they said they could give me the Caesar salad w/o the caesar but light balsamic instead. Uh, didn't happen, when it came out as a regular, heavily dressed caesar with caesar dressing, I asked the food server if it was the balsamic.  She said it was, then whispered to our waiter and they both came to the table where he proceeded to ask me if the salad dressing was "okay"--like I was an idiot who didn't know that I had just been served a regular caesar salad...) 
My husband had the pork shoulder, he said it was dry and a little over spiced.
Add one glass of wine and there you have it.
Sad.
We would go back on two conditions. We got the chicken and someone else paid.
Great atmosphere/ambiance though.
author: Ashley L.

description:
It was bestie's bday week and also christmas week. So, I blindfolded her and hoped with all my might that maybe we'd luck out and get a walk-in table at Zuni. Reservations had been packed for weeks and I had three other places mentally lined up in case of a long wait. 
However, there was a cute corner table available in the cafe, near a huge tree brilliantly lit with thousands of white lights. All this right when we walked in. 
Our server was sweet and bubbly and extremely informed. 
We started with oysters, tempura fried veggies, and la fettuna. All three were very yummy. 
The true reason to our visit to Zuni obviously was rooted in the chicken for two. We had mulled over this chicken for what felt like years. For some reason, we never made it to Zuni to try the infamous chicken. Why, I do not know. 
However, that night, we were ready. With stretchy pants on and tummies a-rumbling, we approached the chicken and bread salad like the foodie warriors we have been shaping ourselves to be. 
There is absolutely no exaggeration. That is some of the most tender, flavorful chicken, ever. And the bread salad... it is divine. 
The carb lover in me was staving off the urge to ask for a tray of just bread salad to take home. 
We closed out our scrumptious meal with an apple tartin split between the two of us and blissfully headed off the mission in a thunderstorm to drink and dance with boys. Lovely.
author: rachel b.

description: Came here last night around 11 pm so it was winding down and not too busy or loud. We were both starved and craving oysters so we immediately ordered 2 dozen oysters to kick the night off right. We got a mix because we entrusted our server Jeff with choosing the right kinds for us. My favorites were the kusshi (duh), and then the mix of east coast oysters. I insisted that I wanted dessert wine for dinner so Jeff brought me a selection of 3 to try and his recommendations were all on point, it was a tough decision. Without telling him he even knew what my favorite was. The guy ordered the salmon and a dry red (I wasn't interested to learn more about it because I don't enjoy dry reds), and we both thought his salmon was pretty bland and unexciting. I ordered the pork chop which was kind of hard to cut and tough on the outside but very flavorful on the inside and juicy, but not as juicy as I would have expected for a place of this caliber. It was a pretty hefty hunk of meat and the dish could probably benefit from having two separate portions the same size so the outside would not have to be cooked for so long. But who am I, Michael Bauer?!! I'll drop it because I still  scarfed it down and enjoyed every bit of it. For 3 glasses of wine, 2 dozen oysters, and 2 entrees our bill was almost $300. Pretty hefty as well, but because of the fantastic and attentive service provided by Jeff and the other staff,great and extensive oyster selection, and cozy but elegant ambience, I would come back when I feel like dining late night and splurging.
author: Heather U.

description: My Zuni's tale starts with a drunk woman pouring out the front door of the restaurant and slurring to our party, 'Robin Williams is in there. Good luck finding him."  Before you can say 'I don't give a...' there we were, seated at the table right next to Mr. Williams. A glamorous start to a glamorous birthday meal. We started with the oysters, which were amazing. Our waitress recommended a not-so-good gewurztraminer which we followed with a bottle of the other gewurztraminer on the menu (actually the less expensive one), which was good. We went on to have the celery-laced soup, cured anchovies and the almighty Zuni's roasted chicken. Dessert was some sort of tasty ice-cream. After the meal I felt a massive wave of nostalgia pour over me. Was it the effects of too much gewurztraminer? Was it my twenties gone by (I was now thirty-one)? And then, the answer suddenly occurred to me just as it does to the weary detective in bad detective films when he discovers the killer (montage, baby!): the soup tasked just like mom's homemade potato soup...that glorious chicken tasted just like the roasted chicken the local Lion's club used to do twice a year in my hometown...and that ice-cream...tasted...just...like...Eureka!: Chi-chi's fried ice-cream! All of my favorite foods from the past in one single meal. Hallelujah!! So why the three stars? Easy. The price of this meal at Zuni's: well over $200. Same meal back home: $12, tops. Bottom line: beautiful venue, excellent food, solid service, sky-high prices...but hey, maybe you'll get to sit next to Robin Williams, which would be priceless, that is, if you happen to give a....
author: Matthew Z.

description: I have been to this place so many times.  Not sure why, I guess I find it...reliable.  Good, overpriced. Nothing special in SF, except location and windows.  Nice to stop in for oysters and champagne, but that is pretty standard fare these days in most places.  But it comfortable.  And out of town folks will like it.  And the staff is always nice.  So you stay on my list of options, Zuni, but it is a half-hearted affair...
author: SD S.

description: Definitely a good restaurant but I agree the vibe can get a little snot-nosed.  The chicken is unreal but the prices are a bit high for what you get, I think.  I really don't like some of the claustophobic seating areas upstairs--I feel banished when I sit up there.  They occasionally have a wild mushroom soup that is unreal.  I would risk arrest to find out how it's made.
author: Kevin S.

description: Great restaurant.  The food is consistently excellent and the service  impeccable.  This is definitely one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  They use the freshest ingredients to create original and interesting dishes with incredible flavors and textures.  This is a great place for special occasions.
author: Bruce B.

description: Zuni is the essence of San Francisco dining, in my opinion. It's consistently delicious - for brunch, for dinner, the cocktails. The space is so cool, and I love the feeling of being virtually on the sidewalk, but in such a refined dining setting.  Accordingly, avoid eating upstairs. Of course, I have to mention the burger. It's stunning. Brunch is also a fun experience. My family are bloody-mary people (I am so not), and they gushed about the Zuni iteration. It'd be a crime to be a San Franciscan, or visit the city, and not hit up Zuni.
author: Emily M.

description:
Let's start this review by saying that I have sciatica. No, I am not 143 years old, but I have managed to get sciatica none the less. Let me tell you, its wonderful! Who wouldn't love shooting pain down one's leg...all the time? Who knows, maybe next week I'll get bursitis. Oooh! Or better yet, gout!
Anyway, last night I went to the symphony with a friend to see Midori - not the melon liqueur, but the famous (???) violinist. It was wonderful except for the damn sciatica. I couldn't get comfortable and with my senses distracted everything seemed a bit "off."
"What does this have to do with Zuni Cafe?" you ask.
Well, here goes:
After the symphony my friend and I walked (well, he walked, for me it was more of a hobble) to Zuni Cafe. Well actually, we were walking to catch a cab and ended up in front of Zuni Cafe and decided to just have dinner there. Neither of us had been and we both had heard people rave about it being "one of the best" restaurants in San Francisco.
We were seated immediately at a table near the bar. Our server was very friendly, although a bit dry. We tried to joke around with her a little and she just kind of stood there. Maybe they frown on levity. Anyway, we ordered drinks and perused the menu. For some reason, I found the menu difficult to read. I didn't quite understand how it was organized and it seemed to all run together. (That might have just been the combination of alcohol and pain killers, you decide.) So we asked for some recommendations. Recommendations were made and we ordered. At this point our server went inexplicably AWOL. Then I noticed her flirting with a hot number wearing thigh high boots at a table in the corner. Oh well.
Let me say that the food was pretty mediocre. The highlight for me was my first course - the onion and sorrel soup. It had a great oniony flavor and some still crunchy homemade croutons floating around in it. This was the highlight of the meal. My friend's Caesar salad was good, but nothing special. For a second course, we split the penne at the servers recommendation. She said it was "too rich" for one. I really didn't feel it was rich at all. The pasta was perfectly cooked, but the flavors were nothing special.
The main courses were okay. The beef was amazingly tender, but the accompanying endive seemed to fight with the subtle flavors of the beef. The white beans were under seasoned. The bass was overcooked and the preparation of the accompanying artichoke made it very difficult for my friend to eat. 
"Where the hell is the waitress? Our drinks have been at the bar melting for 5 minutes now. I hope she gets a phone number at least."
Dessert consisted of a flour-less chocolate cake (not nearly as good as the port I had to go with it) and the espresso granita (good, but very strong in flavor).
"oh look, the cell phones are out. I guess she did get a number."
Then the bill came.
I felt that this place was very overpriced for the quality of the food. Not at all deserving of being in the top 50 restaurants of San Francisco.
Having said that, the food was good, just not great. Much like my sciatic stupor, everything was just a bit "off."
I'm going to give this place another shot, hopefully after the sciatica is a distant memory.
"SCIATICA!!!!!!"
author: Jamie M.

description:
Zuni Cafe to me will always be a San Francisco classic.
I bought the cookbook a few years ago and convinced myself that I'd perfected the roast chicken for two.  Upon another visit to the restaurant--I realized that I am definitely missing something!
Maybe it's the perfect martini to start my dinner off --or the cured olives+cheese plate followed by the  yummy oyster options.  I just love it there--the service, the atmosphere, the food.  It comforts me to know that it's always there--and I'm reminded every once and awhile when I'm chasing the hot new thing--a visit to Zuni is all I really need.
author: Amy C.

description: This is a tough one. Considering I dropped over 3 bills, I was expecting to be blown away, but definitely wasn't. We didn't order the chicken, which was probably the first mistake. The oysters were good, they gave us a nice mix. The Caesar salad was good, the croutons were awesome. The burger was fine, but not the best I've ever had. Foccacia is an interesting bread choice, but I would've preferred a regular burger bun. The meat itself was great, but it became a sloppy mess and I had to resort to fork and knife. The shoestring potatoes were nice and different and reminded me of potato sticks i used to eat as a kid. We ended with the peach tart and some cheese. The tart was actually great, but the cheese was forgettable. Overall, its a fine place, but not somewhere I'd frequent on a regular basis. I guess I'll come back one day for the chicken...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I cannot believe I have not reviewed Zuni yet!

So, this is a fantastic spot for after-ballet / symphony / opera when the whole crowd heads into the Hayes valley and you didn't bother making reservations at Absinthe or Jardiniere and are faced with "we have a one hour wait" and you just have to discuss that pa de de!

You cut through the Hayes Valley to Market and head into Zuni, where you can grab one of those seat yourself tables downstairs.  Because what more could you want other than:

some of the best oysters in town
a comprehensive bar menu (I mean, chicken after 7 is just bad for you)
great selection of wines by the glass or by the bottle
and very friendly and helpful staff who are well versed in both the oyster speak and the wine list

And it's just so great to sit at one of those window tables facing Market when you are all dolled up after the show!
author: Localista I.

description: I came here to celebrate my birthday over the weekend.  First off, if you have a large party, expect to be making reservations at least 1 month in advance to get that large table...and expect to put down credit card to keep your reservations.  Also, apparently they only have 1 large table in the restaurant so you can only have your reservation at 5 PM .  Despite that, we had all been wanting to try this place so we went with it. .. got here at  4:45pm.. we were walking around all day from the Urban Air Market so we were hot and tired and we had hoped that we could get seated and start ordering drinks.. but no.. they said we will seat you promptly at 5 pm.. seesh..  anyway so we got seated.  Our waiter was quite pleasant.. we started off with drinks.  I had the balsalmic spicy bloody mary.. it was OK.. not the best bloody mary i've had but.. decent.. i donno if was $12 decent.. but ok..  my friend got the prosecco and champagne.. it was quite bubbly and you could tell they did use good alcohol in that drink... the dinner choices were pretty scarce but I guess most people are there to get the roasted chicken and warm bread salad.. we got one order to share amongtst us 10 people. each person was alloted 1 piece a about .. then we also got our own entrees.  Someone got the fried calamari and that was Delicious!  Someway.. they just make their fried calamari totally crunchy and I love the breading it was seasoned well and the calamari tasted chewy and fresh too.  Moving on.. the roast chicken was tasty very juicy and tender and salty.. but .. it IS hyped up I think.. you could definetly make a roast chicken like that at home for $10.. whereas they charge $48.. the warm bread.. it wasn't anything special either.. it was just soggy bread soaked in some chicken juices (kinda sour tasting..).   We ordered a variety of dishes for dinner...  I ordered the duck simmered in chipotle/peanuts/cinnamon.  It was pretty good, the duck ($26) itself was really tender and I really liked my dish.  My hubby ordered the pork chop, it was also good, but really plain. .. nothign really special about that dish.. it was just a pan friend pork chop ($26-28) browned and seasoned.  It was kinda actually undercooked and rare near the bone ... couldnt' eat that part. There were some veggies on the side. My brotherinlaw got the filet... and so did my sister's boyfriend.. they didnt' seem too happy with it.... being that they paid $35 for a "filet' they thought would be a filet minon... but it was just precut for your to 5 VERY SMALL slices of beef.. yikes.. they ate a lot of bread.... my sister got the ahi tuna.. it was really small as well.. and kinda bland.  Overall, we were pretty stuffed so we didn't order dessert..  the waiter was a bit pushy about that... if we don't want dessert, please don't tell us that we DO... otherwise, the waiter was quite nice and responsive.
author: Margie C.

description: Really? The chicken? Either people in San Francisco don't know chicken or they think its an exotic bird. After the reviews and the people sitting next to us telling us it was the best chicken and worth it...we ordered it. Wow. Its just a chicken...and not as good as my Moms. Both of us have been joking about it since we returned to Boston...but sadly...we only had 3 nights in the city and am wracked with a bit of guilt and remorse that I took my friend there...who had never been to California before and as an Italian (actually from Italy not an IA) is a lover of food...Sorry my friend, that I took you there...or that we ordered the chicken. But I guess it will be memorable in its own way. People..its CHICKEN!
author: Deborah M.

description: Zuni is, I believed, over-yelped ... so I'll be brief.  Their spartan menu is unnoteworthy ... accept for the oysters: that variety plate of delicate pacific oysters.  Seriously delicious.
author: Martin W.

description: My husband and I recently ate here for the 3rd time and we both walked away feeling like it was just okay - again. The string potatoes were absolutely wonderful as was our bottle of Sancerre. We both felt our entrees were a little lackluster. I had the duck and my husband had the prawns - judging by the other reviews, we should have gotten the chicken. The atmosphere in the restaurant is really wonderful and is probably great for a relaxing lunch, but we definitely wont be in a hurry to return.
author: Kent C.

description:
This place has the audacity to add a mandatory 4% charge on all checks for the San Francisco Universal Health Care Program. And then pile sales tax on top of that!
Whether you are a fan of that program or not, no business should impose its charities on its customers--especially without any advance notice.
As to the food, it was served luke warm and the wines by the glass suck.
author: Harvey P.

description: Wonderful roast chicken...The Caesar salad was not exciting.  Order the roast chicken and be happy!
author: Bleep S.

description: Another great interior space in soma, go figure.  They have a nice bar downstairs and some more tables up in the mezzanine.  Its looks cramped up there but it really isn't and I didn't feel like I had to yell to talk, nice feature for high ceilings.  I was here for lunch and still spent quite a bit so I am sure dinner gets more spendy, but worth it for local meat and produce.
author: Matt N.

description: Mmmm burrrger.... This is the place to come with parents.  Such yummy stuff- the roast chicken is a classic, mmm!!
author: Catherine R.

description:
i've been here soooo many times and i've always had a great time.  the food is consistently excellent, the service is right on.  i had a small birthday party at the bar the other night with about 12 people.  we had about 3 bartenders catering to us for 5 hours.  no attitude, all smiles.  they have some of the best oysters in the city, bar none.  the decor is super cool, exposed brick, weird angles, open kitchen, huge windows looking out over market st.  
awesome, just awesome.  and yes, a san francisco classic.
author: Betsy K.

description: Excellent! Went last night and had a long dinner with the friends, never felt rushed. Had oysters and martini's to start, then on to salads (the Cesar was awesome!) I had the hanger steak which was very light and the perfect amount! I am so happy that I finally made it here, and can't wait to go back!
author: Lisa K.

description: I recently went to dinner at this place and assumed based on all the positive reviews that it as going to be amazing. The atmosphere is good, the service was pretty good, but maybe I should have ordered the chicken!!! I ended up getting the steak- it was horrible! I didn't know you could mess up steak any other way besides burning it...but its possible! The wine and appetizers were good though.
author: Krystle M.

description:
went for lunch, had a Cesar salad and a beer and im convinced.
the salad was whole lettuce leaves, grated parm, huge croutons and the best part...the dressing. oh the dressing... i want to call it an
anchovy vinaigrette, which usually im o fan of anchovies but this was 
heaven. beer selection is great, had me a nice thick sams nut brown ale.
author: Jacquelyne M.

description: Best Caesar salad in the city. I can't count the number of times I've eaten at Zuni and I've yet to have a meal that was less than stellar. One other thing that is very unusual is that their bar staff is every bit as accomplished as the chef and wait staff. Try their Cosmopolitan - even if you don't like Cosmopolitans. All too often, high-caliber restaurants don't train the staff and hope that the food will cover for them. That's not the case at Zuni. They are unflappably cool and always gracious. I thought we might have a hard time once when I dined there with a friend who had forgotten his pants but they didn't bat an eye.  There may be better gnocchi in the city but I've yet to find it. Be with some entertaining people if you order the roasted chicken because it takes a while.
author: Joe H.

description: Attentive service, organic seasonal ingrediants, and even the atmosphere make Zuni a stand out in SF dining.  Go for any meal of the day and order anything off the menu, and it will be delicious.  The oysters are superb, and I like the elderflower & prosecco cocktail to sip on.  The burger and fries are like non you've tried, and the whole roast chicken can easily feed four.  Reservations are recommended, but if you are spontaneously in the mood to go, take your chances with getting a seat in the bar.  It's worth it.
author: Leslie R.

description: If for some godforsaken reason I ever end up on death row, Zuni's roasted chicken will no doubt be my last meal.  Enough said.
author: Shelley M.

description: Food and wine were superb!!  Hands down one of the best meals I've had since moving to San Francisco.  Service was unbelievably bad which was really unfortunate...
author: Jules S.

description:
The Food was good if I remember; what bothered me was the service.  Three of us went there for an early dinner and all of us had Ice Tea to drink.  The waiter kept asking of us if we wanted refills on the tea and we of course said yes.  You know how Ice Tea goes down, especially when someone is constantly refilling your glass.  Finally the waiter said it would be better for him to just bring us a pitcher, and we just sort of agreed with him.  We got our bill and the ice tea portion of the bill was over $40.00; broken out by the per glass and picture fee.  When I asked what that was all about thinking that it was free refills the way brewed iced tea always is the waiter told us that they charge per glass, and that's why he decided to bring us the picture "to save us money".  He continued to tell us in a very condescending manner that is how it is done at most higher class restaurants.

We decided to eat the bill; but I feel compelled to tell others about our experience.   
While I love to eat out, and do not mind paying for a good meal; I hate it when I feel like I over paid for what I got or when I'm paying for bad service.

I hope you have a better experience.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Recently dined here after a trip to the symphony and was very disappointed and will not be back. This place must get rated highly either because A) diners feel nostalgic since it has been around awhile and is sort of an SF restaurant landmark, and/or B) diners simply have not dined in better restaurants and do not know what to expect from a supposed top restaurant (good menu, good food, good service, prices in line with all of the above - Zuni has none of these). 

Starting with the menu: short and limited, nothing exciting. Their main fish dish was salmon... wow. They advertised it as Coho salmon, however it did not look like Coho when it was served to me. They have one salad option: Caesar.... again, wow. The menu seems to revolve around their roasted chicken for two, which you have to wait an hour for and costs $48. 

Next: Service. Our bespectacled waiter was surly and the service was at par and lukewarm at best. At the prices they are charging, I expect better service.... at least 'act' like you are happy to still have customers willing to shell out dough for mediocre food at inflated prices. The waiter stepped on my husband's foot 3 times during the service, as if my husband's foot kept getting in the way or his work. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was okay, no complaints there. 

They automatically add a 4% surcharge to every check to cover SF's mandatory healthcare coverage for restaurant workers. There was no justification for how they arrived at this %.   

Overall, disappointing menu, mediocre food, inflated prices not on par with food quality, mediocre service. Thankfully this city is filled with better options, so I don't have to go back.
author: Andrea A.

description: One of my favorite places in SF. The chicken is well worth the wait, the salads are fresh and delicious, and I love the burger. I am also a big fan of the balsamic bloody merry. Some of the pizzas are better than others -- for example, I wasn't particularly impressed with the Wagon Wheel. Ambiance is casual yet sophisticated, and the service is wonderful.
author: Tadeek P.

description: I last ate here 25 years ago, and had dreamed about trying the roast chicken again -- but it was somehow disappointing.  They seem to have lost a little bit of the edge.  Service was super friendly however.
author: Harvey S.

description: I was a little disappointed by Zuni, given what I've heard about it.  We ordered what they're famous for: caesar's salad, burger, roast chicken, as well as a spinach soup.  Out of all four, only the burger stood out for me, even though I could easily name 3 places in LA that serve a better burger.  The roast chicken was most disappointing.  It was so mediocre that I thought perhaps they had an off night.  Our friends and I were thinking, this took you an hour to prepare?  Seriously!  I'd rather be eating Zankou Chicken for a quarter of that price.  (For $48, Zuni does set up high expectation that the chicken would do everything but get up and dance.)  It was not a bad meal, by any means, but the food was definitely not worth the price.  Thank God for good friends and strong drinks.
author: Eric W.

description:
I went last night for the first time ... after a couple of unsuccessful attempts (that I wont mention here). First off the Manhattan that I ordered was fantastic.... perfectly executed with a Spicy Rye and at least 30 seconds of stirring. Bravo! I found the staff to be a bit dour....not off putting but not many smiles and no real attempt to engage. The space is great, the flowers are striking and beautiful and the atmosphere is good.
 To start we ordered some oysters that were fantastic (kusshi's i believe) We ordered the Bread Salad and Caesar Salad as apps. The Bread salad was amazing and we scraped up every last current and pine nut on the plate after the succulent chicken juice soaked bread was gone (The real highlight of the meal). I thought it was slightly under seasoned but my companions didn't and anyway, no problem there's salt on the table. The Caesar salad was meh in my opinion..but fine. For a main course we had the Pork chop and the Salmon ...and we had the rabbit loin appetizer come out with the meal ..because we had to try it. I was not blown away by either of the main courses ... I love the style ..unfussy rustic food that is really fresh and quality and executed really well ...but neither knocked my socks off. The pork loin was served with a sauerkraut and some fried polenta and was good ... honestly I didn't really get what the polenta was doing on the plate it didn't seem to tie into the dish all that well. Dont get me wrong i love polenta but  If you are going to go completely German like that just commit  and hook me up with some spatzle. The salmon was quite good and super fresh, with large white beans that were buttery and delicious. Surprisingly the rabbit app. was the hit of the main course.
 All and all I was pretty happy with my experience. I liked the food, I think it is a great example of Bay Area cuisine. I do think it is a bit pricey but really what do you expect from such an institution. The service was decent. I am a bit torn between 3 and four stars ..but given the prices and the fact that this place is supposed to define San Francisco food and  for some inexplicable reason you cant order the Hamburger until after 10 at night... I am going with three.
author: Ben S.

description: Wasn't that impressed with the food, good but not that good for the price. Good drink and people watching place to be. After my $150 dinner (for two, with one glass of wine each, well, i had shell fish/oyster platter to start) i still can't remember much what is really really good. perhaps i need to give it another shot!
author: Angela H.

description: I came here for brunch on a Sunday.  The wait was super long.  We wante to try the place so decided to wait at the bar.  It took forever to get the bartenders attention.  I finally orderd my mocha to hold me over till we could eat.  When I got it...it tasted like hot chocolate...I had my bf try it and he said it did too.....I asked the bartender...and he goes "ohhhhhh I forgot to put the espresso in it".  Umm???  He then poured it in there and it basically was one of the worst mochas I've had in my life.  I've had better mochas out of those coin-operated nescafe machines.  We then decided to leave, so I actually never tasted the food, but if you can't make a mocha...I don't even want to try it.
author: Neety P.

description: Tell me, how does roasting a chicken take this long???? Yes, those skinny fries are good, but I would eat a meal at home before heading to Zuni's for the chicken for two, and maybe some Prozac, as we waited FOREVER, with a reservation, to be seated in the outer reached of the restaurant.  You people have been at this for far too long to be offering such bad service, but the assumption is that you can get away with it.
author: Beth V.

description: Finally a place where to ge a bottle of Prosecco and one of Marsanne (both very close to perfection) and a nice example of eclectic californian cuisine for the right price. Bread was great and made in house, wood fire cooked pizza (good but could have been better), burgers, salad, chips....everything with that eclectic glitch that makes you satisfied. Finally? Coffee granita...I'll go there on and on just for that. Darn! I missed the chicken! Next time...
author: Dario B.

description: sunday brunch: fantastic food, coffee and drinks, super service. can't wait to come back.
author: Luvlife R.

description: Since opening, this place has been one of my all time favorites. Their cookbook rocks also. They know their food - down to the little and time consuming things like salting meats days ahead and focusing on  home made simplicities. I give it 5 stars b/c it's been in my mind space all these years.
author: A. P.

description: Went here with my boyfriend for dinner when we were visiting SF.  Really enjoyed the bar area and we both thought the space was pretty cool.  Service was helpful, down to earth and attentive but not overbearing.  Food was good but not great - I think maybe my expectations were too high going in.
author: Geoff P.

description: Nice atmosphere with high ceilings and brick walls. Fast service. Nice wine selections. The pasta was wonderful with panceta. We ordered the chicken for two which was recommended by a local. It was
author: Marc F.

description: "The only reason robots haven't yet taken over is that they haven't learned how to climb stairs."  -The fancy people sitting next to us.
author: Frankie D.

description: I eat things here that I never thought I'd eat.  The waiter said "try the bone marrow dish" with such innocence and sweetness.  So I did.  And now I have eaten marrow.  And it is delicious.  The atmosphere is a bit snotty, but I can get over that for the chicken.
author: Natalie M.

description: Meh. Not worth the price or the reputation. Eaten here formally 5 times (one lunch and four dinners) and none of them were particularly good. Not bad, but I could make the same foods just as well in my tiny studio kitchen and pay half as much for a bottle of wine as I would for a glass here and be more comfortable and happy and have a better time. Sure, there might not be as many celebrity sightings outside my Cole Valley kitchen window, but when it comes down to it: I've had better.
author: Thom M.

description: One of my all-time favorites in SF and I've been going consistently since 1992. The food is always very good and the menu changes often. A few things on the menu don't change, however, and one is their signature dish, the roast chicken with bread salad. Consistently fantastic. If you know you want to order it, do so right off the bat when your server greets you so s/he can have the kitchen fire it -- takes about 45 minutes. If it's just two of you, split a Caesar salad and a bowl of polenta as appetizers. Zuni also has a lovely selection of oysters. The service has always been quite good and friendly. I've always loved the exposed brick walls and the copper bar. Terrific food and good people-watching as well. Highly recommended! It's also a good restaurant for a date, family gathering, dinner with friends.
author: Duncan M.

description: I have no idea what I said about the place last time I reviewed it....nthing about the atmosphere has changed, its stilla very nice place and good outdoor seating etc etc etc. But, come on, $3.50 for a fountain drink x 2 (refill) so $7.00 total is absurd. And the oysters werent good, whic were around $3.00 each. Im used to paying .50 per oyster (if I actually ordered them regulary)
author: Jared M.

description: On my quest for the best burger in SF, and Zuni almost has it.  except they only serve burgers before 5pm or after 10pm, which is annoying.  My server was really busy and seemed harrassed the whole time, but the maitre'd took over for her and the bartender helped her out also.  So the service ended up being good.  The burger was very good, on foccacia bread.  But I like Abisnthe's version of the burger on foccacia just as well.  And Chez Maman's burger on french bread is on par.
author: Janet S.

description: Went there with a bunch of friends after class.  It was definitely the most expensive lunch I've ever had!  With a price tag like that, one would expect generous and sincere service.  It was anything but that.  The hostess looked at us like we were transients off the street, and felt as we weren't treated with the same level of respect as the other guests.  The draw to Zuni was the reputation of the restaurant and the constant hype of their famed roasted chicken.  It was good, but nothing out of this world.  Perhaps it was the major hype of the chicken that lead me to have too high of an expectation.
author: Hiro A.

description:
I like their foods.  I like their service. I would have voted five starts had I not been served by this particular waiter who pays little attention to the guests.  He didn't explain the menu well.  He didn't bring wine quickly. Although we told him that we are sharing everything, and they usually pre-divide foods to individual plates, this waiter didn't. Frankly this is OK except for soup.  We asked him to divide each regular bowl of soup to two smaller bowls but he refused because they can't divide an egg.  It is only after we asked strongly that he complied our request, by that time the soup was cold. (Still tasted good thanks to the chef, however.) This waiter isn't looking around and we have to make lots of effort to get his attention.
I hope he won't be there for too long.
OK, enough complain.  For those who go, be sure to order Cezar's salad.  Theirs are the best.
author: Kamome K.

description: I came here once on a date on the advice of a good friend. The location is cool, the building is funky, and the menu was great. I had my first experience with raw oysters here and they were as delicious as the waiter was helpful in explaining where they came from, taste, etc. We had the best table in the house, split a gorgeous bottle of wine, and left full and happy. Its a little flashy and trendy and kinda pricey, but a great date place. I would bring my lady back.
author: Jordan P.

description: Deserves every star. The caesar salad and goat cheese appetizer were the perfect starters. The oyster menu is fabulous and so fresh. Everything was great and the service was above par!
author: A D.

description: This is my all time favorite place!!  Whenever we have company in town or want to go out for a really great dinner with great service this is our place. I can't say enough about the Cesar salad and the chicken of course. The last few times we have gone we branched out and tried some new things. I have never had anything here that was not perfect!  I love this place so much that I bought the cook book! If I can make the chicken or Cesar salad half as good as they do I would be happy!
author: Leslie M.

description: Ok, I am big on the price to wow factor ratio.  The food here is good, the service was great (they made a mistake with our reservation, it happens, and still got us a seat within 10 minutes when the place was packed).  So why 3 stars?  BIG TICKET PRICE, small portions.  If you are looking for a quality gourmet meal this is not a bad option, just pricey like all the other gourmet places.
author: William b.

description:
I was very disappointed to discover that the menu had only 5 entree choices. One of them was their chicken for two (with a 2-hour wait). Because my husband and I like to have different entrees, and because we were eating at 8PM and didn't want to wait to eat until 9PM, I felt that in effect there were only 4 choices.
 
It is hard for me to understand how a restaurant with so few choices can make the top Chronicle's 100 restaurant list. While I realize that specialization allows restaurants  to concentrate on what they do best, I think 4-5 entrees is taking it too far--especially at Zuni Cafe prices. I made a choice (halibut), but only because it was the best of the lot for me, not because I really wanted it.
author: Lynne T.

description:
i finally got to try this place after wanting to come for a million years.  my friend and i shared everything, and we really liked the fact that they split all our share plates into 2 portions.  we had the infamous caesar, the ricotta gnocchi, the halibut, AND the bread salad.  usually the bread salad comes w/ the roast chicken, but we asked our server if we can just get the bread salad.  the server said that the bread is usually cooked w/ the chicken in its juices, so he would have to ask the kitchen, and they allowed us to get it.  thank god, b/c the bread salad was THE best part of the meal.  i could have just eaten that alone!!  the caesar was good, but it didn't blow my mind, considering that is what they are famous for.  the gnocchi was really good, b/c it was light, fluffy, and came in a very subtle meyer lemon sauce.

we didn't have a reservation on a fri night, and we got there around 645 just to be safe.  the wait was about 30-40 minutes, which wasn't bad, and we just enjoyed a drink at the bar.
author: Helen T.

description:
Wow.  I kind of forgot to go back to Zuni for about 9 months until I went in early December.  I have been back 4 times since and it feels almost like a new restaurant.  

First of all, the desserts are fantastic.  Did they get a new pastry chef?  Or did someone wake up and realize that the gateau chocolate cake thing is boring, dry and done better elsewhere?  It doesn't matter.  The desserts rock.  None of my friends believed me, but time after time do the desserts blow us away.  They are simple, elegant and a great bargain compared to what you get at so many other restaurants.

The service is also in a different league than I remember it.  No longer do I leave fuming because of the inattentive and rude servers.  They look the same, but they seem to be acting like a friendly waiter ought to, which is the point of going to Zuni Cafe, right?  A fun, relaxed and good time...

Just bring back the apple tart with red wine sauce, or the grapefruit sorbet, or the pistachio ice cream.
author: frank w.

description:
Went to have lunch here with my husband and 2 other friends before our early showing of Wicked.  I have to say i was a bit dissappointed.  we had the crostini appetizer and ceasar salad (the salad was a mistake i had originally wanted Arugula salad but i didn't complain).  They were both good.
