The main dishes was the famous whole chicken, pork tenderloin, and a glorified hamburger.   

The chicken, yes, it was good, but not for the price paid for.   It didn't stand out as the BEST chicken EVER as the price would make you think.  The pork was way over salty and they gave sparse amount (i was still hungry after eating it and i'm usually a light eater!).  The burger, was on a foccacia like bread , but as my husband put it "it's just a pretty burger for $14".

So overall the food was good, but  not outstanding.  Totally not worth the money to spend.  the bill came out to be about $150 for the four of us not including tip.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Been here on and off for years, but finally back in The City the last year, and so have been 8-12 times.  Clearly, I am OK with the place.  And if what you crave is a glass of excellent champagne with excellent oysters, with a fun atmosphere, this is your place.  And the food is overall very good to excellent, with some stunning mis-steps (the roasted chicken for $50ish; yes it's a signature dish, but someone is forging that signature now). 

 The real issue at Zuni in the last several months has been the bar.  You order a drink in a quiet restaurant.  Your drink takes 10-20 minutes, because the bartender(s) have to be found, and then they have to stop talking to each other long enough to make your drink.  You order a drink in super busy restaurant, and it takes 15-30 minutes because the bartenders are (a) making drinks and (b) stopping for minutes at a time to chat with each other.   You decide to cut to the chase and order a bottle of wine.  Well, only the manager can get the bottles, and if s/he is not available, then you wait.  Possibly until you have eaten the course for which you ordered the wine.

It's a chill atmosphere, and the waitstaff is generally friendly and knowledgeable.  But the bar staff -- what is going on there?  They have motivated me to try other restaurants in the area.  And I don't think that's what they should be doing.
author: Laura T.

description: $47 for a tiny hamburger, fries & a salad!! Are you kidding me? And I had to put up w/ a slow, very bitchy waiter. Zuni has gone to hell in an uppity handbasket!
author: cricket x.

description: I'm definitely a fan of their oysters. They have a whole menu page dedicated to them. I ate 18, and 1 tasted metallicy, but rest were perfect. My friends seem to enjoy the food quite a bit, as they have been going almost weekly since the first time. They are open a little later than other SF spots, so that's nice. The drinks were good. They seem to have a decent wine selection, though I know nothing about wine. The music was horrible. Some kind of old, folky, something or other. Not a fan. The ambience was a little quiet for my taste, but friendly and the service was very good. I will probably go back for the oysters tomorrow. Closed on Mondays.
author: Tonya S.

description: Others have talked extensively about the food, but I want to tell you about the bloody mary.  Balsamic...oh my!   There isn't a hangover this can't cure--especially if paired with those haystack fries.
author: L W.

description: This place is why you love your family.  My uncle and his partner routinely take me to lunch here, and when family from out of town come to visit, they take me to dinner.  My favorite thing to do at Zuni is draw pictures on the paper table cloth with the crayons.  I've made some masterpieces while waiting for the famous chicken to cook, which takes a while.
author: Josh K.

description: What's all the chicken hype about?  It's good SF standard food but nothing worth revisiting or writing home about.
author: Amber L.

description: Zuni is perfection or dang near and I have judged many a restaurant on how they compare.  I love coming here for brunch although the recent request for a bottle of champagne and a carafe of oj left at the table for do-it-myself mimosas left the waiter baffled.  We resolved it though and moved on to their wonderful food.  The polenta is to die for and like the creamiest cream of wheat ever it's so comforting.  Their pizzas will dare you to call anything else pizza.  Every person I have gone with here has been converted to a Zuniphile and rightly so.  It ain't for the small pocketed but for those special occasions and just gotta have its...make it happen.
author: Jill D.

description: Wow, it's been a long time since I've been here, but my experience at Zuni's was actually pretty good. The one thing I can say for them (back when I used to go there) is that they had a fabulous oyster bar. Has that changed? I don't even remember any chicken on their menu! They had a lot of strange things like bulls balls, or something, which I didn't try. My sister and I were always busy scarfing up the raw oysters! They were always fresh. The place was expensive, though, and the wait staff wasn't very nice. I just went for the oysters....
author: Shari D.

description: The roasted whole chicken for 2 is what they are known for so I decided to give it a shot...it is amazing.  It is the juiciest, most succulent, near perfection of a chicken ever.  The wine list is extremely nice as well, the service was great, and the wait was short.  We sat in the back where they have these long wide cushioned benches so you sit at your table and someone sits right at your back at their table.  Not a fan of this.  They are not comfortable and you get bounced around every time the person behind you shifts.  Other than that the meal was great.
author: Ryan G.

description:
I have to say that, given the mixed reviews below, I might not have chosen Zuni had I read them in advance of venturing to the city.  Thankfully, I didn't read them.

  Of course, the space itself has its charms, from the copper bar to the way-too-crowded dining rooms with uncomfortable seating which would be a huge knock on a new restaurant, but the place shows its age in many ways, and the seating does hearken back to San Fran in the 70's and 80's, a simpler time when cushioned booth seating was not the standard. (How's that for a run-on sentence?)  The open kitchen adds to the charm as well.  We were seated promptly, as long as we promised not to linger for more than about 1 hr 45 min due to a reservation (we had none).  Fair enough.

  The menu is shockingly brief, with a few rotating daily selections (fish, pizza) as well as some seasonal items and the old stalwarts of hamburger and the legendary chicken.  An amazing seafood "raw bar" menu is also available.  As we were a bit pressed for time, needing to get back to Sacramento at a decent hour, we thought about ordering the bird, but both the menu and our waiter cautioned that it takes a good hour to get to the table.  We grudgingly opted out of the chicken.  Turned out, it was a good choice for us.  A couple at the next table had ordered it, and it really did take an hour.  Maddeningly, they had a direct view of the kitchen, where they saw the bird resting (or languishing, depending on one's perspective) on the cutting board for a virtual eternity.  Seems that the bird actually roasts for 40 minutes, but rests for an additional 20.  Culinarily, this is the right thing to do; I do it myself at home.  However, in a busy restaurant where the chicken is a huge seller, why not just fire a bird or two every half hour?  The likelihood that it will sell is almost 100%, and customers will wait a lot less, resulting in both happier clientele and faster table turnover, i.e. a win-win for patron and proprietor.  Oh well, forewarned is forearmed.

  The meal that we did order was just great.  Oysters were presented simply and were impeccable.  A lettuce and beet salad was perfect, with museum-quality lettuce and a sublime tarragon vinaigrette.  The Zuni Caesar ought to be in the Smithsonian in an argon-filled chamber as an example of what this near-universally desecrated dish was meant to be.

  Entrees included a brine-cured pork chop, which was seasoned perfectly and juicy throughout, and the house burger, which, while less "classic" in execution than the Caesar, was no less on-point.  Dessert was a deep, rich chocolate cake for her, and a simple cheese plate for me.  Everything was just right, period.  

  As previous reviewers have noted, the service is a bit lacking.  Our server appeared constantly rushed, though he was never rude or inconsiderate.  Just think of it as bistro service and it becomes tolerable, almost charming in keeping with the energy of the place.  Drinks and water were attended to promptly.  By the way, this is one place where you should forget what your mother told you and DO load up on bread; Zuni's comes from Acme and is an experience in itself.
author: Nate S.

description: Came here for dinner before watching  Mamma Mia at the Orpheum with wifey.  It has been years since I've been here....aka 7 odd years ago.  Nothing has changed.  The roast chicken is exactly as a I remember.  Their ceasar salad has always been good and still lives up to it's reputation.  They still have a wide variety of oyster/shellfish.  It is  still good after all these years.   Service was good, wine selection was good.  Will always come back.
author: David M.

description: The food ranges from good to great, but it just costs too damn much for how good it is.  I really don't mind spending money on food, but in general, and particularly at lunch, Zuni is just not a good value.  That said, I have had some really good meals here.  The roast chicken and bread salad is deservedly famous, the oyster selection is great, and it's a really nice place to be with a date.  But bring your wallet.
author: Ficus K.

description: I have no effen clue what other reviewers are complaining about when they refer to the "rude and pretentious" service. Perhaps we just went on a night when all of the nice people were working, but we found the quality and friendliness of service to be top-notch. In fact, that's the whole reason I'm giving Zuni a 4-star rating and not a 3. The food itself was good, but nothing spectacular. Definitely worth trying out on a week day night.
author: Chris B.

description: Why did is take me so long to review this iconic staple in San Francisco's diet?  Because is sort of sucks and I keep trying to forget I've ever been there.  You know how people talk about how a band was better before everyone knew about it, like when Green Day played small venues in the early 90's?  I'm guessing that's what happened to Zuni.  No doubt it was probably good back in the day, but beyond the fries, oysters and cocktails, it's offerings are pretty much limited to being able to say you've been there.  Nothing on the menu amazes.  For a shorter wait and much better food, walk up Gough to Paul K.
author: Lane K.

description: One of the best well reviewed restaurants in all of SF.  Anything you get at this place will be good, if not great.  They are also open for lunch, and serve an amazing burger.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Decided to eat lunch here today on a whim with my daughter. We just walked in with no reservation, but they were able to seat us at the small tables around the bar.

The restaurant's interior is very nice. We sat adjacent Market Street so there was a lot of interesting stuff to see outside. They also had a live piano player which added to the ambiance.

The food was good with some strong spots and one big weak point.
* They started us with bread. I really don't care for their bread. It's a denser sourdough with a fairly tough crust (with some serious chew). Not my cup of tea breadwise. But that's fine. Some folks like this style of bread. I prefer crustier fare. But the upshot is that I didn't fill up on bread.
* We started with little neck clams and a smattering of oysters. They were served raw with some shallot vinagrette. I like my oysters/clams straight up, so I didn't use the condiment. The seafood was very fresh had that wonderful ocean brinyness and came from Tomales Bay and the Humboldt Coast according to the menu. Really good stuff.
* I ordered the grilled pork chop dish for myself. The pork chop was excellent. Very thick (2 inches? Maybe more). It's was tender and well seasoned and the pork flavor was very good, very intense. The chop was accompanied by two sweet potatoe medallions and a mound of grilled raddichio. Presentation was simple as were the preparations. Clearly this style of cooking is about straight-forward flavors with quality ingredients. 
* My daughter had the ricotta salata pizza. This was the big disappointment. I realize Zuni isn't a pizza joint, but if you're going to put something on your menu I'd hope it's good. This pizza was probably 2 stars, maybe 3 (if I was feeling charitable). Fortunately I have a small appetite so I was able to share the delectable pork chop with my disappointed kid.

We were too full for dessert, so we didn't even see what they had on the menu wrt sweets. 

Still, on the basis of the shellfish and the pork chop alone, I'm giving Zuni 4 stars. The pork chop was really stellar. I don't often get to taste such a deeply rich pork flavor in a pork chop like that. I'm sure they must be lining up the quality vendors for their meat products.

My only other gripe with Zuni -- one that made me consider going to 3 stars -- is that it seems to be a tad overpriced. So you may be able to find a better value. But I'll definitely return at some point for another meal.
author: David P.

description: One of my favorite bars in all the land.  The oysters are the best in the city (you pay for the quality however).  The roasted chicken is otherworldly in a good way.  Love the anchovies as well.  Great people-watching as well...
author: C.M. L.

description: I often take out of towners here who are looking for the true SF restaurant experience.  I am not sure what that means, but I love the quirkiness of Zuni.  Neither the rooms nor the tables conform to the usual rectangular mold. Their food is consistently superb with a menu that changes often but always has certain staples, such as their chicken and burgers.
author: Steve S.

description:
Zuni is great. I took my wife there a few weeks ago for her birthday. 

I was told there were no tables, so we sat in the bar for a few minutes...and then I had to pull a Larry David and 'speak' with the maitre d....we had a table in 10 minutes.

We both loved it...Food was great...it's lived up to it's reputation.

The Zuni and a quick cab ride to the Orpheum....I think I'm doing pretty well in this husband-gig.
author: Kevin A.

description: I love the food at Zuni every time. Whether it's the famous oven-roasted whole chicken and bread salad or it's pork chops for breakfast (!!), Zuni has never disappointed. The restaurant's eponymous cookbook is also a compendium of straightforward preparations of meats and fishes.
author: David Y.

description: There was a reason that I proposed to my wife at Zuni more than a decade ago.  Even for San Francisco, the ambience, food quality and attention to detail is exquisite.  Want fresh oysters, it's hard to beat Zuni. Well-prepared entrees that are almost always cooked to perfection.  Oh, and they make some of the best martinis as well. Try their fries for an added treat.
author: Daniel C.

description: Came here last weekend with a group of friends.  That hamburger was sick.  One of the best made hamburgers I've ever tasted.  Our main course was the chicken.  I like the bread they put under the chicken.   That was good.  The chicken was ok.   Too expensive though for my buget at the moment, ended up dropping at least $50 bones for the dinner.  Didn't plan on sepnding that much on food.  Great food though! Don't get me wrong, but I feel you can get a better bang for your buck somewhere else.  but, if you have cash, and like to spend hella money on food, then knock yourself out.  You'll go home full though.  That's important.  Very!
author: Ryan K.

description: I went to this place many years ago and it still rocks! Love the atmosphere and fun menu. This is definitely a happening place to bring a friend, whether or not they're local or from out of town visiting the San Francisco bay area.
author: Anne H.

description: A tradition on a warm Sunday afternoon! Robert is a doll! Love to sit outside if weather is warm. Food consistantly good, not great! Service good.
author: lynn t.

description: Went for lunch today with a co-worker. We split a pizza and a burger with shoestring fries. The pizza was very tasty and the crust was super thin-- the burger was juicy. The service was great. Next time I want to try the roasted chicken.
author: a b.

description: I have lived 4 blocks from Zuni for 20 years or more, and have never eaten there....thought it was all hype...thought they'd be snobby...Thought it would be overpriced.  I finally had lunch there on tues. afternoon with friends who treated me for my birthday, and I became an instant Zuni convert!! PERFECT Ceasar salad...Great roast duck/fennel salad. Great deserts...I am about to become a "regular". The server was great...friendly, helpful...did not look down on us for wanting to split the Ceasar...delivered it on 2 plates....I can't WAIT to return to Zuni.
author: Jane L.

description: over rated and kind of cliche. I don't remember what I ate. I do remember they pack so many people in and thus i think the quality of service is lacking. Very nice atmosphere though.
author: Nicole H.

description: After hearing about this restaurant for years, finally had a chance to try it during a reunion in SF with 3 college girlfriends (foodistas from LA, Seattle and Boston).  Surprisingly, all of us were disappointed.  The biggest failure was the over-hyped $48 whole roast chicken, which was good but not great.  Oddly, the chicken was served not on vegetables, but on a bed of baked bread squares, which was pretty ridiculous, considering that we'd already been served a huge (delicious) bread basket which was consumed during the 40 minutes of waiting for the chicken.  In addition, there were no vegetable sides listed on the menu (unless you count potatoes), nor was there a vegetable plate or vegetarian option.  When we asked for one, the waitress said she'd have the kitchen make up a veggie plate for us.  With the exception of very good, caramelized brussels sprouts, the rest of the vegetables were either undercooked or forgettable.  Pretty weird for high-standards, market-driven, locavore San Francisco.
author: Amy M.

description: Back in April, I was walking home one weeknight when I finally decided to step into the Zuni Cafe for dinner. I was celebrating life at that moment, so, what better place to celebrate life than a nice dinner at a nice restaurant. I walked in and went up to the hostess to see if she had a table for one. She smiled and said she did. I asked if I could have the little corner table next to the side door/Market Street side, where I could watch the hustle and bustle of Market Street. The hostess was fantastic to accomodate me at the last minute, and with a smile no less! After just a few minutes, a really nice waitperson came up with a very warm smile and welcomed me to the restaurant. She offered me a drink and gave me the run-down on the food served, all with such a warm, honest, pleasant demeanor amidst such a busy night. I had the gnocci which was very different from the usual gnocci: cheesy goodness!!!! The thing is this: the food is delicious, and I was going to take the time to give a thorough review of the food, but what overtook the delicious food was the excellent service. If you want to park it here for a while and go where you can feel welcomed and warm, after a long day at work, this is the place to go. Everyone, from the hostess, to the waitperson, to the busperson, was perfect. And the fries were to DIE for.
author: Julien N.

description: Chicken was very juicy and delicious but also expensive. The bread was also very good. Live piano playing in the background. Friendly and courteous staff.
author: Angela K.

description:
Unfortunately my date did not want chicken the night we dined at Zuni.  Too bad because we ordered all the other dishes (3 salads, 2 entres)  along with a half dozen oysters and felt we'd had almost nothing to eat. 

Along with small portions, the food itself was quite unimpressive, not very flavorful.  Read the cookbook instead.

In the future I'd either avoid Zuni or just have oysters.
author: T T.

description: A solid favorite.  The food is simple and delicious. The house cured white anchovies are a must. Their burger and roasted chicken for two are legendary. But possibly one of my favorite treats is their brunch menu: if they are offering baked eggs when you next visit, get them!
author: Pamela B.

description:
zuni is mediocore and totally not worth the price or wait.  

the mojito was delish but grossly overpriced (yes, even by SF fine dining standards.)  menu is severely limited, both in selection and creativity.  we got a salad and some tomato crostini for appetizers.  while it was good, it wasn't anything special.  waited 1 hour for their famed chicken, and it was a total let down.  i think the olive oil fried bread underneath was better.  the chicken was too dry and tasted like salt, meaning it lacked total complexity of flavors and was too salty.

decor & crowd there is very hip and i can imagine this would be lovely place to chillax provided you don't drink that much.
author: Miss K.

description:
I can't believe it has taken me 6 years of living in the city and hearing the rave reviews to finally get to Zuni. Loved the casual atmosphere (my dining partner was in jeans and a t-short while I took the opportunity to dress up a bit for the first time in weeks), friendly service and cozy environment. 

And then there is the food (sigh). Cesar salad? Bring it on with that zesty, lighter (but traditional) dressing. The grilled sardines were delicious. And then there was the ricotta gnocchi - we couldn't decide if we should call them pillows or clouds of yum.
author: Kara F.

description:
Have been to zuni a few times over the years.  In the last 2 months or so something has happened and its gone downhill.

Ordered their gnocchi, which arrived smelling richly of eggs.  They looked like swollen egg yolks, and tasted just like yolks that have been boiled.  They smelled pretty gross.  Others at the table thought the same after sampling: "simply disgusting." $12.

One thing everyone know about zuni is that you get the ceasar, or the roast chicken, or if its late, get the $15 burger.  Arriving after 10 on a Saturday, I was told they were out of hamburger. Ok.... So I got a $26 chicken dish.  It was good, but no better than something my wife and I can make, the portion was small and full of little tiny bone fragments which were only discovered after popping a piece. For $26 give me a lot of chicken with some bones, or a little piece that doesn't have surprises of cartiledge and ribs.  Total rip-off. I mean, chicken for $26?

The waiter forgot my wifes $5 fries. He admitted it and they came 10 minutes after I finished my dinner (and that was after politely waiting for another 10).  Well, I thought, surely they will take this little item off the bill, which has happened many times at other well-regarded restaurants. Nope, not in Zuni's case.  And the fries were hard little sticks.  Coul have been from a bag.

We ordered the "lamb's lettuce salad with parsley, pepper rubbed croutons blah blah"  It came and I thought I was at Denny's.  A few leaves of lettuce, some dressing, and that was it.  For $10. Come on.  At least at chez panisse that could pull that off. But not here.

Before dinner my wife asked the bartender for a recomendation with rum (they have no cocktail menu). He thought about this for about 10 seconds and offered, "Rum Gimlet?"  Uh, you're the bartender at zuni right, not a college party-goer? Hm.  Then he asked us if we were dining with them. "yes." He promptly returned with our bar bill. 

Anyway, go to Quince, the prices are the same but the food and service is impeccable.
author: m. y.

description:
For me Zuni is like listening to the best of Toad The Wet Sprocket. Sometimes you forget about it entirely, but then one day you realize you're sick of Arctic Monkeys, LCD Soundsystem and Clap Your Hands Say Yeah, and you flip through your old CDs and you're all like, Woah, I haven't listened to this in a while. And then you listen to Toad The Wet Sprocket, and you're all like, Wow, this is STILL REALLY GOOD. Zuni's like that.

The only difference is that, while Toad broke up, Zuni is still together making sweet, buttery halibut, and pancetta wrapped guinea hen-breast Music.
author: J.D. W.

description:
great bloody marys
great oysters
enough said
author: City G.

description:
Anticipation is a beautiful thing. I anxiously awaited my meal at Zuni on our recent mini-stop through San Francisco. On our cabride there I had butterflies in my stomach like I was meeting a stranger across town for a first date. The place was truly lovely. The large, copper bar won me over. We were seated upstairs in a sort of loft type area with angled ceilings and a view of the street. 
Because we got there rather late, unfortunately too late for the legendary brick chicken, I ordered the scallops and D the pork chop. Though my dish was delicious, D's pork chop was fantastic. It melted in your mouth and paired beautifully with the apple sauce. It was so simple and rustic, but beautifully cooked. For dessert we shared the flourless chocolate cake, which was incredibly light and moist. The bread served before the meal was probably my only complaint about the meal. It was not fresh and tasted a bit stale. 
My favorite thing about the meal was seeing D's face after taking the first bite of his dish. It was a look of complete surrender and utter 
happiness--all that you can wish for from a meal.
author: veronica q.

description:
Excellent pre-ballet/opera/symphony place for a dinner date.  Really interesting place from an architectural/design perspective.  The place is rather narrow, but there are a lot of weird angles in the walls that make every table special.  

I enjoyed a glass of pinot noir to start and thought the caesar salad was outstanding.  I savored every last bit of it.  I selected the ricotta gnocchi and was surprisingly underwhelmed.  I had read so many spectacular reviews on Yelp about it that I was shocked I didn't enjoy it as much as many a diners before me.  It was the consistency of scrambled egg (and even a little bit yellowish), which was "odd" to me.  But perhaps my palate is just not sophisticated enough.  The mushrooms that served as garnishes were great.  I did get to try a bite of the grouper, which was fantastic.  Small portion though, and by the end of the night we were hungry again.

Good service, very punctual but accommodating (we were about 15 minutes late).  Overall enjoyed Zuni Cafe and would recommend to friends looking for a classy place to have a bite for dinner.  Oh, and I'd love to try the roasted chicken that everyone has been raving about.
author: Lindsay M.

description: A San Francisco classic that I was not disappointed by!  Every expectation I had of Zuni Cafe was met.  The service was prompt and friendly.  The food was fresh, fresh, fresh.  What else is there to know?  I think everyone has said something good about Zuni, and I'm sure they've said it better than I have.
author: Christie L.

description: Best hamburger I've ever had... twice!  I also LOVE the ketchup that they put out for the fries and burger.
author: Jennie Y.

description: Fancy Shancy right on Market street surprisingly can still find parking around there. Kind of pricey, but worth it. I went there with a couple of other friends, we had our dinner in the waiting area - they have some tables there which are not as well decorated but what the heck, I want the food and now ! But now is a very subjective word when you are at Zuni, cauz you when you are there, you do want to eat their famous chicken, yes you do and yes it does take the whole hour. Even if the waiter tells you he will get it on immediately and it will be there sooner, dont expect it and rightfully so, how else would you make something like chicken taste good ;) . One of the softest and juiciest chicken I have ever had, so make sure you order it as soon as you get there and then pass your time with other tit bits, like we did with oysters and wine :) !
author: Varun G.

description: What can I say...I really really.  really.  like this place. It's a San Francisco institution for a reason!  BUT, follow the reviews and stick with the standards.  I've been several time and keep coming back to a delicious classic cocktail (Manhattan, anyone?), some oysters, classic caesar, and the roast chicken.  The staff is extremely knowledgeable and helpful, even when its insanely busy (which it always seems to be).  -1 star for it being super hot inside on more than one occasion and once-in-a-while slow service, but it could also be that we were sitting in one of their "nooks" where the air didn't hit.  Nothing a bottle of Bandol Rose can't fix =)  There's a reason this made the 7x7 list of things to eat before you die.  The roast chicken and bread salad really are THAT good.
author: Vijay N.

description:
i've been here a few times for lunch, once for brunch. i recommend getting a reservation so you don't have to sit in the corner alcove near the front door.

brick walls, wood-buring oven, and linen-covered tablecloths all add up to a comfortable and relaxing atmosphere. sometimes i fantasize about eating here and even go so far as to enter a time into opentable to see if it would be possible to get a reservation. 

lately (for the past 6 to 9 months) i've been ordering caesar salad everywhere i go. it is very good at zuni, nice croutons and a heaping amount of romaine. i would like the dressing to be a little thicker, have a little more substance, it seems like it's been pared down to be "healthy" but i think when you order a caesar salad you know what you're getting into, so bring it on! although, i hope you don't get the wrong impression, i do think their caesar salad is lovely and order it every time.

another food kick i've been on lately is scallops. whenever they are on the menu i can't resist ordering them. even though my BF is allergic to shellfish and it means we won't be sharing, i still order them. they were on the menu here on my birthday. i ordered them. they were absolutely fantasic. best scallops of my life.

another must order is a bloody mary, extra spicy style: 
  balsamic vinegar + diced red onions = quite tasty!
author: Sherry H.

description: I went to Zuni on pride weekend.  It was my first time since I moved here from Philadelphia.   I LOVED it!  We had a reservation but showed up for drinks almost an hour early and were seated 30 mins before our reservation.  Loved that the server took our drinks to the table for us...nice touch.  Our table was upstairs overlooking the raw bar.  The server was nice, fun, and was just amazing.  I had a few clams, and the burger...It was awesome. I know it's a bit pricey, but I can't wait to go back.  I've been reading so much about the roasted chicken...can't wait to try it!
author: Barry G.

description: Just before leaving SF for a work assignment, i finally made it to Zuni cafe for the roast chicken.  Did not make a reservation for Saturday lunch, but we were seated in 15 minutes.  The bloody mary drink was very tasty.  I usually don't order bloody mary because it tends to be medicinal in taste.  Zuni makes a great one, spicy and flavorful.  Now to the chicken...  It does take a very long time, a little bit over an hour, but the chicken was juicy and tender.  The frisee salad was also quite good.  Overall a great dining experience.
author: Yen T.

description: Our favorite place in the city for the chicken.  The Zuni chicken is delicious and worth the wait.  They also have a very nice selection of oysters and the shoestring potatoes are so good.  I am also a big fan of the espresso granita.
author: renee c.

description: Overall, I thought the quality of food at Zuni was good.  The menu says that their chicken dish takes an hour to prepare, but luckily it didn't take that long.  I really liked the pork roast dish.  I felt jipped on the chorizo appetizer-the serving wasn't too generous.  The prices were decent.  Our waiter was cute, so that made the experience pleasant.  It was a nice and quiet to chat and catch up with friends.  I'm not sure though if I'd go a second time.
author: Christine E.

description: I enjoy a trip to Zuni, whether it's a mid-afternoon burger or a late night post concert meal. The burger is one of my favorites in the city, and mind you, I consider myself connoisseur. On a recent visit, friends and I shared  a burrata, caesar, and piccolo fritto of California's finest veggies - all were great. Not the best Burrata ( I prefer A16), but still, we were happy. I dug into the spaghetti with bacon, onion, etc etc - this portion was much bigger than anticipated and I was satiated. As always, the espresso granita was a light, but revelatory ending to the meal. I think this is a solid place to stop at in SF - I wouldn't clamor for a peak hour resi, but this is one of my picks for a late al fresco lunch or a late night dinner.
author: Lee T.

description:
Simply delicious, and superb service.

I often come just for a light dinner with friends when we're out late and want something elegant and delicious but light.  the polenta with mascarpone is *amazing* and only $6, and you can pair that with oysters, or another starter.  and the huge windows make the space open and airy and light, and everyone here seems happy.
author: Dan J.

description:
There are a number of reasons why this was one of the best dinners ever.

1. Our waiter, Graham
2. The apple tart
3. Ambience

My friend and I went to Zuni to celebrate her birthday.  She had been trying to get here for dinner for the past 6 years, so we were both thrilled when we were seated in a table that overlooked the kitchen.  Usually, I don't want to have a view of the kitchen in a restaurant-not wanting to see what was going on behind the scenes.  But, it was quite fun to watch everyone preparing the food.  Our waiter, Graham, introduced himself and off we went into our 3 hour dinner.  The dinner wasn't 3 hours because it took that long to get our food.  We got all of our food very quickly.  The last 2 hours were  my friend and I talking and relaxing.  Graham allowed and ENCOURAGED us to stay as long as we wanted.  He was such a pleasure-unintrusive, but still courteous and inviting.  I had even stopped by earlier in the day to tell them that it was my friend's birthday.  When we walked in, the manager winked at me to let me know that he remembered, and he made sure to have a candle placed on my friend's dessert.  It was cute.  I will definitely be making Zuni one of my regular places to dine-especially since I just moved a block away.
author: Lisa H.

description: After completing an arduous semester over the summer, I decided I deserved a treat.  So after my last final, the boyfriend and I made our way to Zuni for a late lunch.  Our waitress was punctual, courteous, and the bartender made my cocktail exactly the way I wanted it.  I don't eat red meat often, but given my celebratory mood, I felt like having a nice steak which, unfortunately, was not on the lunch menu.  After letting my waitress know what I wanted, she immediately proceeded to the kitchen to find out if they could accommodate my request.  She returned and informed me that the kitchen could make it happen, but they would have to fire my order "right now."  I told her that wouldn't be a problem and ordered another Sidecar(with a splash of St. Germaine, hold the sugar) in preparation for my steak, which arrived at my table a perfect example of rare.  If I had a third thumb, I'd put it up for Zuni's atmosphere, selection, quality and service.  Good job, guys.
author: Steven F.

description: Amazing bloody marys and hamburgers.  I had to remove some stars because the menus were very dirty and the tables are covered in butcher paper...not very elegant for such an expensive place.
author: Irving B.

description: Brick Oven Roasted Chicken for two, a plate of fries and a bottle of Gruener Veltiner. It doesn't get much better than this.
author: A E.

description:
Came here for lunch the other day with a friend.  I've heard a lot about it, but this was my first time eating here.

We split the rabbit salad to start - it was absolutely delicious.

She had the salmon entree, which she said she enjoyed.

I had the famous burger, with heirloom tomatoes and grilled onions.  The only complaint I have is that it was so tall that there was no way I could possibly fit it into my (rather large) mouth.  After a couple half-hearted bites at the buns, since I couldn't reach anything else, I resorted to using my knife and fork.  Yes, I felt like an idiot, but I couldn't think of any better way to successfully eat it.  Fortunately, it was so good that I forgot my embarrassment as soon as I got a real bite of it.

Side note: the neighborhood is a little ... less than ideal.  I parked near and walked through what appeared to be a rather threatening gang on the way there, and when I got back they were all leaned against my car.  Distracted by my attempt to get back into my car without being mugged, I failed to notice the dead body (!!!) being covered with a sheet and loaded into an ambulance behind my car until I looked behind the car to back up.
author: Morgan M.

description: Yes, it is awesome.  Went about 3 weeks ago and am still dreaming of the roast chicken.
author: John K.

description:
Everything I wanted it to be and more. My 29th year, and I had high expectations, it could not have been more perfect. 
Possibly the most flawless dinner I have ever had. We got there and were seated right away, no usual SF wait despite a reservation. 
Our table was exceptional, as we were seated, we passed all of these great tables, and I kept thinking if our table is not as nice I will be bummed, but then on the horizon, a booth, on a level with only one other table, overlooking all the downstairs, the oven, the kitchen, the fire, the scene, appeared, and it was ours.
 By this point I was thrilled, and ZUNI and the fiancee had scored major points. We had martinis and the gnocchi app, and a pair of tomalas bay oysters, and then.......drum roll.......the main event, the chicken. 
Amazing, phenomenal, absurdly good, wow! Seriously, I make a mean chicken, and it is not even close, no chicken I have ever tasted comes close. It was so good it almost did not seem like chicken. 
We had kumquat caparihainis (sp) also amazing. I know, this all sounds over the top, well, it was. I honestly do not have one negative thing to say. 

Teddy, our waiter, was the BEST, I mean that. The best. He was informative, interesting, intelligent, funny, attentive, and all around great. We already have plans to go see Teddy again for lunch, to try the burger and Caesar salad. 
I never ever ramble on my reviews, so I want you to know, I mean this, this was, the best birthday dinner ever, and I think we may have to go back for the milestone next year. A perfect night!
author: Adrienne G.

description:
After all this time in San Francisco, I am both shocked and disappointed I had not come to Zuni earlier. I finally decided a visit by the parents was deserving of the occasion. I have envied this place for their ability to score a venue almost entirely wrapped with huge windows and great people watching on Market St. Needless to say, I was thrilled that we were able to sit in the corner of the restaurant, surrounded by windows. The lighting and ambiance were perfect. 

The bread was so good. I know it seems obvious to mention good bread in an SF restaurant, but this really was amazing. The wine list was extensive and I was able to find a really good bottle of Pinot for a very reasonable price. We ordered the gnocchi and fried beans and veggies for an appetizer. The gnocchi had an unusual flavor that I did not care for, but the fried garbanzo beans were shockingly amazing. The texture was really light and airy and they didn't feel too heavy. I decided to do it right since this was my first visit by ordering and patiently waiting for the chicken. Again, the bread stuffing accompaniment was amazing and the chicken was the most juicy thing  I have ever tasted. AMAZING. The steak and bass, also ordered at my table, were cooked to perfection and the flavors were spot on. To end, we shared an unusual espressoish, ice creamish dessert which seemed to try to hard to hit the 'inventive and unique' mark.

We had a later reservation and our dinner came to a late end (damn, but delicious chicken). As the night weaned to a close, the service fell apart in a big way. Our waitress simply forgot about our small party in the remote corner and could instead be seen in the kitchen having a good time with other wait staff. For a restaurant of such high iconic value in San Francisco (something I feel is necessary where there is so much delicious food and exceptional chef talent) I expected more on the service end. Way more.
author: Alicia J.

description: I enjoyed a rather drunken dinner here one night, after one too many drinks at Chaya, where the oysters and Chicken under a Brick really blew me away. But then I had brunch, and that was the icing on the cake. Go for brunch. Oysters, french fries, burgers, polenta - it's all fantastic. Be prepared to blow $50 a head if you order to your heart's content and add some Bloody Marys to the bill, but it is well worth it my friend.
author: Sarah R.

description: Ok I get it.  the food is really good.  the service is top notch.  The place has a classy feel.  But ... well, I guess the bar in SF is really high as i wasnt so sure that it was good enough to justify the price differential.  I liked it a lot.  But not in my top 10 I guess.
author: Fallon C.

description:
Zuni is a pretty solid restaurant.  I think it rests on its laurels far less than Chez Panisse, to whom I've given three stars for some sloppy cooking and service.  To me, this place is like the Susan Sarandon of SF restaurants.  Sure, there are a lot of hottie starlets that catch the eye, but Susan is still very attractive and very sexy, with the confidence of an older woman who knows what's what; she can show her serious acting chops in "Dead Man Walking" but also do light fare (ok, schlock) like the "Banger Sisters."  Zuni knows what it can do well--roast chicken, whole leaf Caesar, gnocchi, gateau victoire--and does them well without fucking around with trendy preparations and ingredients to draw in the crowds.  Zuni's Cali-Itali food suits serious, intimate dates or semi-raucous feasts with friends or a leisurely lunch alone, which explains a wide variety of people who fill the place day after day.

The restaurant space itself is a crazy quilt of odd-shaped rooms that can be frustrating or just right.  Some tables are tucked away in a corner perfectly, but sometimes you may find a steel beam between you and a dining companion at a table that's a crazy polygon custom cut to fit in a place that was probably not meant for a table.  Personally, I prefer to sit downstairs and will specify so when I make the reservation.  If you don't know the space, there's a good chance you might be unhappy with your table (don't wanna scare you, but it's true); try to be specific about your occasion if you don't want to end up at the table that's wrong for you.  

The food can be spectacular to satisfactory.  I tend to stick to the Zuni classics and I don't get disappointed.  My most favorite thing here is the Caesar salad made with whole romaine leaves, which I like to eat with my fingers.  The dressing is perfectly garlicky and anchovy-y and I always meticulously swab every molecule of it with the bread at the end.  The salad usually gets split between me and someone else; there isn't a time I didn't semi-regret I didn't eat the whole thing.  The roast chicken is legendary, but I don't order it since I now have the Zuni recipe and it'll cost 1/4 of what I'd pay at the restaurant.  Their stealth menu item is the ricotta gnocchi, which are the lightest cloud-pillows from dreamland.  It's not filling at all so you will inevitably have to dig into a snack after coming home, but the wonderment of eating something so ethereal and substanceless made of cheese and potatoes is worth it.  And even though the flourless chocolate cake thing has been done to death, the gateau victoire is still one of my favorites.  Also, their specialty cocktails are worth a try, too, though they have a pretty good wine list.

The service here can be efficient or it can be a hair short of disaster.  I've had great servers who never missed a beat, if a tad stodgy in their ways.  But I've had a mess of a server, for example, who entirely forgot to place our cold seafood platter order with the seafood bar, then was quite annoyingly flippant about it when she showed up with our entrees and we asked what happened to our appetizer.  This--unlike the seating which can be pre-arranged somewhat--is entirely up to the luck of the draw.
author: maiko h.

description:
Zuni, this is my go-to place and I love it!

I love the chicken, crispy on the outside moist on the inside, mmmmmmm.

They have never, ever failed with a fish dish - which I normally order. The burgers are good! The fries are perfect to share with a friend while having a glass of wine. I like their wine and oyster selections. And, their staff is kind and attentive, but not annoying.
 
If you want a lovely place to go, reasonable but not cheap, and consistently great - don't miss Zuni.
author: Diana B.

description: $48 for a roasted chicken and bread?!? My corner store has $4.99 rotisserie chicken and it's fabulous. Avoid this pretentious trap and its overpriced fare. Why was the waiter's nose in the air? Why are people so willing to drop $20 for a cheeseburger with grilled onions? The white bean/kale soup? Coulda done that better at home with some chicken stock and corner-market kale and beans. Don't be seduced by the urban-chic interior, the valet parking, or the chi-chi menu.
author: Skeeter M.

description: I love this restaurant.  The ambiance is fantastic, great wine list, great oysters, and the roast chicken is to die for.   My boyfriend, however, feels similar to the naysayers on this list.  What can I say, I think it lives up to the hype.  It's the quintessential SF restaurant, to me.  I have read a few reviews, though, that say that the first time dining at the restaurant was disappointing, but at the 2nd visit, it became clear why the place is such a legend.  *shrug* so, you may want to give it another chance.
author: Liz C.

description: Went with the crew CHA-CHING. Had a plate of Oysters to go along with a round of the best Margaritas in town. CHA-CHING. Chicken for two, times two and "Can we get another round of Margies??" CHA-CHING! CHA-CHING! CHA-CHING!  Delicious food...and Margies! CHA-CHING. "The price of civility: CHA-CHING!"  But hey it's Zuni.
author: Johnny C.

description: It was okay. The chicken was good but not worth $50. The cocktails are super expensive too. For a date night we walked with a tab of $175. Too much for this place - it is not that special...
author: Jenn S.

description: What is the hype about this place?  I honestly don't get it......I made a reservation at Zuni and went there to celebrate.  It took me way too long to get a beer from the bar.  After I was seated, it took way too long for the waiter to come to our table.  He forgot to bring us water.  I ordered the pasta.  I am sure that it was supposed to be al dente, but it was nothing special to me.  I mean, if I am going to pay so much for spagetti, I would like to see something special here......
author: Joanna S.

description:
My first date with my present husband of 20 years was at this restaurants. Moved to Marin and have eaten here a handful of times since then. Last night, we came in a group - 9 persons - at  8:45pm. WE asked to be seated together and they refused to accommodate us. The hostess refused to put 2 tables together saying "it's just not done" I asked if the tables were glued together but no, they are not.  There was another table next to these two and they still refused to do anything particularly since they actually put the first two tables together after all. So, 4 sat apart.  
The food was okay. Nothing exciting. The gnocchi was good but I've defintely had better gnocchi nudi in Italy, the burger was dry and unexciting considering there are tons of amazing burger places all over town, Caesar salad was okay, everything was so-so. Our waiter was great but the bus boy kept removing plates even when one of us was still eating away. Amazing....
So, okay food plus horrible reception equals never again! Buh-bye Zuni, thanks for the memories....
author: Belle C.

description: After going once and being disappointed at the slow service and mediocre food, I thought my experience must have been atypical. I mean, this place is a San Francisco establishment. After eating here three times, I have to say, I'm truly disappointed. The fresh, raw oyster selection is great. Otherwise, the food is very over-rated and the service pretentious.
author: Micki S.

description: My favorite restaurant- and I get around. If you have read my previous posts, you may know that I hate birds. Hate them. However, this does not apply to eating them- I figure each one I eat is one less in the world. Thus, I figure I am pretty much saving the planet via Zuni, one roast chicken at a time. Sure, I love the pristine oysters, the fluffy ricotta gnocchi, the burger with those flourescent house made pickles, the balsamic bloody mary, and the cheese, oh the cheese. But the chicken........join me in my mission!
author: David M.

description: The roasted chicken is the BEST!!!  Excellent service and infused vodkas make it one of my favorites in the city.
author: Lori M.

description:
Excellent food, decor, and service. I'd like to come back again soon.

Their signature dish, roasted chicken for two ($41): worth the one hour wait. Very juicy and flavorful, chicken fell off the bone. Bread salad underneath was my favorite part. 

Good for groups, or a date. 

Probably a good idea to get a bottle of wine while you wait for the chicken.
author: John c.

description: Went for a birthday celebration as a party of seven w/ reservations that I made over a month in advance.  Got there and had to wait for table (but not a big deal).  Got seated.  Waiter messed up drink orders (ie forgot 2 had to repeatedly reorder to get).  Then messed up salad orders gave my salad to someone else and never brought their salad order.  Brought my entrée with everyone else's salad and soup service.  Didn't get two of the entrée orders into kitchen so everyone was done w/ food before theirs came.  Comp'd us all deserts do to the problems but food was small, and bland and both orders of the roasted chicken were overcooked, and dry with the chicken portion dwarfed by a pile of stale bread soaked in grease -- labeled a Tuscan bread salad. so really not worth the hassle especially since there are so many awesome places to eat in the bay area.  Will not be back.  For the same price would much prefer going back to Hubert Keller's Fleur de Lys (where the food was awesome and the staff well trained) and the Chef very gracious.
author: Be J.

description:
I went here last summer. I love the inside, its like casually fancy. That whole, you can wear jeans but your dinner is going to be a few hundred dollars. 
The evening was characterized by several firsts. My first oysters, my first sea bass, my first cognac and my first austrian chef sex. 
I came here with two chefs from NYC so I knew they would direct me well. We started with some champagne and then we were seated. The service was good, not too annoying, the way some nicer restaurants can be, they kind of gave us suggestions but didnt get up our asses about the like way the wine will mix with your saliva. 
We started out with oysters and I have to say I really dont get the point of them, but they were chill, I didnt gag at all, and for someone who gags when they brush their teeth, thats saying alot. Then I had some bomb salad and I ordered the steak, which was good but would have been better if they hadnt thrown a gallon of sea salt on it. The Austrian had the sea bass, which was very good, not fishy or weird at all. If I went back I would get that or the steak sans the salt.
author: Lacey P.

description:
late night burgers never tasted so spectacular!

and the service and staff are great too....
author: David F.

description: Zuni is my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, period. It's a perfect mix of classy and contemporary, and the food and service are always dependably top notch.
author: Andrew C.

description: I like going to Zuni for brunch on Sundays. The best bloodies and oysters! yum!!
author: Caroliina F.

description:
i love zuni cafe.  came for a late-ish (9p) sunday dinner this weekend and was reminded why this place is such a san fran institution.

the copper bar. gorgeous.

caesar salad. to die for.

roast chicken. far and away the best in the city. the bread salad soaks up all the yummy juices and the currents and pine nuts add crunch and additional depth to the salad.  the chicken is perfect, juicy, flavorful - the skin crisp and not too salted.

minus one star: COME ON!!! just serve the burger during dinner already!!! and my polenta was just ok.
author: Brooke M.

description: Zuni Cafe is a great place to enjoy wonderful food.  Some of the things on their menu include chicken, pizza, and oysters for those with a richer taste.  If the San Francisco sun happens to be out they have tables and chairs outside for your dining pleasure.  Zuni Cafe also serves drinks and is a  great place to have a leisurely meal.
author: Allen Y.

description: went here last weekend. our waitress was fantastic, friendly and got our order in quickly since we wanted the share the roasted chicken. had a glass of wine and a bowl of polenta with marscapone. delicious. my friend got the anchovies. the olives and other sides with it were delicious even with the anchovy oil! finally our roasted chicken came out. very very good. but like some have mentioned it is a bit undercooked the bigger pieces. the wings and drumsticks were perfect though. took the leftovers home and nuked for lunch the next day and it was perfectly fine. the only reason i did not give 5 stars was that even though we made reservations we still had to wait almost 20 minutes to be seated. let me also mentioned we had 6 pm reservations so it was well ahead of the dinner crowd.
author: Jen C.

description: Does Zuni really need another review? I've always made it a point to visit everytime I'm in the bay area. It's by far my favorite restaurant here so I am biased. We started off the dinner with oysters, manila clams, then proceeded to ricotta gnocchi with pea sprouts, and of course finished with the roasted chicken. We didn't sit in the restaurant but at the bar area and it was great for people watching. Our server was knowledgeable and intuitive. Knew exactly when we needed tending to and when to leave us alone - it was impressive along with her enthusiasm for the food. I am yet again impressed.
author: Teresa H.

description: Went for drinks. My friend ordered dinner. She says the food was good and had the halibut cheeks. Our waiter was excellent but I'd have to say that the place is a bit pricey and the bartenders downstairs were a tad uppity and inattentive. Not sure if I want to go back. But hey, if someone else is paying, I'm game!
author: Heather L.

description: It's quite small, service wasn't bad but wasn't the best. Food was good but not great. They are famous for their chicken that takes like over an hour to cook. So you resort to ordering appetizers and what not. For the price we're paying, the food wasn't that plentiful nor that great. Again, the service was just lackluster too. They seemed busy and you do need reservatons, but I wasn't very impressed with the place overall unfortunately. The chicken was good and decent size but I could have gotten the same thing at Boston Market.
author: Sarina A.

description: Ok here's the deal, I THOUGHT I had already reviewed this place cause I go here all the time, but then I double checked and NADA, so here I go.  I really like this place, and though others have given it less than glorious reviews, the food is excellent and the alcohol selection is fabulous if a bit esoteric.  They have great bourbons on the list and their oysters are always fabulous.  This is my favorite place to eat right now, ok I admit it is walking distance from my house...BUT I recommend this restaurant as a great place for a date, business meeting, dinner or brunch with parents...well you get the picture.  This gets my vote as best "all around" restaurant.  That, and the bartenders always will give you samples of wine and bourbon if you "don't know" what to order....
author: Claire C.

description: We always have great date nites here..  Love the rustic ambience and the food has yet to disappoint...
author: Rose C R.

description: Took my friend there for a birthday dinner last night. Tried their signature roasted chicken which was amazing. I also learned that squab is actually a farm raised pigeon (who knew). Still get the idea out of my head about eating a bird that Bert once sang about. But I digress, the caesar salad was excellent as well. Just be careful trying to catch a cab home - I had to walk over to Franklin to finally flag one down.
author: Derek B.

description:
I have heard tell of the Zuni burger for quite a while now. Not available on the dinner menu, the burger is available from 10-12 Friday and Saturday nights for those of us who choose to drink and then eat.  I stopped in at 1030 last night to experience the burger after some vino at Hotel Biron (which I love). 

Overall Burger Rating: 8/10
Burger: The burger was perfectly cooked medium rare. The beef was good and I am sure from some small village where they pray to the cows every day before shoveling triple cream fondue down their gullets and offering them afternoon cocktails of Dom Perignon prior to their massages.
Bun: This was a cause of controversy, as the burger is served on Foccacia bread. My burger tasting partner loved the foccacia. I, on the other hand, had issues with the burger sliding out of the foccacia, which resulted in uneven bites of burger. Also, the foccacia made my fingers oily. 
Toppings: The usual preference of cheddar was unavailable, so I was forced to order the burger with Gruyere and grilled onions. While the Gruyere didn't have quite the zip that I prefer with cheddar, it was fine. The grilled onions had a nice vinegary bite to them, but they were so thickly cut that they fell off the burger and onto my plate more often than is to my liking.
Sides: The french fries were crispy and awesome. Shoe string thickness and piled like a foot high. We shared an order and argued over whether they were the best fries in SF, or simply number #2 (I feel like Balboa Cafe's are better).
Notes: Each burger was 17.50 and the side order of fries was six bucks. So even sharing, this burger experience well exceeded 20$ per person, which makes this burger the most expensive that we have had in the city. Certainly, a nice splurge for an insider food experience, but not enough for me to bypass the chicken for two the next time that I find myself at Zuni.
author: Matt C.

description: I never liked caesar salads until I tried one at Zuni. But there are many things to love...the pizzas, the roasted chicken for two, the shortribs, the showstring fries and the location! Fresh quality food...what's not to love.
author: Sara W.

description: Guess what?  It still works.  Zuni still blows my mind with its consistency and quality.  Margies and fries, Caesars and oysters, gnocchi and burgers...all of it just as good as ever.  Nothing better than sitting in the bar with friends drinking up a storm and enjoying the people watching...Yep, Zuni still does what it does very very well.
author: chris b.

description: Ate here last night and both food and service was SO disappointing.  Even the Margaritas shrunk, served in tiny martini glasses at $13 each - skip them!  Our server was horrible, so unprofessional; he was  definitely not interested in providing any type of service. The anchovy appetizer with celery (normally a favorite) was just plain sad looking, limp, hardly any celery, dripping in oil.  Sent back the fishy smelling King Salmon, served barely warm, a strange thin strip of salmon served with beets; no apologies, no nothing; our server could have cared less, the Hangar steak was not much better.  Obviously the meat sat a long while before it was brought to our table.  We had already eaten our two measly thin slices of  bread while waiting 30 minutes for our main entrees, and the server looked pained when we asked for more, really?  Left him the tip he deserved, we won't be back for a while - just a bad night?  Ugh.  All could have been saved with a professional server, but this was not to be.  The secondary service was spot on, whisking away dishes, and filling our water glasses.
author: Chris H.

description:
the chicken here is what everyone claims - bloody amazing! no crazy complexities, but it's so true to what chicken should taste like, that you never walk away unsatisfied.

The hamburger was excellent, but doesn't beat Bistro Aix or Absinthe's burgers

The REAL REASON d'etre for soming to zuni is the dessert - the piccollo meringue is sooo good that i often find myself ordering a second batch
author: Jerome, Jerome T.

description: All Time San Francisco Favorite.  Awesome Food and fantastic atmosphere.  Every time I eat here, I meet really interesting people, and I'm in still in contact with them!  Eat at the bar, share your food and make some cool new friends.  Ceasar Salad, Polenta, Oysters.....
author: Luka D.

description: How many restaurants can say they've been around for 20 years? Props to Zuni for just being Zuni - serving crisp cocktails and dee-licious food. Chicken for 2, kumamotos, Ceasar, shoestring, garlic capons, and on and on. Great for lunch, dinner and a late night snack. I do miss their breakfast - poached eggs on prosciutto on toasted rustic bread. Well, you can try it at home. Though the scene has changed over the last decade, it's still an SF classic.
author: Lizelle G.

description: I can't add anything special about this place except that it is a perennial B+ restaurant.  One of the more interesting rooms in an off location....The wood and glass architecture makes this place a remarkable place for drinks and dinner.
author: Laurence H.

description: Must order the roasted chicken, however be prepared to wait for 45 mins, that's how long it takes! But very worthwhile....mouth-watering and so tasty and tender!
author: Yan M.

description: I went last month for the first time and although the service was amazing....the food was just soso. I really really wanted it to be wonderful and amazing but my gnocci was way too salty and my date had some pasta that was overcooked. I will go back again and give it another chance. I really enjoyed that atmosphere and the great envirornment.
author: Emily L.

description: Finally, we got a chance to try out Zuni Cafe, which has been on my list to try for a long time.  The decor was pretty laid back with floor to ceiling windows everywhere and natural woodbeams.  The bar looked fabulous with its copperish counter and innumerous bottles of liquor.  The Caesar salad was super tasty with little bits of anchovy o accent the roman luttuce and light dressing.  Yum!  We also tried their signature Roast Chicken with Bread salad entree, fit for 2.  While it was good, I'm not so sure it was worth an hour wait.  All in all, I'll definitely go back.
author: Jeannie L.

description: Zuni Cafe is a San Francisco institution.  Their roasted chicken for two with the bread salad is well worth the 40 minute wait.  Great desserts and wine selection.  I love the open kitchen because you see Chef Judy Rodgers and her staff in action.   Make sure to make reservations either by calling  or through open table because it will be difficult to get a table.
author: Belle M.

description: Well, Zuni was pretty good, with nice bread, good wines and salads, but they don't have good vegetarian options at all!
author: Jenni S.

description: Zuni Cafe was very nice.  I'm not sure if theres much else I can describe that hasn't been said in the past 400+ reviews.  Though, I felt that the food could have been better.  The quality of the ingredients were top notch, yet  overall the whole meal seemed a bit thrown together.  The server was very nice but not very attentive even though there was quite a bit of open seating.  I do see why so many people love Zuni Cafe, it was enjoyable.  I probably will be going back again as this place does have a nice overall appeal.
author: Paige C.

description: The atmosphere here is energetic and trendy.   Great place for before or after dining during opera or ballet season.   Definitely make reservations or else the wait may be pretty long.    I love the high ceilings and the various seating areas they have throughout the restaurant.  Has a classy but modern feeling.  The food is yummy, but somewhat overpriced in my opinion.  Good place to hang out with a group of friends who have good taste.
author: Vickie Y.

description:
the bad: hostess and waitress were very unfriendly.  no smiles from either.  waitress rarely checked on us.  drinks took about 10 minutes.  polenta with mascarpone was decent at best.  
the good: roasted chicken, pork chop, ceasar salad and shoestring fries.
would i go back? for the chicken, pork chop or burger and fries yes.  i may consider getting it for take-out instead though due to the service.
author: fernando o.

description: way way overhyped. my gf and i had their famed chicken. It was good, and the portion size was such that it yielded four servings, but we don't think the taste deserves the hype. would not revisit.
author: j d.

description: The Chicken for two is amazing. If you are looking for a late night snack, get the Zuni burger. If you go for lunch on a hot day, don't sit upstairs.
author: Raymond M.

description: Zuni is a San Francisco classic.  There is something about the long copper bar, floor to ceiling windows, extensive oyster selection, and brick oven combination that just make me feel all warm and happy inside.  The wait staff is extremely knowledgeable and professional, and guess what?  The bar stocks Boodles.  They also have a lovely selection of French champagnes and one of our favorite zins, the ol' Green & Red.  My husband's been known to take a hostage just to share the roasted sage chicken for two (because I don't eat meat), and I always go for the classic caesar followed by one of the small plates, like that AMAZING, SUPER FLUFFY, LIGHT AS AIR gnocchi featured from time to time.  The rotating art gallery and random celeb sightings are also a plus.
author: Julie B.

description:
This place really deserves 5 stars, but I'll tell you why in a few minutes. The food was exquisite!! I had a caesar salad for starters and it was fabulous! I've never had a cesar salad quite like they had it. Then came the pot roast. Oh my god, talk about mouth watering, flavorful delight! The best pot roast I've ever had! The meat melted in my mouth.... Dee-li-couuus!!!  Everything was excellent, the server was awesome, he knew all the ingriedents and how it was prepared and he was very attentive. So after the meal, we order dessert. We ordered a meyer lemon tart. It looked delicious, but when we put our forks in it, it was hard as a rock. I'm not kidding! ..it was very tart and I was very disappointed with the dessert. I mean, think about this, you go to a high class restaurant, the food is fabulous, the drinks are fantastic, but when you get to the dessert, it ruins everything. The last thing you remember when eating at a restaurant is usually the dessert. 
So have dinner there, try the post roast or the chicken. Just don't order the dessert!!
author: Dhoris P.

description: Beautiful setting, excellent pork loin, and an asparagus soup that promises you the sunshine of spring is right around the corner.  All this and a hot, I mean hot, chef working his magic in front of the wood-fired oven.  Champagne over an early dinner sometime?
author: Grave Y.

description: Zuni is great for it's oysters, their pasta appetizer, and their burger! I would give them a better rating except for that when I took my mom out for a special occassion, it was packed and the wait was like 2 hours. Ok a bit much for a burger yah?
author: K T.

description: Is this still the default first date spot?  Zuni is a little too overwhelming for me but I still like it.  It's loud and crowded and it can be difficult to find a spot at the bar.  I like to go in for dinner.  Food has always been excellent but a bit pricey.  It's a neat space too, go and check it out...Don't forget your wallet though. Even though the last time I was there my date argued with me the entire time I still enjoyed the experience.  She even argued with me when I paid for the dinner and offered to take me out "next time".  Of course there wasn't a next time...
author: Spidermonkey J.

description: Signature burger is amazing.  Great service and setting (ample natural light with windowed facade and high ceilings).
author: Tapatio S.

description: I like this place, although, I have had some mediocre food.  I think I just like the space so much.  Oh, and the poor busboy/waiter? that fell 3 times going up the stairs!  Poor guy.  Must have been new.  He handled it fairly well, but the 3rd time was a doozy.  Food went flying everywhere!  It was funny, but you really had to try hard to not giggle because that slip truly seemed to bruise his ego a bit.   I think you can get better food elsewhere, but you're not going to get all the lovely daylight during the day or the neat layout.  The service was EXCELLENT too.  Wish I could remember our waiter's name.
author: Kerry L.

description: The chicken is always great and perfect. it reminds me of a cafe in Paris. Also they always serve great bread , great drinks and a good selection of Oysters also. Yummy, always a great place, you can count on them for great quality and there burger is pretty good also.
author: P C.

description: Holy freaking savings account. Went for oysters and bloody marys which were both really tasty - worth five stars easily. But seriously...over $100 for 1.5 dozen oysters, 4 bloodys and a plate of fries. STFU.
author: Kate S.

description: Great restaurant, a lot of fun to go with some friends. The hour chicken is awesome, the fries are amazing, pretty much everything i have had here is out of this world. The service was very good as well. Will have to try and get here for lunch to try the burger though.
author: Stephen K.

description: Dessert was a subtle Cowgirl Creamery fromage blanc with olive oil.  Even the waiter was impressed with their grape juice.  I wish they had fruits de mer that night.  The server only remembered 8 out of the 10 oysters I ordered.  Turnip and greens soup was unmemorable but wine duck crostini is really good when they have it.
author: Ai M.

description: The chicken? Yeah, it's good. But the oysters...WOW! So fresh, and buttery and at a good price. The drinks, they're a little on the expensive side. We could have had a few more anchovies in the appetizer, but it was good nonetheless. The overall dining experience was pretty good. The wait staff was nice and attentive. If you plan on coming here, make a reservation. Eat happy, don't wait.
author: Tan N.

description: I loved every bit of my experience here.  I was in town visiting a friend, so we decided to splurge for one lunch (on her dad's credit card).  They had no tables free inside, so we sat outside - luckily the weather was not too bad.  The service was amazing.  Our waiter was so friendly and nice without being overbearing in the least bit.  We had brought our own wine, which was accompanied by a $20 corking  fee.  I thought that was a bit high, but whatevs I wasn't paying.  I had the sockeye salmon which was perfectly cooked and left me feeling full but not gross.  I loved that everything on the menu was sustainably grown!
author: Samantha G.

description: I went here last night with my friend and we had a wonderful time. Our table was fantastic. We were both facing the open kitchen and they put on quite the show for us. This was perfect since the chicken takes an hour, so we were thoroughly entertained. I had the pinot noir, a delicious 05' bottle, mm, it went great with the roasted chicken. The Oysters were perfect and the garlic vinegar dip they serve them with hit my pallet just right. I recommend this place for a great night out on the town.
author: Brittani M.

description: As my friend states, "it's the most incredible chicken in the world...and I usually don't eat chicken." That says something. That not only made me incredibly curious, but it set the expectations high. I needed to eat this chicken. Let me just say that he was right. It took an hour to prep this chicken, but it was definitely worth the wait. It was probably one of the best chicken dinners I've ever had. Better than the half chicken at Limon.  7x7 should put this in their "100 things to try before you die." It was incredible. Cooked with breadcrumbs, scallions, currants and pine nuts, it has a suculent, juicy flavor to each bite. One of those meals that turns heads every time someone orders. One of those meals that makes you say "mmmm so good" without even thinking. One of those meals that remind you of those great family holiday dinners that made you wait impatiently for the food to be cooked. While you wait for your amazing chicken, try their squid stew and tomato soup appetizers. Zuni is a place--despite it's price--that will keep you coming back for more. Will keep you curious to try new things, despite how tempting it will be to order chicken again. Zuni is a great space, intimate, inviting. It will not disappoint.
author: Alex H.

description: I don't know why other reviews complained about the service. I thought it was amazing. When the hostess brought us to our table and I knocked over my wine getting in (yes, I'm a natural born klutz), they whisked away the table setting, cloth etc. and redid it all in half a minute. Then they replaced the wine I spilled with another glass. Our waiter was super friendly and helped us navigate the choices--I can't eat gluten and my husband is vegetarian. He gave a really good description of the various oysters and I sampled several based on his recommendations--they were spot on and I greatly enjoyed them. My husband loved their version of french fries: very finely sliced and crunchy. They didn't have a large number of choices for him that night, but he was more in the mood for small plates anyway and they had several nice sides/salads, etc. that he enjoyed. They also had some great wines. The best part was the dessert. Usually I'm lucky if I can get creme brulee on the menu; typically desserts are a wheat-filled desert for me. Zuni had a flourless chocolate cake that was to die for, and my husband got the tiered merengue dish (which naturally I sampled, since it was also gluten free). They also had sorbet, ice cream and creme brulee, so I had lots of very tasty choices. I would have given 5 stars if they'd had a veggie entree, but the waiter said they usually did (we came on a Sunday night). We will definitely be going back!
author: Julie B.

description: Always fantastic - great food and service. So hard to get in though! When I actually do manage to get a table, I am always happy. The chicken is exceptional, the oysters are tasty, the produce is fresh...it's just good old fashioned yummy. Love the friendly servers - they are fun and have good recommendations, very knowledgeable. One of my favorites.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Yes, I've had their chicken. Yes, it's delicious. Yes, I always feel guilty for having paid that much and having waited that long for...chicken. Yes, I lick my fingers after eating it. 

Everything is just too over-priced, and service is lackluster. That's about all I have to say about this place.
author: Lemon S.

description: best roast chicken i have ever eaten. that's all.
author: lex s.

description: Good Hang out place for friends. Long bar for you to drink while waiting for tables. Good selections of fresh oysters & clams. Decent Food. Be sure you have reservation. Wait could be outrageously long.
author: cynthia l.

description: If you go for the soup and pasta of the day you will never be disappointed although I am still trying to figure out what nettles are...regardless, Zuni makes em damn tasty.
author: Marils R.

description:
purely simple delicious food
Update 5/8/06: Ricotta Zeppoles with Strawberries and Pistachios....oh sweet jesus. 
Update 3/11/06:  Again, wonderful. I can't believe the consistent pleasure i get from the food at Zuni, and i'm so thankful for it. Tonight, dining solo, I had cold roasted leg of lamb with gribiche (perfectly lambie and not too gamey) with beets and salad (perfectly dressed). it was absolutely delicious. this was accompanied by a glass of billecart brut as were the sensual Bellwether Farm Ricotta Gnocchi with Nettles and Lemon Oil.  God, they just melt away in your mouth...and everytime i have the ricotta gnocchi, i have to force myself to stop....leave some...and leave room for the other courses.  Sadly, when i'm all alone, i can't have too much food and there are always tons of items on the menu that i know i would have adored.  Tonight, for having chosen the lighter dinner, and not opted for the Italian style beef pot roast which was beckoning strongly on this cold and wet night, i rewarded myself with dessert, and ohhhhh was i rewarded. Recently, i have been reminded of something i once told my family a long time ago when we were dining at Chez Panisse for the first time...That in my opinion, a great chef/restaurant was one that could make you love something that you thought you hated. At some point since then, I lost that outlook, and started ordering only my favorites at my favorite restaurants, rarely adventuring into lesser knowns. This was due to the fact that i work nights, and so when i go out for dinner, i want to be happy, guaranteed. Well, sure, i was at one of my favorite restaurants, but this time i didn't get the guaranteed pleasers: espresso granita, nor the chocolate pot de creme, nor the biscotti, nor anything else except for the pine nut tart with creme fraiche ice cream.
