Now, here's the deal...I hate pinenuts, and there is really nothing in the food world that i hate, but i HATE pinenuts, and this tart was sooooo good.  the ice cream was perfect as well. it was tangy and not too sweet, the essence of creme fraiche... and the delamain  i had to finish everything taught me a lesson:  wonderful cognac doesn't have to be the most expensive one on the list. the delamain is so pretty. now that i've loosened my ties a little, i think that next time i'll try one of the grappas. hopefully, next time i eat at zuni; they will have something that i am not very fond of so that i can be converted to it too.
author: sarah C.

description: Zuni Cafe on a Friday night was an ok place for the price.  I like how you can sit outside and drink and smoke if you would like.  The wine choice was good, the gin and tonic, well I had to give the  order then the waitress has to confirm that it was gin and tonic.  She thought that meant with soda but the bartender explained it to her.  My dirty martini was strong but I was not impressed with the bitter olives with puts and the wooden toothpicks.  I thought that was really odd and I was not impressed.
author: Nikki W.

description: Had a great meal here last night. I've been here several times before and am always pleased by the service and the food. The food doesn't ever make me go, "WOW", but it's always good and reliable. I had the fresh porcini and arugula salad, which was delicate and delicious and then the sea bream with clams in a romesco sauce, also very, very good. It's definitely a San Francisco institution for good reason. There's also a pleasant buzz to the place.
author: Pierre K.

description: Love love love. This place is really cool.. I love the way it is laid out, especially the upstairs. One time I got a private dining room for two friends and I...it was quite an experience!  I have been here a dozen times and each time it gets better. Oysters are always fresh.. the bread is always tasty and the chicken.. is oh so worth the wait. The wine list is great and I love the chocolate dessert..
author: A I.

description:
Excellent California meets Mediterranean meets rustic French cuisine in a really cool space.  The food is near flawless.  The service is top notch.
  
Zuni has one of the top oyster selections in San Francisco.  The caesar salad has been voted the best in San Francisco.  The signature baked chicken over bread salad is so rustic and so fabulous.  The roasted chicken is served over the bread salad, and the drippings add the perfect flavor to the dish.  Desserts are great.  Wine menu is great.  

It is simply a great restaurant.  Reservations take some advanced planning, so no last minute dining here.
author: t l.

description:
I don't know how the opinions can be so far apart.  Zuni has been a consistent performer for myself and my family, in particular my daughter.   We are a family that loves to eat out and as Olivia worked her way through the International High School around the corner on Oak Street we celbrated at Zuni at the end of every school year.
Well this weekend was graduation and Zuni did not let us down.  Appetizers were stellar, their ceasar salad is such a classic, the featherweight ricotta gnocchi and for me, thinly thinly slized porcini with roasted hazelnuts and a very fresh olive oil drizzle.  Mains were great all around, the tuna confit pasta, salmon with artichokes and preserved lemons and scallops with fresh spinach.  Top it off with another one of their classics, the espresso granita.  THe food is clean and classic.  The service was just a shad under where it should be and I had to pour the wine a few times.  For that reason only it can't quite get to 5 stars.
author: Jules K.

description: This is the best restaurant around.  The food is amazing and I think it keeps getting better.  I love the roasted chicken, but I find myself craving the hamburger more than any other menu item in the city.  If Zuni has a flaw it's probably the service, but that's pretty much true of any restaurant around.  Good servers are hard to find.  I think their wine service could use and update too.  They have a good list, but it would be nice if there were more options by the glass.  Also, what's with their glasses?  They must be a relic from 1990.  Who wants to drink a $100 bottle of wine from a glass that's made for guzzling Chianti.  Other than that, Zuni is almost perfect!
author: Ezra Y.

description: Oddly enough, I've never gone here for dinner. I usually go here for a weekend lunch. Pluses include: being in a structure surrounded by windows in the daytime, one of the freshest raw bars in the city, great service, and really good modern food. I've even eaten lunch standing at their bar being served drinks from their extremely knowledgeable bar staff. Although I wonder what ever happened to the paper straws they use. Their bloody mary is top top top. Favorite dishes are usually a pizza and their hamburger. One of these days I'll do the roast chicken.
author: Clodel G.

description: Do not go here for brunch!  First of all, they only have like four eggy items...and none were that exciting.  I had the crostone which is basically 1 slice of sopping wet bread with sauteed kale and one poached egg.  It was not filling, not tasty, and definitely not worth $14.  My girlfriend had scrambled eggs with Gruyere. Nothing special.  Even the bloody mary and mimosa were not that good.  Also, the service was interminably slow.  In sum...overpriced, overrated, inattentive, and underwhelmed!
author: Regan P.

description: If you love San Francisco as much as I do, you'll love Zuni because Zuni is San Francisco. The food is great, the cocktails perfect and the service simply impeccable (If I owned a restaurent, I would have my staff come and watch Rob and his team and learn! ). I've come to Zuni on and off for the last 15 years and have fond memories. Have champagne or a great cocktail at the bar, incredible bloody marys and brunch on week-ends, Oysters and champagne with a date. Enjoy, this is as good as it gets.
author: armand d.

description: One of the first places we visited upon moving to this great city. There was a lot of hype about it - great food, great scene, bla, bla, bla. I wasn't impressed. I can't remember what we had and all I remember is the lack of parking and the standing-room-only bar.
author: Eric G.

description:
love the space...big gigantic windows from floor to ceiling (up to 2nd floor).  enjoyed looking in and watching people from the outside, and equally enjoyed watching the street scenes throughout dinner.  also loved the open kitchen, you can literally take a few steps and you're right there alongside the guy in charge of the roasted chicken station.

my bf did some research and we decided we couldn't pass on the famous roasted chicken for 2 (takes an hour, but ours came out in 45min).  it was juicy and good, but i think we both loved the bread salad better than the chicken.  YUM !

also known for the caesar salad....not that great, but it's a caesar salad so how different/amazing could it be?  a caesar salad....is a caesar salad.....is a caesar salad.  now we know.

i'd like to give it 4 stars, but the food didn't blow my socks off.  however, we did have a great dinner and enjoyed the experience.  i do like the fact that zuni's been around (and will probably be around for a long long time).  it's an SF fixture w/its "locally grown, what's in season" approach along the lines of alice waters/chez panisse

To Do: would love to come back for brunch on a weekend on a sunny day with all that light coming in through the windows and watching the people on market st
author: Nana S.

description:
ah, zuni.  

if you're in the civic center area, and want to splurge a bit, walk past hayes, go down to market, and find yourself a seat here.  order the burger, with a side of shoestring fries, and prepare yourself for the experience to come.  

seriously though, the burger here is exceptional.  it's not a conventional burger, but you'll appreciate it nonetheless if you're a true meat lover/appreciator.  

why only 4 stars?  we sat upstairs and our service was a bit slow.
author: Matt P.

description: Definitely a fan.  My husband and I went here to celebrate our 3 year dating anniversary and we had a really nice experience. We took our chances by showing up without reservations and were able to be sat right away.  Not because they weren't busy, but because there was a cute table that had just opened up in the front half of the restaurant where the two huge windows meet to create that corner.  Our server was very attentive and friendly, starting us with champagne and oysters.  From the apps. to the entrees the meal was considerably solid, but nothing left me craving more.  I would definitely go back for the atmosphere and the oysters if nothing else.  It seems like a good place to go for after work drinks.
author: Kelly W.

description: Roasted Chicken! Seriously ... you have to try their roasted chicken when you come here. Make sure you order it right when you there because it takes about an hour to cook (I'm not exaggerating) ... but it is well worth the wait. You can munch on other things while you wait like their shoe string potatoes, pizza, salad, etc.
author: Vincent B.

description:
Zuni is good, but not THAT good...meaning not as good as the hype surrounding it.  Sure it's an institution in SF which is why it will always do well regardless of anyone's reviews. 

The food is just alright.  I can't complain about the quality of the food because the quality was just fine.  But that itself is also a problem.  The food is JUST alright, nothing more and nothing less.  I don't remember it being bad at all, but give me a few more weeks and I probably won't remember the food at all.  It's not memorable.  

We had the roast chicken because we heard rave reviews about it.  It took an hour to prepare, but we were aware of that because it was stated on the menu so no big deal.  The chicken, however, did not live up to its reviews.  Don't get me wrong, it was juicy and tasty, but not $48 worth of juice and taste.  I've had juicy and tasty roast chickens from other restaurants and all of them were far cheaper than $48.  The bread salad that the chicken was laid upon was delicious, though, but still did not merit the $48.  

Overall, it was just OK.
author: Josh C.

description: love the chicken for two (it's worth the wait), orecchiette, gnocchi & zuni caesar salad!
author: Kris P.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE! Service is amazing, the food was just as amazing. And as I was deciding what to get from their delicious dessert menu, I found out that my partner and I were sitting next to the crowned prince of Serbia and family!!! Just the icing on the Zuni cake. =)
author: drew L.

description: On several occasions, afternoon and evening alike, I confess to hoofing it on over to Zuni Cafe.  No, I don't eat moo there, my friend.  Instead, like a creature of habit, I tend to drift and order the same thing: raw oysters and  shoestring fries, which, in my personal estimation is simply the thing to eat at Zuni's.  The oysters are always fresh and cold with a hint of oceanic salt.  The fries are equally fresh but hot--and again, a bit of the salt.   It makes for the perfect balance.  Have a cocktail to go with it.  You will want for nothing else.  But here's my question--and I wonder if I am the only one who wonders this.  Once the waiter points to each variety of oyster and gives you its name, do you really care?  Does it really make a difference?  Or, like me, do you plunge right in, savoring and swallowing each lovely, slimy, shell-clinging oyster?  And which ones do you really like the best?  Big or small?  Or do you simply love them all?  Yum.  You be the judge.
author: Shadi G.

description:
I think people aren't going to like this, but here goes..

Took wifey to Zuni for her birthday yesterday. 

Though the place wasn't busy at all, and we had reservations, we were told to hang out at the bar whilst the three hosts did their thing. 

One of the things I like about drinks at posh restaurants is that, though expensive, they are usually pretty generous - in other words, doubles. Wifey got about the tiniest dirty martini I've ever seen, and I had an equally wee little Manhattan. $25 for two drinks containing less booze than I get in my neighborhood dive is not a good thing. 

We were pretty hungry and were very happy to be seated once we settled our bar bill. 

We ordered some oysters, periwinkles, and a plate of "house cured sardines" with cheese & kalamata olives. For our entree, we decided to split the much vaunted roast chicken for two, with their famous bread salad. 

The oysters, periwinkles, and sardines were lovely and reasonably priced. The roast chicken takes an hour to roast (no par-cooking at Zuni, I guess), which is a good thing because we were pretty full after our appetizers, but by the time the chicken came, we were hungry again. 

Now, about the chicken. An hour wait, a cost of $48, and the unflinching praise of an entire culture of foodies, means this has better be seriously good chicken. 

All I can say is, it's chicken. It was juicy. The skin was nicely colored and nice and salty (though the flesh was fairly bland). I do not know what all the hubub about this dish is. Seriously, I get equally good or better roast chicken out of my own kitchen. I've had tastier chicken href=http://www.yelp.com/search?find_desc=wright%27s+farm+restaurant&ns=1&rpp=10&find_loc=harrisville%2C+ri (too bad it's so far away), here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/chick-n-coop-restaurant-san-francisco-2 and here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/costco-south-san-francisco-4  for about 15% the cost of Zuni.

The service was always friendly, attentive, and quick. The waiter seemed a bit embarrassed and apologetic for the chicken taking so long, but we didn't complain. 

Overall, a pleasant experience, but the over-rated chicken and over-priced drinks make us not likely to go back.
author: fleurd d.

description:
While I probably don't need to come to Zuni Cafe too often, I'm glad I made the trip to this Hayes Valley spot - since I'm new to the city and exploring new neighborhoods.

We made a reservation on open table for 8:45pm on a Friday night about a week before. Parking... we got pretty lucky to find a spot on Market/Gough. Walked into the restaurant and it was huge from left to right and up. The ambiance is nice and up-scale, and I heard that this place has been in business since the 80's.

It gets chilly in there when they have th windows open all over, so definitely bring something warm to wear. And while we were not able to pre-order the chicken when the hostess called to confirm the reservation, we were able to order it when we walked into the restaurant prior to getting seated, to save us 15 minutes.

We were seated upstairs over the oyster bar with a view of the kitchen so we could see how all the food was prepared. Our server was really nice and offered recommendations to try (although it was borderline pushy just to sell additional items i.e. "You can't order 10 oysters, that's like bad luck. You have to get a dozen" or the "You must get the spaghetti!" and "I can't believe you're not getting dessert!"). So what we ended up ordering were 12 oysters (which were all high quality and awesome, though at least $3+ each). We got the spaghetti which did come with fresh tomatoes, but i'm not the type who likes my pasta al dente, or slightly hard.  The roasted chicken was another story, which was enough for our table of 4... and was so juicy and tender, and when eaten with the homemade stuffing. Yum. I never order chicken in restaurants but when it's known for the chicken, you know you have to get it. We also got two orders of the halibut. Perhaps due to the meatiness of the type of fish, we weren't blown away. But the sauce gave it a nice flavor.

Probably giving this place only 3 stars because I don't feel the need to come back again...but it was a good experience overall.
author: Jeanne C.

description: I can only review Zuni on their burger, so keep that in mind if you are considering having dinner here (the burger isn't on the dinner menu). Anyway, the actual burger/meat was outstanding, you could tell it was ground in Zuni's kitchen and that it was a high quality beef, but the rest of the burger really takes away from the meat. First off, the focaccia was a poor choice for a bun, and it couldn't stand up to the juiciness of the burger, and as a result,  the bun turned into mush. My other major issue with Zuni's burger is the price to value. Here's the thing, if you want to charge $15-$20 for a burger you should back-up the price, and not be skimping on the ingredients. I added the grilled onions ($1.75), the blue cheese ($2.00) and the heirloom tomato's ($2.50) which brought my burgers total to $21.25. Now, the price itself is bad enough, but its even worse when I can't taste the blue cheese, tomato's, or grilled onions... I mean, come on, they are $0.20 ingredients which you are marking up at least 5x, there is no need to ration them. Zuni's house made pickles are great, and believe it or not, don't cost extra $$. Their shoestring fries ($6) are also very good. The oyster selection is quite good, and everything was very fresh. If Zuni offered the burger on a traditional bun and loosened up with their portions, I would return... even if the prices didn't change, but this is unlikely to happen, so I probably won't be headed back any time soon.
author: Nick C.

description: This place is great! Decent prices and good atmosphere for being a little fancier than the normal place. I highly recommend the oyster bar if that's your thing. The mussel pasta dish and the roasted chicken are my favorites. You can even pick up a copy of their cook book so you can make their dishes at home.
author: Sal B.

description: An SF Classic? Yes.  Overrated? Yes.  The chicken is really good, but I like the chicken at Delfina even more.  The prices here are above where they should be as well.  The bar is a real scene.  The layout is what makes me enjoy this place.  The feng shui of the multi levels and how it just keeps going on and on is really cool, especially in SF.  Make sure to make reservations, or you might be sitting in that bar for a real long time.
author: Pele N.

description:
First of all, i LOVE thos building. The interior is exposed brick and beams. Lots of skylights. Lots of windows. Generally cool space to be in.

The staff here is super friendly. Service is a relaxed pace - but we told them we had a 7:30 show to make and they were very attentive to the time. 

The food is AMAZING. Best oysters I've ever had. The lamb is to die for. The food is super fresh, perfect protions, and the menu changes daily.

This is one of my favorite places to eat in SF.

Great place for a date - especially if your date is paying (bill was like $150 for two)
author: Kay T.

description:
The ultimate "San Francisco Experience", complete with trendy copper bar, pseudo-intellectuals in turtle necks and thick-rimmed glasses, gay punk posers, and Asian girls pretending to be Anglo-white yuppies.  Lot's of fun if you're in a mood to watch the freaks  and  be watched yourself. 

The food is great and so is the service. The staff made a mistake with our seating arrangements and we ended up half our meal on the house. Try the pear wrapped in Prosciutto as well as the  baked chicken.
author: Peter B.

description: I heart the hamburger.  With gruyere!  Sadly, they don't offer the burger at dinner.
author: Marcus C.

description: Wow, i have been here a couple of times, and both experiences were unimpressive, in different ways.  The first time, the service was awful, myself, and my neighbors all had to ask the server (not during peak dining time) to refill our water glasses.  Though I do love the caesar salad and the oyster selection, I incredibly disappointed w/ the food on my second visit.  I had lusted for the chicken, and after the hour wait (i am completely in love w/ chicken), my friend and I received a dish that was 1. undercooked and 2. tasteles.  My friend that I was with said that he had had it before and it was really good, however, on this occasion, I am pretty sure that I could produce something more edible from an easy bake oven.   But Clearly, I would not be so bitter about this if the price point was better.  Man, I was just SOOOOO excited about it. Argh.  It still disappoints me.
author: suzanne g.

description: From great bloody mary's, juicy pork chops and decadent chocolate cakes!  One of my favorite restaurants for brunch on the weekends.
author: Linh N.

description: Disregard the unorganized free seating system at the bar area, the dining experience I had at Zuni is great.  Good food and good service.  The crowd eating brunch/ lunch there are very cool and well-dressed.  I want to try their famous roasted chicken dish but really had no patience to sit there to wait for one hour. Probably next time....
author: Mei M.

description: Zuni has been around for a long time, and it's no wonder why. They always produce creative, tasty dishes. We went one evening after the symphony, and thank goodness because they were serving their famous burger! Apparently, you can order the burger for lunch or after 9pm. I wish it would be regular on the dinner menu, though. The burger was Niman Ranch meat which was seasoned just right and juicy in spite of it being well-done (which I'd ordered that way). The "bun" was actually a rosemary foccacia, and it totally works. I have yet to try the famed roasted chicken for two, and the next time I go back with a friend, we're going for it. You can't go wrong eating at Zuni.
author: Fern D.

description: This place is worth the dining experience. It may seem pretentious from the window. But if you know the food and cooking world, this place knows what time it is. The crowd was definitely older, but all had great appreciation for the food, of course. I stopped by last minute during midweek and got a table. Could not resist the famous roast chicken & bread salad for two. It was just as described- flavorful and aromatic. The leftovers were even better the next day. Service was indeed great also.
author: Peter Y.

description:
I took my husband to Zuni Cafe to celebrate his birthday.  After reading everyone's reviews, I was really excited to try their famous chicken.  In a nutshell, our experience was just OK.  We started off with the oysters which were absolutely fabulous.  Very fresh and yummy.  Appetizers...check.  The menu says that it takes about an hour for the chicken to cook.  I though that it couldn't possibly take that long because everyone said that it was an average of 40 mins but it actually took a little longer than an hour.

We had the chicken and the shoestring potatoes.  The shoestrings were very yummy but the chicken, I wasn't really that impressed.  it was just alright. It was a little on the salty side.  Everyone around was oohing and ahhing over their chicken and we were excited to do the same thing but  no luck.  It didn't happen.  I think my mom makes better chicken in her turbo cooker.

For dessert we had the espresso granita (took a few of your recommendations) and that was just alright too! It tasted like those coffee candies that are in the shape of a coffee bean and comes in a circular tin.  I was really said that my meal ended with this.  

I don't know if I'll ever come back.  I wasn't really impressed with this place.
author: Katrina T.

description: My partner took me to Zuni for my birthday, we've been to the bar here plenty, but not for dinner for years. Thanks to the hostess for giving us the table she asked for.  Five stars for oysters and champagne (but how hard is that?). Five stars for dessert, the waiter brought both with candles because he wasn't sure whose birthday it was (yes both, we couldn't agree and it was my birthday, so two desserts). I'll give four stars for service. But the entrees...meh. Uninspired salmon and a weird lamb tagine. They drag the whole score down to three stars. I'm sure I'll go back to the bar but probably not for a full meal.
author: Jen S.

description:
I did not realize how large Zuni is. The street entrance leads towards a long copper bar, staffed by people who really know what they're doing and how to welcome you to their spot. Once again, I was running a bit late meeting my parents for dinner. I met them and ordered a glass of Henriot Brut Souverain, which they comped. Maybe it was Thanksgiving generosity, or more likely my dad was working the schmooze earlier. Either way it was a nice gesture, and the Henriot was a tasty drink - crisp and a bit austere as always, lemony with a touch of red currant fruit. Not exciting champagne, but reliable and a great apertif. Zuni looks sort of like an upscale version of a large brewpub, with high expansive ceilings, lots of open space and distressed wood floors. Upstairs, the space is very cleverly broken up into several different smaller dining areas, which helps to keep the noise down and adds a sense of privacy. Our table was directly above the oyster bar. To start we had a bottle of Roland Schmitt Sylvaner, which was round, slightly creamy and tasted like baked apples and a hint of peach. Tasty and cheap. I had an order of roasted sardines, which were fine but not a standout. Salads were fresh and lightly dressed the way I like 'em. For the main course I had ordered a bottle of 2005 Lapierre Morgon - which was a good bit richer and more generous than I had anticipated it. Also considerably lower in acidity, which is too bad. One of my favorite cru Beaujies I have ever had was a Desvignes Morgon 'Javennieres' from the same 2005 vintage; it was much tighter but also a much more interesting wine.

For my main I ordered the much heralded roasted chicken to split with my mom - it was just ok. Back when I lived in DC, I would often judge a restaurant based on how flavorfully and originally they could prepare a plain old chicken dish. It was fun, and actually a good indicator of the overall quality of the cooking. Well, once again the chicken test worked, as I found Zuni to be pretty good, but not all that great. Definitely a good lunch spot, though. For dinner it's ok as well- if the location is convenient - and if someone else is handling the tab.
author: joe m.

description: Great cocktails and service. Their roasted chicken is mouthwatering.
author: Jason A.

description: I liked the atmosphere, decor, and service. The burger with gorgonzola and grilled onions was delicious. One of the better burgers I've had in sf. But it was like $16 which is more than I'd like to pay for a burger with no sides.
author: Bruce D.

description:
So on extremely high recommendations by my culinary conneisseur of a friend, we decided to go to Zuni Cafe to taste the workings of chef Judy Rogers.  Now, I was prepared to be blown away, and in some sense I was, but perhaps my expectations were on the wrong page.  Of course, being a cafe, I ought not to have expected anything super fancy or gourmet, but enjoyable nonetheless.  Wait staff was quick and our waiter was very, very friendly.  

Ok, so onto the food, the important stuff, the reason people usually go to restaurants.  Now, we went for lunch and we decided that we wanted to go for all the stuff that Zuni's was supposed to be known for, so in the end, we got; the burger, caesar salad, shoe string potatoes, and of course the puportedly "world's best roasted chicken".  So let's start with the salad, it was good, a little heavy on the anchovy taste, but it's supposed to be how an original caesar was made, it was a very refreshing salad (and the croutons were amazing).  The burger was pretty much just a burger (but hand ground on the spot), they seem to like making simple foods, and somehow glorifying it, such as serving it on rosemary foccacia with zuccini and onion essentially pickled in wine vinegar (they really like using wine vinegar).  The shoe string potatoes were honestly, something of a waste of money, imagine basically In-N-Out fries (I feel for those who have not had the wonders of In-N-Out) shredded even thinner, not exactly what I'd pay six bucks for.  Finally we come to the chicken, now, having heard it was the "world's best" I had some pretty high standards going in, and of course, I think I over-hyped it.  Now, I have to admit, the chikcen was good, it was a simple roasted chicken served on a bed of bread salad, basically oversized croutons (or more specifically Tuscany bread soaked and baked in a champagne vinegar with salad).  I have to say, the bread salad was amazing, simply amazing, I loved the flavoring.  The chicken, while slightly charred on the skin, was actually the most juicy and tender chicken I've ever had.  Through simple roasting, I've never had a piece of white meat with that much juice still in it.  I think it was quite worth the wait, and it actually came a little faster than I thought it would.  Just make sure you get something else in addition to that to space out your meal.  Overall I thought that while slightly disappointing, Zuni's is a good place to eat.  A little on the expensive side of course (add in $10 for valet parking), it takes very straightforward simple fare, and prepares it to excellence.  While I don't want to overhype it, I don't want to say it's utter trash either, it's really very good.
author: Jonas C.

description: Zuni lives up to the hype and has a great chicken for two.  I have also had the creamy textured saddle of rabbit and several other excellent offerings.  The wine list has a few gems (and the price of gems as well), desserts are lux and the overall services on the second floor window table was fine the last time.  While some people have said the services is snobby, our drink orders, oysters and other requests came promptly and without 'tude.  Also nice to have valet at a reasonable price to deal with hassles of parking on a busy Friday or Saturday night.  I will come back again, especially for the roasted chicken and a bottle of GV.   All things considered, the price is consistent with the locations, ingredients and image.
author: Michael B.

description: The place was nice, the food was above average, the decor was lofty but the bartender was uptight...couldn't even smile or even attempt a slight grin....that set the mood.  The lamb was above average but the portion was slightly smaller than I would expect for the pricepoint.  The waiter was attentive and dessert was great.  I'd say it was an 'average' dining experience with a HIGH pricepoint.
author: Blake J.

description: I've eaten at this place since I was 5 or 6 years old and it never fails to disappoint.  I often want to get things other than oysters, caesar salad, and roast chicken, but I always revert back to my old favorites.  It's fresh, casual, and fun.  I don't eat red meat but I've heard the burgers are heavenly . . .
author: Annie F.

description: Been here awhile, just went here. They were super cool about seating our large group (just came from city hall wedding) the servers were attentive, the food was great, and the prices are fair considering the quality of the food. Definitely want to make a habit out of this place.
author: Josh K.

description: This is okay, but IMO, it's not worth the hype.   Shared a couple dishes with friends -- a ceaser salad, prosciutto with one fig (cut in half, filled with cream cheese and almonds), and a pizza.  I love how everything tastes fresh, and the unique way they melded different veggies on the pizza -- eggplant and feta cheese -- and I kept eating more of this delectable treat.  It's definitely a place worth taking the BF's parents.  If I'm in the mood for something fresh and light, I'd go again, but a little pricey.
author: Jen C.

description: I am rating this place stricktly on the crappy service that I got. Yes, yes we all know the food is great and all but man was this the worst service I ever got! The waiters thought she was gods gift to men and took about 20 min to take are order. She was not attentive nor personable. When we had to physically go to the bar to get are drinks ourselves the bar tender was another prick. I will never go here again!
author: Mitchelle M.

description: Zuni c'est tres bien!  Such a cute little French-feeling sidewalk restaurant, flooded with light, white linen, a stocked bar and attentive waiters.  Great place for a first date or a girl's night out.  Superbe!
author: regina k.

description: My palate seems to be very limited these days since I tend to frequent the same places! Second go'round with friends was delightful at Zuni. Oysters were delicious, service was on par and all of our dishes were consistently good as usual. No need to go into product. I think most people know Zuni by now.
author: lissy L.

description: Even though I live close to Zuni, I've only had the occasion to dine there a couple of times.  Each time, the food and experience were fantastic.  My first visit was a few years ago.  My boyfriend at the time and I stopped in for a late dinner after a free recital at the SF Conservatory of Music.  I  had a filet of halibut or sea bass that was cooked perfectly.  My companion had the ricotta gnocchi, which he thought was too eggy, but he is especially sensitive to egg.  More recently, I went to Zuni with two friends to celebrate their engagement.  We tried to call and pre-order the roast chicken (for my friends), but the staff said that they could only take our order once we were seated.  No problem, we snacked on delicious shoestring fries and olives while waiting for our mains.  I had the spaghetti with sweet and spicy peppers which was very flavorful.  Late last night (about half an hour before closing), a friend and I dropped in for dessert and drinks.  There was only one chocolate dessert on menu - the gateau victoire (which I'd shared with my friends on my previous visit) - so we ordered that since my friend was in the mood for something chocolatey.  It was an interesting experience sipping on wine and rye while looking out onto Market  Street through Zuni's large glass windows - I felt very much like was in San Francisco (sometimes, that feeling evades me).  Our water glasses were constantly filled and service was attentive even though we had only ordered one dessert and two drinks.
author: Grace W.

description:
Zuni makes good food, though it is overpriced.

I don't especially care for the pizza, but that's me.  I also don't like Domino's, Papa John's, or Pizza Hut.

The chicken is delicious, but I don't believe worth the wait or the price.  The burgers are good,  The bar is good.  Service is good, but you may have to wait a long time.

I usually only go to Zuni, when someone I know wants to go.
author: Richard C.

description: Truly a very neat place in San Fran.  Its huge although very unassuming.  We had the chicken, it was tasty although the salad that came with it was a bit to vinegary for my taste buds.  Very unique and loved the bread salad.  The apps were small and not to share although the waiter insisted they were.  They were amazing, some pasta dish with rabbit is a must have.  All in all it was amazing chicken, but chicken nonetheless.  I wish our group would have wanted to try other things.  Check it out
author: Keith D.

description: My nephew (who is a chef in Maryland) had told me about Zuni's reputation so I was expecting to eat my best meal in San Francisco. It was good, but not brilliant. None of the flavors danced on my tongue. My fish took a dogs age to arrive. Finally the manager came to my table and apologized for the timing and told me that dessert would be on the house. I do have to say the customer service was really lovely. The manager's apology was very thoughtful and made waiting a bit longer for the fish totally bearable - hey, I was on vacation - where was I in a hurry to get to :-). So I waited to fall in love with my fish dish. I really wanted to love it, but it was just good I'm afraid. For my complimentary dessert I had the blueberry pie which was, again like everything else I ate that evening, just good. This place should be brilliant. I wanted it to be brilliant. It just wasn't briliant.
author: Sharon G.

description:
I had Valentine's Day dinner here with my boyfriend.  We had a great table with a great view upstairs, but it was a little chilly and I noticed other women sitting nearby also complain about the cold.  There was also a wedding reception of some sort seated upstairs which was a bit annoying, but the wait staff was perfect and attentive nonetheless. 

I have to admit, I was not raised on a diet of foie gras, oysters and caviar, so I always feel a tad uncomfortable in restaurants that serve these things.  Being one of the only brown people in the restaurant besides the busboys and dishwashers can do that to a person.   Inferiority complex aside, the food here was really amazing.  The oyster menu was extensive and were were able to try some from Washington that we never had before.  All of the menu items looked yummy, but we decided on the roast chicken for two (which we ordered right away as it really does take an hour to make).  The hour seems to go by fast especially with the help of some appetizers.  The chicken was cooked to perfection.  The skin was perfectly crisp and buttery and the chicken was moist and tender.  I think that wood burning oven is magic. The bread salad that it came with was also amazing, though some of the bread pieces didn't seem to be soaked well in the vinaigrette and were hard and crunchy which mostly made me sad because I wanted more of it!

The price of the meal with steep but it was surprisingly a bit cheaper than some places in the East Bay I have been to.  I don't know where else I can get roast chicken as good as Zuni Cafe's, and we will definitely be back again soon to experience it's amazingness again.
author: Jennifer A.

description: The style of food tries to be a small italian sit-down, but the atmosphere refuses to cooperate.  There is a bar downstairs that is VERY loud and is connected with the entire restaurant. The high ceilings  translate the noise deafeningly. The chairs are uncomfortable, and and trust me, the noise is overwhelming.  The food is not even to die for; it's nice but not the best I've had.  If you want a quiet sitdown place and a good meal this is most definately NOT what you want.  You will have to put up with a lot of noise and small space if you plan on coming here.  The wait staff was good, but overall I give this place a 2.5, but since I can't I gave it a 3.
author: Eric M.

description: Went to Zuni Sunday night for dinner and had the chicken and it was better than we had expected.  Our server was very attentive and quite friendly which made the experience even better.  Didn't care for where we were seated, but other than that it was a great experience.
author: Runner G.

description:
The food was pretty good, but not the service. Right at the beginning of the meal, the waiter spilled an entire glass of red wine on me. 

Mistakes happen, but the real test is how you deal with them. 
- When I went to the bathroom to clean myself up, the waiter brought out appetizers to be shared by the table. My polite friends waited for me but the waiter encouraged them to eat the appetizers without me before they get cold - seriously?
- I was apologized to and told that I would be comped part of the meal and that they'd pay for my dry cleaning. However, we were only comped for 2 of 4 glasses of wine, and 2 desserts. I didn't expect to pay for any wine. And it's not worth the hassle of sending them a dry cleaning bill and getting a check back in the mail. I'm still not sure if my shirt will survive, which cost more than the meal.
- Being comped part of the meal is nice but what would have been even nicer is if they offered my choice of a complimentary bottle of wine. That would have been a truly professional move. 
- They should have replaced the tablecloth. I ate my entire meal with a sticky wine-stained tablecloth in front of me.

Fortunately I still had an enjoyable dinner with my friends but I expect better service from a place of this caliber.
author: Jonathan G.

description: We both had burgers with the add-ons - definitely among the best burgers in the city, and the service we got was actually pretty good. But, with cheese (~$2) and mushrooms (~$2), they run $19 - way too expensive . Add grilled onions and your laying out a whole Jackson and change. No wonder Hamilton prefers Meister Burger.
author: Brian H.

description: Don't make you feel welcome in their bar. Could I have a scotch and water and a little less attitude?
author: Dave M.

description: I'm not native to the city, but have eaten out and about.  Definitely one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco.  Great to go for a casual occasion or a date.  The bread from Acme was a great starter.  I did not have the rotisserie chicken, however I did have the gnocchi, dried cured beef with chili and goat cheese, and roasted duck with figs.  I also liked the roasted vegetables, which were a tad salty, but were unique and added an intriguing dimension to the duck. All were very nicely plated and delicious.  I split with my date and we were full by the time we finished.  We also had the Mediterranean cheesecake with huckleberry sauce which I highly recommend.  With 2 glasses of wine dinner was ~110 I believe.  I really like this place and it's great to go after the opera. You must go!
author: Erik Q.

description: Great menu, and service. Definitely try the oysters, they taste delighful. Very fun restaurant to dine, see and be seen.
author: Crisa M.

description: Quintessential San Francisco. Outstanding food, excellent people watching, great space. Casual yet refined. Grab a glass of wine around the corner at the terrific Hotel Biron wine bar (not a hotel).
author: Patrick B.

description: I'm confused. I've heard great things about the food here and some bad comments about the service. The problem I have is that I have now given Zuni 3 shots and it has failed each time. The Sea Bass was bland and I know I could have done a better job.  The oysters were fine, but raw oysters are hard to mess up in a good restaurant. My scallops were tough and even the chicken I split once was mediocre. This time, my date had the fillet and that was bland and over-cooked.  I guess I would just caution all of you hopefuls out there to try other places first.  Go have a great meal at Firefly or Chez Spencer before you succumb to Zuni. Someone once told me it was hit or miss; I'd miss it if I were you.
author: Catherine K.

description: You know - I love Zuni because of the food. Any kind of chicken on this menu - is so super fantastic. BUT....the service and the way I have been treated here.....not so enjoyable. Waiting for my table (that I had reserved 3 days ahead of time) I was treated so rudely at the bar by an older blonde woman. And this was the second time this blonde was not so nice to me - from a seperate visit. Not everyone is a skilled purveyor of wine - some of us want to know more info and learn from the staff when we go out to dine. This woman could so not be bothered. Sorry ma'am - but I like to talk to other people and find out what knowledge they can share with me. So lesson learned - I now ony go to Zuni to eat at a tble and do not hang at the bar.....ever. Have fun eating - avoid the bar.
author: Tom R.

description: Dined here for Sunday brunch in Oct 2006 with two friends. Great ambiance and attentive service. I got a burger and one friend got the scrambled eggs with goat cheese and the other chose a rather unique egg dish with cream. Parking in the neighborhood might be a little tough but they have valet service. I'd say this is more like 3.5 stars than 4...the price and portions are a little expensive for what you get but I would return again for the unique and eclectic menu. They seem to also be well known for their oysters but we didn't try any.
author: D C.

description: Superior food and frequently updated menu. Environment/decor are pleasant with lots of natural light.  It has become very difficult to get a weekend reservation due its popularity and the prices are a bit high.
author: Christopher K.

description:
Had brunch there today & the food was okay.  They have a limited menu that you have to narrow down what you're in the mood for: eggs, pizza, salad, burger,...

Ordered the scrambled eggs w/manchego cheese, fennel sausage, & salad...it was okay but nothing special.  The greens had some bitter ones which I had to pick out.

The dessert made up for the meal.  We ordered the Gateau Victoire (flourless chocolate cake) w/whipped cream and the plum sorbet which was a great combination.

Would possibly try this place again for another meal besides brunch, but would check out the menu before getting seated. 

Nice, sunny & open ambience.  Good service.
author: D L.

description:
inspiring:

corner real estate.

the light.

the unpretentious details in the wiring, the floors, the stairs, the slat windows.

the nooks & crannies for dining.

table 66.

the kitchen: exposed wood oven, displayed oyster bar, cooks that smile.

chicken roasted to order. house-made sausages. oysters roulette - amazing the random small production oysters they can locate! perfect caesars. generous pomme frites done in peanut oil. local, seasonal vegetables and meats. flour-less chocolate cake. burnt honey ice cream. comprehensive wine list.

legendary for good reason. why eat anywhere else?
author: randi v.

description:
Dare I even write a review as I peeked at the last count of 455 reviews.
I shall proceed. 
The hostess was very accommodating in letting us select our seating. . mainly since it was 4pm and the cocktail/dinner crowd had yet to converge upon this most popular venue.  
We, of course, ordered the signature dish of shoe string potatoes . .very yummy.
We shared a signature hamburger -grilled to perfection with gruyere and grilled onions. . also major delicious.
We shared a pizza special . . good, but not knock-your-socks off. . . 
Rootbeer was nice and icy cold, as I like it.
Overall, staff was attentive in clearing our plates and filling our water glasses. .
As we left and I glanced over at the exterior window, I was quite impressed with the display of glasses and libation (facing outward)  and the number of vodka displayed. . kudos......
Had not eaten here in ages. . and thankfully, not too much has changes. .thank goodness. . .
author: Kea C.

description: Martinis, oysters, and the chicken bread salad--a perfect pick-me-up dinner for two.  I'm sure there are other menu items that disappoint, but my fiance and I head there for a simple California dinner that's consistently delicious.
author: Ginger C.

description: I do not think the chicken for two is that great.  Get the Rabbit instead!  Service was extremely snotty and slow.
author: Zoe R.

description: Nice setting.  Service is just OK.  However, this place is extremely expensive given the quality and quantity of food you get.  Prices should be half of what they are..
author: adolfo b.

description:
:(  This was one of my biggest letdowns. Zuni has been at the top of my list of restaurants to try and finally when we got there, my optimism kept getting squashed.

Our server was highly uneducated in everything that is food and wine. She seemed completely uninterested in our excited questions about the halibut vs. the salmon, different dishes, which Chardonnay was buttery (c'mon, easiest question ever.) She was like "salmon? what salmon?" There were about 4 Chardonnays on the wine list. One was $30 one was $50 and the next was $88 and more were above that. The $50 wine was out, so we were stuck with basically a crappy wine or an almost $100 bottle. We got the expensive one and it was NOT worth it. It just left a bitter taste in our mouths. Literally and figuratively. The roasted chicken does take a full hour. Fine, great, we'll order appetizers. Our salads came after 45 minutes... our entrees were good, absolutely nothing compared to other restaurants in the city. And they didn't bring out a final dish until a good 5 minutes after the other ones were served. Restaurant Etiquette 101, Zuni. Come on. We ordered dessert, the only thing we wanted was out of course, so we ordered a piece of pie. There were 4 of us, and we LITERALLY got 1 bite. Also, one of my food idols writes in her cookbook about how she always goes to zuni when she's in SF. So I asked if they'd ever seen her, she said she'd ask around. 45 minutes later I asked her again and she had no idea what i was talking about. I asked someone else and he was totally uninterested. 

I am tempted to give this another try but I'm not happy about our $350 meal that I really would value at $200 maximum. Stick with Kokkari for your Cailfornia Mediterannean food.
author: Abbie B.

description: roasted chicken with bread pudding ftw!
author: lavina l.

description: I've been here before an had great experiences, but last night it just did not cut it.  The appetizer we got (which was in spanish I believe) was simply olive oil soaked bread.  Huh?  Really?  The presentation was pretty week too.  Looked like something I'd gotten in Poland when I was there recently.  The pasta dish we got was good but again nothing great.  The only thing that was good was the caesar salad...but c'mon - that can't be your pride and joy.  Luckily I had an amazing date so it worked out ok, but if I had been more focused on the food it would have been a total bust!!
author: Roman A.

description: I don't know what the hype is here.  Granted, I didn't order the chix but the dishes were SO basic and down-right bland.  Super disappointing considering this is one of my sister's favorite spots.  After this visit I wonder how that is.
author: elizabeth s.

description: I have been wanting to dine here forever. Finally got the chance last week before going to a show.  Food was a bit pricey and bar server had an attitude but we had a good time anyway. Probably  will go back for lunch sometime in the future.
author: Kitty Tonka B.

description: Been going to Zuni for almost 20 years and still love the atmosphere.  But  they're getting away with murder on the food these days.  Our bass was horribly fishy-tasting, like it had been sitting around the kitchen for days before being cooked.  The pizza served to my niece was regrettable, with limp dough and bland taste.  Not sure if they're resting on past laurels but it's disappointing to see this SF classic serving up forgettably mediocre dishes.
author: Eric R.

description: I've been here before and felt last night dinner was very mediocre for the prices Zuni charges.  The flank steak was okay, the chocolate cake was sort of dry and the coffee was lukewarm.  The waiter was excellent and the restaurant has great buzz, but I felt they may have gotten a bit complacent on the food quality and basics.
author: Jeff R.

description: One of the best in San Francisco.  Can't miss with anything on the menu but that chicken is pretty darn good.  Stop reading reviews of the place, just go.
author: Alex Y.

description: The's reputation is well deserved.  We got in on a Sunday night with no reservation.  Service was particularly great.  Despite having many dozens of tables the set up still feels intimate and cozy, not like the industrial echo chamber effect that a lot of new restaurants are going for- perfect for romatic date or taking out the parents.  Our meals were literally perfectly prepared and delicious.    Very SF.
author: C O.

description:
After reading rave reviews about this place I thought it was time to try it out.  So we booked a reservation for dinner on a Friday night.  Even at 6:30, the place was packed!  

Bar - drinks are tiny!  One of the smallest martini glasses I have ever seen served at a bar.  If it was any smaller it could have been a Christmas tree ornament.

Food - it's okay, not fabulous.  All of our dishes were okay, but didn't live up to our expectations.  I wouldn't come back unless a really good friend wanted to try it out or someone was paying for me!  

Wine & Drinks - wine menu is very limited for a San Francisco restaurant.  There are more Scotch options than wines!  We brought our own bottle and paid the $20 corkage fee.

Noise level - too loud for dinner!  Even at our small table of four, we had to raise our voices to be heard by the rest of our party.

Parking - valet parking is available, so that's nice.

Price - reasonable, but there are plenty of other restaurants that are much better within the same price range

Service - a bit quirky.  Some of the other reviewers mentioned how aloof their server was, and I have to say that our server was a bit aloof.  Not mean or rude, just aloof.  The hostesses were very friendly and greeted us pleasantly upon arrival and wished us a good evening at departure, but our server was aloof.  It's like he didn't want to be there!  We couldn't get the guy to even crack a small smile!

I'm glad we finally tried out Zuni, but we won't be going back anytime soon.  If you looking for an alternative, try out Bacar on Brannan Street.  Their wine selection is amazing and they serve martinis in nice, large glasses!
author: ARUM A.

description: I've only eaten at the bar so far for lunch. Had the popular burger and it was delicious. I saw they had an awesome oyster selection but didn't try any... yet. Definitely will have to go back. Love the big windows looking over Market and the crowd was good. Service was awesome, scored some Fernet!
author: Take O.

description: You have to go for the roast chicken...even though it takes a long time.
author: Forrest G.

description: I eat here quite often and have never had a bad meal.  Consistently one of the best restaurants in the city and their Balsamic Bloody Marys are sooo good!
author: Gelsomina L.

description: I wouldn't be able to describe the depth of their menu because no matter how many times I go there I always end up ordering the chicken.  I never order it at any other restaurant but it is a must at Zuni.
author: John M.

description:
it is hard not to give zuni 5 stars.  It has been around longer than I've been alive (over 27 years).  As mentioned below the roasted chicken is a classic and should be order immediately upon seating (it takes 45 minutes or so to cook the bird).  The caesar is excellent and one order is plenty for two people.  The burger is one of the best in the city, although reasonable minds can differ as to whether the bread/bun is a proper to hold the burger together.  The pork chop, when it is on the menu, is to die a must if you like a good chop.  The oyster selection is diverse and as fresh as anything you would find at the ferry building.  The wine list is stale and boring.  The upstairs seating in the "little room" is too stuffy, asked to be seated downstairs for the people watching.  The service can be hit or miss, I have a few fav. servers that are amazing but zuni seems to have a high turnover of staff and its a crap shoot sometimes.  (on a completely random sidebar there is this new girl with short brown hair that is, how shall I put it, very easy on the eyes, have no idea how she is as a server though)

Above all this place rocks because 1) it seats diners until 11 pm, 2) regulars get seated faster than randoms, 3) its a 3 minute walk from my pad.

Special shout out to Ren (host) for always hooking me with the best table available.  You are the man.
author: Charlie C.

description:
After having a disappointing gourmet pizza dinner, we were all craving something sweet... so we head over to Zuni's Cafe for some late night dessert & coffee.  We first looked over the dessert menu before being seated, and the manager was kind enough to go over each dessert ---a definite plus for service! After the detailed descriptions, we decided to try the desserts.  I must say the Bittersweet Chocolate Pot de Creme was excellent-- great recommendation! Our other friends tried the Gateau Victoire (dark chocolate cake with whipped cream) & the Pot de Creme as well (they liked it). My boyfriend got the Quince sorbet-- he didn't really care for the tartness & told our server that when asked.  When our server brought our bill, he didn't charge us for the sorbet.  We thought that was a nice gesture-- so thats why I give five stars for the service & especially for the Bittersweet Chocolate Pot de Creme! 

I have not tried the food there, but if its as good as the dessert... then I say its worth a visit.  Make sure to save room for dessert :)
author: Cathy P.

description: Zuni isn't a hip new discovery to share with your foodie friends, but its consistently impressive food makes it worthy of its reputation. The restaurant is famous of their chicken, but if they're serving pork chop you have to get it. Sounds ridiculous but they brine it for two days and it's really tasty. Their pasta is also always really good as are their shoestring fries. Zuni's a great place for a date, a couple friends, and visiting family.
author: Adam M.

description: It's true. The roasted chicken is the best I've ever had. Yes, it's pricey, but it's worth the money. And that's saying a lot given that it's a $48 chicken. Also, it's a *big* chicken. It'll feed 3 or will make for a great lunch the next day.
author: Katherine D.

description: 4 Stars because it tends to be a bit over priced.. .BUT, the food is amazing.  Sunday mornings are the best time to go.  Mimosa and a pork chop with Oysters as an appetizer may seem a little much but what a better way to get ready for a new week.  YUM, I love this place.  (it's also great for dates if you reserve the window seat) wink wink
author: Heather B.

description: Zuni Cafe is, handsdown, THE best restaurant in SF. But for those of you who gave it anything but 5 stars...I'm good with that because it means more table space for me!
author: Corinne M.

description: I've heard mixed reviews on this place and was totally pleased with my first experience there last week. The space is warm and welcoming, definitely good for a date. I made a reservation for a Friday night and was sat as soon as I got there, even though my friend wasn't there yet. The server took my wine order while I waited and was very friendly and accommodating. My friend and I debated between the famous Roasted Chicken with Bread Pudding and the Halibut. I took off half a star because our server was very, VERY nice but not very helpful with ordering. We needed help making food and wine choices and she just kept saying in a nice way that everything is good. Maybe I'm being too picky, but I love a good recommendation (I'm sure I would've been happy if she had said either). We ended up with the chicken and were not disappointed. I've been craving it ever since! It was juicy and delicious and the bread salad was to DIE for. It took every minute of the hour that the server warned us about--but we knew that going in so I can't complain. The other half star off is for slightly high prices. But it is SF after all. All in all, I would definitely recommend this place. Do get the chicken; it lives up to its rep!
author: theresa v.

description:
San Francisco has much better food than this.

My terrible experience may have been the fault of our waitress. She seated us, then dissapeared. After waiting 20 minutes, we finally gave our order to the waiter serving the next table over. This was significant because we wanted the roast chicken, which takes a full hour to cook.

I had a ceasar salad appetizer, which was delicious. But my lamb entree was a disaster--it was tough, flavorless, and stone cold. Everyone else at my table ordered the roast chicken, which leads me to believe that my lamb was sitting on the counter for 45 minutes while the chicken cooked. I almost sent the dish back to the kitchen, and in retrospect, I probably should have.
author: Emily S.

description: Okay, I generally don't like to write reviews, but I felt it was necessary in this case since most of the reviews are strong and I just can't bring myself to agree at all.  First off, our waiter was beyond pretentious and his smile was just so affected that I cringed every time he came to the table, which wasn't very often, by the way.  Next, the apps were good, but not great - 3 stars for this.  We ordered the chicken for 2, as did others at our table.  I took my first bite of the bread pudding, and it tasted like formaldehyde.  I was like, "huh?" and decided to try again.  Yep, every bite (crispy end or soggy middle) had that taste.  I checked out my friend's and it was the same.  I think it was maybe the vinegar dressing reacting with the sourdough or something.  The mustard greens were huge pieces that added bitterness to the formaldehyde taste of the bread.  So, I moved on to the chicken.  The chicken was juicy, a little smokey, and well cooked, but I couldn't escape that weird taste entirely.  Overall, a rather unenjoyable entree.    The chicken at Range is infinitely better.  The desserts were good, but they ran out of the roasted plum ice cream and served us strawberry ice cream and tried to argue with us that it was plum until later the cheesy waiter came back and told us, yep, we were right, "it is strawberry, they just told me we ran out of plum."   I don't know, the apps and desserts were maybe a 3 stars, the ambience was a 4 or 5, but the off-putting flavor of the entree (which is the reason we went) made it a 0.  In all, a 2 is as generous as I can be.  Sorry.
author: montezuma's r.

description: One word:  "Landmark."  Reservation or not, you can enjoy the floor and street show.  Lunching with Nob Hill moms on Saturday afternoon is a kick.  Try Zeitgeist after mid-afternoon oysters.  Must have after-hours burger.
author: Nate B.

description:
Having cooked the Roast Chicken with Bread Salad dish a few times at home, I had to have it at the source on my last trip to SF.  

My 4 friends and I dropped by last Sunday night.  The wait was not long at all, considering we were walk-ins (15 minutes; probably short because it was fairly late for dinner).  Service was impeccable, not to mention the cute host who's also a fellow clubber.

The food itself was a little mixed.  The chicken was wonderful, if a tad bit on the salty side.  The shoestring potatoes were almost unbearably salty.  The halibut was on the dry side, but had good flavorings.  I wasn't very impressed with the bread.  Nice wine selection.  The Gateau Victoire was one of the best dark chocolate cakes ever!

I'll probably come back again soon to see if it was just a fluke but other than the chicken and the cake, I wasn't much impressed with the food.  I'll give a 4 for service/ambience and 3 for food based on my last experience there.  3.5 overall.

BTW, the glass facade reflects everything!  Keep your conversations PG-rated because everyone around you can hear.
author: Quan N.

description: My go-to spot. I especially like the balsamic Bloody Marys - anytime of day. Another great aspect is, unlike too many restaurants in SF, it's open late! You can get some really excellent food, for not too much dough, when everything else is shuttered.
author: C. A. S.

description: GREAT place for a quick bite before a show. You must have reservations though. The food is always great and the wait staff fabulous. The wine list superb. It is not a quiet place for a romantic dinner, though.
author: Kim K.

description: The brunch food was very good, as expected.  A very good burger, and anything from the wood fired oven is awesome.  But the server was snobby and messed up our order twice.  Then as an added bonus he charged us for the next table's espresso.
author: gary p.

description: Loved it! Super down to earth service that leaves nothing to be desired. The roasted chicken is as good as it ever was.
author: Christy F.

description: Love Zuni! The menu is wonderful, the food is perfection. A major draw is the fresh and richly flavorful oyster bar, with choices from British Columbia to Cape Cod. Beautifully presented and perfectly shucked, out of the three varities we had chosen, I preferred the Hog Island humamoto. The homemade ricotta gnocchi is also to die for.  Love the warm atmosphere as well as the great light stemming from the expansive gallery windows. The copper top bar, the exposed brick walls and the street cars whizzing by out your window really set the scene. Traditional cocktails made with top shelf ingredients...try Zuni's homemade margarita, it is to die for.  Fantastic and seemingly effortless hospitality. Zuni is great for a date, a big dinner party, or a quiet business dinner upstairs.
author: Katie K.

description:
I grew up going to Zuni and loving it.  I live in NYC now, but while visiting SF stopped in to share the love with my husband.  We were surprised to get a table for 2 within 15 minutes on a Thursday night (even though there was nothing on Open Table....hmmm?) and while waiting for our table, ordered two glasses of wine at the barn.  The glasses had barely hit the copper bar and the bartender said "that'll be $24.82" and stood there staring at us while my husband pulled out his wallet.  We were in shock.  It was downright odd.

The dinner was pretty good, but we didn't have time to wait for the 1-hr roasted chicken, so I won't judge.  That's simply what you should order there.  

The waiter, however, was just dismal.  Barely gave us any attention.  I was so shocked.  The way plates are just kind of tossed down on the table like it's a quick and dirty bistro.  I don't mind that kind of service, but not at those prices.

So yes, I was disappointed, and not sure I'd go there again.  Sad.
author: Rosie O.

description:
So this is for those other reviewers who claimed that Zuni's chicken is a must have - 

My party of four came early and we had to wait. No big deal since there was a full bar. "Let's just start at the bar," I thought. I asked the bartender for a strawberry mojito. He replied, "Sure! Give me some strawberries and mint and I'll make you one." I should have just left right then and there. I didn't, big mistake. 

We ordered a variety of oysters, caesar salad, the chicken, the steak, fish entree, and a bottle of wine. The oysters were very fresh. The caesar salad was presented in a rustic style (uncut). It cost $30.00 for a few thin slices of steak. Finally, when the chicken came out 45 minutes later, we were all excited to taste it. OMG! Where was the flavor, texture, and aroma I was hearing about. I was very disappointed. I tried to make the best of the situation and requested some sauces to mask the dry and chewy texture. I asked for some sauce or gravy to make up for the dryness. The waiter tried to give me some olive oil and Myer lemon mix as sauce! After the sauce disappointment, I had to use my wine to wash it down. Honestly, that is where I draw the line. For the people that think this chicken is great, you have no idea how far a chicken can go. If you work hard for your money, I would not advise you to dine at Zuni.
author: Ly N.

description: One word: CHICKEN. It's the best I've ever had in my life. I have to be forthright, though, and say that it took me a long time to head back to Zuni after my first foray when I first moved to town. Whatever I ordered that first time (a fish dish, I think - I have blocked it out) wasn't worth what I payed, which was a lot. None of my co-eaters enjoyed what they got that night either. But I got persuaded from hearing everyone talk this place up. The consistent buzz was, of course, that you have to get the chicken. And I have to say, again, GET THE CHICKEN. To be honest, everything my table ordered that night - the fateful night when I fell in love with chicken again - was excellent, so I have no idea what was going on that first time. I'll be back, and I'm getting the chicken. (PS the chicken serves 3 in my opinion, they say only 2.)
author: Phil H.

description: A perfect place for the SF high end gourmet experience- maybe 10 years ago.  Everything is pretty good, but not magical, which is what I expect from such slow service and a fat tab.
author: Passdatanqueray M.

description: Juicy, tender delightful chicken for two. Wonderful bread salad, with nuts and currants with balsamic. Yummy. Not amazing service or ambiance though, and not cheap.
author: Webber B.

description: Worth all the hype.  The chicken is incredible as is the burger (only available after 9pm I believe).  I like to get a burger for the table as an appetizer.  The fresh oysters are also excellent.  Great wine selection and atmosphere.  The Hotel Biron next door is also a great place for a pre or post dinner wine or beer.
author: Ray G.

description: I was so excited to finally try this restaurant, and what a disappointment!! I went with local friends and we took some of our guests from abroad. We had brunch on Sunday a week ago. The service was good but the food, OMG!! the food was so below the expectations and what all the reviews say. We were so in shock that we failed to complain about it. The pizza was overcooked, difficult to eat, the salmon was so mediocre that was at the level of any dinner. My fancy (as described) scrambled eggs were regular, nothing special about them. At the end when some of us order coffe, the cup was dirty!!! We had to go home to eat, because there was not enough food. I don't know if it was just a bad day in the kitchen, but overall the food was way below what we expected and what we paid!!! I won't go back there for sure. A restaurant with such good reviews shouldn't have such lows.
author: ceci r.

description:
I'm adding my voice to the chorus here. 

i had a lovely evening at Zuni with my dad last week. the service was great, and the food was beyond my expectations. Sometimes, over-hyped places like Zuni can disappoint, but in my case it did not. I would go so far as to call it a SF classic!
author: matica g.

description: By far the BEST pork chop I have ever had! I never order pork chops at restaurants because every time I have it has been as dry and tasteless as sawdust. Our waiter told me to go for it. This was the exception! It was tender and well marinated with a smoky, wood oven flavor. The ceasar salad was good, though I'm generally not a fan of ceasar salads, this one tasted like anchovies like it should. The dessert we had was a fruity meringue which was great.
author: McKenzie L.

description: The previous reviewer was right. Why is this place so famous? Food is ordinary, service is so so, and very noisy. He was kind enough to try it again. I am sorry, I would try a different palce. There are so many good restaurants to give a try in the bay area.
author: margret j.

description: I've dined at Zuni Cafe regularly over the years, sometimes with friends, sometimes alone for lunch or dinner, and the experience has always been at least very good if not great. The other evening I stopped by for an early dinner by myself. The food was great: a starter of the Caesar salad, and an entree of Wolf Ranch quail in a sauce of various peppers with a hint of orange. I hadn't eaten the Caesar salad in a long time and I was reminded how superlative that Zuni salad is. The Wolf Ranch quail was fantastic too, roasted brown on the outside, still juicy on the inside, and very satisfying. The service was excellent. A couple servers showed up regularly at my table to check on how I was doing, and the water glass was diligently filled. On other occasions when I've been shopping downtown, I've stopped by the restaurant at 4PM or so for the limited but tasty afternoon menu--good soup, salads, pizza, and always, the famous burger. That's a treat, too.
author: Liz B.

description: Zuni Cafe is always a great place to hang out with friends over a great meal.  The Tuscan chicken is well worth the wait but the price is a bit steep.  I wish they offer more variety of bread though and it will be great if the bread comes warm.  It means a lot if the restaurant is attentive to details like serving warm and toasty bread.  Heck, the pizza oven is right there anyway!
author: Daniel L.

description:
Great place with very good food.
The best Checken ever.
author: Nadav N.

description: The end of a delightful shopping day in Hayes Valley should be followed by relaxing meal at Zuni. It's quintessential San Francisco, simple, effortless, and just plain enjoyable.
author: tami f.

description:
this by far has to be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.... 

my b/f and i love to come here for brunch, dinner or sometimes we just stroll in for martinis and oysters and its great every time.... my favorite part is the famous roasted chicken for 2. worth the wait and money. the chicken is juicy, flavorful and perfect with the warm bread salad, totally delicious!!!! 

only someone who doesn't appreciate food, or like it for that matter, can actually compare it to something so ridiculously unimaginable..... well i cant blame them, they just don't know any better.....  they should just stick to what they know like KFC or POPEYE'S....    the Zuni is great and i truly appreciate the time and effort that goes into the menu, the awesome food and friendly staff.
author: ingrid j.

description:
I've been dining at Zuni for several years, and I have positive things to say about it: good food, service, and ambiance.
But I was present during Andrea M's recent visit.
What she neglects to mention was that she and her dining companion were completely loaded-- messy drunks talking loudly on their phones. When the manager asked them to be quiet, they weren't.
When he asked them again, they cursed him out. They even threatened him, encouraging him to call the police to get them to leave-- which was stupid, because guess what-- he did.
Before the police came, the women stood outside, cursed some more, and flipped off the manager through the window. Maybe Andrea was so drunk she forgot that part?
It's not surprising that the police made them leave their car with the valet and take a taxi because she and her friend were so wasted.
Those women made what would have been a usual enjoyable late dinner at Zuni memorable in the worst way. And it had nothing to do with service or management. Thanks Andrea.
author: B R.

description: Yes, the oysters are fresh and abundant.  The Cesar is right.  And the chicken worth the hour wait.  But really... the attitude found at the bar, hostess stand, and table side is very, very tired.  It seems soooo 1999.  To endure such elitism from a restaurant still serving wine in a clumsy, banquet-style wine glass feels wrong.  Take a risk.  Smile at your customers.  Break a wine glass.
author: Optimus P.

description:
The first oddities we noticed were on the menu. It declares that "Nearly" all of the produce, meat, etc., used is sustainably and organically farmed. What does "Nearly" mean? Grouper on the menu which, according to the  Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Guide is to be avoided due to overfishing and high concentrations of mercury. HMMMM! Secondly, the menu tells us that a 4% surcharge will be added to our bill to pay for the City mandated healthy workers program which guarantees all businesses provide health benefits for their employees. Sounds good. Well, why not just raise the prices 4% rather than adding a surcharge? There is no surcharge for any other business expense, why one for employee benefits? And shouldn't businesses provide said benefits without the government mandating it?

The food. My Ziti with spicy ragu of lamb was anything but spicy. It left me wondering if the chef had taste buds? Bland, Bland, Bland!

The service. Our waiter was hardly ever at table, spoke brusquely, coffee refills were non-existent until well into the meal. The only time he smiled was as we were leaving.

At $50, I would not go back.
author: sf g.

description:
We read so many great reviews about this restaurant that we felt that we HAD to choose it to celebrate my birthday.  What a disappointment!  I've never written a restaurant review before, but I was so appalled by so many things that I felt compelled to post my own opinion.  Keep in mind, I was not in a bad mood when we visited Zuni.  I'd had a great day at work, we had reason to celebrate, and I was with great company.

The first thing that upset us was the fact that we had to wait 30 minutes for our table, in spite of the fact that we had made reservations a week in advance, and HALF THE TABLES in the restaurant were empty!  But this was just the start of the exceptionally slow service.  For instance, we had to ask our waitress several times before she'd bring us anything, and even then it was usually the busboy who finally filled our requests.

Once the waitress FINALLY took our orders, we were so hungry that we had no choice but to choke down the stale, burnt bread.  And for such a "classy" restaurant, we were surprised by the cold, hard, completely unspreadable butter.

A trip to the restroom proved to be a mistake.  When I stood up, a rusty nail sticking out from the rotting window frame tore my shirt.  Then while walking through the restaurant, I nearly tripped on the loose, rotten section of hardwood flooring upstairs.  The restroom proved to be miserable place to go, more akin to what you'd expect to find in an inner-city gas station than an expensive, "hip" restaurant.  The lack of any hot water to wash my hands, or any towels with which to dry my hands, were just the icing on the cake; I'll spare you the details, but let's just say after that first visit to the restroom, I decided to just hold it until I could find a more suitable facility.

Walking back to our table I passed the live pianist, who honestly sounded more like a toddler randomly banging the keys than a paid professional.  A radio and some speakers would be a lot cheaper and a lot less offensive.  At least as the night went on, he seemed to improve (or our alcohol started to kick in).

The salad, which the waitress assured us would be big enough for the two of us to split, turned out to be nothing more than a fist-sized pile of bitter lettuce with a little vinaigrette dressing and two croutons.

We knew ahead of time that their signature dish, the "fabulous" roasted chicken, was going to take an hour to prepare.  But looking around the restaurant, we saw that over half of the tables had also ordered the chicken.  With that the case, I don't understand why Zuni doesn't start preparing the chickens in advance, knowing that there will be dozens of orders each night.  If their excuse is that they want to serve it hot and fresh, then why was it that from our vantage point upstairs directly down into the noisy kitchen, we could watch our and 5 other guests' chickens sitting on the counter for NEARLY 10 MINUTES before the waiters and waitresses got around to bringing them to our tables?

Anyway, once the $48 "chicken" arrived, we found it to be warm - not hot - from having sat so long after being removed from the oven.  It was burnt - black and charred - on the outside, while the breast was still slightly undercooked.  And while it tasted better than what you would get at KFC, it was certainly nothing to write home about.  In all honesty, I would have had a better "chicken" if I had stayed home.  And I would have gotten an actual chicken, instead of the tiny little bird we were served, which was more akin to a Cornish game hen than an actual chicken.  If I was the owner or chef of this restaurant, I would be ashamed to serve this as my signature dish.
