After all of that, we decided against ordering dessert.  We just wanted to get out of there, but again we had to wait forever to get our check.  After asking our waitress and another table's waitress to bring our check, it was finally the busboy who complied - the same busboy who spilled water on my lap while filling our glasses, not just once but TWICE throughout the evening.

So after the poor service and mediocre food, I was floored when I saw the bill.  My advice?  Stick to the East Bay if you want good food, good service, and a reasonable cost.  How such subpar restaurants can get away with exorbitant expense and such snooty attitudes is beyond me.  I guess, to quote another reviewer, that's just the "ambience [sic] that whispers 'San Francisco'."
author: Geoff B.

description:
I hadn't been to Zuni in years.  So for us to actually be able to hear each other talk about the Frida Kahlo exhibit, while savoring every bite of the wonderful food, was a powerful reminder.  Zuni doesn't have to join the Slow Food movement, they've been part of it all along.  

My man & I just walked right in on a Thursday night and were given a great table in the back.  We had a selection of oysters, aptly described by our waiter and a lillet and a kir.  Then an orgasmic charred Early Girl tomato appetizer that put us into pure enjoyment of the simple way Zuni approaches food
.
A caveat - it may be a splurge, but the experience is worth it.
author: Carol H.

description:
Can I say crazy to that previous post??
Zuni has always been my favorite restauranti n the city...definitely get the Caesar salad, the hamburger, and the chicken for two. I ate there last Sunday and they had this farro, kale, egg soup which was to die for!
author: Cody P.

description: Service here is great, as is the atmosphere & food. I went late night recently for a light meal while on a business trip. Started with a dozen fresh oysters, followed by spaghetti with radicchio and aged asiago. The oysters were great, and the pasta cooked perfectly. Sweet red onions balanced out perfectly the bitter radicchio. My only complaint was that it was dressed with way too much oil. Still, Zuni is definitely a place I'll go back to.
author: Travis S.

description: great   chicken  very tender and juicy lots of citrus flavor in the chicken  great with the bread salad  u have to wait 1 hour for the chicken but its worth it the chicken is  flavorful   they used good chicken meat
author: sushiatown s.

description: It's no coincidence that the 'elite' yelp reviewers give zuni significantly more stars than regular yelpers. A place like zuni can opt to pay for glowing reviews while skimping on real service and excellence in quality because of the prices they charge for mediocre food. I've been several times and all experiences there were lackluster to dismal. Had reservations, but was made to wait 45 min for a table. Wait staff couldn't make recommendations for pairing wine with our meal, and their recommendations for entrees were always the chicken... how unimaginative and basic.
author: gary a.

description: I would give five stars for the food and service (chicken and bread salad are unbelievable) but we had a terrible experience with a rude hostess on Sunday evening.  I had called for a reservation the week before and couldn't get one but the person I spoke with told me if we arrived before 5pm, there was a good chance we could get a table relatively quickly.  Unfortunately, my father and his partner arrived first at a quarter to five believing we had a reservation, and when the hostess could not find our reservation, she was extremely rude to them and told them it would be an hour to an hour and a half wait.  My father's partner is perhaps the kindest, gentlest, sweetest, most accommodating male soul on the planet, so when he said the hostess was very rude, my hair stood on end and I marched up to the podium ready for a big fight.  Nobody puts Marty in the corner - not on my watch.  So here's the crazy thing - I calmly told the hostess in question that I'd called in the week before and had been told to show up by five pm (it was then 5:08pm) and she is sweet as pie, doesn't make a big deal over our entire party not being there (my guy was parking), and whisks us back to a table.  There were plenty of empty tables and there continued to be some empty tables for the several hours that we were there.  So I'm sorry to give a three star rating, because the food and service were fantastic, but this hostess was horrible on what was meant to be an anniversary celebration.  Be warned, know their policies and stick to your guns.  Zuni is better than that.
author: Ella C.

description: We had friends in from out of town - so we wanted to find a great dining experience in San Francisco.  After numerous recommendations and reading the reviews on Yelp - Zuni seemed like a great choice.   Our reservations were for 8:15 pm on Saturday.  We arrived about 30 mins early to grab drinks at the bar.  The bar and drinks certainly got the evening off to a terrific start.   The hostess took as to our table promptly at 8:15.  The evening was off to an excellent start.  She led us to a table on the second floor - the view faced the alley.  Not a big deal initially.  As the dining room filled, the dining room got hotter and hotter.  It became really uncomfortable.  The only answer was to open the windows.  The stink for the alley slowly crept into the dining room, not to mention the couples sitting next to windows got cold.  So those not near a window were SOL.  The oysters were fabulous .. we placed several orders!  From here on . the experience was just so so.  We were excited to move to our main course.  The duck was OK, the halibut OK, and the to tell you the truth.. I can't even remember what I had ( not memorable).   So, when they came to clear our table the guy who cleared our table tipped our $90 bottle of wine over .. He didn't even say sorry.  When the server came back - he didn't even acknowledge that more that a glass of wine had spilled from the bottle.  Everyone was denial, and we were in shock.  Zuni did not offer to comp us on another glass of wine, or dessert, or anything.  How crazy is that?  I mean when you're spending $350 on dinner -  they can't comp'd us a dessert to fix the spilled wine?  Crazy.  Just not a classy place.  The service was ok, the food ok, and the 2nd floor dining experience - crappy.   It was not memorable, and I won't go back.  Even though the bar was nice ... not sure I'd even return for a drink.  Oh, I forgot, they also tried to charge us for the drinks we had already paid for at the bar.  Just a poor, sloppy experience.
author: Robin A.

description: woo hoo zuni. if you dont like it screw yourself. (I was paid off to give it 5 stars.)
author: christopher a.

description: Zuni can do no wrong as far as i am concerned. I go there for their gnocci appetizer and their famous caesar salad and their fries. And I love the atmosphere. I can't remember having a negative experience at Zuni. It is the restaurant I always recommend. And they've been at it since -- I think -- 1979 or something? And there is still a wait list each night for dinner. That's a tremendous track record for a restaurant!
author: Jackie O.

description: I called to make a reservation for 3 and was told they could not do that. The receptionist then asked if we could increase our party to 4, then we could make a reservation.  In all the years I have been dining, I have never had a restaurant ask us to increase the size of our party - very bizarre and highly disrespectful to us as customers. This leaves a bad taste in our mouths and we don't want to patronize a restaurant that is so arrogant as to try and dictate how many should be in our party. Thumbs way down!
author: Calvin A.

description: Well tonight I really have to say that I was extremely upset with our dinner, have been a fateful client from Zuni's Cafe for many years, the plan was to have a wonderful time there because we were celebrating my partner's great promotion at his work, got there at 6:30 pm and makes us wait an hour, I normally have reservations but tonight just forgotten to make one thought Wed? surprise!, the service as always awesome!, we know the menu very well, ordered their already signature dish the chicken for two couldn't wait to taste it, but tonight it was just not as normally is (very good) actually very disappointed, told our cool waiter then he send the manager to our table explained the situation, he was very professional and gave us what I really call customer service, didn't charge us for the dish even though I clearly told him that I had no problem if I have to pay for it, in situations like this is when one can see the difference in Rest, customer service, so! even though my dinner wasn't what I was expecting :( and too bad because is suppose to be a celebration, just wanted to shared it with everyone that they somehow care :)
author: Gino D.

description: I haven't been to Zuni Cafe in years.    I made plans to meet 4 friends for dinner there and made reservations for 6:45PM.  Two days before the dinner another friend asked to join us.  I called Zuni Cafe to increase the reservations from 4 to 5 and was told by the person handling reservations  "I can not do that...the next available table for 5 is at 9:15PM".   Her tone was RUDE...she should not work in the service industry.  She offered no solution and really didn't care.  We dined at Luna Park where the food and service was excellent.
author: Sandra A.

description: Just had dinner her a few weeks ago and had a great time. The meal was excellent and I love their shoestring fries
author: Sammy M.

description: with all the yelp ravings of the $48 roast chicken for two, my brother and I were quite curious... I must say I was quite underwhelmed.  it may be a bit snotty to say, but I feel I could have (and already have) produced a juicier and more flavorful roast chicken from my oven.  2 stars for the disappointing chicken, 4 stars for the other dishes (lamb tongue with artichoke hearts and bean salad; rabbit with watercress; pork with varied veggies) and the decor, giving an average of 3 stars.
author: Tammy L.

description: i wanted to like zuni, i really did!  but everything about our meal was not good from our wine, to our entrees, to our anticlimactic cheese plate and dessert.  the service was pretentious which i never understand.  does the head waiter tell their minions to act like punks?  it would take a lot for me to go back here again.
author: Swarup B.

description: Can be the best expensive burger in Bay Area, but you can't count on it.   Sometimes, it's incredibly tasty (5 star-worthy), other times a soggy mess.  The Caesar salad is chock full of tangy anchovies, so you definitely have to love that.  I had a lovely fish entree the other day in a lemon artichoke sauce with a few fava beans that didn't up the carb count by much.  The desserts are just ok and dinky.  Service can be attentive and friendly.  Sadie always gets some love and water.  We love the nattily dressed 'enforcer'  that protects outdoor diners from the more colorfully aggro peeps on the street - menacingly comforting.  On a sunny weekend, it can be enjoyable even with the neg aspects of Market Street scenery, fumes, and racket.  We've only had our experience completely ruined once or twice by couples whose conversational volume got louder as they got drunker and more oblivious.  We've mastered tracking such escalation  while prepping escape - eat faster and flag the wait staff to bring the check asap.
author: Esther R.

description:
Rating is off of my experience and not the food, since we didn't even get to the food!  Here goes my story:

- Walked in early without a reservation, fully knowing we would have to wait.  We were told about 1 1/2- 1 3/4 hours.  No problem!  We put our names on the list and headed elsewhere for a few drinks.
- 45 min in, we phoned Zuni just to let them know we were getting drinks and would be back shortly.  They said no problem, took our number and said if the table came up while we were gone, they would hold it.  How nice!
- Just before 1 1/2 hours hit, we popped back in.  The host said it would only be "a few minutes" before he would be ready to seat us, which was perfect.  About 5 minutes later, another gentleman came up to us and proceeded to lecture us that he was looking for us earlier because a table came up, and next time to leave our number.  He said that about 4 times to us to leave our number next time, while ignoring our protests back that we HAD actually called and left our number.  Oh well, we brushed it off.
- We sauntered up to the bar and ordered a $5 beer and a $11.75 cocktail.  The bartender then charged me $24.75 for the drinks; I checked the menu three times to make sure I did my math right, then asked her how it came to that amount.  She checked the register, came back and said she calculated wrong as it was supposed to be $21.75.  Unless they charge $5 for tap water, I'm still puzzled by how my two drinks cost $21.75.
- 30 minutes AFTER the host said it would be "a few minutes", we still weren't seated.  

We ended up just finally walking out after having such a frustrating experience.  Just didn't feel like giving up my hard earned cash after all the mis-steps they had made up to that point.
author: Jennifer C.

description: A reputation as incredible as Zuni must be a hard act to live up to, I thought before I went here. I have had the pleasure of eating at Zuni twice, and it was nothing less than sensational. The Caesar's Salad is the real McCoy, absolute divine combination of tangy and rich. Ordered ricotta gnocchi, and it was just absolutely light and smooth. I don't know what the fuss is really all about with the shoestring potatoes, but the ROASTED HALF CHICKEN is something at least one person at your table has to order, and share. It's 100% without a doubt the most tantilizing chicken. I didn't even order it, but it's a huge portion so I got to taste. The pine-nut and brioche stuffing kinda takes it over the top, really. The next morning, I had to indulge on cold, roasted chicken for breakfast. I had no choice, it found its way into my dreams that night. Yup, it's really that good and I am not joking. Would have gotten 5 stars if the menu were slightly more varied, with a few more fish options and maybe one or two vegetarian options added. They will happily prepare menu selections for vegetarian diners, not a problem. The enticing thing about returning is knowing the menu is always changing. As long as the chicken stays the same...
author: Rebecca A.

description: I could go into a blow-by-blow of the delicious meal my friends and I enjoyed -- super-fresh oysters, a stellar beet-and-orange salad, ROAST CHICKEN, polenta, a citrus meringue dessert -- but then this review would be miles long. Suffice it to say, this meal was the highlight of meals I enjoyed while in SF, and might just be on one of my all-time fave lists. Service was stellar, food was delicious, and the wine list was great -- my friend who can order a perfect bottle in an instant took forever to choose...and both wines were A+.
author: Amanda M.

description: There are some good things to be said about Zuni cafe, but then again, if you have to start a review like this, maybe it's best to steer clear. Kudos to the beautiful interior space--with airy ceilings and second-floor seating overlooking the bar and kitchen below, and all manner of nooks and crannies into which the tables are tucked--and kudos as well to its beautiful inhabitants, all decked out and knocking back cocktails.  Amusement aplenty for the eye.  But the fun pretty much gives up at this point and goes home.  The interior, while charming is ways detailed in the previous paragraph, amplifies sound in such a way that as the evening wore on and the noise grew louder, I had to holler at my date when international sign language failed to get the point across--should you find yourself committed to going there, I suggest brushing up on your semamphore techniques. The service was spotty, the waiters ignoring us for extended bouts, with our glasses and bellies sitting empty as we waited for Godot, or our server, whichever would deign to put in an appearance first. The food was rather overpriced for the simple fare that it was. A roasted chicken for two perched atop what were basically croutons on steroids and garnished with bits of shrubbery, priced at $45, required that you wait an agonizing 45 minutes for its arrival. Had this been the greatest thing since the aerosol deodorant, I might have cut the restaurant some slack, but it was really only slightly more memorable than Boston Chicken take-out. Still, for all the misery that an evening at Zuni can cause on an emotional, financial and physical level, brunch seems a stronger suit here, with an excellent setup of oysters and bloody marys that can make virtually any hangover seem like a distant memory.  Skip dinner, unless you plan to make it entirely liquid and head over for a pleasant--if pricey--brunch.
author: Kosuke I.

description: I honestly haven't tried anything besides their chicken but I think it definitely lives up to all the hype.  It's so juicy and the bread salad is absolutely fabulous.  The only downside is that you have to wait for a hour for the chicken but I think it's SO worth the wait!
author: Monique C.

description: We wouldn't say it was a WOW experience but it was a really good one. The food was very tasty and well executed. Most of all we liked their desserts. The service was nice and attentive. The ambience is simple and nice, but can get quite noisy. All together it was a wonderful experience and we would like to repeat it.
author: Tatyana M.

description: This place is wonderful.  The roast chicken with salad was unforgettable. Casual yet elegant kinda place. I will be back.
author: Heather B.

description: I am truly  not sure why people continue to frequent this place, given all the actually good/great restaurants in S.F.  Service is abysmal, and the food is not much better.    I've been forced to dine there a few times, each time hoping for a better experience, but no....still poor service and mediocre food.  Please do yourself a favor and try any other restaurant, you'll be glad you did.
author: alycia s.

description: i almost gave them 5 stars because the food was excellent but have to take away 1 star because we were seated in a little nook upstairs that was a little too noisy and unintimate and we ended up practically ignored after our entree was served and i think we actually offended our server when we chose not to order dessert !  otherwise, the calamari salad was amazing, the risotto with pancetta, butternut squash and greens was creamy and delicious and the roasted chicken with warm bread salad was fantastic - we took most of it home.
author: Cyn B.

description:
I've never walked out of a restaurant before, but there's a first time for everything.  I had dinner at Zuni Cafe last Sunday, September 2.

We ordered the signature dish, their famous roast chicken for two, which takes one hour to cook.  We nibbled on oysters and gnocchi while we waited patiently for the chicken.

When the chicken finally arrived, I took a breast piece, and my date took a thigh piece.  After a couple bites, he said, "Does this chicken look raw?"  Well, it was dark in the restaurant, and I guess I wasn't really paying attention, but when I looked closely at his piece, it was pink and translucent.  So then I cut through my piece, and it was raw as well!  I called the waiter over to look, and he said, "It appears kind of pink because we use such young, fresh chickens here."  I didn't believe his explanation, so I asked him to have the chef take a look.  Moments later, the waiter came back and told us that the chef agreed the chicken was indeed "undercooked."  I asked the waiter to send the manager over.  I then expressed to the manager my disappointment in waiting an hour for the chicken in addition to the salmonella dangers of raw poultry.  He offered to put the chicken back in the oven, but I declined.  Since the chicken was already carved into separate pieces, recooking it would have cause the chicken to dry out.  The manager then offered to bring me another chicken immediately, which I can only assume was meant for another table.  A couple minutes later, a brand new chicken arrived, and my date and I dove in.  Again, he took a thigh piece, and I took a breast piece.  As I was about to peel the skin back, I  noticed a 5-inch long, black, curly hair baked into the skin!  I called the waiter back over who then brought the manager again.  The manager offered a third chicken, which you couldn't pay me enough to eat.  We told him that we just wanted to leave, and he said he would take care of the bill.  My date and I left a cash tip for the oysters and gnocchi that we had for appetizers and walked out.

Disgusting.  Zuni Cafe is a safety and sanitation hazard.
author: Ann T.

description: i can't afford to love zuni, but i do.  brilliant burgers, lovely desserts, great service.  once i took myself out to dinner there.  indulgent.  initially the staff made me feel somewhat freakish for dining alone ("only you?") but then found me a great table in a corner upstairs and my waitress was pretty genuinely friendly.  and i had some sort of delicate bird on a bed of greens.  and salad and coffee.  $40 well-spent.  and once i went with a friend and there was a big black hair in our beautiful sorbet dessert.  they had it replaced free of charge and brought out to us by a bald waiter.  charming comeback.  i really want to get the chicken for two sometime.  anyone interested in taking me out??
author: amira p.

description: We finally went for the caesar salad and roast chicken.  I'm not a big fan of caesar salad in general. It was good but I am no expert.  However, the roast chicken was incredible.  Perfectly cooked.  Tasty with the bread salad.  Well worth the hour wait.  Four stars!
author: Swissmister M.

description: My friend and I went here because the roast chicken was on 7x7.com as one of those things you should try before you die. I disagree, I didn't think it was THAT good... it was aiite. We ordered the Kumamoto oysters, Shoestring Potatoes, the Roast Chicken (takes an hour), and Piccola meringata. The kumamoto oysters were yummy, pretty expensive though. When I walked into the restaurant almost every table had the shoestring potatoes, that's the reason why we ordered it! It looked good, and it was! Good thing to order while we waited 1 hr for the chicken to be ready. Didn't really like the chicken and it was $48... -___-'. The Piccola meringata dessert was very.. unique never had anything like that before, and it was quite small. Overall I think the chicken is hella expensive (only cause it wasn't that good to be $48) but the service was excellent!  Probably would come back again, but not order the chicken .. but then again there wasn't anything else on the menu that looked good :T
author: Kimi D.

description: Tried the "chicken for two" recently, again. Most people are probably put off by the 45~60 minute wait for the bird. Zuni has served that "chicken for two" for years and it still rocks. Oyster and wine selection are always top shelf.
author: Jeff B.

description: great service , chicken is worth the wait but a little over priced  , ceasar salad is wow  overall one of the best places in the city ~~
author: NAEL K.

description:
Emeril Lagasse says it's impossible to have a bad meal in this city. Zuni proves him wrong. I just finished a late "brunch" there, and I was sad to have to pay money for the lousy food and bizarre service. This was a bad choice for brunch as there wasn't much of a brunch menu, so my friend and I settled on an egg dish (him) and a trendy burger with goronzola (me). The eggs were basically 2 fried eggs and a gourmet sausage like the kind I buy weekly at Costco. The burger was a wet piece of  meat on a mushy ciabatta roll. Total damage = $78. Are you sick yet? Well I am. I've been bucking the porcelain bronco all afternoon. 
Also, I've spent tons of time in Europe. Snooty staff does not give a place a continental air, it makes a place LAME. Our waiter was so precious about handling our plates, fidgeting with our silverware, constantly interrupting to pour water when it wasn't needed (you don't need to top up my full glass for an 8th time Pedro). It was beyond attentive, it was intrusive. When you're attentive you are smiling and helpful, this guy had his cheeks sucked in and acted like he had a baguette up his ass (an organic, artisanal baguette I'm sure). He was acting like a cafe waiter from central casting. Maybe he was just another cracked out queen. Who knows.
Suffice to say, save yourself the time and money and dine elsewhere. I'm in it for the food, not the 'tude.
author: Brad D.

description: What is left to say?  The roasted chicken and the burger are the go to staples, although I am not a huge fan of the focaccia bun or the cheese choices.  there are many better burgers in town, but Zuni is a great if unremarkable place for a date or night out with the family.
author: Will C.

description:
three recommendations, & you won't go wrong with zuni:

1) cesar salad
2) zuni chicken
3) the gateau 

and if you're eating there for brunch, bloody mary.
author: melanie g.

description: Wonderful San Francisco restaurant.  Delicious, hearty, California cuisine with decent service (particularly challenging in SF) and a great wine list.
author: Bitzz B.

description: This place is very nice.  The bar is great with enormous windows so you can see all of the city elements as you enjoy a nice glass of wine while you wait for your table.  The dining area downstairs is the place to be in my mind as upstairs is a bit like a rabbit warren.   Big open space with a view of the kitchen.  Excellent date place.  The rotisserie chicken is definitely worth the wait.
author: Jon B.

description: This was my first time having brunch at Zuni Cafe.  On a nice sunny afternoon my friend and I decided to stop at Zuni and have a bite at one of their sidewalk cafe tables.  I started with a bowl of spinach soup.  This wasn't one of those vegetable soups that was drowned with cream and butter and barely a trace of the actual vegetable, no!  This was a robust spinach flavor with a mild sweet buttery and nutty after taste.  I could have had a second bowl.  However the star for this meal was my crostini with poached eggs, pancetta, tomatoes and wild mushrooms.  The combination may not sound like anything special but their use of the freshest ingredients made this dish plate-lickable.  The crostini had just the perfect crunch, the poached eggs, oozed over the mixture when punctured and the tomatoes were a sunny perfection.  I would rate this brunch dish THE BEST brunch item I've ever had.  Don't forget to ask for Nathan as your server.  A perfect compliment to a perfect brunch!
author: Ralph C.

description: Zuni is absolutely  my favorite place in the City for brunch. We've tried other places and every time we wonder why.  It's the only place really.  It's  also the only place to order oysters in San Francisco because they are freshly shucked and served chilled with the perfect mignonette. We usually start with a dozen oysters, a round of bloody marys and then the table orders family style and  shares the caesar, an order of shoe string potatoes,  a scone, and the french toast . Some order the burgers; others the scrambled eggs with sausage. It's all good, organic, and well presented. It's not for every palate particularly where large portions are what justify a good meal. It's not the Cheesecake Factory or Costco. It's about quality ingredients that come fresh from the market. It's a great place to sample different plates, relax and enjoy each other's company. The artwork , like the menu,  always evolves. It' s why Zuni has been in business over 20 years. The service is unobtrusive and unhurried which allows for conversation and a lovely brunch. Of course, I also love Zuni for dinner but brunch is definitely my favorite. We have been going to Zuni for over 10 years and will continue to do so. Thanks for the consistency and the table by the window.
author: Gari C.

description: i have wanted to go to zuni for YEARS.  i always thought it looked so cool from market street.  so modern and airy and important with its zinc counters and exclusive patrons.  well, it's all that, but i found the menu frustratingly limited and the portions surprisingly small.  maybe i just don't groove on comfort food enought to love this place.  the oysters were excellent.  the desserts as well.  but the entrees left me underwhelmed.
author: nicole l.

description: I loved the oyster varieties here. It was always fresh. I always love to come back again. The chicken is a must try item. I love the chocolate cake as well. It was rich, but not filling.
author: Tim P.

description: this is where i pretend to be something im not. wealthy. but i meet my financial advisor here once a year on her visit from nyc and i order the same thing. year after year. and it always includes the french fries. id like to think im a french fry aficianado by now. and these really stack up! ha! i said stack up. cause you see they do "stack them up". the fries. i slay me.
author: coffeecake j.

description: This place has always been great.  High quality, reasonable prices and a laid-back atmosphere.  Great flourless chocolate torte and four cheese gnocchi.  The oyster bar is a nice option too.  This was our other "go to" restaurant in the City in addition to Sushi Zone, but it's merely a coincidence they are a block away from each other.  (It's been over a year since we last ate here b/c we're now living in the 'burbs, but I think this review still applies.)
author: Eddie S.

description: really liked this place. the setup is modern without being overly pretentious. food was quite good. everything extremely fresh.
author: Marcelo C.

description: I understand that this place is a SF institution, but I am of the feeling that this place is overpriced for what it offers-- between 30 and 40 dollars an entree. There are lots of other places that are just as delicious and less costly with similar cuisine.
author: katie m.

description: One of my favorite restaurant in SF. I love having lunch on a sunny day there because of the big windows. The food is good. The roast chicken, the salad, the fresh oyster, etc,,,. The cocktails are great as well. The service is good too. Also, it has a causal and relax atmosphere inside which I love. It's a little bit pricey but I think it's worth it given the quality of the food and the nice but simple ambiance.
author: Nick S.

description: Went here with a couple of gals last weekend for lunch. Have been curious about all the Zuni fuss. First off, it was sorta cloudy but the sun was starting to bust through and upon entering the restaurant I felt swathed in fabulousness by the beautiful yet casual SF folk sipping champagne at the bar and partaking in oysters set on pedestals on the tables (of course I look at what people are eating-STARE even). Anyway the ceiling high windows are stunning, and the worn, painted wood floors on the second floor where we sat are comfortably elegant. I had a balsamic bloody mary that was delicious, with little bits of  minced onion. I liked the fact that it was minced as opposed to in huge hunks-do you really want that many veggies mucking up your vodka? Ditto on the straws, I couldn't use mine after about four sips. I had a burger and shared the fries. The burger was tender and very flavorful with gorgonzola for $1.75 extra, the foccacia nice and one certainly doesn't need condiments-but people, is it worth $13.50? I feel it isn't, though I know about the wonderful ingredients, aforementioned fabulous atmosphere, etc. The Bloody mary was $9.25, perhaps a touch high as well. The service was wonderful, mostly because our server was a total lovebug. So I don't know where exactly I'mgoing with this review but to say yes, Zuni is a lovely, lovely place and maybe I should be honored to have a $13.50 + burger to grace it's luminous environs.
author: Isabella R.

description: Great little cafe, good service, good food! The gnocchi was unlike any gnocchi I've ever had, it was more like a steamed dumpling in melted butter. Not great for my diet, but so good for my tastebuds! I can't say I was crazy about the dish I ordered, I had the Albacore, it was cooked perfectly, but it was a little too fatty for my taste. The veggies that accompanied the Tuna were very good. My friends ordered the steak, and said it was fantastic.
author: Susan F.

description: Tacky. I'm so disappointed in Zuni - a restaurant I used to enjoy. I took my boyfriend there on his birthday because he was dying to go. Right when we sat down my bf went to the restroom, and I told our server it was his birthday and asked if they do anything special for birthdays. She said, in a less than friendly or helpful tone, "Well, if you order a dessert we'll put a candle in it." Alright. Fine. Some restaurants do a little something special, some don't. No big deal. Well, after the meal, we politely refused when offered dessert as my bf never orders dessert. A minute later, our server came back with a piece of cake with a candle in it and said "You were supposed to order a dessert! We heard it's your birthday." How nice! Or so I thought. When the bill came, they had charged me for the cake. Really? Zuni? Really? I thought you had more class than that.
author: Jessica C.

description: one of our fav places in sf. whole chicken is the thing here to get which always comes out delicious. lightly tossed with bread salad and some berries really highlights the simplicity of it all. we actually like  waiting a hr for that darn chicken bc it  gives us time to talk and unwind. there is never a rush to leave once the entree arrives. as a new yorker i find it refreshing to have a place like this to just linger with some win and have good simple food.
author: alice b.

description: First went to Zuni over 25 years ago and I can imagine it still being here, virtually unchanged, 25 years from now.   I popped in for a hamburger before a movie and was pleasantly surprised.   It was very tasty.  They must add some secret ingredient.   Loved the rosemary foccacia, the condiments, and the shoestring fries that I couldn't stop eating although it was very time-consuming.
author: David T.

description:
oh zuni, how i  love thee.
i've been going since i was a wee little girl. my fancy pants aunt would take us for ceaser salads and shirley temples before a matinee of sfb's nutcracker. and now, 20 years later i'm still hooked on the ceaser, however that shirley has turned to a mary. a balasamic bloody mary that is.
everything from the great design and decor of the place, whether you snatch a walk in seat if you roll in without a reservation, or get a romantica corner spot in the loft upstairs, zuni has it's steez down. the waiters know their food, and are pros. i've yet to come here and be disappointed with someone.
so once you've gotten yourself a seat and drink, and you're sitting in awe of the sights and smells around you, order yourself a dozen oysters. suck 'em down with a dirty grey goose (warning: martini's on the small side, head up market into martuni's to get your fill of a goblet of goodness if you want yer $s worth). where was i...oysters. right.
ok, so if you're in for lunch, without a doubt i get a ceaser to share, try the burger with some cheezy roquefort goodness smothered on top and a side of shoestring potatoes. it's a lunch you'll never forget and will have you coming back for more no doubt.
so if you roll in after 5, they'll be setting up for dinner where you'll want to switch out the burger for the roast chicken for two. you'll feel like you haven't tasted chicken before. there's nothing like it. and it's always served with a side of something great depending on the season.
desserts are always spot on.
everything i've had i've loved, their menu reminds me chez panisse, i think a chef came from there. and if you're a foodie freak, ask for a tour around the kitchen and they'll gladly show you through, they've got nothing to hide.
in the end you won't want to leave, zuni will delight all.

**if you're still up for a drink afterward, Hotel Biron down the alley is a cool wine bar full of dark corners to get yer drink on. or for a more up beat  time the aforementioned martuni's will give you your fill (and then some) of your drink of choice, and will send you away whistling (or belting out) the tunes that serenade you while you drink.**
author: Olivia R.

description: sigh.. me loves me some zuni. one of those places where you can see all of sf come together to rock out with food. faves: oysters, oysters, oysters! perfect burgers, the snarfle to you barfle french fries, bloody marys, roasted chicken with bread salad and don't forget to get a cheese plate for dessert. bummers: my sad little pocket book that does not let me eat at zuni more often
author: CTP p.

description: Yippee!  We happened upon a last minute reservation via opentable.com and rushed over as quick as we could.  From the moment we arrived, I knew it was going to be a good night.  We were seated promptly in a room upstairs that faced Rose Street - not the best view, but where we sat was like a private little nook so we were very happy.  Our server was awesome.  Very attentive and personable.  We ordered the caesar salad, clams in a tasty tomato-based sauce w/ hazelnuts and the famous roasted chicken for two.  We loved it all.  This is my favorite caesar salad...I like that the anchovies are chopped up into little bitty pieces and the dressing is just tangy enough.  Croutons were buttery and had the perfect crunchiness.  The sauce that the clams came in was delicious.  I had forgotten how much I liked clams.  The roast chicken was absolutely tasty....so moist and flavorful and the bread salad that comes with it was the perfect accompaniment.  I couldn't finish it all and was too full for dessert.  We did have a look at the dessert menu and there were a few things that caught my eye.  Next time...
author: Lisa C.

description: Double-check your credit-card bill when you get home.   Our waiter appears to have helped himself to some extra tip.  I was quite surprised to see this sort of thing going on in a restaurant as nice as Zuni.
author: yao y.

description:
i think it is just too bad, when quality of food and quality of service/dining experience just doesn't come together. i have been a fan of zuni cafe for quite some time. i have been cooking out of their cookbook since it came out and when i visited sf, it was on my MUST visit list. my friend and i went to have brunch there last sunday and we got the worst service from our waiter. he was incredibly rude and stuck up. when we asked him for recommendations, he seemed annoyed and when i told him that my friend was vegetarian, he was so put off, rolled his eyes and went on schooling us that zuni cafe was a "traditional" restaurant. we ordered our food and he went on with the disgusted look on his face, shaming us by saying that what we ordered was an incredibly small portion and waiting for us to order more. 
well dear zuni cafe, the food was great, however i am in the food business and i promise you, that unfortunately the service left a bitter taste in my mouth- and "word of mouth" is a bitch.
author: jasmin b.

description: everyone should know about the chicken for two. although, I you know you're going to get it, I reccommend you order it as soon as you sit down, before drinks and appetizers, as it takes 50minutes to prepare.
author: angela g.

description: shoestring fries.. and the chicken... don't get me wrong.. i love everything else.. but when i go to Zuni all i ever get is THE roast chicken.. it IS THE perfect chicken..hands down perfection
author: Timothy W.

description: 5 stars for Roast Chicken for two and Ceasar Salad. Both filled with garlic and both amazing!! If you haven't tried it, you are MISSING out! Note: the service isn't the best -
author: Michelle D.

description: you can't go wrong. rustic feel. great location. i love sitting at the bar and looking out those windows.  the bartenders make excellent cocktails. the food is fab. the service is meticulous.  my opinion you don't really want to get stuck with a table upstairs in the back but it is one of the more popular spots in SF.
author: Angela N.

description: i just went for lunch and i hadn't been in here in a couple years.  the burger and fries did not disappoint.  it reminds me that i have to go back and try the roast chicken one of these days...
author: michelle k.

description: Vary limited menu. Over-priced and pretentious. Poor quality oysters.
author: Foster A.

description: not much needs to be said about this fine old place..well not old in the true san francisco way but old enough! my one word here is lunch time..fruit de mar...great price fresh seafood as good as in the south of france in the summer...sigh...
author: Ricote F.

description: The best dish in the house is definitely the chicken, but there is a 45 minute to an hour wait for the dish because they cook it as you order. The juicy, flavorful chicken comes served on a hearty bread salad which more than feeds two. If you are hungry, the fresh oysters make a nice appetizer. The selection of oysters is amazing! The shoe string potato fries also make a yummy starter. I recommend visiting Zuni's at least once for a solid meal, but this is definately not a place that would wow you for originality... if you want the wow factor I would try Jardaniare down the street!
author: Mama L.

description: Really expected better. I remember eating here years ago and it was fantastic, but went for lunch the other day. Oily, greasy salad, then a 45 minute wait for them to bring out our overcooked, greasy bass with tough, overcooked potatoes and charred radicchio. Can't remember the ridiculous name they used for the dessert, but it was basically an upside-down brownie with whipped cream. (Which was yummy, but also nearly impossible to screw up.) I don't mind paying money for a good meal, but this was certainly not worth it. Waitress was nice, I guess. Didn't see her too often, and couldn't hear her when she did bother to stop by. What's up with the whispering?
author: Erica B.

description: I've been going to Zuni on and off for the 20 years I have lived in San Francisco, and their quality and consistency are incredible. I now live right behind them, so am able to enjoy Judy's creations more often. The burger (lunch only), caesar, and chicken for two really are not to be missed. But there are many other wonderful finds on the menu also. For posters who wonder why the burger is not offered after 6pm, it is because they need all the space they can get for the chicken(s) for two, which is wildly popular. In any event, don't miss Zuni. Not getting the service complaints - every visit I have made (and I've been there at least 25 times) has been handled impeccably.
author: Justin T.

description: My experience at Zuni was great. The service was absolutely amazing. My friends and I weren't too familiar with some of the things on the menu, but our server answered all our questions without making us feel like idiots. The food was wonderful. Everything tasted just how it should, not too much or too little. Dessert was also fantastic. All and all a very great experience.
author: paige s.

description: Still mediocre after all these years. Undercooked my overpriced burger, then overcooked it after I requested that they sear the (very bloody) meat a little...nice atmosphere though, for sure.
author: Tonya M.

description: written by customer since 1970s. last visit Zuni was out of one of only four appetizers. recommended sub was fancy onion rings, greasy. Out of Loire sauvignon listed by the glass. waiter-recommended sub was too sweet for the fish. fish was overcooked. Long wait to pay after bill came. Finally went downstairs to pay where found waiter flirting with bartender. Overall mood was self-satisfied and not genuinely caring. adios to what used to be one of SF'd best bets
author: ansley c.

description: dining here was as good as i expected it to be.  it took us a month to get reservations for 4--so expectations were high.   the chicken was delicious, dessert was to die for, and our waitress was friendly and attentive.  this place is also much bigger than it looks from the outside--we were tucked away at a private corner table on the top floor...then down a hall, down some steps, and to the left.
author: Lxyz N.

description: I''ve long been a fan of Zuni.  Great food, tons of windows and light, and a really open and nice atmosphere.  Great for dinner, lunch or brunch.  My one regret is that used to serve the world's best bloody mary, but now the bloody mary is actually not that good.  Everything else is fantastic.
author: Adam C.

description: My bf and I love this restaurant.  We've been going here since 2000 and haven't had a bad meal yet.  Always crowded, best to get a reservation, but if you have eyes like a hawk, you might be able to snag a table out front!
author: rei r.

description: I love this restaurant. Between the daily selection of oysters and their famous burger, (Or roasted chicken, or melt-in-your-mouth Ahi Tuna)its hard to beat! Zuni serves until 11pm weekends... so after that movie (or long happy-hour) its one of my most favourite places to eat! Make sure you have the $ though, it ain't cheap!
author: Cassandra A.

description: Zuni, a San Francisco mainstay.  Best chicken (takes 45 minutes) one of the best burgers, best caesar salad, great pork chop, great pasta, great oysters.  My favorite place for a three hour lunch drinking wine and playing cards with friends.  Also great for brunch on Sundays.  If it's nice out you can bring your dog and sit outside!!!
author: eiming j.

description:
had the most memorable meal of 2008 last weekend after spending the afternoon at the slow food nation taste pavillion (so was already eating all day)

between 3 people, we started with 4 appetizer/1st courses, an entree each and thought we were done until the roast chicken for 2 was served to the table next to us. "should we do it" "i will if you will" so we order the chicken after eating our REGULAR meal and boy, was it worth it!!!!!! 

i NEVER EVER order chicken while dining out, because i am often disappointed by dry, poorly cooked, poorly seasoned chicken. this was most definitely not the case. the chicken tasted like chicken. it wasn't hiding behind a sauce, just straight up good quality chicken which was seasoned right and cooked to perfection. it was juicy, moist, the skin was crisp... everything you want in a roti chicken. served over a "salad" of red mustard greens, dried currants, pinenuts with a champagne vinaigrette it is the perfect balance of sweet, salty, spicy, bitter.. all of the senses are enhanced by this delicious dish. and to top it off, it is also served with barely toasted bread which is just dry enough to soak up all of the chicken juices, but moist enough to not be a crouton. it is the perfect vessel for sopping up all of the delicious chicken goodness. it is SO good... so simple and delicious.

all in all the entire meal was perfection from start to finish. the food is just simple, straight up food. it lets the fresh ingredients speak for themselves... no muss, no fuss. to me, that is the best way to experience food, especially at this time of year when produce is so delicious that you really don't need anything else. tomatoes with a little bit of seasoning, letting their natural goodness shine through. 

took home the zuni cookbook as well and can't wait to attempt my try on the roast chicken for 2!
author: Status K.

description: Excellent food, upbeat setting, great service.
author: Morton D. P.

description: Wow, what a disappointment.  I remember eating at Zuni in the day and it was great.  The space is unique and the service is generally good but the food is just not what is used to be.   I like the fact that they use local purveyers but the preparation was truly uninspiring.  Even the deserts lacked something.  I eat out a lot in SF from the the corner diner to the fru fru.  I wish I had better things to say for a place I used to love.
author: Adam W.

description: Only went here once, but was really underwhelmed. It was a while ago so I'm not even sure I can remember what I had, but I definitely remember thinking it wasn't worth the cost.
author: Avid E.

description: Excellent food in a stylish interior. I recommended this place to my friends and they also liked it.
author: Ola L.

description: Awesome! The oysters and the ceasar salad are to die for.  The ambience is quite cosmoplitan as well. Possibly my favorite restaurant in the city!
author: Marko C.

description: So I've been to Zuni a few times. The first two times I would have rated a 4/5 stars. This last time, not so much, I'd give it a 2/5.  Are you kidding me with the service? Really now, a nice restaurant should have some standards. We never got water refills, we didn't get small plates for our bread, the grape juice pour was pathetically small, it took forever to get our food and we never got the oysters we ordered (you get the idea). At least the server was nice when we saw her.   The food is good.  My one complaint is the portabello mushroom version of the burger really didn't have much in the way of portabello mushrooms on it.  Skimpy!!  I am a believer in dining for the sake of eating, but this wasn't worth the price.
author: Amy H.

description:
How shall I start this. I went on 08/24/08. Had drinks followed by dinner. The service was great. It does downhill from there.
1) The second floor seating was uncomfortably hot due to the brick oven downstairs. The window was open for ventilation but it was closed soon after we got there by the guy sitting next to the it. (Can't blame him for doing it. They should not have put a table there.)
2) Ordered the appetizer of anchovies. They and the cheese slices were very good, the celery and the nicoise olives were a bit pretentious. 
3) Ordered two different entrees. a) The Yellow Fin tuna was fantastic and the baby green beans were cooked to perfection. BUT as most "upscale" restaurants tend to think that olive oil is healthy, they use it - a lot of it. The dish on the whole felt "greasy" including the beans which was a shame.
4) The other dish was a flat out MISTAKE to order. Wanting something light, we chose the Spaghetti with rapini. The noodles were less than al dente bordering on RAW. You could taste the rapini IF you could get past the 1/4 cup of olive oil it was swimming in.
We also ordered their award winning french fries just to see what an award winning french fry was like. It was great. The problem was there was nothing on the menu that went with french fries. We missed being able to order their famous burgers by 35 minutes.

I must confess that when the waiter (again, great service) came by and asked how everything was, I said fine. I did not give him the chance to address my concerns because I knew I wasn't coming back. That was my fault. Maybe I should have said something but when a upscale restaurant can't boil noodles and has virtually everything soaking in olive oil, what is there really to say? Change your style of cooking? No, you simply go away.
author: Jay Y.

description: This would be the kind of operation I'd want to create if I owned a restaurant.   It's not cheap, yet it's a actually good value for the quality of ingredients and balance of the dishes.   Good service.   Generally first-rate.    Casual, but not super casual, so drunken hipster revelers will feel out of place.
author: Barry C.

description: We went to the famous Zuni Cafe for our anniversary, had heard they had a great creative bartender.  Instead we got  a snobby-grouchy bartender, and my scallop entree had sand in the scallops.  Hmmm.  The good news:  we got the table we wanted and the waiter was lovely.  The fact that Zuni decided to go ahead and let 6 extra-loud & argumentative patrons sit at a 4 person table next to us is what ruined the atmosphere.  I won't bother going back - there are too many other wonderful restaurants within a mile or 2.
author: Cindy R.

description: If you want to pay $20 dollars for a 3 oz piece of fishy tasteless grouper, go to Zunis. I was excited because it said it came with an artichoke. If by an artichoke they mean the left over shell of what they used for an artichoke heart then they should consider saying that on the menu. The fish had no flavor and i had to resort to putting some mustard that came with my boyfriends burger on top just to make it edible. The best part about our meal was the bread, which comes from Acme bread Co.
author: Lindsay E.

description: I took a friend to Zuni for her birthday a few weeks ago, Food was good service was excellent. We had a $150 tab with another 4% added on for employees health benefits,  No warning, it it just there, I paid it but won't go back for that reason. Prices are high there but why not just add another $1 to the entree prices so you won't know that the owner is too cheap to pay for his employees benefits and pass it on to the customer... I had halibut that was excellent. It was supposed to have fingerling potatoes with it. 3 slivers of a potato. We are talking about less than a bite. Potatoes are really cheap and yet you don't get any. Again our waitress was really good, but they won't see me again there.
author: Nel M.

description: Wow, it shows how strongly bad service can affect your whole experience. We were having happy hour drinks to celebrate a bday. The waitress was a complete bitch! And slow on getting the drinks to boot. I've eaten there before and the food was good, but I won't go back. I don't need to spend good money for crappy service.
author: Ian W.

description: What a cool venue - we read the reviews and had to see what the fuss was about. First impressions on arriving by taxi is that this is a cool, small, local restaurant - then they take us up through a labyrinth to the back top corner  of the restaurant where Reubin looks after us. We had read the reviews and instantly looked for the $20. burger - not there..hmmm..is this a new menu.. . Reuben gives us the daily menu - it is hard to distnguish the starters/appetizers from the main courses.. not a problem..as mix'n'match is encouraged.. we took the rabbit sausage, piccolo fritto &  the "infamous" caesar salad (it is how it should be with the correct flavoring of anchovies as previously over-exaggerated by a prior reviewer). All starters are great - good flavor and not over-powering - so far so good - full marks. For the main courses we try the duck breast (with asparagus, white beans & kumquat-olive relish), polenta (with parmesan) and the ricotta Gnocchi... as to wine Reuben was able to offer a choice of 2 wines - a cabernet or a pinot noir (wow ! he had an opinion)..Impressive.  The Gnocchi was bland both in flavor and in texture and needs to be worked on to pep up the flavors/texture.  The rabbit sausage was exquisite ( we ordered a second portion).  Overall service was good  and ambiance great. Definitely a recommended visit for foodlovers... not sure if regular visits would become a tad boring with the small menu however it seems they change the menu often, so the spark of interest is kept.. Great Restaurant!
author: Gary M.

description: Nice decor, good service, but food failed to impress. We had oysters, sardine salad, trenne, sand dabs and the roast chicken, all were ok tasty, but i really expected more.. The sand dabs (a fish dish) was probably the best among what we had, especially the boiled potatoes that came with it - buttery and melt-in-your-mouth.. Chicken was moist and tasty, but really not worth the $48 and 1 hour wait.. Oysters (Kumamoto and Pacific Coast) were fresh, but so small we could hardly taste it.. Trenne (like penne, but triangular) was the most disappointing, pasta was tough and tasted boring. Overall, we felt it really didn't live up to the hype.
author: Lydia C.

description: great food and ambiance. the chicken was a LOT for two people. should change the name to 'chicken for 4'.
author: Heaven K.

description: TERRIBLE!!!! Go only if you like terrible service, overpriced food and bad attitudes. We arrived at 5:15 pm on a wednesday night. The place was empty we still had too wait 15 minutes for a table.When we were seated we were given a late lunch menu????? 4 items too choose from. We asked for a dinner menu and were told dinner is not until 6 and the menu was not even printed yet??? It is 5:40 pm and no dinner menu? we ordered drinks 3 beers and 2 glasses of wine which took another 15 minutes to get. The waitress with a bad attitude  took our late lunch order before we got the drinks. We ordered 4 burgers and a pork chop for our meals, we also ordered 2 appitizers to share. BILL $180.00 for burgers and beer are u kidding me. I have no problem spending money on good food .But when you can't cook a burger med and send it out well done you should cook  @ jack in the box not a resturant. Maybe that's why this a cafe?  I will never go back to this toilet again. Why ask how you wan't a burger cooked when you can't cook? Maybe that is why they have a 4 item menu.If you go too zuni cafe bring some extra money so when you leave u can go eat somewhere else. Zuni should  buy some new chairs because the ones we were sitting on were falling apart and looked like they bought them at a bad garage sale. The white paper over linen tablecloth was a touch a class (haha). The rats running around outside won't even come inside. They know better. I am suprised this place has stayed in business, but there are a lot of people in S.F. Do yourself a favor and go somewhere else to eat any place would be better. I would give Zuni zero stars but i can't.
author: John L.

description: I went to Zuni last night with my wife who for an age wanted to go.  I hate to wait too long before getting a seat in any establishment so of course it didn't bode well for me when I was told a 40min wait which of course means it's gonna be an hour before we eat at best!  However,  I agreed for my wife's sake and was told we could wait whilst having a drink at the bar.  so many staff;  I counted 3 at the door and at least 4 bar staff not including the glass collectors and many waiters.  I'll never know.  No eye contact, a hello or nod to acknowledge us waiting and why the 15minute wait to get a drink when not that busy I'll never know .  hmmm not going well.  ok so now with a drink and waiting for a table and they were right about the 40 minute wait.  The restaurant decor is very nice and interesting as we wound through it to our table.  Nice spot and seating well spaced out.  The waiter was pleasant enough though when I asked about the  lamb mixed grill didn't seem too knowledgeable about the dish as he just repeated pretty much what it said in the menu.   After we chose he said it was a good choice which made me feel good and I started to really look forward to the meal......... until I heard him say the same to each new table that arrived no matter what they ordered!  ok so now the meal;  the starter Caesar salad was very nice, though a little too much olive oil. The main course was the lamb and again much to much olive oil, grisly meat on the lamb kebab and all just room temp not hot at all. The chop was great just wish it had been a little bigger and the other meats just not really up to much.  we also had the shoe string chips - don't!  greasy greasy and just not as good as they look.  Throughout the meal I had to keep wiping my mouth of oil.  horrible feeling. My wife had the gnocchi.  see her review.  Also oily and in fact not gnocchi but gnudi.  The atmosphere is nice though for $95 bucks all in (a glass of wine, starter salads, starter plate of gnudi and a main course (and not that well cooked)) I expected a higher standard. I would go else where for this price bracket.  saying that this was my 1st visit here and I don't like to blow them off after just one visit so I will probably try again just not sure when.
author: SIMON m.

description: One of my all-time faves in the city.  My wife and I have been coming for both special occasions and date nights for almost a decade.  We never leave disappointed. I've seen reviewers pan Zuni because it's expensive.  It is expensive.  But my goodness, the food is fantastic.  So many people talk about the chicken - why?  Because it's so damn good.  Because it feeds two easily, ordering the chicken is also a good way to get out without spending a ton.  If you want to spend though, the seafood plate appetizer is great - stocked with oysters, clams, prawns, and mussels - or just skip the other stuff and stick with their outstanding and shifting variety of oysters.  At times, they also have anchovies on the menu that are oh so tasty, and I once had a lamb dish off the appetizer menu that was outstanding.  The fish entrees can be hit or miss, and the burger is very good but too pricey.  So, fine, go to Burger Meister if you don't want to pay $15 for a burger.  That said, whatever you get at Zuni, the ambience is fun, the martinis are stiff, the wine list is strong, and going out to dinner feels like "going out."
author: Warren B.

description: been probably 30 times - always phenomenal.  slightly pricey but you get what you pay for.  love the oysters.  hanger steak is great when on the menu. of course the chicken for two, piccolo fritto.  can't go wrong here.
author: hary n.

description: eaten here twice, and both times the laid back san francisco vibe coupled with a well paced delicious meal played the best background for a night of celebration
author: John L.

description: zuni might possibly be my all time favorite restaurant in san francisco. that's a difficult assessment, as there are so many amazing restaurants here, but i gather my opinions about zuni in a more cumulative fashion. the architectural space is ideal, structurally beautiful, modern in a very comfortable way, not so hard-edged that you don't want to relax, and windowed in such a way that the openness of the restaurant allows for so much natural light that one doesn't feel guilting eating indoors on a sunny day. i usually spend my first few minutes there fantasizing about what a wonderful living space it would be. in addition, the dichotomy of upscale restaurant juxtaposed with the highest concentration of homeless shopping carts passing by is pretty amusing and so classically sf.  add the security guard patroling the corner and its a mini-series. though, it's nice to have those consistently good restaurants where you can throw a dart at the menu for your decision making process. i'm pretty sure it's impossible to order a bad item.  however, having come here for lunch so consistently lately, i'm realizing their lunch menu doesn't change as often as the dinner menu.  and we've now vowed to chill out on our brunches here and seek out dinners more readily, though advance reservations are much more crucial at dinner time.  the zuni burger is legendary and always on the menu so it is an ideal standby. but the best item i've had at zuni would have to be the rabbit sausage, and if you cannot bare to wait and wonder when it may come around again, the ambitious foody type should definitely buy the cookbook for its recipe. i don't cook, but i'm reeping more culinary benefits from its purchase than i've ever thought possible.
author: little gem z.

description: The other night I had dinner at Zuni for the first time in many years. I have to admit my past memories of the restaurant were much better than the experience I had the other night.  The food was reasonable good but I found the portions to be painfully small and quite expensive for what we got.  My wife and I split a ceaser salad and each had an entree with no dessert or alcohol.  The tab came up to around $80 with tax and tip.  My pork tenderloin was tasty but consisted of exactly 5  pieces roughly the size of a silver dollar accompanied by a small sausage and a bit of greens.  Tender and tasty but I was quite unsatisfied.  The famous chicken is still on the menu but takes an hour to prepare and seems strange that the restaurant's high point is chicken .  Finally our table was located in an area of the restaurant where there are padded benches with no backs so we could not sit back unless I wanted to rest against the back of the other guest sitting behind me.  OK for the first 10 minutes but uncomfortable by the end of dinner.  For the price I can think of a number of other restaurants I would rather dine at (Delphina, Myth, Foreign Cinema, etc)
author: Stuff D.

description: I really want to love Zuni Cafe.  It's ambiance is really nice, but that's about it.  I came to Zuni seeking their illustrious burger and sat down giddy with excitement.  The service was fine, but this was to be expected considering I was the only one in the restaurant (some holiday, i forget which one).  I payed five dollars for a root beer, five dollars!  I finally recieved my burger and fries and was not impressed.  The burger was fine, just fine and definitely not worth fifteen dollars.  The frites were good, but nothing special.  I was extremely dissapointed with Zuni, but wasn't ready to completely give up.  I have a copy of the Zuni cookbook and made the burger recipe the next day.  The homemade Zuni burger was much better and way cheaper so I'm giving Zuni two stars instead of three.  The reason to have professionals prepare your food is that they can do a much better job of it than the average home cook unfortunately Zuni dishonors restaurants everywhere by not living up to this basic standard.  Don't waste your money at Zuni.
author: Ryan E.
